Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 1: Works By Anne Hebert. Russell, D.W. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 117-145

Part 1 Works by Anne Hébert; Contributions to periodicals and books (poems, short stories, excerpts and serials, reprinted anthology contributions: A selection, plays, essays, children's stories and plays, and journalism) and audio-visual material; Audio-visual material  

Russell, D.W. (compiler)

Audio-Visual Material

Note: This listing does not include a number of poetry readings for which no archival holdings have been found. (See introductory note to Audio-Visual Material in Section A.)

B174     "La Fille maigre." Narr. Anne Hebert. Voix de 8 pontes du Canada. Prod. Gilles Henault and Jean-Guy Pilon. Folkways, FL 9905, 1958. Broadcast ("Poetry from French Canada: 'La Fille maigre'"). Anthology. cat Radio, 22 May 1959. See Tr ("La Fille maigre"), TK ("La Fille maigre/The Thin Girl"), Poemes ("La Fille maigre"), and B32. The 1959 broadcast includes critical comments by Maurice Beaulieu (C28) and Herbert Steinhouse (C29).

B175     "Il y a certainement quelqu'un." Narr. Anne Hebert. Voix de 8 pontes du Canada. Prod. Gilles Henault and Jean-Guy Pilon. Folkways, FL 9905, 1958. See Tr, TK ("Il y a certainement quelqu'un/ There Is Certainly Someone"), Poemes ("Il y a certainement quelqu'un"), and B47.

B176     "Les Petites Villes." Narr. Anne Hebert. Voix de 8 pontes du Canada. Prod. Gilles Henault and Jean-Guy Pilon. Folkways, FL 9905, 1958. Rerecorded trans. F.R. Scott ("The              Little Towns"). Anthology. CBC Radio, 9 Oct. 1959. Rerecorded trans. John Glassco. Quebec Now. CBC Radio, 13 March 1973. See Tr ("Les Petites Villes"), TK ("Les Petites Villes/The Little Towns"), Poemes ("Les Petites Villes"), PAH ("The Small Towns"), P[QRL] ("Small Towns"), and B21 ("Les Petites Villes"). The 1959 broadcast includes critical comments by Norman Levine (C31).

B177     "Le Tombeau des rois." Narr. Anne Hebert. Voix de 8 pontes du Canada. Prod. Gilles Henault and Jean-Guy Pilon. Folkways, FL 9905, 1958. See Tr, TK ("Le Tombeau des rois/The Tomb of the Kings"), Poemes ("Le Tombeau des rois"), and B35.

B178     "Vie de chateau." Narr. Anne Hebert. Voix de 8 pontes du Canada. Prod. Gilles Henault and Jean-Guy Pilon. Folkways, EL 9905, 1958. Rerecorded trans. F.R. Scott ("Manor Life"). Narr. Nonnie Griffin. The Feminine Touch. CBC Radio, 6 July 1966. Rerecorded ("Vie de chateau"). Narr. Nonnie Griffin. The Feminine Touch. CBC Radio, 6 July 1966. See Tr ("Vie de chateau"), TK ("Vie de chateau/Mansion Life"), PAH ("Life in the Castle"), P[QRL] ("Castle Life"), and B34 ("Vie de chateau"). The 1966 recording also includes a critical comment by Janet McQuillan (C53).

B179     La Merciere assassinee. Dir. Jean Faucher. Quatuor. CBC TV/Radio-Canada, 16 juil. 1958. Rebroadcast (revised). CBFT [CBC TV/RadioCanada], aout 1959. Rebroadcast. Prod. and dir. Paul Legendre. CBC Radio/Radio-Canada, 7 juin 1971. Part I of a four-part series. See Ts.Ma.Ip and B145.

B180     La Merciere assassinee. Dir. Jean Faucher. Quatuor. CBC TV/Radio Canada, 23 juil. 1958. Rebroadcast (revised). CBFT [CBC wv/RadioCanada], aout 1959. Rebroadcast. Prod. and dir. Paul Legendre. CBC Radio, 14 juin 1971. Part II of a four-part series. See Ts.Ma.Ip and B145.

B181     La Merciere assassinee. Dir. Jean Faucher. Quatuor. CBC TV/Radio Canada, 30 juil. 1958. Rebroadcast (revised). CBFT [CBC TV/RadioCanada], aout 1959. Rebroadcast. Prod. and dir. Paul Legendre. CBC Radio, 21 juin 1971. Part III of a four-part series. See Ts.Ma.Ip and B145.

B182     La Merciere assassinee. Dir. Jean Faucher. Quatuor. CBC TV/Radio Canada, 6 aout 1958. Rebroadcast (revised). cart [aBe Tv/RadioCanada], aout 1959. Rebroadcast. Prod. and dir. Paul Legendre. CBC Radio, 28 juin 1971. Part IV of a four-part series. See Ts.Ma.Ip and B145.

B183     "Poetry from French Canada: 'Eveil au seuil d'une fontaine'" (excerpt). Anthology. CBC Radio, 22 May 1959. See Tr ("Eveil au seuil d'une fontaine"), TK ("Eveil au seuil d'une fontaine/Awakening at the Edge of a Fountain"), and Bll ("Eveil au seuil d'une fontaine"). The broadcast includes a critical comment by Maurice Beaulieu (C28).

B184     "Our Hands in the Garden." Trans. Jean Beaupre. Anthology. CBC Radio, 9 Oct. 1959. Rerecorded trans. Gwladys V. Downes ("The Planting of Hands"). Anthology. CBC Radio, 23 May 1970. See TK ("Nos mains au jardin/Our Hands in the Garden"), PAH ("Our Hands in the Garden"), P[QRL], and B54 ("The Planting of Hands"). The 1959 broadcast includes a critical comment by Norman Levine (C31). The 1970 broadcast includes a critical comment by JeanLouis Morgan (C80).

B185     "Shannon." Nouveautes dramatiques. Dir. Ollivier Mercier-Gouin. CBC-FM/Radio-Canada, 12 fev. 1961. See B73.

B186     "As if for a Holiday." Trans. F.R. Scott. Narr. Nonnie Griffin. The Feminine Touch. CBC Radio, 6 July 1966. Rerecorded ("En guise de fete"). Narr. Nonnie Griffin. The Feminine Touch. CBC Radio, 6 July 1966. See Tr ("En guise de fete"), TK ("En guise de fete/By Way of Holiday"), Poemes ("En guise de fete"), PAH ("A Kind of Feast"), P[QRL] ("Mock Celebration"), and B31 ("En guise de fete"). The broadcast also includes a critical comment by Janet McQuillan (C53).

B187     "La Chambre fermee." Narr. Nonnie Griffin. The Feminine Touch. CBC Radio, 6 July 1966. Rerecorded trans. F.R. Scott ("The Closed Room"). Narr. Nonnie Griffin. The Feminine Touch. CBC Radio, 6 July 1966. See Tr ("La Chambre ferm6e"), TK("La Chambre fermee/The Closed Room"), Poemes ("La Chambre fermee"), PAH ("The Closed Room"), P[QRL], and B39. The broadcast also includes a critical comment by Janet McQuillan (C53).

B188     "The Two Hands." Trans. F.R. Scott. Narr. Nonnie Griffin. The Feminine Touch. CBC Radio, 6 July 1966. See B4 ("Les Deux Mains"). The broadcast also includes a critical comment by Janet McQuillan (C53).

B189     "Neige." Narr. Nonnie Griffin. The Femintne Touch. CBC Radio, 6 July 1966. Rerecorded trans. F.R. Scott ("Snow"). Narr. Nonnie Griffin. The Feminine Touch. CBC Radio, 6 July 1966. See Poemes ("Neige"), PAH ("Snow"), and B41 ("Neige"). The broadcast also includes a critical comment by Janet McQuillan (C53).

B190     Kamouraska. Dir. Robert Blondin. Lecture de chevet. CBC Radio/Radio-Canada, 20 sept.-1 oct. 1971. (10 episodes.) See Kam.

B191     Le Temps sauvage. Prod. and dir. Madelaine Gerome. Sur Toutes Les Scenes du monde. CBC-FM Radio/Radio-Canada, 7 jan. 1974. See Ts.Ma.Ip.

Memoir

A18      The Crow Journals. Introd. Douglas Barbour. Western Canadian Literary Documents. Vol. I. Edmonton: NeWest, 1980. 6, 81 pp.

Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 1: Works By Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 273-291

Part 1 Works by Robert Kroetsch; Books (novels, poetry, mixed genre collection, memoir, criticism, travel book, and books edited), broadside, editorial work, audio-visual material, and manuscripts; Mixed genre collection  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Mixed Genre Collection

A17      Kroetsch, Robert, James Bacque, and Pierre Gravel. Creation. Ed. and introd. Robert Kroetsch. Toronto: new, 1970. 213 pp. Includes the following prose: "Election Fever" (A2, expanded- "Saturday"), "Say Ah" (A4, revised, expanded -- Chs. i-iv), and "That Yellow Prairie Sky' (B81). Includes the following poems: "The Stone Hammer Poems: Fish Trap," "The Stone Hammer Poems: Spring Harvest" (B45), "The Stone Hammer Poems: Stone Hammer Poem" (A8). Includes the following criticism: "A Conversation with Margaret Laurence" and Introduction. Includes the following drama: "The Man in the Winter Catalogue."

Source: Part 1: Works By Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 273-291

Part 1 Works by Robert Kroetsch; Books (novels, poetry, mixed genre collection, memoir, criticism, travel book, and books edited), broadside, editorial work, audio-visual material, and manuscripts; Novels  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Robert Kroetsch

An Annotated Bibliography

[underbar]

Robert Lecker (sections C and D were prepared by Robert Lecker and Kathleen Maracle)

Part I

Works by Robert Kroetsch

[underbar]

A     Books (Novels, Poetry, Mixed Genre Collection, Memoir, Criticism, Travel Book, and Books Edited), Broadside, Editorial Work, Audio-Visual Material, and Manuscripts

Novels 

A1     But We Are Exiles. London: Macmillan, [1965]. 145 pp.
             New York: St. Martin's, [1965]. 145 pp.
             Toronto: Macmillan, [1965]. 145 pp.
             Laurentian Library, No.45. Toronto: Macmillan, 1977. 145 pp.



A2     The Words of my Roaring. London: Macmillan, 1966. 211 pp.
             New York: St. Martin's, [1966]. 211 pp.
             Toronto: Macmillan, [1966]. 211 pp.
             Markham, Ont.: PaperJacks, 1977. 211 pp.



A3     The Studhorse Man. London: Macdonald, [1969]. 168 pp.
             Toronto: Macmillan, [1969]. 168 pp.
             New York: Simon and Schuster, [1970]. 191 pp.



A4     Gone Indian. Toronto: new, 1973. 158 pp.
             Nanaimo, B.C.: Theytus, 1981. 158 pp.



A5     Badlands. TrendSetter. Toronto: new, 1975. 270 pp.
             Don Mills, Ont.: PaperJacks, 1976. 270 pp.
             New Press Canadian Classics. Toronto: General, 1982. 270 pp.



A6     What the Crow Said. Don Mills, Ont.: General, 1978. 218 pp.
             Markham, Ont.: PaperJacks, 1979. 218 pp.
             New Press Canadian Classics. Toronto: General, 1982. 218 pp.



A7     Alibi. Don Mills, Ont.: Stoddart, 1983.239 pp. --. New York: Beaufort, 1983.239 pp.

Title:

<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP1000007003001002&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 1 Works by Robert Kroetsch; Books (novels, poetry, mixed genre collection, memoir, criticism, travel book, and books edited), broadside, editorial work, audio-visual material, and manuscripts; Poetry</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 1: Works By Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 273-291

Part 1 Works by Robert Kroetsch; Books (novels, poetry, mixed genre collection, memoir, criticism, travel book, and books edited), broadside, editorial work, audio-visual material, and manuscripts; Poetry  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Poetry

A8     The Stone Hammer Poems: 1960-1975. Nanaimo, B.C.: Oolichan, 1975. 63 pp.

          Lantzville, B.C.: Oolichan, 1976.64 pp. Includes "The Agony on Cape Cod" (B6), "Birthday" (B21), "Dogteam Race in Manitoba" (B27), "Elegy for Wong Toy" (B17), "F.P. Grove: The Finding" (B31), "Idea for a Poem" (B44), "Mackenzie River: Nightfall" (B29), "Meditation on Tom Thompson" (B30), "Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights" (B16), "October Light" (B18), "Old Man Stories: 1-12" (B26, B28), "Outside Moose Jaw: A Whirlwind: Silence" (B5), "Poem of Albert Johnson" (B32), "Projected Visit" (B19), "Pumpkin: A Love Poem" (B33), "Sentence" (B23), "Sketches towards a Couplet on Love: 1-3" (Bll), "Spring Harvest" (B45), "Stone Hammer Poem," "Syllogisms of Desire" (B10), "Tidewater Burial" (B3), "20/20 Vision," and "Winter Birds" (B34).

A9     The Ledger. London, Ont.: Applegarth Follies, 1975. [28] pp.

          Coldstream. Ilderton, Ont.: Brick/Nairn, [1979?]. [32] pp.

A10    Seed Catalogue. Turnstone Poetry Series One, No. 7. Winnipeg: Turnstone, 1977.75 pp. Winnipeg: Turnstone, 1979. 50 pp. Includes "Abandon Ship" (B14), "Alberta Haiku (failed)" (B39), "Anthem," "Conservative Streak" (B22),"Getting Up to Find an Aspirin" (B2), "Highway One" (B36), "Historia Animalium" (B4), "How I Joined the Seal Herd" (B41), "Identification Question" (B37), "Jealousy," "My Tree Poem" (B38), "Native" (B9), "Seed Catalogue" (B42-B43), "Snowfall," and "There Is a World" (B40).

A11    The Sad Phoenician. Toronto: Coach House, 1979. 75 pp. Includes "The Sad Phoenician: A-Z" (B47-B48), "The Silent Poet Sequence: The Silent Poet at Intermission" "The Silent Poet Sequence: The Silent Poet Craves Immortality," "The Silent Poet Sequence: The Silent Poet Eats His Words," "The Silent Poet Sequence: The Silent Poet Finds Out," "The Silent Poet Sequence: The Silent Poet Moves His Office," "The Silent Poet Sequence: The Silent Poet Sees Red," and "[thir / st sin...]."

A12    The Criminal Intensities of Love as Paradise. Lantzville, B.C.: Oolichan, 1981.29 pp. Includes "And Dreamers, Even Then, If Dreaming," "Awoken and, Again, Hungry, Again," "Bear Story with or without Bear" (B53), "Breakfast, After, & Looking," "Campsite, Home, Away From," "Fire & Pan," "Into Town, .... Morning, Jasper Park," "Nude Swimmers in Late Afternoon" "Post Card to a Hillside," "Salt, of Ocean Sea, of Tears," and "Standing Near a Waterfall."

A13    Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch. Preface Eli Mandel. Spectrum Poetry Series. Don Mills, Ont.: General, 1981. 144 pp. Includes "The Criminal Intensities of Love as Paradise: And Dreamers, Even Then, If Dreaming [A12]; Awoken and, Again, Hungry, Again [A12]; Bear Story with or without Bear [B53]; Breakfast, After, & Looking [A12]; Campsite, Home Away From [A12]; Fire & Pan [A12]; Into Town [A12]; Morning, Jasper Park [A12]; Nude Swimmers in Late Afternoon [A12]; Post Card to a Hillside [A12]; Salt, of Ocean Sea, of Tears [A12]; Standing Near a Waterfall [A12]," "How I Joined the Seal Herd" (B41), "The Ledger" (B25), "The Sad Phoenician" (B47-B48), "Seed Catalogue" (B42-B43), "The Silent Poet Sequence: The Silent Poet at Intermission, The Silent Poet Craves Immortality, The Silent Poet Eats His Words, The Silent Poet Finds Out, The Silent Poet Moves His Office, The Silent Poet Sees Red" (All), "Sketches of a Lemon" (B54), "Stone Hammer Poem" (A8), and "The Winnipeg Zoo" (B52).

A14    Letters to Salonika. Toronto: Grand Union, 1983. [34] pp.

A15    Advice to My Friends: a continuing poem. Vol.II of Field Notes. Spectrum Poetry Series. Don Mills, Ont.: Stoddart, 1985. 143 pp. Includes "Advice to My Friends: 1 for a poet who has stopped writing [B67]; 2 to Eli Mandel, setting his new alarm [B68]; 3 to the Wahs, on the Kootenay River; 4 Slocan Valley, July 17, 1983: for Smaro [B661; 5 listening to the radio: for Michael Ondaatje; 6 reading it in the (comic) papers: for bp; 7 the bridegroom rises to speak; 8 wedding dance, country-style; 9 philosophy of composition: for Paul Thompson; 10 back in the spring of '76: for Laurie Ricou; 11 Laurie Ricou waiting to present a paper entitled 'the Intersections of Plain/s Space and Poetry,' March, 1982; 12 late fall drive: for Byrna Barclay [B711; 13 November 9, 1983: for Robert Hilles [B72]; 14 I find myself reading the old guys now: December 6, 1983; 15 for Doug Jones: the explanation [B70]; 16 seeing the bear; 17 having a word with Columbus: a song for Ed Dyck; 18 four questions for George Bowering; 19 stairway: for Giovanna Capone; 20 a ritual for one [B74]," "Delphi: Commentary" (B73), "The Frankfurt Hauptbahnhof' (B69), "Letters to Salonika" (A14), "Mile Zero" (B16), "The Poet's Mother: 1-4; envoi (to begin with)," "Postcards from China," and "Sounding the Name: birthday: June 26, 1983; I'm getting old now; sonnet for my daughters; Sonnet//1; Sonnet//5; sounding the name."

A16    Excerpts from the Real World. Lantzville, B.C.: Oolichan, 1986. 64 pp. See [B75-B78].

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Books, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews and profiles, adaptation, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Adaptation

Adaptation

C352       Goldman, Alvin, adapted. Adelaide Menthe. CBC Radio, 14 Feb. 1962. (90 min.) A radio adaptation in English of Hebert's La Merciere assassinee.

Item Number: ABCMA07AHP2000007002003005
Record: 24
Title:
Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Books, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews and profiles, adaptation, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Articles and sections of books
Other Title:
Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Books, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews and profiles, adaptation, miscellaneous, and awards and honours
Record Type:
Reference Series
Series Title:
Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors, no. 7
Author(s):
Russell, D.W. (compiler)
Genre(s):
Bibliography
Subject(s):
Authors discussed:  HEBERT, Anne; HEBERT, Anne -- Criticism & interpretation -- Bibliography
Topics:  CANADIAN literature -- Bibliography; FRENCH-CANADIAN literature -- Bibliography
Book Source:
Russell, D.W. (compiler) Part 2: Works On Anne Hebert.

ABCMA07AHP2000007002003002

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07AHP2000007002003002&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Books, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews and profiles, adaptation, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Articles and sections of books</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Anne Hebert. Russell, D.W. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 145-263

Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Books, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews and profiles, adaptation, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Articles and sections of books  

Russell, D.W. (compiler)

Articles and Sections of Books

C15      Hilaire, Pere, capucin. "De Francois d'Assise Anne Hebert." Gants du ciel, No.4 (juin 1944), pp. 21-34. In the discussion of poets who have been inspired by a Franciscan sense of the simple beauty of nature, Hilaire discusses the poetry of Saint-Denys Garneau and Anne Hebert (Les Songes en equilibre), among many others. Hebert's poetry is "le chant authentique d'une source impolluee." Hilaire comments as well on the religious qualities of this first volume of poetry, in which he sees many similarities in doctrinal point of view to that of Saint Francis of Assisi.

C16      Lemelin, Roger. "Voici notre jeune litterature: Anne Hebert." La Revue populaire, oct. 1946, pp. 12, 73. In this short, two-paragraph bio-bibliography, Lemelin mentions Hebert's modesty and poetic nature. Les Songes en equilibre as well as two stories, "La Maison de l'Esplanade" and "L'Ange de Dominique," are mentioned. She is currently working on a volume of stories.

C17      Emmanuel, Pierre. "Prdsentation." In Le Tombeau des rois. By Anne Hebert. Quebec: Institut litteraire du Quebec, 1953, p.[7]. Rpt. in Poemes. By Anne Hebert. Paris: Seuil, 1960, pp.ll-12. Rpt. (Preface) in The Tomb of the Kings. By Anne Hebert. Trans. Peter Miller. Toronto: Contact, 1967, p. 13. Emmanuel gives a succinct analysis of the poetry: "Reduite a l'essentiel, cette langue refuse tousles prestiges qui la rendraient habitable aux amateurs de poesie. Elle demande ses lecteurs un renoncement egal a son exigence." His description of the imagery is often quoted by critics: "Un verbe austere et sec, rompu, soigneusement exclu de la musique: des poemes comme traces dans l'os par la pointe d'un poignard, voila ce qu'Anne Hebert propose." He concludes, "On peut faire l'experience des deserts de l'ame a Quebec aussi bien qu'en Arabie petree."

C18      Racette, Jacques. "Anne Hebert publie." La Revue dominicaine, juil.-aout 1953, pp. 25-30. Racette's detailed study of Le Tombeau des rois begins with a discussion of the general cultural context in which the work was created. The generalizations are presented to suggest that French-Canadian literature is leaving its childhood and entering adolescence; an example of this painful growth is found in Hebert's Le Tombeau des rois. He analyzes four poems "Les Pecheurs d'eau," "Les Petites Villes," "En guise de fete," and "Rouler dans des ravins de fatigue" -- as representative, respectively, of poetic sensibility, conscience, memory, and intelligence. These four faculties show the evolution within the volume of poems. Continued in C19.

C19      Racette, Jacques. "Anne Hebert publie." La Revue dominicaine, sept. 1953, pp. 79-86. A continuation of C18.

C20      Viatte, Auguste. Histoire litteraire de l'Amerique francaise des origines a 1950. Quebec/Paris: Les Presses de l'Univ. Laval/Les Presses Universitaires de France, 1954, pp. 195-96, 515. Les Songes en equilibre combines the themes of childhood and death. "L'Ange de Dominique" shows a similar poetic quality in its surrealistic world. In Le Tombeau des rois "... elle arrive une limite, la poesie concentree, a l'essentiel ... " Her later poetry is closer to the work of Jules Supervielle and Jean Cocteau.

C21      Robert, Lucette. "Ce dont on parle." La Revue populaire, sept. 1955, pp. 8, 53. This is a photograph of Hebert and a brief mention of the award of "une bourse de la Societe Royale du Canada pour des etudes en France." Hebert is the author of the script Le Cocher for the ONF, as well as of Les Songes en equilibre, Le Torrent, Le Tombeau des rois.

C22      Lapointe, Jeanne. "Quelques apports positifs de notre litterature d'imagination." Cite libre, No. 10 (oct. 1954), pp.18, 20, 21, 22, 32-35, 36. Rpt. ("Quelques apports positifs de notre litterature") in Presence de la critique: critique et litterature contemporaines au Canada francais. Ed. Gilles Marcotte. Montreal: HMH, 1966, pp.104, 105, 106, 109, 116, 117-19. In this survey of Quebec literature, Lapointe briefly analyzes Les Songes en equilibre, Le Torrent, and Le Tombeau des rois. Of this latter she notes that the painfulness of the poetic adventure is counterbalanced by the aesthetic beauty of the verse.

C23      Collin, W.E. "The Poetry of a Dissolving Society." The Canadian Modern Language Review, 11, No. 2 (hiver 1955), 10-11. Commenting on Les Songes en equilibre and Le Tombeau des rois, Collin states, "The world of her earlier poems, as with Garneau, is a world of darkness .... Pitiable children forever outside the world, the key to our childhood paradise lost, we look upon an icy garden each in his eery loneliness .... Her second volume is the poetry of a heart that wants to shut itself in with its pain. The conceits are of one order: a well, a hedge, an inner court with a fountain, a closed room with a heart set on a table .... The art is anatomical; not the luscious, decorative art of a Gautier but the austere art of St. Denys Garneau."

C24      Baillargeon, Samuel. "Anne Hebert: Une solitaire angoissee" In his Litterature canadienne-francaise. Montreal: Fides, 1957, pp. 338-42. Rpt. (revised -- "Anne Hebert: Un coeur 'que deshabita la jeunesse'") in his Litterature canadienne-francaisa 3rd ed. Montreal: Fides, 1960, pp. 376-81. "Le Miroir" "illustre, point par point, l'evolution sentimentale" of the poet. "Dans le retroviseur du passe, elle voit surgir les visions familieres qu'elle a rant aimees. Mais elle voit soudain monter son coeur triste qui la rappelle au present et fair evanouir le jeu." Baillargeon prefers to see her poetry as the expression of the adolescent crisis: "Les Songes en equilibre sont un temoignage candide, inscrit au premier tournant de sa maturite ..." Although he qualifies Le Tombeau des rois as "une oeuvre plus angoissee, plus hermetique, mais plus solide que la precedente" Baillargeon does not discuss this work in any detail. "Le Miroir" is cited in full (pages 379-81).

C25      Jasmin, Judith. "Canadiens a Paris." La Revue populaire, juil. 1957, p. 5. This article contains a photograph and two short paragraphs on Hebert's life in Paris, where for almost three years she has been moving from rented room to rented room, spinning out her scholarship money as she finishes her first novel. "Pour Anne Hebert ... Paris signifie la liberation de resprit." She wishes to complete her novel "loin des contraintes familiales, sociales et mentales que comporte la vie dans un milieu aussi cloitre que celui qu'elle a connu dans son pays."

C26      De Sacy, Samuel S. Preface. In Les Chambres de bois. By Anne Hebert. Paris: Seuil, 1958, pp. 9-24. De Sacy discusses the stereotypes of cultural differences between Quebec and France: the physical vastness, the struggle for survival, as well as the modern industrial cities of Canada are what the French associate with Quebec. Saint-Denys Garneau is the first truly modern poet in Quebec, who "sut pour la premiere fois douer de la parole les puissances nocturnes de ia solitude, du desespoir et de la frustration" De Sacy demurs from any extended comment on the present novel for which he is writing this Preface. He does describe Michel, however: "... Anne Hebert promeut a la vie romanesque un homme a la fois pris dans l'existence et exile de l'existence, dechire entre la necessite d'etre et l'impossibilite d'etre." Hebert's style is one which evokes objects "par des touches rapides, legeres et sures, par le signe prefere a la description, dans le style de la pudeur et de l'allusion ... Nous pourrions croire a un poeme en prose plutot qu'a un roman ..." The last part of "Alchimie du jour" is quoted as an example of the metamorphosis evident in the character of Catherine in the novel.

C27      LeMoyne, Jean. "Hors les chambres d'enfance: Les Chambres de bois, roman d'Anne Hebert," Le Journal musical canadien, 5 (nov. 1958), 3, 5. Rpt. in Presence de la critique: critique et litterature contemporaines au Canada francais. Ed. Gilles Marcotte. Montreal: HMH, 1966, pp. 35-42. LeMoyne deals with the end of cultural alienation and the beginning of a "prise de possession" of life which he sees in the novels of Robert Charbonneau, Robert Elie, Andre Langevin, and Anne Hebert. With reference to Les Chambres de bois, he comments on the poetic language of the novel and on the setting, which may be France, but which deals with a completely French-Canadian situation. The "royaume sacre de l'enfance," which holds Michel prisoner, also held Saint-Denys Garneau prisoner. Catherine escapes from the hold of this love for a lost innocence, and from Michel who remains married to dreams, as indicated by the ring "pour le songe" which Catherine gives him at the end of the novel. Catherine is able to grow beyond this cloistered life; she is "capable aujourd'haui comme on ne i'etait pas au temps precedent non pas seulement de survivre, mais de prendre et de donner, et de faire et de former." Although the description of Catherine's new love at the end of the novel is not fully expressed (it is "le recit d'une liberation et non celui d'une vie deja possedee"), it is not a banal love affair, but "la premiere et indispensable possession de la terre

C2      Beaulieu, Maurice. "Poetry from French Canada: The Seven Stages of Modern French-Canadian Poetry." Trans. Louis Dudek. Anthology. CBC Radio, 22 May 1959. Beaulieu places Hebert at the fourth of seven stages in the development of French-Canadian poetry. "Here we discover desire pressing out puritanism to its last lines of defence, but yielding a sense of time as sensual as it was heretofore proscribed. Life throbs with blood to the very reach of desire." An excerpt from "Eveil au seuil d'une fontaine" is read (B183). A rebroadcast of "La Fille maigre" (B174) follows Beaulieu's critique.

C29      Steinhouse, Herbert, host. "Poetry from French Canada." Anthology. CBC Radio, 22 May 1959. Steinhouse notes that Twelve Modern French-Canadian Poets (B103) and Voix de 8 pontes du Canada (B174-B178) "are welcome new works." He introduces Maurice Beaulieu's comments (C28) and plays an excerpt from the record at the end of the program (B174).

C30      Blain, Maurice. "Anne Hebert ou le risque de vivre." Liberte, 1 (sept.-oct. 1959), 322-30. Rpt. in Presence de la critique: critique et litterature contemporaines au Canada francais. Ed. Gilles Marcotte. Montreal: HMH, 1966, pp.155-63. Rpt. in Approximations: Essais. Montreal: HMH, 1967, pp. 180-90. Blain talks of the coming of age of French-Canadian literature, which inevitably had to begin with an "inventaire de notre misere spirituelle," with the mastery of the geography of the new land, before "le temps des hommes" could arrive. Hebert's first novel marks a change from the exploration of the painful shadows of alienation visible in her earlier work. "C'est l'avenement incertain de l'espoir dans un univers jusque 1a sans autre issue que la mort." Blain analyzes the two sides of her fictional space: "une absence du reel -- la chambre de bois, et une presence a l'irreel -- le chateau des seigneurs" He sees death, the "principe et fin de toute naissance" as a central myth or motif of her work. The images of a cloistered or reduced life are attempts to know death. But, in Les Chambres de bois, Hebert has destroyed the attraction of this myth and exorcised death. "Pour la premiere fois apparaissent la tentation et le risque de vivre, et d'etre heureux." Blain comments on the difficult structure of the novel, which alternates between the dream world and a very banal real world. The poetic current in the work does not always escape vagueness, and Blain sees a struggle by the artist to arrive at a dialogue with others, which is the form most suitable for the novel. The novel is only partly successful, then, in the technical sense, but it shows great promise for future developments in her work and marks a break with previous alienation. The true novel is just beginning at the end of Les Chambres de bois. But the expression of the break was necessary, and it closes "un temps psychologique et un cycle artistique revolus dans l'oeuvre d'Anne Hebert."

C31      Levine, Norman. "My Ear against the Doors." Anthology. CBC Radio, 9 Oct. 1959. This is a rebroadcast of a program prepared for the BBC by Levine. French-Canadian poetry is better known in England than English-Canadian poetry, perhaps because the former is more personal and symbolic than the latter. Poems of Saint-Denys Garneau, Anne Hebert, and Pierre Trottier are read. Anne Hebert is very similar to Garneau, although in her work "... a feminine sensibility seeps through the isolation and loneliness .... The general tone of Anne Hebert's poetry is sober to the point of suggesting the deliberate exclusion of enjoyment." "The Little Towns" (B176) and "Our Hands in the Garden" (B184) are read, using translationsby F.R. Scott and Jean Beaupre.

C32      Lapointe, Jeanne. "Note explicative: une petite aventure en litterature experimentale." Ecrits du Canada francais, 7 (1960), 195-201. Rpt. in Dialogue sur la traduction: a propos du "Tombeau des rois." By Anne Hebert and Frank Scott. Collection sur parole. Montreal: HMH, 1970, pp. 23-35. Lapointe explains how the publication of the correspondence between F.R. Scott and Anne Hebert came about. In the course of the exchange of translation, comments, and response to comments and new translations, Lapointe remarks that there were many areas of mutual discovery: these include the comparative stylistics of English and French, the effects of harmony and rhythm, and the volition behind the poet's choice of metaphor.

C33      Smith, A.J.M. Introduction. In The Oxford Book of Canadian Verse: In English and French. Ed. A.J.M. Smith. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1960, pp.xlviii-xlix. Smith comments on the "spiritual insight" of Saint-Denys Garneau and Anne Hebert. "Anne Hdbert is perhaps less adventurous [than SaintDenys Garneau], but her sensibility and style are even purer, if that is possible .... Her poems ... also deal with childhood, loneliness, memory and death. They show an awareness that sometimes approaches mysticism. Solitude, reverie, and the enclosed life are valued in their personal aspect. In some of her poems.., she expresses a sense of the stifling atmosphere created by the enclosed, backward-looking, ancestor-worshipping, earthbound spirit of French-Canadian nationalism."

C34      Allaire, Emilia. "Poetesse, romanciere, dramaturge: Anne Halbert." La Revue populaire, juil. 1961, pp. 14-16. Two photographs and bio-bibliographical information are given in this article based on interviews with Hebert and with her parents. Her writing routines are briefly described; she is currently working on a play. Both parents are quoted briefly on the effect of success on their daughter, and Hebert is quoted several times with reference to her work.

C35      Purcell, Patricia. "The Agonizing Solitude: The Poetry of Anne Halbert." Canadian Literature, No.10 (Autumn 1961), pp.51-61. Rpt. (excerpt) in Modern Commonwealth Literature: A Library of Literary Criticism. Ed. John H. Ferres and Martin Tucker. New York: Frederick Ungar, 1977, pp. 283-85. Purcell's thematic analysis of the three volumes of poetry refers to the evolution of the poet's sensibility. Purcell recapitulates the movement from painful introspection to the assertion of liberation from isolation and pain. The article concludes: "The three volumes of Anne Hebert's poems, then, record her evolution from carefree childhood through an agonizing solitude of poetic and spiritual formation to a freedom in which she embraces her French-Canadian people and all humanity -- a triumphant development of thought through poetry."

C36      Marcotte, Gilles. "'Le Tombeau des rois' d'Anne Halbert." In his Une litterature qui se fait: Essais critique sur la litterature canadienne-francaise. Montreal: HMH, 1962, pp. 272-83. Enl. ed., 1968, pp. 286-97. Marcotte relates the dispossession expressed in Le Tombeau des rois to that shown in "Le Torrent." Both works express a willed exploration of alienation: in the poetry, the language is adapted to the rigorously reduced life of a skeleton, or life within a pebble; the verse is spare, the imagery austere. The final poem is an extended exploration of the marriage with death, to exorcize finally the attraction of solitude and silence. The poem is a confrontation with the real and the risk of death which this contains. "II fallait aller jusqu'au bout du songe pour en abolir la fascination. I1 fallait traverser tout le royaume de la mort pour retrouver la vie."

C37        Wyczynski, Paul. "L'Univers podtique d'Anne Halbert." L'Enseignement secondaire, 42, No.2 (mars-avril 1963), 5-20. Rpt. in Poesie et symbole. By Paul Wyczynski. Montrdal: Deom, 1965, pp. 147-85. Wyczynski discusses the imagery of "chair, sang, vibration, plainte, cri, meditation, reverie," for these are the images of the interior being of the poet. Three key images, "eau, mains et oiseau," are distinguished in this study of her three volumes of verse. The use of imagery also becomes more expansive with each volume of verse, so that the final one uses ample poetic lines packed with multiple images that go well beyond the dominant imagery of water, hands, and birds of the previous volumes.

C38      Brault, Jacques. "Philosophie et litterature." Incidences [Univ. d'Ottawa], No.3 (oct. 1963), pp. 5-7. Brault comments on the role of the poet as outlined by Hebert in "Podsie, solitude rompue" and as expressed in her poetry. Brault suggests that the philosophers of French Canada could well heed this theoretical statement, which demonstrates that the poetic use of language is a means of being in the real world.

C39      Marcotte, Gilles. "La Religion dans la litterature canadienne-francaise contemporaine" In Litterature et societe canadiennes-francaises Ed. Fernand Dumont et Jean Falardeau. Quebec: Les Presses de l'Univ. Laval, 1964, pp. 169, 170-71, 172, 173, 174, 176. Marcotte discusses the role that religion plays in contemporary novels, as well as in some poetry and plays. "Le Torrent" is presented as one of the strongest stateraents of revolt against the negative aspects of traditional religion found in French-Canadian literature.

C40       Sainte-Marie-Eleuthere, Soeur. "Symboles de la mere." In her La Mere dans le roman canadienfrancais. Vie des lettres canadiennes, 1. Quebec: Les Presses de l'Univ. Laval, 1964, pp.64-72, 121-28. Sainte-Marie-Eleuthere comments on "Le Torrent" and Les Chambres de bois as well as on many other works in the course of her discussion of symbols. Perceval is seen as the symbol of 'Tesprit" and beauty, and water is symbolic of the mother. Francois' desire for unity with the cosmos is presented as thwarted by the hatred which his mother has forced him to have for the world.

C41      "Anne Hebert (1916- )." In Ecrivains Canadiens/ Canadian Writers: A Biographical Dictionary. Ed. Guy Sylvestre, Brandon Conron, and Carl F. Klinck. Toronto: Ryerson, 1964, pp. 63-64. Rpt. in Canadian Writers/Ecrivains Canadiens: A Biographical Dictionary. Rev. and enl. ed. Ed. Guy Sylvestre, Brandon Conron, and Carl F. Klinck. Toronto: Ryerson, 1966, pp. 71-72. The authors include brief bio-bibliographical data. Les Songes en equilibre are "des reves d'une enfant recluse qui se joue des mots .... " Le Tombeau des rois has a tragic tone, and "... le style est d'un depouillement extreme." The last part of Poemes celebrates "la reconciliation du porte avec le monde et avec la vie .... " The story "Le Torrent" has an "intensite bouleversante" and is one of the best in French-Canadian literature. Les Chambres de bois is "ecrit dans une langue poetique d'une belle qualite" and presents "un univers de reve ...." La Merciere assassinee is an apprentice piece; Le Temps sauvage is much superior, and takes up the basic themes of her poetry and stories.

C42      Wilson, Edmund. O Canada: An American's Notes on Canadian Culture. New York: Farrar, Straus and Giroux, 1964, pp.122, 123-27, 150. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Carolyn Riley. Vol.lv. Detroit: Gale, 1975, 219. Wilson admits his bias against vers libre "when it is written in France itself, [but the]... abstraction and ... purified metaphors that do not seem to refer to anything in their actual Canadian world" leave him cold. Hebert's prose "does take us into the maisons seigneuriales and other recognizable Canadian places, but these, too, are rather stripped. And we are partly in a realm of dream." In Les Chambres de bois, the characters "do not always quite know where they are." The cheerful ending is unusual in French-Canadian literature.

C43      Amyot, Georges. "Anne Hebert et la renaissance." Ecrits du Canada francais, 20 (1965), 233-53. Amyot discusses Samuel S. de Sacy's Preface to Les Chambres de bois (C26), not with reference to the novel, but with reference to the poetry, commenting on several poems briefly. "La sagesse m'a rompu les bras," for example, is cited as proof of Hebert's revolt against, and escape from, a repressive Quebec society. Amyot also comments briefly on the stylistic changes between Le Tombeau des roi and Mystere de la parole. He prefers Hebert's poetry to her poetic novel, Les Chambres de bois, which he feels is not successful. But this criticism should not obscure the greatness of Hebert as a writer: "Je crois que Garneau et Anne Hebert sont deux grands pontes de langue francaise, et qui supportenttoutes les comparaisons"

C44      Page, Pierre. "Le Porte et son pays." In his Anne Hebert. Ecrivains canadiens            d'aujourd'hui. Montreal: Fides, 1965, pp. 9-119. Page discusses the influence of Hebert's family background, including the role played by her father, and by her cousin Saint-Denys Garneau. Page traces the obvious connection Hebert has with the physical countryside, expressed in part by the explicit statements in her works, and by her films, particularly her study of the life and work of Saint-Denys Garneau. This study also devotes one chapter each to prose, drama, and poetry. His analysis of Le Torrent and Les Chambres de bois points out the significance of the dream-like nature of the action, and the psychological finesse of the characterization. Her poetry is a means of recreating man and, more specifically, of recreating a world which will be habitable for man. The final chapter underlines the aesthetic rigour of Hebert's work, which resists facile biographical interpretations and attains a perfection of form and a universality of meaning. "C'est ainsi que l'oeuvre d'Anne Hebert, au moment ou le Canada tend vers sa maturite, temoigne des qualites, les plus n6cessaires, la rigueur, la verite, le souci de la perfection." The book also includes a selection of H4bert's work (B107) and a Bibliography (C45).

C45        Page, Pierre. "Bibliographie." In Anne Hebert. By Pierre Page. Ecrivains canadiens d'aujourd'hui. Montreal: Fides, 1965, pp. 175-87. Bibliographical data including primary and secondary sources.

C46      Robidoux, Rejean. "Les Chambres de bois d'Anne Hebert." Prod. Jean Raymond St.-Cyr. CJBC Radio [Toronto], 6 sept. 1965. [Archives, Centre de recherche en civilisation canadienne-francaise, Univ. d'Ottawa.] Robidoux analyzes the poetic qualities of Les Chambres de bois. These comments are followed by an interview of Hebert by Robidoux (C330).

C47        Brault, Jacques. "Une poesie du risque ...." Culture vivante, No. 1 (1966), pp. 41,42. Brault provides a short analysis of poetry in Quebec in the last twenty years (1944-64), in which Hebert is listed as one of the major poets. Poetry is seen as the avant-garde literary art: "... nos pontes ne parlent pas pour nous, il nous parlent, au sens intransitif du verbe." For Brault "... la poesie de nos pontes thematise la revolution d'un Quebec en marche vers le courage de vivre."

C48      Canadian Literature / Litterature canadienne 1959--1963: A Checklist of Creative and Critical Writings/Bibliographie de la critique et des oeuvres d'imagination. Ed. Inglis F. Bell and Susan W. Port. A Canadian Literature Supplement. Vancouver: Publications Centre, Univ. of British Columbia, 1966, p. 135. Seven bibliographic entries.

C49        Paradis, Suzanne. "Anne Hebert: Claudine Perrault, Ade1aide Menthe, Catherine, Lia, Agnes Joncas." In her Femme fictive, femme reelle: le personnage feminin dans le roman feminin canadien-francais, 1884-1966. Quebec: Garneau, 1966, pp. 128-47. Paradis briefly summarizes the plot and analyzes the female characters. Claudine is the traditional French-Canadian fictional mother who is repressively vengeful and destroys the potential man to be found in her own son. "Le Torrent" shows the need for a more liberal social attitude toward illegitimate children. Ade1aide is an amoral, caricatural representation of revenge. Catherine is like many other heroines in that she is without a mother and is made responsible for younger children. Catherine's return at the end of the novel to a sensual life, Paradis suggests, is a return to a natural female condition unfettered by the ambitions that contemporary feminists have for the role of women. Lia is condemned to a life of unrequited passion. Agnes Joncas and her family repeat many of the qualities of earlier female characters: "... la femme n'est pas heureuse, dans notre roman, et la mere, irrecuperable." Paradis concludes that "... a l'heure d'Anne Hebert, la litterature ne croit pas encore au salut de la femme."

C50      Robidoux, Rejean, and Andre Renaud. "Les Chambres de bois." In their Le Roman canadien-francais du vingtieme siecle. Ottawa: Editions de l'Univ, d'Ottawa, 1966, pp. 171-85. This analysis of the novel shows its relationship to the poetry of Le Tombeau des rois. It is "toute l'aventure poetique du Tombeau des rois qui se trouve projetee dans une autre forme d'expression litteraire." Robidoux and Renaud also comment on the poetic structure of the novel. The work is one in which subjective reality dominates, instead of an objective exterior fictional world. The lyricism of the novel, which respects the value of a poetic experience rather than attempting discursive prose, makes the work more like a prose poem than a novel.

C51        Bessette, Gerard. "La Dislocation dans la poesie d'Anne Halbert." Revue de l'Universite d'Ottawa, 36 (jan.-mars 1966), 50-60. Rpt. in Une litterature en ebullition. By Gerard Bessette. Montreal: Jour, 1968, pp. 13-23. "Dislocation," meaning dismemberment, or the separation of the parts of the body, is traced in the imagery of Hebert's poetry. Bessette suggests that there is an element of masochism and a need for punishment present in this imagery, which is centred on the hand, the face (especially the eye), and the heart; the hand predominates in Le Tombeau des rois, the heart in Mystere de la parole, which suggests a progressive interiorization in the imagery. The curious lack of emotion which is present in the early poetry connected with self-mutilation begins to be replaced in "Le Tombeau des rois" by a feeling of rebellion, which blossoms in Mystere de la parole. This is an indication that the poet has been able to rid herself of the sadistic-masochistic impulse.

C52        Aylwin, Ulric. "Vers une lecture de l'oeuvre d'Anne Hebert." La Barre du jour, No. 7, [2, No. 1] (ete 1966), pp. 2-11. In a stylistic analysis, Aylwin examines the use of articles, conjunctions, sentence structure, as well as the themes of silence and dreams. A short study of "La Fille maigre" serves as an introduction to a semantic and stylistic study of Les Chambres de bois, in which Aylwin gives some statistical examples of the frequency of particular structures. The relative paucity of subordinate clauses, for example, helps create the impression of a "univers formellement incoherent, fragmental, qui s'accorde parfaitement au rythme du reve."

C53      McQuillan, Janet. Commentary. The Feminine Touch. CBC Radio, 6 July 1966. Critical comments and biographical details precede and follow the reading of five poems by Hebert (B178, B186-B189). "Mr. Scott's translations have kept the rhythms of ordinary speech." Hebert's poetry follows in the style of St. Denys-Garneau and is "introspective and free-flowing"

C54        Rochon, Claude. "Le Temps sauvage ou la souffrance cride." Incidences [Univ. d'Ottawa], No. 11 (automne 1966), pp. 43-45. This brief analysis of the play emphasizes the poetic sensitivity of the work. It is the "drame d'une conscience torturde qui n'a jamais appris la joie. Drame dont la consdquence avouee est le refus quotidien, le refus total." Rochon stresses the forcefulness of the expression of this feeling of violence and suffering.

C55      Aylwin, Ulric. "Au pays de la fille maigre: 'Les Chambres de bois' d'Anne Hebert." Voix et images du pays, 1 (1967), 37-50. 2nd ed., 1970, pp. 37-50. In this thematic study of the Les Chambres de bois, Aylwin suggests that it is a continuation of the "fille maigre" image found in Hebert's poetry. The combination of fire and water imagery is an attempt to find the original unity of man beyond sexual duality, but in the end this attempt is abandoned by Catherine.

C56      Ethier-Blais, Jean. "Anne Hebert et Paul Toupin: Fleurons glorieux." In his Signets. Montreal: Cercle du Livre de France, 1967. Vol. II, 195,197-202. Ethier-Blais declares that there is a troubling element in Hebert's work: "Il y a chez elle une crainte de la vie, un repliement sur soi, une question a laquelle aucune reponse n'est donnee ...." He qualifies Hebert as "un porte de questions, sur le mode mineur," and states that "Anne Hebert penetre dans l'univers des morts, mais c'est pour y poser des questions." Her writing reflects the French-Canadian soul: "Le monde ecrit d'Anne Hebert est fait d'un fantome qui hurle dans la foret un message dont il ne saura jamais le sens. Pourquoi? Peut-etre parce que nous aussi nous sommes des fantomes de l'histoire et qu'un lien organique unit l'oeuvre d'Anne Hebert a sa race. Sa voix nous chante nos malheurs."

C57       Miller, Peter. "Translator's Note." In The Tomb of the Kings. By Anne Hebert. Trans. Peter Miller. Toronto: Contact, 1967, pp. 11-12. Miller comments briefly on the existence of earlier translations, particularly those of F.R. Scott published in 1962 (B4, B31-B32, B34-B35, B39, B41-B42, B47), as well as Dialogue sur la traduction: a propos du "Tombeau des rois." Le Tombeau des rois "is one of the few collections in the poetry of any country which persists in the imagination as a fullness, a unit. To provide the complete text in bilingual edition has therefore been an insistent ambition of mine .... " This volume of Hebert's poetry "is justly famous for its economy and purity of language, its richness of imagination, and its intensity of feeling .... Le Tombeau des Rois is her key work: her masterpiece."

C58      Story, Norah. "Anne Hebert." In her The Oxford Companion to Canadian History and Literature. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1967, p. 352. Story briefly describes Hebert's career and works.

C59        Le Grand, Albert. "Anne Hebert: de l'exil au royaume." Conferences J.-A. de Seve, Univ. de Montreal. Montreal, 23 fev. 1967. Printed in Anne Hebert: de l'exil au royaume. Conferences J.-A. de Seve, 7 (1966-67) (pamphlet). By Albert Le Grand. Ed. Dept. d'etudes francaises, Univ. de Montreal. Montreal: Presses de l'Univ, de Montreal, 1967. 37 pp. Rpt. ("Anne Hebert: de l'exil au royaume") Etudes francaises, 4 (fev. 1968), 3-29. Rpt. in Litterature canadienne-francaise: Conferences J.-A. de Seve. Ed. Dept. d'etudes francaises, Univ. de Montreal. Montreal: Les Presses de l'Univ, de Montreal, 1969, pp. 181-213. Le Grand approaches the work from a Jungian point of view, arguing that "... aucune autre oeuvre d'ici ne me semble conjuguer avec autant de bonheur dans ses structures, ses images et son ecriture, les divers temps: passe, present, avenir, d'un univers mythique d'ou emergent les signes d'un destin a la lois personnel et collectif." He uses Hebert's prose piece from Le Devoir [Montreal] in 1960 and "Poesie, solitude rompue" to show her concern with her fellow countrymen. Le Grand analyzes her work from Les Songes en equilibre to Le Temps sauvage to show that there is a movement from the expression of the "terre d'exil" to the assumption of life in the present. He places Hebert in the literary context of Quebec, which until the second quarter of the twentieth century had been repressively religious and didactic, the better to show the strength of her literary revolt. Hebert's film on Saint-Denys Garneau (A14) expresses well the sense of moral rigour and physical dispossession which she deals with in her work: "... were we not taught to be in the world, but not of it?" It is this Jansenism which is the source of the images of failure and death which haunt her work, and which are exorcized in Le Temps sauvage and Les Chambres de bois after the liberating struggle of Le Tombeau des rois. Le Grand presents the literary context which led to the cult of "absence au reel" in analyzing the treatment of this theme in "Le Torrent" and Le Temps sauvage. But it is the victory over this enchantment with death and other-worldly ideals which is the central meaning of the work of Hebert: "de la tentation du silence a la parole nombreuse, de la tentation de la mort a l'affirmation de la vie, de l'exil au royaume, tel nous apparait le sens profond d'une oeuvre enracinee dans le salut du vivant et l'honneur du porte."

C60       Barberis, Robert. "De l'exil au royaume." Maintenant avri1 1967, pp. 122-24. Barberis reviews the lecture by Albert Le Grand (C59) and quotes extensively from Hebert's "Quand il est question de nommer la vie tout court, nous ne pouvons que balbutier" (B153) and "Le Quebec, cette aventure demesuree" (B154) to further buttress Le Grand's analysis of Hebert's work.

C61      Chamberland, Paul. "Fondation du territoire" Parti pris, 4, Nos.9-10-11-12 (mai-aout 1967), 14, 16, 17-20, 23-24, 40. Chamberland places Hebert in the context of the later development of the Hexagone group of poets -- Gilles Henault, Roland Giguere, Maurice Beaulieu, Jean-Paul Filion. Hebert and Alain Grandbois are presented as initiators of the poetry of origins, of beginnings.

C62      Le Grand, Albert. "Une parole enfin liberee." Maintenant sept. 1967, pp. 267-72. Le Grand analyzes Hebert's work to show the end of an "absence au present, au reel" and a sense of "rupture, contestation, liberation." This is a change which is central to Quebec literature in the twentieth century.

C63      The Seven O'Clock Show. CBC TV, 16 Oct. 1967. Hebert is one of the three winners of the 1967 Molson Literary Awards.

C64      Bessette, Gerard, Lucien Geslin, and Charles Parent. "Anne Hebert." In their Histoire de la litterature canadienne-francaise parles textes: des origines a nos jours. Ed. Gerard Bessette, Lucien Geslin, and Charles Parent. Montreal: Centre educatif et culturel, 1968, pp. 259-61, 262, 263-64, 265-66, 267, 268-69, 270. Bibliographical information is given, as well as brief critical introductions to excerpts, to place the excerpts in context for students. The excerpts are followed by questions for class discussion.

C65      Cloutier Wojciechowska, Cecile. "En guise de presentation." In POESIE DU QUEBEC CONTEMPORAIN / [...] Trans. Hlib Sirko / [...]. Ed. Constantin Bida. Etudes Slaves, No. 2. Montreal: Librairie Deom, 1968, p. 8. Cloutier Wojciechowska discusses briefly the renaissance in Quebec poetry. "Mais ce renouveau est venu, au bout d'une experience noire de solitude de nos aines immediats, de cette experience d'angoisse et de froid, qui se chiffre par le desespoir epuise d'Anne Hebert ou la desesperance comique d'Alain Grandbois. Ensuite il y a eu le temps du rugissement."

C66      Houde, Gilles. "Les Symboles et la structure mythique du "rorrent.'" Pts.I-II. La Barre du jour, No. 16 (oct.-dec. 1968), pp. 22-46. Houde's psychological study of "Le Torrent" develops the premise that the two characters really represent separate parts of a single identity: Claudine is the conscious part of the individual, Francois is the subconscious part. When the conscious attempts to suppress the subconscious, there is the inevitable rebellion and destruction of the individual, for neither part can exist separately. See C74 for the continuation of this piece.

C67        Garneau, Rene. "Anne Hebert." In 1945 a nos jours -- la poesie. Vol. III of Histoire de la litterature francaise du Quebec. Ed. Pierre de Grandpre. Montreal: Beauchemin, 1969, 47-50, 51, 53-55. Garneau provides a short introduction to Hebert's work, with accompanying extracts from the texts.

C68      Lacote, Rene "Anne Hebert: une etude." In his Anne Hebert: une etude avec un choix de poemes, soixante illustrations, une chronique bibliographique: Anne Hebert et son temps. Pontes d'aujourd'hui, No.189. Paris: Seghers, 1969, pp. 5-92. This is a general introduction to the works of Hebert which is indebted to Pierre Page's study (C44). Also, as in Page's study, there are numerous photographs of Hebert and her family. Lacote analyzes the Jansenism in Quebec society and Hebert's reaction against it. His analysis concentrates on Le Torrent and Les Chambres de bois, as well as the three volumes of poetry. He mentions the plays only in passing. His study points out the relationship between the prose works and the poetry, as Page had done earlier. See also C69 for Lacote's "Chronique: Anne Hebert et son temps" and B56, B58, and Bl16 for the poems included in this volume.

C69        Lacote, Rene. "Chronique: Anne Hebert et son temps." In his Anne Hebert: une etude avec un choix de poees, soixante illustrations, une chronique bibliographique: Anne Hebert et son temps. Poetes d'aujourd'hui, No.189. Paris: Seghers, 1969, pp. 166-88. Bibliographical data.

C70        Marcotte, Gilles. "Anne Hebert." In his Le Temps des pontes: Description critique de la poesie actuelle au Canada francais. Montreal: HMH, 1969, pp. 46-49. Marcotte's overview of Hebert's poetry rejects a biographical basis for her work: "... l'histoire se fait mythe, creation par et dans le langage d'un univers donneur de sens."

C71      Pacey, Desmond. Essays in Canadian Criticism 1938-1968. Toronto: Ryerson, 1969, p. 237. Most contemporary Canadian poets (including Hebert) "still draw much of their imagery from the protean Canadian landscape and weather."

C72        Page, Pierre. "La Poesie d'Anne Hebert." In La Poesie canadienne-francaise: perspectives historiques et thematiques, profils de pontes, temoignages, bibliographie. Vol.IV of Archives des lettres canadiennes. Ed. Paul Wyczynski, Bernard Julien, Jean Menard, and Rejean Robidoux. Montreal: Fides, 1969, pp. 357-78. Page examines the imagery of death in the poetry. In the first part Page studies the forms and symbols of death under the subheadings "La Mort reliee au passe," "La Mort psychoiogique," "La Perversion de l'amour," and "La Mort du silence." In the second section he studies the victory over death, under the subheadings "La Revolte," "La Parole," "L'Euphemisation de la mort," and "L'Union amoureuse." Page shows the evolution of these images, which do not so much change, as change meanings, so that water, associated with death in "Le Tombeau des rois," is combined with a life-giving image in "Je suis la terre et l'eau." Page also shows the efficacy of the Jungian approach to the imagery in these poems and presents the dialogue between the conscious and the unconscious as one of the fundamental aspects of Hebert's works.

C73        Lacote, Rene. "Le Sentiment de frustration dans la poesie d'Anne Hebert." Europe [Paris], Nos. 478-79 (fev.-mars 1969), pp. 139-48. This is an extract, with some slight changes in the number of quotations, from Lacote's study, "Anne Hebert: une etude" (C68), pages 48-63. Lacote gives an analysis of Le Tombeau des rois and of"Le Torrent" as expressions of a collective alienation.

C74       Houde, Gilles. "Les Symboles et la structure mythique du Torrent." Pts.II-III. La Barre du jour, [No. 21] (sept.-oct. 1969), pp. 26-68. A continuation of C66.

C75        Frye, Northrop. Foreword. In Dialogue sur la traduction: a propos du "Tombeau des rois." By Anne Hebert and Frank Scott. Introd. Jeanne Lapointe. Collection sur parole. Montreal: HMH, 1970, pp.11-14. Rpt. trans. Jean Simard (Preface) in Dialogue sur la traduction: a propos du "Tombeau des rois." By Anne Hebert and Frank Scott. Introd. Jeanne Lapointe. Collection sur parole. Montreal: HMH, 1970, pp. 17-21. Frye comments on the difference between what Gerard Manley Hopkins calls "a poet's 'overthought,' or explicit meaning, and his 'underthought' or the meaning given by the progression of images and metaphors .... Mr. Scott went directly to the real meaning, the imagistic and metaphorical meaning, of what he was translating: this caused Mlle Hebert to think long and deeply about the real meaning of her poems, and so the whole conversation is carried on within the proper context of meaning ....without the stimulus of the other language, Mlle Hebert would never have discovered so much about her own meaning. Translation here becomes a creative achievement in communication, not merely a necessary evil or a removal of barriers."

C76        Godin, Jean Clio. "Rebirth in the Word." Trans. Rosemary Brown. Yale French Studies, No.45 (1970), pp. 137-53. Hebert's work marks the most important stage in the development of Quebec literature which leads to the rebirth of the 1960s. Godin traces the development of Hebert's work over Les Songes en equilibre, Le Torrent, Les Chambres de bois, Mystere de la parole, as well as the essay "Quand il est question de nommer la vie" (B153). In Mystere de la parole, "... there is complete agreement here between the personal inspiration of the poet, her concept of poetry, and the expression of a collective identity at a privileged moment in its history." Her work has been both the expression, then, of a collective truth, and an instrument in creating this collective identity: "... poetic speech, in the work of Anne Hebert, serves to clarify the thought of her countrymen, but by awakening it and provoking it; this is why her words are 'creative.' "

C77      Jones, D.G. Introduction. In his Butterfly on Rock: A Study of Themes and Images in Canadian Literature. Toronto: Univ. of Toronto Press, 1970, pp.9-10, 11. Rpt. (excerpt) in Modern Commonwealth Literature: A Library of Literary Criticism. Ed. John H. Ferres and Martin Tucker. New York: Frederick Ungar, 1977, pp. 285-86. In the course of a brief resume of the major themes of French-Canadian poetry, Jones mentions that Anne Hebert initially shares "the sterility of an overly ascetic order resulting from a complete withdrawal from life," as can be seen in her "Vie de chateau," where the rooms "are empty except for the mirrors from which spectres of the past emerge to embrace her in a barren shiver imitating love." Hebert's recent work "rejects this mentality," moving out to embrace the world. "Anne Hebert states that her country has arrived at a point in time analogous to the first days of the creation: 'Notre pays est a l'age des premiersjours du monde.'"

C78      Mailhot, Laurent. "Anne Hebert ou le temps depayse" In Le Theatre quebecois. By Jean Clio Godin and Laurent Mailhot. Montreal: HMH, 1970, pp. 123-50. Mailhot studies the published plays, with the emphasis on Le Merciere assassinee and Le Temps sauvage. Le Merciere assassinee is not only a murder mystery, but a comedy of manners, a psychological drama, and a study of decadence. The murder of Adelaide serves to expose the psychological drama of the humiliation of the innocent and introduce the theme of human evil; it also provides the framework for the humorous encounter of two cultures, those of Quebec and France; and it serves to outline the destruction of the artistocracy as seen in the family De Beau Bassin. These levels all successfully operate at once within the play. In discussing Le Temps sauvage, Mailhot emphasizes both the poetic complexity of the characters and the dramatic quality of the play. This is the most complex and the most demanding of Hebert's plays and presents the conflict between two generations and two ways of life through the creation of multi-faceted characters. The dramatic action is expressed as well by stage movements, costumes, and silences, as it is by the dialogue which uses a highly poetic language. Mailhot links the play with "cet 'age des premiers jours du monde,' ces 'paysages d'avant l'homme,'" and the "visages obscurs, coeurs silencieux" which await the rebirth into the world. This liberation is celebrated more fully in Mystere de la parole.

C79      Woodcock, George. Canada and the Canadians. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1970, pp. 258-59. Woodcock briefly alludes to the "generation of the thirties and forties which moved the literature of Quebec forward out of a colonial dependence on French trends and influences into the maturity of independence. In poetry, the initiator of the new movement was Saint-Denys Garneau. ..." Anne Hebert, among others, continued this development of poetry, and figures among "the elders of the renaissance in French-Canadian writing. Anne Hebert's Le Tombeau des rois is possibly the best volume of poems ever published in Canada, French or English."

C80      Morgan, Jean-Louis."Introduction to the Poetry of French Canada." Anthology. CBC Radio, 23 May 1970. On the occasion of the publication of The Poetry of French Canada in Translation, by John Glassco, Morgan gives a survey of FrenchCanadian poetry. He says, "... nature, the self, and death pervade the stanzas of Anne Hebert ..." Her poetry gives one the same uneasy feeling that one sometimes gets from the paintings of Salvador Dali. "The Planting of Hands" is read (B184).

C81      Dudek, Louis. "The Mirror of Art: Relations between French and English Literature in Canada." Culture, 31 (Sept. 1970), 229. Rpt. in Selected Essays and Criticism. By Louis Dudek. Ottawa: Tecumseh, 1978, p. 294. Dudek notes that "... it's usual to center the shift in modern French Canadian writing on the poetry of Saint-Denys Garneau and Anne Hebert. But... the main seismological disturbance in French occurs in the mid-1950's (not in 1937) .... The major poets before 1955... SaintDenys Garneau, Anne Hebert, and Rina Lasnier, correspond to our A.J.M. Smith, and Leo Kennedy, and in a less obvious sense F.R. Scott, the Anglican and aesthetically-oriented moderns in English Canadian poetry."

C82      Bodart, Marie-Therese. "Anne Hebert, canadienne-francaise" Syntheses, Nos.292-93 (oct.-nov. 1970), pp. 121-25. Bodart briefly discusses Rene Lacote's study French people feel to this "exotic" French-language writing. A brief description of the cultural history of Quebec is given, tracing the theme of alienation back to the English conquest of Quebec in 1759, and showing the presence of this theme in Quebec literature since its beginnings. The major themes of Hebert's works are mentioned as an introduction to a discussion of Kamouraska. This novel is judged less than successful technically, since the use of ellipsis is too sustained in the work. There is a tension in the novel between the heroine's hatred for the English language of the prosecution during her trial and her attraction to her lover who is English-Canadian. This tension is presented as representative of the fundamental Quebecois love-hate relationship with the English Canadians.

C83      May, Cedric R.P. "Hebert, Anne (1916- )." In Britain and the Commonwealth. Vol.I of The Penguin Companion to Literature. Ed. David Daiches. Harmondsworth, Eng.: Penguin, 1971, p. 243. May comments on "the sense of dispossession and of spiritual solitude, threatened by silence," in Hebert's poetry. Hebert "has been acclaimed in France ... and this interest has been sustained .... Her novel is a poetic transcription, in three phases, of the experience also described in her poetry .... "

C84        Merler, Grazia. "La Realite dans la prose d'Anne Hebert." Ecrits du Canada francais, 33 (1971), 45-83. Merler's study of Kamouraska begins by objecting to the critical labelling of Hebert as French-Canadian, since this suggests that the aesthetic qualities are not important or non-existant. Her study concentrates on the use of interior monologues and on the quality of the prose which she defends as realistic rather than poetic.

C85        Reference Division, McPherson Library, Univ. of Victoria, B.C., comp. "Hebert, Anne* 1916- ." In their Creative Canada: A Biographical Dictionary of Twentieth Century Creative and Performing Artists. Vol.I. Toronto: Univ. of Toronto Press, 1971, 148. This is a short bio-bibliographical entry listing facts under the headings "Education," "Religion," "Home," "Career," "Member," "Awards," "Honours," "Writings," and "Contributed."

C86      Sutherland, Ronald. Second Image: Comparative Studies in Quebec/ Canadian Literature. Toronto: new, 1971, p. 69. Sutherland mentions the attraction of "the Puritan ethos" and lists Hebert among six examples of women writers who in general "seem drawn to this mental condition."

C87        Le Grand, Albert. "Kamouraska ou l'Ange et la Bete." Etudes francaises [Univ. de Montreal], 7 (fev. 1971), 119-43. Le Grand places Kamouraska in the context of the "oeuvre." Violent crime is the pretext for a psychological reconstruction of the event, which is slowly dredged up from the silt of repressed memory, as can be seen in "Le Torrent" and La Merciere assassinee, as well as in Kamouraska. The crime becomes the object of an inner analysis, which is a confrontation with the authentic self, an exposure of hypocrisy and tyrannical repressions. It is a technique of discovery "qui decouvre au crime officiel sa doublure de tenebres, son envers secret qui, tout a la fois seduit et affole la conscience." The narrative technique is that of the text within the text, the crime within the crime, or "composition en abime." The staircase is seen as symbolic of the structure of the novel: "... l'escalier apparait comme la verticalite figee d'une spirale faite de ces fuites et approches qui animent, circulairement et sur l'horizontale, les grands rythmes excentriques et concentriques de l'oeuvre." The narrative is never to be taken merely at its surface meaning: "... l'ecriture de Kamouraska n'est jamais innocente. Elle avance derriere un masque. Cette duplicite de l'ecriture habite tous lesjeux du songe, de la memoire et du sommeil. Toute cette action clandestine de l'oeuvre tend a provoquer la metamorphose des personnages. Les amener a se voir." Le Grand evokes the feminine world in which Elisabeth grew up as one in which the supreme duty was to suppress the evil of the flesh. But Elisabeth has been marked from birth by desire, and it is the conflict between these two parallel lives that is her central tragedy. Desire is associated with the earth and mud and, in the character of Antoine, with violence, which leads inevitably to the violence of his own murder. As the characters are attracted to desire they are "animalism" and their masks of respectibility are torn away. Le Grand suggests that Elisabeth has never really loved Nelson, but merely used him to rid herself of Antoine, and that her final mask is her basic hatred of men and her preference for women ("On peut se demander si tant de violence n'est pas l'effet du peu de plaisir que procure tant de desir? ... Ne serait-elle pas justement victime d'une 'fraternelle complicite'?"). He suggests that the frequently repeated words of Aurelie, "Vos amours me font mourir," are to be interpreted literally. When Elisabeth finds herself bereft of all possibilities of passion after the disappearance of her three lovers, she can only demand to be considered neither "Ange" nor "Bete," but simply human.

C88      Bordaz, Robert. "Anne Hebert et le roman canadien." La Revue des deux mondes, juin 1971, pp. 617-22. Bordaz introduces his discussion of Kamouraska with some general comments on the renaissance of writing in Quebec in the last fifteen years, and on the wealth of writers whom one could present as representative of this phenomenal rebirth. Hebert is chosen as perhaps most representative for she participated in the earliest part of the literary explosion and has just had great success with her last novel. The novel is poetic "grace a l'admirable noblesse de coeur et de langage de l'auteur." The technique is marked by the use of interior monologue ("qu'inventa Dujardin et qu'illustra ensuite James Joyce"). The style of the novel is concrete and precise, avoiding all lyrical effusions in its cruelly exact expression of passion.

C89        Sylvestre, Roger. "Du sang sur des mains blanches." Critere, No. 4 (juin 1971), pp. 46-61. The study begins with a description of the alienation from life which is frequently the result of a socially correct education, making reference to Hebert's poetry which presents characters who are aware that "... la vraie vie est absente," but who, nonetheless, are filled with the desire to live. This theme is also traced briefly through all the prose works preceding Kamouraska, culminating in the statement that the "rage de vivre" is the one dominant transcending theme in her work. The retelling of the events of Kamouraska becomes, then, a logical continuation of this theme. Everything is presented on three simultaneous planes: the perspective of history, the perspective of the trial, and the perspective of the conscience of Mme Jerome Rolland who is waiting for her husband to die. It is the insistence of the trial scenes which forces Elisabeth to reconsider her past, to restructure her conscience. It is this "rage de vivre" which makes the reader feel that despite all the evidence, such as blood on her white hands, Elisabeth is not to be blamed.

C90        Dorais, Fernand. "'Kamouraska' d'Anne Hebert (essai de critique hermeneutique)." Laurentian University Review/Revue de l'Universite Laurentienne, 4, No. 1 (nov./Nov. 1971), 76-82. Dorais's hermeneutic analysis is based on Maurice Blanchot's L'Entretien infini. "I1 s'agit par retour dirige sur un texte d'en expliciter les conditions d'existence. De l'oeuvre etudiee ce sont ses postulats de possibilite et d'intelligibilite qui sont degages et fondus." Dorais proposes that the novel is a tautological labyrinth which demonstrates the essence of human tragedy: "Exilee de l'Amour, elle est entree dans le regime de la Legalite, ou de la Justice, qui se fair absence d'amour. D'ou la structure tautologique de ce roman: labyrinthe ou l'on tourne en rond pour revenir a une inutile apparence (derniere phrase du roman ...)." Dorais later states, "Conscience et langage ici se recouvrent ... tous deux tissent le subtile reseau ... pour seulement revenir au point de depart. Mouvement inutile; mouvement de pure immobilitY, l'agonie, l'appel en chambre ardente d'attente de ce roman. Rien ne dit rien; rien ne resout ni n'absout rien. Et la conscience est le voyage vers, autour de Kamouraska: de l'Amour qui n'est pas lh, qui n'estjamais la."

C91      Mitcham, Allison. "The Violence of Isolation: A Theme in Canadian Literature." Laurentian University Review/Revue de l'Universite Laurentienne, 4, No.1 (nov./Nov. 1971), 15, 17-18, 22. Rpt. ("The Violence of Isolation") in The Northern Imagination: A Study of Northern Canadian Literature. By Allison Mitcham. Moonbeam, Ont.: Penumbra, 1983, pp. 54, 56, 57. Mitcham compares the theme of isolation, both physical and social, in the works of six Canadian authors, to show that the frustration caused by this isolation leads to violence. "Le Torrent" is compared briefly to La Belle Bete by Marie-Claire Blais, and the violence done by a mother on a child is noted.

C92      Atwood, Margaret. Survival: A Thematic Guide to Canadian Literature. Toronto: House of Anansi, 1972, pp. 189, 205, 224, 230. Atwood makes passing reference to the "claustrophobia" of Hebert's "airtight poems," and to the sterile old lady of "The House on the Esplanade." She comments briefly that "In 'The Closed Room,' Anne Hebert has a vision of herself martyred, with heart removed." "There Is Certainly Someone" exemplifies an obsession with death which is "an image of ultimate sterility and powerlessness,the final result of being a victim."

C93        Brazeau, J. Raymond. "Anne Hebert." In his An Outline of Contemporary French Canadian Literature. Toronto: Forum House, 1972, pp. 59-74. Brazeau points out the continuity in the themes of alienation and rebirth in "Le Torrent," Le Tombeau des rois, and Les Chambres de bois. In an initial attempt to be open to the outside world, the characters in Hebert's work suffer rejection and frustration, leading to a rejection of the outside world, and a sense of alienation. The attempt to retreat to the purity and innocence of childhood leads only to further frustration, and, eventually, revolt against the perverse attraction of death. The resolution in "Le Torrent" is death, however, as opposed to the liberation suggested in Le Tombeau des rois and in Les Chambres de bois. Brazeau comments on the links between the three literary forms (poetry, short story, novel) which are found "... on the levels of themes, structure and symbolism."

C94      Leblond, Sylvio. "Le Drame de Kamouraska d'apres les documents de l'epoque." Les Cahiers des dix, No. 37 (1972), 239-73. Leblond recounts the historical basis for the novel. Each character is presented in detail: Achille Tache (Antoine Tassy), Josephine d'Estimauville (Elisabeth d'Aulnieres), Georges Holmes (George Nelson). A chronological account of the events leading up to the murder, the inquest, the trial, and the extradition proceedings is also given.

C95        Lemaitre, Henri, Francoise Bagne, and Marie Ce1ine Serres. "Poesie francophone a tous les horizons du monde: Du cote du Quebec." In La Litterature d'aujourd'hui. Vol.V of La Litterature francaise. Ed. Andre Lagarde and Laurent Michard. Paris: Bordas-Laffont, 1972, p. 90. The authors mention "les recherches formelles et techniques caracteristiques du besoin d'identite litteraire" and suggest that "... i'influence de la poesie francaise moderne se combine ici avec celle de la poesie americaine pour produire un langage a la lois neuf et savoureux ..." Part of "La Chambre de bois" is quoted.

C96      New, W.H. Articulating West: Essays on Purpose and Form in Modern Canadian Literature. [Three Solitudes: Contemporary Literary Criticism in Canada, No.1.] Toronto: new, 1972, p.xvi. The "divided landscape is within, as much as without" and provides Hebert's labyrinthine setting in "Le Tombeau des rois."

C97        Therio, Adrien. "La Maison de la belle et du prince ou l'enfer dans l'oeuvre romanesque d'Anne Hebert." Livres et auteurs quebecois 1971. Gen. ed. Adrien Therio. Montreal: Jumonville, {1972], pp. 274-84. The image of the house is the central one in Hebert's work. The house is either castle-like, or a pitiable hut, but is almost always isolated. Associated with these dwellings are female characters who dream, like princesses, of charming princes and of the castles they will live in, or male characters who are like princes seeking the sleeping beauty. Hebert's fictional world is one of "un monde de contes de fees avorte et c'est de cet avortement que nait la plupart du temps le drame." This theory is applied to "Le Torrent" where Claudine is an aged princess still seeking her ideal of purity; Francois in turn seeks his sleeping beauty in Arnica. The other "contes" are also used as examples of the application of this theory, as well as the novels and the plays. Kamouraska is presented as perhaps the best example of the fairy tale structure, with its battle between two knights for the beautiful lady. The only work to escape this structure of the princess who dreams of the prince, then finds castle life boring and retreats to a silent life in an isolated dwelling, is Les Chambres de bois. Therio questions Albert Le Grand's belief that the work of Hebert has expressed a collective identity (C59): "... je ne vois rien dans l'oeuvre romanesque d'Anne Hebert qui puisse me faire croire que le pays qu'elle explore ressemble d'une facon ou d'une autre au Canada francais que nous avons connu ou que nous connaissons encore."

C98      Dufresne, Francoise M. "Le Drame de Kamouraska." Quebec-Histoire, 1, Nos.5-6 (mai-juin-juil. 1972), 72-77. Dufresne points out the historical sources for Kamouraska and traces Hebert's family connection with the incident. She quotes from Le Canadien of 20 fevrier 1839, from Abbe Couillard-Despres's Histoire de Sorel, as well as from Georges-Isidore Barthe's novel Drames de la vie reelle. Dufresne notes that the name Dr. Nelson reflects on the Patriote leader and suggests that both fled in cowardly fashion from justice in Canada.

C99      Adam, Jean-Michel. "Sur cinq vers de Mystere de la parole: lire aujourd'hui 'Neige' d'Anne Halbert." Etudes litteraires [Univ. de Laval], 5 (dec. 1972), 463-80. Rpt. in Linguistique et discours litteraire. By Jean-Michel Adam. Paris: Larousse, 1976, pp. 226-38. Adam's Structuralist study of the poem is based on the theories of S.R. Levin, Roman Jakobson, Jean-Pierre Richard, and Michael Riffaterre. The analysis is semantic and syntactical and arrives, finally, at an analysis of the "signifiant producteur." Adam treats each verse as a "matrice textuelle" in which the second verse is "produit" by the first, and in its turn produces the following verse. "De meme que le premier vers apparaissait comme une matrice textuelle, on peut dire du dernier qu'il est totalement le produit des precedents." Adam concludes "I1 est dans 'Neige,' et en depit des apparences, moins question du monde (espace referentie], denotatif, quebecois) que de l'ecriture (espace connotatif de la page). Si les mots ne cessent de denoter, il s'agit d'un monde off les choses sont avant tout des mots.
