Le texte reorganise l'univers (du monde comme de la langue) en fonction d'une autre logique: celle de l'ecriture, bien proche, comme l'a montre Freud, de celle du reve."

C100      Giguere, Richard. "D'un 'equilibre imponderable' a une 'violence e1ementaire': Evolution thematique de la poesie quebecoise 1935-65: Saint-Denys Garneau, Anne Hebert, Roland Giguere et Paul Chamberland." Voix et images dupays, 7 (1973), 51-90. This is an extract, with slight changes, from Giguere's M.A. thesis (C286).

C101      Jones, D.G. "Myth, Frye and Canadian Writers." Canadian Literature, No.55 (Winter 1973), pp.14-16. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Carolyn Riley. Vol. IV. Detroit: Gale, 1975, 219-20. Moving from the personal to the regional, Hebert examines "a cultural paralysis, a collective vision bequeathed by the past." Her poetry and prose reject the "rapacious kings" of the past and go "on to articulate a new [vision] .... Anne Hebert managed to effect an imaginative revolution without cutting herself off entirely from her cultural heritage. She re-interpreted the Christian tradition of her province .... The poet is not, she protests, the rival of God; but a witness to His grace .... Certainly it is difficult in Miss Hebert's view not to see him as the rival of the priest."

C102      Lennox, John Watt. "The Past: Themes and Symbols of Confrontation in The Double Hook and 'Le Torrent.'" Journal of Canadian Fiction, 2, No.1 (Winter 1973), 70-72. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Dedria Bryfonski and Laurie Lanzen Harris. Vol. XIII Detroit: Gale, 1980, 266-67. Lennox briefly compares Sheila Watson's novel and Anne Hebert's novella as examples of the universal theme of reconciliation between the self and the community. Both deal with liberation on a personal and communal level, but Watson's work is optimistic in its resolution, while "Le Torrent" is pessimistic. In both works a son rebels against his mother in an isolated setting. The religious imagery in Watson's novel is positive, whereas religion is negative in "Le Torrent."

C103      Marmier, Jean. "Du Trombeau des rois' 'Kamouraska': vouloir vivre et instinct demort chez Anne Hebert." In Mission et demarches de la critique: melanges Jacques Vier. Ed. Edouard Guitton. Paris: Klincksieck, 1973, pp. 807-14. Marmier traces the existence of an epic struggle between the forces of life and death in Hebert's work. The struggle is the source of the tragic sense in her writing. This struggle is evident at the level of the action in the prose pieces, in the construction of the poems, and in her symbolic themes. In Le Tombeau des rois the dead are "assassin,s" but the victory over death is not final. The attraction of death is again obvious in Le Torrent and Les Chambres de bois, as well as in the plays. But it is in Kamouraska that the interweaving of both the "vouloirvivre" and the "instinct de mort" is done most effectively. It reaffirms the "vision fondamentale du monde qui associe le sens tragique a la vitalite acharnee."

C104      The Sense and Sensibility Collective, comp. "Hebert, Anne." In Women and Literature: An Annotated Bibliography of Women Writers. 2nd rev. and enl. ed. Cambridge, Mass.: Sense & Sensibility, 1973, p. 149. Bibliographical data.

C105      S[tory]., N[orah]., and J[oyce]. M[arshall]. "Anne Hebert." In Supplement to The Oxford Companion to Canadian History and Literature. Ed. William Toye. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1973, p. 127. Story and Marshall briefly describe Hebert's career and works.

C106      Tomli[n]son, Muriel D. "A Comparison of Les Enfants terribles and Les Chambres de bois." Revue de l'Universite d'Ottawa, 43 (1973), 532-39. Tomlinson compares two "romans lyriques" or "romans poemes" which use a discontinuity of language to suggest the subjective states of the characters, and symbolic language to express profound meanings. Despite similarities in form and fictional worlds, the novels are at opposite poles: in Jean Cocteau's Les Enfants terribles the childhood world is maintained eternally by the suicide of the characters who keep their childish innocence. In Hebert's Les Chambres de bois the characters seek to regain a lost childish innocence, and suicide is rejected as a means to this end.

C107      Tougas, Gerard. Les Ecrivains d'expression francaise et la France. Paris: Denoel, 1973, pp. 192, 194,214. French interest in Quebec literature was renewed after De Gaulle's visit in 1967, and this interest is dominated by preconceived ideas of Quebec. "I1 devait appartenir a Pierre Emmanuel [en 1969] de designer 'la poetesse canadienne francaise la plus achevee, la plus accomplie de notre temps.' En proposant Anne Hebert, Pierre Emmanuel a quelque peu surpris les pontes canadiens. A Montreal, on eut situe Anne Hebert parmi les meilleurs pontes de l'heure, mais au dixieme rang parmi eux ... Mais la n'est pas la question. Pour informer le monde francophone de la poesie canadienne, la voix respectee de Pierre Emmanuel pese plus lourd que celle des pontes canadiens reunis ... les ecrivains canadiens ... ont du assister, impuissants, a l'imposition d'un nouvel ordre d'arrivee. Pour la poesie Anne Hebert; pour le roman Rejean Ducharme .... "

C108      Waterston, Elizabeth. Survey: A Short History of Canadian Literature. Methuen Canadian Literature Series. Toronto: Methuen, 1973, p. 43. "The French-Canadian writer best known to English writers is Anne Hebert. Her work, translated by Frank Scott and others, shows intricate, introverted, often neurotic intensity" Waterston also refers to D.G. Jones's "Portrait of Anne Hebert" (C353), which "speaks of her deft probing of ... a sense of guilt and repression" and demonstrates "the image of an old lace-making lady."

C109      Lemieux, Pierre-Herve. "La Symbolique du Torrent' d'Anne Hebert." Revue de l'Universite d'Ottawa, 43 (jan.-mars 1973), 114-27. Lemieux discusses the form of "Le Torrent," which is above all a poetic creation of the narrator, Francois, in the sense in which this act is described in "Poesie, solitude rompue." The major part of this study is devoted to establishing the nuances and meanings associated with the symbol of the "torrent," which becomes an interior possession and possessor as well as an exterior fact. "La complexite de la metaphore du torrent baigne le recit dans un clair-obscur poetique impossible a elucider entierement, et c'est bien ainsi."

C110       de Bellefeuille, Normand. "Tel qu'en lui-meme." La Barre du jour, Nos.39-40-41 (printemps-ete 1973), pp. 104-23. De Bellefeuille proposes that the phonemic structure of a poem is an aspect that is too often ignored. "Les sons ne doivent plus etre consideres comme les 'elements d'une harmonie exterieure' accompagnant le sens, mais comme un formant linguistique existant hors de tout lien avec l'image et ayant une fonction autonome de structurateur" In his analysis of "Il y a certainement quelqu'un," he establishes tables of frequencies of particular phonemes, to compare this with normal frequencies. The centre of the poem can be found by locating "dans le texte le segment reunissant le plus grand nombre de ces phonemes." De Bellefeuille finds a structure of oppositions at the phonemic level, which is also found in the syntactic and semantic organization of the poem.

C111      Haeck, Philippe. "Naissance de la po6sie moderne au Quebec." Etudes francaises [Univ. de Montreal], 9 (mai 1973), 95, 96, 97, 99, 101-04. Haeck analyzes one poem each from SaintDenys Garneau, Anne Hebert, Alain Grandbois, and Paul-Marie Lapointe, in a re-evaluation of the Modernity of these poets. Hebert's "Marine" is analyzed. Haeck disputes the commonly held belief that Saint-Denys Garneau, Hebert, and Grandbois were the founders of Modernity in Quebec poetry, opting instead for Lapointe's Le Vierge incendie as the first truly Modern work in Quebec.

C112      Macri, F.M. "Anne Hebert: Story and Poem." Canadian Literature, No.58 (Autumn 1973), pp. 9-18. Macri analyzes "Le Torrent" and its relationship to the poetry. "Le Torrent" is a "zenith point within the tradition to which it belongs" and it expresses the "archetypal conflict between the flesh and the spirit." The mother image in the story "represents land, duty, religion, country, culture, the past and the present." Macri demonstrates that Le Tombeau des rois "perfectly describes the poetic journey undertaken by the persona and the dark journey undertaken by Francois." The ending of "Le Torrent" is optimistic: "Francois' end allows him to experience the unknown, and therefore his new adventure could possibly be a new beginning."

C113      Urbas, Jeanette. "Reflet et reve1ation: la technique du miroir dans le roman canadienfrancais moderne." Revue de l'Universite d'Ottawa, 43 (oct.-dec. 1973), 580-84. Urbas demonstrates that the mirror is used frequently as a device by novelists to reveal changes in characters to both the characters and to the reader. Le Torrent and Kamouraska are discussed as examples.

C114      Colombo, John Robert. "Hebert, Anne." In his Colombo's Canadian Quotations. Edmonton: Hurtig, 1974, p. 255. Colombo cites passages from "The Two Hands," translated by F.R. Scott, and the essay "Quebec: The Proud Province."

C115      Moisan, Clement. "Le Phenomene de la poesie dans le Quebec contemporain (1945-1970)." Identite culturelle et francophonie dans les Ameriques, Univ. of Indiana, Bloomington, Indiana. 28-30 March 1974. Printed in Identite culturelle et francophonie dans les Ameriques. Ed. and preface Emile Snyder and Albert Valdman. Travaux du Centre international de recherche sur le bilinguisme/Publications of the International Center for Research on Bilingualism, No. A-11. Quebec: Les Presses de l'Univ. Laval, 1976, pp.215-17. Rpt. ("Poesie de la clandestinite") in Poesie des frontieres: etude comparee des poesies canadienne et quebecoise. By Clement Moisan. Collection constantes, No. 38. Montreal: Hurtubise HMH, 1979, pp. 39-42. Rpt. in Culture populaire et litteratures au Quebec. Ed. and preface Rene Bouchard. Stanford French and Italian Studies, No.19. Saratoga, Cal.: Anma Libri, 1980, pp. 127-29. Rpt. ("Poetry of Clandestinity") in A Poetry of Frontiers: Comparative Studies in Quebec/Canadian Literature. By Clement Moisan. Trans. George Lang and Linda Weber. Victoria: Porcepic, 1983, pp. 13-15. Anne Hebert is mentioned, along with SaintDenys Garneau, Alain Grandbois, and Rina Lasnier, as representative of "cette premiere prise de conscience individuelle et psychologique du monde et de l'univers." While Garneau's work refers back to his personal life, Hebert's work "commence deja a rejoindre un drame collectif ... Cette poesie de la solitude interieure devient celle de la parole, de la parole comme forme habitable." Moisan concludes that "... l'aspect positif du message d'Anne Hebert est cette presence au monde, faite d'acceuil cordial, de sympathie et de comprehension" See C174 for further material from Moisan's book.

C116      Godard, Barbara. "The Oral Tradition and Contemporary Fiction." The Learned Societies, APFUC, ACQL, and CCLA, Univ. of Toronto, Toronto, Ont. 30 May 1974. Printed in Essays on Canadian Writing, Nos. 7-8 (Fall 1977), pp. 48, 49. Godard briefly refers to the use of the Faustian plot in "Le Torrent" (which "pioneered the use of the Faustian plot" in Quebec), in Marie-Claire Blais's La Belle Bete, and in Kamouraska. "All three of these novels make use of the demonic past to explore the tragic fate of individuals compelled by a passion over which they have no control .... While Hebert is almost exclusively interested in exploring the fate of persons who have crossed boundaries into the state of madness, she does not categorize her characters as marginal, but rather shows that it is the exclusively religious society which labels these people damned."

C117      Cloutier, Cecile. "L'Influence de quelques pontes francais sur quelques pontes quebecois." Presence francophone [Univ. de Sherbrooke], No. 9 (automne 1974), pp. 45-46, 48. One of the pairs of poets discussed here is Pierre Emmanuel and Anne Hebert. There are similarities in their theoretical discussions of poetry, in their view of the genesis of poetry, and in their poetic sensibilities. Both have a sense of solitude out of which poetry becomes a means of communication. "Pour eux, la poesie est une expression totale et une de1ivrance en meme temps qu'une evasion."

C118      Blais, Jacques. "L'Univers magique d'Anne Hebert." In his De l'ordre et de l'aventure: la poesie au Quebec de 1934 a 1944. Quebec: Les Presses de l'Univ. Laval, 1975, pp. 253-68. In this study of the poems in Les Songes en equilibre, Blais points out many of the themes which will be developed more fully in Hebert's later work. This first volume of poetry is a serious examination of life and death, the real and the unreal, and a necessary prologue to Le Tombeau des rois. Blais also comments on the series of poems published in little magazines from 1942-45, which show important signs of maturity and significant changes in her poetry.

C119      Bucknall, Barbara J. "Hebert, Anne." Encyclopedia of World Literature in the 20th Century. Rev. ed. Vol. II. (1975). Bucknall presents a brief critical overview of Hebert's works. In the discussion of Hebert's poetry, Bucknall writes that "... her best work is Poemes .... She writes in free verse, using dense, closely packed images, achieving an almost surrealistic effect. Her main themes are sorrow and joy, love, solitude, and death." Of the stories and novels, Bucknall writes that "In 'Le torrent' ... she castigates the morbid sense of sin that is a product of the old traditions of Quebec." Elisabeth, in Kamouraska, "is a symbol of alienation, passionately desiring a fulfillment that cannot be achieved by a woman in 19th-c. Canada." Les Enfants du sabbat "was poorly received in Quebec, where it seemed out of touch with present-day preoccupations" Bucknall concludes, "Recent studies on H. focus on her poetry, and it is for her poetic qualities that she is chiefly respected."

C120      New, William H. Among Worlds:An Introduction to Modern Commonwealth and South African Fiction. Erin, Ont.: Porcepic, 1975, p. 111. New notes that "The Gothic world" in Hebert's novels, among others, exemplifies "an explicit moral tension."

C121      Giroux, Robert. "Lecture de 'La Fille maigre' d'Anne Hebert." Presence francophone, No.10 (printemps 1975), pp. 73-89. This Structuralist reading of "La Fille maigre" uses the theories of Michael Riffaterre, Roman Jakobson, and Nicolas Ruwet: "Decrire le texte (jeux des equivalences lexicales ou syntaxiques, jeux de symetries, etc.) et tenir compte de son fonctionnement et de son efficacite, du titre au point final, sur le ou les lecteurs, voila ce que devrait retenir une lecture attentive." Giroux's analysis is preceded by a long discussion of theoretical matters. The analysis of "La Fille maigre" in the last half of the article divides the poem into "sequences narratives" before a more detailed analysis of the relationships between the parts, supplemented by charts and diagrams, is given. Giroux proposes various "jeux de parallelisme ou isotopies du contenu" in his "lecture syntaxique et semantique .... Cette etude isotopique du contenu n'a ete possible qu'a partir d'un choix d'organisation paradigmatique suggere par l'iteration de categories semantiques qui nous ont rendu possible la lecture uniforme du texte. Nous aurions pu proceder differemment et nous ne signalons cela qu'a titre indicatif .... "

C122      Lemieux, Pierre-H. "La Mort des rois: commen-taire du poeme-titre: Le Tombeau des rois d'Anne Hebert." Revue de l'Universite d'Ottawa, 45 (avril-juin 1975), 133-61. Rpt. ("La Mort des rois du songe") in Entre songe et parole: structure du Tombeau des rois d'Anne Hebert. By Pierre-Herve Lemieux. Cahiers du centre de recherche en civilisation canadienne-francaise, 15. Ottawa: Editions de l'Univ, d'Ottawa, 1978, pp. 198-226. This study of "Le Tombeau des rois" discusses the movement to liberation found in the poem. The article is the concluding chapter of Lemieux's dissertation (C300). See also Lemieux's book (C7).

C123      Bouchard, Denis. "Erotisme et erotologie, aspects de l'oeuvre poetique et romanesque d'Anne Hebert." La Revue du Pacifique [California State Univ.], 1 (automne 1975), 152-67. Rpt. (revised -- "Erotisme et sublimination") in Une Lecture d'Anne Hebert: la recherche d'une mythologie. By Denis Bouchard. Montreal: HMH, 1977, pp. 133-48. Bouchard asserts that there are two poles of the "imaginaire" in Hebert's work, evident after the death of Saint-Denys Garneau: at one extreme there is an aggressive eroticism, at the other extreme an erotic sublimation or "repliement." "Le Torrent" begins the aggressive erotic stream in Hebert's work, which finds its culmination in Kamouraska. Les Enfants du sabbat provides a synthesis of the two opposing poles of aggression and sublimation. The works presenting sublimation are Le Tombeau des rois and Les Chambres de bois. Bouchard faults Kamouraska for its borrowings from classical French literature, citing Rimbaud, Sartre, Voltaire, Proust, Camus, Mallarme, and Bouchard objects as well to the caricatural view of Quebec ("Les emprunts aux grand auteurs francais ne manquent pas de gener..." and "... les concessions a la mode, a cette neige eternelle qui ressemble tant au Canada vu par les Francais..."). Bouchard frequently suggests an autobiographical basis for Hebert's work: he refers to his theory that Hebert was strongly influenced by Garneau and comments on the influence of the restrictive society on Hebert. He suggests a strong personal relationship between Hebert and Garneau, and notes that in her work "L'experience personnelle y est pour quelque chose .... " See C6 for other essays included in Bouchard's book.

C124      Renaud, Benoit. "Kamouraska: roman et poeme." Co-Incidences, 5, Nos.2-3 (mars-avril, oct.-nov. 1975), 26-45. Renaud analyzes the echoes of poetic imagery from earlier works which are found in the novel. The non-linear narration and the use of dreams are ideally given to the use of poetic images which surge up from the depths. The reader is more guided by the train of mental images and associations than by the traditional narrative guide posts found in the novel. Renaud compares the most central images common to both Kamouraska and Le Tombeau des rois. In addition to the use of such images as the heart, the novel also uses a style which owes much to the techniques of poetry: the use of sentences with no verbs, lack of punctuation, altered syntax, and the frequent use of juxtaposition. The text of the novel could even be typeset to look like poetry. Renaud also compares the style of the novel with other accounts of the events at Kamouraska by writers of the time, to show that it is by the creation of her style that Hebert does indeed give life to the work in an act which is, at the more general level of meaning, poetic.

C125      Lecker, Robert. "The Rooms of Kamouraska." Waves, 4, No. 1 (Autumn 1975), 14-21. In this review-essay on the translation of Kamouraska, Lecker discusses the control exercised over the narrative by Elisabeth, who plays out her various roles on the stage of her memory, and who remains entrapped.

C126      Weiss, J.M. "Images des Etats-Unis dans le roman quebecois moderne." American Review of Canadian Studies, 5, No.2 (Autumn 1975), 82, 83, 84, 86-87, 91-93, 94, 99-103. Weiss discusses the different approaches to the attraction and threat offered by the United States in three representative novels: Ringuet's Trente Arpents, Roger Lemelin's Les Plouffe, and Anne Hebert's Kamouraska. In Ringuet's novel, the United States offers escape for economic reasons; in Lemelin's novel, the United States seems to offer personal success in the sports world; and, in Hebert's novel, George Nelson, the American, is the symbol of gentle, cultured sexuality. The threat posed by the Americans is even greater, however, than the attraction: in Ringuet economic depression and cultural assimilation are found, in Lemelin the American sports world is seen as dangerous infantilism, and in Hebert Nelson brings adultery, disorder, and death along with eroticism. Weiss places these three novels in the wider context of Quebec literature to show that they are representative of common approaches to the image of the United States.

C127      Fabi, Therese. "Le Theme de la violence dans 'Le Torrent' d'Anne Hebert." L'Action nationale, 65, No.2 (oct. 1975), 160-68. Fabi describes the characters and the natural setting of the story as examples of violence which is caused by the aggression of the mother, which leads inevitably to violent revolt.

C128      Feral, Josette. "C1oture du moi, cloture du texte dans l'oeuvre d'Anne Hebert." Voix et images: etudes quebecoises, 1 (dec. 1975), 265-83. Rpt. in Litterature, No. 20 (Dec. 1975), pp. 102-17. Feral proposes a dialectic between captivity and liberation in the works of Hebert. The forces of captivity are usually stronger, and liberty is won slowly and painfully, if at all. Feral comments generally on this dialectic, but concentrates on Kamouraska to show that all the characters are prisoners of their environments, of others, and finally, of themselves. Elisabeth is, above all, prisoner of her social self. The characters can only remember past happiness and past acts which further entrap them: "captif de son univers interieur, replie sur lui-meme, seul, le heros se refugie dans le silence. Refus de la communication, mais aussi refus de la parole." Between Elisabeth and the world there intrudes the screen of her memory, so that she remains forever blocked from reality. Feral points out that the text of these works is also "closed" in the sense that the characters are always presented at the beginning of the work as having failed to attempt an escape which the work then proceeds to portray: "... ainsi l'histoire ne s'accomplit que par un retour au point initial." But the text of Kamouraska escapes from the negation of the narrative by presenting several conflicting points of view on the events, seen by the different personalities of Elisabeth, and from different points in time.

C129       Ouellette, Gabriel-Pierre. "Espace et delire dans Kamouraska d'Anne Hebert." Voix et images: etudes quebecoises, 1 (dec. 1975), 241-64. Ouellette examines the complex portrayal of time and space in Kamouraska. In the end, Elisabeth relives and re-senses events which she never did experience. It is by entering into this new space that she confronts her true identity, that she finds "la vraie vie" which goes beyond her normal life and space. But she is also propelled out of this delirious space at the end of the novel: "... nile songe, ni l'espace ne sont encore assez vastes pour contenir la peur de Mme Rolland qui doit demander de l'aide a un mourant: 'Si tu savais, Jerome, comme j'ai peur.'"

C130      Biblowitz, Iris, Liza Bingham, Frances M. Goodstein, Julia Homer, Jill Janows, Ann Kautzmann, Peggy Kornegger, Virginia Rankin MacLean, Jane Tuchscherer, and Judy Wynn, comp. "Hebert, Anne." In Women and Literature: An Annotated Bibliography. 3rd ed. Cambridge, Mass.: Women and Literature Collective, 1976, p. 149. Bibliographical data.

C131      Colombo, J.R. "Hebert, Anne (b.1916)." In his Colombo' s Canadian References.             Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1976, pp. 233. Brief bio-bibliographical data.

C132      Farley, T.E. Exiles and Pioneers: Two Visions of Canada's Future 1825-1975. Ottawa: Borealis, 1976, pp. 119, 125-26, 130, 132. Hebert is compared to Alain Grandbois. "She is not more existentially engagee than Grandbois, but her poems carry a stronger sense of relatedness to her fellow man, and at the same time impart the stubborn conviction that, although it does not always do so, love can conquer death. Whereas Grandbois seeks the altitudes of spiritual space, Anne Hebert probes the depths of human consciousness." The poem "Je suis la terre et l'eau" is cited in its entirely and "represents not only a spiritualization of sex, but a sexualization of spirit ...." Hebert's use of water imagery is commented on, as an example of her "commitment to life," which "implies both a rejection of death and an act of love."

C133       Fee, Margery, and Ruth Cawker. "Hebert, Anne 1916- ." In their Canadian Fiction: An Annotated Bibliography. Toronto: Peter Martin, 1976, p. 57. The entry provides a brief description of The Torrent ("Anne Hebert's famous 'closed universe' is evident in this collection of stories"); of The Silent Rooms (here, "Hebert wrote in prose much that she had put in her collection of poems, Le Tombeau des rois. The translation of this romanpoeme does not capture all the poetry of the original ..."); and of Kamouraska ("Based on an actual murder in 1840, the novel is told as a series of jumbled flashbacks, with emphasis on the heroine's moral and psychological make-up").

C134      Hamel, Reginald, John Hare, and Paul Wyczyn-ski. "Anne Hebert." Dictionnaire pratique des auteurs quebecois (1976). Hamel provides a brief, critical overview of Hebert's work, with bibliographical data on primary and secondary sources.

C135      Lemieux, Pierre-H. "Un theatre de la parole: Anne Hebert." In Le Theatre canadien-francais: evolution, temoignages, bibliographic. Vol. V of Archives des lettres canadiennes. Ed. Paul Wyczynski, Bernard Julien, and Helene Beauchamp-Rank. Montreal: Fides: 1976, 551-79. Lemieux applies his interpretation of the dichotomy of "songe" and "parole" to the plays of Hebert. All the plays discussed ("L'Arche de midi," Les Invites au proces, La Merciere assassinee, and Le Temps sauvage) are presented as having the same structure, which places the characters in a situation where they must decide between the attraction of the silent world of dreams or the attraction of the spoken word.

C136       Northey, Margot. "Psychological Gothic: Kamouraska." In her The Haunted Wilderness: The Gothic and Grotesque in Canadian Fiction. Toronto: Univ. of Toronto Press, 1976, pp. 53-62. Northey points out the traditional elements of Gothic romance which can be found in the novel. It is in the creation of a complex mental state for Elisabeth that the novel succeeds in creating a sense of psychological terror which transcends the commonplaces of Gothic romance.

C137      Rinfret, Edouard G. "Hebert, Anne." In his Repertoire analytique des origines a nos jours. Vol.II of Le Theatre canadien d'expression francaise. Montreal: Lemeac, 1976, pp. 191-94. Rinfret includes brief bibliographical entries for, and descriptions of, "L'Arche de midi," Les Invites au proces, La Merciere assassinee, and Le Temps sauvages.

C138      Stratford, Philip. "'Kamouraska' and 'The Diviners.'" Review of National Literatures, [Canada], 7 (1976), 110-26. Rpt. ("Territorial Prerogatives: Margaret Laurence and Anne Hebert") in All the Polarities: Comparative Studies in Contemporary Canadian Novels in French and English. By Philip Stratford. Toronto: ECW, 1986, pp. 45-55. Stratford has chosen these novels by Anne Hebert and Margaret Laurence as "almost random" samples of distinguished works from English and French Canada in order to compare them to begin a discussion of what keeps these two cultural groups separate from each other. He notes similarities of content, plot, and conception: both are biographical, both are factual, both are cumulative works in the context of their author's career, and "... both make a statement about the cultural heritage of the protagonist" The differences in the novels include the important one of narrative focus: Hebert uses elliptical language, a controlled confusion of time; Laurence uses a more discursive style to capture the commonplace in a discriminating and allinclusive point of view. Stratford sees this difference as one which points out the basic difference in the tradition of the novel in the two cultures. Laurence writes in a tradition which goes back to Henry Fielding, while Hebert writes in a tradition which goes back to Racine. "Where Laurence is comic, Hebert is tragic. Where Hebert's structure is dramatic, close-knit, almost preserving the unities of time, place and action, Laurence's is an itinerary sprawling in time and place and welcoming the diverting detour, its unity assured by the central character .... "

C139       Urbas, Jeanette. "Society as Repression." In her From Thirty Acres to Modern Times: The Story of French-Canadian Literature. Toronto: McGrawHill Ryerson, 1976, pp. 100-09. This survey of the short stories, Les Chambres de bois, and Kamouraska, is intended for use in high schools. Hebert's characters "are all alienated from themselves and from society. This applies equally to the scoundrels and betrayers and to their innocent victims." She comments further: "... the catalogue of suffering is long and the sum total is an indictment of a closed society, obsessed with sin and ridden with guilt, stratified into layers of doubtful respectability .... "

C140       Cohen, Henry. "Le Role du mythe dans Kamouraska d'Anne Hebert." Presense francophone, No.12 (printemps 1976), 103-11. Rpt. trans. Chitra Reddin ("The Role of Myth in Anne Hebert's Kamouraska") in Essays on Canadian Writing, No. 10 (Spring 1978), pp. 134-43. Cohen analyzes the use of French-Canadian stereotypical figures, of European, fairy-tale mythologies, and of Classical mythical figures in the novel. The "pays d'en haut" myth is destroyed here, as is the image of the saintly woman colonizer, such as one finds in Maria Chapdelaine. Going beyond the modern mythologies of French Canada, Hebert uses elements of the story of Beauty and the Beast in the fashion of a variant which shows a femme fatale bringing down the vengeance of an ignorant society on a hapless beast. The myth of Theseus and the labyrinth, as well as the myth of the descent of Orpheus, could also be applied to the novel. Thus, the novel destroys the FrenchCanadian mythology of evangelical colonization and places the characters in the wider context of European civilization by the use of parallels to Classical mythology.

C141      Bouchard, Denis. "Les Enfants du sabbat d'Anne Hebert: l'enveloppe des mythes." Voix et images: etudes quebecoises, 1 (avril 1976), 374-86. Rpt. Une lecture d'Anne Hebert: la recherche d'une mythologie. By Denis Bouchard. Montreal: HMH, 1977, pp. 177-91. Bouchard offers some judgements of Hebert's previous work and of the novel in question. He sees this as a turning point in her work: "... l'introduction du comique etait devenue essentielle. L'oeuvre prenait des allures insolites de froideur et d'insensibilite. Un autre bain de sang comme Kamouraska aurait risque de peser trop lourd." This novel is the "contestation du serieux, c'est-a-dire de son oeuvre anterieure. Nous lui en savons gre." See C6 for other essays included in Bouchard's book.

C142      Marchand, Pierre. "A propos de la traduction du 'Tombeau des rois.'" Meta, 21, No. 2 (juin 1976), 155-60. Marchand analyzes the dialogue between Anne Hebert and Frank Scott on the translation of "Le Tombeau des rois." The discussion concentrates on semantic elements to the detriment of phonetic effects, and this serves to emphasize the impossibility of translating poetry.

C143       Marmier, Jean. "Le Sabbat des enfants dans le roman quebecois contemporain." Etudes canadi. ennes/Canadian Studies [Univ. de Bordeaux III], No.2 (juin 1976), pp.25, 26, 27, 28, 30, 31, 32. Marmier makes a few brief allusions to Les Enfants du sabbat in the course of a rapid examination of children in the novels of Rejean Ducharme and Marie-Claire Blais. These audacious characters represent "une transposition dans l'imaginaire des refus et des decouvertes, de l'aspiration a une nouvelle forme de societe au Quebec."

C144      Francoeur, Louis. "Le Monologue interieur narratif: (sa syntaxe, sa semantique et sa pragmatique)." Etudes litteraires [Univ. de Laval], 9 (aout 1976), 341-65. Francoeur discusses the syntax, the semantics, and the pragmatics of the interior monologue in a passage drawn from Kamouraska, as well as some brief examples from two other Quebec novels, and James Joyce's Ulysses. His analysis is concerned with the semiotics of the interior monologue, not with the content of the message. As C.S. Pierce says in his Preface to his Logic and Mathematics, interior monologue is a "'dialogue between different phases of the ego.'" Kamouraska follows this pattern. The reader has to decipher the communication which passes between the two phases, the two "emetteurs' (E', E"). The act of communication between E' and E" implies that there is an exchange of new information between E' and E". "La mesure de l'information du message du monologue interieur sera celle-la meme de l'inattendu dans la combinatoire des differents elements (signes) effectuee par E' et, eventuellement, par E"." The information is not the content but the measure of unpredictability of the message. The reason for the existence of the interior monologue is that the soliloquy of the Ego "... s'oriente vers une decision, une action..." by means of this dialogue between its two phases. The monologue differs from the dialogue in its syntax, which is more unpredicable, abnormal, personal, than in usual speech. The fragments of speech which frequently may not seem to be addressed to anyone by E' are in fact messages to E". What would seem incoherent in the context of interpersonal speech becomes highly significant in the context of the interior monologue: these figures of speech (repetition, anaphora, irony, litotes, metaphor) "constituent une veritable rhetorique, c'est-a-dire une logique de construction du message, un procede de seduction mis en place par E' pour influencer E" de quelque maniere." The interior monologue is structured thus to give the appearance of reality, of a "... vision d'un univers interieur."

C145       Merler, Grazia. "Translation and the Creation of Cultural Myths in Canada." West Coast Review [Simon Fraser Univ.], 11, No.2 (Oct. 1976), 26-30, 33. Merler discusses the translation of The Silent Rooms by Kathy Mezei and of Saint-Denys Garneau's poetry by John Glassco. She gives details of the deficiencies, particularly of The Silent Rooms, which she sees as a caricature of the original novel, created in part in response to an out-dated English-Canadian stereotyped view of French Canada.

C146      Kunstmann, Pierre. "'Le Tombeau des rois' ou la progression regressive." Voix et images: etudes quebecoises, 2 (dec. 1976), 255-64. This Jungian analysis of "Le Tombeau des rois" points out the effective use of Egyptian mythology in this central piece of Hebert's work. "Les anciens parlaient de descente aux enfers, je dirai avec Jung qu'il s'agit d'une phase d'introspection de la libido."

C147      Amprimoz, Alexandre. "Four Writers and Today's Quebec." The Tamarack Review, No. 70 (Winter 1977), pp. 72-75. Amprimoz comments on the threat of fanaticism within religion, as exposed in Les Enfants du sabbat, and states that Julie rejects both worlds of magic and religion. The only evil is the denial of human nature, which Julie successfully resists.

C148      Cartano, Tony. "Anne Hebert." Dictionnaire de litterature francaise contemporaine (Paris, 1977). Cartano presents a short Bibliography and a critical appraisal: "Fantastique, poetique et romanesque, l'oeuvre d'Anne Hebert est un hymne a l'imagination et a ses pouvoirs liberateurs" Le Tombeau des rois, Kamouraska, and Les Enfants du sabbat are discussed.

C149      McClung, Molly G. Women in Canadian Literature. Women in Canadian Life. Toronto: Fitzhenry & Whiteside, 1977, pp. 48-50. In this brief bio-bibliographical sketch, McClung notes that "In both the novels and the poetry Anne Hebert has concentrated on the inner life of the individual, usually a woman, caged in by tradition or by other people. Her protagonists need emotional fulfilment."

C150      Moss, John. Sex and Violence in the Canadian Novel: The Ancestral Present. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1977, pp. 28-29. Anne Hebert, Roch Carrier, and Marie-Claire Blais are writers who fit the tradition of "a preponderance of contemporary Quebecois novels featuring death and the grotesque."

C151      Bouchard, Denis. "Anne Hebert et le Mystere de la parole: un essai d'anti-biographie." Le Revue du Pacifique [California State Univ.], 3 (printemps 1977), 67-81. Rpt. (revised -- "Anne Hebert, situation de l'ecrivain") in Une lecture d'Anne Hebert: la recherche d'une mythologie. By Denis Bouchard. Montreal: HMH, 1977, pp. 13-29. Bouchard discusses the connection between Hebert's work and her life. He suggests an elitism: "Un certain snobisme se degage des quelques declarations qu'elle a bien voulu livrer au public. Une Quebecoise ecrivain, issue de la bonne bourgeoisie, n'est pas entierement a son aise parmi les petites gens. Le conflit entre le silence et la parole, entre la solitude et la solitude rompue, est peut-etre a la source du besoin d'expression qui nie en quelque sorte l'austere tradition des classes privilegiees, volontairement coupee du peuple." Hebert's reticence about her personal life is, however, a source of richness for her writing: "Anne Hebert pousse tres loin son desir d'anonymat. Son oeuvre enest d'autant plus riche. Il y a desorientation puis reconstruction de notre monde .... Au lieu de figurer elle-meme dans son oeuvre, elle place au premier plan le Quebec. Son exil volontaire, qui dure depuis plus de vingt ans, fait penser aux ecrivains americains du debut du siecle." Bouchard compares Hebert to her character Elisabeth in Kamouraska, suggesting that Hebert also creates for herself a number of possible lives in her work: "L'effacement de l'ecrivain le place paradoxalement dans une situation de choix de 'la vraie vie... ,' ... ceile qui n'est pas prisonniere d'un seul visage puis qu'elle se manifeste dans toutes les vies que rejoint son oeuvre." See C6 for other essays included in Bouchard's book.

C152      Mezei, Kathy. "Anne Hebert: A Pattern Repeated" Canadian Literature, No. 72 (Spring 1977), pp. 29-40. The movement from near death to life seen in Les Chambres de bois is a pattern which can be found in all the works of Hebert from Les Songes en equlibre to Kamouraska. Mezei outlines the close relationship which exists between Le Tombeau des rois and Les Chambres de bois. Mystere de la parole and Kamouraska show a vigorous affirmation of life, an acceptance of self, and a delight in passion. She comments on the change in the language of the works as well, moving from the effusiveness of the first volumes, through the "depouille" period, to the mature sophistication in the wealth of imagery of the later works. This study proceeds to analyze some central images found in the works, but the emphasis is complete]yon those before Kamouraska.

C153      Bouchard, Denis. "Anne Hebert et 'la solitude rompue': tentative de demythification d'un des lieux communs de notre litterature." Etudes francaises, 13, Nos.l-2 (avril 1977), 163-79. Rpt. (revised -- "La Solitude rompue") in Une lecture d'Anne Hebert: la recherche d'une mythologie. By Denis Bouchard. Montreal: HMH, 1977, pp. 55-70. Bouchard characterizes the feelings of isolation and exclusion found in the work of SaintDenys Garneau as typical of a whole society and as the determining influence on Hebert's Les Songes en equilibre. He presents examples of"le soupir et non le rale" evident in this volume. Even though many of her later images appear here first ("la chambre, l'enfant, la mort, le miroir, la pluie"), her later poetry is radically different after the death of Garneau: "C'est le meme porte, dans deux univers entierement differents. L'un ne mene pas logiquement vers rautre quant au fond. La rupture sera si entiere que le premier recueil est comme un panorama eteint d'une vie anterieure, eelle de l'acceptation passive du 'mal du siecle' quebecois avant 1944." Bouchard compares the two final poems from Les Songes en equilibre and Le Tombeau des rois to demonstrate this difference. He comments that Hebert destroys the cliche of isolation in her later work: "D'un livre a l'autre, son oeuvre est impitoyablement tournee contre la solitude, qu'elle rend absolument insoutenable en l'analysant comme un travers vicie d'une psychologie collective." See C6 for other essays included in Bouchard's book.

C154      Russell, D.W. "Anne Hebert: Les Invites au proces." Canadian Literature, No. 74 (Autumn 1977), pp. 30-39. This thematic study of the play outlines the basic unity of the piece and discusses it from a Jungian perspective. The play is an imaginative placing on trial of Quebec society by means of the characters who act out an indictment of the Jansenism of their society.

C155      Boak, Denis. "Kamouraska, Kamouraska!". Essays in French Literature [Univ. of Western Australia], No. 14 (Nov. 1977), pp. 69-104. This discussion centres on the paradox of the modern form of a work whose content "belongs to the tradition of wild Romanticism." Boak discusses the style and characterizes it as a stream of consciousness similar to the nouveau roman, with its shifting narrative point of view; the narrative technique succeeds in making "the form of the novel reflect its content." Boak points out the elements of the novel which can be traced to the tradition of Gothic Romanticism and the German Marchen, in his treatment of the main themes and motifs of the novel. His analysis of the style is also detailed, showing the effectiveness of the self-conscious style which draws the reader's attention to the fictional nature of the work. Boak's comments on the historical accuracy of the novel should be examined in the light of the articles by Sylvio Leblond (C94) and Francoise Dufresne (C98).

C156      Blodgett, E.D. "Prisms and Arcs: Structures in Hebert and Munro." In Figures in a Ground: Canadian Essays on Modern Literature Collected in Honor of Sheila Watson. Ed. Diane Bessai and David Jackel. Saskatoon: Western Producer Prairie, 1978, pp.99-110, 112, 115, 118, 120, 121. Rpt. in Configuration: Essays in the Canadian Literatures. By E.D. Blodgett. Downsview, Ont.: ECW, 1982, pp. 53-66, 68, 70, 72, 73, 77, 79-84. Blodgett examines the use of the house as a rhetorical figure (in the sense which this term is used by Gerard Genette, Roman Jakobson, and Roland Barthes) in the work of Alice Munro and Anne Hebert. He uses the stories and the first two novels in his analysis of the "variety of ways in which character is shadowed forth through its figural relationship to the house." Hebert uses the house mainly as metonymy, while Munro uses the house as metaphor. Blodgett's discussion of Hebert includes the use of screens and mirrors in these works. He concludes: "Seen in relation to the house, characters tend to become microcosms (synecdochic types) that by a process of absorption exclude by paradoxically including all .... Furthermore, the house creates a kind of two-dimensionality (in a positive sense) that threatens extinction by the very fact of its proximity .... Houses do not signify the free existence of other characters and actions with which identity and analogy is made possible. They leave the protagonist either dead (self-absorbed) or in fragments .... "In contrast, houses in English-Canadian fiction tend to be used as a"socio-economic motif."

C157      Falzoni, Franca Marcato. "Dal reale al fantastico nell'opera narrativa di Anne Hebert." In Canadiana: Aspetti della storia e della letteratura canadese. Ed. Luca Codignola. Venice: Marsilio, 1978, pp. 97-109. The rebellion of Hebert's characters against moral and social hypocrisy is expressed in her early works by means of dreams and myths. In Les Enfants du sabbat the masquerade of dreams and myths is dropped, and the fantastic world of the novel expresses openly all the characters' secret passions and desires. The fantasy world is the means of upsetting the existing order, and the fantastic reality supplants the previous order.

C158      Harris, Michael. "Miche! Garneau in Conversation with Michael Harris." CV/II, 3, No.3 (Jan. 1978), 20. In this interview, Michel Garneau notes that "Anne Hebert is a Duplessis poet .... Nothing much happened [then] in poetry .... But then, poets are not free people .... We are caught up in shapes and forms and we're, by essence, traditionalists?"

C159      Mezei, Kathy. "The Literature of Quebec in Revolution." In The Human Elements: Critical Essays. Ed. David Helwig. Ottawa: Oberon, 1978, pp. 33, 34, 36, 42, 45, 48-49, 50. The work of Anne Hebert is mentioned several times in the course of a discussion of the relationship between political and artistic developments in the period from 1960 to 1977 in Quebec. "Le Tombeau des rois" is evoked as an allegorical expression of the idea that "... it is time to escape from the tombs .... " Both Kamouraska ("an affirmation of passion and love over death and duty") and Les Enfants du sabbat (a "macabre and exotic treatment of the Catholic heritage") are briefly placed in the context of the other works of the 1970s. The article ends by asking what will be the effect of the Parti Quebecois victory in 1976 on "... apolitical writers like Anne Hebert."

C160      Naaman, Antoine, and Leo A. Brodeur. Repertoire des theses litteraires canadiennes de 1921 & 1976. Sherbrooke: Naaman, 1978, pp. 99, 163, 171-72, 192, 224, 251. Bibliographical data.

C161      Owen, Iron, and Morris Wolfe. Introduction. In The Best Modern Canadian Stories. Ed. Ivon Owen and Morris Wolfe. Edmonton: Hurtig, 1978, p. 10. Augustin, from "A Grand Marriage," admires those who can do business as well as the English. Delia, the Metis character, is the only one who keeps her integrity, but her "inability to be a hypocrite destroys her."

C162      Rinfret, Edouard G. "Hebert, Anne: Merciere assassinee (La)." In his Television (1962-1973). Vol.IV of Le Theatre canadien d'expression francaise. Montreal Lemeac, 1978, pp. 135-36. This bibliographical entry includes a brief description of the play.

C163      Sutherland, Ronald. "The Two Cultures in the Canadian Novel." The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel, Univ. of Calgary, Calgary, Alta. 16 Feb. 1978. Printed in Taking Stock: The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel. Ed. Charles R. Steele. Downsview, Ont.: ECW, 1982, pp. 46, 54. Hebert's Kamouraska is noted among books in the "second category" -- the "'Image of the French-Canadian in English-Canadian Novels and Vice-Versa.'" Hebert's Doctor Nelson is a "fully developed, intriguing" character.

C164      Ross, Malcolm. "The Ballot." The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel, Univ. of Calgary, Calgary, Alta. 18 Feb. 1978. Printed in Taking Stock: The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel. Ed. Charles R. Steele. Downsview, Ont.: ECW, 1982, p. 151. Hebert's Kamouraska was picked among "the most 'important' one hundred works of fiction."

C165      Marta, Janet. "Dechiffrage du code biblique dans les Poemes d'Anne Hebert." Presence francophone, No. 16 (printemps 1978), 123-30. Marta studies the "presence explicite ou implicite de saints, de martyrs et du Christ dans Poemes." The two parts of the volume function in the same relationship as the Old and New Testament: "... nous esperons avoir demontre le role central que jouent les deux testaments de la Bible dans les systemes semantiques et morphologiques du recueil."

C166      Lennox, John W. "Dark Journeys: Kamouraska and Deliverance." Essays on Canadian Writing, No. 12 (Fall 1978), pp. 84-104. Lennox discusses the Gothic elements in both novels, showing the similarities that exist between the literatures of French Canada and the American South. Both novels studied are "full of darkness, revenge, blood" and are "absorbing examples of the self-renewing persistence of a particular kind of writing which seems congenial to much of the creative mentality of French Canada and the American South." Hebert has used the traditional elements of Gothic romance, to which she has added FrenchCanadian folklore to give to the novel "an authentic, archetypal power. It is this blending of general patterns with evocations of particular motifs that makes a skillful new novel out of an old theme."

C167      Marcotte, Gilles. "Les Cinq 'prix du Quebec' 1978. Prix David: Anne Hebert." Le Devoir [Montreal], 7 oct. 1978, pp. 19-20. Marcotte briefly overviews Hebert's works on the occasion of the Prix David for her oeuvre. "Que, par cette exigence qui la traverse, toute roeuvre d'Anne Hebert occupe dans notre litterature une des places les plus hautes, il n'est plus permis d'en douter. Elle est aussi, parmi nos oeuvres majeures, la plus purement francaise. Francaise, non pas de Paris; francaise de Nouvelle-France, du Canada francais."

C168      Monette, Pierre. "A propos du prix David 1978. Anne Hebert: Poesie rompue." Lettres quebecoises, No. 12 (nov. 1978), pp. 49-51. Monette notes that the younger generation "qui n'ont pas vecu la situation politique, culturelle et sociale qu'Anne Hebert a pu utiliser comme base a sa symbolique peuvent difficilement apprecier les poemes des Songes en equilibre et du Tornbeau des rois." Monette agrees with Denis Bouchard's theory of class snobbery in Une lecture d'Anne Hebert: la recherche d'une mythologie (C6 and C151) and suggests that Hebert has remained faithful to this elite background while the rest of Quebec society has evolved along a different path. Monette condemns both the Quebec government which chose the prize winner, and the recipient of the prize.

C169      Emond, Maurice. "Bibliographie sommaire." Quebec francais, No.32 (dec. 1978), p.40. Rpt. (revised -- "Bibliographie") in Romanciers du Quebec. Ed. Quebec francais. Quebec: Quebec francais, 1980, pp. 120-21. Bibliographical data.

C170      Emond, Maurice. "Une vie secrete." Quebec francais, No.32 (dec. 1978), p.35. Rpt. (revised -- "Biographie") in Romanciers du Quebec. Ed. Quebec francais. Quebec: Quebec francais, 1980, pp. 102-03. Biographical data.

C171      Emond, Maurice. "Introduction a l'oeuvre d'Anne Hebert." Quebec francais, No.32 (dec. 1978), 37-39. Rpt. in Romanciers du Quebec. Ed. Quebec francais. Quebec: Quebec francais, 1980, pp. 111-19. In her first volume of poetry "... les reves conservent leur serenite..." in the evocation of nature and adolescent dreaming. Le Tombeau des rois is "d'une rare densite, d'un grand depouillement." After the enormous success of this volume, "... le risque etait grand de se taire jamais." But Mystere de la parole shows "la renaissance du monde et du porte ..." There is "une veritable explosion de couleurs, d'odeurs et de sons .... " "Le Torrent" "trace avec lucidite un tableau saisissant d'un milieu janseniste en proie a la culpabilite et a la deposession .... " Les Chambres de bois is "la meilleure introduction et l'illustration la plus juste" of the two series of poems in Poemes. Kamouraska shows the revolt of women in its "histoire d'amour fou, de passion demesuree et de violence." Les Enfants du sabbat is "un roman terrible, deconcertant et envoutant." Here "Tous les desirs refoules de la femme dominee par un univers d'hommes, de pretres surtout, se dechainent avec une violence inouie." Hebert's early experiments with theatre are mentioned. Le Temps sauvage is her best play, and her theatre "se lit plus facilement qu'il ne se joue."

C172      Benson, Renate. "Aspects of Love in Anne Hebert's Short Stories." Journal of Canadian Fiction, Nos. 25-26 (1979), pp. 160-74. Benson examines the theme of love in the stories and emphasizes the opposition of the sterility of bourgeois materialism and the spiritual vision of the completely dispossessed. The latter alone seems to permit love. The stories are discussed in chronological order and present the idea that "... where love is denied there can only be sterility and death," and that love is not possible within the confines of rigid social restrictions. This is clearest in "La Mort de Stella" where "the true theme ... concerns the love between two people which is perfect precisely because of their total dispossession:'

C173      Cantin, Pierre, Normand Harrington, Jean-Paul Hudon. "Anne Hebert." In Bibliographie de la critique de la litterature quebecoise dans les revues des XIX" et XX siecles. Documents de travail du Centre de recherche en civilisation canadienne-francaise, 15. Ottawa: Centre de recherche en civilisation canadienne-francaise, 1979. Vol. IV, 614-21. Bibliographical data on secondary sources.

C174      Moisan, Clement. Poesie des frontieres: etude comparee des poesies canadienne et quebecoise. Collection constantes, No. 38. Quebec: Hurtubise HMH, 1979, pp.15, 25, 72, 86, 91, 97n., 99-115, 131,196, 200, 206, 279, 285, 299, 324, 327. Rpt. of Frontiers: Comparative Studies in Quebec/ Canadian Literature. By C1ement Moisan. Trans. George Lang and Linda Weber. Victoria: Porcepic, 1983, pp.x, 34, 45, 53--64, 76, 123-24, 128, 179-80, 183,190, 193,206. Hebert's work is mentioned in passing contrasts throughout the book and in more detail in a comparison with the work of P.K. Page. Both poets use similar themes and language, both see poetry as "decouverte et creation de l'univers, eveil de l'etre aux choses qui l'environnent .... " Both works have two cycles, one of death, the other of life: "L'etude comparative de la poesie d'Anne Hebert et de P. K. Page pourrait se faire selon deux cycles: celui de la mort et celui de la victoire sur la mort, ou de l'affirmation de la vie. Les deux cycles sont un dialogue constant entre la vie et la mort, qui s'alimente de motifs secondaires, mais essentiels, comme l'amour, le silence (et son oppose la parole), la revolte et la volonte d'aneantissement" Moisan presents parallel texts from Hebert's Poemes and Page's The Metal and the Flower, Cry Ararat! Poems New and Selected, and P.K. Page: Poems Selected and New. Passing comparison is also made with the work of Michele Lalonde: "Geoles, prolongement de la demarche d'Anne Hebert, exprime l'emotion de l'ame qui decouvre non pas seulement qu'elle est seule, coupee des autres, mais aussi prisonnitre." The sense of place found in the works of Margaret Atwood and the Parti pris group of poets ("Lors qu'ils parlent de pays, les pontes entendent plus ou moins parole, nomination, et leur contraire, silence, anonymat") is derived ultimately from Hebert. See C115 for an earlier article republishedin this book.

C175      Union des ecrivains quebecois. "Anne Hebert." Petit Dictionnaire des ecrivains quebecois (1979). Bio-bibliographical data.

C176      Iqbal, Francoise Maccabee. "Kamouraska, 'la fausse representation demasquee.'" Voix & images: etudes quebecoises, 4 (avril 1979), 460-78. Iqbal analyzes the theme of narcissism and the importance of male/female attempts at domination, each of the other. "Que l'etre d'Elisabeth se consume, aujourd'hui comme autrefois, en ce qu'Adler nommer la protestation virile et que cet etre dans le monde soit lie a un equilibre narcissique qui le situe a une place invariablement centrale et triomphante, ce sont les decors d'une representation savamment montee que nous allons, a l'invitation de la narratriceprotagoniste, demontrer." In this application of the theories of Adler and his followers on female neuroses which lead to attempts to dominate men, Iqbal suggests that Elisabeth wishes to dominate the various men in her life and that she is a product of her society and her education in this respect. Speaking of Elisabeth's passion for Nelson, Iqbal states: "... le docteur George Nelson, mysterieux etranger aux yeux et cheveux noirs, au regard foudroyant, est un heros fait sur mesure, aussi la chasseresse Elisabeth refera surface pour tendre des pieges de coquette." Iqbal sees the novel in terms of the "rivalite du masculin et du feminin et non leur harmonieuse synthese. Cette rivalite procede de l'agressive revendication d'amour et de reconnaissance par autrui d'un personnage en proie, de concert, a une virile protestation de l'inferiorite sentie et a une contemplation narcissique de son reflet dans un miroir."

C177      Weir, Lorraine. "'Fauna of Mirrors': The Poetry of Hebert and Atwood." Ariel [Univ. of Calgary], 10, No. 3 (July 1979), 99, 100-04, 109-13. Weir analyzes Le Tombeau des rois and some of the poetry of Margaret Atwood in the light of Jorge Luis Borges' "fauna of mirrors." In this retelling of a Chinese myth, the mirror people, banished from the previous state of harmony with the world of men, await the day when they will break the glass barrier and wage victorious battle against man. In her discussion of the persistence of mirror imagery and other-world imagery in Le Tombeau des rois, Weir states that Hebert "presents four stages in the life of a woman, perhaps of women collectively: awakening and innocence; entrapment (imaged in both physical and psychological terms) in childhood, in memory, in anguished situations of love and passion, and in an equally painful domesticity; a middle stage of change or reversal characterised by a dream of escape or a bitterly ironic resolution to act on illusory freedom; and finally the death of the self, entombment in the underworld of the kings." The speaker in these poems "hardly realizes that she has herself passed over into the kingdom of the Shades, perceiving her final imprisonment in the world of the living dead as only a 'songe horrible.'" In contrast to Atwood, where "the politics of love involves a bitter game of dominance and irony, in Hebert there is no question of woman's power .... She becomes one of the Shades without realizing it." In contrast to the pain felt by Atwood's personae, Hebert's characters wear masks of "emotional desensitization."

C178      Amprimoz, Alexandre L. "Semiotique de la segmentation d'un texte narratif: 'La Mort de Stella' d'Anne Hebert." Presence francophone, No. 19 (automne 1979), pp. 97-105. Amprimoz divides the text of the story, by a "segmentation synthetique" into seven sequences, which he analyzes according to remembered or narrative time. He concludes that the narrative "suit d'abord un mouvement retrograde allant du narratif au memorial, puis retournant au temps narratif pour enfin se stabiliser dans l'alternance des deux poles."

C179      Bolduc, Yves. "La Comparaison dans l'oeuvre poetique d'A. Hebert." Si que: etudes francaises [Univ. de Moneton], No.4 (automne 1979), pp. 123-42. Bolduc analyzes the frequent use of similes in the poetry. The qualifying words which flesh out the similes are frequently the essential part of the poem: "... dans les meilleurs cas, en effet, le determinant assure le retentissement de la comparaison au niveau du contenu du poeme." The simile is frequently strategically placed to govern the complete articulation of the poem; secondary similes are often used to expand the central one.

C180      Paterson, Janet M. "Bibliographie critique des etudes consacrees aux romans d'Anne Hebert." Voix & images: etudes quebecoises, 5 (automne 1979), 187-92. Bibliographical data on secondary sources.

C181      Pepin, Fernande. "La Femme dans l'espace imaginaire de la dramatique d'Anne Hebert: Le Temps sauvage." Canadian Drama / L'Art dramatique canadien [Univ. of Waterloo], 5 (Fall/automne 1979), 164-78. Pepin's study of the use of space in relation to the female characters of the play is organized around the opposition between the desire for roots and protected space, and the desire for open confrontation with the outside world. The first part of the analysis describes the structures and the traps of the enclosed female space; the second part presents the fascination exercised by the outside and the dangers inherent in this fascination. In the end the characters are able to move from the cloistered silence of their previous lives to the "rendez-vous" of the future.

C182      "Hebert." In 1978 Bibliography of Literature in English by and about Women: 600-1976 [Women and Literature, 7, No.[3] (Fall 1979)], p. 213. This brief bibliographical entry lists Children of the Black Sabbath and Gillian Davies' review of the book (D92).

C183      Ahmed, Maroussia. "'Transgresser, c'est progresser.'" Incidences [Univ. d'Ottawa], NS 4, Nos.2-3 (mai-dec. 1980), 119,123-24, 127. In this analysis of Marie-Claire Blais's Les Manuscrits de Pauline Archange, Anne Hebert's Les Enfants du sabbat, and Louky Bersianik's L'Euguelionne, Ahmed discusses "les espaces de la transgression, en rapport avec l'espace de la loi." In Hebert's novel, the revolt of woman is expressed in a long series of opposing forces. The spatial dichotomy is perhaps best expressed in the black sabbath scene, where the religious mass is routinely placed in juxtaposition with the occult mass. A list of the contrasting values, based on pages 34-35 of the novel, is given. "L'espace de la transgression se presente a la fois comme un espace carnavalesque et comme un espace feminin .... La transgression est devenue la loi dans une structure symetrique inchangee." In all three novels discussed, "La femme habite et explore l'espace, la chair et le verbe."

C184      Dionne, Rene, and Pierre Cantin. "Bibliographie de la critique. B.: Revues (1974-1975). Anne Hebert." In Histoire litteraire du Quebec:1. 1979. Montreal: Bellarmin, 1980, pp. 207-09. Bibliographical data.

C185      "Hebert, Anne 1916- ." In Contemporary Authors: A Bio-Bibliographical Guide to Current Writers in Fiction, General Nonfiction, Poetry, Journalism, Drama, Motion Pictures, Television, and Other Fields. Ed. Frances Carol Locher. Vols. LXXXV-LXXXVIIL Detroit: Gale, 1980, 249-50. Brief bio-bibliographical data is given under the headings "Personal," "Career," "Writings," "Sidelights," and "Biographical Critical Sources." There are a few factual errors. (The original publication of Le Torrent should be Montr6al: Beauchemin, 1950, and Anne Hebert has not received a Guggenheim award.) Quotations from reviews of The Tomb of the Kings, Kamouraska, and Children of the Black Sabbath are given from Samuel Moon (D20),Christina H. Roberts-Van Oordt (D66), Mel Watkins (D89), and an anonymous review in Choice (D63).

C186      Birney, Earle. Spreading Time: Remarks on Canadian Writing and Writers. Book 1: 1904-1949. Montreal: Vehicule, 1980, pp.86, 114. Birney reflects on his work with the Canadian Poetry Magazine: "What about Anne Hebert? I want CPM to publish the best good FrenchCanadian poets, and in their language .... To my mind the best poems in my final issue were all by women: Anne Hebert, P.K. Page, and Colleen Thibaudeau."

C187      Demers, Jeanne, and Lise Gauvin. "Contes -- et nouvelles -- du Quebec." In Culture populaire et litteratures au Quebec. Ed. and preface Rene Bouchard. Stanford French and Italian Studies, No.19. Saratoga, Cal.: Anma Libri, 1980, pp. 231-32. Demers and Gauvin note that "alors que le conte se situe du cote de la tradition, la nouvelle, plus inquietante, est defi, provocation .... 'Le Torrent' d'Anne Hebert est comme la mise a vif d'une plaie plus aigue parce qu'inexplicable et injustifiee. La surdite de Francois ... est la marque de son inalienable solitude, de sa fuite interieure hors de l'univers de vivants."

C188      Juery, Rene. "Recit et discours de 'La Robe corail.'" In Approches structurales des textes. By Serge A. Theriault and Rene Juery. Hull: Asticou, 1980, pp. 128-31. A reworking of Juery's dissertation (C311) to make a textbook suitable for students. It presents a semiotic analysis of "La Robe corail" using the "modeles actantiels et actoriels" developed by A.J. Greimas. This study concentrates on "La Robe corail" and makes less reference to Kamouraska than is found in Juery's dissertation. The story is analyzed as forming seven "sequences": "l'attente," "la seduction" "la transgression: la souillure" (sequences 3, 4), "l'impossible retour du reve," "l'errance," "la revelation." The analysis of the "semenes" in the "sequences" is followed by a study of the organization of the "modeles narratifs," and of the "modeles discursifs."

C189      Mailhot, Laurent. "Le Roman quebecois et ses langages." In Culture populaire et litteratures au Quebec. Ed. and preface Rene Bouchard. Stanford French and Italian Studies, No.19. Saratoga, Cal.:Anma Libri, 1980, pp. 150, 154. In this survey of the Quebec novel, Mailhot briefly notes "Meme le beau Kamouraska d'Anne Hebert ... ne peut supporter la comparaison avec les grands romans russes ou scandinaves" Le Torrent, Les Chambres de bois, and Les Enfants du sabbat present fictional worlds which are similar to those found in the work of Marie-Claire Blais.

C190      Poulin, A., Jr. Afterword. In Poems [Quarterly Review of Literature: Poetry Series, 21, Nos. 3-4 (1980), Pt. V], 58-60. Anne Hebert, along with Saint-Denys Garneau, Alain Grandbois, and Rina Lasnier, have attempted "to establish a poetry that was not the provincial voice of a European French culture, but rather an aesthetically viable poetry rooted in and giving voice to a thoroughly French-Canadian experience and sensibility in a uniquely intimate language and music." Between her first volume of poetry, dealing with a nostalgia for childhood and Le Tombeau des rois, Anne Hebert "seems to have undergone some kind of personal and aesthetic dark night of the soul out of which emerged the more fiercely personal and darker vision, the greater intensity, and the sometimes agonizing power of the poems in Le Tombeau des rois .... The personal vision in The Tomb of the Kings intensifies even more in The Mystery of the Word and becomes the foundation on which Anne Hebert erects another kind of personal poetry of metaphysical and oracular proportions, a personal poetry fired to the pitch of visionary ethics .... "

C191      Roy-Hewitson, Lucille. "Le Theme de l'enfance dans la poesie quebecoise contemporaine." Canadian Children's Literature, Nos. 18-19 (1980), pp. 42-43. The theme of childhood develops from an image of idealized purity to an image of vital energy, found particularly in the children of Le Temps sauvage, Kamouraska, and Les Enfants du sabbat.

C192      Viatte, Auguste. Histoire comparde des litteratures francophones. Paris: Nathan, 1980, pp. 130, 156-57. Viatte gives a short account of Hebert's work: the poetry moves from the juvenile accents of Les Songes en equilibres, through "la densite et l'intensite incroyables du Tombeau des rois (1953)." The stories of Le Torrent reflect the absurd "et les desesperances de l'apres-guerre. Puis elle changera; dans Poemes de 1960, elle decouvrira, sans rien perdre de son intensite, la vie et l'amour .... " A new beginning is marked in the Quebec novel in 1958 with the publication of Les Chambres de bois, where the influence of poetry is evident. Kamouraska is Hebert's masterpiece, and the presence of evil, felt there, is again found in Les Enfants du sabbat.

C193      Benson, Renate. "Character and Symbol in Anne Hebert's Les Invites au proces." Canadian Drama/L'Art dramatique canadien [Univ. of Waterloo], 6 (Spring 1980), 22-29. In an exposition of the basic themes and images of the play, Benson points out as well the expansion of some of these elements in later works. For example, the examination of evil inherent in human nature found in this play prefigures Les Enfants du sabbat. The play is unremittingly cynical and pessimistic, since the Devil takes control of society at the end of the play. This study also points out some interesting parallels with the imagery and the use of fairytale elements found in German Romanticism.

C194      Couillard-Goodenough, Marie. "La Femme et le sacre dans le roman quebecois" Revue de l'Universite d'Ottawa / University of Ottawa Quarterly, 50 (jan.-mars/Jan.-March 1980), 74-81. In her discussion of the revolt against the traditional role of women as mothers and upholders of the faith, Couillard-Goodenough cites Le Temps sauvage and Le Torrent as examples of works where the characters explicitly or implicitly demonstrate this sense of revolt. In Hebert's later novels, Kamouraska and Les Enfants du sabbat, we see "des univers essentiellement feminins, des univers ou la femme regne seule, insensible et cruelle. Les personnages masculins en sont de1iberement exclus et ce, par la volonte meme de la femme .... La cruaute, la violence, le carnage et la sauvagerie dominent ces univers amoureux ou les motifs du sang et du ventre constituent dans le discours mythique de ces deux romans, des mythemes manifestes patents ... Anne Hebert semble avoir pris les deux archetypes, Eve et Marie, au pied de la lettre et les avoir fondus dans ces deux femmes [Elisabeth and Julie]." Hebert's feminist point of view is a rejection of the old archetypes of women and the creation of new archetypes based on "le pouvoir magique du corps feminin pour y decouvrir le principe d'une spiritualite fondee sur l'experience feminine."

C195      Paterson, Janet M. "L'Ecriture de la jouissance dans l'oeuvre romanesque d'Anne Hebert." Revue de l'Universite d'Ottawa / University of Ottawa Quarterly, 50 (jan.-mars/Jan.-March 1980), 69-73. Paterson applies the Barthesian definition of a "texte de plaisir" ("'celui qui contente, emplit, donne de l'euphorie'") and of the "texte de jouissance" ("'celui qui met en etat de perte, celui qui deconforte .... fait vaciller les assises historiques, culturelles, psychologiques, du lecteur, la consistance de ses gouts, de ses valeurs et de ses souvenirs, met en crise son rapport au langage'") to Hebert's first three novels. Les Chambres de bois revolts against the traditional Realism of the novel, presenting instead "une conjonction entre differents niveaux de representation, a savoir, le reel, l'irreel et le songe" The meaning of the novel is found in the simultaneous juxtaposition of these planes. "Jouissance" is a direct result of "la cohabitation de ces differents codes; le roman s'avere foncierement ambigu et ouvert et c'est par 1a qu'il fait appel a l'imaginaire." The poetic style of the novel, in which words are used to suggest rather than denote, means that "... l'expression reste toujours en deca de l'explicite et du determine." Similarly, in Kamouraska, the "jouissance" of the reader comes from this juxtaposition of time and space in the narrative which raises questions in the reader on the nature of fiction and reality. The upsetting of cultural assumptions which is part of Barthes's "texte de jouissance" is most notable in Les Enfants du sabbat.

C196      Smart, Patricia. "La Poesie d'Anne Hebert: une perspective f6minine." Revue de l'Universite d'Ottawa/University of Ottawa Quarterly, 50 (jan.-mars/Jan.-March 1980), 62-68. Smart analyses the poetic works, revealing a surprising cohesion in the development of the feminine mythology within the different volumes. "Axee au ddpart sur la mythologie du Redempteur male et de la mere Douloureuse, elle evolue vers une mythologie transformee centree sur la femme redemptrice et bien resumee par la figure d'Eve, mere passionnee et pai'enne qui preside sur l'histoire humaine." Les Songes en equilibre shows the traditional, passive and self-sacrificing woman, particularly in the religious poems. In "Le Tombeau des rois" the falseness of the role is revealed. The passiveness reaches its ultimate in the consent given by the narrator to her own rape, but this coincides with the introduction of the active female figure, the huntress with her falcon on her wrist. In Mystere de la parole, it is woman who redeems man. The final image is a "fusion de plusieurs mythes: redemptrice, sorciere, sibylle, sirene et mere, elle est toujours la femme forte."

C197      Rubinger, Catherine. "Actualite de deux contestemoins: 'Le Torrent' d'Anne Hdbert et 'Un jardin au bout du monde' de Gabrielle Roy." Presence francophone, No. 20 (printemps 1980), pp. 121-26. Rubinger compares Hebert's "Le Torrent" to Gabrielle Roy's "Un jardin au bout du monde," pointing out the opposite views of women found in each. Hebert creates a revolutionary view of the French-Canadian mother, in a world of claustrophobic suffering, psychological prisons, and lacking love. In Marthe, Roy creates an image of an unconquered soul, "la sagesse meme."

C198      Ryan, Marie-Laure. "'Neige' d'Anne Hebert: un dialogue avec Saint-John Perse." Presence francophone, No. 20 (printemps 1980), pp. 127-35. Ryan proposes that "Neige" is a consciously worked "travail intertextuel" responding to the work of Saint-John Perse, and not an unconscious use of imagery typical of Perse. This intertextuality is also found in the concluding sections of "Mystere de la parole," but it is not characteristic in general of Hebert's poetry. Ryan also discusses the Structuralist interpretation of the poem by Jean-Michel Adam, arguing that both critical views of the work are valid.

C199      Roy-Hewitson, Lucille. "Anne Hebert: 'Le Torrent' ou l'integration au cosmos." The French Review, 53 (May 1980), 826-33. Roy-Hewitson discusses the dialectic of fire and water in "Le Torrent." The increase in the use of water imagery, which symbolizes the growing attraction to the instinctual life, is balanced by an increase in the imagery of fire, which expresses the character's increasingly lucid awareness of his state. In the end, the water imagery dominates, of course, as Francois gives up his own awareness and surrenders to a dissolution within the cosmos: "... la poussee instinctive vers une identification complete avec le cosmos mene graduellement Francois a une espece de suicide moral ou rien ne subsiste plus de sa conscience propre." At this point in Hebert's work, she seems to propose that "... la chute de la vie dans l'inconscient, voire la mort de l'esprit, etaitla conditionmeme du salut de l'homme."

C200      Bishop, Neil B. "Les Enfants du sabbat et la problematique de la liberation chez Anne Hebert." Etudes canadiennes / Canadian Studies [Univ. de Bordeaux III], No.8 (juin 1980), pp. 33-46. Bishop presents Julie as an adolescent "a la recherche de sa liberation et de son epanouissement." He studies the search for liberation as embodied in the themes of the body and space, to determine if Julie fails, as did Elisabeth in Kamouraska, or succeeds, as did Catherine in Les Chambres de bois. Bishop points out that Julie's childhood is permeated by physical discomfort and dependence, that the spatial images associated with the mountain cabin are imprisoning ones. This lack of liberty and happiness in the world of Philomene and Ade1ard is found with ever greater force in the convent life. The ending of the novel indicates Julie's continuous enslavement to male domination. Julie may have committed suicide, rather than have escaped from the convent. Bishop discusses the possible readings of the novel and concludes that it remains fundamentally ambiguous, remaining within the "genre fantastique pur" as defined by Tzvetan Todorov.

C201      Couillard, Marie. "Les Enfants du sabbat d'Anne Hebert: un recit de subversion fantastique." Incidences [Univ. d'Ottawa], NS 4, Nos. 2--3 (mai-dec. 1980), 77-83. Couillard accepts the convent/cabin opposition as reflecting the polarization of reality and imagination. She agrees with Denis Bouchard's interpretation of the irony and sarcasm of the novel (C141), which is used to attack male chauvinism. At the end of the novel, Julie is the objectification of all the standard male fantasies of women. For Couillard, "... rouvrage d'Anne Hebert depasse le refus du langage assigne par Todorov au recit fantastique, pour s'eriger en une remise en question de la condition faite a la femme par ce meme langage et la symbolique qui le sous-tend."

C202      Pascal, Gabrielle. "Soumission et revolte dans les romans d'Anne Hebert." Incidences [Univ. d'Ottawa], NS 4, Nos.2-3 (mai-dec. 1980), 59-75. The heroines in Hebert's novels alternate between submission and revolt. "La condition feminine chez Anne Hebert presente le spectacle d'heroines qui passent de l'etat intolerable de victimes a celui, injustifiable, de criminelles." According to Pascal, "... toute tentative de liberation comporte le risque de sombrer dans le desordre de la de1iquance, de la folie ou de l'autodestruction"

C203      Pascal-Smith, Gabrielle. "La Condition feminine dans Kamouraska d'Anne Hebert." The French Review, 54 (oct. 1980), 85-92. Pascal-Smith comments on the image of women in the novel. To remain a spinster is to be shamed, but marriage also carries a price, for Elisabeth realizes she has become an object. The novel presents two possibilities for women: to function within the power mechanisms of maledominated society, or to escape into an inner dream world. Elisabeth chooses the latter.

C204      Vaillancourt, Pierre-Louis. "Semiologie d'un ange: etude de 'L'Ange de Dominique' d'Anne Hebert." Voix & images: etudes quebecoises, 5 (hiver 1980), 353-63. After an initial analysis of the "spatialisation du recit," Vaillancourt examines the description of Ysa, which is "assertive" as well as "denegative" and "poetique" in the first part of the story. In the second part of the story, Ysa changes from a "vision exterieure et concrete" to become "abstrait et interieur." This story expresses the same sort of alienation that is traditionally found in "Le Torrent" for "... les elements structuraux mis a jour indiquent l'importance de la notion de fermeture au monde exterieur, caracteristique bien souvent soulignee du Quebec d'alors."

C205      Backes, Jean-Louis. "Le Systeme de l'identification dans roeuvre romanesque d'Anne Hebert." Voix & images: etudes quebecoises, 6 (hiver 1981), 269-77. Heloise, Kamouraska, and Les Enfants du sabbat all present a complicated search for identification on the part of the characters and the reader. The identity of Heloise is meant to remain ambiguous. The same is true of the other two novels discussed, where this question of personal identity is even more complex. Indeed, the act of identification is a trap, for the characters cannot be limited to one particular identification of themselves. "L'identite est impossible, le labyrinthe ne s'acheve pas."

C206      Godard, Barbara. "Blais' La Belle Bete: Infernal Fairy Tale." In Violence in the Canadian Novel since 1960/dans le roman canadien depuis 1960. Ed. Virginia Harger-Grinling and Terry Goldie. St. John's: Memorial Univ., [1981], pp. 164-65. Godard notes that motifs from Hebert's "Le Torrent" reappear in Marie-Claire Blais's La Belle Bete -- notably, the Narcissus myth, death as "an inversion of the process of birth," water which "symbolizes the mother to whom the protagonists are attached in a deadly Oedipal bond: both try to free themselves through horses" and both novels "exhibit characteristics of Quebec Jansenism."

C207      Juery, Rene. Initiation a l'analyse textuelle. Hull: Asticou, 1981, pp. 18-33, 75-146. The chapter entitled "Articulation recit discours: etude de Kamouraska" is a reworking of Juery's dissertation (C311) to make it suitable as a textbook chapter for students. In a chapter called "L'Expression et le contenu dans un poeme d'Anne Hebert," Juery proposes several readings of "Survienne la rose des vents." A close analysis of the images, the rhythms, the syntax, and the semantic structures is given. The results are given in terms of the "modUle actantiel des recits mythiques de A.J. Greimas .... "

C208      Moss, John. A Reader's Guide to the Canadian Novel. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1981, pp. 312-14, 353, 354, 357, 360, 362, 368, 369, 370, 374.
