Moss reviews The Silent Rooms and Kamouraska. The Silent Rooms has been highly praised for conflicting reasons: "For some, the novel is ephemeral, a dream; for others, it is a vision of unwavering authencity. One thing is certain: this is not a realistic novel." Moss finds it "a fascinating achievement" which, while deriving from the folk-tale, has an elegance, "a sureness of style, that has little to do with the folk tradition." He calls it "a fable of emancipation, of a woman who ... [takes] possession of herself. Beyond that it is -- like a good fairy tale -- whatever the reader wants it to be." Moss sees Kamouraska as "an overwhelmingly powerful post-modern romance set in the historical past" and the author's "unparalleled command of time and consciousness within the narrative lifts this novel to the highest level of contemporary achievement." These two novels figure in a variety of lists established by Moss at the end of his guide including chronological listings, a listing of types of settings ("Primary Setting: Quebec" or "Primary Setting: Other"), and other lists too numerous to mention.

C209      Paterson, Janet. "Anne Hebert." The Canadian Modern Language Review, 37 (Jan. 1981), 207-11. This article is a recasting in English of Paterson's article on "jouissance" (C195), although there is no reference to the Barthesian theoretical framework here. Paterson presents a brief analysis of the three levels of meaning which she finds in Hebert's work: the real, the unreal, and the dreamlike. As she mentioned in her earlier article, these three levels are juxtaposed, merge, and oppose each other.

C210      English, Judith, and Jacqueline Viswanathan. "Deux dames du Precieux-Sang: a propos des Enfants du sabbat d'Anne Hebert." Presence francophone, No. 22 (printemps 1981), pp. 111-19. In Les Enfants du sabbat, blood imagery is used to reverse the traditional Christian images of the immaculate Virgin and to restore to woman her essential femininity, which includes her carnal and sexual nature. English and Viswanathan discuss the traditional taboos associated with menstrual blood and the eating of raw meat.

C211      Mailhot, Laurent. "Quand les Francais nous decouvrent .... " Lectures europeennes, Montreal. Avril 1981. Printed in Lectures europeennes de la litterature quebecoise. [Ed.] and preface Jean Clio Godin. Montreal Lemeac, 1982, pp. 261, 269-70. Mailhot takes Jean-Michel Adam to task for his analysis, in "Sur cinq vers de Mystere de la parole: lire aujourd'hui 'Neige' d'Anne Hebert" (C99), in which "en voulant trop bien faire, en voulant nous lire par nos yeux, ce critique structuraliste a cede a un impressionnisme deplorable." The reference is to the analysis of the verb "sacre," of which Mailhot says, "Ce sens 'specifiquement quebecois" est un "gros contresens .... " Other European critics are also discussed. "Dans la monographie de Rene Lacote [C3], Anne Hebert est partout et nutle part -- partout ailleurs que dans son oeuvre --, admiree, aimee sans doute par Lacote, mais utilisee a des fins de propagande et de tourisme." Mailhot finds that Lacote creates his own image of Quebec and of Hebert, without giving objective attention to either: "Cette emotion, qui brouille la vue, risque de faire ecran entre le lecteur francais et le texte quebecois."

C212      Marcato-Falzoni, Franca. "Presence de la litterature quebecoise en Italie." Lectures europeennes, Montreal. Avril 1981. Printed in Lectures europeennes de la litterature quebecoise. [Ed.] and preface Jean Cleo Godin. Montreal: Lemeac, 1982, pp. 47, 61, 62. Marcato-Falzoni is critical of the translation of the title of Kamouraska in the Italian edition (Dietro il gelo dei vetri). Bibliographical information on translations and articles about Hebert in Italian are given.

C213      May, Cedric. "La Grande-Bretagne: 'la folle entreprise de nommer' et 'les court-circuits du langage.'" Lectures europeennes, Montreal. Avril 1981. Printed in Lectures europeennes de la litterature quebecoise. [Ed.] and preface Jean Cleo Godin. Montreal Lemeac, 1982, pp. 37, 38, 39. Hebert is evoked briefly in May's discussion of Quebec poetry and its act of naming, in its turning of alienation into "parole rompue."

C214      Moisan, Renate. "L'Acceuil reserve a la litterature quebecoise dans les pays de langue allemande." Lectures europeennes, Montreal. Avril 1981. Printed in Lectures europdennes de la littdrature quebdcoise. [Ed.] and preface Jean C1eo Godin. Montreal: Lemeac, 1982, pp.2. Moisan lists the translations of Hebert's work into German and places the critical reception of these in the context of other Quebec works. The translations of Kamouraska, "Le Torrent," and "La Maison de l'Esplanade" are mentioned.

C215      Davidson, Arnold E. "Canadian Gothic and Anne Hebert's Kamouraska." Modern Fiction Studies, 27 (Summer 1981), 243-54. Davidson examines Kamouraska in the context of English-Canadian Gothic novels; he refers, among others, to the studies of Margot Northey (C136) and John Lennox (C166) on the Gothic elements. The central question of human character posed by Gothic novels ("What manner of being is this?") receives an ambiguous answer. Davidson agrees with Lennox that "... this sense of profound dislocation is central to the theme and technique of the novel." Furthermore, "... it is also central to the Canadian gothic tradition, a tradition that in appropriate double fashion informs this major novel and is justified by it."

C216      Da Silva, Edson Rosa. "La Regeneration du cosmos dans un poeme d'Anne Hebert." Presence francophone, No. 23 (automne 1981), pp. 163-75. Da Silva's analysis of "Printemps sur la ville" uses the theories of Gaston Bachelard, Mircea Eliade, and Gilbert Durand to uncover "le symbolisme imaginaire qui nous aide a depasser nos limites personnelles et a recuperer les images universelles" For the author "... par le pouvoir (re)createur du langage, ce poeme reactualise, a son tour, le moment primordia! et acquiert les caracteristiques d'un recit mythique."

C217      Dionne, Rene, and Pierre Cantin. "Bibliographie de la critique. B.: Revues (1976-1977). Anne H~bert." In Revue d'histoire litteraire du Quebec et du Canada francais: 2 (1980- 81). Montreal: Bellarmin, 1982, pp. 249-50. Bibliographical data.

C218      Dionne, Rene, and Pierre Cantin. "Bibliographie de la critique. B.: Revues (1978). Anne Hebert." In Revue d'histoire litteraire du Quebec et du Canada francais: 3 (hiver-printemps 1982). Montreal: Bellarmin, 1982, pp. 219-20. Bibliographical data.

C219      Emond, Maurice. "Les Chambres de bois, roman d'Anne Hebert." Dictionnaire des oeuvres litteraires du Quebec, 111: 1940-1959 (1982). Emond includes a resume of the novel, an analysis of the work, and bibliographical data on secondary sources for the novel. "L'elegance et la finesse de la langue, la densite poetique des images, l'evocation envoutante d'atmospheres et d'etats d'ame a la fois morbides et seduisants donnent a ce roman toute sa richesse et son originalite." This novel is significant since it is "la decouverte d'une ecriture romanesque qui deviendra le mode privilegie d'expression d'Anne Hebert."

C220      Lemieux, Pierre-Herve. "Arche de midi, poeme dramatique d'Anne Hebert." Dictionnaire des oeuvres litteraires du Quebec, 111:1940-1959 (1982). Arche de midi is the first-known play by Hebert, which remains, regretably, unpublished. It combines the modern theme of revolt with the ancient theme of sacrifice. Brief bibliographical data follows.

C221      Lemieux, Pierre-Herve. "Les Invites au proces, poeme dramatique d'Anne Hebert." Dictionnaire des oeuvres litteraires du Quebec, llI: 1940-1959 (1982). Lemieux includes a brief resume and a critical overview of "cette piece mineure mais bien d'avant-garde, dont le symbolisme raffine renvoie a l'oeuvre anterieure et dont les 'diableries' comme les 'sortileges' preparent celles des Enfants du sabbat." Bibliographical data for criticism on the play is also included.

C222      Lemieux, Pierre-Herve. "La Merciere assassinee, drame d'Anne Hebert." Dictionnaire des oeuvres litteraires du Quebec, III: 1940-1959 (1982). Lemieux includes a resume and a critical overview, followed by bibliographical data on studies of the play. It is "une piece policiere ecrite par un porte," which goes beyond the formula of the murder mystery The play was written "au moment ou l'auteur est en pleine possession, pratique et theorique, de sa nouvelie maniere de voir le monde et de l'ecrire." She had at this point virtually completed her poetic cycle, was publishing her first novel, and delivering her art poetique, "Poesie, solitude rompue."

C223      Lemieux, Pierre-Herve. "Les Songes en equilibre, recueil de poesies d'Anne Hebert." Dictionnaire des oeuvres litteraires du Quebec, III: 1940-1959 (1982). The critical resume of the collection of poems is accompanied by biographical data and bibliographical data on critical studies. Lemieux sees three phases in Hebert's poetry: "'nuit,' 'lutte,' et 'jour,'" which are found in the individual poems as well as being characteristic of the three volumes of poetry. Les Songes en equilibre belongs to the night phase. In a sense it presents a just image of Quebec society at the time: "... on s'apercoit que Les Songes en equilibre de 1942 decrivaient exactement ce qu'a ete l'imaginaire quebecois clerico-colonise, sans utiliser ces termes evidemment, mais avec quelle conscience et quel acharnement."

C224      Lemieux, Pierre-Herve. "Le Tombeau des rois, recueil de poemes d'Anne Hebert." Dictionnaire des oeuvres litteraires du Quebec, III: 1940-1959 (1982). Lemieux evaluates the genesis, the publication history, and the critical reception of Le Tombeau des rois, placing the work in the context of Hebert's oeuvre and in the context of Quebec society. The analysis is followed by bibliographical data on secondary sources.

C225      Paterson, Janet M. "Anne Hebert." In Profiles in Canadian Literature. Ed. Jeffrey M. Heath. Vol. III Toronto: Dundurn, 1982, 113-20. Paterson presents a critical overview, concentrating on the prose works, followed by a chronology, a selection of excerpts from interviews with, and articles on, Hebert, and a short Bibliography.

C226      Roy, Max. "Le Torrent, recueil de nouvelles d'Anne Hebert." Dictionnaire des oeuvres litteraires du Quebec, III: 1940-1959 (1982). Roy presents a resume of the publishing history and a critical overview of the work and its reception, followed by bibliographical data on secondary sources.

C227      Tougas, Gerard. Destin litteraire du Quebec. Montreal: Quebec/l'Amerique, 1982, pp. 25, 36-37, 78. Tougas evokes the favourable attitude of the French toward Quebec writers, visible in part in the publication by Paris publishers of the work of Anne Hebert and Reean Ducharme. "Aucun auteur quebecois n'a mieux reussi ... [que Hebert] a se forger une reputation en France. Pourtant les cabanes a sucre n'abondent pas dans son oeuvre. Sa langue, loin de refleter l'experience joualisante de tant de ses contemporains, demeure tres classique. Sans les references topologiques et historiques au Quebec, elle pourrait, a cet egard, passer pour un ecrivain francais. Comment expliquer que, sans s'etre enrobee d'une catalogne, elle ait reussi la ou d'autres ont echoue? C'est qu'elle y a mis le prix, et ce prix, beaucoup ne sont pas prets le consentir. Receptions mondaines, programmes a la radio et a la television .... Anne Hebert a largement fait acte de presence la-bas. C'est son droit. Ce n'est pas en elaborant une oeuvre a Chicoutimi qu'elle se ferait connaitre Paris. Anne Hebert a rendu service aux ecrivains quebecois ... devenant une sorte d'ambassadrice des lettres quebecoises"

C228      Waelti-Walter, Jennifer. "'Beauty and the Beast' and The Silent Rooms (Hebert)." In her Fairy Tale and the Female Imagination. Montreal: Eden, 1982, pp. 13-30. The "fairy tale substructure" of The Silent Rooms, which uses "Beauty and the Beast," is analyzed in detail. For Waelti-Walters, "... the novel has a lot to teach us about the way women are taught to be victims and to believe they are princesses" She stresses that the novel is about mothers and daughters: "They have been raised to be victims and victims they are, bearing the burden of shame put upon them by their men folk. And what is that shame? Male sexuality, which he looks on as a weakness or a sin, and for which he holds woman responsible .... " The ending of the novel is disquieting: it is "the traditional sop fed to women for generations: when you find your True Love all will be well. This happy ending is the 'and they all lived happily ever after' of the fairy story, and, as such should undermine itself totally."

C229      Jacques, Henri-Paul. "Un probable souvenirecran chez Anne Hebert." Voix & images: litterature quebecoise, 7 (printemps 1982), 449-58. This is a Freudian analysis of the image of the rooster caught in the horse's mane, the two frightened animals becoming one "corps fabuleux," which Elisabeth remembers in Kamouraska. Jacques traces the recurrence of this imagery and its sexual connotations in Kamouraska and Les Enfants du sabbat and, to a more limited extent, in Les Chambres de bois.

C230      Major, Ruth. "Kamouraska et Les Enfants du sabbat: faire jouer la transparence." Voix & images: litterature quebecoise, 7 (printemps 1982), 459-70. Les Enfants du sabbat is a "remake" of Kamouraska in the sense that the same triangular structures in narrative focus, characters, and situations are to be observed in both works. Julie's role as omniscient narrator is similar to that of Madame Rolland, who occasionally allows other aspects of her previous self to be narrator. Both novels demonstrate similar changes in place and character and the same relationships between love and death, and women and society.

C231      Paterson, Janet. "Bibliographie d'Anne Hebert." Voix & images: litterature quebecoise, 7 (printemps 1982), 505-10. Bibliographical data.

C232      Pestre de Almeida, Lilian. "Heloise: la mort dans cette chambre." Voix & images: litterature quebecoise, 7 (printemps 1982), 471-81. Pestre de Almeida uses a Freudian analysis of Heloise to demonstrate that He1oise represents the incestuous mother fixation of Bernard. Christine, in many ways merely a double of Bernard, is not capable of displacing Bernard's mother in his affections.

C233      Rosenstreich, Susan L. "The Poet in Pieces: Anne Hebert's Marginal Poetics." NEMLA, New York. April 1982. Printed ("Counter-Tradition: The Marginal Poetics of Anne Hebert") in Traditionalism, Nationalism and Feminism: Women Writers of Quebec. Ed. Paula Gilbert Lewis. Contributions to Women's Studies, No.53. Westport, Conn.: Greenwood, 1985, pp. 63-70. Hebert is discussed in the context of marginal poets "who are engaged in a literary struggle between old and new perceptions:' "Eve [Commencement du monde ...]" from Les Songes en equilibre, as well as "Le Tombeau des rois" and "Mystere de la Parole" are analyzed to show that Hebert is concerned with the conflict between present reality and historical tradition. "Hebert wants us to reject the world as we have been taught to see it ...." Hebert's poetry "separates sense from nonsense, that which is already known from that which is yet to be understood. This is the margin on which Hebert writes."

C234      Roy, Lucille. "Anne Hebert ou le desert du monde." Voix & images: litterature quebecoise, 7 ( printemps 1982), 483-503. Roy analyzes the imagery of light, which informs both the images of hands and of looking, makes reference to the works up to Les Enfants du sabbat, but concentrates on Kamouraska, Le Torrent, and the poetry. Light is necessary for the true life of the protagonists, for without it they have no contact with reality. But, paradoxically, the cruel light which violates the unconscious desires of the protagonists also leads inevitably to the destruction of their world, to the desert, to the void.

C235      Russell, D.W. "Quatre versions d'une 1egende canadienne." Canadian Literature, No. 94 (Autumn 1982), pp. 172-74, 176-78. Russell discusses the legend behind Marguerite de Roberval's punishment during the voyage of settlement to the New World in 1540-42 and compares four versions of this story: Anne Hebert's L'Ile de la demoiselle (B147), George Woodcock's The Island of Demons, Marguerite de Navarre's sixty-seventh tale from the Heptameron, and the film Marooned in the Land God Gave to Cain, produced by Rosebud Films, Toronto. Anne Hebert presents a feminist perspective on the traditional role of women "dans un monde ou l'homme ... est 'maitre apres Dieu.'" Marguerite de Roberval is initially portrayed as "naive et innocente" accepting Nicolas' advances and rejecting her uncle's without thinking of the consequences. Later, she is portrayed as resourceful and strong, rejecting "toute sa formation europeenne de jeune fille bien eduquee," in order to stay alive. In honour of her victory over the island, the fishermen rename the island "l'ile de la Demoiselle" Her victory is further signalled by her acceptance of de Roberval's assassinationas an act of justice.

C236      Downes, Gwladys. "Women Poets in Quebec Society." The Malahat Review, No.63 (Oct. 1982), pp.105, 106-07, 108, 109. Downes comments briefly on Hebert: she "has become a novelist, but her vision is naturally and fundamentally poetic." Although she "has been hailed by the feminist movement, she is not fundamentally a feminist. Her commitment is to literature."

C237      Amprimoz, Alexandre. "Semiosis du tactile: exemples de Kamouraska." Incidences [Univ. d'Ottawa], 6, No. 3 (sept.-dec. 1982), 81-88. Basing his discussion on A.J. Greimas (Du sens: essais semiotiques, Paris, 1970) and Umberto Eco (La Struttura assente, Milan, 1968), among others, Amprimoz, in opposition to Greimas, posits a "langage gestuel romanesque" which is not referential to the natural world, but purely literary. He uses a passage from Kamouraska to demonstrate his hypothesis. One of the dream sequences initially seems to place the tactile in opposition to the visual code. This in turn is affected by an aesthetic code, leading in the end to "... le passage de la semiosis a la mimesis .... La semiosis du tactile relive de la litterarite d'un texte, on ne peut donc la lire sous l'angle referentiel .... la surdetermination litteraire oppose le tactile et le visuel en les distribuant selon une fonction esthetique qui, par sa divergence meme, cree paradoxalement rillusion d'une certaine vraisemblance."

C238      Jones, Grahame C. "Alexandre Chenevert et Kamouraska: une lecture australienne" Voix et images: litterature quebecoise, 7 (hiver 1982), 329-49. Jones compares the two principal characters of Alexandre Chenevert and Kamouraska, pointing out that both Elisabeth and Alexandre find themselves in similar situations. Both spend a sleepless night, awaiting dawn, both create a fictional world within the fictional world of the novel. While the two novels seem to be very different, Jones suggests that the similarities between the characters is a result of "un sentiment d'alienation et une recherche de soi qui sont ceux de la societe qu'ils peignent .... "

C239      Poulin, Gabrielle. "L'Ecriture enchantee: Les Fous de Bassan d'Anne Hebert." Lettres quebecoises, No. 28 (hiver 1982-83), pp. 15-18. This is a review-article on Les Fous de Bassan. The novel has created a legend about the Loyalists who settled in the Gaspe region in 1784. It is not historically oriented; "... elle s'attache ... plutot, comme dans toute son oeuvre anterieure, a la vie secrete des passions. Celle-ci, comme un grand courant de fond, en les boulversant, reunit les univers que l'histoire et la politique ont cloisonnes." All the characters share the "courant de vie, fait de desir, de passion et de revolte, qui parcourt l'univers romanesque d'Anne Hebert."

C240      Blais, Marie-Claire. Introduction. In The Oxford Book of French-Canadian Short Stories. Ed. Richard Teleky. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1983, pp.xiv-xv. "The Torrent" "amazes us by its youthfulness and the strength of its passion. We recognize the writing of a poet and feel the flow of a torrent .... In these lines the breath of a great poet transports us .... with writing that whirls towards the edge of death."

C241      Dionne, Rene, and Pierre Cantin. "Bibliographie de la critique. B.: Revues (1979). Anne Halbert." In Revue d'histoire litteraire du Quebec et du Canada francais: 4 (ete-automne 1982). Montreal: Bellarmin, 1983, p. 183. Bibliographical data.

C242      Hajdukowski-Ahmed, Maroussia. "The Unique, Its Double and the Multiple: The Carnivalesque Hero in the Quebecois Novel." Yale French Studies, No. 65 (1983), pp. 143-47. The change operative in Quebec during the Quiet Revolution is that of a passage "from Lent to Carnival in the Bakhtinian sense." The Quebecois novel reflects this passage, where the hero can be seen as "an ideologem which enters into a dialogic rapport" with the constraints of society, or with the law of the society. The law, initially represented by the traditional novel, is transgressed in the carnivalesque novel. "Le Torrent" is evoked in this context, where the "hero owes his 'conversion' (the passage from the sacred to the carnivalesque) to a character-trustee" whose lack of social status or even name indicative of the social and ideological open which they bring." This revolt against sacred reaches a new intensity in later novel which Les Enfants du sabbat is an exam Soeur Julie wishes to display openly her in with her father: "'Que l'atroce se change bien. Telle est la loi: l'envers du monde.'" In evolution of Quebec literature, the ca valesque figure, which becomes as predicabl the earlier sacred figure, is also left behind the development of a carnivalesque writing which "Fiction no longer takes itself for real And "... the narrative carnivalesque is a way refuse the political mystification of the reader mystifying him literally/literarily"

C243      "Halbert, Anne." Who's Who in Canadian Litera ture 1983-1984 (1983). Bio-bibliographical data.

C244      Lemieux, Pierre H. "Halbert, Anne (b.1916). The Oxford Companion to Canadian Literature. Gen. ed. William Toye. Toronto: Oxford U Press, 1983, pp. 341-43. Lemieux provides bio-bibliographical data and outlines the evolution of various theme Hebert's works.

C245      Paterson, Janet M. "Anne Hebert and the course of the Unreal." Yale French Studies. No. 65 (1983), pp. 172-86. Paterson demonstrates the "departure from long-standing tradition of realism in FrenchCanadian literature," which is found in Les Chambres de bois. While there is "a referential element, we also observe that this element is transgressed, subverted and liberated by a discourse which uncovers the realm of the imaginary and the forbidden." Paterson closely analyzes the first sentence of the novel, then extrapolates to the larger structures of the narrative. The first sentence "immediately suggests two possible meanings, the real and the unreal, two meanings which exist within a close dialectical tension" Paterson limits her discussion of the larger structure to "three main operations: 1) semantic expansion, 2) interpenetration of narrative and tales, 3) the movement toward a metafictive discourse." The semantic expansion is the repetition of key words to "form a semantic nucleus which guarantees a certain meaning." By the use of tales told by characters within the narrative, "... narrative levels become fused and confused ... and the fiction loses its specificity as fiction." These tales create, as well, "fusions in time and space. Transcending the present spatial and temporal dimensions of the narrative, past and present frequently merge, creating one atemporal literary dimension ... In the final analysis, the verbal features of the unreal and the doubling of spatio-temporal structures are but vehicles of a code which allows the narrative to unveil itself as 'unreal' and ultimately as fictive." Paterson notes that "... the various forms of autorepresentation, notably references to books and fables, raises en abyme of a story by various tales and intertextual references to other fictive universes converge to create a textual reflection of a literary and imaginary discourse. Hence the discourse of the unreal in this novel, carefully constructed on the level of semes, codes and narrative, refers to itself and reflects itself by displaying its textual links to language and literature."

C246      Union des ecrivains quebecois. "Anne Hebert." Dictionnaire des ecrivains quebecois contemporains (1983). Bio-bibliographical data.

C247      Manguel, Alberto. "The Other Solitude: An Outsider Surveys French-Canadian Fiction, and Finds in It Some of the Most Venturesome and Successful -- Writing Today." Books in Canada, May 1983, pp.7, 8. In a discussion of the lack of temporal perspective for critics of Canadian literature, Manguel notes that "For some future critic perhaps Anne Hebert and Antonine Maillet will be sisters in style." He also notes that "... it is an open secret that French publishers are given the prizes in turn ...." So "One should really say that Seuil obtained the prize [Femina] for her." Yet, the book "is excellent. Her old poetic voice is there ...; also the closed atmosphere ...." Her use of language "is astounding ... perhaps John Hawkes comes close to Hebert's dark obsessions ...," perhaps Djuna Barnes.

C248      Godard, Barbara. "My (m)Other, My Self: Strategies for Subversion in Atwood and Hebert." Essays on Canadian Writing, No.26 (Summer 1983), pp. 13-44. Margaret Atwood's Lady Oracle and Anne Hebert's Kamouraska, are similar in that "Dialectical confrontation must be replaced by oxymoronic or multiplistic vision, or be exploded through parody which subverts our logical structures." Elisabeth "is of course not two but five or more personae, the spliting process proliferating as she moves to greater depths of her being." Both novels "are models of paradox .... Both books dramatize the clash of two modes of perception, the marvellous facing-off with the real. ... An additional mise en abyme occurs in these novels in that the fictional characters are all projections of Hebert and Atwood .... The worlds of fact and hallucination, autobiography and fiction, kept apart at the beginning of the novels have become intermingled by the end. These and the subject/object division, the author/character separation, the male/female distinction, which the patriarchal tradition would view as polarities, are in these novels by women shown to be different aspects of the same thing, multiple and fluid, as they tend to run into one another. Every woman is many women, just as every story is many stories." These novels also examine "women's relationships to women .... Discovery of self comes not from a movement towards unity of being, but, rather from a recognition of the lost tradition of the goddess, triple in nature ... virgin, mother, hag .... " In these novels the female characters go through a process of giving birth to themselves, through a rejection of the social roles imposed on them by their education and their society. "... Kamouraska and Lady Oracle question the fictions of women's lives and outline new scripts to give birth to the reality they experience ...."

C249      Backes, Jean-Louis. "Le Retour des morts dans l'oeuvre d'Anne Hebert." L'Esprit createur, 33, No. 3 (Fall 1983), 48-57. Hebert's work shows the constant attraction that the world of the dead has on the world of the living. Backes interprets the line from "Le Tombeau des rois" ("L'immobile desir des gisants me tire") in both a passive and an active sense. Heloise permits us to reread Les Chambres de bois, which metaphorically presents vampirism as well: "... Catherine echappe au lieu terrible ou elle se tenait enfermee, ou elle a failli mourir. Ce lieu est celui des morts. Michel est un vampire." But the novel, by its realism and by its ending which shows Catherine escaping, refuses to be other than metaphorically about vampirism. Kamouraska also shows the attraction of the other world; the final nightmare of Elisabeth proves this: "Mais est-on stir que l'enterree vive soit tout entiere du cote des vivants?" In Les Enfants du sabbat, the other world dominates, for "... la sorcellerie, telle qu'Anne Hebert la recompose ... vit de la mort .... Mais c'est le terrible vraisemblable du monde malefique qui s'empare de la narration ...," which is the real threat to the world of the living. "Le roman vire au fantastique." In the next novel, the change is complete. "Dans Heloise, le virage est acheve. Le monde qui vit au soleil a tout perdu de sa belle assurance; on n'y expliquera pasce qui se passe dans le metro." But the work is far from being "une banale histoire de vampires," for it uses none of the traditional religious elements of the struggle between good and evil. "Fantastique, sans aucun doute, le roman ne joue que sur une seule idee: les morts vivent, reviennent, ont besoin des vivants, les entrainent, les transforment a leur tour .... Les morts connaissent le monde des vivants, et le porte est dans le double royaume." In Les Fous de Bassan, Hebert finally presents a character who is dead: "Autorisee exister pleinement, et non plus comme un cauchemar, une hallucination, delivree de tous les deguisements de la metaphore, Olivia peut dire, comme dans un poeme: 'Il y a certainement quelqu'un qui m'a tuee.'" The character is not there to help the living find justice, nor to aid the reader in solving the mystery, but to present the life of the dead: one of the main purposes of the novel is "donner la parole a un mort .... [Heloise and Les Fous de Bassan] proposent peut-etre les deux reperes extremes d'une irremediable ambiguite. Vivre la mort, comme l'a fait Orphee, ce n'est pas apprivoiser son horreur."

C250      Ducrocq-Poirier, Madeleine. "Les Romancieres quebecoises contomporaines et la condition feminine." L'Esprit createur, 33, No.3 (Fall 1983), 40-41. Quebec literature has become feminized, particularly after the Quiet Revolution. Criticism has not kept pace, however: "... la critique litteraire, tres peu feminisee encore, s'est montree longtemps reticente et partiale h l'egard de nombre d'elles [ecrivaines feministes], leur reprochant ... un 'feminisme' entendu dans l'acception la plus pejorative .... Seules, les romancieres les plus traditionelles, comme Gabrielle Roy ou Anne Hebert furent epargnees."

C251      Whitfield, Agnes. "Reading the Post-1960 Quebec Novel: The Changing Role of the Narratee." L'Esprit createur, 33, No.3 (Fall 1983), 35-36. Whitfield concentrates on Hubert Aquin and Rejean Ducharme for the most part, but also mentions Anne Hebert briefly: "In Kamouraska by Anne Hebert, ego and super-ego of the main character are both narrator and narratee. As in Prochain Episode, but more clearly, the superego function is associated with social repression. Elizabeth [sic] is forced by her conscience to relive her adultery and her complicity in the murder of her first husband."

C252      Manguel, Alberto. "Voyeurs chez nous." Rev. of L'Ecrivain devant son oeuvre, by Donald Smith. Books in Canada, Nov. 1983, p. 32. In this review of Donald Smith's book (C343), Manguel notes that "Two writers who might be expected to concentrate on purely linguistic problems -- Anne Hebert and Marie-Claire Blais -- surprise us by turning instead to the factual source of their fiction .... Hebert seems to say ... the world is at the origin of her dreams."

C253      Bishop, Neil B. "Distance, point de rue, voix et ideologie dans Les Fous de Bassan d'Anne Hebert." Voix & images: litterature quebecoise, 9 (hiver 1984), 113-29. Using Gerard Genette's theories regarding distance, point of view, and voice, Bishop analyzes Les Fous de Bassan to discover "une substance ideologique de caractere feministe." He discusses the effects gained by the division of the novel into six different recits. In each, the narrator moves between the first person (and identification with the events narrated) and the third person (creating a distance between the events and the narrator). There is one example of a sort of "narrateur collectif' in the "Livre de Perceval Brown et de quelques autres," which can also be found fleetingly in Nicolas Jones's narrative. There is also the "voix des femmes passees," a sort of collective voice which expresses itself primarily through Olivia. Bishop contrasts the phallocratic chauvinism of the male characters to the feminist views of the female characters. The women who dare to express their "faim de vivre," risk "d'etre chatiee a l'extreme." But both Felicity and Nora react against the religious power of men, claiming their own equality to men. Bishop finds, then, that the collective voice, which is part of the novel's structure, also expresses an ideology "de la liberation et de l'epanouissement des femmes."

C254      Dionne, Rene. "Classiques de la litterature quebecoise (essai de bibliographie fondamentale)." In Le Quebecois et sa litterature. Ed. and introd. Rene Dionne. Sherbrooke: Naaman, 1984, pp. 416, 417, 420, 423. Les Chambres de bois, Kamouraska, Les Enfants du sabbat, Poemes, Le Torrent, Le Temps sauvage are all listed as classic texts in Dionne's bibliographical essay.

C255      Dionne, Rene. Introduction. In Le Quebecois et sa litterature. Ed. Rene Dionne. Sherbrooke: Naaman, 1984, pp. 42, 44. Dionne briefly mentions Hebert's importance in the rebirth of Quebec literature, as both a poet and a novelist.

C256      Dionne, Rene, and Pierre Cantin. "Bibliographie de la critique. Revues (1980). Anne Halbert." In Revue d'histoire litteraire du Quebec et du Canada francais: 5 (hiver-printemps 1983). Ottawa: Les Editions de l'Univ, d'Ottawa, 1984, pp. 219-20. Bibliographical data.

C257      Giguere, Richard. Exil, revolte et dissidence: etude comparee des poesies quebecoise et canadienne (1925-1955). Vie des Lettres quebecoises, No.23. Quebec: Les Presses de l'Univ. Laval, 1984, pp. 8, 10, 11, 14, 48, 54, 63, 65, 69, 71-78, 81, 83, 87, 88, 89, 90, 115, 142, 146, 149-51, 160, 169, 174, 219, 226, 229, 230, 243-44. This is a much reduced and substantially revised version of Giguere's dissertation (C315). The book is divided into five main sections: 1) "Les Soirs rouges," in which Giguere examines the Depression and its reflection in the radical and social poetry of the 1930s; 2) "Exil et alienation du monde," in which he examines the philosophical and metaphysical poets between the two wars and their themes of loss, death, and religious dualism; 3) "Le Nord, l'Amerique et les grands espaces," in which he examines poets who compensated for the losses caused by the Depression by creating poetry about a heroic nature, poetry of "conquete et rayonnement" and poetry of physical love; 4) "La Tentation de l'Eros," or the development of erotic poetry and the feminist movement (as seen in Dorothy Livesay); 5) "Une Poesie de la dissidence" in which he examines poets during and after the Second World War and social radicalism. Hebert is mentioned frequently in passing, with other names, as a contrast to particular poets being discussed. Hebert's work is presented in more detail in the second and fourth sections. Giguere retraces the development of Hebert's poetry. "L'affranchissement de la prison, la necessaire liberation de l'exil interieur et l'exorcisme de la mort se font lentement, progressivement, dans des conditions extremement penibles pour la porte" Evil and the shadow of death are present in her first volume of poems, along with the expression of childish innocence. This evil is examined more closely in Le Tombeau des rois, where the alienation becomes increasingly more profound. A reverse movement is found in Mystere de la parole: "... la thematique d'Anne Hebert passe de la prison a la liberation, de l'exil interieur a un retour sur la terre des hommes ...." Although Hebert's poetry regains life, it does not become socially committed in the sense that is found in the work of Dorothy Livesay, or even in the work of P.K. Page, although in 1967 Hebert did publish "un premier poeme a incidence sociale, 'Les Offenses.'" Hebert shares many other themes and attitudes with P.K. Page. Giguere contrasts Saint-Denys Garneau's Jansenist manicheanism and Francois Hertel's misogyny with the physical love in Anne Hebert's poetry. In the early work, including the plays, Giguere finds a fear of sensual love, which turns into a sado-masochistic obsession in some of her poems ("Inventaire," "La Fille maigre," and "La Chambre fermee" are quoted as examples). The paroxysm is found in "Le Tombeau des rois." In later poems "... la porte se transforme en Eve du debut du monde et celebre les noces avec la nature dans une poesie sensuelle et charnelle pleinement incarnee."

C258      Fournier, Gerard-Claude. "Quatre grands pontes: Garneau, Hebert, Grandbois, Lasnier." In Le Quebecois et sa litterature. Ed. and introd. Rend Dionne. Sherbrooke: Naaman, 1984, pp. 176, 181-85. Fournier provides bio-bibliographical details on Hebert, seen as one of the founders of modern Quebec poetry, and gives a brief analysis of her three volumes of poetry. Les Songes en equilibre contains images which prefigure later thematic developments of death, enclosure, revolt. The confrontation with the self is found in Le Tombeau des rois, where ".. le parcours onirique du recueil sera repris dans le dernier poeme ...." This poem suggests the arrival of a new freedom, "... un mode d'etre affranchi du songe vecu tout au long du recueil." This freedom is found, of course, in Mystere de la parole, where, although some negative elements from the preceding volumes do appear, they appear only to be banished unequivocally, "pour mieux affirmer la victoire de l'affranchissement vers la vie .... son oeuvre poetique ... se situe par sa richesse et son exemplarite comme une des plus belles et des plus importantes de la litterature quebecoise"

C259      Gerols, Jacqueline. Le Roman quebecois en France. Cahiers du Quebec, Collection Litterature. Montreal: Hurtubise HMH, 1984, pp. 8, 12, 15, 35, 42-43, 63, 80, 158-65, 169, 171, 173, 198, 202-03, 205-12, 226-29, 233-35, 238, 244-45, 261-62, 266-68, 283-84, 286, 301-03, 306-07, 314, 323, 326-27, 353-56. Gerols gives a detailed study of the tastes of the book-buying public in France, the reputation and practices of various publishers, and the critical and commercial success of the Quebec novel in France. Statistics on sales and press runs, furnished by the publishers, are given. Les Chambres de bois, for example, was launched with the distribution of 2,549 press copies, as compared to 2,137 press copies for Kamouraska. It is the latter, of course, which was the outstanding commercial success, being one of only two Quebec novels to sell over 200,000 copies. Gerols quotes extensively from press reviews of Kamouraska (an extensive Bibliography of reviews in France is given, pages 353-56). The success of the novel stems from several factors, the most important being the novel's exotic Canadian flavour, its story of passion, and its modern, yet conservative, style. It also coincided with the French public's perception of a new Canadian myth; the struggling hero resisting the English dominance has replaced the earlier favourite myth of Canada as portrayed in Louis Hemon's Maria Chapdelaine. When Hebert is compared to well-known writers, she is most often likened to Emily Bronte or Balzac, both in favourable senses. Gerols demonstrates that Quebec writers, despite a general awareness by the French of the political climate in Canada, are still seen in France as "Canadian" and not "Quebec" writers. The study concentrates on the period 1945-75.

C260      Lamontagne, Gilles. "Poemes, d'Anne Hebert." Dictionnaire des oeuvres litteraires du Quebec. Tome IV: 1960-1969 (1984). The complexity of the parallel structures which exist between the two parts of Poemes is outlined. Even the two prose texts, by Pierre Emmanuel and by Anne Hebert, can be seen in this light. Le Tombeau des rois presents an obsession with security and death, associated principally with water images. This imagery undergoes a remarkable change in Mystere de la parole: "Ici, l'eau n'est plus associee a une regression dans les profondeurs de la nuit. lieu de l'indetermination ou se melent les cauchemars et les monstres; elle signifie plutot regeneration. La vie, l'amour, le chant ... vont etre liberes." Mystere de la parole completes the "opposition entre reve et reverie, incommunicabilite et ouverture," which is first seen in Les Songes en equilibre. The analysis is followed by a Bibliography.

C261      Le Blanc, Alonzo. "Le Temps sauvage, drame d'Anne Hebert." Dictionnaire des oeuvres litteraires du Quebec. Tome IV: 1960-1969 (1984). A resume of the action of Le Temps sauvage is given. "Une veine feministe traverse cette piece ou Anne Hebert a beaucoup investi d'elle-meme. Les personnages representent divers aspects du moi et de la pensee de l'ecrivaine: Agnes se revolte contre une societe dominee par les males et les clercs ...." The mixed reception of the work is due to the excessively literary and lyrical quality of the play: "... la piece conserve une allure trop litteraire .... les repliques des personnages, plus lyriques qu'incisives, ne sont pas toujours integrees au conflit central ...." The play nonetheless marks an important point in Hebert's evolution. The entry is completed by a Bibliography.

C262      Lemieux, Denise. Une culture de la nostalgie: l'enfant dans le roman quebecois de ses origines nos jours. Montreal: Boreal Express, 1984, pp. 32-35, 50-53, 109-11,140, 143, 148-49, 160, 163, 164, 170-71, 186. Lemieux studies the evolution of social stereotypes as they are reflected in the novel. The house as a symbol of refuge, for example, evolves in Hebert's work from the social prestige of Augustin's house ("Un grand mariage"), to the lowly cabin in the woods of Julie (Les Enfants du sabbat). Frequently characters rebell against this refuge to free themselves from the past: Julie, for example, dreams of the burning cabin, and Catherine also dreamed of the seigneurial mansion being burned (in Les Chambres de bois). The theme of dispossession is also linked to the parental house, seen in Hebert's first two novels. In family relationships, incest between siblings is a frequent theme and is a means of rebelling against the parental world and maintaining the childhood world (Les Chambres de bois, Les Enfants du sabbat). The stereotyped image of the parents also surfaces: the father is a failed priest, the mother a dominant figure. The image of the mother becomes completely negative in Les Enfants du sabbat, a completion of the negative image first seen in "Le Torrent." The title of the study stresses the nostalgia generally held for the state of early childhood, the only time when love can be freely claimed or given. As Elisabeth (Kamouraska) demonstrates, she was happiest when she was "la petite," and Francois (Le Temps sauvage) reminds his family that happiness has to be paid for.

C263      Major, J.-L. "Hebert, Anne." Dictionnaire des litteratures de langue francaise, G-O (Paris, 1984). Major gives an overview of all of Hebert's work up to Heloise. Her work, in some aspects, is "la fine pointe de l'imaginaire collectif," as well as an embodiment of Quebec society's "volonte de s'exprimer et de s'affirmer." Major comments on the diversity of genres and the recurrent themes, images, and situations, the "reseau intertextuel complexe." He finds that many of Hebert's works have "un meme schema dynamique: une forme d'inferiorite sociale ou d'asservissement psychologique suivie d'une revolte." This thematic constant also expresses "une irreductible tension entre culture et nature ...." The opposition of "culture" -- associated with the past, death -- and "nature" -- associated with physical sensations and revolt -- also invokes a search for self-identity and the basic question of Hebert's work: "Ou est 'la vraie vie'?"

C264      Poulin, Gabrielle. "Le Temps des metamorphoses (1958-1979)." In Le Quebecois et sa litterature. Ed. and introd. Rene Dionne. Sherbrooke: Naaman, 1984, pp. 117-20. Anne Hebert's Les Chambres de bois and Gerard Bessette's La Bagarre are both works which "annoncent le bouleversement de l'univers romanesque quebecois." Although Catherine escapes from the enclosing rooms, the novel remains ambiguous. "Aucune antimonie n'est encore resolue ...," says Poulin, referring to "la vie, la mort; le reel, le reve; le mensonge, la verite." Catherine's struggle tends to be repeated by each new Hebertian heroine. "En somme, tout se passe comme si, a chacune des ses nouvelles tentatives romanesques, Anne Hebert revenait toujours, sur les pas de Catherine, vers les chambres de bois et tentait, avec elle, de rendre au mari-enfant la petite bague du songe .... les femmes de l'univers hebertien se revelent etrangement vulnerables. La liberte, comme l'amour, prend ... le visage menacant de la mort." But the most important influence of the novel is to be found in its form, which opened the way for a whole new wave of novelists who experimented with the form of the novel.

C265      Resnick, Margery, and Isabelle de Courtivron. Women Writers in Translation: An Annotated Bibliography, 1945-1982. New York: Garland, 1984, pp. 93, 94, 103-04. Bibliographical data.

C266      Sullivan, Rosemary. Introduction. In Stories by Canadian Women. Ed. Rosemary Sullivan. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1984, pp. xiii-xiv. Sullivan briefly notes that Hebert's "early works show an absorption with entrapment and spiritual deprivation .... In 'House on the Esplande' -- which evokes the traditions of French literature with its Flaubertian rigour of language and commitment to style -- Stephanie Bichette ... is as much a symbol as a person, a female sacrifice to the outmoded cult of patriarchy" and "suggests Hebert's demand for a new order."

C267      Whiteman, Bruce. The Archive of the Macmillan Company of Canada Ltd.: Part I, 1905-1965 [Library Research News (McMaster Univ.), 8, No. 1 (Spring 1984)], 61. Whiteman lists one archival holding for Le Torrent, plus lists for other authors.

C268      Francoli, Yvette. "Griffin Creek: refuge des fous de Bassan et des Bessons fous." Etudes litteraires [Univ. de Laval], 17 (avril 1984), 131-42. The motifs of twins and madness are used to express the themes of love, death, and motherhood, or the lost paradise of childhood. Francoli describes the "ecriture narcissique chargee de valeur symbolique, effets de miroir, multiples facettes d'un meme episode qui se reflete l'infini puisque chacun des narrateurs ecrit son histoire en l'integrant a ses propres fantasmes, a sa propre mythologie, d'ou l'extreme complexite des themes psychologiques qui s'entrecroisent dans ce recit." Francoli demonstrates that incest is one of the central obsessions of this work, evident in the complex relationships that exist between the inhabitants of Griffin Creek. The pastor not only sins with his niece, but also longs to be reunited with his mother, Felicity. The self-destruction of this community is an attempt to return to the lost paradise of childhood: "Il n'est donc point d'autre solution pour retrouver le 'paradis perdu' de renfance et de la mere que la Mort."

C269      Couillard, Marie. "Ecrire et vivre au Quebec des femmes: Impression et expression d'une culture." NDQ: North Dakota Quarterly [Univ. of North Dakota], 52, No. 3 (Summer 1984), 95-96. Couillard analyzes briefly Kamouraska, Les Enfants du sabbat, and Heloise as works which destroy the conventional stereotypes of "man the protector," eventually inverting this image. In Kamouraska, the three images of men are the "seigneur assassine," the "saint damne," and the "Epoux et Pere gisant a l'agonie," "somme toute de bien pietres heros." Similarly, in Les Enfants du sabbat, all the male characters are reduced to "leur stricte verite" through the mockery of Soeur Julie. The inversion of the hero is completed in Heloise, where Bernard "n'est plus que la chose" of Heloise.

C270      Duquette, Jean-Pierre. "Le Porte et la parole." Ecrits du Canada francais, 54 (1985), 11-14. Duquette's brief critical overview draws on earlier comments by Serge A. Theriault (C8), Albert Le Grand (C59), and Andre Rousseaux (D19), and also cites Hebert's own critical work entitled "Quand il est question de nommer la vie tout court, nous ne pouvons que balbutier" (B153). "Mais ce qui se reconnait a coup stir, depuis Les Songes en equilibre jusqu'aux Fous de Bassan, c'est un ton, un style uniques, nourris des elements d'une symbolique riche et diverse, avec quelques motifs privilegies .... cette oeuvre qui continue de se concerter sous nos yeux est, veritablement, classique, au sens le plus noble et le plus fort de ce terme: il est aussi vrai de l'affirmer de la poesie que de la prose."

C271      McGregor, Gaile. The Wacousta Syndrome: Explorations in the Canadian Langscape. Toronto: Univ. of Toronto Press, 1985, pp. 103, 105, 106, 108, 123-24, 129, 131, 149-50, 152, 229, 250, 282, 285, 298, 303, 321, 330-31, 364, 365, 371, 374, 384. Reference is made, mainly to Kamouraska and The Silent Rooms, to illustrate such themes as the failed marriage, the trap of love, sex as an act of aggression rather than an act of love, art as a menace to life, or fairy tales that are associated with death and dying.

C272      Sachs, Murray. "Love on the Rocks: Anne Hebert's Kamouraska." In Traditionalism, Nationalism and Feminism: Women Writers of Quebec. Ed. Paula Gilbert Lewis. Contributions in Women's Studies, No.53. Westport, Conn.: Greenwood, 1985, pp. 109-23. Sachs examines the relationship between historical setting and characterization in Kamouraska. The novel's place in Hebert's work is also analyzed in terms reminiscent of Delbert W. Russell (C11) and Albert Le Grand (C59, C87). Sachs comments that cinematographic techniques were first used by Hebert in Les Chambres de bois, which has, as well, the same plot situation and character types as Kamouraska. But "... Les Chambres de bois was a kind of preliminary sketch, or rehearsal, for the eventual composition of her most fully realized masterpiece, Kamouraska." Sachs analyzes in more detail the novel's double narrative voice and skilful manipulation of point of view. In the end, the novel goes beyond the tragic central character to suggest a wider human tragedy, both male and female, connected in part with the harsh physical reality of the country.

C273      Bishop, Neil B. "Energie textuelle et production de sens: images de l'energie dans Les Fous de Bassan d'Anne Hebert." University of Toronto Quarterly, 54 (Feb. 1985), 178-99. Bishop begins with the hypothesis that "... toute problematique de la liberation implique une didgese de l'energie en fonction de ses lieux d'investissement, son comportement, et son destin." He takes the moment of the murder as "l'apogee de la diegese, ce moment ou l'energie textuelle se manifeste le plus intensement, moment evoque avec la redondance de l'obsession par le texte qui focalise ainsi rattention et le suspense ...." He distinguishes four types or stages of energy in the text: harmonious energy; "energie 'pregnante'" or potentially explosive energy; "entropie energetique" or destructive and expanding energy; and "la chute de l'energie." The images in the text of' the first stage are found in the descriptions and speech of the female characters, who see themselves as at one with nature and whose movements are structured and constructive, such as dancing or swimming. The male characters are associated with the third stage, destructive and chaotic energy. Male aggressiveness and sadism, which Bishop sees as the central qualities of males in the novel, lead both men and women to destruction. The four stages of energy, moving from harmony, through a transitional stage to destructive chaos, and returning to peaceful repose, also reflect the structure of the novel. The text projects the character's kinetic state onto its descriptions of the natural world, which becomes a metaphor of the inner world of the character. Throughout the novel the wind is a symbol of destructive sexual desire. Initially the book of Nora begins positively, in harmony with nature. The arrival of Stevens introduces perturbations, leading from the feminine world of daylight, and eros, to the chaotic night and thanatos of male desire. The conclusion that Bishop is led to after a detailed study of this diegisis in the text, is that "Les Fous de Bassan fait entendre que les desirs masculin et feminin different fondamentalement: le premier suscite une energie entropique destructice, voire meurtriere, qui aboutit la violence et a la mort; le desir feminin, par contre, anime une energie positive .... Les Fous de Bassan presente ainsi une image globalement dysphorique et pessimiste de la condition feminine et des rapports hommes-femmes."

C274      Sirois, Antoine. "Bible, mythes et Fous de Bassan." Canadian Literature, No.104 (Spring 1985), pp. 178-82. Sirois counts over one hundred quotations, adaptations, or references to the Bible in Les Fous de Bassan. This frequent use of Scripture is consistent with Hebert's avowed interest in the Bible and the characters she has drawn. The setting of the novel parallels the biblical fall of man; "Le fruit a croquer, dans ce drame contemporain, c'est celui du sexe ..." After the Fall, the novel continues the biblical parallel of the expulsion and punishment of the transgressor. In short, the Bible "offre au recit actuel une prefiguration, un module de deroulement clairement identifie, un pattern de lecture." But, although Hebert uses the Bible for a mythic pattern underlying her novel, she also uses other mythological allusions to widen the scope of the work. Among the many Classical mythical allusions, the myth of Prometheus is the most important, seen in the ravaging of Stevens' heart by the Fous de Bassan, an obsession that will haunt him forever. Hebert skilfully uses these mythical elements in her own original and creative work.

C275      Ewing, Ronald. "Griffin Creek: The English World of Anne Hebert." Canadian Literature, No. 105 (Summer 1985), pp. 100-10. "The Englishness of Griffin Creek seems to serve three main purposes: one, to portray accurately the situation of the rural EnglishQuebecer in the past and in the present; two, to allow Hebert to create a mood and use a writing style which are both strongly identified with William Faulkner; three, to illustrate how a closed society will eventually destroy itself." The parallels with Faulkner are stressed. There is not just the obvious parallel between Faulkner's Benji of The Sound and the Fury and Hebert's Perceval; a more revealing parallel is found between Nicolas Jones and Stevens Brown and two characters from Faulkner's Light in August, the Reverend Gail Hightower and Joe Christmas. "The similarities between Stevens Brown and Joe Christmas form the most important connection between the two novels. The characters, however, are not identical though they share many traits and have common experiences. Hebert seems to use Light in August as a backdrop not as a model." Both characters "occasionally act as if they are not in control of their destinies. They are both harshly disciplined as children, and it seems the violence which they suffered must be passed on to somebody else ... Both Stevens and Joe have unhealthy relations with the opposite sex ... Like Joe Christmas, Stevens can be viewed as an Anti-Christ." These parallels do not dominate the novel, "... however, they do add depth and complexity ...." The destruction of the closed society is seen as inevitable in the novel because of the closed nature of the society, not because it is an English town in Quebec. The town's coverup of the crime is a sign that the town no longer recognizes evil. The town is as guilty as Stevens, and "... the cancer is within."

C276      Green, Mary Jean. "The Witch and the Princess: The Feminine Fantastic in the Fiction of Anne Hebert." American Review of Canadian Studies, 15 (Summer 1985), 137-46. Green demonstrates how Hebert has reworked a theme from Hans Christian Andersen's The Little Mermaid in her novel Les Fous de Bassan. "Hebert's conscious reworking of the fairy-tale material shifts the cruelty and injustice from the female witch to human male sexuality, and, if there is any afterlife in store for Hebert's Olivia, it consists not in earning the right to possess an eternal soul but rather in attaining reunion with the maternal spirits who have warned her away from Stevens: in Hebert's version, Andersen's witch becomes one with his princess." In Hebert's first three novels, she was concerned with the conflict between, "to use [Tzvetan] Todorov's terminology, a natural and a supernatural explanation of the events which have taken place." The heroines may choose the "supernatural" explanation offered by patriarchal myths of women, or they may choose to reject these stereotypes and seek their own reality. In Les Chambres de bois and Les Enfants du sabbat, the heroines refuse to play either witch or princess, while Elizabeth in Kamouraska never escapes from the male vision of woman. The legend of La Corriveau can be seen as a subtext for Kamouraska.

C277      Paterson, Janet M. "'Ah! Perceval, qui etiezvous donc?'." In Solitude rompue. Cahiers du CRCCF, 23. Ed. Cecile Cloutier-Wojciechowska and Rejean Robidoux. Ottawa: Editions de l'Univ, d'Ottawa, 1986, pp. 287-93. The allusion of the name Perceval is presented as "une intertextualite que nous qualifierons de 'complementaire' puisqu'elle permet d'elargir ... le champs de signification." The parrallels between "Le Torrent" and the mediaeval Perceval by Chretien de Troyes are numerous: both have the same family situation of an isolated, fatherless adolescent who reaches maturity in the narrative. In both narratives the psychological evolution is touched off by a chance meeting with a stranger and affected by guilt associated with the death of the mother. Above all, the quest structure and the question of responsibility for sin and personal liberty is basic to both narratives. The intertextuality of Perceval and "Le Torrent" serves to express the positive possibilities of Francois' revolt: "... son role c'est de laisser transparaitre une verite cachee et inavouee. Ce que la nouvelle tait, l'intertexte le murmure."

C278      Stratford, Philip. "Conclusion: The Wings of the Paradox." In his All the Polarities: Comparative Studies in Contemporary Canadian Novels in French and English. Toronto: ECW, 1986, pp. 99, 100, 102, 103, 105. Comparing English-Canadian and Quebec literature, Stratford comments on the theme of abandonment and the restrictive sense of space in Quebec literature, as exemplified in some of H6bert's poems. A sense of entrapment is also central in Kamouraska. At the same time, there is often a spirit of revolt in Quebec fiction, as seen, for example, in Les Enfants du sabbat. But the revolt is rarely consummated. Kamouraska is cited as one of many examples that demonstrate this futile revolt.

C279      Naudin, Marie. "Conscience et (me)connaissance de soi chez Therese Desqueyroux et Elizabeth d'Aulnieres." Etudes canadiennes/ Canadian Studies, No. 20 (juin 1986), pp. 81-86. The comparison of the heroines of Francois Mauriac's Therese Desqueyroux and of Kamouraska shows the affinities between the crimes committed and "the specious logic used to justify them ..." However, "... regardless of time, period or locale, attitudes which are peculiarly bourgeois do not tend to vary."

Previous Entry in publication.

Source: Part 2: Works On Anne Hebert. Russell, D.W. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 145-263

Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Books, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews and profiles, adaptation, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Awards and honours  

Russell, D.W. (compiler)

Awards and Honours

C357       Prix David, for Les Songes en equilibre (1943).

C358       Grant from the Royal Society of Canada which allows her to write in Paris (1954).

C359       Prix Duvernay from the Societe Saint-Jean Baptiste (1958).

C360       Prix France-Canada(1958).

C361       Prix litteraire de la province du Quebec for Les Chambres de bois (1959).

C362       Elected member of the Royal Society of Canada (1960).

C363       The Governor-General's Award for Poetry for Poemes (1961).

C364       Special Artist's Grant, given by The Canada Council (1961-62).

C365       The Molson Literary Prize (1967).

C366       The Prix Desbordes-Valmore, awarded by the Societe des pontes francais (1968).

C367       Companion of the Order of Canada (1969).

C368       Honorary LL.D., University of Toronto (1969).

C369       Prix de l'Academie royale de Belgique for Kamouraska (1971).

C370       Prix des Libraires (Paris) for Kamouraska (1971).

C371       Governor-General's Award for Fiction for Les Enfants du sabbat (1976).

C372       The Prix de l'Academie francaise for Les Enfants du sabbat (1976).

C373       The Prix Prince Pierre de Monaco (1976).

C374       Prix David (1978).

C375       Honorary LL.D., Universite de Quebec Montreal (1979).

C376       Honorary LL.D., McGill University (1980).

C377       Prix Femina for Les Fous de Bassan (1982).

C378       Honorary LL.D., Universite de Laval (1983).

C379       Medal of the Academie canadienne-francais (1984).

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Anne Hebert. Russell, D.W. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 145-263

Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Books, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews and profiles, adaptation, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Books  

Russell, D.W. (compiler)

Part II: Works on Anne Hebert

[underbar]

C     Books, Articles and Sections of Books, Theses and Dissertations, Interviews and Profiles, Adaptation, Miscellaneous, and Awards and Honours

Books

C1      Robert, Guy. La Poetique du songe. Introduction a l'oeuvre d'Anne Hebert. Les Cahiers de I'A.G.E.U.M., No. 4. Montreal: Association generale des etudiants de l'Univ, de Montreal, 1962. 125 pp. Robert presents a thematic study of the imagery in the works up to and including Mystere de la parole. The analysis discusses all the works with reference to specific themes. Chapter i presents the themes of time, death, anguish, despair, God, and mother; Chapter ii, the themes of water, games, magic, mirrors, and daydreams; Chapter iii, dance, music, laughter, the smile, love, and lucidity; Chapter iv, the witness, the cat, the hand, the room, and solitude. A final chapter attempts to draw all these themes together and to establish the "poetique du songe." The element of dream is seen as a constant in her work, which also expresses a presence "au monde et a soi." This book was originally Robert's thesis (C282).

C2      Page, Pierre. Anne Hebert. Ecrivains canadiens d'aujourd'hui. Montreal: Fides, 1965. 189 pp. Since this book also includes a section of works by Hebert, each piece has been listed separately in the appropriate section of Sections B and C of this bibliography. See B107, C44, and C45.

C3      Lacote, Rene. Anne Hebert: une etude avec un choix de poemes, soixante illustrations, une chronique bibliographique: Anne Hebert et son temps. Pontes d'aujourd'hui, No. 189. Paris: Seghers, 1969. 188 pp. Since this book includes a section of works by Hebert, each piece has been listed separately in the appropriate section of Sections B and C of this bibliography. See B56, B58, Bl16, C68, and C69.

C4      Le Grand, Albert. Anne Hebert (Francais 341, Univ. de Montreal, Faculte des Arts et des Sciences, Liste externe). Montreal: Librairie de l'Univ, de Montreal, 1973. 228 pp. In this thorough study of the prose works, Le Grand reprints material from his articles, "Anne Hebert: de rexil au royaume" (1968) and "Kamouraska ou l'ange et la bete" (1971), as well as new material on "Le Torrent." His analysis of the latter is particularly detailed. He includes a large selection of press reviews of the works.

C5      Major, Jean-Louis. Anne Hebert et le miracle de la parole. Collection "Lignes quebecoises." Montreal: Les Presses de l'Univ, de Montreal, 1976. 114 pp. Major examines the two parts of the volume Poemes, namely Le Tombeau des rois and Mystere de la parole. Major shows that the second volume of poems picks up specific structures from the first, to offer a positive restatement: "la reprise des valeurs ferrules du Tombeau des rois pour les ouvrir a la vie, a la lumiere et a l'espace." Examples are "Survienne la rose des vents" and "De plus en plus etroit," "La Ville tuee" and "Les Petites Villes," "La sagesse m'a rompu les bras" and "La Chambre de bois." In particular, Major studies the title poem of each volume in some detail, bringing in references to other poems from her work to support his analysis. Major concludes that Hebert's poetry does not so much present the act of transformation as the result of this transformation; the poetic technique he finds in "Mystere de la parole" is a means "d'assurer le pouvoir de la parole plutot que de l'assumer." He asks further: "... l'auteur s'est-il libere au detriment de la poesie? On est en droit de se le demander et, peut-etre, de le deplorer." His pessimism with respect to "Mystere de la parole" is attenuated, however, by his admission that the work has maturity and forceful language. He suggests that it is, finally, a new beginning in her work, and may be analogous to Les Songes en equilibre within the context of the development of her work: "... il confirme une experience plus qu'il ne l'accomplit comme ecriture."

C6      Bouchard, Denis. Une lecture d'Anne Hebert: la recherche d'une mythologie. Cahiers du Quebec, Collection litteraire, 34. Montreal: Hurtubise HMH, 1977. 242 pp. Bouchard focuses on the poem "Le Tombeau des rois" in the first half and on Les Enfants du sabbat in the second half. Bouchard discusses at some length Hebert's family background and the influence of Saint-Denys Garneau on her work. He suggests snobbish elitism on Hebert's part and tends to dismiss her previous critics. The final forty-two pages of Bouchard's book are devoted to a supplementary bibliographical study which attempts to assess the reception offered Hebert's works in the popular press. The material is divided into two periods, the reception of works published before Kamouraska, and the reception of Kamouraska and Les Enfants du sabbat, in order to demonstrate the connection between the publicity given a work and its financial success. The book includes Bouchard's "Erotisme et sublimination" (C123), "Les Enfants du sabbat d'Anne Hebert: l'enveloppe des mythes" (C141), "Anne Hebert, situation de l'ecrivain" (C151), and "La Solitude rompue" (C153).

C7      Lemieux, Pierre-Herve. Entre songe et parole: structure du "Tombeau des rois" d'Anne Hebert. Cahiers du centre de recherche en civilisation canadienne-francaise, 15. Ottawa: Editions de l'Univ, d'Ottawa, 1978. 249 pp. This study is a publication of Lemieux's dissertation (C300), in which he discusses the dichotomy between "songe" and "parole" in Hebert's work, especially in Le Tombeau des rois. The movement from the silence of unspoken dreams to the articulation of speech in poetry is chronicled in the seven chapters of the book. Lemieux makes frequent allusions to the existence of the same or similar images in earlier or later works by Hebert. The passage from "songe" to "parole" was made possible by Le Tombeau des rois and this has permitted the writer to "revenir d'outre-tombe, de dialoguer avec le monde et avec son histoire, de mettre profit la virtualite multiple de l'axe poetique."

C8      Theriault, Serge A. La Quete de l'equilibre dans l'oeuvre romanesque d'Anne Hebert. Hull: Asticou, 1980. 223 pp. Theriault's Structuralist and psychological analysis is based on his dissertation (C317). Andre Niel's L'Analyse structurale des textes is the major source of inspiration, along with the psychology of transactional analysis, as found in the writings of Eric Berne. A brief introduction outlines the theoretical basis of the study, which borrows from the transactional psychology of Euguene Gendlin and uses various Structuralist paradigms in its analysis of the relationships "moi-autrui-le monde" with respect to the characters in Les Chambres de bois, Kamouraska, and Les Enfants du sabbat. Theriault supplies a brief glossary of the terminology used in his study, as well as a Bibliography of primary and secondary sources.

C9      Bibliotheque du Seminaire de Sherbrooke, comp. Anne Hebert: Dossier de presse 1942-1980. Sherbrooke: Bibliotheque du Seminaire de Sherbrooke, 1981.134 pp. This consists of photocopies of newspaper clippings compiled from Quebec newspapers.

C10      Harvey, Robert. Kamouraska d'Anne Hebert: une ecriture de la Passion, suive de Pour un nouveau Torrent. Les Cahiers du Quebec, Collection Litteraire. Montreal: Hurtubise HMH, 1982. 211 pp. The major part of this book is based closely on Harvey's M.A. thesis (C320). In the last part, pages 131-84, Harvey examines Le Torrent, showing "La fonction matricielle de la structure symbolique du Torrent dans l'oeuvre d'Anne Hebert." The analysis of Le Torrent makes frequent reference to all the other works up to Heloise, in its presentation of the dramatic constant in these works. "Une alchimie sacree semble toujours vouloir s'operer a l'interieur d'une Trinite de personnages dont l'exces du desir constitue le ferment." This basic interaction of three main characters in each work is discussed in detail with respect to Kamouraska and "Le Torrent."

C11      Russell, Delbert W. Anne Hebert. Twayne's World Authors Series, No. 684. Boston: Twayne, 1983.155 pp. Russell provides a comprehensive overview of all the works published up to Heloise, which concentrates on the evolution of literary forms and the development of themes within Hebert's work. The experimentation with literary forms and complex themes found in the early poetry and drama is replaced by both greater realism and more successful handling of symbolism in the stories. The exploration of the individual psyche achieves an effective combination of form and theme in Le Tombeau des rois, which successfully develops elements found in her earlier work. Hebert moves beyond the intensely restricted world of her poetry in her later works to depict and explore a wider social context, as well as to analyze the relationship between the artist and society. Despite her remarkable success in the novel with Kamouraska and Les Enfants du sabbat, she continues to experiment with literary forms, as can be seen in L'Ile de la demoiselle (B147), a radio play set in the sixteenth century.

C12      Emond, Maurice. La Femme a la fenetre: l'univers symbolique d'Anne Hebert dans Les Chambres de bois, Kamouraska, et Les Enfants du sabbat. Vie des Lettres quebecoises, No. 622. Quebec: Les Presses de l'Univ. Laval, 1984. 392 pp. The thesis on which this study is based (C323) has been recast and reorganized for publication as a book. Emond's critical perspective remains the same as in the thesis, of course, but he here reduces the length and number of quotations, particularly from secondary sources. His critical approach to Hebert's work is based on theoretical and critical works of Gaston Bachelard, Jean-Pierre Richard, Jean Rousset, and Gilbert Durand. The study is divided into three main parts: "Une symbolique du noir et du blanc," "Une dialectique de l'eau et du feu," and "Une poetique du regard"; these are followed by a general conclusion and a detailed Bibliography. The images which Emond studies form two main groups or "regimes"; "le regime diurne" and "le regime nocturne." In the first part of the study, Emond discusses "le regime de l'image que privilegie l'auteure, l'evolution possible d'un regime a l'autre ou la valorisation parallele des deux regimes." He notes "le manicheisme des images, le dualisme impenitent d'un univers de contrastes dechire par des forces antithetiques" In the final chapter in this section, Emond discusses the images "qui illustrent une transformation des valeurs symboliques sous l'impulsion du regime nocturne de rimaginaire. Ce renversement symbolique permet a l'auteure d'echapper temporairement a la tentation omnipresente de regime diurne de la representation et illustre la vitalite et la complexite d'une imagination aux ressources insoupconnees." In the second part, Emond presents the symbolic values attached to the dialectically opposed images of fire and water, for "... il nous est vite apparu que ces deux elements, dans l'imagination materielle d'Anne Hebert, refletent avec le plus d'intensite et de fide1ite les forces antithetiques ou de synthese de son univers symbolique." This is seen in the images of snow in Kamouraska which replace "en quelque sorte, l'impossible union de l'eau et du feu en devenant la grande transformatrice." Snow "vient rassembler les multiples ambivalences de la symbolique du noir et du blanc et de la dialectique de l'eau de du feu." In the third part, Emond studies the "poetique du regard," to demonstrate that the theme of the "regard" is a basic organizing structure in Hebert's work. This theme is expressed by images of eyes, windows, mirrors: "Yeux, fenetres et miroirs sont des regards multiplies. Ils sont les soutiens dynamiques d'une poetique du regard .... Il y a, dans l'oeuvre d'Anne Hebert, une presence constante des miroirs dans un univers ou le jeu des regards est reflete a l'infini. Dans ces espaces reduits oh vivent les personnages, maisons fermees, chambres, appartements, le miroir vient offrir au regard une fenetre supplementaire, a la fois securisante et troublante, qui s'ouvre sur un monde imaginaire ... qui sauvegarde souvent toutes les apparences du reel tout en le niant constamment. Il est idealisation ou deformation angoissante." Although Emond's study concentrates on the three novels mentioned in his title, he also refers in passing to Hebert's other works. The Bibliography is revised to bring it up to date since the writing of his thesis.

C13      Roy, Lucille. Entre la lumiere et l'ombre: l'univers poetique d'Anne Hebert. Collection Theses ou Recherches, No.17. Sherbrooke: Naaman, 1984. 204 pp. This study is based on Roy-Hewitson's dissertation (C319). Roy has completely reworked the material, however, updating the Bibliography and including studies of Hebert published since 1979 in her discusssion of Hebert's work. Also included are chapters on Heloise and Les Fous de Bassan, both of which were published after Roy's dissertation was written. These latter works are analyzed as further proof of Roy's initial thesis: "Au coeur de son oeuvre reside une poesie qui constelle autour de deux themes a la fois contraires et connexes, tels l'envers et l'endroit d'une seule et meme realite. Il s'agit de la lumiere et de l'ombre .... Mouvement cyclique ou parabolique, l'ombre ici s'eclaire, et la lumiere rappelle les tenebres, hun rythme de plus en plus accelere a mesure que de nouvelles oeuvres s'ajoutent au Tombeau des rois et au Mystere de la parole. On avance, en effet, dans cet univers comme dans un labyrinthe, toutes les voles ayant ete tracees d'avance, a travers maints dedales, vers une issue unique." This study is divided into three parts (each with two chapters): "La Lumiere," "L'Ombre," "Entre la lumiere et rombre"; followed by a conclusion, a detailed Bibliography, and Indexes of authors and works. Chapter vi, the concluding section of Part III, is devoted entirely to a discusssion of Heloise, which Roy sees as an important work in the Hebert canon. Roy says, "... route l'oeuvre d'Anne Hebert... annoncait [Heloise], tout nous preparait a acceuillir ce roman etrange ou se joue a chaque page la dialectique de la lumiere et de rombre, source de vie et de mort. I1 n'y a rien d'inconnu dans cet univers, rien qui ne soit pas tout de suite identifiable dans l'ensemble des oeuvres d'Anne Hebert." In Heloise and Les Fous de Bassan, "... l'auteur depasse l'alternance manifeste dans Kamouraska et Les Enfants du sabbat. Ainsi que les personnages des Fous de Bassan, Bernard vit simultanement, dans la plus grande partie du recit, l'emprise de la lumiere et de l'ombre, tout comme a la fin il aspire en meme temps a la vie et a la mort. En aimant Christine et Heloise, symboles des deux puissances opposees, le heros se manifeste a la fois diurne et nocturne." The ending of Heloise is ambiguous: "L'issue meme du recit demeure ambivalente. Le geste par lequel le heros affirme son amour pour Christine, la lumiere et la vie, constitue aussi le moment ou il se soumet Heloise, a l'ombre et a la mort; comme si, dans ce court roman ou l'auteur devoile clairement les deux principes de son oeuvre, elle n'avait su donner la victoire ni a l'ombre ni a la lumiere. En ce sens, Heloise est une oeuvre de synthese ... Trop schematique peut-etre, elle reste neanmoins tres fiche par son pouvoir d'evocation."

C14      Paterson, Janet M. Anne Hebert: architexture romanesque. Ottawa: Editions de l'Univ. d'Ottawa, 1985. 192 pp. This is a revised version of Paterson's dissertation (C324). Some sections are shortened in this publication, a new section on Les Fous de Bassan has been added, and the Conclusion is revised. The Conclusion restates the arguments made about Les Fous de Bassan: "... dans ce roman comme dans roeuvre romanesque entiere d'Anne Hebert, la fonction representative du discours est modifiee par la projection sur la chaine syntagmatique des composantes paradigmatiques d'un signifiant litteraire; ... ce repli du texte sur lui-meme laisse entendre l'impossibilite de l'ecriture de dire le reel."

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Title:
