Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Anne Hebert. Russell, D.W. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 145-263

Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Books, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews and profiles, adaptation, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Interviews and profiles  

Russell, D.W. (compiler)

Interviews and Profiles

Note: Not included in this listing are a number of radio and television guest appearances and interviews, both in Canada and Europe, for which no archival holdings have been found and, consequently, for which no annotation was possible.

C327       Lasnier, Michelle. "Anne Hebert la magicienne." Chatelaine, avril 1963, pp. 28-29, 74, 76. Lasnier discusses Hebert's approach to writing, her earlier difficulties in getting her work published, the influence of her family on her early career, as well as her comments on her writing.

C328       Saint-Germain, Pierre. "Anne Hebert: 'Mes personnages me menent par le bout du nez.' "La Presse [Montreal], 21 dec. 1963, Sec. Cahier Arts et lettres, p. 3. Saint-Germain interviews Hebert in Paris at the time of the re-edition of Le Torrent in Montreal. She discusses the two new stories which are included in this edition -- they are more realistic than the earlier stories, although this is not necessarily an indication of progress. Hebert had not realized to what extent the subject of "Le Torrent" "pouvait etre terrifiant," and the piece seems to her now to be "achevee, murie."

C329       Godin, Gerald. "'J'ai un signe de feu ...': Une entrevue de Gerald Godin avec Anne Hebert." Le Magazine Maclean, fev. 1965, p. 45. Godin interviews Hebert at the time of ber return to Paris for the launching of the Paris edition of Le Torrent. Hebert notes that she writes everything longhand and that she was in Paris when Queen Elizabeth visited Quebec in 1964.

C330       Robidoux, Rejean. "Interview with Anne Hebert." Prod. Jean Raymond St.-Cyr. cJBC Radio [Toronto], 6 sept. 1965. [Archives, Centre de recherche en civilisation canadienne-francaise, Univ. d'Ottawa.] In an interview with Robidoux, Hebert discusses her use of different genres: in the end, each genre is "une facon differente de dire la meme verite." Robidoux also comments on Les Chambres de bois (C46).

C331       [Beaulieu, Francois.] "Theatre ecrit: Anne Hebert, poete-dramaturge" Sept-jours, 15 oct. 1966, pp. 41-42. "Alors que l'univers du 'Torrent' etait extremement reduit, il y a dans 'Le Temps sauvage,' et pour la premiere fois, l'affrontement de toute une famille, veritables personnages tchekhoviens, qui vivent apparemment une existence inutile." Anne Hebert is quoted on her feelings about the play and its production: "Je me suis decouvert, avec la piece, un gout veritable pour la dramaturgie. Il faut dire qu'il est agreable de travailler avec un metteur en scene comme Albert Millaire .... Ce n'est evidemment pas un drame agricole, il se situe au niveau de la pensee, et pour cela meme, les personnages peuvent parfois avoir un air d'irrealite. Ce n'est pas une famille comme on en voit tousles jours .... Ces personnages vivent, independamment presque de moi. Bien sur, je les ai portes cruellement, mais on aurait tort de voir dans la piece, un essai d'autobiographie"

C332       Kauffman, Jean-Paul. "De Paris, elle reinvente le Quebec." Perspectives [La Presse] [Montreal], 12 dec. 1970, Supplement, pp. 8, 10. Hebert is interviewed in her apartment on Boulevard Saint-Germain in Paris and talks of the difficulty of writing Kamouraska. She wrote several versions, and the characters only slowly came to life for her, until finally they almost became obsessive. In response to the comment on the tragic nature of her work, she replies "Je suis d'un pays ou l'on ale gout du malheur." Asked if she feels cut off from Quebec because she lives in Paris, she replies: "Je suis Quebecoise et le resterai toute ma vie." She refuses to be drawn out on the subject of Quebec separatism.

C333       Lafond, Andrdanne. "Anne Hdbert a Paris. Entrevue-express avec l'auteur de Kamouraska." Forces, No. 17 (1971), p. 47. Hebert discusses writing the novel Kamouraska, the making of the film, as well as the reasons why she found it easier to be published in France than in Canada. Although she lives in Paris, she has always written about Canadian subjects; one day she may write about France while living in Quebec.

C334       Tremblay, Gisee. "Kamouraska ou la fureur de vivre." Le Devoir [Montreal], 12 juin 1971, p. 13. Interviewed in Montreal when Kamouraska has become a bestseller and is about to be made into a movie, Hebert discusses the style of the novel. It expresses a "fureur de vivre qui n'est pas typiquement quebecoise, qu'on sent surtout dans la jeunesse du monde entier." The elliptical style of the work was found instinctively, but Hebert feels it expresses well the emotional state of Elisabeth. Hebert attempts to achieve the intensity of poetry in the novel, although it must be more sustained. After a discussion of the character of Elisabeth, they discuss the more general development of Hebert's work; she feels that she has been blessed with a gift of vitality and the need to write; "... moi, ce que je veux faire c'est ecrire, et puis vivre comme n'importe qui ...." Although she lives in France, she will always remain profoundly influenced by Quebec.

C335       Interview with Anne Hebert and Claude Jutra. Quebec Now. CBC Radio, 1 May 1972. Hebert, with voice-over translation, discusses the adaptation of Kamouraska. She notes that, while she was writing the novel, she had already been influenced by film technique. The scenario for the film is not completely different from the novel, yet not the same as the novel. The film remains faithful to the novel, particularly in the use of flashbacks. Hebert says, "Tous les flashbacks et tout ca, il me semble que c'est possible de les faire passer dans le film." Comments on the difficulties of finding suitable locations and costumes, on casting and funding, are made by Claude Jutra, Michel Brault, and Francois Barbeau.

C336       Tadros, Jean-Pierre. "Anne Hebert en entrevue: roeuvre ecrite." Le Devoir [Montreal], 7 avril 1973, p. 23. This is a report of an interview with the author after the premier of the film version of Kamouraska. Hebert speaks of the gradual process by which the film took form; it emphasizes the period flavour of the novel and brings many changes, which she felt were the prerogative of the director of the film, Claude Jutra. For example, the murder becomes very realistic in the film, whereas in the novel it is not.

C337       Basile, Jean. "Rencontre avec Anne Hdbert: soeur Julie qui a bien tourne." Le Devoir [Montreal], 25 oct. 1975, p. 15. Hebert's chances of winning the Prix Goncourt are briefly discussed, along with the reception of Les Enfants du sabbat in Canada and France. Although she lives in Paris, Hebert visits Quebec regularly -- and finds it changed. She prefers to call herself "canadienne" as well as "quebecoise," this latter term meaning only "native of Quebec City." Hebert discusses the factual and sociological basis for Les Enfants du sabbat. Basile cites, in order to corroborate it, the standard myth that Hebert is difficult to interview, in that she never reveals herself to the interviewer.

C338       Lebrun, Paule. "Je ne suis en colere que lorsque j'ecris." Chatelaine, nov. 1976, p. 42. This profile is based on an interview in connection with an article on witchcraft by Lebrun which mentions Les Enfants du sabbat among other works. The discussion centres on the cornposition of Les Enfants du sabbat. Hebert says, "'Quant j'ai commence, pour mon roman, a life sur la sorcellerie, ca m'a rappele l'atmosphere de mon enfance. Le Moyen Age me paraissait proche de la vie que j'avais connue au Quebec.'" She refers to the common beliefs held at the time in Quebec: "Tous ces combats avec le Diable faisaient partie d'une mythologie populaire bien vivante.'" The victimization of women is explicitly commented upon: "'La vie claire, ordonnee, rangee des femmes de ce pays n'etait qu'une surface mince.'" Religion as well is condemned; "'Le christianisme chez nous avait amene une sorte de refoulement de la vie. Ce refoulement se vivait surtout au feminin.'" Women who were strong were made to feel guilty: "Mais les femmes qui avaient du pouvoir, qui pouvaient tenir tete au pouvoir masculin se savaient coupables. Le pouvoir, plus la culpabilite d'etre forte, c'est ca qui devenait le mal." And finally: "Les sorcieres sont des reveateurs, des revelatrices de ce qui existe de latent en chacun de nous."

C339       Dufaux, Paule France. "Si l'on veut que le prix David ait un sens ...." Le Soleil [Quebec], 21 oct. 1978, p. D12. Hebert discusses details of work in progress. L'Ile de la demoiselle (B147) is a play for the French radio-network; Heloise, the novel, was first composed as a film scenario.

C340       Dube, Cecile, Maurice Emond, and Christian Vandendorpe. "Anne Hebert: entrevue." Quebec francais, No. 32 (dec. 1978), pp. 33-36. Rpt. ("Propos") in Romanciers du Quebec. Ed. Quebec francais. Quebec: Quebec francais, 1980, pp. 104-10. The interview briefly examines the strong women characters in Hebert's work, especially Julie de la Trinite. Many of her characters have names which she has found in real life: for example, Amica and Flageole. George Nelson was originally George Wilson, but the Paris publishers wanted Wilson changed because it was the name of a French actor. Hebert also comments on the richness of religious liturgy as a source of her writing and on her love of the cinema, particularly that of Ingmar Bergman. The interview is followed by a biographical sketch and a page of school-exercises based on an extract from Kamouraska.

C341       Martel, Reginaid. "Un simple eloge de l'innocence: une interview." La Presse [Montreal], 1 dec. 1979, pp. B1-3. Hebert discusses her childhood reading, the literary influences introduced by Hector de Saint-Denys Gameau, and her move from poetry to prose. Hebert prefers to avoid self-analysis, to leave her art to function at the level of instinct and intuition. She talks of the difficulty of finding a publisher for Le Torrent (published eventually at her own expense), of the unpublished plays of her youth, and her destruction of many of her manuscripts when she moved to Paris. She recounts the factual basis for both Kamouraska and Les Enfants du sabbat (Hebert remembers going with friends to buy bootleg liquor). She mentions the new novel she has just finished (Heloise) and that she writes occasional poems which are not for publication. Hebert feels that she has not yet written work at a level that she is capable of, and she often fears that what she has written is not as good as it should be. Her weakest work is Les Songes en equilibre; her writing that has given her the greatest satisfaction is Kamouraska and Les Enfants du sabbat.

C342       Royer, Jean. "Anne Hebert: jouer avec le feu." Le Devoir [Montreal], 26 avril 1980, pp. 21, 22. In this interview given in Quebec after the publication of Heloise, Hebert discusses her childhood in Quebec and the development of her writing. On the subject of poetry she states: "... je trois qu'il faut tendre vers l'absolu en sachant bien qu'on ne l'atteindra jamais." She remarks that literary realism is not reality: "... le reve, c'est du reel aussi." On writing: "... ecrire, c'est vraiment jouer avec le feu. Mais ce n'est pas seulement le feu, c'est la lumiere aussi. C'est extraordinaire, la possession de la lumiere. Mais c'est des instants. Tres fulgurants. Des instants tellement lumineux qu'ils ne se remplacent pas."

C343       Smith, Donald. "Anne Hebert et les eaux troubles de l'imaginaire: une entrevue de Donald Smith." Lettres quebecoises, No.20 (hiver 1980-81), pp.64-73. Rpt. (revised "Anne Hebert et les racines de l'imaginaire") in L'Ecrivain devant son oeuvre. By Donald Smith. Montreal: Quebec/l'Amerique, 1983, pp. 35-58. Hebert was educated at home, not because of illness, but because it was traditional among certain families in Quebec City to employ private tutors rather than send children to school at the usual school-starting age. Hebert talks about all her works, from the stories of Le Torrent to Heloise, with the exception of "L'Ile de la demoiselle."

C344       Vanasse, Andre. "L'Ecriture et l'ambivalence: entrevue avec Anne Hebert." Voix & images: litterature quebecoise, 7 (printemps 1982), 441-48. Hebert comments on the difference between prose and poetry, states that the major literary influences on her were Saint-Denys Garneau and the Bible, and that her mother also influenced her. She is interested in psychoanalysis, but does not consciously attempt to use it. Hebert also comments on the importance of the mother in Heloise and on the general francophone dislike for fantasy, which perhaps accounts for the cool reception of this novel.

C345       Duncan, Ann. "Prize-Winning Novelist Hebert 'Spoiled' by Success." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 9 Dec. 1982, Sec. Entertainment, p. 23. In response to comments by the interviewer on Les Fous de Bassan not winning the Prix Goncourt before winning the Prix Femina, Hebert says modestly that she has already "been very spoiled" by the many awards her work has won. She comments on the hardships of her career, for example, the fact that she felt obliged to forgo motherhood in favour of writing. She comments on the discipline required of the writer and on her decision to live in Paris, rather than in Quebec: "I find that when one is too close, one does not see very well what is happening"

C346       Royer, Jean. "Anne Hebert: la passion est un risque, mais c'est un risque indispensable." Le Devoir [Montreal], 11 dec. 1982, pp.21, 40. Rpt. ("La Passion d'ecrire") in Ecrivains contemporains: Entretiens 3: 1980-1983. By Jean Royer. Montreal: L'Hexagone, 1985, pp. 18-22. Hebert is interviewed in Montreal after winning the Prix Femina. She admits to having a long fascination with the Saint Lawrence River ("J'ai toujours ete frappee par le fait que le fleuve possede des marees comme la vraie mer. J'ai reve de tous ces paysages pendant assez longtemps. J'imaginais les personnages. Ces petites colonies fermees.") She finally decided to create an imaginary village, Griffin Creek, as a setting for Les Fous de Bassan, which she began writing in 1977. She is above all interested in portraying human passions, a rare quality which she believes necessary for life: "... pour moi, c'est le pire malheur, l'indifference. La passion c'est un risque. Cependant, c'est indispendable pour faire quelque chose. Il faut risquer de se perdre pour se trouver." In the end, she sees Les Fous de Bassan as "un roman sur le desir."

C347       Faucher, Francoise. "Interview: Anne Hebert: 'J'aurais aime etre avocate, peintre, comedienne .... Mais ecrire resume tout cela.'" L'Actualite, fev. 1983, pp. 11, 12, 14, 15. Hebert comments that the Prix Femina ensures her certain financial security again, as well as a gratifying public recognition. Her life as a writer is of necessity often solitary and arduous, but rewarding. Writing has seemed to encompass all the other things in life she might have otherwise pursued, such as motherhood, other careers. Her own childhood and early love of literature have been constant sources of inspiration in her writing. As a child she was strongly influenced by her mother and by the presence of illness and death in her extended family; she feels less affected by death now than in her youth ("... quand on est jeune, on le decouvre, tandis qu'en vieillissant, au contraire, on voit que ca fait partie de la vie; je ne dis pas qu'on se resigne, mais on s'etonne moins"). Her decision to live in Paris was gradual -- initially she spread a one-year-grant out over three years; since the death of her mother she has lived mainly in Paris. Quebec remains, however, her main inspiration.

C348       Morissette, Brigitte. "Prix Femina '82: lointaine et proche. Anne Hebert." Chatelaine, fev. 1983, pp.47, 48, 50, 52, 54. Morissette describes the suspense before the Prix Goncourt and Prix Femina winners were announced and the subsequent flurry of public receptions before beginning the interview proper. Hebert talks of the genesis of Les Fous de Bassan: she did not, for example, do any research on the Loyalists, but simply imagined the characters and the village setting in the novel. She comments on the Bible as a source of literary language, on her own religious beliefs ("profondement religieuse mais non pratiquante"), and on the need to free one's self from the constraints of traditions. When asked about a possible film version of Les Fous de Bassan, Hebert mentions that she found Claude Jutra's Kamouraska "un beau film, tres proche du roman," which has been unjustly treated by the critics. Les Fous de Bassan would be more difficult to adapt to film, although she has had several proposals about a film version.

C349       Cohen, Matt. "Queen in Exile: Though Now One of Canada's Best-Known Writers, Anne Hebert Still Bears the Scars of a Long Literary Apprenticeship." Books in Canada, Aug.-Sept. 1983, pp. 9-12. Cohen describes Hebert's grace and confidence. Her apartment is like her novels -- "... all speak of deliberate taste: an aesthetic imposed." Hebert discusses her process of writing. Cohen supplies bio- and bibliographical information and notes that in "the 1950s she worked freelance for Radio-Canada" and "for the National Film Board." She is currently working on a film script for Les Fous de Bassan, which Claude Jutra will direct. Her novels "are almost totally impressionistic, relying heavily on dreams, fantasy, flashbacks." She writes through "intuition" and does not necessarily follow the plans for a novel. "Les Fous de Bassan was started several years ago," in the third person, but she changed it a year later to "a multiplicity of first persons:' Cohen notes that the violence in her novels seems "not only to symbolize the plight of women trapped in a patriarchal society, but also of a French society trapped on an English continent," though Hebert says her books are not written "to demonstrate a thesis." Hebert also replied that it was mere coincidence that her most violent characters have been Americans. Although she has resided in Paris for years, she has not "become French." As "a Quebecoise she is finally too uncivilized, too much ruled by instinct and passion. Nor has she cut off her ties with Quebec."

C350       McDonald, Marci. "The Woman Is Not for Taming." Maclean's, 17 Oct. 1983, pp. 62, 64. McDonald briefly describes Hebert's apartment and her character, then notes that "... to read her spare, elegant prose is to plunge into a dark netherworld of Quebec Gothic." Hebert "has conjured up the repressed passions simmering just below the sanctimonious veneer of a prewar society cut off from its cultural roots and stifled by the Roman Catholic Church's medieval grasp." McDonald briefly discusses In the Shadow of the Wind and the Prix Femina and notes that the book "has sold 150,000 copies, with 500,000 more through book club orders." Hebert "is currently writing the first draft of the screen version." Hebert comments on the violence in her books: "'It must be something I can't express in life,' she said, 'because I am only angry when I write. Sometimes I have the feeling I go fishing for monsters as a way to exorcise them from my imagination.'" Biographical data is given. "She confesses to finding herself in a 'no man's land,' unsure of where her imagination will take her. But, implacably, it is certain to lead her back to Quebec and a rude landscape far from the rue de Pontoise. It is there to which she swears she will return someday, denying that she could ever become truly Parisian."

C351       Rihoit, Catherine. "Anne Hebert: l'Heritage partage. Entretien avec Catherine Rihoit." Autrement [Paris], No. 69 (avril 1985), pp. 165-66. Hebert and Rihoit discuss the possible displacement felt by Quebec writers. Hebert says, "Meme si mes veritables racines sont au Canada, j'ai quand meme maintenant des racines en France." Hebert also comments on the effort needed to retain one's language as a francophone in Quebec: "Quand on est dans un environnement principalement anglophone, cela suppose une vigilance de tous les instants, de preserver son francais." This unique position has helped Quebec writers: "C'est peut-etre une situation angoissante, mais cela peut etre aussi un facteur de creativite. Exprimer avec une langue latine une experience de type plutot americain, cela donne un autre regard: c'est un decalage qui peut etre fecond."

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Anne Hebert. Russell, D.W. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 145-263

Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Books, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews and profiles, adaptation, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Miscellaneous  

Russell, D.W. (compiler)

Miscellaneous

C353       Jones, D.G. "Portrait of Anne Hebert." In his The Sun Is Axeman. Toronto: Univ. of Toronto Press, 1961, p. 3. Poem about Anne Hebert.

C354       Anne Hebert. Prod. Virginia Cole. London, Ont.: International Historical Enterprises, [1970?]. (Cassette; 25 min.) The tape provides an analysis of Hebert's poetry.

C355       Marchessault, Jovette. La Saga des poules mouillees. Montreal: La Pleine lune, 1981. 178 pp. Rpt. Saga of the Wet Hens. Trans. Linda Gaboriau. Vancouver: Talonbooks, 1983. 134 pp. A play based on the lives of Laure Conan, Germaine Guevremont, Anne Hebert, and Gabrielle Roy.

C356       Godbout, Claude. "Anne Hebert: Dompter les demons." Profession ecrivain, No. 8. Prod. Productions Prisma. Dir. Claude Godbout. Montreal, 1982. (16 mm; 27".) This is a critical overview of Hebert's career, beginning with comments on her most recent work, Les Fous de Bassan, then returning to the beginning of her career and her early education. The influence of her parents and of Saint-Denys Garneau is commented on, as well as the education in the "froide ambiance des religieuses:' Scenes of the Grand Seminaire of Quebec are placed in juxtaposition with excerpts from "Le Torrent" as examples of Hebert's criticism of and revolt against repressive Quebec society. She was thirty-seven years old when Le Tombeau des rois was published, and shortly after she began what would be a long-term residence in Paris, although she frequently visits Quebec. The archival research needed to write Kamouraska and Les Enfants du sabbat is mentioned. As a writer, Hebert has to fight "la tentation de se taire ..." and "... elle ne veut passe repeter."

Title:

Book Source:

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Anne Hebert. Russell, D.W. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 145-263

Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Books, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews and profiles, adaptation, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Theses and dissertations  

Russell, D.W. (compiler)

Theses and Dissertations

C280       Chatillon, Pierre. "Les Themes de l'enfance et de la mort dans l'oeuvre poetique de Nelligan, Saint-Denys Garneau, Anne Hebert, et Alain Grandbois." M.A. Thesis Montreal 1961. Chatillon analyses the themes of death and childhood, characterized by the following statement: "Anne Hebert est d'abord une femme et, par consequent, moins cerebrale que sensible."

C281       Walker, Cheryl Anne. "Anne Hebert: The Mystery of Innocence and Experience." M.A. Thesis Western Ontario 1961. Walker provides a thematic study of the imagery in Les Songes equilibre, Le Tombeau des rois, and Les Chambres de bois. There is a movement from childhood fantasy, to fear of the adult world and the experience of anguish, indifference, evil, to liberation, expressed in these three works.

C282       Robert, Guy. "Anne Hebert et sa poetique du songe." M.A. Thesis Montreal 1962. Also published in book form (C1).

C283       Moussalli, Mireille. "L'Oeuvre romanesque d'Anne Hebert." M.A. Thesis Laval 1966. Moussalli studies the themes and techniques, principally with reference to Les Chambres de bois. Although the works show originality in the use of time, they are weakened by the poetic subjectivity of the fictional world. This creates "une certaine monotonie et un manque de souffle evident."

C284       Sincennes, Gustave. "Le Tombeau des rois d'Anne Hebert et l'introspection" M.A. Thesis Ottawa 1968. Sincennes studies the "je" in the volume, which is presented as a struggle between the desire for death and the desire for love. Love is expressed by the images of trees, hands, sun, fire, and birds; death is expressed by the images of water, the house, the room, islands, and caves. Death is wished for as solitude, then as a means of escaping bitter love.

C285       Stheme de Jubecourt, Lila. "L'Univers poetique d'Anne Hebert dans Le Tombeau des rois." M.A. Thesis Alberta 1969. Stheme de Jubecourt analyses the poetic in Le Tombeau des rois.

C286       Giguere, Richard. "L'Evolution thematique de la poesie quebecoise (1935-1965): etude de SaintDenys Garneau, Anne Hebert, Roland Giguere et Paul Chamberland." M.A. Thesis Sherbrooke 1970. Giguere analyzes the development from the "mal individuel" of Saint-Denys Garneau to the "mal collectif' of Paul Chamberland. The close parallel between Garneau and Hebert is demonstrated in the poetry of the 1940s and 1950s, but in the 1960s Hebert moves into a new area which "revele un besoin d'appartenance" which will be central to Quebec poetry from then on. Giguere shows that "... la thematique de la depossession a ete recue et exprimee, bien avant Miron, Marchand ... par Saint-Denys Garneau et Anne Hebert." An extract from this thesis is published in Voix et images du pays (C100).

C287       Hoffmann, Pierre. "Theatre canadien d'expression francais et realisation televisee" M.A. Thesis Montreal 1970. Hebert's work is briefly discussed in this analysis of the characters and themes found in televised French-Canadian drama, concentrating on the family, the couple, the isolated person, and placing the characters within traditions such as that of the strong mother, the "survenant."

C288       Macri, Francis M. "L'Alienation dans l'oeuvre d'Anne Hebert et de P.K Page." M.A. Thesis Sherbrooke 1970. Macri's thematic study is based in part on Northrop Frye's interpretation of the development of French and English poetry. The sense of alienation grows out of an awareness of both physical and cultural isolation. This theme is discussed first with reference to the works of Saint-Denys Garneau, A.J.M. Smith, F.R. Scott, and A.M. Klein, followed by a more detailed analysis of the work of Anne Hebert and P.K. Page. Macri discusses the prose works first, concentrating on Hebert's "Le Torrent" and Page's "The Green Bird" and "The Woman," followed by an analysis of the poetry, dealing mainly with Hebert's Les Songes en equilibre and Le Tombeau des rois and Page's The Metal and the Flower and Cry Ararat! Poems New and Selected. In Hebert, Macri finds an "espace fermi" and time past, while in Page he finds an "espace vide" and time present.

C289       Savoie, Paul. "Anne Hebert, Saint-Denys Garneau: maison vide, solitude rompue." M.A. Thesis Manitoba 1970. Savoie examines the four stages of poetic creation in the work of the poets discussed, namely, the solitude in which the idea germinates, the exercise of the imagination, the creation of images which express this vision, and the creation of a poetic order which informs the cosmos. In Savoie's study of imagery, he discusses the presence of these four elements.

C290       Coleno, Gilbert. "Le Milieu physique dans l'oeuvre d'Anne Hebert." D.E.S. Montreal 1971. The work of Hebert presents characters who are at different levels in their relationship with the exterior world; for complete freedom, characters have to repossess the world from which they have been alienated. Coleno sees the characters as bearing "cette marque etrange d'etres qui ont noue avec le milieu physique, a une certaine epoque de leur vie, un lien difficile, subtil et inattendu."

C291       Mezei, Kathy. "Anne Hebert's Les Chambres de boss: A Translation and Interpretation." M.A. Thesis Carleton 1971. The translation into English is the major part of this thesis. In her introduction to the translation, Mezei analyzes briefly the main themes and images of the novel, making reference to the earlier and later works of Hebert. The central theme is the "incapacite de vivre," while the central images are of the body, nature, and the house. Mezei comments on the lack of complexity in structure and characterization and on the stylistic flaws of the novel.

C292       Telles, Mercedes. "Lecture d'Anne Hebert: Kamouraska." M.A. Thesis McGill 1971. Telles discusses the themes and structures of the novel and stresses the continuity of this work with Hebert's preceding pieces. The historical and social context of the novel, the use of time and space in the narration, and the theme of Jansenism are studied.

C293       Nahmiash, Robert. "L'Oppression et la violence dans l'oeuvre d'Anne Hebert." M.A. Thesis McGil1 1972. Nahmiash presents an inventory of the forms of violence found in Hebert's works to show that there is a movement from abdication in the face of death, and from refuge in silence, towards revolt and struggle for life.

C294       Champagne, Jean-Marc. "L'Enfance dans les romans d'Anne Hebert." M.A. Thesis Quebec Trois-Rivieres 1973. Champagne contrasts Hebert's idyllic childhood with the miserable fictional children she portrays, suggesting that she wishes to give her readers examples of the kinds of education not to force upon children.

C295       Doray, Michele. "Le Torrent d'Anne Hebert ou le mythe devenu roman." M.A. Thesis McGill 1973. Doray uses a Structuralist analysis to argue that "Le Torrent" is not a "conte," but a roman de suspens" The sociological implications of the work are also discussed: it is a criticism of a repressive society, dominated by the Church.

C296       Muirsmith, Elizabeth. "L'Eau dans l'oeuvre poetique d'Anne Hebert." M.A. Thesis Ottawa 1973. Muirsmith analyzes the use of water imagery in the three volumes of poetry and in "Le Torrent." Using Gaston Bachelard's L'Eau et les rdves, she argues that Hebert uses water imagery badly in her first volume of poetry, showing only the diverse surface reflections of water. In Le Tombeau des rois, the poet penetrates beneath the surface reality to plumb her own unconscious depths, the same "eau des instincts obscurs" which was first found in "Le Torrent." In the final volume of poetry, Mystere de la parole, the poet returns to the surface water, which is now connected to the earth, and shows the reintegration of the poet with exterior reality.

C297       Beaton, Nancy. "La Vision gothique de la survie dans les oeuvres de Marie-Claire Blais, Anne Hebert, Carson McCullers, et Flannery O'Connor." M.A. Thesis Montreal 1974. Beaton compares the parallel imagery found in the works of writers from the American South and Quebec. In both cases, the writers are writing from a culture which has suffered a political defeat at the hands of the majority group in the country. Beaton analyzes the themes and images of the family, the castle, the tomb, the cyclical voyage, and Narcissism. Beaton concentrates on "Le Torrent" when discussing Hebert's works.

C298       Chiasson, Arthur Paul. "The Tragic Mood in the Works of Anne Hebert." Diss. Tufts 1974. Chiasson introduces the literature of Quebec, then discusses Hebert's plays, novels, stories, and poetry from the point of view of the tragic mood. The plays are tragic for the characters do not achieve their goals; in the novels there is revolt, but also failure; in "the attempts at liberation described in each [of the stories], fate, combined with tragic irony, constantly subverts the instinct for survival"; in the poems there is a progression from "self-anguish to social awareness of suffering in the world." Chiasson concludes that the tragic mood is "a feeling produced by the paradox of a history which sustains life while preventing the emergence of the self for the poet and her nation." Chiasson does not find her later works optimistic, and compares this "esthetic of desperation" with Third-World writers from the West Indies and Africa.

C299       Gosselin, Michel. "Etude du discours narratif dans Kamouraska d'Anne Hebert." M.A. Thesis Sherbrooke 1974. Gosselin's Structuralist study is based on Gerard Genette's Figures III and examines only the "voix" and "mode" in the "discours narratif" of Kamouraska. In "voix," the first part of the thesis, Gosselin establishes the number of "micro-recits" and their various properties as defined by "niveaux narratifs," "instance narrative," "personne," "fonctions du narrateur," and "temps de la narration." The last part of his study, "mode," examines narrative perspective.

C300       Lemieux, Pierre-Herve. "Entre songe et parole: lecture du Tombeau des rois d'Anne Hebert." Diss. Ottawa 1974. Also published in book form (C7).

C301       Amar, Wendy. "L'Amour dans roeuvre d'Anne Hebert." M.A. Thesis McGill 1975. Amar presents a thematic study of love and death. Love can be the source of hate and death, as well as the source of liberation.

C302       Fulton, Barbara Leigh. "Kamouraska: le vide au centre." M.A. Thesis British Columbia 1975. The essential structure of the novel is "la revelation du vide par l'antithese. Kamouraska se base sur rantithese de l'etre et du paraitre, ralternance de ia vie reelle et de la vie imaginaire." Both Aur61ie and George are projections of Elisabeth.

C303       Mayes, Hubert G. "Rythmes et structures dans le roman quebecois de 1950 a 1965." Diss. Laval 1975. Mayes briefly analyzes the narrative rhythm of Les Chambres de bois in his general discussion of rhythms and structures in quebecois novels.

C304       Miller, Joanne Elizabeth. "Le Passage du desir a l'acte dans roeuvre poetique et romanesque d'Anne Hebert." M.A. Thesis Western Ontario 1975. Miller uses the works up to Kamouraska as the basis for her analysis. She discusses the evolution of the fictional characters, and of the poet, who all pass from an initial awakening to a state of silent retreat from failure. Some of the characters, and the poet, are able to move beyond this state of immobility to make an act of love and, thereby, move into maturity and forge bonds with their fellow men.

C305       Ferraton, Delores Claire. "La Couleur dans l'oeuvre d'Anne Hebert." M.A. Thesis Manitoba 1976. Ferraton studies the use of colour in both poetry and prose, devoting the first part of the thesis to Les Songes en equilibre, Le Tombeau des rois, and Mystere de la parole. In the second part of the thesis, she examines the stories from Le Torrent and the novels Les Chambres de bois and Kamouraska. Throughout her work, Hebert uses colour in an increasingly deliberate and symbolic fashion, particularly evident in Kamouraska. "Partout elle [la couleur] permet de concretiser le vague et l'insaisissable, de rendre plus reel le cauchemar ou la souffrance."

C306       Lefebvre, Louisette Bernard. "Le Theme de la femme dans l'oeuvre romanesque d'Anne Hebert." M.A. Thesis Quebec a Trois-Rivieres 1976. Lefebvre's thematic study of the presentation of women in Hebert's work moves from a detailed study of the fictional childhood and adolescence, to the frustrated adult life of her characters. "Angoisse, culpabilite, solitude" are studied as the main "complexes feminins," followed by an analysis of love, revolt, hatred, and death, the dominant emotions experienced by the female characters. Lefebvre concludes that H6bert denounces "un siecle etouffant et nefaste" by means of the "demesure des personnages feminins en qui reside le dualisme du bien et du mal, de la vie, de l'amour et de la mort. Leur tragique existence traduit bien leur gout du malheur."

C307       Lynch, Arlene. "La Symbolique de L'Arche de midi d'Anne Hebert." D.E.S. Ottawa 1976. Lynch studies setting, character, and language for symbolic meaning. The analysis of language includes a statistical study of the type of comparisons used and a discussion of the variety of nouns, adjectives, and verbs. Lynch concludes that this play is a link between the language of poetry and that of prose.

C308       Nadeau-Fournelle, Jeanine. "Analyse des techniques narratives dans Kamouraska." M.A. Thesis Quebec a Montreal 1976. This technical study of the novel uses a modification of Gerard Genette's "grille d'analyse" from Figures III. The thesis divides the novel into sequences or narrative units; it plots the macrostructure and the microstructure and analyzes the relationship between the narrators and the level of narration.

C309       Veroneau, Pierre. "Kamouraska: etude du roman et de son adaptation cinematographique." M.A. Thesis Quebec a Montreal 1976. Working from archival materials from the filming, Veroneau uses a Structuralist analysis to prove that the film fundamentally betrays the novel. "Force nous est de constater qu'il epure le roman de plusieurs de ses composantes pour ne conserver que les anecdotes gentilles, amusantes ou spectaculaires." Jutra has sacrificed the very essence of the novel: "a une ecriture romanesque basee sur la mouvance et rambiguite, il substitua un recit quasi univoque ...; il remplaca un recit totalement nourri de phantasmes, de souvenirs et meme de fantastique par la mise au reel et l'objectivisation. Il effaca la multiplicite des temps et des points de vue." Veroneau suggests that Hebert was aware of the film's betrayal of the novel.

C310       Bishop, Neil Breton. "La Thematique de l'enfance dans l'oeuvre poetique et romanesque d'Anne Hebert." Doctorat de troisieme cycle Provence I (Aix-en-Provence) 1977. For Bishop, the central problem for Hebert's characters is the struggle to pass from the world of childhood to that of the adult. Childhood is not just physical age, but rather a psychological state, characterized by "un refus du monde," and "une absence au reel et au bonheur." The dissertation catalogues and analyzes the images in Les Chambres de bois, Poemes, and Kamouraska, using a triple axis of "dependance/independance," "enfant/adulte authentique," "malheur/bonheur" Bishop finds a movement from an "enfance double," which is either "independante et heureuse" or "dependante et malheureuse," towards liberation and a "reveil a la vie." In an "Appendix Bishop discusses Les Enfants du sabbat as a further exploration of the theme of childhood and the need to leave childhood, as well as an "ecriture de la folie."

C311       Juery, Rene. "Oeuvres en prose d'Anne Hebert: essai de semiotique narrative et discursive de 'La Robe corail' et de Kamouraska." Diss. Ottawa 1977. Juery defines his method carefully in a long introduction; following the example of Noam Chomsky and A.J. Greimas, he uses a "structuralisme strictement methodologique" to study "La Robe corail," which is Hebert's first story, and then tests the validity of his "semiotique du recit" and his "semiotique du discours" by applying his theoretical results to Kamouraska. This dissertation is also published in a revised format (C188 and C207).

C312       Levasseur-Ouimet, France. "L'Archetype de la renaissance dans la poesie d'Anne Hebert." M.A. Thesis Alberta 1977. Levasseur-Ouimet's psychological study examines the Jungian concept of individuation, or the fusion of objective and subjective reality in the process of rebirth, death, and rebirth, as applied to the poetry of Hebert.

C313       Saint-Pierre Allaire, Solange. "Le Fonctionnement du discours dans Kamouraska d'Anne Hebert." M.A. Thesis Quebec a Montreal 1977. Saint-Pierre Allaire's Structuralist and psycho-analytic study of Kamouraska is based on theories of Tzvetan Todorov, Roland Barthes, and Sigmund Freud for its methodology. The novel is divided into "sequences" and the narrative techniques and levels are presented. There is a detailed analysis of the way the narrative of the novel is organized according to the psychological logic of dreams. The author also discusses the "organisation des codes" in the novel, namely, "psychanalytique, hermeneutique, gnomique ou culturel, rhetorique."

C314       Ceschi, Genevieve. "A la source du Torrent d'Anne Hebert." M.A. Thesis British Columbia 1978. Ceschi examines Le Torrent and points out the complexity and richness of the work. Le Torrent is a social criticism; it uses parallels with the mediaeval Grail quest; it is a fantasy based on biblical literature; it presents a finely drawn psychological study, a suspense novel, an allegorical treatment of the role of the involuntary memory on the act of literary creation; and it uses the Oedipus myth, as analyzed by Claude Levi-Strauss, to comment on the biological origin of life.

C315       Giguere, Richard. "Une poesie de dissidence: etude comparative de l'evolution des poesies quebecoise et canadienne modernes a Montreal, 1925-1955." Diss. British Columbia 1978. Drawing on the critical work of Ronald Sutherland, D.G. Jones, Clement Moisan, JeanCharles Falardeau, and Antoine Sirois, Giguere develops three basic hypotheses: 1) "... les mouvements de poesie moderne au Canada et au Quebec suivent une evolution parallele de 1920-25 a 1950-55"; 2) "... Montreal est le lieu central, la ville-carrefour off se produit l'eclosion des deux mouvements poetiques"; 3) "... des analyses comparees des oeuvres des pontes quebecois et canadiens representatifs des annees 30 et 40 devraient prouver que leurs textes sont marquis pars des themes, des questions de fond, une problematique qui leur est commune." In the first six chapters, Giguere presents a detailed description of the development of groups of writers, poetical movements, periodicals, and publishing houses. The remainder of the dissertation has been revised and published in book form; see C257.

C316       McQuaid, Catherine. "Women's Changing Roles in the Novels of Anne Hebert and Margaret Laurence." M.A. Thesis Sherbrooke 1978. McQuaid studies the division between biological and intellectual functions in the female protagonists of Anne Hebert and Margaret Laurence. The division in the characters between Eros and Logos is caused by social conditioning which leads the protagonist to suppress the Eros side of her nature. The characters usually are unsatisfied in their conventional lives, but discover their suppressed erotic side after meeting an unconventional character who acts as a psychic guide, leading the character back to a new balance, in Jungian terms, between the animus and the anima. This is true of Catherine in Les Chambres de bois; Elisabeth does not establish this balance in Kamouraska, but suppresses Eros again instead by marrying Jerome; Julie rejects both Eros and Logos, and McQuaid sees her "... exclusively as a symbolic psyche."

C317       Theriault, Serge. "La Quete d'equilibre dans l'oeuvre romanesque d'Anne Hebert." Diss. Ottawa 1978. Also published in book form (C8).

C318       Deneault-Turcot, Louise. "Une lecture de l'oeuvre d'Anne Hebert: Les Enfants du sabbat." M.A. Thesis Quebec a Montreal 1979. Using a variety of approaches -- Structuralism, psycho-analysis, thematic criticism, and historical criticism -- Deneault-Turcot argues that Les Enfants du sabbat is "un produit direct du coeur, de l'ame, de l'etre de l'homme quebecois saisi dans son actualite"

C319       Roy-Hewitson, Lucille. "La Cosmologie poetique d'Anne Hebert: metamorphoses et interaction de la lumiere, du feu, du bois, de la terre et de l'eau." Doctorat de troisieme cycle Bordeaux III 1979. Using a thematic analysis inspired by Gaston Bachelard's La Poetique de la reverie, RoyHewitson defines five basic themes to be found in Hebert's work up to Les Enfants du sabbat. These are, as the title of the thesis indicates, "lumiere, feu, bois, terre, eau." The first five chapters, Part I of the study, are entitled "De la lumiere aux eaux profondes"; the second, and last part, is entitled "Des eaux souterraines a la clarte de l'ocean." Roy-Hewitson presents a detailed discussion of these themes or images, in an attempt to reach "... l'interpenetration de l'homme et des elements jusqu'a l'experience de l'imagination creatrice." She finds a basic dichotomy in these systems of images: "Si notre eude retrace un long trajet partant de la lumiere de midi et y revenant, a travers un mouvement de chute et de remontee, la vue d'ensemble qui se degage en conclusion revele une opposition fonciere entre la terre-matrice et la lumiere qui porte vers autrui, entre la nuit de la matiere et la clarte de la vie sociale." This dissertation is completely reworked in her book (C13).

C320       Harvey, Robert. "Rememoration et commemoration dans Kamouraska d'Anne Hebert." M.A. Thesis Montreal 1980. Harvey studies the narrative structure of Kamouraska. Elisabeth Rolland's progressive awareness of her role as exclusive narrator of the "recit second" is used to make the "rememoration" of the event into a "commemoration": "... l'evocation se fait alors invocation, et la narration, recitation pour cette fois revivre au present une toute autre Passion." Harvey also shows that liturgical allusions in the novel are carefully used to create two ritual acts; while Jerome Rolland is receiving the last rites, Elisabeth and George are re-enacting an inverted Christ-like sacrifice. Harvey's study, using some of Gerard Genette's terminology, analyzes the different narrative levels, including narrative voice and time. Harvey also published a book largely based on this thesis (C10).

C321       Aonzo, Jeannine. "La Femme dans les romans d'Anne Hebert." M.A. Thesis McGill 1981. Aonzo studies Hebert's works as a criticism of the status of women in Quebec society from 1830 to 1950. Hebert's work "is a kind of plea in favour of the equality of the sexes at all levels of life: family, social, cultural, legal and political." Aonzo opposes Adrien Therio's claim that Hebert's work has no real connection with Quebec society (C97) and draws on sociological works that analyze such problems as rape and violence in Quebec to underline the realism of Hebert's work.

C322       Baszczynski, Marilyn Jane. "Le [sic] Poetique du discours dans Les Enfants du sabbat d'Anne Hebert." M.A. Thesis Western Ontario 1981. Baszczynski systematically presents the rhetorical devices found in Les Enfants du sabbat to demonstrate that the work accentuates a fragmented vision which forces the reader to seek the poetic level of meaning in the novel. The analysis begins with a study of key semantic fields to show that, at the lexical level, the work reinforces the dialectic tensions basic to the overt theme of the opposition of good and evil. Baszczynski studies, for example, the images of the body, clothing, open and closed space. The second level of rhetorical analysis includes the variety of sentence structure found in the novel, based on Marcel Cressot's Le Style et ses techniques. A third and final level of rhetorical analysis deals with the techniques used to disrupt the linear narration of the basic story and force the reader to view the action from a new perspective: such figures as "asyndete" "expolition," "abruption," and "juxtaposition" are discussed.

C323       Emond, Maurice. "Le Monde imaginaire d'Anne Hebert dans Les Chambres de bois, Kamouraska etLes Enfants du sabbat." D. es L. Laval 1981. Using a theoretical framework derived from Gaston Bachelard and Gilbert Durand, Emond notes that "Cette etude met en evidence les images, themes ou motifs qui constituent le monde imaginaire d'Anne Hebert: ses couleurs, ses lumieres et ses ombres, ses bruits, ses odeurs, ses nourritures, son bestiaire, ses personnages, ses matieres, ses temps et ses espaces privilegies, ses regards, ses fenetres, ses miroirs .... De plus, elle indique les constellations, les foyers d'images, les poles dynamiques, les carrefours, les constantes et les frequences significatives, en d'autres mots les lois internes de ce monde imaginaire, sa 'constitution poetique.'" His dissertation has been substantially reworked and published in book form; for more details see C12.

C324       Paterson, Janet. "L'Architexture des Chambres de bois: modalites de la representation chez Anne Hebert." Diss. Toronto 1981. Paterson examines the "structure matricielle" of Les Chambres de bois. She makes detailed and extensive references to a wide range of semiotic and Structuralist theoretical criticism which is applied in the course of this analysis of the novel. Beginning with an "analyse semique" of the word "pays" in the novel, Paterson proceeds to an analysis of the existence and interrelationships of three basic "codes": "le reel, l'onirique et l'irreel." The second half of the thesis examines the "systeme d'autorepresentation" in the work, discussed under five subheadings. The results of this analysis are applied to other novels. Paterson concludes with a discussion of the theoretical implications drawn from this study of "auterepresentation" in Hebert's work. This dissertation was later revised and published in book form (C14).

C325       Nazair Garant, France. "Eve et le cheval de greve." M.A. Thesis Laval 1982. Using a Bachelardian approach, Nazair Garant analyzes the theme of the horse throughout Hebert's work. "Le theme du cheval, jusqu'a maintenant meconnu, vehicule, au niveau de l'imaginaire, des reseaux d'images riches et profondes ou se cachent des forces inconscientes puissantes" Nazair Garant connects the image of Eve, the first mother, with that of the horse. The horse symbolizes an awakening: "une prise de conscience: il revele le visage interieur, il fait jaillir les etres et les choses ...." In this awakening, "du fond de l'humanite Eve est convoquee, exorcisee. On s'attaque aux blessures, aux meutrissures, au serpent, au dominanteur."

C326       Davis, Pauline Marie. "L'Affrontement des sexes dans les romans d'Anne Hebert." M.A. Thesis Calgary 1983. Davis studies the novels under the headings "Les Couples et l'amour," "La Femme et l'homme: Eve nouvelle et statue de sel," and "La Sexualite: agent double." In the end there seems to be no resolution of the deep antagonism that exists between the sexes in Hebert's work. All characters suffer from a dichotomy between what they say they are and what they really are. But, although the women rebell in favour of seeking a new life, the male characters are inevitably drawn to prefer death to love. Neither sex is a victor, although both use sex as a tool to dominate the other, or to express violence. "L'analyse des couples montre que derriere l'amour se cache souvent la cruaute, le mepris et la trahison, et que sous la haine on decouvre la complicite." No one is capable of love, despite a desperate desire to love and live seen in the women characters; all are either "tourmentes sexuels" or "affectifs impuissants .... Nous ne pouvons donc que conclure a une impossibilite de l'amour et a l'incompatabilite des sexes auxquelles nous ne voyons pas d'issue .... "

Title:
Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews; Dialogue sur la traduction: à propos du 'Tombeau des rois
Other Title:

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Anne Hebert. Russell, D.W. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 145-263

Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews; Dialogue sur la traduction: à propos du 'Tombeau des rois  

Russell, D.W. (compiler)

Dialogue sur la traduction: a propos du "Tombeau des rois"

D148      Aylwin, Ulric. Rev. of Dialogue sur la traduction: propos du "Tombeau des rois." Prospectives, 7 (avril 1971 ), 120. This dialogue between two poets is a good source of reflection for those interested in questions of aesthetics and poetic language. Aylwin quotes several examples of the discussion between Anne Hebert and Frank Scott as proof that poets do indeed carefully consider the choice of words. This book gives an excellent answer to those who inevitably ask themselves: did the poet really think of all that?

Title:
Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews; Héloïse
Other Title:
Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews

Genre(s):

Subject(s):
Authors discussed:  HEBERT, Anne; HEBERT, Anne -- Criticism & interpretation -- Bibliography
Titles critiqued:  HéLO&IUML;SE (Book)

Accession Number:
ABCMA07AHP2000007002004007
Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07AHP2000007002004007&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07AHP2000007002004007&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews; Héloïse</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Anne Hebert. Russell, D.W. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 145-263

Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews; Héloïse  

Russell, D.W. (compiler)

Heloise

D93      Royer, Jean. "Anne Hebert: comment separer le songe du reel." Le Devoir [Montreal], 29 mars 1980, p. 19. The novel charms more than it unsettles the reader as it presents, in a fantastic fictional world, the conflict between two aspects of woman: the domestic beauty of day-time life, and the fatal beauty of death and the underworld. The novel poses once again the principal question of Hebert's work: "comment separer le songe du reel, l'amour de la mort, le sacre du quotidien?"

D94     Johnson, William. "Strange World Set Out in Hebert Novel." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 22 April 1980, p. 8. Johnson discusses the strange world presented in this novel which ultimately fails because "... its technique falls midway between that of poetry and the novel." The work has the economy of poetry but the "denser atmosphere" of the realistic conventions of the novel are needed to make the "reader believe in the presence of living death." The first part of the novel is interesting, but the "book declines in the end toward the grotesque."

D95      Marcotte, Gilles. "Anne Hebert et la sirene du metro." Actualite, juin 1980, p. 82. Hebert's first Parisian novel is not really a novel, but a longish short story. It examines the current taste for old fashions and suggests that this is perhaps the wish for the death of the present civilization. "Heloise est un plaidoyer pour la vie immediate, la vie au grand jour."

D96     Ouellette, G.-P. Rev. of Heloise. In Livres et auteurs quebecois 1980. Gen. ed. Maximilien Laroche, Andre Berthiaume, and Jean-Noel Pontbriand. Quebec: Les Presses de l'Univ. Laval, 1981, pp. 40-42. The novel could have ended at page seventy-five and been made into a decent story. Ouellette is particularly critical of the vampirism, which he finds too realistic and jarring in the context of the work.

D97     Ferry, Jacqueline. "Heloise dans le Metro: propos sur Heloise de Anne Hebert." Lettres quebecoises, No. 21 (printemps 1981), pp. 24-25. Heloise is irritating. Ferry suggests that the cause for her disillusionment is perhaps that Hebert has become too Parisian.

D98      Lewis, Paula Gilbert. "Anne Hebert: Heloise." The French Review, 54 (April 1981), 763-64. "Heloise is a well-written novel in Hebert's typically beautiful, simple, and effective style ... One does wish, however, that its symbolism were somewhat less obvious; and one does wonder, in particular, in what further direction Anne Hebert is intending to move in her fiction."

D99      French, William. "Hebert's Heloise Laughably Inept." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 25 Nov. 1982, p. 23. "The most recent sample of Hebert's work available in English is her 1980 novel, Heloise, just published in translation by Sheila Fischman. Heloise didn't win any prizes and it's easy to understand why. Part allegory, part Dracula motif, part ghost story, it's surprisingly inept. There is certainly nothing in it to suggest that its author, with her next novel, would win one of France's major literary awards."

D100      Money, Darlene. Rev. of Heloise, trans. Sheila Fischman. Quill & Quire, Jan. 1983, pp. 30, 32. Money outlines the plot, notes that the novel is haunting, though not entirely successful: "Suspense mounts inexorably in an obsessively evil atmosphere; then a jarring, though brief, change of tone occurs as impressionistic surrealism becomes factual realism," as Heloise and Bottereau reveal themselves as vampires.

D101      Thomas, Audrey. "Mademoiselle Blood: Anne Hdbert Re-Explores the Link between Passion and Death in an Eerie Tale of Vampirism and the Paris Metro." Books in Canada, Feb. 1983, pp. 11-12. Thomas points out the similarity between the book's epigraph and the opening stanza of Hebert's poem "A Kind of Feast." "The Metro serves an important function of this novel. It is where the action begins, and it is also where it ends, in a scene at once erotic and blasphemous .... Sex and death, or passion and death, have always been linked together in her [Halbert's] works, and she has often explored the theme of 'mastery.' ... The image of the vampire is a brilliant, 'objective correlative' for the passionate possession of one human being by another." It is important that Heloise "appears in the same [subway] car as Bernard" after Christine, the symbol of life, gets off. Christine does not have the power to save Bernard, "not because 'death' is more powerful than 'life,'" but "because of the nature of Bernard .... In the hands of an artist less skilled than Anne Hebert this could have been a very silly book." Hebert's use of the Metro is "wonderful." Thomas outlines the possibilities of the novel as an allegory of St. Bernard, Abelard, and Heloise, and traces some detailed geographical and costume references. "Heloise [translated by Sheila Fischman] is full of Hebert's usual superb writing, striking imagery, and careful observation of human (and inhuman) nature."

D102      Mezei, Kathy. "Letters in Canada: 1982. Translations?' University of Toronto Quarterly, 52 (Summer 1983), 393-94. Mezei comments on Hebert's obsession with eros and thanatos, which is central to this novel. "Artfully composed, Heloise nevertheless remains a remote allegory in black and white, with a splash of red. Sheila Fischman has a fine, accurate touch but the apparent simplicity, delicacy and fastidiousness of Hebert's tale is difficult to recreate in the more cumbersome English language."

D103      Godard, Barbara. "Crazy Quilt." Rev. of Junction, by Elizabeth Brewster; Heloise, by Anne Hebert, trans. Sheila Fischman; and Quilt, by Donna Smyth. The Fiddlehead, No. 141 (Autumn 1984), pp. 83-84, 86-89. All three novels, although disparate, have "a common concern with inversion ... This inversion of life and death ... is at the heart of all three novels." Heloise is "both a wonderful joke and a ghostly tale ... Plotting is not Hebert's strength, and to give an outline of this tale is to reduce it to its most cliched and melodramatic moments." The theme of incest is effectively expressed by the haunting language of the novel. The novel is "also a very witty allegory about Parisian life in what is certainly no city of light." The literary allusions in the novel may not "link up to provide a fully developed allegory, [but] these allusions combine with the spreading of the dark, underground city to give new articulation to a familiar Hebert theme: the dead weight of the past."

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Item Number: ABCMA07AHP2000007002004007

Title:
Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews; Kamouraska
Other Title:

Series Title:

Author(s):
Russell, D.W. (compiler)
Genre(s):
Bibliography
Subject(s):
Authors discussed:  HEBERT, Anne; HEBERT, Anne -- Criticism & interpretation -- Bibliography
Titles critiqued:  KAMOURASKA (Book)
Topics:  CANADIAN literature -- Bibliography; FRENCH-CANADIAN literature -- Bibliography
Book Source:
Russell, D.W. (compiler) Part 2: Works On Anne Hebert.
Publisher Information: Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987. (pp. 145-263)
ISBN: 0920763111 (hardcover); 092076312X (paperback)

Accession Number:
ABCMA07AHP2000007002004005
Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07AHP2000007002004005&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07AHP2000007002004005&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews; Kamouraska</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Anne Hebert. Russell, D.W. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 145-263

Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews; Kamouraska  

Russell, D.W. (compiler)

Kamouraska

D45      Kanters, Robert. "Entre Rhone et Saint Laurent." Rev. of Kamouraska, by Anne Hebert; and L'Amour des autres, by Henri Bonnier. Le Figaro Litteraire [Paris], 14-20 sept. 1970, p. 20. Kanters writes, "... nous lisons simplement l'histoire dramatique, parfois haletante, d'un grand amour interdit et finalement criminel. Cela fait un tres bon roman." The heart of the novel is "l'effort tenace, desespere de la jeune femme pour conquerir sa liberte et son amour, d'autant plus sensible que nous le voyons, dixhuit ans plus tard, envahir l'ame d'Elisabeth vieillie comme une maree jamais domptee."

D46      Nourissier, Francois. "Kamouraska: roman d'Anne Hebert." Les Nouvelles litteraires [Paris], 24 sept. 1970, p. 2. Kamouraska is one of the six or seven interesting novels of the season. Although Hebert is not as much influenced by American mores as her younger contemporaries, such as Marie-Claire Blais, Rejean Ducharme, Jean Basile, Kamouraska does have many elements of an American thriller. The non-chronological narrative, now just as classic a technique as the earlier chronological narrative, is perhaps too complicated and too slow. Despite Nourissier's reservations about the style, Kamouraska is "un roman tres solide, tres attachant."

D47      Bosquet, Alain. "Deux Ecrivains canadiens: L'Homme rapaille de Gaston Miron; Kamouraska d'Anne Hebert." Rev. of L'Homme rapaille, by Gaston Miron; and Kamouraska, by Anne Hebert. Le Monde [Paris], 3 oct. 1970, p. 17. Kamouraska "marque l'entree veritable d'Anne Hebert dans le domaine romanesque." Bosquet analyses the "trois plans etroitement meles": the present and immediate past ("realiste" and "objectif'), the distant past ("plus poetique" with airs of "le desordre" "le chaos," and incessant memory), and a composite writing (mixing first and third persons and "interrogativeS' and telegraphic sentences).

D48      Juin, Hubert. "Deux Points de vue sur 'Kamouraska': les ferocites de l'amour." Les Lettres francaises, 30 sept.-6 oct. 1970, pp. 5, 7. This review is written in conjunction with one by Rene Lacote (D49). The exercise of the writer's poetic imagination on the historical anecdote of Kamouraska makes it into "un univers a la fois tragique et humain." Juin finds that the novel "qui n'a rien de realiste, paradoxalement, eclaire la realite." The novel recreates through the power of its language both the complex reality of Elisabeth and the space and time of her life: "ce temps ressaisi, cet espace retrouve: voila qui permet aux folies de la passion et aux ferocites de l'amour de paraitre. C'est le roman d'Anne Hebert."

D49      Lacote, Rene. "Deux Points de vue sur 'Kamouraska': 'Kamouraska.'" Les Lettres francaises, 30 sept.-6 oct. 1970, pp. 5, 7. This review is written in conjunction with one by Hubert Juin (D48). Lacote sees Kamouraska as confirming the poetic style and essential themes of Hebert's earlier work. It builds on the previous oeuvre, at times repeating key phrases from Le Tombeau des rois or Les Chambres de bois, while giving new expression to the "mouvement d'emancipation qui apparut au Quebec avec la generation de La Relive." The novel transcends the historical anecdote from which it springs. "La composition et l'ecriture d'Anne Hebert n'ont pas les complaisances traditionnelles. Chaque phrase de ses livres est essentielle et Kamouraska est plus grand encore que les precedents"

D50      Ferron, Jacques. "'Kamouraska' ou l'invention du pays." Le Magazine Maclean, jan. 1971, pp. 44, 46. Ferron criticizes the novel's false social image of Quebec in the early nineteenth century and accuses Hebert of pandering to MetropolitanFrench tastes in creating characters who belong to the elite.

D51     Robidoux, Rejean. Rev. of Kamouraska. In Livres et auteurs quebecois 1970. Gen. ed. Adrien Therio. Montreal: Jumonville, [1971 ], pp. 24-26. This is Hebert's first truly successful novel, in the sense that it is fully a novel; poetic elements do not dominate the technique of the work, as could be charged of her earlier novels.

D52     Gay, Richard. "Kamouraska: une histoire d'amour et de mort." Maintenant, mars 1971, pp. 94-95. Gay praises the style of the novel which achieves a synthesis between character and setting without sacrificing subtlety in the analysis of complex emotions. "Ce roman, c'est une serie de traits, d'images rapides et a travers cet impressionnisme vibrant l'oeuvre apparait et parle."

D53      Jones, Lousia. Rev. of Kamouraska. The French Review, 44 (April 1971), 961-62. The language of the novel is poetic, and it combines "unself-conscious romanticism" with a "very modern narrative technique and striking descriptive detail." Jones compares Kamouraska to Thomas Hardy's Return of the Native. Hebert's novel is "a complex echo chamber where constantly recurrent expressions, parts of events, striking images grow ever richer from new contexts."

D54      Rev. of Kamouraska. The Times Literary Supplement [London], 2 April 1971, p.402. Rpt. (excerpt) in Modern Commonwealth Literature: A Library of Literary Criticism. Ed. John H. Ferres and Martin Tucker. New York: Frederick Ungar, 1977, pp. 286-87. The novel is far from mediocre, but the reviewer laments the fashionable jumps in time within the narrative, and the lack of FrenchCanadianisms. "It is somewhat over-long, perhaps, but gives a clear picture of the stifling life and conventions of provincial nineteenthcentury Canada."

D55      Robidoux, Rejean. "Letters in Canada: 1970. Romans, Recits, Nouvelles, Contes." University of Toronto Quarterly, 40 (Summer 1971), 430-31. Kamouraska is one of the best novels of the year: "... la passion a toute la force du 'desir absolu.'" Hebert "a invente le plus prodigieux assortiment d'elans, d'images et de visions qui se puisse imaginer."

D56      Vachon, G.-Andre. "Chroniques: le roman -- une litterature qui se louisianise?". Etudes francaises [Univ. de Montreal], 7 (nov. 1971), 419-20. This novel is "a la fois le sommet et le terme de la carriere d'Anne Hebert. Le livre est si parfait? Le suivant et les autres ne peuvent que lui ressembler? Et pourquoi pas? I1 est permis d'aimer un Mauriac, qui a passe sa vie a polir sa propre image .... le Quebec d'aujourd'hui est unanime a se reconnaitre dans Kamouraska .... " Vachon suggests, however, that Hebert may be creating a new fashionable cliche: "Qu'elle retrouve le pouvoir de sedition des Songes en equilibre, on l'en aimera moins. Casser le miroir devant lequel les Nouveaux Quebecois aiment se penetrer de leur etat d' 'alienes,' si elle le faisait, elle ferait du moins ce qui est en son pouvoir pour que le Quebec n'entre vivant, politique, culture et litterature, dans un nouveau folklore, les yeux rives sur des cliches."

D57      Merker, Rene. Rev. of Kamouraska. Canadian Modern Language Review, 28, No.3 (March 1972), 85. Merker calls the work a long prose poem and praises its "style morcele, hache et les monologues interieurs de la narratrice." He hopes it will become a classic and rank with the works of Louis Hemon, Ringuet, and Claude-Henri Grignon.

D58       Chartier, Armand. "French-Canadian Gothic: Notes on Anne Hebert's Kamouraska." ACSUS Newsletter, 2, No.2 (Autumn 1972), 66-67, 74. Rpt. (excerpt) in Modern Commonwealth Literature: A Library of Literary Criticism. Ed. John H. Ferres and Martin Tucker. New York: Frederick Ungar, 1977, p. 287. "In Kamouraska, Anne Hebert succeeds remarkably well in exploiting the ceaseless conflict between the self and society, the dichotomy between appearance and reality and, to a lesser extent, the contrast between the main character's past and present," The historical setting lacks precision, but this is "less important for the author than the creation of a highly individualized world." The recitation of names is like prayer. "The great incantory power which the name has in common with prayer, the magic of a name, the phenomenon of verbal alchemy, employed to evoke a tragic destiny, there is no better illustration of this than the name which gives the novel its title." This novel "represents a significant advance in technique and scope ...." In particular, there is "a multiplicity of means employed to emphasize the dichotomy between appearance and reality..." and a complex ambiguity in the identity of the narrator. Chartier suggests that a number of structural and thematic studies will be needed to fully appreciate Kamouraska.

D59       Gerus, Claire. Rev. of Kamouraska. Quill & Quire, June 1973, p. 13. In this review of the Norman Shapiro translation of the novel, Gerus praises the "spell-binding tale of psychological intrigue" in which "... Elisabeth's inner tumult has been drawn with painful clarity." The story has "a sense of beauty which is undiminished by the sordid events described in it."

D60      Purcell, James Mark. Rev. of Kamouraska. The Antigonish Review, No. 14 (Summer 1973), pp. 111-13. Reviewing the original French version of the novel, Purcell compares it to Anglo-American literate thrillers and praises the "authors willingness to risk her literary caste position in Paris and Quebec by writing suspense fiction."

D61       McAlpine, Mary. "The Voice of Passion Seeking Her." Saturday Night, Aug. 1973, p. 32. In reviewing the Norman Shapiro translation, McAlpine praises the novel; it is a "tale of imagination and horror, yet it is never a simple gothic fable: the author is as human as she is talented, and she projects a compassion which mysteriously pervades her relentlessly cold and evil story."

D62       Ryan, Frank L. Rev. of Kamouraska. Best Seller's [Univ. of Scranton, Pa.], 1 Aug. 1973, p. 199. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Carolyn Riley. Vol. IV. Detroit: Gale, 1975, 220. Ryan hopes Hebert's award for Kamouraska will be "enough to permit both the purchase of Aristotle's 'Rhetoric' and leisure time" to read it, so that, in her next novel, the "narrator's emotion in the involvement both in herself and in her attempts to provoke emotion in the reader square in intensity with the theme and with the structuring of that theme through plot."

D63      Rev. of Kamouraska, trans. Norman Shapiro. Choice, Sept. 1973, p. 990. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Authors: A Bio-Bibliographical Guide to Current Writers in Fiction, General Nonfiction, Poetry, Journalism, Drama, Motion Pictures, Television, and Other Fields. Ed. Frances Carol Locher. Vols. LXXXV-LXXXVIIL Detroit: Gale, 1980, 250. The reviewer compares the "almost unendurable excitement" felt by the reader to that generated by a Bronte novel. "Hebert's poetic vision draws the thoughtful reader to be one with each of the frenzied characters .... Hebert, long one of French Canada's foremost poets, now joins Marie-Claire Blais and Gabrielle Roy as a leading Canadian novelist."

D64       Godard, Barbara. Rev. of Kamouraska. Open Letter, Ser. 2, No. 6 (Fall 1973), pp. 121-23. Godard places Kamouraska (translated by Norman Shapiro) in the context of Hebert's previous work and comments on the influence of this work on Quebec literature. In this last novel "... the subject of the love-triangle murder... has been given a thorough social background, not the sensational romance treatment which it might at first suggest." The precision of the geographical and historical context is a change from her earlier work.

D65       Orenstein, Yukie. "Murder from the Past." The Financial Post [Toronto], 27 Oct. 1973, p. C3. Orenstein praises Kamouraska's "vivid imagery and accomplished story-telling technique" through which the reader becomes totally involved in the intrigue and torment of Elisabeth (in the Norman Shapiro translation).

D66       Roberts-Van Oordt, Christina H. Rev. of Kamouraska. The Canadian Forum, Nov.-Dec. 1973, pp.32-33. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Authors: A Bio-Bibliographical Guide to Current Writers in Fiction, General Nonfiction, Poetry, Journalism, Drama, Motion Pictures, Television, and Other Fields. Ed. Frances Carol Locher. Vols. LXXXV-LXXXVIIL Detroit: Gale, 1980, 250. In the original, the reviewer had "the delightful, rare shock of discovering a masterpiece while it was still newborn." The novel also works in translation: "On the whole the [Norman Shapiro] translation moves along smoothly and doesn't stand in the way of the original too much."

D67       Smart, Patricia. "Novels and Novelists" Queen's Quarterly, 81 (Winter 1974), 474-46. Smart presents an overview of Hebert's work before discussing the Norman Shapiro translation of Kamouraska, which she sees as "the crowning point of Hebert's career." The novel "reconciles the poetic quest for absolute and timeless truth with that other and contradictory truth which is contained within time, change, the family, society, and history." This reconciliation with time is the subject of the major part of this analysis, and Smart concludes that "... the reconciliation with time in Kamouraska is also a reconciliation with French Canadian history, which in all of Anne Hebert's work is at the root of the alienation from life."

D68      Hainer, R.C. Rev. of Kamouraska. English Quarterly, 7, No. 4 (Winter 1974-75), 89-92. Hainer compares Elisabeth to Hamlet and discusses the major theme of survival and self-fulfillment in the novel. He finds the translation by Shapiro good: "Its imagery is drawn from Shakespeare, Joyce, and the narrative folklore of Quebec. Its stream-of-consciousness style is economical and tight: its language is taut, reverberating with the passions of life and love."

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Item Number: ABCMA07AHP2000007002004005
Record: 33
Title:
Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews; Le Temps sauvage. La Mercière assassinèe. Les Invités au procès
Other Title:

Russell, D.W. (compiler)

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Anne Hebert. Russell, D.W. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 145-263

Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews; Le Temps sauvage. La Mercière assassinèe. Les Invités au procès  

Russell, D.W. (compiler)

Le Temps sauvage. La Merciere assassinee. Les Invites au proces.

D146      Biron, Herve. Rev. of Le Temps sauvage. La Merciere assassinee. Les Invites au proces. Culture, 28 (1967), 426. Biron comments on the three kinds of theatre presented in this volume, the one common element being their poetic nature. In the first play he finds that the dialogue, "fermi, emporte, parfois declamatoire, respire souvent le mystere." Of the last two plays he laments the excessive violence and questions the validity of the characters: "... la seule consolation est que la langue est belle."

D147      Leroux, Norman. Rev. of Le Temps sauvage. La Merciere assassinee. Les Invites au proces. Livres et auteurs canadiens 1967. Gen. ed. Adrien Therio. Montreal: Jumonville, [1968], pp. 74-75. Leroux mentions and disagrees with Guy Beaulne's review of the 1963 publication of Le Temps sauvages (D168). He notes that La Merciere assassinee is a "drame policier hausse au niveau de l'oeuvre d'art." Les Invites au proces is a dramatic poem which also has elements of the murder mystery. Leroux gives a resume of the play and adds that the radio production would no doubt aid in making the poetry of the piece felt by the listener.

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Title:
Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews; Le Tombeau des rois
Other Title:
Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews
Record Type:
Reference Series

Author(s):
Russell, D.W. (compiler)

Titles critiqued:  LE tombeau des rois (Book)
