Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Anne Hebert. Russell, D.W. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 145-263

Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews; Le Tombeau des rois  

Russell, D.W. (compiler)

Le Tombeau des rois

D10     Bonenfant, Y.D. Rev. of Le Tombeau des rois. Le Soleil [Quebec], 15 avril 1953, p. 4. Bonenfant praises the purity of the verse, which is haunted by three symbols: hands, death, and water.

D11       Richer, Julia. Rev. of Le Tombeau des rois. Notre temps [Montreal], 18 avril 1953, p. 3. These short poems are the work of a true poet and show "l'homme... aux prises avec luimeme et dans une solitude inquietante."

D12       Valois, Marcel. Rev. of Le Tombeau des rois. La Presse [Montreal], 2 mai 1953, p. 66. This collection places its author among the best contemporary poets. Valois compares Hebert to Jules Supervielle, Jean Cocteau, Stephane Mallarme. "Forme et fond deviennent inseparables."

D13       L'Illettre. "Nouveaux Poemes d'Anne Hebert." Le Droit [Ottawa], 4 mai 1953, p. 3. This review condemns the poet's use of Modern verse forms, and suggests that she is abusively Romantic, egocentric, and macabre. She could do so much better if she imposed poetic discipline on herself.

D14      Marcotte, Gilles. "Vie des lettres: Le Tombeau des rois."Le Devoir [Montreal], 9 mai 1953, p. 7. Marcotte analyzes the contrast between the deceptive simplicity of the language and the profound despair which it expresses. "La parole sort apparemment purifiee, d'une immense douleur qui, elle, n'accepte pas de se rendre." He discusses the journey through suffering to death, and then rebirth found in the poems.

D15      Sylvestre, Guy. Rev. of Le Tombeau des rois. La Nouvelle Revue canadienne, 2 (juin-juil. 1953), 342-43. The poems verge on being excessively dry and laconic, but they do express a spiritual adventure. The poet expresses a sense of "depossession en presence d'un monde qui l'attire mais lui reste definitivement etranger." This volume shows Hebert's deepening sense of the tragedy of life.

D16       Beguin, Albert. "Anne Hebert et la solitude." Le Devoir [Montreal], 3 oct. 1953, pp. 6-7. The theme of profound solitude, in Hebert's poetry, is a significant expression of French-Canadian society. Beguin compares her austere verse to that of Mallarme. In Hebert's poetry, there is a pact of the soul with death and recurring images of the closed room and the dead-end street. "Poesie d'un etre enferme, poesie d'un etre qui vit dans le desert de soi-meme et qui ose y vivre." But, at the same time, there is optimism: "... la poesie ... en exprimant la solitude, semble ouvrir la chambre fermee, decouvrir l'issue de l'impasse."

D17       Duhamel, Roger. "Poesie des cimes arides." L'Action universitaire [Univ. de Montreal], 20, No. 2 (jan. 1954), 88-89. Duhamel praises "cette haute et exigeante poesie" which expresses "les interrogations les plus profondes qui peuvent hanter un esprit humain."

D18     Collin, W.E. "Letters in Canada: 1953. Publications in French." University of Toronto Quarterly, 23 (April 1954), 325-26. Collin sees the volume as "the poetry of the heart that wants to shut itself in with its pain" and proceeds to analyze the poems from this point of view. The poetry shows "the nothingness, the dust of a tradition of guilt."

D19      Rousseaux, Andre. "Pontes canadiens." Le Figaro litteraire [Paris], 8 mai 1954, p. 2. Rpt. in Le Devoir [Montreal], 12 juin 1954, pp. 6-7. Rousseaux praises the density of the poetic imagery which expresses an anguish similar to that of Saint-Denys Garneau. At all times the poems express the wish of an imprisoned soul for freedom.

D20      Moon, Samuel. "Canadian Chronicle." Rev. of Extended, by Dorothy Roberts; Exso Hate, by Richard Outram; The Tomb of the Kings, by Anne Hebert; and The Circle Game, by Margaret Atwood. Poetry [Chicago], 112 (June 1968), 203. Rpt. (excerpt) in Modern Commonwealth Literature: A Library of Literary Criticism. Ed. John H. Ferres and Martin Tucker. New York: Frederick Ungar, 1977, p.285. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Authors: A Bio-Bibliographical Guide to Current Writers in Fiction, General Nonfiction, Poetry, Journalism, Drama, Motion Pictures, Television, and Other Fields. Ed. Frances Carol Locher. Vols. LXXXV-LXXXVIII. Detroit: Gale, 1980, 250. The book is "unified by its constant introspection, by its atmosphere of profound melancholy," and its themes. Moon comments on Hebert's remarkable "imagery, the simplicity and directness of her diction, and the restrained lyric sound of her vers libre." Sometimes, however, "... the imagery becomes too elaborate, turns into machinery .... "

D21     "Capsule Reviews." Canadian Author & Bookman, 43, No. 2 (Winter 1967), 24. This capsule review (four sentences) of the Peter Miller translation mentions that "Anne Hebert's poetic world is a haunting fairyland of gorgeous surroundings which reflect loneliness, adult despair, isolation and suicide .... she descends to the permanent bedrock of alienation and frustration."

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Item Number: ABCMA07AHP2000007002004002
Record: 35
Title:
Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews; Le Torrent
Other Title:
Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews
Record Type:
Reference Series
Series Title:
Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors, no. 7
Author(s):
Russell, D.W. (compiler)
Genre(s):

Subject(s):

Titles critiqued:  LE torrent (Book)
Topics:  CANADIAN literature -- Bibliography; FRENCH-CANADIAN literature -- Bibliography
Book Source:

https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07AHP2000007002004009&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07AHP2000007002004009&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews; Le Torrent</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Anne Hebert. Russell, D.W. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 145-263

Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews; Le Torrent  

Russell, D.W. (compiler)

Le Torrent

D128      Bonenfant, Y.D. Rev. of Le Torrent. Le Soleil [Quebec], 11 mars 1950, p. 4. Bonenfant praises the stories, commenting on the powerful imagery, the psychological depth, the stylistic beauty, and the vibrant life of the work. "Le Torrent" itself could easily have been a novel, since it goes beyond the usual limits of the short story.

D129      Elie, Robert. "Anne Hebert et les possedes innocents" Notre temps [Montreal], 25 mars 1950, p. 3. Elie praises the style and content of the work: "... une phrase, un mot nous revelent une profonde experience de la douleur et, surtout, une genereuse attention a la douleur des autres et a cet appel d'amour si combattu, mais qui est la seule promesse de vie."

D130      Marcotte, Gilles. "Le Torrent d'Anne Hebert." Le Devoir [Montreal], 25 mars 1950, p. 8. Marcotte states that these stories contain more poetry than Hebert's first volume of verse; "... pour la premiere fois un ecrivain canadien s'affirme par le prodige de son style, et j'y vois un evenement capital pour notre jeune litterature." However, the title story is too long to sustain its poetic content. "L'Ange de Dominique" is weakened by the occasional banality of language, "Le Printemps de Catherine" is a little too melodramatic, but the other two stories have attained a fragile perfection.

D131      Hamelin, Jean. "Quand un porte se fait conteur." La Presse [Montreal], 15 avril 1950, p.65. Hamelin laments the lack of definition in the language and symbolism of these stories which "baignent toutes dans une fantasie irreelle." Although there is little dialogue, the language of the stories has a simple beauty. The strongest characters are the women, particularly Claudine of "Le Torrent" and Catherine of "Le Printemps de Catherine."

D132      Racette, Jacques-Thomas. "Le Torrent d'Anne Hebert." La Revue dominicaine, mai 1950, pp. 294-97. Racette is impressed with the strength of these stories which could have become novels. They present the suffering of beings without grace. Hebert has created "de beaux types tragiques; elle leur donne une time aux prises avec l'existence et le destin." Hebert is a poet who is called to give a disquieting vision of the world, and her stories can be reduced to one essential message: "... ils sont une reintegration de la sensibilite originelle de l'autre."

D133      Amyot, Georges. "Anne Hebert." Liaison, sept. 1950, pp. 350-52. Amyot prefaces his comments by discussing the genius of Saint-Denys Garneau, who resembles his cousin Anne Hebert in his artistic sensibilities. He also comments on previous works of Hebert: Les Songes en equilibre has "sept ou huit poemes de grande classe." It also has weaknesses: "La valeur des Prieres, par exemple, est tres discutable." Although the poems published in Gants du ciel before 1950 show maturity of style, this promise is not yet fully realized in Le Torrent. "Dans ces contes l'auteur n'a pas resolu tous les problemes poses par la poesie. L'alliage du reel et de l'imagination n'est pas pleinement reussi. Il y a parfois de l'incertitude. Une certaine gaucherie peut-etre" He affirms that the flaws are not major, however: "'L'Ange de Dominique' est une feerie exquise. Beaucoup moins parfait, le 'Torrent' est un recit terrible et magnifique. La poesie en est sombre et dense, et d'une richesse inouie." These are small masterpieces, and Hebert, along with Saint-Denys Garneau "preparent certainement une place pour nos futurs poetes de la joie." He suggests that Hebert may be soon to produce "l'oeuvre vraiment geniale qu'elle porte en elle ..."

D134      Duhamel, Roger. Rev. of Le Torrent. L'Action universitaire [Univ. de Montreal], 17, No. 1 (oct. 1950), 75-76. The stories verge on being too poetic, on being too dreamed, rather than lived. Despite the melodramatic and unreal elements, Hebert does manage to convey a sense of human emotion in her characters.

D135      Sylvestre, Guy. Rev. of Le Torrent. Le Droit [Ottawa], 11 nov. 1950, p. 2. Sylvestre discusses Les Songes en equilibre as an introduction to his review of the stories. The poems were an impressive collection which showed more grace than the usual serious tone found in much French-Canadian poetry; the disquieting humanity of her poems was a welcome change from the sterile formal correctness of other poets. The stories are very uneven. However, the title story has a force and a troubling tragic intensity which is unusual. The stories also express the theme of solitude, although only the title story is effective.

D136      Lombard, Bertrand. "Litterature canadienne d'expression francaise: Le Petite Poule d'eau, Le Torrent et autres ouvrages." Revue de l'Universite Laval, 5 (jan. 1951), 465-67. "Le plus grave ... c'est que les personnages de mademoiselle Hebert ne sont pas de notre terroir et appartiennent par la tristesse de leur destin, aux absurdites existentialistes"

D137      Collin, W.E. "Letters in Canada: 1950. FrenchCanadian Letters" University of Toronto Quarterly, 20 (July 1951), 397-98. Rpt. (excerpt) in Modern Commonwealth Literature: A Library of Literary Criticism. Ed. John H. Ferres and Martin Tucker. New York: Frederick Ungar, 1977, pp. 283-84. The poetic nature of these works expresses the duality of the poetic personality: "... a poet, who is aware of his life as a surge of impulses within him, is irked by routine, every-day existence." The house of "La Maison de l'esplanade" could be seen to symbolize the "bondage of tradition" while the water of the falls could be seen to represent "the essential life of the poet." Collin comments on both the title story and on "L'Ange de Dominique" which he finds particularly effective.

D138      Marcotte, Gilles. "Reediton d'un grand livre." La Presse [Montreal], 18 jan. 1964, Sec. Cahiers Arts et lettres, p. 6. In a new appraisal of the volume, Marcotte gives a classic criticism of Le Torrent: "Cette fable terrible et belle est l'expression la plusjuste qui nous ait ete donne du drame spirituel du Canada francais. Sa portee sociale est explosive" He praises the stylistic perfection of this story. The other stories seem weak in comparison to "Le Torrent," and the two new stories show the author moving toward a more realistic style.

D139      Basile, Jean. "Les Lettres canadiennes: Le Torrent d'Anne Hebert." Le Devoir [Montreal], 25 jan. 1964, p.13. The stories are all retellings of the same theme. They can be defined by the theme of rape, and its opposite, virginity. Basile discusses "La Maison de l'esplanade" as an example of this theory. Although he dislikes the prose style of the stories, they contain a sense of an inner life which is attractive, but which is absent from the two new stories in this edition.

D140      Lockquell, C1ement. "Le Torrent d'Anne Hebert." Le Soleil [Quebec], 1 fev. 1964, p. 46. The stories create an atmosphere of poetic terror.

D141      Sinoir, Mariel. "Le Torrent d'Anne Hebert." Les Nouvelles litteraires [Paris], 18 fev. 1965, p. 4. The stories are written in a simple, but strongly descriptive style. All the characters live a sort of"depossession"

D142      Macri, F.M. "A Skeleton Closet." Journal of Canadian Fiction, 3, No. 2 (1974), 105-06. The Gwendolyn Moore translation is "a poor reflection of the interesting and exciting world of Hebert's fiction." Macri gives details about the deficiencies, among which is the absence of the story "L'Ange de Dominique." "These stories, about sterility, solitude, isolation, failed love and death, told with surgical acuteness, will be like glimpsing into a skeleton closet for readers of Kamouraska."

D143      Vintcent, Brian. "Hebert in Awkward English." Saturday Night, Feb. 1974, pp.34-35. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, and Other Creatwe Writers. Ed. Carolyn Riley. Vol. IV. Detroit: Gale, 1975,220. The Gwendolyn Moore translations are faithful, but too literal, and "L'Ange de Dominique" is missing. Vintcent gives a brief summary of the stories, which are "... all carefully worked miniatures which outline the boundaries of Hebert's artistic world. It is a limited one in which humans struggle more with themselves than with social forces outside their control. But what Hebert loses in breadth, she gains in depth."

D144     Shohet, Linda. "The Torrent." Canadian Fiction Magazine, No. 15 (Autumn 1974), pp. 97-99. Shohet characterizes the title story as "one of the most brilliant pieces of short fiction in Quebecois literature." Its "magically allusive prose which is forever becoming poetry ... has been sadly reduced, frequently lost, in Gwendolyn Moore's plodding translation."

D145      Godard, Barbara. "Quebec in Translation." The CanadianForum, Nov.-Dec. 1974, p. 24. The Torrent (trans. by Gwendolyn Moore) is the "first great classic of modern Quebec fiction" and "the first poetic novel in Quebec fiction."

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Item Number: ABCMA07AHP2000007002004009
Record: 36
Title:
Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews; Les Chambres de bois
Other Title:
Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews
Record Type:
Reference Series
Series Title:
Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors, no. 7
Author(s):
Russell, D.W. (compiler)
Genre(s):
Bibliography
Subject(s):
Authors discussed:  HEBERT, Anne; HEBERT, Anne -- Criticism & interpretation -- Bibliography
Titles critiqued:  LES chambres de bois (Book)
Topics:  CANADIAN literature -- Bibliography; FRENCH-CANADIAN literature -- Bibliography
Book Source:
Russell, D.W. (compiler) Part 2: Works On Anne Hebert.
Publisher Information: Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987. (pp. 145-263)
ISBN: 0920763111 (hardcover); 092076312X (paperback)
Series Data: Lecker, Robert (editor). David, Jack (editor). Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors ; no. 7
Book Control ID: ABCMA07AHP2
p. 238-239 (2 p.)

<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07AHP2000007002004004&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews; Les Chambres de bois</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Anne Hebert. Russell, D.W. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 145-263

Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews; Les Chambres de bois  

Russell, D.W. (compiler)

Les Chambres de bois

D34       de Grandpre, Pierre. "Un roman d'Anne Hebert: Les Chambres de bois." Le Devoir [Montreal], 27 sept. 1958, p. 11. This novel expresses "par fines approches symboliques le drame de sa propre evolution interieure .... " The victory of Catherine and Aline is over the forces of alienation, solitude, "l'absence au monde, le vertige de la mort .... " The theme of the novel is also the dominant one of contemporary French-Canadian poetry, and the work is addressed to the "compatriotes" of the novelist, who is urging them to "regarder vers le monde, avant de se mirer comme Narcisse au miroir de ses propres reves." De Grandpre praises the poetic style, which is far removed from traditional novelistic style. The brief elliptical chapters are "chants" which give the novel its poetic beauty and rigour.

D35      McLean, Eric. "A Poetic Novel by Anne Hebert: Les Chambres de bois." The Montreal Star, 18 Oct. 1958, p. 34. This is "one of the finest Canadian works I have read in many years." McLean praises above all the poetic structure and language of the work.

D36       Lockquell, Clement. Rev. of Les Chambres de bois. Le Soleil [Quebec], 9 nov. 1958, p. 4. Lockquell contrasts the characters' painful complexes with the elegant and serene style which expresses these complexes. Hebert's understatement is very effective in conveying these passions which the reader will quickly recognize.

D37       Lombard, Pierre. Rev. of Les Chambres de bois. L'Action catholique [Montreal], 15 nov. 1958, p.4. Although Lombard is impressed with the lyrical style of the novel, he does not approve of certain scenes ("comme des poubelles cabossees placees sur l'autel par un bedeau possede") in this novel which is for adult readers only.

D38       Simon, P[ierre]. Henri. Rev. of Les Chambres de bois. LaRevue de Paris, dec. 1958, p. 178. Hebert has talent, but her poetic temperament dominates the novel too much. The style of the work reminds Simon of certain aspects of Villiers de l'Isle-Adam and Maeterlinck, and he suspects that Hebert has not yet found her authentic voice.

D39      Robert, Guy. "Petit Bilan de notre litterature 1958: Les Chambres de bois." La Revue dominicaine, mars 1959, pp. 84-86. The poetic style is "impressionniste, pointilliste, allant par vagues, par touches." The novel is "un poeme delicat et subtil, delicieusement feminin et cousin rapproche de Saint-Denys Garneau."

D40       Beaver, John. Rev. of The Silent Rooms. Quill & Quire, Dec. 1974, pp. 22-23. Although this work compares unfavourably with Kamouraska, it is "nonetheless fascinating as it similarly evokes a young woman's struggle against a blighted and decaying society." Beaver praises the translation which "has nicely caught that tone; brittle and obsessive yet finally, when Catherine breaks the spell, rich and expansive."

D41     Raspa, Anthony. Rev. of The Silent Rooms. Journal of Canadian Fiction, 4, No.3 (1975), 173-75. In this review of the translation by Kathy Mezei, Raspa praises the original novel which is a watershed work in Quebec. Hebert's symbolist techniques free the novel from the constraints of the Quebec literary tradition. The theme of the work is the choice between normalcy and a certain kind of art.

D42      Grosskurth, Phyllis. "Vapour from a Jewelled Casket." Canadian Literature, No.65 (Summer 1975), pp. 117-18. The translation (The Silent Rooms) is faulty, but not unbearable. The true fault lies in the original, which is not good poetic prose, but a "transitional work belonging in that indulgent and rather murky region between poetry and prose." Les Chambres de bois is disappointing in comparison with Kamouraska, for here "all is hint, vague echo, allusion, a vapour evapourizing from a jewelled casket."

D43      Rudzik, O.H.T. "Letters in Canada: 1974. Fiction." University of Toronto Quarterly, .44 (Summer 1975), 310. Rudzik comments on the translation (The Silent Rooms), done sixteen years after the original. This time lapse has made "the ancestral manor a recognizable trope across the Ottawa. But the psychic silence is still hard to assimilate fully. Obliqueness and intensity of perception and a self-attenuating consciousness -- are felt and apprehended; understanding them as a given condition, a pre-literary reality, is more difficult."

D44     van Varseveld, Gail. "Speaking Out from Silent Rooms." Room of One's Own, 1, No. 2 (Summer 1975), 75-76. Van Varseveld laments the time lag between the original and the English translation (The Silent Rooms) of this work. She sees a hint of Marxian analysis in the novel in the contrast between the pure, working-class Bruno and the degenerate, aristocrat Michel. Van Varseveld is pleasantly surprised by the character Bruno: "... here perhaps is a man who may be capable of allowing his wife to be a person rather than an object."

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Anne Hebert. Russell, D.W. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 145-263

Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews; Les Enfants du sabbat  

Russell, D.W. (compiler)

Les Enfants du sabbat

D69       Basile, Jean. "Le Nouveau Roman d'Anne Hebert: seraient-ce des enfants qui frequentent le sabbat?". Le Devoir [Montreal], 6 sept. 1975, p.13. "Ce livre d'apparence choquante est, au contraire, un moment essentiel de notre psyche collective." Basile points out particularly the influence of Jules Michelet's La Sorciere, of which Hebert's novel is in part a paraphrase, since both deal with a fundamental revolt against the position in which a religious inversion has placed women. The principal theme of the novel is the "inversion maligne des valeurs," the question of good and evil. Basile's only regret is that the author "se laisse prendre au petit jeu de la haine des valeurs institutionnelles" and does not give the Church any redeemingqualities.

D70       Martel, Reginald. "La Quadrature du cercle de famille." La Presse [Montreal], 6 sept. 1975, p.D3. Hebert has exposed another aspect "de notre etrange aventure culturelle" and given perhaps the definitive view of sorcery in Quebec.

D71      Hebert, Francois. "Mere nature et ses enfants ou un samedi pas comme les autres." Le Jour [Montreal], 13 sept. 1975, p. 14. This is one of the greatest Quebec novels, and its subject matter extends well beyond the short bibliography of demonology given at the end of the novel. Les Enfants du sabbat deals with many of the fundamental myths of man, beginning with the nature of good and evil and the Oedipus myth, to name only two. Hebert finds the characters well-rounded and disagrees with Jean Basile's criticism that the novelist is too cynical with respect to the Church (D69).

D72      Vallieres, Pierre. "Anne Hebert celebre la beaute du Diable." Le Jour [Montreal], 13 sept. 1975, p. 14. Vallieres describes the novel as "... notre 'saison en enfer' quebecoise, un tres beau livre, un extraordinaire eloge au Mal, vainqueur du temps, de l'espace et des interdits." If published in the 1940s or 1950s this novel would have been scandalous. Although it is now accepted by Quebec society, they will not necessarily understand that its subject is the need for revolt against all constraints, and that life really only exists beyond good and evil.

D73      France, Peter. "The Rending of the Veil." The Times Literary Supplement [London], 10 Oct. 1975, p.1208. Rpt. (excerpt)in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Dedria Bryfonski and Laurie Lanzen Harris. Vol. XIII. Detroit: Gale, 1980, 267-68. The subject matter is too overworked to be memorable, and the tone of the novel is too anthropologically detached to involve the reader. France compares this novel ("the work of a considerable poet") with "Le Torrent," which presents many of the same dilemmas. "In spite of its larger dimensions and more inflammatory subjects, Les Enfants du sabbat is a less powerful piece of work than 'Le Torrent.'" Instead of the obsessional, first-person narration we have a shifting point of view which allows the author to make fun of many of her outwardly prim ecclesiastical characters.

D74      Renaud, Andre. "Les Enfants du sabbat: une oeuvre forte." Le Droit [Ottawa], 11 oct. 1975, p. 18. This novel marks a strict continuity with Hebert's previous work: "ne marquant rien de fondamentalement neuf dans la thematique d'Anne Hebert, mais poussant l'experience originale plus avant, dans une technique renouvelee puis dans un langage plus carrement quebecois, donc plus authentique." Renaud praises the style, with its brief sequences which repeat thematic variations, and he comments on the increasingly concrete Quebec flavour in her works, very evident in both Kamouraska and this last novel. Continued in D75.

D75     Renaud, Andre. "Les Enfants du sabbat: une oeuvre forte." Le Droit [Ottawa], 18 oct. 1975, p.16. A continuation of D74.

D76      Allard, Jacques. "Les Enfants du sabbat d'Anne Hebert." Voix et images: etudes quebecoises, 1 (dec. 1975), 285-86. Allard comments on the style of the novel, which he sees as the structural expansion of the verse in poetry. The novel is divided into fiftythree "lexies"; "... les unites de lecture ne sont visiblement pas des chapitres, mais des recits plutot courts (d'une dizaine de lignes a une douzaine de pages) qui ont diverses fonctions au plan narratif."

D77      Roiter, Howard. "Sister Julie Planting Seeds." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 6 Dec. 1975, p. 34. This is an "unsettling work" which is "far removed from her 1971 masterpiece, Kamouraska." Despite the similarities to Rosemary's Baby, The Devils, and The Exorcist, this novel shows the fundamental unity of Hebert's vision. The novel is "memorable because it convincingly depicts universal moral ambiguities against the concrete background of an old, mentally rigid Quebec teetering on the brink of a new era."

D78       Rivard, Yvon. Rev. of Les Enfants du sabbat. In Livres et auteurs quebecois 1975. Gen. ed. Clement Moisan, Marcel Belanger, and Maximilien Laroche. Quebec: Les Presses de l'Univ. Laval, 1976, pp. 24-26. The novel is not completely successful, for, although it has delved into "l'imaginaire pour y redecouvrir ce couple qui a engendre l'ame quebecoise, celui du coureur de bois et de l'habitant," the conflict between these two forces is not sustained enough. Sister Julie's victories are too easy.

D79      Resch, Yannick. "Anne Hebert: Les Enfants du sabbat." Europe [Paris], Nos.561-62 (jan.-fev. 1976), pp. 254-55. Resch comments on Hebert's continuity with her earlier work, repeating in particular the examination of the world of childhood. The double life of Julie is compared to that of Elisabeth in Kamouraska.

D80      Dube Pelletier, Irene. "Lettre ouverte a Anne Hebert." Le Devoir [Montreal], 14 fev. 1976, p. 18. In this letter written from Santa Monica, California, the novel is roundly criticized for plagiarism from Rosemary's Baby and The Exorcist and for its cynical depiction of religious life. "Pourquoi cette trahison de votre heritage chretien servi comme un ragout de 'pattes de cochon' sur les defoulements psycho-pathologiques d'une sexualite etalee comme une 'boucherie'.?" The writer invites Hebert to visit Quebec and rediscover the truth about the people -- then "... vous aurez tellement honte de votre livre que vous ferez comme moi: vous le jetterez a la poubelle apres l'avoir pilonne."

D81       Poulin, Gabrielle. "La 'Nouvelle Heloise' quebecoise: une lecture des Enfants du sabbat." Relations, mars 1976, pp.92-94. Rpt. in Romans du pays 1968-1979. By Gabrielle Poulin. Montreal: Bellarmin, 1980, pp. 299-306. Julie incorporates the three qualities of woman found in Kamouraska, and Poulin develops the relationship between Julie's revolt against the constraints of society and the revolt found in Hebert's poetry. "Le roman penetre dans les preoccupations de toute une epoque qui fut tragiquement divisee entre le spirituel et le charnel." The novel rewrites "une page de l'histoire du Quebec, reinvente l'univers fermi, tragique, dresse comme un bastion aux confins du ciel et de l'enfer. Face a elle, se dresse le monstre historique aux multiples tetes, dieu et diable a la fois."

D82       Poulin, Gabrielle. "Qui sont les 'Enfants du sabbat?'". Les Lettres quebecoises, No.1 (mars 1976), pp.4-6. Rpt. in Romans du pays 1968-1979. By Gabrielle Poulin. Montreal: Bellarmin, 1980, pp. 307-13. Poulin concentrates on the conflict between the attraction life exercises on Julie and the Mother Superior's conviction that the outside world is evil. "La vie est peche, la vie est douleur, la vie est diabolique. Soeur Julie est donc possedee du demon, ainsi en a decide mere Marie-Clothilde de la Croix." The birth of the child at the end of the novel signals a victory of the appeal of life, and Julie escapes from both the demonic and the religious ways of life.

D83       Poulin, Gabrielle. "D'Elisabeth a soeur Julie: Les Enfants du sabbat d'Anne Halbert." Le Droit [Ottawa], 17 avril 1976, p. 20. Again, Poulin compares Julie to the three women in Kamouraska: Elisabeth had tried to use the demonic power of Aurelie and the divine powers of Catherine in her attempt to win the love of Nelson (see D81). In this novel, Julie assumes all three of these roles, for she is lover, witch, and nun. She refuses the "Tombeau des rois" type of existence offered by the convent, and her instinct for life wins out over the silence of death. The birth and death of her child at the end of the novel is a sign of the liberation of women from all three of these roles which society has placed them in.

D84     Mezei, Kathy. "Commands and Desires." Canadian Literature, No. 70 (Autumn 1976), pp. 79-81. Les Enfants du sabbat is "the archetypal Quebec literary experience: a precocious adolescent becomes the battleground between the commands of the spirit and the desires of the flesh."

D85      French, William. "A Bizarre Story of a Young Nun Now on Two Levels." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 28 April 1977, p. 17. The novel is a "powerful indictment of the priest-ridden society that began to crumble with the death of Maurice Duplessis in 1959." Julie escapes from the convent "just as Quebec within a few years escaped from the kind of society that produced her." He finds the English translation serviceable.

D86      Stratford, Philip. "Anne Hebert's Romance of Evil." Quill & Quire, April 1977, p. 38. Stratford calls the translation a solid piece of work which "catches the nervous power and demonic hilarity of the original." He comments on the "brilliant sustained use of black humour" in "this powerful gothic tale" by one of Quebec's most distinguished writers.

D87      Oates, Joyce Carol. "Four Novels." Rev. of Sadler's Birthday, by Rose Tremain; Staggerford, by Jon Hassler; Children of the Black Sabbath, by Anne Hebert, trans. Carol DunlopHebert; and A Wreath of Pale White Roses, by Erika Duncan. The New York Times Book Review, 24 July 1977, pp.14--15. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Dedria Bryfonski and Laurie Lanzen Harris. Vol. XIII. Detroit: Gale, 1980, 268. Children of the Black Sabbath "is merely silly ... Anne Hebert seems to have settled for dispirited pop fiction. And that it is so plainly derivative is both puzzling and embarrassing."

D88     Socken, Paul G. "Almost Anachronistic" The Canadian Forum, Aug. 1977, p.39. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Dedria Bryfonski and Laurie Lanzen Harris. Vol.XIII. Detroit: Gale, 1980, 268. Finding little new in the thematic content, Socken states that "... it seems anachronistic after the Quiet Revolution and Nov. 15 to continue painting a picture of Quebec that is one of unrelieved gloom and despair." The strength of the novel lies in its poetic language, which is evident even in the English translation.

D89      Watkins, Mel. "Books: Artful Maleficence. Children of the Black Sabbath." The New York Times, 7 Sept. 1977, p.C19. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Authors: A Bio-Bibliographical Guide to Current Writers in Fiction, General Nonfiction, Poetry, Journalism, Drama, Motion Pictures, Television, and Other Fields. Ed. Frances Carol Locher. Vols. LXXXV-LXXXVIII. Detroit: Gale, 1980, 250. This is "... an impressionistic tale that moves smoothly from the detail of convent ritual and liturgy to the supernatural manifestations of Sister Julie's mind. The vitality of the prose, of itself, makes it one of the best of its kind."

D90      Micros, Marianne. "Rape and Ritual." Rev. of Children of the Black Sabbath, by Anne Hebert, trans. Carol Dunlop-Hebert; and Poems by Anne Hebert, by Anne Hebert, trans. Alan Brown. Essays on Canadian Writing, Nos.7-8 (Fall 1977), pp. 31-34. The novel is "a gothic thriller or horror story," but also "moves on several levels." The writing is "poetic, filled with symbolism and imagery" and leads "us to a psychological interpretation .... The structure of the book intensifies the horror of the diabolism"; the "contrast between the convent and the diabolical world is not as extreme as one would expect," and the symbols ambiguously indicate both. Hebert's writing has "power without sensationalism" and the translation remains faithful to her style. "While Hebert's novels become darker, they also become more polished in technique, and reach deeper levels of the mind."

D91       Hind-Smith, Joan. "Forget Politics, the Artists Have the Heart." Rev. of Family, by Jean-Guy Carrier; and Children of the Black Sabbath, by Anne Hebert. Books in Canada, Oct. 1977, pp. 23-24. The translation is sensible, and Hebert's earlier work is "surpassed by the dramatic clarity and firm technique of Children of the Black Sabbath." The novel "focuses on the polarities of pallid goodness and earthy evil" and the "sacred and profane merge as one and the same, mirror images and inversions of each other."

D92      Davies, Gillian. "Of Princes and Scarecrows: A Look at Contemporary Quebec Fiction." Queen's Quarterly, 85 (Autumn 1978), 447,448-50, 451. Davies discusses several recent Quebec novels, all of which "fascinate less than they repel." Children of the Black Sabbath combines the incest of Les Chambres de bois with the "gory passions" of Kamouraska. The novel is melodramatic and Gothic; it is "neither poignant nor frightening .... It resembles an intellectual exercise more than an intensely felt spiritual experience."

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Anne Hebert. Russell, D.W. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 145-263

Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews; Les Fous de Bassan  

Russell, D.W. (compiler)

     Les Fous de Bassan

D104      C[haillet]., J[ean].-P[aul]. "Anne Hebert: bal tragique a Griffin Creek." Les Nouvelles litteraires [Paris], 26 aout -- 1 sept. 1982, p. 31. "Anne Hebert dans ce recit palpitant, serie noire d'une nuit d'ete, mele habilement differents genres litteraires, parfaitement maitrises par l'auteur de Karnouraska. Ce cinquinine roman nous plonge dans un univers dramatique au ton fortement empreint de cet amour du style, de cette capacite a faire revivre les caracteres et les situations."

D105      Tremblay, Regis. "Une rentree litteraire en tornade." Le Soleil [Quebec], 4 sept. 1982, p. D8. "Parmi les trois autres, il faut mentionner la toute premiere, Anne Hebert dont le nouveau roman, Les Fous de Bassan, est disponible dans nos librairies a partir d'aujourd'hui meme .... C'est le meilleur Anne Hebert, encore bien meilleur que 'Kamouraska.'"

D106      Martel, Reginald. "Les Fous de Bassan: magnifique. A la tres douce memoire de rinnocence brisee." La Presse [Montreal], 11 sept. 1982, p. C3. "C'est un texte magnifique, d'ou surgit la puissance conjuguee et mysterieuse de lamer et des meres .... I1 y a trop de richesses dans Les Fous de Bassan pour pretendre les apprehender en une seule lecture."

D107      Ouellette-Michalska, Madeleine. "Anne Hebert: l'attrait du double." Le Devoir [Montreal], 11 sept. 1982, pp. 17, 32. "Dans Les Fous de Bassan comme dans Les Enfants du Sabbat, Heloise et meme deja Kamouraska, en marge de l'univers manicheiste presentant la normalite apparente ... se meut un monde parallele obscur, clandestin, tout aussi dense et agissant, ou s'ebauchent des gestes et se creent des liens de parente qui prolongent ou brouillent les identites acquises. Et c'est peut-etre le sens fondamental de l'oeuvre d'Anne Hebert ... C'est tout le manicheisme occidental, et son puritanisme, qui se trouve interpele dans Les Fous de Bassan, beau roman a l'ecriture parfaite."

D108      Tremblay, Regis. "Anne Hebert atteint a une beaute insoutenable." Le Soleil [Quebec], 18 sept. 1982, p. F8. "Anne Hebert vieillit bien et mal. Son ecriture atteint a une beaute insoutenable, et en meme temps, ce que cette ecriture livre et delivre tourne au plus exemplaire des desespoirs. C'est le souffle genereux et penetrant de la mort qui balaie Griffin Creek .... "

D109      Cellard, Jacques. "Le Canada inattendu d'Anne Hebert." Le Monde [Paris], 24 sept. 1982, p. 17. This is the first good novel by Hebert since Kamouraska: "le retour d'une grande romanciere, avec les accents inattendus du Canada drier .... Construit et ecrit de main de maitre. Seul reproche que l'on pourrait faire a ce tres beau livre: sa quasi-perfection technique (en particulier celle du journal de Nora, beaucoup trop litteraire et 'sophistique' pour pouvoir etre celui d'une enfant de quinze ans ...) nous empeche, par moments, d'y adherer pleinement. Mais quel beau travail."

D110      Lamy, Suzanne. "Le Roman de l'irresponsabilite." Spirale, nov. 1982, pp. 2, 3. Les Fous de Bassan is as great, or even greater, a disappointment as Heloise, but will be popular with the public. The characters are all variants of well-worn stereotypes: Stevens, for example, "... c'est un peu Alexis, un peu Le simple soldat, un peu le Survenant ...." Some readers will like the presence of nature: "Comme on a eu le roman de la terre, on a la le roman de lamer." The novel allows an escape into an exotic, irrational, and chaotic natural world, which absolves the characters of responsibility for their actions. The novel is criticized above all for its failure at the level of language. The use of local colour at the lexical level may appeal to some, but Hebert does not succeed in creating five distinct narrative voices. Lamy criticizes "cette ecriture repetitive et pleonastique ...," Hebert's facile use of "phrases nominales" and elliptical sentences, and her banal and cliched expressions and images. On the level of content, Hebert examines such themes as the irreconcilable hatred between the sexes, a distorted and violent image of sexuality, the impossibility of women ever assuming their sexuality, female competition for a single male, and the myth of the bad mother.

D111      "Anne Hebert laureate du prix Femina." Le Devoir [Montreal], 23 nov. 1982, pp.1, 8. Rpt. in Le Droit [Ottawa], 23 nov. 1982, pp. 1, 28. Rpt. in La Presse [Montreal], 23 nov. 1982, p. C4. "Anne Hebert a obtenu le prix Femina au premier tour par cinq voix contre trois .... Les Fous de Bassan est dans la tradition de l'oeuvre de son auteur, un roman poetique dont le pretexte est une enigme policiere .... Dans Les Fous de Bassan, sorte de roman noir, Anne Hebert ... poursuit une oeuvre qui, tout en illustrant le devenir du Quebec, se refuse sacrifier au folklore."

D112      Robitaille, Louis-Bernard. "Petite Histoire d'un gros prix." Le Devoir [Montreal], 27 nov. 1982, p. 23. Robitaille discusses competition for the Prix Goncourt, for which Hebert was a favourite, then for the Prix Femina. Les Fous de Bassan has the literary qualities to make it a financial success, perhaps even greater than that of this year's Goncourt winner: it has an "ecriture a la fois romantique et classique, une 'vraie' histoire, un climat."

D113      Royer, Jean. "Anne Hebert ou la passion de vivre." Le Devoir [Montreal], 27 nov. 1982, p. 23. "Son dernier roman, Les Fous de Bassan, non seulement se revele un chef-d'oeuvre de l'ecriture d'Anne Hebert mais se situe en quelque sorte au sommet d'une thematique qui, creusee de livre en livre, touche ici de la facon la plus complete a la passion de vivre."

D114      Garneau, Rene. Rev. of Les Fous de Bassan. Ecrits du Canada francais, 47 (1983), 177-81. The fictional world of Hebert is moving closer to that of classical tragedy with each succeeding work. "On est temoin en effet, chez Anne Hebert, d'une descente dans le noir, ou mieux, d'une exploration du mal .... " The novel places the source of modern violence "dans une violence antique qui avait nom tragedie." Hebert "a imagine de remettre aux habitants d'un village canadien de la cote atlantique le sort d'un extraordinaire reseau de sentiments et de passions, de reves et de delires, de pulsations et d'instincts, de vertus et de vices, ou devait s'exprimer, dans son authenticite originelle, ce qu'on peut appeler la violence d'aujourd'hui." The mastery of form in the novel is similar to that of Kamouraska. "En somme, l'oeuvre tres belle et solidement structuree d'un ecrivain au sommet de son talent."

D115      Cosse, Laurence. "Anne Hebert: Les Fous de Bassan." La Nouvelle Revue francaise [Paris], fev. 1983, pp. 130-32. The novel presents monologues of both victim s and of their three possible murderers, revealing gradually the chronology of the events leading to the murders, and the psychological make-up of the participants. Although the plot has no surprises, there is the same sort of suspense as in a thriller. "Et on ne juge pas: car le jugement humain serait derisoire dans ce drame cosmique oh les determinismes reduisent a rien la liberte des hommes, de toute eternite." In the end, it is nature and the elements that are guilty of destruction.

D116      Melacon, Robert. "Ce qui est sans nom ni date. Anne Hebert: Les Fous de Bassan." Liberte, 25, No. 1 (fev. 1983), 89-93. Melancon examines the significance of the fairy-tale world in presenting truth which goes beyond historical detail. He compares Heloise with Les Fous de Bassan in this light, where human destiny is not governed merely by reason: "Fantastique, imaginaire, feerie, n'importe. Dans tout le texte courent les ills d'or d'innombrables allusions aux contes pour enfants .... Ce n'est pas sans raison que ce roman domine par la fatalite a lieu sur la scene elementaire de la tragedie ...."

D117      Sejour, Laurence. "De l'envoutement a la folie, ou l'univers dualiste de Griffin Creek." Critique [Paris], mars 1982, pp. 242-47. Sejour comments on the duality of the omnipresent wind in this novel: it is both the "Esprit de Dieu" and its opposite, "un vent de folie." All the characters feel both an "aspiration la paix et le desir de violence." The village of Griffin Creek is both paradise and hell and suddenly becomes a theatre of violence, madness, and murder. The development of the major characters is described briefly. In the end, all the characters are touched by the madness that is the "affirmation incontrolee de [leurs] passions les plus vives."

D118      Michon, Jacques. "Letters in Canada: 1982. Romans." University of Toronto Quarterly, 52 (Summer 1983), 338-39. Michon notes the themes and style in Hebert's work: "On est frappe par la grande continuite, la permanence des images et des themes hebertiens. Comme l'univers de Griffin Creek cette oeuvre ne se transforme pas, elle s'approfondit. On y reconnait la maniere de l'auteure, ses phrases courtes, exactes, rhythmees comme des vers, avec une economie de moyens remarquable."

D119      Johnson, William. "Hebert's World Bathed in Poetry." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 5 Aug. 1983, Sec. National, p. 8. Johnson notes that Les Fous de Bassan won the Prix Femina, was on the short list for the Prix Goncourt, and will be published in English. "Hebert's world bathes in poetry, the characters never fully emerge from the ambience of fog or blinding sunlight reflected on the water." Her "simple story of a crime becomes suffused with symbols, with intimations of the supernatural, which are themselves perhaps emanations of psychological states." Nature "responds to the moral climate of human agents:' Johnson discusses the different narrators and notes "Some will find the book extravagant, indigestible. Others will respond to the sheer play of imagination, sprung."

D120      Collins, Anne. "A Closet Full of Snakes." Maclean's, 17 Oct. 1983, p. 61. In Hebert's novels, men and women are "eternal enemies which the repression of smalltown Quebec society and the control of the Roman Catholic Church bring to outright war." In the Shadow of the Wind differs from her earlier novels only in the respect that the characters are English, United Empire Loyalist descendants, rather than French Catholics. Collins mentions the themes and the different narrators. "In the Shadow of the Wind is as powerful as Kamouraska, numbing in its psychological full force, flowing naturally through the medium of Sheila Fischman's translation. Reading it feels like being locked in a closet full of poisonous snakes."

D121      Clark, Matthew. Rev. of In the Shadow of the Wind. Quill & Quire, Nov. 1983, p. 20. The "multiple viewpoints of the central event" and the "narrative section by the village idiot" resemble "Faulkner's As I Lay Dying, but the resemblance ends there. Sheila Fischman's translation does justice to the faults of Hebert's prose .... Sentence fragments abound." The language is "precious, the characterization thin, the situation conventionally Gothic, and the actions unmotivated:' The book "is mere melodrama."

D122      French, William. "Stifling Passions among Loyalists." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 26 Nov. 1983, Sec. Entertainment, p. 15. In the Shadow of the Wind is another exploration of "the violence that lurks under the surface." French suspects that the "Gothic quality, the intensity of the writing, a certain element of the primitif, the exotic" were what impressed the jurors of the Prix Femina, since the characters and their names are all caricatures. Hebert's "non-linear" approach, her use of several narrators, and her "false clues" suggest "cerebral Agatha Christie writing in nouveau roman style." Sheila Fischman's "artful translation" preserves "the power of Hebert's writing" in her imagery, symbolism, the "brooding undercurrent of sexual passion .... The devices don't always work [in the novel], but even when they don't, they're provocative." French wonders about the political allegorical level of the book and notes that simply as "a Gothic crime thriller," Hebert, again, makes "us marvel at her dexterity."

D123      Adachi, Ken. "Rich Imagery and Lyricism from Quebec." The Toronto Star, 10 Dec. 1983, p. F10. Hebert's "energy comes from a rare devotion to an insistent inner voice." Like her other novels, In the Shadow of the Wind "adds up to ... an ugly portrait of an inbred and stagnating rural society .... " Her language is poetic and rich, although "Occasionally her prose sinks into a sticky poeticism." Adachi praises her use of detail, although at times she is "selfindulgent to a fault." He mentions the different narrators and notes that "Hebert has captured the pathos and madness of characters who live 'too close to one another.'"

D124      Merler, Grazia. "On Hebert." Rev. of Les Fous de Bassan, by Anne Hebert; and Kamouraska d'Anne Hebert: une ecriture de la Passion suivi de Pour un nouveau Torrent, by Robert Harvey. Canadian Literature, No. 99 (Winter 1983), pp. 132-34. Merler comments that "... the novel remains enigmatic, perhaps because of its richness and the multiple readings it offers." The novel does not deal with "the manichean opposition between light and darkness, good and evil, life and death," but rather with "the notion of simultaneity" and "the imperceptible shifts in form and substance of given patterns of behaviour as dictated not by love or reasoning but by the imperative desire to affirm life." Merler finds that "... the distinction between guilt and innocence is irrelevant," since it is really a competition between Stevens and nature: "The match is between organisms both of different species and different orders: man and nature, man and time, man and objects." The narrative structure is "reminiscent of the New Testament," and "Jones's book follows the Pauline tradition, somewhat obscurantist, dogmatic, self-centred, and eminently unkind to women. But Stevens's version is decidedly diabolical." The novel "is a true feast of technical virtuosity.., but the forreal sophistication is secondary to the emotional tension it creates" in the "atmosphere of savage beauty, desolation, movement, sensual loneliness ....

D125      van Herk, Aritha. "The Sound and the Fury: Anne Hebert's Powerful New Novel, In the Shadow of the Wind, Is a Subtle Conversation Between Water and Wind: Sometimes Breathless, Sometimes Cresting." Books in Canada, Feb. 1984, pp. 8, 10. In the Shadow of the Wind "is an extraordinary novel, as superbly elusive as the elements that control its world .... Once again, Anne Hebert has prised open the unimaginable, imagined for us the underbelly of an eerie and intractible, irrevocably doomed, place and people." Van Herk comments on "the central metaphor of the novel," which is "a terrific apocalyptic storm, magnificently written." By the use of different points of view, Hebert creates a work which has "more texture than narrative, more voice than content." With reference to Perceval's narrative, van Herk states, "Only occasionally does he seem too much like Faulkner's Benjy, too given to howling at the moon." The novel's subtle style "calls for an imaginative and yet perspicacious translation, which has been, I think, achieved. Only some too obvious repetitions mar the whole, and they are quickly forgotten."

D126      Mezei, Kathy. "Letters in Canada: 1983. Translations." University of Toronto Quarterly, 53 (Summer 1984), 406-07. The translation is praised as "astute and skilful," although several passages are analyzed to demonstrate that the translator has not caught the full power of Hebert's prose. "This, the most enthralling of Hebert's novels, is redolent with the sea, its tides, its salt scents, and the wind." The translation occasionally diminishes the force of the original. "The persistent difficulty in translating Hebert is in recreating her lyricism, her language which is simultaneously precise, evocative, and highly figurative."

D127      Kroller, Eva-Marie. "Shadows of the Past." Rev. of Marie-Eve, Marie-Eve, by Adrien Therio; In the Shadow of the Wind, by Anne Hebert, trans. Sheila Fischman; and Mere-solitude, by Emile Ollivier. Canadian Literature, No. 103 (Winter 1984), pp. 129, 130-31. "... Sheila Fischman's impressive translation .... not only remains close to the original, but also succeeds in duplicating much of its poetic texture." Passages from the section "Olivia de la haute mer/Olivia of the High Seas" are mentioned in detail in the analysis of the translation. Some patterns and effects of the novel are lost in translation, however, such as the "gradual build-up of the word 'fou' which gathers in demented force until the final climax ..." and the juxtaposition of English and French in the original.

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Anne Hebert. Russell, D.W. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 145-263

Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews; Les Songes en équilibre  

Russell, D.W. (compiler)

D     Selected Book Reviews, Selected Play and Film Reviews, Selected Play-Script Reviews, and Selected Television-Play Reviews

Selected Book Reviews

Les Songes en equilibre

D1     Pelletier, Albert. "Plaisir de lire." La Revue Moderne, avril 1942, p. 18. Pelletier finds the verse structure artificial and contrived; the emotions described in the poems are adolescent.

D2     d'Auteuil, Georges-Henri. Rev. of Les Songes en equilibre. Relations, mai 1942, pp. 139-40. D'Auteuil notes Hebert's serene grace and nostalgic memories of childhood. Beneath the dreamlike poems is discernible a depth of thought which forces the reader to reflect on life.

D3     Mondello, Romeo. Rev. of Les Songes en equilibre. L 'Action universitaire [Univ. de Montreal], juin 1942, p. 27. The poems succeed in giving order to some of the dreams of childhood. Mondello finds the sincerity of the poetic prayers a pleasure to read.

D4     Lacroix, Albert. "L'Esprit des livres." La Revue dominicaine, juil.-aout 1942, pp. 62-63. Lacroix comments on the fresh effusiveness of the poems which express "un enchainement de visions successives" in a verse form which is completely non-traditional.

D5     Duhamel, Roger. "Voies de la poesie." Relations, oct. 1942, pp. 278-79. In a longer survey of French-Canadian poetry Duhamel briefly mentions Hebert's first volume of poetry, which expresses the essence of poetry; the poems are "l'apotheose discrete et enjouee de la gratuite etje crois que c'est la le plus bel eloge faire."

D6     Baillargeon, Pierre. Rev. of Les Songes en equilibre. Amerique francaise, 3, No. 16 (sept. 1943), 53-56. Baillargeon comments on the volume in the course of a long discussion. He praises the images of childish innocence and the verse structure of the poems.

D7     Aristocritos. "Chroniques de poesie." Les Carnets viatoriens, 8 (oct. 1943), 298-99. Aristocritos criticizes the verse form of the poems, but finds the religious poetry appealing; "... le talent n'est pas douteux; il n'attend sans doute que sa maturation naturelle."

D8     Lasnier, Rina. "De quatre pontes" Rev. of Le Vitrail, by Cecile Chabot; Les Songes en equilibre, by Anne Hebert; Palinods, by Gustave Lamarche; and Regards et jeux dans l'espace, by H. de St.-Denys Garneau. Les Carnets viatoriens, 9 (juil. 1944), 203-06. The "songes" are the dominant theme of the work, and they are neither disorderly nor effusively lyrical, but a "prise de conscience du monde." The poet remains on the threshold of the dream world, the better to report what it contains, and this attitude is not an easy one to maintain. The themes of love, suffering, and faith are expressed with a careful artistic purity of vision. The reviewer finds the religious poems less effective than the others, and the poem "Musique" serves as a definition of her poetry.

D9     Sylvestre, Guy. Rev. of Le Torrent. Le Droit [Ottawa], 11 nov. 1950, p. 2. Sylvestre discusses Les Songes en equilibre as an introduction to his review of the stories (D135). The poems were an impressive collection which showed more grace than the usual serious tone found in much French-Canadian poetry; the disquieting humanity of her poems was a welcome change from the sterile formal correctness of other poets.

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Item Number: ABCMA07AHP2000007002004001

Title:
Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews; Poèmes
Other Title:

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Anne Hebert. Russell, D.W. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 145-263

Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected book reviews; Poèmes  

Russell, D.W. (compiler)

Poemes

D22      Lockquell, Clement. "L'Art poetique d'Anne Hebert: la solitude rompue comme du pain ...." Le Devoir [Montreal], 18 j uin 1960, p. 11. Lockquell comments particularly on "Poesie, solitude rompue" and gives a resume of the main ideas of this "art poetique."

D23      Lapointe, Jeanne. "Mystere de la parole par Anne Hebert." Cite libre, NS No. 3, avril 1961, pp. 21-22. Rpt. ("Mysteres [sic] de la parole, par Anne Hebert") in Presence de la critique: critique et litterature contemporaines au Canada francais. Ed. Gilles Marcotte. Montreal: HMH, 1966, pp. 120-23. Lapointe contrasts the two parts of the volume, concentrating on the second half which shows the development of the poet. She notes "... aujourd'hui, roeuvre s'elargit aux dimensions de l'humanite: villes et pays entiers, perdus, puis sauves. L'amour est charite. Je devient nous." Lapointe suggests that Anne Hebert is to French Canada what James Joyce is to Ireland, Sibelius to Finland.

D24      Sylvestre, Guy. "Letters in Canada: 1960. Livres en francais: La Poesie." University of Toronto Quarterly, 30 (July 1961), 481-82. Sylvestre comments on the dramatic change between the two parts of the volume; in contrast to the laconic tone of Le Tombeau des rois, the second half, Mystere de la parole, presents "la parole d'une femme reconciliee, qui s'epanouit et qui, delivree d'elle-meme, a decouvert la realite des choses, l'epaisseur du monde, et enfin une chaleur humaine."

D25       Chamberland, Paul. "Poemes de Anne Hebert." Lectures, NS 8, No. 2 (oct. 1961), 39-41. Chamberland comments on the second half of the volume which shows the remarkable development of the poetic sensibility. "Les derniers poemes manifestent une evolution marquante dans la poesie d'Anne Hebert, sans que, pour autant, les poemes anterieurs en aient perdu leur caractere de beaute definitive." Both the language and the poetic vision are more ample in the second half and form "un chant en l'honneur du monde et de l'homme qui le prend dans ses mains pour l'offrir."

D26       Pyke, Linda. "Living and Dying Rooms." Books in Canada, Dec. 1975, p. 24. Pyke prefers the first half of the volume (translated by Alan Brown), for it "seemed more immediate and tangible than the last. While the former is concerned more with the persona's spiritual quest, her sense of enchantment and her childhood visions, the latter was Biblical, abstract and impersonal." Pyke feels that the second half of the volume leaves one uninvolved, although it is "almost the necessary complement finally offering hope in the face of despair."

D27      "Poems by Anne Hebert." Canadian Review, Christmas 1975, pp. 55, 59. In a review-article on literature, Alan Brown's translation of Poemes is discussed. Since this poetry is not narrative, it is hard to translate, and this volume "brings up the whole issue of the appropriateness of translation -- and doesn't reflect well upon it."

D28      Woodcock, George. "Levels of Translation." CV/II, 2, No. 1 (Jan. 1976), 19-20. In this review-article, Woodcock compares the translations in The Complete Poems of SaintDenys Garneau, translated by John Glassco, and in Hebert's Poems by Anne Hebert, translated by Alan Brown. Brown's translations lose all of the music, nuances, and innuendoes of the original -- thus blurring the meaning." He concludes, "We must still await the day when a poet of the same class as Anne Hebert will translate her with the authority of the original creator."

D29      Slote, Daniel. "Literary Translation: A Few Remarks (Poems by Anne Hebert; Translated by Alan Brown)." Meta, 21, No.2 (juin 1976), 165-68. Slote comments on the impossibility of translating poetry into another language, but finds Alan Brown's translation an acceptable "interpretation" of the work, in the same way that each musical performance is an interpretation of the score. Brown has done a good job as "'transcreator.'"

D30      Walker, David. "Poems by Anne Hebert, Translated by Alan Brown: Exorcising Demons." The Canadian Forum, Aug. 1976, pp.38-39. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Literary Criticism,: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Dedria Bryfonski and Laurie Lanzen Harris. Vol.XIII. Detroit: Gale, 1980, 268. Walker discusses the nature of the poetry and its place in the cultural history of Quebec. Alan Brown's "translation of Poemes is a model of the art."

D31     Downes, G.V. "Hebert in English." Canadian Literature, No. 71 (Winter 1976), pp. 87-89. Downes comments on the difficulties of translation in general, and on the weakness of Alan Brown's translation of Hebert in particular. "Although readers who are quite unfamiliar with Anne Hebert's work will certainly gather some idea of its themes and general characteristics from this English version, they will certainly not understand why her reputation stands so high."

D32      Micros, Marianne. "Rape and Ritual." Rev. of Children of the Black Sabbath, by Anne Hebert, trans. Carol Dunlop-Hebert; and Poems by Anne Hebert, trans. Alan Brown. Essays on Canadian Writing, Nos. 7-8 (Fall 1977), pp. 34-35. "A reading of Anne Hebert's poems enriches the message of the novels, and helps the reader understand the mind from which evolved stories of such evil, guilt, and solitude .... Many of the themes and images seen in the novels are included here -- blood, the closed room, eating, the heart separated from the body .... Her poetry and her novels are words telling of despair in order to reach out beyond it for salvation.

D33      Moritz, Albert. "Hebert with Anglo-Saxon Flair." Books in Canada, Nov. 1980, p. 20. Without detracting from previous translations, Moritz claims that A. Poulin's translation has found "a new tone" which is more "colloquial, speech-based" than that found in the translations of either Alan Brown or F.R. Scott. Poulin "achieves a voice that does not disguise the poet's own, and yet speaks a language based on standard conversational English. The poet's beauty and intensity are made to rise directly out of our daily talk."

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Item Number: ABCMA07AHP2000007002004003
Record: 41
Title:
Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected play and film reviews; Kamouraska
Other Title:
Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected play and film reviews
Record Type:
Reference Series
Series Title:
Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors, no. 7
Author(s):
Russell, D.W. (compiler)

Bibliography

Authors discussed:  HEBERT, Anne; HEBERT, Anne -- Criticism & interpretation -- Bibliography
Titles critiqued:  KAMOURASKA (Book)
Topics:  CANADIAN literature -- Bibliography; FRENCH-CANADIAN literature -- Bibliography

<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07AHP2000007002004013&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected play and film reviews; Kamouraska</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Anne Hebert. Russell, D.W. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 145-263

Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected play and film reviews; Kamouraska  

Russell, D.W. (compiler)

Kamouraska

D152      P[errault]., L[uc]. "Copie trop conforme: Kamouraska de Claude Jutra." La Presse [Montreal], 31 mars 1973, p. D13. The film follows the novel very closely and well: "... l'essentiel du style et du fond a ete conserve."

D153      Scully, Robert-Guy. "Kamouraska, l'oeuvre de notre grande bourgeoisie." Le Devoir [Montreal], 31 mars 1973, p. 15. Scully comments on the image of the bourgeoisie which is portrayed in the film. Jutra and Hebert share the same artistic sensibilities: both are very good at portraying upper-middle-class Quebec society. The film is not identical to the novel, since it must use dialogue and dramatic situations, rather than the poetic, one-character focus of the novel.

D154      Tadros, Jean-Pierre. "Une espece de joie dans la creation." Interview with Claude Jutra. Cinema quebec, 2, Nos. 6-7 (mars-avril 1973), 15-9. In the course of an interview on the making of the film Kamouraska, Claude Jutra comments that it was the producer, Carl Lamy, who suggested he do the film. Jutra insisted that Genevieve Bujold play the role of Elisabeth. Jutra collaborated for three months with Hebert in writing the scenario for the film; both worked at converting the subjectivism of the novel into a filmable script. They both agreed that many aspects of the novel had to be left out of the filmed version.

D155     Tadros, Jean-Pierre, "'Kamouraska,' une certaine perfection." Le Devoir [Montreal], 6 avril 1973, p. 15. Although the film is guaranteed success in Quebec, and is a good film, it is not without weaknesses. Jutra succeeds by using interior shots and period costume. But the lack of outdoor settings suitable for the period is a severe limitation. Similarly, the film has been forced to drop many aspects of the novel's strength: "... le film epure trop, emascule trop les sentiments et la passion."

D156      Scully, Robert Guy. "Un malaise? La superproduction." Le Devoir [Montreal], 7 avril 1973, p.22. Scully analyzes the social and economic factors which made the film Kamouraska a "super production," involving a bestseller novel, a well-known film maker, and large, financial backing. The novel does not have the historical qualities which permit it to be readily made into an immensely popular film, however. Because the novel is not really realistic in style, but primarily a psychological work, it will probably fail as a movie.

D157      Gay, Richard. "Kamouraska: un evenement" Maintenant, mai 1973, pp. 32-34. The film has succeeded in portraying the same depth as the novel, although "... le rytheme est trop souvent pesant ... et dans ce sens le film par rapport au roman decoit un peu."

D158      Tadros, Jean-Pierre. "The Film Will Be Shown as a Protest." The Toronto Star, 12 May 1973, p.83. Kamouraska will be shown at the Cannes festival, although it was excluded by the selection committee. Tadros quotes from interviews with Hebert in Montreal during the opening of the film. Since Sorel could not be used as a site for shooting street scenes, some anti-English elements which were set in Sorel in the novel had to be dropped from the film.

D159      Gelinas, Marc-F. "Une saison dans la vie de Kamouraska." Le Maclean, juin 1973, p. 56. Gelinas saw the film before reading the novel, but, when compared, "... le roman est de loin superieur au film en intensite, en profondeur, et en logique." The film is visually impressive, but dramatically weak.

D160      Lee, Betty. "Jutra's Latest a Stunning Portrayal of Tragedy in Quebec." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 6 Oct. 1973, Sec. Entertainment Travel, p. 23. "Kamouraska, of course, is the ideal story for director Jutra to showcase his special talents. It snouts for a him-maker who understands texture, measured pace and methodical characterization. The novel is a dark tapestry, interwoven with unvarnished, sometimes unpleasant truth. And so is Jutra's film."

D161      Delaney, Marshall. "The High Cinematic Art of Michel Brault." Saturday Night, Dec. 1973, p.43. "Jutra's direction of the actors is not ... greatly distinguished; nor is the Hebert-Jutra script very impressive. So far as I can see, the art in Kamouraska is mainly in the cinematography; and this is very distinguished indeed ... In Kamouraska it is Brault the formalist who is at work. Every shot seems set up exquisitely, and a dozen of them linger long afterwards in the mind."

D162      Shek, Ben. "Quebec Films: Sharp Image of a Separate Society." Performing Arts in Canada, 11, No.3 (Fall 1974), 34. In the course of comments on some dozen films, Shek gives a resume of the film Kamouraska and remarks on the difficulty in expressing interior monologue in film. "I missed the engulfing presence of the heroine's monologue and would have liked to have seen the use of voice-over."

D163      "A Reconstructed Canadian Classic" The Toronto Star, 7 Nov. 1983, p. D1. For the first time, Kamouraska will be shown as Claude Jutra intended -- "as a four-hour, darkly intense look at rural Quebec a century ago." The program has been redubbed. Kamouraska "remains a remarkably fine achievement, even in the [earlier] truncated version .... [In this new version] the development of Elizabeth's character is said to be deeper and the poetry and superstitions of a vanished rural society expertly conjured up."

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Anne Hebert. Russell, D.W. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 145-263

Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected play and film reviews; Le Temps sauvage  

Russell, D.W. (compiler)

Selected Play and Film Reviews

Le Temps sauvage

D149      Basile, Jean. "Le Temps sauvage d'Anne Hebert." Le Devoir [Montreal], 12 oct. 1966, pp. 10-11. Basile praises the strength of the archetypal mother, for "Anne Hebert a fort bien compris que la mere canadienne est parfois mere avant d'etre femme ...." The play is "d'une force incroyable, d'un pessimisme jusqu'a l'insoutenable" But the dramatic structure of the play is weak, and there is no movement within the play. The language is also disappointing because there is an "abus de qualificatifs visceraux ... d'images approximatives"

D150      d'Auteuil, George-Henri. Rev. of Le Temps sauvage. Relations, nov. 1966, pp. 316-17. The play has no denouement, since the "temps sauvage" remains unresolved at the end of the play. The author needs more dramatic experience, for the work is not a masterpiece, although it is not completely mediocre either.

D151      Greffard, Madeleine. "Les Lettres quebecoises en 1968: Le Theatre." Etudes litteraires [Univ. de Laval], 5 (aout 1969), 232-33. Anne Hebert's play, without reflecting current social or political events, transposes for the stage "certains themes de son oeuvre poetique: la conquete de la liberte et de l'amour contre les forces de la mort." Who would not recognize "l'incarnation des forces de mort et d'inertie qui dominaient notre societe" in the character of Agnes, victim of a dogmatic and Jansenist society? "Bien qu'il plonge ses racines plus loin dans notre passe, et que sa fabulation temoigne de plus d'originalite, Le Temps sauvage rejoint cette partie de notre theatre qui temoigne directement de la societe quebecoise."

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Item Number: ABCMA07AHP2000007002004012

Title:
Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected play-script reviews; Le Temps sauvage (B146)

<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07AHP2000007002004014&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected play-script reviews; Le Temps sauvage (B146)</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Anne Hebert. Russell, D.W. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 145-263

Part 2 Works on Anne Hébert; Selected book reviews, selected play and film reviews, selected play-script reviews, and selected television-play reviews; Selected play-script reviews; Le Temps sauvage (B146)  

Russell, D.W. (compiler)

Selected Play-Script Reviews

Le Temps sauvage (B146)

D164      Marcotte, Gilles. "Anne Hebert et Le Temps sauvage." Perspectives [La Presse] [Montreal], 6 juil. 1963, Supplement, p. 8. Marcotte compares the themes of the play to those of "Le Torrent" and finds them valid and recognizably French Canadian. The form of the play bothers Marcotte, however, for it is between two styles- the fable and the realistic drama. The characters are not extreme enough to be purely symbolic, and not banal enough to be realistic.

D165      Ethier-Blais, Jean. "Cette sensibilite maladive." Le Devoir [Montreal], 20 juil. 1963, p. 11. Ethier-Blais comments on the French-Canadian sense of an alien landscape, coupled with a certain Jansenistic religiosity, and compares this atmosphere with that found in Russian literature. This atmosphere is very evident in Le Temps sauvage. Ethier-Blais compares it to plays by Lorca and Chekhov, commenting on the image of the hard, vengeful mother and the themes of 'Tattente, le depart, les genies sauvages."

D166      Lockquell, Clement. Rev. of Le Temps sauvage. Le Soled [Quebec], 20 juil. 1963, p. 6. The play is too lyrical and sententious:"On ne sait plus si Anne Hebert a pretendu illustrer des symboles, avec un minimum d'action et de langage dramatiques, ou si elle a voulu hausser la valeur de symboles des situations existentielles. Il n'y a pas, ici, fusion de genres, mais confusion."

D167      Vachon, G.-Andre. "Ecrits du Canada francais XVI." Relations, dec. 1963, p. 362. Le Temps sauvage is a culmination and resolution of all the major themes of Hebert's preceding work. Vachon notes, "... l'image de la mere elle-meme infiniment bienfaisante et infiniment menacante, realise runion des contraires et atteint la perfection d'un archetype." On the poetic qualities of the language, he states, "... le dialogue monte spontanement au niveau du lyrisme, il se coule dans une prose opulente."

D168      Beaulne, Guy. "Le Temps sauvage de Anne Halbert." In Livres et auteurs canadiens 1963. Ed. Adrien Therio. Montreal: Jumonville, 1964, pp. 44-45. Le Temps sauvage adds nothing new or important to Quebec literature or to theatre. The play is unduly verbose and complicated in its treatment of the three main themes of frustration within Quebec at the moment it is emerging from the Duplessis era: the role of the mother, the clergy, and education. The style of the play is non-dramatic, and Beaulne predicts it will soon be forgotten.

Selected Television-Play Reviews

La Mercere assassinee (B179-B182)

D169      Chicoine, Rene. Rev. of La Merciere assassinee. Le Devoir [Montreal], 22 juil. 1958, p. 7; 29 juil. 1958, p. 7; 5 aout 1958, p. 7; 12 aout 1958, p. 7. Chicoine criticizes the television production of the play for structural weaknesses. The piece fails as a "roman policier." Part of the difficulty lies in the division of the play into four separate broadcasts, but Chicoine also finds the characterization flawed, the suspense badly sustained, and the plot childish.

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Item Number: ABCMA07AHP2000007002004014

Title:
Part 2 Works on Marian Englel; Selected book reviews; Adventure at Moon Bay Towers
Other Title:

Author(s):
Wengle, Annette (compiler)

Authors discussed:  ENGEL, Marian; ENGEL, Marian -- Criticism & interpretation -- Bibliography
Titles critiqued:  ADVENTURE at moon bay towers (Book)
