Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07MEP2000007001004010&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Marian Englel; Selected book reviews; Adventure at Moon Bay Towers</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Marian Engel (nee: Passmore). Wengle, Annette (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 38-109

Part 2 Works on Marian Englel; Selected book reviews; Adventure at Moon Bay Towers  

Wengle, Annette (compiler)

Adventure at Moon Bay Towers

D161      Jackson, Marni. "Children's Tale Conforms to New Rules." The Toronto Star, 15 June 1974, p.F7. The story is summarized and evaluated: "it is well-behaved, inoffensive and perfectly drab." While "... the book conforms so beautifully to the unwritten rules for liberated kids' literature" (it is not sexist, patronizing, or moralistic), it is "prosaic," lacking imaginative richness and "fantasy."

D162      Smiley, Calvin. Rev. of Adventure at Moon Bay Towers. Quill & Quire, Aug. 1974, p. 25. Engel is "too conscientious ... in avoiding the pitfalls of 'old-fashioned' children's literature." The book is colourless, humourless, and uninteresting. "The two major virtues of Marian Engel's first children's story are negative ones: it is non-sexist and non-violent. Unfortunately, the story also lacks an engaging story-line, interesting characterizations, humour and all traces of human emotion."

D163      Ashdown, Fran. Rev. of Adventure at Moon Bay Towers. In Review, 8, No.4 (Autumn 1974), 46-47. "... Mrs. Engel's book is refreshingly entertaining and her characters likeable." However, "... adventure and fantasy blend uneasily in her first book for children."

D164      Cleaver, Nancy. Rev. of Adventure at Moon Bay Towers. Canadian Author & Bookman, 50, No. 1 (Fall 1974), 26. "The pictures and the story of this captivating book are all of one piece, a very special one for children."

D165      Leslie, Susan. "Juvenile Delinquency." Books in Canada, Nov. 1974, p. 12, 14. The book is "not conspicuously Canadian in either setting or content," and, although free of regionalism, "... it is not likely to enjoy an international audience .... One can only assume that Ms. Engel considers writing for children a minor literary enterprise"

D166      Du Vernet, Sylvia. "Ill Writ by Moonlight." Rev. of Adventure at Moon Bay Towers. Canadian Children's Literature: A Journal of Criticism & Review, 1, No. 1 (Spring 1975), 66-67. Engers use of language does not take advantage of the story's potential; therefore, the adventure never turns into a magical imaginative experience. "The style of writing both in its selection and arrangement of words and in its total lack of metaphoric overtone, is in icy conflict with the warm feeling of mind-expanding excitement which the multi-level plot structure would seem to suggest."

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors ; no. 7 ISBN: 0920763111 (hardcover); 092076312X (paperback), Book ID: ABCMA07MEP2.
Item Number: ABCMA07MEP2000007001004010

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Marian Engel (nee: Passmore). Wengle, Annette (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 38-109

Part 2 Works on Marian Englel; Selected book reviews; Inside the Easter Egg  

Wengle, Annette (compiler)

Inside the Easter Egg

D134      Vintcent, Brian. "Inside the Engel Easter Egg." Quill & Quire, Dec. 1975, pp. 29, 36. Vintcent glances at Sarah Bastard's Notebook, The Honeyman Festival, Monodromos, and Joanne: The Last Days of a Modern Marriage and finds that Inside the Easter Egg contains "the themes, places and characters of her novels .. in condensed miniature. A kind of microcosm of the modern female world." He prefers the Ziggy and Marshallene stories and finds the collection uneven.

D135      Bradbury, Maureen. Rev. of Inside the Easter Egg. In Canadian Book Review Annual: 1975. Ed. Dean Tudor, Nancy Tudor, and Linda Biesenthal. Toronto: Peter Martin Associates, 1976, p. 128. The organization of the stories into three sections is "unnecessarily arbitrary." Overall, the collection is uneven, and the stories lack "individuality or distinction" with the exception of "The Salt Mines," "Transformations," and "Bicycle Story." 'the tone of the book is bland, leaving the feeling that the author has narrowly missed creating a meaningful statement about the complexities of human relationships."

D136      Dickman, Thelma. "Somewhere in Here There's a Good Writer." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 10 Jan. 1976, p. 35. Dickman notes that she has not read any of Engel's other work and that she has a distaste for writings about the frustrated fives of married ladies. She finds that Engel is not the storyteller that Somerset Maugham was.

D137      MacSkimming, Roy. "Toughness, Affection, Humour Mark the Best of Engel's Stories." The Toronto Star, 24 Jan. 1976, p. 117. MacSkimming notes the "collective experience that the book documents, the domestic and amatory journeys of the generation now into its 40's." The short story is "a form that suits her quicksilver style and sensibility" He hopes that the collection will mark the end of "her preoccupation with domestic crisis" and the beginning of growth beyond.

D138      Dennys, Louise. "Lit, O Lit, O Careless Lit: Engel's Disappointing New Collection Raises Questions about General Literary Complacency." Books in Canada, Feb. 1976, pp. 8-9. "While... [Engel's] earlier work showed that she had talent, Monodromos confirmed her as a fine writer." However, Inside the Easter Egg is disappointing, boring, and irritating. The characters and situations are banal, sentimental, and platitudinous. While individual stories "are not well sustained and are peculiarly loose-ended," the impression of authorial carelessness is reinforced by Engel's use of the same material in a few stories. Dennys links the mediocrity of Inside the Easter Egg to a "self-perpetuating 'crisis of standards' in the world of Canadian letters -- a slumbrous complacency that slowly, insidiously overwhelms writer, publisher, and reader alike."

D139      Russel, G. "Making Do." Time Canada, 16 Feb. 1976,p. 8. Engel's stories are impressionistic sketches with little narrative line, and her characters are repressed and pallid hangers-on. There is a brief biography of Engel and an overview of her work to date. Her recurring theme is the financial struggle and social frustration of the lower middle-class, intellectually gifted women who are her main characters.

D140      Williamson, David. "Emptiness of Existence" Rev. of Bear and Inside the Easter Egg, by Marian Engel. New Leisure Saturday Magazine [Winnipeg Free Press], 17 April 1976, p. 17. "In the stories, couples quietly live through dreary lives. Women look neurotically for ways to prove they exist. Men turn cold, dull and redundant .... Written in direct, succinct prose, nearly all of the 19 stories are razor-sharp portraits of people trapped in stultifying relationships, but author Engel sprinkles her narrative with crisp dialogue and wry humor."

D141      Hay, Linda. "Through the Looking Glass and Beyond." The Canadian Forum, May 1976, pp. 35-36. Hay describes the stories in relation to the title of the collection.

D142      Lund, Mary. Rev. of Inside the Easter Egg. The Fiddlehead, No. 110 (Summer 1976), pp. 143-46. "Single details type and judge. This shrewd prose mocks the neat conventionality of each story and works its wonder. Thus, Engel selects and insinuates details that betoken the treachery and wonder of our loves." Lund prefers the "brisk, epigrammatic" stories of Sections I and II. Three of the stories in the final section "are written in a lyrical form that suggests a novel." Their "circling, delving meditations" recall Minn's monologues in The Honeyman Festival and predict "another such novel."

D143      Dodd, Jean. Rev. of Inside the Easter Egg. Emergency Librarian, 3, No. 6 (July-Aug. 1976), 25. The recurring theme that ties the stories together is "how we fail to recognize others and therefore how we fail to recognize ourselves." The first section shows "woman's loss of identity as she is submerged into wife and mother"; the second section "reveals different problems with relationships"; the third section concerns "torn loyalties within families, people clinging to, yet resenting the mores and poses of their parents ..." The stories are simple, the style crisp and clean. Engel presents "a sardonic and cool appraisal of what people do to each other."

D144      Labonte, Ronald. Rev. of Inside the Easter Egg and Bear. Canadian Fiction Magazine, Nos. 24-25 (Spring-Summer 1977), pp. 183-90. Inside the Easter Egg and Bear represent respectively the worst and the best of Engel's works. Both books are "plagued by Engel's characteristic lack of depth." The "flaws" in Engel's characterization of women are examined: "Engel ... ends her stories just at the point when her characters are beginning to resolve themselves into flesh and blood." Besides lacking characterization, Engel's heroines lack character: "They do not control their own fate; more seriously, they resign themselves to their conditioned weaknesses without struggle."

D145      Sonthoff, Helen. "The Stories of Wilson & Engel." Rev. of Mrs. Golightly and Other Stories, by Ethel Wilson; and Inside the Easter Egg, by Marian Engel. Canadian Literature, No.86 (Autumn 1980), pp. 148--52. The books are feats of "skill and delight occurring together." Engel achieves her effects through sentence structure and sequence and is skilful in the "handling of the cumulative." In Engel's stories there is "an observer, a recorder, who shows not how things fit [as does Wilson] but how they happen. The unseemly, the accidental, the inexplicable occur as simply as the ordinary, the expected." Unlike Wilson's characters, Engel's characters' lives are "an accumulation, often accidental, sometimes hilarious, sometimes so tedious as to threaten sanity ... Society is not a fabric, woven, tearable, reparable, useful -- but something more rigid, heavier -- a weight on the spirit, a negative force." Both Wilson and Engel redefine importance and purpose, and both "change my view of the moment, the bulk of our days."

D146      Rule, Jane. Rev. of Inside the Easter Egg. Room of One's Own, [Special Issue on Marian Engel], 9, No. 2 (June 1984), 41-45. In Inside the Easter Egg, which "should have a more prominent place in the Engel canon than it has yet achieved," the difference between male and female manners of dealing with the world is depicted: "... women are preoccupied with how other people feel and what they are thinking. Stories from a male point of view, like 'Amaryllis' and 'Nationalism" are more decisively limited to what a man wants, how he goes about getting it and what judgments he must make." While the men are "apt to be successful in their work," the women's sense of authority over their world is deceptive -- Ruth's in "Bicycle Story" comes more from pain killers and whiskey than from the reality of her circumstances. Rule admires the "deftly shorthanded pasts and a richness of quickly sketched characters," the celebration of vital sexuality throughout the collection, and Engel's knack for comic writing.

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Marian Engel (nee: Passmore). Wengle, Annette (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 38-109

Part 2 Works on Marian Englel; Selected book reviews; Lunatic Villas  

Wengle, Annette (compiler)

Lunatic Villas

D113      Adachi, Ken. "Absurd and Absorbing Novel from Marian Engel." The Toronto Star, 7 March 1981, p. F10. Lunatic Villas "is a small-scale but delightfully absurd and absorbing book, awash in the everyday comedy of Harriet Ross ..." Adachi praises Engel's characterization ("This is contemporary society in microcosm. Each voice is distinct ...") as well as Engel's "sense of place, way with detail and sneaky sense of humor [which] produce a different outlook," imbued with a keen sense of the compromises necessary in unromantic everyday life.

D114      French, William. "Urban Renewal and Single Parenthood. Scenes from the Bleak Contemporary Social Landscape Served Up with Marian Engel's Tough, Sardonic Humour." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 7 March 1981, p. E16. The novel celebrates the single mother and demonstrates numerous instances of the breakdown of the nuclear family. Although Engel succeeds in making Harriet's plight credible, the other residents of Rathbone Place are not very interesting, and Mrs. Saxe is a plot device. "Lunatic Villas will not be remembered as one of Engel's major novels, but by spotlighting an important current social problem and illuminating contemporary Toronto it serves a useful purpose."

D115      Morley, Patricia. "A Fun Look at the Lunacies of Urban Life." The Citizen [Ottawa], 7 March 1981, p. 35. "Lunatic Villas out-soaps Soap in a hilarious romp through the lunacies of modern urban life." Although the large cast is sometimes confusing, and "Many of the characters are charming grotesques, two-dimensional oddballs ... Harriet is solid gold." The book is "a good read ... an inspired pot-boiler."

D116      Wyatt, Louise. "Lunatic Villas Captivates Reviewer." The London Free Press, 7 March 1981, p. B9. Lunatic Villas is an "unusually captivating and well-written novel .... "The story examines "six households" but "The heart of the story is Harriet Ross at No. 10 [Rathbone Place] and the seven assorted highly individual children and teenagers whom she is almost inadvertently but willingly stuck with." The story is well told, and the characters and situations are "made vital through Marian Engel's creative skill ..." Engel is a life-lover, one of "those who have reached open-eyed acceptance, often hard won ..." Lunatic Villas "will be one of the best novels of 1981."

D117      Amiel, Barbara. "Insight, with a High Price of Admission:' Maclean's, 9 March 1981, p. 62. "At best they [the women in Lunatic Villas] are unremarkable, at worst they are dreadful, and on the whole they are what the English call 'wet.'" Although "Engel's view of life is more thoughtful, [and some of her insights are more interesting and original" than what one finds in H.V. Kershaw's Coronation Street, the price is a slower denser pace. Amiel acknowledges Engel's stature as a prose stylist, but questions whether the insights she offers are worth the price: "It is as if the characters had been hard done by through some fault of the reader's -- and now are taking their revenge."

D118      Gervais, Marty. "Flakey Novel Could Sell Lots of Soap." The Windsor Star, 14 March 1981, p. E8. "Marian Engel's newest novel, Lunatic Villas, ... is a real-life soap opera. It focuses upon everydayness in a Toronto redevelopment project peopled by artists, the disabled, the disenchanted, the divorced." The many stereotypical characters include "Marshallene, the hardcore feminist," Roger, the traditionalist, and "Harriet the single mother." Lunatic Villas may anger feminists with its view that "... liberation is the exhilaration one finds at the bottom of chaos. It's Depressed Housewife seeing some value in her efforts." The book is flawed by being "fragmented and disjointed" but it "accurately portrays real lives, values and attitudes."

D119      Williamson, David. "Gentle Novel Engel's Best." Winnipeg Free Press, 14 March 1981, p.10. After two books which "seemed to advocate that any woman worth her salt should pull out of society ... Engel dives right back into the hurlyburly of urban living. This novel is so readable and so funny that some critics may regard it as trivial. Yet it does contain many shrewd insights and, for me, it is her best book yet."

D120      Simpson, Leo. "Best Novel Yet from Engel." The Spectator [Hamilton], 21 March 1981, p. 78. Lunatic Villas "is a comedy in the sense that it is wittily styled and written, a novel without a dull page. Its concerns, however, with their air of domesticity and hence triviality, are serious enough for a much more earnest work." Although Harriet Ross writes an advice column, "The irony of her situation is that she issues advice about situations she can't conquer herself ... Lunatic Vdlas is a funny novel without being merely light and it weaves a tapestry of serious agony and desperation as it holds the reader in the magnetism of sheer entertainment."

D121      Cowan, Doris. "A Fine Madness." Books in Canada, April 1981, pp. 20-21. As usual, Engel lets "the story develop at its own pace through the perceptions and ruminations of the central character, with many detours and backtrackings, and as little exposition as she can possibly get away with." Cowan notes the unusually large cast of characters for an Engel novel, including the unbelievable character Mrs. Saxe, who pulls the plot together; the insights into writing, expressed through Harriet and Marshallene; and the vivid episodes which are sometimes not well integrated. "But the heart of the book -- the story of Harriet and her children -- is thoroughly coherent, unaffected by the constellation of subplots around it." Cowan appreciates the "superb and scornful wit and... hurtling energy" of Engel's writing, and she notes the seriousness beneath "the jauntiness of her professed optimism."

D122      Simpson, Leo. "Comic Reactions from the Fusion of Laughter and Realism." Quill & Quire, April 1981, p. 33. "Despite this groundwork for what publishers like to call a zany novel, Marian Engel's characters are, as usual, real people .... Lunatic Villas manages the fusion of laughter and reality superbly, sparkles wittily throughout, and contains an earnest volume's worth of truth about the way lives are lived by women and children."

D123      Kareda, Urjo. "Children and Chaos." Saturday Night, May 1981, p. 56. Lunatic Villas is "a dispiriting chronicle of a scattered, miserable family held together by a woman whose gifts for motherhood seem to be blind love and tenacity." We recognize Harriet as someone "we would travel a mile to avoid," and the neighbours "don't exist except in episodic guest appearances:' The material would be more suitable for a weekly television series.

D124      Bannon, Barbara A. Rev. of The Year of the Child [Lunatic Villas]. Publishers Weekly [New York], 15 May 1981, p. 72. "Engel's novel is wonderful, different from but equal in brilliance to 'Bear,' 'The Glassy Sea' and her other triumphs .... It is the feat of the strange guest [Mrs. Saxe] and her partner Mick that crowns this joyous, funny, poignant tale

D125      Pendleton, Elsa. Rev. of The Year of the Child [Lunatic Villas]. Library Journal [New York], Aug. 1981, p. 1565. "Engel's rueful comments and her vivid choice of detail lift this funny and touching novel above the ordinary."

D126      Greenwood, Beth. Rev. of Lunatic Villas. Quarry, 31, No. 1 (Winter 1982), 96-97. The novel fails to resolve its "real conflict," which is not "the spreading mess of the characters' lives," but "the pull between the book's style and its content." Greenwood outlines three aspects of the book's "real problem": lengthy monologues substitute for exposition of complicated relationships, "situation rules character," and after the opening, the sense of place disappears. However, the novel is "an easy read, and Engel's sense of language never deserts her."

D127      Kirkwood, Hilda. Rev. of Lunatic Villas. The Canadian Forum, Feb. 1982, p. 43. "Does anyone write as honestly and amusingly about the nitty-gritty of women's domestic lives in our milieu as Marian Engel?" The story is an update of George S. Kaufman's play The Man Who Came to Dinner "set in the same sort of madhouse." There are a number of memorable secondary characters, and, in the final episode, Engel "has some fun with Can Lit and the CBC and its commentary."

D128      Godard, Barbara. Rev. of Lunatic Villas, by Marian Engel; The Charcoal Burners, by Susan Musgrave; and The Tent Peg, by Aritba van Herk. The Fiddlehead, No. 132 (April 1982), pp. 90-92. Godard bases her criticism on Engel's stated intention of writing "'a book about the surrealism of everyday life'" (see Betty Lee, C79). The novel's flaw lies in the fact that it reads "true to life," rather than "reaching towards the terrain of Munro where occurrences of everyday life are charged with magical overtones ... Engel has made us aware that the plots of life are as bizarre as those of art, but her focus on this question is fuzzy." Without the necessary "ironic distance" providing "cutting interplay?" between narrator and writer, "... the novel sinks into Harriet's commonplace vision."

D129      Rev. of Lunatic Villas. The Financial Post Magazine [The Financial Post] [Toronto]. "Paperbacks," 1 June 1982, p. 7. "Somehow Engel manages to keep the whole cast zipping along, alternating pathos with humour and finding an acceptable kind of happiness."

D130      Hoy, Helen. "Letters in Canada: 1981. Fiction: 2." University of Toronto Quarterly, 51 (Summer 1982), 329-30. Lunatic Villas is "an intelligent book," which examines "how far family life has moved from its classic model." Harriet's morley family and the other households on the street are examples of unorthodox family groups." Engel is concerned to justify the woman required to be efficient and pragmatic ... a mother to whom parenting is all-important and yet who is not defined by that role ... With fresh metaphors, witty balance, and occasional ironic literary allusions, Engel's style displays a precision and intelligence which match well the humour and insight of her observations"

D131      Irvine, Lorna. Rev. of Lunatic Villas. World Literature Written in English, 21 (Summer 1982), 613-16. "Lunatic Villas presents the chaotic, noisy, erotic involvement with life that Engel so splendidly captured in The Honeyman Festival." Irvine emphasizes the "allegorical dimensions' of the story. The prologue is dated 1967, Canada's centennial year, and "... the ensuing novel is about Canada's coming of age." Harriet writes under a nom-de-plume, a split characterizing "both the female psyche ... and a split Canadian culture, the result of a dual heritage." Mrs. Saxe's presence is necessary to the allegory, invoking the colonial past, as is the novel's concern with "the cultural and, more important, economic dominance of the United States .... the concluding episode, the great Canadian bicycle race ... geographically impresses the reader with Canada's space and ties together Canada's history and literature .... As Mrs. Saxe, the symbol of the British aristocrat, even of the British empire, and Mick, the son of the dead, American Tom, bicycle across Canada ... the novel traces the landscape by the names of the writers who have given the land its image .... "As well as being a celebration of Canada's future, Lunatic Villas "is a radical book, a woman's book, a book that places women at the very centre of Canada's continuance."

D132      Gadpaille, Michelle. "A Perfect Five." Canadian Literature, No. 94 (Autumn 1982), p. 127. In a comparison of Lunatic Villas with early children's fiction, Gadpaille notes that "the Ross Littlemores of Marian Engel's Lunatic Villas [are] distant relations of all the poor-but-virtuous families of this sentimental moral fiction .... " Similarities include "multiplicity of characters" and families which were "often fatherless, usually poor, and fiercely loyal to a 'Ma' who was a good strong woman, daily rubbing in the lesson that they possessed in their happy home a wealth that no riches could purchase." The Ross Littlemore children's failings "aren't any more seriously deviant than the March girls' pranks .... "The strongest similarity is in the emphasis on unromantic, unsentimental love, and "what originality there is in Lunatic Villas comes ... from its unspectacular rejection of idealized pictures of parenthood and childhood" and in its eschewing of morals and didacticism.

D133      Robson, Nora. Rev. of Lunatic Villas. In Canadian Book Review Annual: 1981. Ed. Dean Tudor and Ann Tudor. Toronto: Simon & Pierre, 1983, p. 131. Lunatic Villas is "humorous and fast-paced [and] it is a good read." It is also "a serious comment on today's urban society and its sociological problems." The eccentric characters, the combination of "all of today's problems and horrors ... in a fairly natural manner," the depiction of "the love that surfaces during periods of stress and trouble," and the welldrawn subplots and minor characters all help to make Lunatic Villas an "amusing and simultaneously a telling observation on modern life."

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Marian Engel (nee: Passmore). Wengle, Annette (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 38-109

Part 2 Works on Marian Englel; Selected book reviews; My Name Is Not Odessa Yarker  

Wengle, Annette (compiler)

My Name Is Not Odessa Yarker

D167      Laurence, Jocelyn. "Kids Can Press: When Rufus Decides to Change His Name, It's a Relief." Rev. of Kyrylo the Tanner, by Odarka Chandon; The Shirt of the Happy Man, by Mariella Bertelli; How Trouble Made the Monkey Eat Pepper, by Rita Cox; and My Name Is Not Odessa Yarker, by Marian Engel, illus. Lazlo Gal. The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 10 Dec. 1977, Sec. Entertainment-Travel, p. 42. My Name Is Not Odessa Yarker is "a vast improvement on Engel's first children's book: "a nice blend of reality and fantasy .... "

D168      Adilman, Sid. "Marian Engel Writes a Children's Story." The Toronto Star. "Eye on Entertainment" 16 Dec. 1977, p. D7. Adilman comments mostly on the illustrations, but notes that the story is "a fast likeable tale."

D169      Amey, L.J. Rev. of My Name Is Not Odessa Yarker. In Canadian Book Review Annual: 1977. Ed. Dean Tudor, Nancy Tudor, and Linda Biesenthal. Toronto: Peter Martin Associates, 1978, p. 226. Amey provides a synopsis of the story and evaluative commentary. The age level is indicated. "Marian Engel does a fine job of capturing the abrasive give and take between a nine-year-old boy and his ten-year-old sister."

D170      Rubio, Mary. "Breaking into the Children's Market." Rev. of The Leaves of Louise, by Matt Cohen; Up in the Tree, by Margaret Atwood; and My Name Is Not Odessa Yarker, by Marian Engel, illus. Lazlo Gal. Quill & Quire, July 1978, p.36. This review notes Engel's "keen insight into child behaviour, with a special focus on sibling rivalry."

D171      Roche, Anne. "Kid Lit: Not for Huron County" Rev. of No Way Back, by Bill Roche; Exile at the Rocking Seven, by Joan Sherman Weir; My Name Is Not Odessa Yarker, by Marian Engel, illus. Lazlo Gal; and The Reunion, by Joan Lingard. Books in Canada, Dec. 1978, p. 28. "... My Name Is Not Odessa Yarker is a charmingly and amusingly written fable .... There is no attempt at realism, though the Toronto locations are recognizable ...."

D172      Lanthier, Phil. "What's Really in a Name?". Rev. of My Name Is Not Odessa Yarker, by Marian Engel, illus. Lazlo Gal; and The Leaves of Louise, by Matt Cohen. Canadian Children's Literature: A Journal of Criticism and Review, No. 21 (1981), pp. 80-81. Both books address the problem of "how to deal with false labels" and both "skillfully ... [develop] tension between reality and fantasy." Lazlo Gal's illustrations reinforce the realism, but not the fantasy. Odessa and Yarker "are names of Ontario towns familiar to anyone who travels Highway 401 east of Toronto .... Engel's story presents a problem, an injustice which must be corrected by strong action .... The book ... dramatizes the value of forceful declarations of independence backed by law... -- the story is well-shaped and clearly told."

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

This content is intended solely for the use of the individual user.
Source: Wengle, Annette (compiler); . Part 2: Works On Marian Engel (nee: Passmore), Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987. pp. 38-109 ; Lecker, Robert (editor). David, Jack (editor). Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors ; no. 7 ISBN: 0920763111 (hardcover); 092076312X (paperback), Book ID: ABCMA07MEP2.
Item Number: ABCMA07MEP2000007001004011
Record: 48
Title:
Part 2 Works on Marian Englel; Selected book reviews; The Glassy Sea
Other Title:
Part 2 Works on Marian Englel; Selected book reviews
Record Type:
Reference Series
Series Title:
Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors, no. 7
Author(s):
Wengle, Annette (compiler)
Genre(s):
Bibliography
Subject(s):
Authors discussed:  ENGEL, Marian; ENGEL, Marian -- Criticism & interpretation -- Bibliography
Titles critiqued:  GLASSY sea (Book)
Topics:  CANADIAN literature -- Bibliography; FRENCH-CANADIAN literature -- Bibliography
Book Source:

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Marian Engel (nee: Passmore). Wengle, Annette (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 38-109

Part 2 Works on Marian Englel; Selected book reviews; The Glassy Sea  

Wengle, Annette (compiler)

The Glassy Sea

D86      Clery, Val. "Look Outward, Engel, Now." Books in Canada, Aug.-Sept. 1978, p. 14. Clery admires Engel's writing generally (she is "the imaginative superior of Laurence and Atwood"), but deplores her subject matter in Bear and The Glassy Sea and hopes that she will "escape the vicious circle of regionalism."

D87      Fallis, Sheila Robinson. Rev. of The Glassy Sea. Quill & Quire, Sept. 1978, p. 12. The women in the novel are "real and fully drawn," but the treatment of male characters and "The description of growing up in rural Canada" are less successful. The Glassy Sea confirms Engel's place in "the front rank of Canadian writers."

D88      West, Barbara. "New Women's Books: No Man's Land." Rev. of Final Payments, by Mary Gordon; Violet Clay, by Gail Godwin; Abra, by Joan Barfoot; and The Glassy Sea, by Marian Engel. Chatelaine, Sept. 1978, p. 6. "The pressures of conscience, guilt, duty, faith, and the conflicting demands of the flesh are handled here with great subtlety by a Canadian writer of continuing excellence."

D89      Adachi, Ken. "Engel Follows Bear with Unsettling Novel of Uneven Riches." The Toronto Star, 30 Sept. 1978, p. D7. Adachi faults the novel for its lack of "story telling, the ability to conceal and surprise" and for its feminist message. "It's a curiously unsettling and uneven novel, rich with stylistic and descriptive graces, but ultimately as abstract and analytical as its stagey monologue artist, the heroine Rita Haber [sic]." The small-town Ontario background is "nicely delineated" but there is "a surfeit of rhetoric and polemic ... in which Engel tries very hard to lift radical feminism on to the serious and unsentimental plane of literature."

D90      Duffy, Dennis. "When Early Life's So Cold, Later Years Must Pass in a Hothouse of Dreams." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 30 Sept. 1978, p. 26. Duffy links the novel with other Engel works and with her interview with Graeme Gibson (C174), in which she talks about Western Ontario. The novel covers Rita's journey "from a Christianity that has become a set of esthetic motifs rather than convictions to a Christianity finding its meaning in social service ..." Engel's invention of the Eglantine Order is praised. Duffy distrusts Rita's "ability to see straight" at the end and cautions that "The novel has to be read ironically."

D91      Amiel, Barbara. "Bearing Up Under the Strain, Part II."Maclean's, 9 Oct. 1978, p. 64. Amiel admires Engel's "undeniable writing skill," but not her "chosen perspective on life[which] happens to be the sour loser's." Although Marguerite Heber is "the most interesting character Engel has created," Amiel finds similarities between her and Bear's Lou: "Both share an unhappy condition: a desire for more love, respect, and dominance than their brains, looks, and personalities can fetch on the open market."

D92      Edinborough, Arnold. 'the Books of Autumn A Time for Readers to Revel." Rev. of Karen Kain: Lady of Dance, by David Smart, illus. David Street; The Glassy Sea, by Marian Engel; E.M. Forster: A Life, 2 vols., by P.N. Furbank; The Railroad's Not Enough, by Heather Menzies; and The Joy of Hockey, by Eric Nichol, illus. Dave More. The Financial Post [Toronto], 14 Oct. 1978, p. 44. "Engel's talent for writing is as finely honed, as prismatically shimmering, as Kain's for the dance. Her style is lyrical, resonant and allusive, yet always drives her story on with a relentless power ... If you read one novel this year, read The Glassy Sea."

D93      Wachtel, Eleanor. "Pleasure of Engel's Company." The Vancouver Sun, 27 Oct. 1978, p. 40L. The Glassy Sea, largely epistolary in format, has "a convincing forcefulness ... Its immediacy is grounded in detailed images of the physical environment ... At the same time, the book revolves around an elaborate and repeated symbol of the rose, and the implications of the heroine's changing name." The Eglantine Order offers escapism and aestheticism. After Rita leaves the Order, the novel is weaker. "There is less actuality and more cliched speculation" and the new Order that Rita finally enters, modeled on Nellie's, the Toronto women's hostel, is characterized by "social usefulness, too familiar perhaps to be free of a propagandistic tone."

D94      Gordon, Alison. "Through Endless Agony with an Engel Heroine." Saturday Night, Nov. 1978, pp. 61-63. "The Glassy Sea is a disappointingly stereotyped and strangely bloodless novel."

D95      Bobak, E.L. Rev. of The Glassy Sea. Dalhousie Review, 58 (Winter 1978-79), 786-88. "The device of a letter requires a writer to maintain an unusually consistent tone and point of view. Engel saddled herself with a problem which she only partially resolves." Bobak admires the technical and thematic ambition and courage displayed in the novel, but finds that, due to the writing problems, "suspension of disbelief proves impossible."

D96      Biesenthal, Linda. Rev. of The Glassy Sea. In Canadian Book Review Annual: 1978. Ed. Dean Tudor, Nancy Tudor, and Linda Biesenthal. Toronto: Peter Martin Associates, 1979, pp. 144-45. "Both Bear and The Glassy Sea are dominated by a single character who is uncomfortable with her femaleness," but, unlike Lou in Bear, the heroine of The Glassy Sea is affected adversely by her venture into the world of passion. The sections about the Eglantine Order "are particularly good. Engel is less successful at capturing the essence of Rita's bewilderment in the world outside the convent. She does not sufficiently prepare us for Rita's falling apart, so that the character does not seem consistent. Despite this problem, Rita is a striking character and The Glassy Sea is a good novel."

D97      Dretzsky, George. "The New 'Woman's Novel.'" Rev. of Abra, by Joan Barfoot; Judith, by Aritha van Herk; and The Glassy Sea, by Marian Engel. The Fiddlehead, No. 120 (Winter 1979), pp. 143, 144-45. The "woman's novel" is reverting to fantasy-response after a healthy spell of "serious" writing. "Writers like Margaret Laurence ... have held that the fantasy-response is not an adequate way of dealing with the complications of a woman's life ..." Although challenging, The Glassy Sea is disappointing thematically and structurally, and is in need of rewriting.

D98      Manning, Linda. Rev. of The Glassy Sea. Quarry, 28, No. 1 (Winter 1979), 89-91. The "plot, woven about the war of the sexes, brings a modem twist to an age old tale." Although "The first two sections are quietly pragmatic, at times verging on the tedious," the last section is "gutsy and headstrong with a definite emphasis on survival."

D99      Vance, Sylvia. "A Novel Worth the Wait." Branching Out, [Fifth Anniversary Issue], 6, No. 1 (1979), 52. Vance greets The Glassy Sea as the novel by a woman, about women, for women, for which she has been waiting. "The Glassy Sea begs for more. It seems to be the first piece of fiction about women; it puts other literature of the same ilk in a retrograde position, demanding more of the other women novelists and readers."

D100      Farkas, Edie. "A Ride That Promises Everything." The Last Post [Toronto], 7 (Feb. 1979), 44-45. The novel disappoints because it fails to fulfil the promise it holds of leading to great ideals: Faith, Love, Community, and Death. It is "a beautifully written fraud, a hoax more disturbing than the middle-class mysticism purveyed by her previous novel ... it is Engel's talent to create believable if prosaic outcasts within a brief literary space ..." but the central character is shallow; the events that have occurred in her life "remain dim, hurriedly paraphrased, and ... seemingly inconsequential." The secondary characters are also lifeless. Engel's novels are really extended short stories.

D101      Gevier, Katherine. "Patching Up the Victims." The Canadian Forum, March 1979, p. 30. Govier relates The Glassy Sea to Sarah Bastard's Notebook and examines the effects of formally dividing the book into "a Prologue, The Letter, and an Envoi." "Articulate, integrated, mainlining rage forms the core of this novel. It is the rage of the woman set aside after her fruitful years are over, the woman set aside for not being sufficient to man's fantasies."

D102      Dewar, Elaine. "FEMCANLIT: Six Authors in Search of a Character: Reflections on a State of Mind." Rev. of Who Do You Think You Are?, by Alice Munro; The Glassy Sea, by Marian Engel; A Casual Affair, by Sylvia Fraser; Where the Cherries End Up, by Gail Henley; Judith, by Aritha van Herk; and Considering Her Condition, by Margaret Gibson. City Woman, March-April 1979, pp. 44, 46, 48, 50. Dewar's review of The Glassy Sea is mainly descriptive, with a minimum of evaluative comment. "This is a bitter, symbol-laden and at times incoherent version of Munro's story. It is dressed up with roses and thorn images, and a fanciful setting. But it is still about the dislocation and destruction of the small community; the struggle for female authenticity. There is little room for men. That point of view is a constant in five of the six books." Dewar suggests that in all six books migration from country to city is an allegory for a psychological movement "from restraint to freedom, from repression to anomie ... Alice Munro is the only one in the group capable of turning the story into literature ... The others manage partial statements at best. While Engel can be annoying and difficult to read, Rita does lay out the issues at hand most clearly." The metaphors in The Glassy Sea "are drenched with the memory of a time when morals had real force. It was a moral code that pinned us to motherhood and wifehood, willy-nilly."

D103      Watson, Wilfred. "Sisterly Satire." NeWest Review, April 1979, pp. 5, 14. Watson wonders why "the author of Honeyman's [sic] Festival and Bear [would] choose such a persona as Sister Pelagia." He sees the book as a riddle: "Even the most skilful writer of detective fiction could learn something from the way in which Marian Engel keeps clueing us in to a solution that continually evades us. It comes as a distinct shock to realize that the sleuthing-out of answers which the book entails on us is the very heart of the characterization of the central character of The Glassy Sea." Watson examines the genre of the novel and concludes that it is satire. Watson notes the book's link with the Pelagian heresy. (See B336 for Engel's response.)

D104      Atherton, Stan. "Long Day's Journey into Light." Rev. of Christopher Breton, by Selwyn Dewdney; The Glassy Sea, by Marian Engel; and Judith, by Aritha van Herk. The University of Windsor Review, 14, No.2 (Spring-Summer 1979), 111,113-14. The heroine of The Glassy Sea is "utterly convincing," "tough-minded and mordantly witty." Although Atherton's review is mainly descriptive, he ends by applying to Engel's work the accolade given by Kenneth Allsop to Iris Murdoch's novels: they "'give one the satisfying pleasure that only good writing can -- the really authoritative use of words, the felicity of phrase, the meticulous style which does not at the same time mean a nervous limitation of ideas.'"

D105      Bannon, Barbara A. Rev. of The Glassy Sea. Publishers Weekly [New York], 11 June 1979, p. 96. The Glassy Sea is "Even more imaginative and uninhibited than Engel's Bear ..." The heroine is unforgettable and "The language is as intricate, rich and sensuous as the wild rose and also thorny with the wit of desperation."

D106       Solecki, Sam. "Letters in Canada: 1978. Fiction: 2." University of Toronto Quarterly, 48 (Summer 1979), 320-22. Solecki expresses admiration for Engel's skill as a writer, but finds that her "use of the feminist ideology seriously unbalances her ending and consequently undermines the artistic success of her novel."

D107      Bennett, Sally H. Rev. of The Glassy Sea. Library Journal [New York], Aug. 1979, p. 1586. Rpt. in The Library Journal Book Review: 1979 [New York], 1980, p. 607. Bennett observes that The Glassy Sea is "Not as sparsely and starkly written as Bear ... but [is] richer and quietly elegant in style ..."

D108      Leonard, John. "Books of the Times." Rev. of In Between the Sheets and Other Stories, by Ian McEwan; and The Glassy Sea, by Marian Engel. The New York Times, 14 Aug. 1979, p. C12. "Parts of 'The Glassy Sea' seem to have been written in haste ... Rita's husband ... is an undeveloped and improbable monster... [and] feminist themes hop in and out of the narrative ... as if on the lam from another book." However, on second reading, the Mary/Martha division in Rita becomes clear, and with it the meaning of her return to the order of Anglican nuns. "Miss Engel, a wind from the north with every novel, has a mind in which one wants to live, various and witty and risk-taking and erotic and fiercely intelligent."

D109      McLellan, Joseph. "Convent of the Scared Heart." The Washington Post, 4 Sept. 1979, p.B2. The Glassy Sea "is a brief but very eventful novel, an agenda for a woman's movement, an exploration of the basic problems in our society and frequently poetry of a very high order." Engel uses the concrete details of Marguerite Heber Bowen's meditation on her life "beautifully, working them together in a prose collage of biographical fact, symbolism, fragments of philosophy and theology and acute social observation:' Both Marguerite's return to re-establish Eglantine House as "'a core of women helping other women to put their lives ... in order'" and the earlier uses of the Eglantine Order to shelter a "handful of women ... from reality" make a worthwhile statement about life in the twentieth century, and make it with "quirky elegance."

D110      Gordon, Mary. "The Quest of Sister Mary Pelagia." The New York Times Book Review, 9 Sept. 1979, pp. 12, 42. Although the novel is a serious work on an important theme -- the spiritual life of women -- it is unsuccessful. "... the book is full of isolated riches," and Engel is extremely good at describing rural Ontario life, but once Marguerite leaves home to join the Eglantine Order, the book's weaknesses in pacing, characterization, plot, and language come to the fore.

D111      Oates, Joyce Carol. "The Canadian Inheritance: Engel, Munro, Moore." Rev. of The Glassy Sea, by Marian Engel; The Beggar Maid, by Alice Munro; and The Mangan Inheritance, by Brian Moore. Ontario Review, No.ll (Fall-Winter 1979-80), pp. 87, 88, 90. Oates observes a common concern in all three novels with the problem of individual identity. "... the concern of serious Canadian fiction has always been for a defining of the self in terms of origins ... Of the three books, Marian Engel's is the shortest, the most stubbornly undramatic; one might almost call it ascetic."

D112      Ross, Catherine. "Mary and Martha." Journal of Canadian Fiction, No. 33 (1981-82), pp. 138-41. The Mary side of Rita Heber "yearns for beauty, images and metaphor." The Martha side is practical and hardworking. Ross discusses "the two meanings of Pelagian, the further opposition of contemplation and action and of Mary and Martha, together with the conflicting elements of Rita's nature that are reflected in her various names, [which] are all worked out in Rita's counterpointing of her Ontario past and her seaside present." The device of letter and frame sometimes becomes obtrusive and "more detail would be welcome as would more sense of place." While Bear succeeded with both mass market popular romance readers and with those able to appreciate a seriously symbolic work, The Glassy Sea is only likely to succeed with the latter.

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Marian Engel (nee: Passmore). Wengle, Annette (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 38-109

Part 2 Works on Marian Englel; Selected book reviews; The Islands of Canada  

Wengle, Annette (compiler)

The Islands of Canada

D173      French, William. "Island Junkies Indulge Habit." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 20 Oct. 1981,p.15. Engel "chooses islands for discussion that she and photographer Janis Kraulis have particular affection for, or islands they have always wanted to visit. In describing them, she brings a lyrical sheen to her prose and a romantic historical imagination that populates her islands with the ghosts of our past."

D174      Freedman, Adele. "Gift Books: Celebrations of Art and Nature." Quill & Quire, Dec. 1981, p. 28. In a feature review of eight Christmas gift books, Freedman notes that "Travel literature is a difficult genre, and Engel's stab at it often recalls its parody, travel brochures."

D175      Darragh, Ian. Rev. of Canada from theAir, by Bo Curtis, illus. J.A. Kraulis; and The Islands of Canada, by Marian Engel and J.A. Kraulis. Canadian Geographic, 101, No.6 (Dec.-Jan. 1981-82), 82-83. "For some reason, the photographs and text in Islands do not mesh together as well as they do in Canada from the Air." Engel's writing is "evocative and sprinkled with anecdotes," but the book's coverage is perhaps overly ambitious and therefore superficial.

D176      Brydon, Diana. "Picturing Our Past." Rev. of The Inuit: Life as It Was, by Richard Harrington; Canada: A History in Photographs, by Roger Hall and Gordon Dodds; The Icelanders, ed. David Arnason and Michael Olito; and The Islands of Canada, by Marian Engel and J.A. Kraulis. Canadian Literature, No.95 (Winter 1982), pp. 168--69. Of the four "attractively produced collections of photographs which, despite appearances, are not designed simply for the coffee table," The Islands of Canada is the least favourably reviewed. Brydon objects to the "glossy colour photographs and gushy prose .... The pretentiousness and conventionality of this book irritated" her. However, "... there is an interest in recovering lost histories and out-of-the-way places and peoples for the mainstream .... "

D177      Hume, Christopher. "A Thousand Words: The Past in Perspective: From the Extinction of the World's Animals to Historic Photos of Immigrants as They Emerge from the Dark Ages." Books in Canada, Jan. 1982, p.29. The Islands of Canada is one of a number of picture books discussed briefly in the review. "The emphasis is on the quaint and artsy-craftsy, but it preserves enough island quaintness to keep islomaniacs happy. Engel's text is quite bearable and Kraulis's pictures are simply superb."

D178      "Photography Books." Queen's Quarterly, 89 (Summer 1982), 460. The Islands of Canada is one of ten books briefly reviewed. It "celebrates geology, sights and people .... The text is felicitous and, unsurprisingly, a good deal more enjoyable than one is likely to encounter in the vast majority of such books."

D179      Mattison, David. Rev. of The Islands of Canada. In Canadian Book Review Annual: 1981. Ed. Dean Tudor and Ann Tudor. Toronto: Simon & Pierre, 1983, pp. 78-79. "The selection of islands is entirely personal .... Arranged from west to east, Engel writes of islands she not only visited but also simply flew over. Her writing is, of course, impeccable and conveys a range of feelings about our islands and their inhabitants." The photographs of landscape are superb, although the reproduction is faulted: registration of printing screens should be more accurate, and there are red spots on many photos.

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07MEP2000007001004009&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Marian Englel; Selected book reviews; The Tattooed Woman</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Marian Engel (nee: Passmore). Wengle, Annette (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 38-109

Part 2 Works on Marian Englel; Selected book reviews; The Tattooed Woman  

Wengle, Annette (compiler)

The Tattooed Woman

D147      Rule, Jane. "Posthumous Collection Confirms Engel's Power and Insight." Quill & Quire, June 1985, p. 39. Timothy Findley's Introduction (C122), "locates a unifying tone of 'oddness' [in the stories], something Engel herself calls 'the irrational.'" However, Rule finds that "... neither her characters nor their experiences are odd. What is irrational about them is their ability to express feeling, which is the source of creativity, something apparently much mistrusted in Ontario." Rule comments specifically on some half dozen of the sixteen stories in the collection. The couple in "The Confession Tree" also appears in an earlier story in Inside the Easter Egg. "Though there is darkness and pain in most of these stories, their tone nearly always transforms them into affirmations of a life more truly seen through satire, fantasy, and sometimes directly stated insight ... In them her craft is certain, her insight sharp, her tone distinctively her own, a voice of our time which, because Marian Engel risked being a writer against Ontario odds and to the end, transcends our loss."

D148      Adachi, Ken. "In Need of a Bigger Canvas." The Toronto Star, 20 July 1985, p. M5. Engel's "abundant talent" is evident in her novels. However, the short stories collected in The Tattooed Woman, "with some striking exceptions" leave one "wishing that she had done more with them ..." Engel creates "a perfidious world in which cancer or mutilation, both psychic and physical," operate "as a metaphor." The title story is "by far the best in the collection .... " In the weaker stories, "... Engel squanders her gift, the observation of reality ....The confluence of feeling and discipline, of severely controlled methods, is a most demanding art which few short-story writers have mastered." Nonetheless, Engel has an "enduring place -- as a novelist -- in Canadian literature."

D149      Hill, Douglas. "Striking Gold in a Major Resource." Rev. of The Tattooed Woman, by Marian Engel; Darkness, by Bharati Mukherjee; and Dark Arrows: Chronicles of Revenge, by Alberto Manguel. The Globe and Mail, 20 July 1985, p. E17. The Tattooed Woman "is both valediction and memorial to her [Engel's] gifts of compassion and daring." Engel's prose displays "lucidity," "directness" and "purity of line." The tales, usually first-person narratives, are about "women reassuring and reasserting themselves, compensating, settling in, triumphing .... Each of the pieces has the Engel touch, but there are few repetitions either of treatment or situation. ... The best of Engel's fiction, which is to say nearly all the work collected here, offers a ... shock of freedom."

D150      Morley, Patricia. "Superb Last Stories Match Best Engel Novels." The Citizen [Ottawa], 20 July 1985, p. C2. "Marian Engel's superb collection of 16 stories ranks beside or above the best of her novels (Bear, The Glassy Sea) and assures her a place among Canada's leading writers of fiction." Morley's favourite stories are "among the finest stories which this country has produced." Engel's "forte [is] in the surreal." She uses "the surreal to illuminate the real world and extend its boundaries:' Her vision "is charitable, witty and wise."

D151      Posesorski, Sherie. "Engel's Glorious Failure." Now [Toronto], 25-31 July 1985, p. 26. Engel's self-acknowledged failure "to lead a conventional life" resulted in renown as a Canadian writer. A standard theme of her work is "that of a woman escaping the bounds of convention." The stories collected in The Tattooed Woman have an "imaginative and emotional scope .... the predominant mode is magic realism," which Engel describes as "super reality."

D152      Bemrose, John. "A Graceful Epitaph." Maclean's. "Books," 5 Aug. 1985, p. 51. The stories collected in The Tattooed Woman "constitute an impressive final statement from one of the most graceful and humane writers in contemporary Canadian fiction .... Her hallmark was a style of a great naturalness and transparency:' With the best story in the collection, "Could I Have Found a Better Love Than You? .... and a handful of others, The Tattooed Woman proves that Marian Engers short fiction was as skilful and moving as any in Canadian literature."

D153      Post, Pamela. "Engel's Last Collection, a Celebration of Life." The Vancouver Sun, 10 Aug. 1985, p. D11. The Tattooed Woman is "a collection of 16 superbly skewed short stories," chosen by Engel for "the unity of their 'oddness' ... The magical quality of Engel's writing comes when she shows how close to the surface of normalcy floats the strange and the irrational." Post discusses the themes of metamorphoses and transcendence in Engel's stories. Engel's heroines "present and counsel an ability to cope, and even create, in the face of harsh odds."

D154      Glover, Douglas. "Bodily Harm." Books in Canada, Aug.-Sept. 1985, p. 15. "Unfortunately, Marian Engel's posthumous story collection ... is a somewhat flat close to a notable opus .... It seems clear that Engel needed the amplitude and accreted detail of a novel to bring her characters to life. The brevity of story-writing only served to expose a weakness for eccentricity as a stock device .... the best writing in this book is the flat-out realism of 'The Smell of Sulphur.'"

D155       Black, Barbara. "Canadian Authors Shine in Diverting Distinguished Stories." Rev. of Darkness, by Bharati Mukherjee; The Tattooed Woman, by Marian Engel; and Dark Arrows: Chronicles of Revenge, ed. Alberto Manguel. The Gazette [Montreal], 24 Aug. 1985, p. C1. Engel's short story collection, chosen by her "when she knew she was dying of cancer," and spanning the decade from 1975, is one of three new publications in Penguin's short fiction series. "Engel's forte was probing, loving description of mess, both household disarray and relationships that were shot full of holes .... " Her theme is "the insistent pull of human bonds."

D156      Hill, Gerald. "Dazzling Book by Simply Great Writer." The Edmonton Journal, 24 Aug. 1985, p.D7. The Tattooed Woman is "a brilliant book." The characters who "are more or less successful in approaching a kind of individual beatitude" are "distinctly believable and true .... Engel was a great writer, one of the best, an often fanciful chronicler of the heart's journey towards self-knowledge"

D157      McCracken, Rosemary. "Feelings Mark Engel's Stories." Calgary Herald, 25 Aug. 1985, p. C8. Engel's stories describe "the states of mind, or feelings" of characters caught "in the act of taking stock of their lives .... Her essentially androgynous vision reaffirms itself in these stories, which show women questioning and often rebelling against male dominated systems, and the few sympathetic male characters gravitating towards relationships in which both sexes function as spiritual equals .... Along with her novels, the book will assure her a place in Canadian literary hi story."

D158      Marshall, Tom. "A Vital, Bemusing World." Cross-Canada Writer's Quarterly, 8, No. 1 (1986), 19. Although a few of the stories are "thin" or "marred by sentimentality or cuteness" most are substantial. Like her best novels (The Honeyman Festival and Lunatic Villas), "... the better stories explore.., several generations of Ontario life, high and low, rural and urban, then and now."

D159      Micros, Marianne. "The Miracle of Everyday Life." Rev. of Raspberry Vinegar, by Joan Fern Shaw; Fables of Brunswick Avenue, by Katherine Govier; The Tattooed Woman, by Marian Engel; and Various Miracles, by Carol Shields. The Fiddlehead, No. 147 (Spring 1986), pp. 98, 99, 100, 101. Micros reserves her highest praise for the Shields and Engel collections. "If there is a theme or message that runs through [Engers] ... book, it is that deformity, illness, and bizarreness are what make people alive and human." The stories display Engel "at the height of her career"; the book will "live on."

D160      Boston, Anne. "Irrational Areas." Rev. of The Tattooed Woman, by Marian Engel; and Fables of Brunswick Avenue, by Katherine Gorier. The Times Literary Supplement [London], 18 July 1986, p. 792. The collection is uneven. It displays "a penchant for the surreal, offset by a deft hard sureness of tone, with occasional startling nosedives into cute whimsy .... 'Banana Flies' is, frankly, a mistake ... But the inventiveness and originality of the rest repays pursuing."

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Source: Part 1: Works By Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 273-291

Part 1 Works by Robert Kroetsch; Books (novels, poetry, mixed genre collection, memoir, criticism, travel book, and books edited), broadside, editorial work, audio-visual material, and manuscripts; Criticism  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Criticism

A19       Robert Kroetsch: Essays. Ed. Frank Davey and bpNicbol. Introd. Frank Davey. [Open Letter, Ser. 5, No. 4 (Spring 1983)]. 4, 123 pp. Includes "Beyond Nationalism: A Prologue" (B133), "Canada Is a Poem" (B120), "The Canadian Writer and the American Literary Tradition" (B113), "Carnival and Violence: A Meditation" (B137), "Contemporary Standards in the Canadian Novel" (B124), "The Continuing Poem," "Effing the Ineffable" (B119), "The Exploding Porcupine: Violence of Form in English-Canadian Fiction" (B129), "The Fear of Women in Prairie Fiction: An Erotics of Space" (B125), "For Play and Entrance: The Contemporary Canadian Long Poem" (B130), "The Moment of the Discovery of America Continues" (B121, B132, B147), "On Being an Alberta Writer" (B128), "Taking the Risk" (B122), and "Unhiding the Hidden: Recent Canadian Fiction" (B114).

Part 1 Works by Robert Kroetsch; Books (novels, poetry, mixed genre collection, memoir, criticism, travel book, and books edited), broadside, editorial work, audio-visual material, and manuscripts; Editorial work  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Editorial Work

A27     Annotator. Twentieth Century Literature, Oct. 1958-Dec. 1966.

A28     Faculty advisor. Barrow [Harpur College, State Univ. of New York, Binghamton, N.Y.], 1965-67, 1969-71, 1973-75.

A29     Editor. boundary 2 [State Univ. of New York at Binghamton], 2, Nos. 1-2 (Fall-Winter 1973-74)-6, No. 2 (Winter 1978).

A30     Editorial Board member. MOSAIC: A Journal for the Comparative Study of Literature and Ideas [Univ. of Manitoba], 10, No. 2 (Winter 1977)-12, No. 2 (Winter 1979) -- MOSAIC: A Journal for the Interdisciplinary Study of Literature [Univ. of Manitoba], 13, Nos. 3-4 (Spring-Summer 1980).

A31     Associate editor, boundary 2 [State Univ. of New York at Binghamton], 6, No.3 (Spring-Fall 1978).

A32     Editorial Board member. Dandelion, 4 (Oct. 1978).

A33     Publisher-Editor. NeWest Publications, Spring 1980.

A34     Prairie representative. Books in Canada, Aug. 1981-Jan. 1984.

A35     Editor. The Camrose Review: a journal of lutheran thought, No. 1 [1981?]-No.5 [Oct. 1984]-The Dinosaur Review, No. 6 (Winter 1985).

A36     Editorial Advisory Board member. The Prairie Journal of Canadian Literature, No. 2 (Spring-Summer 1984).

A37     Contributing editor. Swift Current, No. 1 (July 1984).

ABCMA07RKP1000007003001011
Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP1000007003001011&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP1000007003001011&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 1 Works by Robert Kroetsch; Books (novels, poetry, mixed genre collection, memoir, criticism, travel book, and books edited), broadside, editorial work, audio-visual material, and manuscripts; Manuscripts</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 1: Works By Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 273-291

Part 1 Works by Robert Kroetsch; Books (novels, poetry, mixed genre collection, memoir, criticism, travel book, and books edited), broadside, editorial work, audio-visual material, and manuscripts; Manuscripts  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Manuscripts

A39      "When Sick for Home." Diss. Iowa 1961.

A40      Robert Kroetsch Papers, Department of Rare Books and Special Collections, University of Calgary Library, Calgary, Alberta

         The Robert Kroetsch Papers include the mss of an unpublished novel in two versions, one his Ph.D. dissertation, "When Sick for Home," and the other a unique copy of a revised version. There are notes, drafts, galley sheets, and proofs of Kroetsch's books. Also included are mss and correspondence relating to published short stories and critical essays. Other correspondence pertains to his books, editorial work for boundary 2, and that of a more personal nature. There are various editions of his literary works, with copies of periodicals and little magazines containing contributions by Kroetsch. Five additional boxes of material are under negotiation.

A short list of the contents of each box follows.

Box 1: Creation

Box 2: Articles and essays

Box 3: Alberta

Box 4: Novels

Box 5: Plays

Box 6: Poetry

Box 7: Reviews by Kroetsch

Box 8: Short Stories

Box 9: Correspondence

Box 10: Interviews

A41     The Macmillan Company of Canada Archives, Mills Memorial Library, McMaster University, Hamilton, Ontario

        The Macmillan archives at McMaster contain correspondence with Kroetsch regarding But We Are Exiles (1964-68) and publicity files.

Part 1 Works by Robert Kroetsch; Books (novels, poetry, mixed genre collection, memoir, criticism, travel book, and books edited), broadside, editorial work, audio-visual material, and manuscripts; Travel book  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Travel Book

A20       Alberta. New York: St. Martin's, 1968. 231 pp. Toronto: Macmillan, 1968. 231 pp.

Title:
