Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 1: Works By Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 273-291

Part 1 Works by Robert Kroetsch; Contributions to periodicals and books (poetry, short stories and excerpts, reprinted anthology contributions: A selection, articles, reviews, and miscellaneous work) and audio-visual material; Poetry  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

B    Contributions to Periodicals and Books (Poetry, Short Stories and Excerpts, Reprinted Anthology Contributions: A Selection, Articles, Reviews, and Miscellaneous Work) and Audio-Visual Material

Note: When an item is reprinted in one of Kroetsch's books, this fact is noted in the entry through one of the following abbreviations: 

 Advice to My Friends ........................... AMF
 Alberta ...................................... Alta.
 Badlands ...................................... Bad.
 But We Are Exiles ............................. BWAE
 Creation ..................................... Crea.
 The Criminal Intensities of Love as Paradise .. CILP
 The Crow Journals ............................... CJ
 Excerpts from the Real World ................... ERW
 Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem.
 The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch ...... ...FN
 Gone Indian ..................................... GI
 The Ledger ................................. Ledg.-1
 The Ledger (2nd ed.) ....................... Ledg.-2
 Robert Kroetsch: Essays 
   [Open Letter, Ser. 5, No.4 (Spring 1983)] .... RK
 The Sad Phoenician .............................. SP
 Seed Catalogue .................................. SC
 Sketches of a Lemon ............................. SL
 The Stone Hammer Poems 1960-1975 ............... SHP
 The Studhorse Man ............................... SM
 What the Crow Said ............................. WCS
 The Words of my Roaring ........................ WmR

     Poetry

B1       "Letter to a Friend's Wife." Prism, 3, No. 1 (Fall 1961), 56.

B2       "Getting Up to Find an Aspirin." The Canadian Forum, Jan. 1962, p. 234. SC (revised).

B3       "Tidewater Burial." Prism, 3, No.3 (Spring 1962), 14-15. Rpt. in Clarendon [Harpur College, State Univ. of New York, Binghamton, N.Y.], 15, No.3 (Spring 1964), 14-15. SHP (revised).

B4       "Historia Animalium." The Canadian Forum, Feb. 1963, p. 254. SC (revised).

B5       "Outside Moose Jaw: A Whirlwind: Silence." Trace [London, Eng.], No. 49 (Summer 1963), p. 148. SHP (revised).

B6       "The Agony on Cape Cod." Prism, 3, No. 4 (Winter 1963), 25. Rpt. in Prism International [Prism International: Twenty-Five Years in Retrospect], 23, No. 2 (Winter 1984), 21. SHP.

B7       "Fortunate Fall." The Canadian Forum, Jan. 1964, p. 233.

B8       "Short Litany from a Shy Saint." Trace [London, Eng.], No. 57 (Summer 1965), p. 108.

B9       "Native." Prism International, 5, Nos. 3-4 (Winter-Spring 1966), 80. SC (revised).

B10      "Syllogisms of Desire." Prism International, 5, Nos.3-4 (Winter-Spring 1966), 81-82. SHP (revised).

B11      "Sketches toward a Couplet on Love: 1-4." The Canadian Forum, Sept. 1966, p.134. SHP (revised -- "Sketches towards a Couplet on Love: 1-3").

B12      "Tourist from Toronto." Alphabet, No.13 (June 1967), pp. 110-11.

B13      "The Skunk under the Granary." Prism International, 7, No. 2 (Autumn 1967), 52-53.

B14      "Abandon Ship." West Coast Review, 2, No. 2 (Fall 1967), 21. SC (revised).

B15      "Apology to the Girl in the Student Christian Centre Who Got Mad When I Criticized the Poet She Had Reputedly Slept With." Pluck [Univ. of Alberta], 1, No. 1 (Jan. 1968), 13.

B16      "Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 1-6." Alphabet, No.17 (Dec. 1969), pp. 54-56. Rpt. (revised) in The Canadian Forum, May 1982, pp. 21-24. SHP (revised); AMF (revised). This sequence of poems was later reprinted in a larger form, which includes six other poems. See B60 ("Descent, as Usual, into Hell"), B61 ("Driving, Accidental, West"), B62 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Awake, Awakening' "), B63 ["Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Chateau (A Landing) Frontenac'"], B64 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Collected Poem'"), and B65 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Weather Vane'") for other pieces included in the reprints.

B17      "Elegy for Wong Toy." Copperfield [Hamilton, Ont.], No.3 (Nov. 1970), 102-03. Rpt. (revised) in Salt: A Little Magazine of Contemporary Writing [Moose Jaw], No. 16 (Summer 1977), pp. 6-7. SHP.

B18      "October Light." Copperfield [Hamilton, Ont.], No. 3 (Nov. 1970), 44-45. SHP.

B19      "Projected Visit." Wascana Review, 5, No.1 (1970), 31. Rpt. (revised) in Salt: A Little Magazine on Contemporary Writing [Moose Jaw], No. 16 (Summer 1977), p. 5. SHP (revised).

B20      "Academic Question." Prism International, 11, No. 1 (Summer 1971), 41.

B21      "Birthday." Prism International, 11, No. 1 (Summer 1971), 41. SHP (revised).

B22      "Conservative Streak." Prism International, 11, No. 1 (Summer 1971), 42. SC (revised).

B23      "Sentence." Prism International, 11, No. 1 (Summer 1971), 43. SHP.

B24      "Authorities Have Launched Investigation." Island [Nanaimo, B.C.], No. 1 (1972), p. 8.

B25      "The Ledger." The Mysterious Barricades [New York], No.1 (Spring 1972), pp.8-11. Rpt. (expanded) in Applegarth's Folly [London, Ont.], [1], No. 1 (Summer 1973), 79-97. Ledg.-1 (revised); Ledg.-2 (revised);FN (revised).

B26      "Old Man Stories: 1-2, 5, 10-12." The Literary Half-Yearly [Univ. of Mysore, India], [Canadian Number], 13, No.2 (July 1972), 90-95. SHP (expanded -- "Old Man Stories: 1-12").

B27      "Dogteam Race in Manitoba." The Fiddlehead, No. 96 (Winter 1973), p. 47. SHP (revised).

B28      "Old Man Stories: 3-4, 6-9." Grain, 1, No. 1 (June 1973), 1-6. Rpt. (revised, excerpt -- "Old Man Stories 9") in Salt: A Little Magazine of Contemporary Writing [Moose Jaw], No.16 (Summer 1977), p. 7. SHP (revised, expanded -- "Old Man Stories: 1-12").

B29      "Mackenzie River: Nightfall." Northern Journey, No. 3 (Oct. 1973), p. 92. SHP.

B30      "Meditation on Tom Thompson." Northern Journey, No. 3 (Oct. 1973), p. 90-91. SHP.

B31      "F.P. Grove: The Finding." Lakehead University Review, 6 (Fall-Winter 1973), 209-10. SHP.

B32      "Poem of Albert Johnson." Lakehead University Review, 6 (Fall-Winter 1973), 211-12. SHP.

B33      "Pumpkin: A Love Poem." Barrow [Harpur College, State Univ. of New York, Binghamton, N.Y.], 1975, pp.14-15. Rpt. ("Pumpkin") in Nebula! [North Bay], [Margins], No. 1 (1975), pp. 20-21. SHP ("Pumpkin: A Love Poem").

B34      "Winter Birds." Barrow [Harpur College, State Univ. of New York, Binghamton, N.Y.], 1975, pp. 16-17. Rpt. in Nebula! [North Bay], [Margins], No. 1 (1975), pp. 18-19. SHP.

B35      "Code-A-Phone 500." Nebula! [North Bay], [Canadian Lyric-Poetry], No. 2 (1975), p. 12.

B36      "Highway 401." Nebula! [North Bay], [Canadian Lyric-Poetry[, No.2 (1975), p.11. SC("Highway One").

B37      "Identification Question." Nebula[ [North Bay], [Canadian Lyric-Poetry[, No. 2 (1975), pp. 10-11. SC.

B38      "My Tree Poem." Dandelion [Calgary], 2 (Spring-Summer 1976), 28-29. SC (revised).

B39      "Alberta Haiku (failed)." Grain [Saskatoon], 4, No. 2 (June 1976), 52. SC.

B40      "There Is a World." Grain [Saskatoon], 4, No. 2 (June 1976), 53. SC (revised).

B41      "How I Joined the Seal Herd." boundary 2 [State Univ. of New York at Binghamton], 5, No. 1 (Fall 1976), 229-32. SC; FN.

B42      "Poems from 'Seed Catalogue': A Suite." CV/II, 2, No.4 (Dec. 1976), 10-11. SC (expanded -- "Seed Catalogue"); FN.

B43      "Selections from 'Seed Catalogue.'" Arts Manitoba, 1, No.1 (Jan.-Feb. 1977), 30-31. SC (revised, expanded -- "Seed Catalogue"); FN (revised -- expanded).

B44      "Idea for a Poem." Salt: A Little Magazine of Contemporary Writing [Moose Jaw], No.16 (Summer 1977), p. 5. SHP.

B45      "Spring Harvest." Salt: A Little Magazine of Contemporary Writing [Moose Jaw], No.16 (Summer 1977), pp. 7-8. SHP; Crea. ("The Stone Hammer Poems: Spring Harvest").

B46      Kroetsh, Robert, and E.R. "American Mistress:' Island [Lantzville, B.C.], Nos. 5-6 (Fall-Spring 1978-79), 71-79.

B47      "This is a Love Poem (stanzas N-Z)." Descant, [Nos.22-23], 9, No.3-10, No.1 (1978-79), 19-25. SP (revised -- "The Sad Phoenician: A-Z"); FN.

B48      "The Sad Phoenician (Sections A-M)." Periodics, No.5 (Spring 1979), pp. 5-11. SP (revised -- "The Sad Phoenician: A-Z"); FN.

B49      "Zoo Poems: Zoo Poem 1." Whetstone [Univ. of Lethbridge], Sept. 1979, n. pag.

B50      "Zoo Poems: Zoo Poem 2." Whetstone [Univ. of Lethbridge], Sept. 1979, n. pag.

B51      "Zoo Poems: Zoo Poem 3." Whetstone [Univ. of Lethbridge], Sept. 1979, n. pag.

B52      "Zoo Poems: The Winnipeg Zoo." Whetstone [Univ. of Lethbridge], Sept. 1979, n. pag. FN (revised -- "The Winnipeg Zoo").

B53      "Bear Story with or without Bear." In Profiles in Canadian Literature. Ed. Jeffrey M. Heath. Vol.II. Toronto: Dundurn, 1980, 108. CILP (revised); FN ("The Criminal Intensities of Love as Paradise: Bear Story with or without Bear").

B54      "Sketches of a Lemon." The Malahat Review, No. 54 (April 1980), pp. 46-49. FN (revised); SL (revised).

B55      "Calgary Lover." Writing [David Thompson Univ. Centre], No. 2 (Winter 1980-81), p. 40.

B56      "Calgary Morning." Writing [David Thompson Univ. Centre], No. 2 (Winter 1980-81), p. 39.

B57      "Calgary Valentine." Writing [David Thompson Univ. Centre], No. 2 (Winter 1980-81), p. 39.

B58      "One a Them Prairie Stories." Grain, 9, No. 1 (Feb. 1981), 60-61.

B59      "Runes " Brick, No.12 (Spring 1981), p.48.

B60      "Descent, as Usual, into Hell." Canadian Literature, No. 90 (Autumn 1981), p. 24. Rpt. (revised -- "Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canadain the Dead of Six Nights. 'Descent, as Usual, into Hell'") in The Canadian Forum, May 1982, p. 23. AMF (revised -- "Mile Zero: 'Descent, as Usual, into Hell'"). This piece incorporates an earlier poem into a larger form. See B16 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 1-6"), B61 ("Driving, Accidental, West"), B62 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Awake, Awakening'"), B63 ["Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Chateau (A Landing) Frontenac'"], B64 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Collected Poem' "), and B65 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Weather Vane' ") for the other pieces included in the reprints.

B61      "Driving, Accidental, West." Canadian Literature, No. 90 (Autumn 1981), p. 24. Rpt. ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights 'Driving, Accidental, West'") in The Canadian Forum, May 1982, p.22. AMF ("'Mile Zero: Driving, Accidental, West'"). This piece incorporates an earlier poem into a larger form. See B16 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 1-6"), B60 ("Descent, as Usual, into Hell"), B62 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Awake, Awakening'"), B63 ["Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Chateau (A Landing) Frontenac'"], B64 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Collected Poem'"), and B65 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Weather Vane'") for other pieces included in the reprints.

B62      "Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Awake, Awakening.'" Canadian Forum, May 1982, p.23. AMF (revised -- "Mile Zero: 'Awake, Awakening' "). This piece incorporates an earlier poem into a larger form. See B16 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 1-6"), B60 ("Descent, as Usual, into Hell"), B61 ("Driving, Accidental, West"), B63 ["Mile Zero: Being Some Account. of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Chateau (A Landing) Frontenac'"], B64 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Collected Poem' "), and B65 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Weather Vane' ") for other pieces included in the reprints.

B63      "Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Chateau (A Landing) Frontenac.'" The Canadian Forum, May 1982, p.21. AMF [revised -- "Mile Zero: 'Chateau (A Landing) Frontenac'"]. This piece incorporates an earlier poem into a larger form. See B16 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 1-6"), B60 ("Descent, as Usual, into Hell"), B61 ("Driving, Accidental, West"), B62 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Awake, Awakening'"), B64 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Collected Poem'"), and B65 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Weather Vane'") for other pieces included in the reprints.

B64      "Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Collected Poem.'" The Canadian Forum, May 1982, p. 24. AMF ("Mile Zero: 'Collected Poem'"). This piece incorporates an earlier poem into a larger form. See B16 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 1-6"), B60 ("Descent, as Usual, into Hell"), B61 ("Driving, Accidental, West"), B62 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Awake, Awakening'"), B63 ["Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Chateau (A Landing) Frontenac'"], and B65 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Weather Vane' ") for other pieces included in the reprints.

B65      "Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Weather Vane.'" The Canadian Forum, May 1982, p.24. AMF ("Mile Zero: 'Weather Vane'"). This piece incorporates an earlier poem into a larger form. See B16 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 1-6"), B60 ("Descent, as Usual, into Hell"), B61 ("Driving, Accidental, West"), B62 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Awake, Awakening'"), B63 ["Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Chateau (A Landing) Frontenac'"], and B64 ("Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights. 'Collected Poem'") for other pieces included in the reprints.

B66      "from Advice to My Friends: 4 Slocan Valley, July 17, 1983: for Smaro." Writing [David Thompson Univ. Centre], No. 7 (Fall 1983), p. 29. AMF ("Advice to My Friends: 4 Slocan Valley, July 17, 1983: for Smaro").

B67      "Advice to My Friends: 1 for a poet who has stopped writing." Canadian Literature, No. 100 (Spring 1984), p. 181. AMF.

B68      "Advice to My Friends: 2 to Eli Mandel, setting his new alarm." Canadian Literature, No. 100 (Spring 1984), pp. 181-82. AMF (revised).

B69      "The Frankfurt Hauptbahnhof'.' Open Letter, Ser. 5, No. 7 (Spring 1984), pp. 83-93. AMF.

B70      "View from the North: Robert Kroetsch. for Doug Jones: the explanation" Descant, [Nos.44-45], 15, Nos.l-2 (Spring-Summer 1984), 9. AMF ("Advice to My Friends: 15 for Doug Jones: the explanation").

B71      "View from the North: Robert Kroetsch. late fall drive: for Byrna Barclay." Descant, [Nos. 44-45], 15, Nos.l-2 (Spring-Summer 1984), 7. AMF ("Advice to My Friends: 12 late fall drive: for Byrna Barclay").

B72      "View from the North: Robert Kroetsch. November 9 1983: for Robert Hilles." Descant, [Nos.44-45], 15, Nos. 1-2 (Spring-Summer 1984), 8. AMF ("Advice to My Friends: 13 November 9, 1983: for Robert Hilles").

B73      "Delphi: Commentary." Open Letter, [Essays on Robert Kroetsch], Ser. 5, Nos. 8-9 (Summer-Fall 1984), pp. 22-40. AMF.

B74      "from 'Advice to My Friends': a ritual for one." CV/II, 8, No. 3 (Sept. 1984), 18. AMF ("Advice to My Friends: 20 a ritual for one").

B75      "from 'Excerpts from the Real World': 11/1/85-12/1/85, 14/2/85-15/2/85, 20/2/85, 28/2/85." Dandelion, [Tenth Anniversary Issue], 12, No.1 (Spring-Summer 1985), 33. ERW.

B76      "from 'Excerpts from the Real World': 1/3/85-2/3/85, 4/3/85-5/3/85, 8/3/85, 10/3/85, 13/3/85-20/3/ 85, 22/3/85-23/3/85 25/3/85." NeWest Review, Summer 1985, p. 4. ERW.

B77      "from Excerpts from the Real World: 24/4/85-26/4/85, 28/4/85, 30/4/85, 2/5/85-3/5/85, 5/5/85-6/5/85, 8/5/85-9/5/85, 11/5/85, 14/5/85, 25/5/85, 27/5/85, 30/5/85." Canadian Literature. No. 108 (Spring 1986), pp. 36-38. ERW.

B78      "from 'Excerpts from the Real World': 7/6/85-8/6/85, 11/6/85, 14/6/85, 16/6/85-20/6/85, 25/6/85, 28/6/85-29/6/85, 5/7/85-6/7/85." NeWest Review, Sept. 1986, p. 7. ERW.

Record: 59
Title:
Part 1 Works by Robert Kroetsch; Contributions to periodicals and books (poetry, short stories and excerpts, reprinted anthology contributions: A selection, articles, reviews, and miscellaneous work) and audio-visual material; Short stories and excerpts
Other Title:
Part 1 Works by Robert Kroetsch; Contributions to periodicals and books (poetry, short stories and excerpts, reprinted anthology contributions: A selection, articles, reviews, and miscellaneous work) and audio-visual material
Record Type:
Reference Series
Series Title:
Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors, no. 7
Author(s):
Lecker, Robert (compiler)
Genre(s):
Bibliography
Subject(s):
Authors discussed:  KROETSCH, Robert; KROETSCH, Robert -- Bibliography
Topics:  CANADIAN literature -- Bibliography; FRENCH-CANADIAN literature -- Bibliography
Book Source:
Lecker, Robert (compiler) Part 1: Works By Robert Kroetsch.
Publisher Information: Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987. (pp. 273-291)
ISBN: 0920763111 (hardcover); 092076312X (paperback)

p. 285-286 (2 p.)

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 1: Works By Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 273-291

Part 1 Works by Robert Kroetsch; Contributions to periodicals and books (poetry, short stories and excerpts, reprinted anthology contributions: A selection, articles, reviews, and miscellaneous work) and audio-visual material; Short stories and excerpts  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Short Stories and Excerpts

B79     "The Stragglers." The Montrealer with Fashion, April 1950, pp. 34, 60.

B80     "The Toughest Mile." The Montrealer with Fashion, Nov. 1950, p. 38.

B81     "That Yellow Prairie Sky." Maclean's, 30 April 1955, pp. 28-29, 48-50. Rpt. trans. Zhang Mu in Foreign Literatures [Foreign Languages Institute, Beijing, China], [Special Number on Canadian Literature], No. 10 (1981), pp. 39-48. Crea.

B82     "Who Would Marry a Riverman?". Maclean's, 4 Feb. 1956, pp. 18-19, 28-29, 32, 34.

B83     "The Harvester." Maclean's, 29 Sept. 1956, pp. 22-23, 36, 38, 42-43.

B84     "Mrs. Brennan's Secret." Maclean's, 14 Sept. 1957, pp. 36, 94-98.

B85     "The Blue Guitar." The Canadian Forum, Feb. 1958, pp. 250-51.

B86     "Defy the Night." The University of Kansas City Review, 26 (Spring 1960), 229-33.

B87     "The Prophet." Sage [Univ. of Wyoming], 11, No. 1 (Spring 1966), pp. 19-30. WMR (excerpt).

B88     "It Was a Fair Trade: His Freedom for a Mug of Tea." North [Dept. of Northern Affairs and National Resources Ottawa], 13, No. 3 (May-June 1966), 20-22. BWAE (expanded -- "[The frozen rain rattled on the hood of his parka,...]").

B89     "The Ride." The Tamarack Review, Nos. 50-51 (Summer-Fall 1969), pp. 88-102. SM (Chs.i-iii).

B90     "Hit Us Again, We Love It: Something Fishy in the Pool." Toronto Life, Jan. 1978, pp. 100-01.

B91     "What the Crow Said." NeWest Review, 4, No. 2 (Oct. 1978), 7, 8, 15. WCS (revised, expanded -- Chs.x, xiii).

B92     "What the Crow Said." Exile, 5, Nos. 1-2 (1977), 202-15. WCS (revised, expanded -- Chs. xxix-xxxi).

B93     "from The Studhorse Man/DIOJOM FLKD." In 25 Top Canadian Prose Writers: An Anthology. Trans. Arie Hashavia. Ed. Marion Richmond and Robert Weaver. Tel-Aviv: Yachdav, 1982, pp. 183-88. SM.

B94     "Alibi: Dorf's Predicament (A Chapter in Which Much Is Foretold, But --); (Or, In Which Dorf Claims to Have Got Laid); In Which Dorf Imagines That He Should Have Written a Novel Instead; Burning, Burning." The Canadian Forum, Aug.-Sept. 1983, pp.19-21, 24-25, 27. Ali. ["Dorfs Predicament (A Chapter in Which Much Is Foretold, But --)," "(Or, In Which Dorf Claims to Have Got Laid," "In Which Dorf Imagines That He Should Have Written a Novel Instead," and expanded -- "Burning, Burning"].

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 1: Works By Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 273-291

Part 1 Works by Robert Kroetsch; Contributions to periodicals and books (poetry, short stories and excerpts, reprinted anthology contributions: A selection, articles, reviews, and miscellaneous work) and audio-visual material; Reprinted anthology contributions: A selection  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Reprinted Anthology Contributions: A Selection

B95     "Earth Moving." In Stories from Western Canada. Ed. and introd. Rudy Wiebe. Toronto: Macmillan, 1972, pp. 134-40. Originally entitled "Defy the Night."

B96     "That Yellow Prairie Sky." In Modern Canadian Stories. Ed. and introd. John Stevens. New York: Bantam, 1975, pp. 106-15.

B97     "Elegy for Wong Toy," "F.P. Grove: The Finding," "Old Man Stories (No. 7)," "Outside Moose Jaw: A Whirlwind: Silence," and "Stone-Hammer Poem." In Twelve Prairie Poets. Ed. and introd. Laurie Ricou. Ottawa: Oberon, 1976, pp. 79-97.

B98     "Elegy for Wong Toy," "F.P. Grove: The Finding," "From a Conversation with Margaret Laurence," and "Stone Hammer Poem." In Horizon: Writings of the Canadian Prairie. Ed. and preface Ken Mitchell. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1977, pp. 131-32, 202-03, 258, 277-79.

B99     "The Harvester." In Wild Rose Country: Stories from Alberta. Ed. and introd. David Carpenter. Ottawa: Oberon, 1977, pp. 79-90.

B100    "Old Man Stories: 3-4, 7." In Canadian Myths and Legends. Ed. and introd. Michael O. Nowlan. Themes in Canadian Literature, No. 3. Toronto: Macmillan, 1977, pp. 7-10.

B101    "That Yellow Prairie Sky." In The Best Modern Canadian Short Stories. Ed. and introd. Iron Owen and Morris Wolfe. Edmonton: Hurtig, 1978, pp. 435-41.

B102    "That Yellow Prairie Sky." In Literature in Canada. Vol.II. Ed. and introd. Douglas Daymond and Leslie Monkman. Toronto: Gage, 1978, pp. 435-41.

B103    "The Day of the Horses" (excerpt from SM) and "Stone Hammer Poems." In The Alberta Diamond Jubilee Anthology. Gen. ed. and introd. John W. Chambers. Edmonton: Hurtig, 1979, pp. 105-08, 110-14.

B104    "Seed Catalogue." In The Long Poem Anthology. Ed. and introd. Michael Ondaatje. Toronto: Coach House, 1979, pp. 21-44.

B105    "Collected Poem" and "The Winnipeg Zoo." In Draft: An Anthology of Prairie Poetry. Ed. Dennis Cooley. Winnipeg/Downsview, Ont.: Turnstone/ECW, 1981, pp. 88-92.

B106    "Identification Question" and "The Silent Poet at Intermission" In The Maple Laugh Forever: An Anthology of Comic Canadian Poetry. Ed. and "Prologue" Douglas Barbour and Stephen Scobie. Edmonton: Hurtig, 1981, pp. 75, 125.

B107    "Elegy for Wong Toy," "F.P. Grove: The Finding," "Mile Zero: Being Some Account of a Journey through Western Canada in the Dead of Six Nights," "Pumpkin: A Love Poem," "The Silent Poet Sees Red," "Stone Hammer Poem," "Winter Birds." In Canadian Poetry. Ed. Jack David and Robert Lecker. Introd. George Woodcock. New Press Canadian Classics. Toronto/Downsview, Ont.: General/ECW, 1982. Vol. II, 92-108.

B108    "Stone Hammer Poem." In The New Oxford Book of Canadian Verse: In English. Ed. and introd. Margaret Atwood. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1982, pp. 264-69.

B109    "F.P. Grove: The Finding," "Poem of Albert Johnson," "Stone Hammer Poem," and "Unhiding the Hidden: Recent Canadian Fiction" (essay). In An Anthology of Canadian Literature in English. Ed. and introd. Donna Bennett and Russell Brown. Vol. II Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1983, 238-50.

B110    "Getting Up to Find an Asprin," "How I Joined the Seal Herd," "Identification Question," "Seed Catalogue," "Sketches of a Lemon," "Syllogisms of Desire," and 'There Is a World." In The Contemporary Canadian Poem Anthology. Ed., introd., and notes George Bowering. Toronto: Coach House, 1983. Vol. III, 162-76.

B111    "Beyond Nationalism: A Prologue" (essay) and "On Being an Alberta Writer: Or, I Wanted to Tell Our Story" (essay). In Towards a Canadian Literature: Essays, Editorials and Manifestos. Ed. and preface Douglas M. Daymond and Leslie G. Monkman. Vol. II Ottawa: Tecumseh, 1985, 577-96.

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 1: Works By Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 273-291

Part 1 Works by Robert Kroetsch; Contributions to periodicals and books (poetry, short stories and excerpts, reprinted anthology contributions: A selection, articles, reviews, and miscellaneous work) and audio-visual material; Articles  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Articles

B112      "Writing from Prairie Roots." Alberta School Library Conference, Calgary. 1 May 1971. Printed in The Alberta School Library Review, 8, No. 1 (Fall 1971), 7-14.

B113      "The Canadian Writer and the American Literary Tradition." The English Quarterly, 4, No. 2 (Summer 1971), 45-49. RK.

B114      "Unhiding the Hidden: Recent Canadian Fiction." MLA Conference, Chicago. 27 Dec. 1973. Printed in Journal of Canadian Fiction, 3, No. 3 (1974), 43-45. Rpt. in Canadian Novelists and the Novel. Ed. Douglas Daymond and Leslie Monkman. Ottawa: Borealis, 1981, pp. 239-43. RK.

B115      "A Canadian Issue." In boundary 2 [State Univ. of New York at Binghamton], [A Canadian Issue], 3, No. 1 (Fall 1974), 1-2.

B116      "Kingdom of the Male Virgin." NeWest Review, Nov. 1975, p. 1.

B117      "Turning Alberta into Fiction." The Lethbridge Herald, 13 March 1976, p. 5.

B118      "Waiting for Riel." NeWest Review, April 1976, p. 3.

B119      "Voice/in prose: effing the ineffable." freeLance [Regina], 8, No.2 (Nov. 1976), 35-36. RK ("Effing the Ineffable").

B120      "Canada Is a Poem." In Divided We Stand. Ed. Gary Geddes. Toronto: Peter Martin, 1977, pp. 13-16. RK.

B121      "One for the Road: An Introduction:' In Prairie Pub Poems. By Glen Sorestad. freeLance [Regina], 8, No.3 (Feb. 1977), 11-12. RK (expanded -- "The Moment of the Discovery of America Continues").

B122      "Beginnings 11: Robert Kroetsch: Taking the Risk." Salt: A Little Magazine of Contemporary Writing [Moose Jaw], No.16 (Summer 1977), pp. 2-5. RK ("Taking the Risk").

B123      "The Plains of My Youth." The Weekend Magazine [The Globe and Mail] [Toronto], 9 July 1977, pp. 10-11.

B124      "Contemporary Standards in the Canadian Novel." The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel, Univ. of Calgary, Calgary, Alta. 16 Feb. 1978. Printed in Essays on Canadian Writing, No. 20 (Winter 1980-81), pp.7-18. Rpt. in Taking Stock: The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel. Ed. Charles R. Steele. Downsview, Ont.: ECW, 1982, pp. 9-20. RK.

B125      "Fear of Women in Prairie Fiction: An Erotics of Space." Crossing Frontiers, Univ. of Alberta/ Idaho State Univ., Banff, Alta. 14 April 1978. Printed in The Canadian Forum, Oct.-Nov. 1978, pp.22-27. Rpt. in Crossing Frontiers: Papers in American and Canadian Western Literature. Ed. Dick Harrison. Edmonton: Univ. of Alberta Press, 1979, pp. 73-83. RK ("The Fear of Women in Prairie Fiction: An Erotics of Space"). For Sandra Djwa's response, see C84.

B126      Kroetsch, Robert, and Don Romanchuk. "The Big City." Calgary Magazine, 1, No.4 (Dec. 1978), 48-53.

B127      Participant. "Ethnicity and Identity: The Question of One's Literary Passport:' Identifications: Ethnicity and the Writer in Canada, Univ. of Alberta, Edmonton, Alta. Sept. 1979. Printed in Identifications: Ethnicity and the Writer in Canada. Ed. Jars Balan. Edmonton: Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies, Univ. of Alberta, 1982, pp. 73, 75, 76. Kroetsch, a member of the audience, is drawn into the panel discussion by Pier Giorgio Di Cicco, Maria Campbell, Andrew Suknaski, and Rudy Wiebe.

B128      "On Being an Alberta Writer: Or, I Wanted to Tell Our Story." 12th Annual Western Canadian Studies Conference, Univ. of Calgary, Calgary. 15 Feb. 1980. Printed in The New Provinces: Alberta and Saskatchewan, 1905-1980. Ed. Howard Palmer and Donald Smith. Vancouver: Tantalus Research, 1980, pp. 217-27. RK ("On Being an Alberta Writer").

B129      "The Exploding Porcupine: Violence of Form in English-Canadian Fiction." Violence in the Canadian Novel since 1960, Memorial Univ., St. John's. 25 April 1980. Printed in Violence in the Canadian Novel since 1960/dans le roman canadien depuis 1960. Ed. Virginia Harger Grinling and Terry Goldie. St. John's: Memorial Univ., [1981], pp. 191-99. RK.

B130      "Canadian Literature: What Happened in the Seventies." MLA Conference, Houston, Tex. 29 Dec. 1980. Printed ("For Play and Entrance: The Contemporary Canadian Long Poem") in Dandelion, 8, No. 1 (1981), 61-85. RK.

B131      Introduction. In Alberta: The Badlands. By Glen Rollans. Illus. Brian Noble. A Reidmore Book. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1981, n. pag.

B132     Preface. In Dreaming Backwards: 1954-1981. By Eli Mandel. Don Mills, Ont.: General, 1981, pp. 9-12. RK (expanded -- "The Moment of the Discovery of America Continues").

B133      "Beyond Nationalism: A Prologue." MOSAIC: A Journal for the Interdisciplinary Study of Literature, [Beyond Nationalism: The Canadian Literary Scene in Global Perspective], 14, No. 2 (Spring 1981), v-xi. RK.

B134      "The Voice of the Land Is Heard in Our Turtle." CACLALS [Canadian Association for Commonwealth Literature and Language Studies] Conference, Univ. of Winnipeg. 1-4 Oct. 1981. Printed in The Commonwealth in Canada. Ed. Uma Parameswaran. Proc. of the Second Triennial Conference of CACLALS. II. Calcutta: Writers Workshop Greybird, 1983, pp. 297-98.

B135      "Electronics and Publishing." Rampike [Toronto], [Electricitee], 2, Nos. 1-2 (1982), 44.

B136      Kroetsch, Robert, Tamara Palmer, and Beverly Raspo. rich. "Introduction: Ethnicity and Canadian Literature." Canadian Ethnic Studies/etudes ethniques au Canada, [Ethnicity and Canadian Literature], 14, No. 1 (1982), iii-vii.

B137      "Carnival and Violence." Joint Conference of the Canadian Association for American Studies and the Association for Canadian Studies in the United States, Saint Michael's College, Univ. of Toronto, Toronto. 22 Oct. 1982. RK ("Carnival and Violence: A Meditation").

B138      "Field Notes: Words/Works" Books in Canada, Dec. 1982, pp. 5-6.

B139      Contributor. "Keynote Address: Discussion." Long-Liners Conference on the Canadian Long Poem, York Univ., Toronto. 29 May-1 June ] 984. Printed in Open Letter, [Long-Liners Conference Issue], Ser.6, Nos.2-3 (Summer-Fall 1985), p. 24.

B140      Contributor. "Locality and the Long Poem: Discussion." Long-Liners Conference on the Canadian Long Poem, York Univ., Toronto. 29 May-1 June 1984. Printed in Open Letter, [Long-Liners Conference Issue], Ser. 6, Nos.2-3 (Summer-Fall 1985), pp. 283-84, 286, 287.

B141      "American Poetry Now: Making Room for the Weather." Open Letter, [Essays on Robert Kroetsch], Ser. 5, Nos.8-9 (Summer-Fall 1984), pp. 41-46.

B142      "The Grammar of Silence: Narrative Pattern in Ethnic Writing." Ethnicity and Literature: Canadian Perspectives on Language, Silence, and Translation, Univ. of British Columbia, Vancouver. 26 Sept. 1984. Printed in Canadian Literature, No. 106 (Fall 1985), pp. 65-74.

B143      Preface. In Gaining Ground: European Critics on Canadian Literature. Ed. Robert Kroetsch and Reingard M. Nischik. Western Canadian Literary Documents. Vol. VI. Edmonton: NeWest, 1985, 7-8.

B144      "The Half-Imagined Land." Brick [Toronto], No. 26 (Winter 1986), pp. 40-43.

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 1: Works By Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 273-291

Part 1 Works by Robert Kroetsch; Contributions to periodicals and books (poetry, short stories and excerpts, reprinted anthology contributions: A selection, articles, reviews, and miscellaneous work) and audio-visual material; Reviews  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Reviews

B145      Rev. of But We Are Exiles. Library Journal, 1 Feb. 1966, p. 729. See D3.

B146      "Mirror, Mirror Show Us All." Rev. of The Scorched-Wood People, by Rudy Wiebe. Books in Canada, Jan. 1978, p. 14.

B147      "The Disappearing Father and Harrison's Born Again and Again and Again West." Rev. of The Unnamed Country: The Struggle for a Canadian Prairie Fiction, by Dick Harrison. Essays on Canadian Writing, No.ll (Summer 1978), pp. 7-9. RK (expanded -- "The Moment of the Discovery of America Continues").

B148      Rev. of Landscape Planning [Amsterdam, Neth.], [Canada: Landscape Planning for People], 6, No.2 (Aug. 1979). Plan Canada, 20 (June 1980), pp. 126-27.

B149      "No Match for the Devil." Rev. of Voice Storm, by Raymond Gariepy; Inanna Poems, by Karen Lawrence; Where Have You Been, by Miriam Mandel; and Echo and Montana, by J.O. Thompson. Books in Canada, May 1981, p. 34.

B150      "From Magpies to Booby Coots." Rev. of Lying in Bed, by Mary Howes; EXTREME POSITIONS, by bpNichol; A Grand Memory for Forgetting, by Stephen Scobie; and Gaullimaufry, by Jon Whyte. Books in Canada, Jan. 1982, pp. 9-10.

B151      "Small Presses: More Than Just Books, Eight New Poetry Collections from the West Are Visual Works of Art." Rev. of Writing Right: Poetry by Canadian Women, ed. Douglas Barbour and Marni A. Stanley; Kissing the Body of My Lord, by Doug Beardsley; Country of the Open Heart, by David McFadden; Smoking Mirror, by George Bowering; Excuses for Archery, by Glenn Deer; The Least You Can Do Is Sing, by Cecelia Frey; Awe, by John Nold; and Mass on Cowback, by Wilfred Watson. Books in Canada, Jan. 1983, pp. 31-32.

B152      "Getting Beyond Structure." Rev. of Montage for an Interstellar Cry, by Andrew Suknaski; and The Mossbank Canon, by E.F. Dyck. Books in Canada, April 1983, pp. 28-29.

B153      Rev. of Women and Words: The Anthology/Les Femmes et les Mots: Une Anthologie, ed. West Coast Editorial Collective. Contemporary Verse 2, 9, No. 2 (Fall 1985), 58-60.

Source: Part 1: Works By Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 405-425

Part 1 Works by Thomas H. Raddall; Books (novels, short stories, histories, memoir, and book edited), pamphlets, audio-visual material, and manuscripts; Histories  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

     Histories

A18     and C.H.L. Jones. The Markland Sagas. Illus. T.W. Hayhurst. Montreal: Gazette Printing, 1934. 118 pp.

A19     West Novas: A History of the West Nova Scotia Regiment. Foreword Thomas H. Raddall. [Montreal: Provincial Publishing, 1947.] 9-11, 326 pp.

A20      Halifax, Warden of the North. Preface Thomas Raddall. Illus. Donald C. Mackay. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1948. vii-xi, 348 pp.

     Preface Thomas Raddall. Illus. Donald C. Mackay. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1949. vii-xi, 348 pp.

     Preface Thomas Raddall. Illus. Donald C. Mackay. London: Dent, 1950. vii-xi, 348 pp.

     Rev. ed. Preface Thomas Raddall. Garden City, N.Y.: Doubleday, 1965. vii-x, 334 pp.

     Rev. ed. Preface Thomas Raddall. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1971. vii-x, 343 pp.

A21     The Path of Destiny: Canada from the British Conquest to Home Rule 1763-1850. Garden City, N.Y.: Doubleday, 1957. 468 pp.

     Toronto: Doubleday Canada Book Club, [1959]. 468 pp.

     New York: Popular Library, [1968]. 478 pp.

     Toronto: Popular Library, [1968]. 478 pp.

A22     Footsteps on Old Floors: True Tales of Mystery. Preface Thomas Raddall. Garden City, N.Y.: Doubleday, 1968. 11-13, 239 pp.

     Braille ed. 2 vols. Toronto: CNIB, 1968. Includes "Adventures of the H.M.S. Blonde" (B146), "Grey Owl," "The Lost Gold at Kejimkujik," "Mary Celeste," "The Murders Aboard the Herbert Fuller," and "Sadie Davenport."

A23     A Pictorial Guide to Historic Nova Scotia. Halifax: The Book Room, 1970. 31 pp.

A24     The Mersey Story. Liverpool, N.S.: Bowater-Mersey Paper Co., 1979. 124 pp.

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP1000007004001008&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 1 Works by Thomas H. Raddall; Books (novels, short stories, histories, memoir, and book edited), pamphlets, audio-visual material, and manuscripts; Manuscripts</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 1: Works By Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 405-425

Part 1 Works by Thomas H. Raddall; Books (novels, short stories, histories, memoir, and book edited), pamphlets, audio-visual material, and manuscripts; Manuscripts  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

     Manuscripts

A35      Raddall Manuscript Collection, Dalhousie University Archives, Killam Memorial Library, Dalhousie University, Halifax, Nova Scotia

Raddall has inscribed a number of the typescripts in File J, explaining where they were eventually published. Many of the publications are, however, no longer in evidence and are not, therefore, listed in Section B, but are noted here. The manuscripts are filed according to the following categories:

A. Diaries

B. Scrapbooks

C. Photographs

D. Memorabilia

E. Books and Pamphlets (Fiction and Poetry)

F. Books and Pamphlets (Non-Fiction)

G. Publications in Anthologies

H. Forewords and Introductions

I. Periodical Publications (Fiction and Poetry)

J. Periodical Publications (Non-Fiction).

Raddall's inscriptions on the following typescript articles are given in square brackets following the title: "Book Window Overseas" [Trade Circular. London: W.H. Smith and Sons, 1951] (3 pp.); "Citadel Hill," Pt. 1 [Halifax Chronicle-Herald, 1951] (4 pp.); "Citadel Hill," Pt.II [Halifax Chronicle-Herald, 1951] (4 pp.); "Citadel Hill," Pt.III [Halifax Chronicle-Herald, 1951] (4 pp.); "Royal Halifax" Pt.I [Halifax Chronicle-Herald, 1951] (4 pp.); "Royal Halifax," Pt. II [Halifax Chronicle-Herald, 1951] (4 pp.); "DeWolfe Memorial Library" [Liverpool Advance, Feb. 1953] (8 pp.); "John William Turner" [Obituary, Liverpool Advance, 1956] (2 pp.); "Canada's 'Maritimes'" [Bowaters Magazine, 1957] (9 pp.); "Departure" [Weekend Magazine, about 1960] (8 pp.); Foreword in unnamed literary magazine to be published by Dalhousie University students [written in 1968, a single issue of the magazine appeared in 1969] (2 pp.}; "The Original Canadian Legion in Queen's County" [Liverpool Advance weekly, June 1976] (3 pp.).

K. Lectures and Addresses

L. Radio and Television Broadcasts

M. Interviews

N. Unpublished Writings (Fiction)

O. Unpublished Writings (Non-Fiction)

P. Unpublished Writings (Memoirs)

Q. Research Notes and Material

R. Notebooks

S. Correspondence

A36      Thomas Raddall Papers, Humanities Research Center, University of Texas, Austin, Texas

The Humanities Research Centre holds 6 letters from Raddall to T.B. Costain (1956-60) and replies.

A37      The Macmillan Company of Canada Archives, Mills Memorial Library, McMaster University, Hamilton, Ontario

In the Author Correspondence section of these papers, McMaster holds correspondence from Raddall regarding The Rover: The Story of a Canadian Privateer (1956-63).

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Raddall; Books (novels, short stories, histories, memoir, and book edited), pamphlets, audio-visual material, and manuscripts; Novels</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 1: Works By Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 405-425

Part 1 Works by Thomas H. Raddall; Books (novels, short stories, histories, memoir, and book edited), pamphlets, audio-visual material, and manuscripts; Novels  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

Thomas H. Raddall

An Annotated Bibliography

[underbar]

Alan R. Young

Part I

Works by Thomas H. Raddall

[underbar]

A     Books (Novels, Short Stories, Histories, Memoir, and Book Edited), Pamphlets, Audio-Visual Material, and Manuscripts

Novels 

 A1     --[author], and C.L. Jones [instigator]. 
        Saga of the "Rover" Illus. Thomas W. Hayhurst. 
        Halifax: Royal Print and Litho, [1931]. 92 pp.



 A2      His Majesty's Yankees. Garden City, N.Y.: 
               Doubleday, Doran, 1942. 409 pp.
        Garden City, N.Y.: Doubleday, Doran, 1943. 409 pp.
        Edinburgh: Blackwood, 1944. 430 pp.
        Edinburgh: Blackwood, 1945. 430 pp.
        Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, [1945]. 409 pp.
        Braille ed. 9 vols. London: National Library for the 
               Blind, 1946.
        Toronto: Harlequin, 1952. 317 pp.
        Garden City, N.Y.: Doubleday, [1957]. 374 pp.
        New York: Popular Library, [1968]. 413 pp.
        Toronto: Popular Library, [1968]. 413 pp.
        Introd. James Gray. New Canadian Library, No. 33. 
               Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1977. xi-xviii, 409 pp.
        Braille ed. Toronto: CNIB, [1985?].



 A3      Roger Sudden. Preface Thomas Raddall. 
        Garden City, N.Y.: Doubleday, Doran, 1944.358 pp.
        Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1944. 358 pp.
        Garden City, N.Y.: Doubleday, Doran, 1945. 358 pp.
        De Ukuelige. Trans. Rose-Marie Tvermoes.  Odense, 
               Denmark: Scandinavisk Bogforlag, 1946. 478 pp.

     Roger Sudden. London: Hurst & Blackett, 1946. 255 pp.

     Prague, Czechoslovakia, 1947. [Details not located.] This was a pirated edition for which Raddall was eventually paid a minimal sum through his London literary agent.

     De Okuvliga. Trans. Ulla Hornborg. Helsinki, Finland: Holger Schildts, 1948. 359 pp.

     Roger Sudden. Montreal: Reprint Society of Canada, 1949. 358 pp.

     [Abridged ed.] Toronto: Harlequin, 1951. 320 pp.

     New York: Bantam, 1953. 406 pp.

     De Ukuelige. Trans. Rose-Marie Tvermoes. Odense, Denmark: Scandinavisk Bogforlag, 1963. 281 pp.

     Roger Sudden. Introd. J.R. Leitold. New Canadian Library, No.85. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1972. [iv-viii], 359 pp.

A4       Pride's Fancy. Foreword Thomas Raddall. Garden City, N.Y.: Doubleday, 1946. v-vi, 308 pp.

     Foreword Thomas Raddall. New York: Literary Guild (Canadian Branch), 1946. v-vi, 308 pp.

     Foreword Thomas Raddall. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1946. v-vi, 308 pp.

     London: Hurst & Blackett, 1948. 240 pp.

     Toronto: Harlequin, 1954. 288 pp.

     Introd. Fred Cogswell. Foreword Thomas Raddall. New Canadian Library, No. 98. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1974. iii-x, xi-xii, 308 pp.

A5     The Nymph and the Lamp. Boston: Little, Brown, 1950. 376 pp.

     Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1950. 376 pp. Book Club, [1951]. 376 pp.

     London: Hutchinson, 1951. 392 pp.

     [Abridged ed.] Illus. Henry Pitz. Pleasantville, N.Y.: Reader's Digest Condensed Books, 1951, pp. 331-494.

     Braille ed. 7 vols. London: National Library for the Blind, 1951.

     New York: Popular Library, 1952. 382 pp.

     Toronto: Harlequin, 1952. 320 pp.

     De Nimf en de Lamp. Trans. Margrit de Sablonitre. Assen, Netherlands: Born, 1952. 354 pp.

     La Nymphe et la Lampe. Trans. Roger W. Allard. Collection Marabout. Verviers, Belgium: Gerard, 1952. 228 pp.

     London: Hutchinson, 1953. 408 pp.

     London: Universal Book Club, 1953. 408 pp.

     't gebeurde op Marina. Trans. R. Goris. Amsterdam, Netherlands: Grote Nederlandse Huisbibliotheck, 1954. 255 pp.

     La Nymphe et la Lampe. Trans. Roger W. Allard. Illus. Henry Pitz. [Abridged ed.] In Selection du Livre. Paris: Reader's Digest, 1956, pp. 123-290.

     Die Nymphe unterm Leuchtturm. Trans. Pia von Hartungen. Hamburg, W. Get.: Zsolnay, 1957. 485 pp.

     Nymfen Och Lampen. Trans. Torsten Scheutz. Illus. Henry Pitz. [Abridged ed.] In Det Bastas Bokval. Stockholm: Reader's Digest Aktiebolag, 1958, pp. 355-524.

     La Nymphe et la Lampe. Trans. Paris: Seghers-l'Inter, 1958. 345 pp.

     The Nymph and the Lamp. Illus. Henry Pitz. [Abridged ed.] In Reader's Digest Condensed Books. London: Reader's Digest Association, 1959, pp. 367-502.

     The Nymph and the Lamp. [Abridged ed.] London: Readers Digest, 1959, pp. 363-503.

     Nymfen og Lampen. Trans. Jon Kehler. Illus. Henry Pitz. [Abridged ed.] In Det Bedstes Boger. Copenhagen: Reader's Digest, 1961, pp. 229-386.

     The Nymph and the Lamp. Introd. John Matthews. New Canadian Library, No. 38. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1963. v-ix, 331 pp.

     De Nimf en de Lamp. Trans. Leo van de Wiel. Illus. Rein van Looy. [Abridged ed.] In Het Beste boeke. Amsterdam: Reader's Digest N. V., 1971, pp. 237-392.

A6     Son of the Hawk. Illus. Stanley Turner. Philadelphia: Winston, 1950. 247 pp.

     Foreword Thomas Raddall. Illus. Stanley Turner. Toronto: Doubleday, [1963]. v, 247 pp.

A7     Tidefall. Boston: Little, Brown, 1953. 309 pp.

     Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1953. 309 pp.

     London: Hutchinson, 1954. 304 pp.

     Give and Take. New York: Popular Library, 1954. 221 pp.

     Tidefall. New York: Book League of America, 1954. 309 pp.

     London: Universal Book Club, 1955. 304 pp.

A8      The Wings of Night. Garden City, N.Y.: Doubleday, 1956. 319 pp.

     Garden City, N.Y.: Doubleday Dollar Book Club, [1957]. 319 pp.

     London: Macmillan, 1957. 319 pp.

     Schwingen der Nacht. Trans. Melita Ollendorff.

     Hamburg, W. Ger.: Zsolnay, 1959. 435 pp.

     The Wings of Night. Braille ed. 8 vols. Toronto: CNIB, 1961.

     London: Pan, 1961. 318 pp.

     Schwingen der Nacht. Paperback ed. Trans. Melita Ollendorff. Hamburg, W. Ger.: Zsolnay, 1961. 435 pp.

A9     The Rover: The Story of a Canadian Privateer. Foreword Thomas Raddall. Illus. Vernon Mould. Great Stories of Canada, No. 16. Toronto: Macmillan, 1958. 5-7, 156 pp.

     Foreword Thomas Raddall. Illus. Vernon Mould. New York: St. Martin's, 1959. 5-7, 156 pp.

     Foreword Thomas Raddall. Illus. Vernon Mould. Toronto: Macmillan, 1966. 5-7, 156 pp.

A10     The Governor's Lady. Garden City, N.Y.: Doubleday, 1960. 474 pp.

     London: Collins, 1961. 447 pp.

     New York: Doubleday Dollar Book Club, [1961]. 474 pp.

     New York: Popular Library, [1969]. 541 pp.

     Toronto: Popular Library, [1969]. 541 pp.

     Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1979. 474 pp.

A11     Hangman's Beach. Preface Thomas Raddall. Garden City, N.Y.: Doubleday, 1966. v-vi, 421 pp.

     Preface Thomas Raddall. New York: Popular Library, [1969]. 5-6,416 pp.

     Preface Thomas Raddall. Toronto: Doubleday Book Club, 1969. v-vi, 421 pp.

     Preface Thomas Raddall. Toronto: Popular Library, [1969]. 5-6, 416 pp.

     Preface Thomas Raddall. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1979. v-vi, 421 pp.

Raddall; Books (novels, short stories, histories, memoir, and book edited), pamphlets, audio-visual material, and manuscripts; Pamphlets</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 1: Works By Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 405-425

Part 1 Works by Thomas H. Raddall; Books (novels, short stories, histories, memoir, and book edited), pamphlets, audio-visual material, and manuscripts; Pamphlets  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

     Pamphlets

A27      A Souvenir from the Land of Maple. Liverpool, N.S.: Mersey Paper Co., [early 1930s]. 2 pp. A copy of this undated and unsigned pamphlet is in the Dalhousie University Archives, together with a letter from Raddall claiming authorship in the early 1930s.

A28     Ogomkegea: The Story of Liverpool, Nova Scotia. Liverpool, N.S.: Advance Publishing, [1934]. 12 pp.

     Liverpool, N.S.: Liverpool Advance/Business and Professional Women's Clubs of Nova Scotia, 1951. 15 pp.

     Rev. ed. Liverpool, N.S.: Liverpool Advance, 1964. 15 pp.

     Rev. ed. Liverpool, N.S.: Liverpool Advance, 1972. 15 pp.

     Liverpool, N.S.: Queen's County Museum, 1983. 16 pp. Includes "Ogomkegea: The Story of Liverpool, Nova Scotia" (B109).

A29     Canada's Deep Sea Fighters. Halifax, Government of Nova Scotia Information Bureau, 1936. 28 pp. Unsigned pamphlet. A copy of this 1936 version is in the Provincial Archives of Nova Scotia.

     Rev. ed. Halifax: Government of Nova Scotia Information Bureau, 1937.

     Rev. ed. Halifax: Government of Nova Scotia Information Bureau, 1938.

A30      Halifax and the World in 1809 and 1959, A Comparison of the Times. Halifax: Halifax Insurance Company, 1959. 10 pp. Unsigned pamphlet. A copy is in the Provincial Archives of Nova Scotia.

A31      A Brief History of Zion Church Liverpool, N.S. 1760-1967. Liverpool, N.S.: Zion United Church of Canada, 1967. 16 pp. A copy is in the Acadia University Library.

A32   Perkins House, Liverpool, Nova Scotia. Halifax: Nova Scotia Museum, n.d.N, pag. Unsigned pamphlet.

Raddall; Books (novels, short stories, histories, memoir, and book edited), pamphlets, audio-visual material, and manuscripts; Short stories</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 1: Works By Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 405-425

Part 1 Works by Thomas H. Raddall; Books (novels, short stories, histories, memoir, and book edited), pamphlets, audio-visual material, and manuscripts; Short stories  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

     Short Stories

A12     The Pied Piper of Dipper Creek and Other Tales. Foreword Lord Tweedsmuir (John Buchan). Edinburgh: Blackwood, 1939. v-vi, 318 pp.

     Foreword Lord Tweedsmuir (John Buchan). Preface Thomas Raddall. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1943. v-vi, vi, 332 pp.

     Foreword Lord Tweedsmuir (John Buchan). Preface Thomas Raddall. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1946. v-vi, vi, 332 pp. Includes "Before Snow Flies" (B23), "Champeen Liar" (B14), "The Courtship of Jupe M'Quayle" (B20), "Kum-Oo-Je-Ka-Tei, Unlimited" (B21), "Lady Lands Leviathan" (B22), "North" (Bll), "The Pied Piper of Dipper Creek" (B12), "The Proselyting of Mo-Ke-Ne" (B10), "The Road to Fortune" (B17), "The Taming of Mordecai Mimms" (B15), "Tit for Tat" (B8), and "Winter's Tale" (B13).

A13      Tambour and Other Stories. Preface Thomas Raddall. Illus. Stanley Turner. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1945. 3, 388 pp. Includes "The Amulet" (B29), "Bald Eagle" (B43), "Barkip's Railroad" (B16), "Blind MacNair" (B45), "By Any Other Name" (B38), "MacIvor's Salvation" (B34), "The Man from Cap d'Amour" (B24), "North from Vinland" (B44), "The Odour of Sanctity," "On Quero" (B31), "A Petticoat for Linda" (B57), "The Powers of Darkness" (B59), "Reunion at Grand Pre," "Sarker's Folly" (B47), "Sport" (B54), 'Tambour" (B30), "The Trap" (B27), "Triangle in Steel" (B46), and "Winter Idyll" (B52).

A14     The Wedding Gift & Other Stories. Preface Thomas Raddall. [Illus. C.W. Jefferys.] Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1947. v, 325 pp. Includes "At the Tide's Turn" (B35), "Between the Lines" (B25), "By Tellygraft" (B67), "Full Cargo South" (B49), "A Harp in the Willows" (B36), "The Love Moon" (B41), "Memorial to Miss Letty" (B18), "The Outcasts" (B28), "The Passing Show" (B40), "Pax Britannica" (B32), "The Resurrection of Malachi Beld" (B64), "The Siege" (B33), "The Sword of Justice" (B37), "The Trumpeter" (B60), and "The Wedding Gift" (B50).

A15     A Muster of Arms and Other Stories. Preface Thomas Raddall. Illus. Jack Gray. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1954. vii, 236 pp. Includes "The Badge of Guilt," "The Golden Age" (B65), "The Mistress of CKU," "Morale," "A Muster of Arms" (B55), "Naval Honors" "The Pass O'Killiecrankie" (B53), "Resurrection" (B69), "Silk for Lennie" (B62), and "The Whale Killer" (B58).

A16      At the Tide's Turn and Other Stories. Introd. Allan Bevan. New Canadian Library, No.9. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1959. v-ix, 178 pp.

     Braille ed. 5 vols. Toronto: CNIB, 1970. Includes "At the Tide's Turn" (B35), "Between the Lines" (B25), "Blind MacNair" (B45), "By Tellygraft" (B67), "A Harp in the Willows" (B36), "The Passing Show" (B40), "Pax Britannica" (B32), "The Siege" (B33), "The Trumpeter" (B60), "The Wedding Gift" (B50), and "Winter's Tale" (B13).

A17     The Dreamers. Foreword John Bell. Atlantic Classics. Porters Lake, N.S.: Pottersfield, 1986. 5-7, 141 pp. Includes "Brooms for Sale" (B71), "The Credit Shall Be Yours" (B72), "The Dreamers" (B73), "The Drumlin of Joe Tom" (B63), "The Lower Learning" (B26), "The Miracle" (B66), "Mr Embury's Hat" (B42), "The Payoff at Duncan's" (B9), "Swan Dance" (B51), and "Three Wise Men" (B2).

Title:
Part 1 Works by Thomas H. Raddall; Contributions to periodicals and books (short stories, serials, excerpts from novels and histories, reprinted anthology contributions: A selection, articles, reviews, and poems), radio material, and television material; Short stories

Raddall; Contributions to periodicals and books (short stories, serials, excerpts from novels and histories, reprinted anthology contributions: A selection, articles, reviews, and poems), radio material, and television material; Short stories</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 1: Works By Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 405-425

Part 1 Works by Thomas H. Raddall; Contributions to periodicals and books (short stories, serials, excerpts from novels and histories, reprinted anthology contributions: A selection, articles, reviews, and poems), radio material, and television material; Short stories  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

B     Contributions to Periodicals and Books (Short Stories, Serials, Excerpts from Novels and Histories, Reprinted Anthology Contributions: A Selection, Articles, Reviews, and Poems), Radio Material, and Television Material

Note: When an item is reprinted in one of Raddall's books, this fact is noted in the entry through one of the following abbreviations:

At the Tide's Turn and Other Stories -- ATTO

The Dreamers -- Dream.

Footsteps on Old Floors: True Tales of Mystery -- FOF

Hangman's Beach -- HB

In My Time:A Memoir -- IMT

A Muster of Arms and Other Stories -- MAOS

The Nymph and the Lamp -- NL

Ogomkegea: The Story of Liverpool, Nova Scotia -- O:SLN

The Path of Destiny: Canada from the British Conquest to Home Rule 1763-1850 -- PD

The Pied Piper of Dipper Creek and Other Tales -- PPDC

Pride's Fancy -- PF

Roger Sudden -- RS

Tambour and Other Stories -- TOS

The Wedding Gift and Other Stories -- WGOS

The Wings of Night -- WN

      Short Stories

B1     "The Singing Frenchman." Halifax Sunday Leader, 11 Dec. 1921, p. 3.

B2     "Three Wise Men." Maclean's, 1 April 1928, pp. 6-7, 56, 58, 61. Dream.

B3     "The Ghost of Sable Island" Sea Stories, Jan. 1929, pp. 33-39.

B4     "Pounding Brass." Sea Stories, Aug. 1929, pp. 1-9.

B5     "The Pressing of Bowline." Sea Stories, Oct. 1929, pp. 57-62.

B6     "Admiral Togo's Remark." Sea Stories, Dec. 1929, pp. 1-12.

B7     "Captain Moonlight: A Serial of the Crimson Raiders." Excitement, 20 (July 1930), 2-28 (Pt.I); 42-61 (Pt.II); 61-83 (Pt.III); 85-106 (Pt. IV).

B8     "Tit for Tat." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], Sept. 1933, pp. 346-58. PPDC.

B9      "The Pay-Off at Duncan's." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], Sept. 1934, pp. 390-405. Dream.

B10     "The Proselyting of Mo-Ko-Ne." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], March 1935, pp. 289-309. PPDC.

B11     "North." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], July 1935, pp. 123-44. PPDC.

B12     "The Pied Piper of Dipper Creek." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], Oct. 1935, pp. 455-74. PPDC.

B13     "Winter's Tale." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], Jan. 1936, pp.l-17. Rpt. in Fiction Parade and Golden Book Magazine, March 1936, pp. 585-97. Rpt. (condensed -- "Cable to Colonel Gordon") in Reader's Digest [Canada], Dec. 1980, pp. 135-40. PPDC ("Winter's Tale"); ATTO.

B14     "Champeen Liar." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], March 1936, pp. 321-41. PPDC.

B15     "The Taming of Mordecai Mimms." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], July 1936, pp. 1-14. PPDC.

B16     "Barkip's Railroad." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], Nov. 1936, pp. 692-714. TOS (revised).

B17     "The Road to Fortune." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], Dec. 1936, pp. 746-62. Rpt (revised) in Maclean's, 15 Dec. 1939, pp. 10-11, 27-29. Rpt. (revised) in The Atlantic Advocate, Dec. 1965, pp. 39-44, 46-48. PPDC (revised).

B18      "Memorial to Miss Letty." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], March 1937, pp. 303-23. Rpt. in The Crucible, 9, No.1 (Feb.-March 1943), 7-19. WGOS (revised).

B19      "A Matter of History." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], May 1937, pp. 57 5-95.

B20     "The Courtship of Jupe M'Quayle." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], July 1937, pp. 106-24. PPDC.

B21     "Kum-oo-je-ka-tei, Unlimited." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], Sept. 1937, pp.395-413. PPDC.

B22     "Lady Lands Leviathan." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], Dec. 1937, pp. 747-68. PPDC.

B23     "Before Snow Flies." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], March 1938, pp. 298-315. PPDC.

B24     "The Man from Cap d'Amour." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], June 1938, pp. 736-53. TOS (revised).

B25     "Between the Lines." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], Sept. 1938, pp. 309-23. Rpt. (revised -- "The Deserter") in Maclean's, 15 Oct. 1944, pp.16-18, 34, 37-38. WGOS (revised "Between the Lines"); ATTO. See B205.

B26     "The Lower Learning." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], Oct. 1938, pp. 533-49. Dream.

B27      "The Trap." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], Dec. 1938, pp. 768-80. Rpt. in Toronto Star Weekly [Toronto Daily Star], 21 March 1942, pp. 4, 11. TOS (revised).

B28      "The Outcasts." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], Jan. 1939, pp. 22-40. WGOS (revised).

B29      "The Amulet." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], Feb. 1939, pp. 174-85. TOS (revised).

B30   "Tambour." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], May 1939, pp. 581-99. Rpt. (revised) in Maclean's, 1 Jan. 1943, pp. 17-20, 27-29. TOS (revised).

B31      "On Quero." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], June 1939, pp. 843-64. TOS (revised).

B32   "Pax Brittanica." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], July 1939, pp. 36-54. WGOS (revised); ATTO.

B33      "The Siege." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], Aug. 1939, pp. 283-300. Rpt. (revised, abridged) in Maclean's, 1 March 1945, pp. 16-17, 26-27. WGOS (revised); ATTO.

B34   "MacIvor's Salvation." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], Oct. 1939, pp. 550-66. TOS (revised). Raddall gave permission for publication of this story in the Town Crier, a short-lived Halifax "little magazine," on 1 April 1940, but this issue cannot be located. See B208.

B35      "At the Tide's Turn." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], Nov. 1939, pp.624-41. WGOS (revised); ATTO.

B36   "A Harp in the Willows." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], Jan. 1940, pp. 99-115. Rpt. (revised, abridged) in Maclean's, 15 Sept. 1944, pp. 16-17, 35-36, 38. WGOS (revised);ATTO.

B37   "The Sword of Justice." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], Feb. 1940, pp. 239-55. WGOS (revised).

B38   "By Any Other Name." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], April 1940, pp. 424-41. Rpt. in Maclean's, 1 April 1944, pp. 16-17, 22, 24-26, 28. TOS (revised).

B39   "Lupita." Maclean's, 1 June 1940, pp. 5-7, 34-35.

B40   "The Passing Show." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], June 1940, pp. 694-705. WGOS (revised); ATTO.

B41   "The Love Moon." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], July 1940, pp. 71-81. Rpt. (revised) in Maclean's, 1 May 1945, pp. 16-17, 34, 36. WGOS (revised).

B42   "Mr. Embury's Hat." Maclean's, 1 July 1940, pp. 14-15, 28, 30-31. Dream. ("Mr Embury's Hat").

B43   "Bald Eagle 'Iggins." Illus. Floyd Davis. Saturday Evening Post [Philadelphia], 6 July 1940, pp. 14-15, 63, 65, 67-69. TOS (revised -- "Bald Eagle").

B44   "North from Vinland." Maclean's, 1 Aug. 1940, pp. 10-11, 30-33. TOS (revised).

B45      "Blind MacNair." Illus. F.R. Gruger. Saturday Evening Post [Philadelphia], 10 Aug. 1940, pp. 22-23, 71-75. TOS (revised); ATTO.

B46      "Triangle in Steel." Maclean's, 1 Nov. 1940, pp. 7-9, 46, 48-49. TOS (revised).

B47     "Sarker's Folly." Illus. Courtney Allen. Saturday Evening Post [Philadelphia], 4 Jan. 1941, pp. 16-17, 66-68. TOS (revised).

B48     "O'Shannaigh's Wooden House." The Star Weekly [Toronto Daily Star], 28 Jan. 1941, pp. 1, 6.

B49     "Full Cargo South." Illus. Harold von Schmidt. Saturday Evening Post [Philadelphia], 22 Feb. 1941, pp. 12-13,102, 104, 106. WGOS (revised).

B50     "The Wedding Gift." Illus. Amos Sewell. Saturday Evening Post [Philadelphia], 29 March 1941, pp. 20-21, 93-94, 96, 98. Rpt. trans. Armin Arnold ("Das Hochzeitsgeschenk") in Kanadische Erzahler der Gegenwart. Ed. Armin Arnold and Walter Riedel. Zurich: Manesse, 1967, pp. 11-37. Rpt. ("The Wedding Gift") in Reader's Digest [Canada], June 1982, pp. 79-84. WGOS (revised); ATTO. See B206 and B220.

B51     "Swan Dance." Maclean's, 15 April 1941, pp. 14-15, 50-52. Dream.

B52     "Winter Idyll." Illus. Courtney Allen. Saturday Evening Post [Philadelphia], 26 April 1941, pp. 24-25, 44, 46, 49-50. TOS (revised).

B53      "The Pass O'Killiecrankie." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], May 1941, pp. 475-83. Rpt. in Maclean's, 15 Jan. 1944, pp. 16-17, 22, 24, 26. MAOS (revised).

B54      "Sport." Illus. Amos Sewell. Saturday Evening Post [Philadelphia], 26 July 1941, pp.12-13, 37-38, 40. TOS (revised).

B55     "A Muster of Arms." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], Sept. 1941, pp. 177-86. Rpt. (revised -- "Muster of Arms") in Maclean's, 15 Oct. 1943, pp. 8-9, 32, 34-35. MAOS (revised "A Muster of Arms"). See B178.

B56     "Once Upon a Time." Chatelaine, Dec. 1941, pp. 12-13, 60-62, 71.

B57     "Petticoat Pilot." Adventure Magazine, Dec. 1941, pp. 74-83. TOS ("A Petticoat for Linda").

B58     "Lars." Blue Book Magazine, 1942 [issue not located]. MAOS ("The Whale Killer").

B59     "The Powers of Darkness" Maclean's, 15 Jan. 1942, pp. 18-20, 22-23. TOS (revised). See B202, C206, and C210.

B60     "The Trumpeter." Illus. Matt Clark. Saturday Evening Post [Philadelphia], 17 Jan. 1942, pp. 16-17, 38-39, 42. WGOS (revised);ATTO.

B61     "Action at Sea." Collier's, 11 April 1942, pp. 22, 57-58, 60-61.

B62      "Silk for Lennie." Illus. Robert Skemp. Saturday Evening Post [Philadelphia], 2 May 1942, pp. 28-29, 82-85. MAOS (revised).

B63     "The Drumlin of Joe Tom." Adventure Magazine, Canadian Ed., June 1942, pp. 34-43. Dream.

B64   "The Resurrection of Malachi Beld." Blue Book Magazine, 1943 [issue not located]. WGOS.

B65     "The Golden Age." Collier's, 9 Jan. 1943, pp. 11-13, 52-53. MAOS (revised). See C207.

B66     "The Miracle." Saturday Evening Post [Philadelphia], 9 Jan. 1943, pp. 19, 78-80. Dream.

B67   "By Tellygraft." Collier's, 2 Oct. 1943, pp. 15, 51, 53-54. WGOS (revised);ATTO.

B68   "Combined Operations, 1758." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], Nov. 1943, pp. 312-21. This item could be classified as an historical documentary; see B114.

B69     "Three against Death." Maclean's, 1 March 1944, pp. 5-6, 37-39. MAOS (revised "Resurrection"). Originally signed: Robert E. Coffman. This item could be classified as an historical documentary; see B116.

B70   "For Beginners Only." The Writer, 57 (Sept. 1944), 259-61.

B71   "Brooms for Sale." In Wide Open Windows. Ed. Franklin L. Barrett. Toronto: Copp Clark, 1947 [not located]. Dream.

B72      "The Credit Shall Be Yours." Weekend Picture Magazine [The Standard] [Montreal], 16 Oct. 1954, pp. 2-4, 37. Dream.

B73      "The Dreamers." Weekend Magazine [Evening Telegram] [St. John's], 30 July 1955, pp.2-4. Dream.

Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Books, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews and profiles, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Adaptations  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Adaptations

C253   McNair, Rick, adapted. The Words of my Roaring. Dir. Miles Potter. Calgary: Theatre Calgary, 8-27 Jan. 1980. Adapted from Kroetsch's novel of the same title. The cast includes Jack Ackroyd, Sharon Bakker, David Fox, Jim Leyden, Hardee Lineham, Clement Martini, Colin Miller, Valerie Pearson, Patricia Phillips, and Frank C. Turner.

C254   Moher, Frank, adapted. The Studhorse Man. Dir. Paul Thompson. Prod. Theatre Passe Muraille. Toronto: Theatre Passe Muraille, 13 May 1981. Adapted from Kroetsch's novel of the same title. The cast includes Bob Collins, David Fox, John Jarvis, and Mary Vingoe.

C255   Ondaatje, Michael, adapted. "The William Dawe Expedition 1916." Descant, [No.42], 14, No.4 (Fall 1983), 51-73. A screenplay adapted from Kroetsch's novel entitled Badlands.

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Books, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews and profiles, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Articles and sections of books  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Articles and Sections of Books

C5      Wilson, Claudia. "Tidewater Burial: Form and Content to 'Tidewater Burial.'" Clarendon [Harpur College, Binghamton, N.Y.], 15, No.3 (Spring 1964), 16-17. Kroetsch's "Tidewater Burial' contrasts the banality of small-town burial rites with the power and exaltation of ancient rituals found in Beowulf, and accordingly, the language and form used expresses [sic] the antithesis present in the theme."

C6     "Who They? People Being Talked About ... That's Who: Robert Kroetsch." Maclean's, 5 Feb. 1966, p. 4. "... Kroetsch is makinghis Alberta upbringing pay off." In But We Are Exiles, he draws on "his three seasons on the Mackenzie River." Macmillan of Canada has been unusually encouraging. They released his first novel in both London and New York, have agreed to publish his second novel, and are "encouraging him as he works out a third in the early hours before classes each morning."

C7     Jones, D.G. Butterfly on Rock: A Study of Themes and Images in Canadian Literature. Toronto: Univ. of Toronto Press, 1970, p. 163. "Robert Kroetsch's The Words of my Roaring has come out of the west with a buoyant optimism unknown in the novels of [F.P.] Grove or [Sinclair] Ross, the crude vitality of his hero, J.J. Backstrom, shrugging off political, social, marital, and financial problems like a summer shower."

C8     Campeau, DuBarry. "Governor General's Awards: Poets Scoop Up 3 of 6 Prizes." The Telegram [Toronto], 14 April 1970, p. 55. Campeau notes that Kroetsch's The Studhorse Man is among the Governor-General's Award winners and briefly sketches biographical data.

C9     "Heisler Author Wins Gov.-Gen. Award." The Edmonton Journal, 14 April 1970, p. 25. Kroetsch's The Studhorse Man won the Governor-General's Award. Brief biographical data is included.

C1     Sypnowich, Peter. "Poet Wins Literature Award Two Years Ahead of Schedule." Toronto Daily Star, 14 April 1970, p. 34. Sypnowich's title refers to George Bowering, but he also notes that Kroetsch's The Studhorse Man won the Governor-General's Award. Since Robin Mathews suggested that Warren Tallman withdraw from the awards because of his American citizenship, Sypnowich also notes that Kroetsch called Tallman "one of the most brilliant critics in North America."

C11    "Professor Wins Award in Canada." Press [Binghamton,N.Y.], 6 May 1970, p. 16. Kroetsch's The Studhorse Man won the Governor-General's Award. A photograph of Kroetsch is included.

C12    "Albertan-Born Author Receives Award." Albertan [Calgary], 12 May 1970, n. pag. This announcement includes a photograph of the Governor-General's Award winners. Clipping from the Kroetsch Papers, Calgary.

C13    Sutherland, Ronald. Second Image: Comparative Studies in Quebec/Canadian Literature. Toronto: new, 1971, p. 70. Kroetsch's The Words of my Roaring, among other novels, includes "magnificent curses, fullthroated, juicy curses," which, "in the best Calvinist-Jansenist tradition," have "a virulence and intensity all of... [their] own."

C14    New, W.H. "The Studhorse Quests." In his Articulating West: Essays on Purpose and Form in Modern Canadian Literature. [Three Solitudes: Contemporary Literary Criticism in Canada, No. 1 .] Toronto: new, 1972, pp. 179-86. The Studhorse Man "appears as a kind of freewheeling adaptation of Homer's Odyssey," both in plot and characterization. But Kroetsch deliberately subverts the epic convention he employs: "catalogues become breeding lists; epic similes turn into outrageous puns ...; heroic battles descend to vituperative verbal exchanges." The style of the novel "captures the implicit distinction between heroic and ironic possibilities that the book as a whole exposes." But unlike Homer, Kroetsch focuses (like Joyce) on the exile who cannot find his kingdom. In their search, Demeter and Hazard are hampered respectively by art and sexuality: "Both men are the prisoners of their visions .... " The art/ sexuality polarity which defines the novel expresses "an aesthetic credo (form rooted in life, life shaped by artifice) and an analysis of the impact of myth on social structure" Thus the novel "circles over the difference between the spiritual impulse and the artificial fabrication that both go by the name of myth, and the distinction affects both the study of art and the study of history."

C15    Jones, D.G. "Adam's Inventory: Aspects of Contemporary Canadian Literature." In Readings in Commonwealth Literature. Ed. William Walsh. Oxford: Clarendon, 1973, pp. 250-51. The characters, in The Words of my Roaring and The Studhorse Man, "embody from the outset an inclusive view, accepting in themselves both the crude and the refined, the moral and the vital, and affirming themselves and their world with a Homeric gusto that is both physical and spiritual- or perhaps I should say, verbal and sexual." Kroetsch's fictions articulate, in part, "our identity as Canadians, but they point beyond any national character towards an identification with the whole of life, towards what [Northrop] Frye calls the apocalyptic vision of Nature contained in the image of Man."

C16    New, W.H. "The Disappointed Decade." In Readings in Commonwealth Literature. Ed. William Walsh. Oxford: Clarendon, 1973, p. 224. "Political protest is ... [an] extension of ... [the] problem of chaos, and ... [is] characteristic of the 196ffs ..." The psychology of protest is examined in Kroetsch's The Words of my Roaring.

C17    Mandel, Eli. "Romance and Realism in Western Canadian Fiction." In Prairie Perspectives 2. Ed. Anthony W. Rasporich and Henry C. Klassen. Toronto: Holt, Rinehart and Winston, 1973, pp.197-203, 207-11. Rpt. in Another Time. By Eli Mandel. Three Solitudes: Contemporary Literary Criticism in Canada, No.3. Erin, Ont.: Porcepic, 1977, pp. 54-60, 63-67. Mandel discusses The Studhorse Man as a part of the Western Canadian literary tradition which explores myth. "Yet to present the story as myth does not do it justice. For experience, an intensely realized world, plays an extraordinary part in this novel .... " The narrator almost compulsively "insists on turning events into lists, genealogies, catalogues, histories, and more often than not for him the lists gravitate, as his world does, toward a subsuming metaphoric vision, the radical metaphor implied in the title of the book, man as stud horse." Mandel discusses the numerous metaphors in the novel. They "appear even in the hero's name, Lepage, at once 'the page written upon' and a glue label. The label-man, now labelled, is also horse-man (studhorse man), fabulous creature out of a mythic past."

C18    Ricou, Laurence. "Empty as Nightmare: Man and Landscape in Recent Canadian Prairie Fiction." MOSAIC: A Journal for the Comparative Study of Literature and Ideas [Univ. of Manitoba], 6, No.2 (Winter 1973), 156-60. Rpt. ("The Bewildering Prairie: Recent Fiction") in Vertical Man/Horizontal World: Man and Landscape in Canadian Prairie Fiction. By Laurence Ricou. Vancouver: Univ. of British Columbia Press, 1973, pp.133-36. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, Short Story Writers, Filmmakers, Scriptwriters, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Sharon R. Gunton and Jean C. Stine. Vol. XXIII. Detroit: Gale, 1983, 270-71. Ricou considers the relation between landscape and theme in Kroetsch's novels. Kroetsch "articulates new comprehension of the prairie landscape, both embracing the destructive nullity of his environment and defying it by a comic ebullience which celebrates man and life." For Kroetsch, as for W.O. Mitchell, "... the prairie is a landscape of elementals where the primary questions of existence become immediate." Although "Kroetsch's anti-heroes are painfully aware of their isolation in a meaningless world running to waste ...," they escape their anguish "through sheer gusto."

C19    Ross, Morton L. "Robert Kroetsch and His Novels." In Writers of the Prairies. Ed. Donald G. Stephens. Vancouver: Univ. of British Columbia Press, 1973, pp. 101-14. A detailed study of the development of language and point of view in Kroetsch's first three novels. Kroetsch writes with "a verbal energy which is at once remarkable and elusive," an energy generated by his "increasingly keen sense of the difficulties in re-creating experience in language." In But We Are Exiles, the act of piloting the river is a metaphor for Kroetsch's own attempt to "command his narrative raw material." Insofar as the characters are concerned, "... Kroetsch's method seeks to illuminate inner states by a technique akin to [T.S.] Eliot's objective correlative, a reliance on the precise image of external detail to evoke and thus display the equivalent feeling." In The Words of my Roaring, "The creation of Johnnie Backstrom completes the movement from restrained precision as a means of containing experience to more extravagant styles for evoking it." Here, "... the objective order affirmed by techniques of biography is constantly imposed upon and reorganized by expressions of the biographer's own peculiar appetites ...." The novel is "a parable in which Kroetsch deliberately explores once again his own developing conception of the problems, both technical and moral, in capturing the essence of prairie experience in language." Because he demonstrates "how an artist's consciousness may intrude upon, even substitute itself for, his material, Kroetsch signals a shift in his interest from a mimetic to an expressive theory of art."

C20    Strickland, David. "Quotations" from English Canadian Literature. Modern Canadian Library. Toronto: Pagurian, 1973, p. 86. Strickland quotes from The Studhorse Man under the heading "Knowledge."

C21    S[tory]., N[orah]. "Kroetsch, Robert (1927- )." In Supplement to The Oxford Companion to Canadian History and Literature. Ed. William Toye. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1973, pp. 176-77. Story provides a brief overview of Kroetsch's works, up to Gone Indian. The western and northern landscapes are "integral" to the themes. They exert their influence on the "varied" characters. Kroetsch has exceptional versatility and is master of several styles.

C22    Thomas, Peter. "Keeping Mum: Kroetsch's Alberta." Journal of Canadian Fiction, 2, No. 2 (Spring 1973), 54-56. All of Kroetsch's novels actually develop the themes emerging in Alberta. Kroetsch's fiction "has moved progressively away from the realism which so often is, de facto, a 'requirement' of the regional writer." He leads us to myth, to the "urmyth of Creation," while his characters "are all engaged upon a sexual quest for the final, annihilating act in which self is lost." Kroetsch's work is dialectical and "a-historical," resistant to "temporal or spatial frames." He has been influenced by Williams, Olson, and D.G. Jones in his attempt to "locate the-thing-itself as metaphor and myth."

C23    Moss, John G. "Canadian Frontiers: Sexuality and Violence from Richardson to Kroetsch." Journal of Canadian Fiction, 2, No. 3 (Summer 1973), 36-41. But We Are Exiles is a romance in which "... the frontier is the indifferent landscape of an existential parable." As a romance dealing with frontier thought and existence, the novel can be compared to Wacousta, The Atonement of Ashley Morden, or Wild Geese. In these novels (and others) "... perverse or illicit sexuality and the distortion of identity generate the principal conflicts on which they are based." Kroetsch's work presents a "vision of reality confronted by itself, the possessed and the possessor, the   pursued and the pursuer, ultimately are one."

C24    Colombo, John Robert. Colombo's Canadian Quotations. Edmonton: Hurtig, 1974, p. 316. Colombo quotes from The Words of my Roar. ing, Alberta, and Donald Cameron's interview with Kroetsch (C232).

C25    Davey, Frank. "Robert Kroetsch." In his From There to Here: A Guide to English-Canadian Literature since 1960. Vol. II of Our Nature -- Our Voices. Erin, Ont.: Porcepic, 1974, pp. 155-59. "The sense of a fragmentary, chaotic universe which has pervaded so much of Canadian writing since 1960 receives nowhere more powerful expression than in the novels of Robert Kroetsch." His narrative structures "terminate in ambiguity," and characters voyage ambiguously as they search for discovery in an "unknowable environment" of "mythologic" settings. All of the novels "involve a male protagonist in a quest for his own identity and purpose." In But We Are Exiles, "... Guy's quest can end only when he has somehow re-enacted his moment of failure... ," a failure which can be redeemed "only by his lying in the bed of death." In The Words of my Roaring Backstrom's "enormous vitality" propels him "not only to increased self-understanding but to relative invulnerability in an external chaos in which life and death are siblings rather than opposites." Hazard Lepage must "undergo ritual death before his quest can be fulfilled." Similarly, Jeremy Sadness gains his quest for increased sexual potency because he literally does "'rise again' -- becoming at long last able to make love while horizontal." Because death is a "redeemer" rather than a "persecutor' in Kroetsch's fiction, his novels fall outside Margaret Atwood's thesis in Survival: A Thematic Guide to Canadian Literature. Kroetsch's heroes are released from "the paralytic effects of a pragmatic, mechanized culture" into a "green world," "unbridled human sexuality," "meaning," and "joy."
