C26    Moss, John. Patterns of Isolation in English Canadian Fiction. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1974, pp. 39-42. The analysis here is essentially the same as that presented in Moss's earlier article (C23). In But We Are Exiles, "Identity is obliterated by awareness, the future by the present. Exile sought at the periphery of consciousness is a desperate temporary measure with which to withstand oblivion, and doomed to fail."

C27    Gross, Konrad. "Looking Back in Anger? Frederick Niven, W.O. Mitchell, and Robert Kroetsch on the History of the Canadian West." Journal of Canadian Fiction, 3, No.2 (Spring 1974), 49-54. Gross compares Kroetsch's approach to the question of historic tradition with Niven's and Mitchell's. All three "feel the need for a historical tradition," but they are aware of the "shortcomings of the past." In The Studhorse Man, Hazard is "symbolic of the Canadian West, but he is also French-Canadian, the prototype of the white man, and ... of Western man." Like Louis Riel, Hazard's madness is the way to truth. The associations with Riel "emphasize Kroetsch's demands to accept the past, even if it is bleak." As a symbolic reading of The Studhorse Man shows, Kroetsch, unlike Niven, "regards Indian culture as an essential part within the matrix of Canadian reality."

C28    Godard, Barbara. "The Oral Tradition and Contemporary Fiction." The Learned Societies, APFUC, ACQL, and CCLA, Univ. of Toronto, Toronto, Ont. 30 May 1974. Printed in Essays on Canadian Writing, Nos. 7--8 (Fall 1977), pp. 55-59. The Studhorse Man is clearly an attempt "to capture the essential spirit of the oral form." The novel combines "tall tale" and "verbal practical joke" and illustrates "the ironic contrasts of literary and oral traditions, of control and chaos." Hazard Lepage is "a version of the braggadocio hero descended from Sam Slick who affirms himself through his shrewdness and humour." His biographer, Demeter Proudfoot, "avows his own inadequacy: his narrative becomes increasingly broken by the insertion of tales from his own experience within the main narrative thread." Demeter's lying banter illustrates the triumph of the oral tradition within the form of the book. "As storyteller-trickster, Demeter is the means by which the rupture with the rational world is effected for the reader. Through him, ... we are initiated into a wider world than that bounded by logic ... By favouring the category of lying tales, Kroetsch has drawn our attention to the fact that all art is illusory .... It is ultimately in his insistence on the comic powers of language as well as on their magic ones that Kroetsch belongs to the oral tradition he so obviously enjoys."

C29    McCaughy, G.S. "The Studhorse Man: A Madman's View of Canadian History." ACUTE, Queen's Univ., Kingston, Ont. 1973. Printed in Revue de l'Universite d'Ottawa, 44 (juil.-sept. 1974), 406-13. McCaughy examines The Studhorse Man, in historical terms, as a story "built deliberately on the history of Canada." Hazard is "a representative French-Canadian" embodying "a Canadian past." Demeter represents the "Canadian world of the present, never able to grow into the maturity of a participant role." McCaughy supports his view by referring to historical data and incidents.

C30    Thomas, Peter. "Priapus in the Danse Macabre." Canadian Literature, No. 61 (Summer 1974), pp.54-64. Rpt. in The Canadian Novel in the Twentieth Century: Essays from Canadian Literature. Ed. George Woodcock. New Canadian Library, No. 115. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1975, pp.285-97. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Carolyn Riley and Phyllis Carmel Mendelson. Vol. V. Detroit: Gale, 1976, 220-21. A reading of Kroetsch's use of myth and archetype as organizing principles in But We Are Exiles and The Studhorse Man. Considered together, "... Kroetsch's heroes are compulsive actors, doers, drawn into the paradoxes of apocalyptical romanticism, especially in sexual terms." For them, "The drive to freedom is also a quest for death." In his first three novels, Kroetsch's tone shifts from "introspective agony to comic picaresque" as the "priapic hero" is "transformed from the principal in a claustrophobic, inward-turning personal catastrophe, to the fool in a cosmic comedy." The Narcissus myth "provides the central thematic thread of But We Are Exiles." The theme emerges through an interpretation of the Nahanni Jane voyage, a voyage analogous to the movement in Conrad's The Secret Sharer, "The Ancient Mariner," arid Jack Kerouac's On the Road. Like Conrad, Kroetsch emphasizes "the quest for the Other, the river journey motif," and the "theme of freedom-through-mastery" In The Words of my Roaring, the priapic hero becomes comic. "Against Hornyak's consuming triumphs we may now measure Narcissus as anti-hero." Thus the "death-lust of the ego" is expressed comically in Backstrom's profession, paradoxically, as a will-to-live which is a drive-to-death. In The Studhorse Man, "... the sexual theme expresses the life-forcer's will to assert most explicitly." We see the end of a "natural line of progression towards the ultimate, simple, mastering phallus -- symbolic of creative mastery." Although "... Hazard himself expresses the eternal creative rebellion," the creation myth concludes "not with a bang but a whinny." Kroetsch's priapic heroes are seen as "essentially absurd questers compelled by the sensual itch yet denied the consummation they so passionately wish."

C31    Mitcham, Allison. "Northern Mission: Priest, Parson and Prophet in the North: A Study in French and English-Canadian Contemporary. Fiction." Laurentian University Review/Revue de l'Universite Laurentienne, 7, No.1 (Nov. 1974), 27-28. Rpt. ("Northern Mission: Priest, Parson and Prophet in the North") in The Northern Imagination: A Study of Northern Canadian Literature. By Allison Mitcham. Moonbeam, Ont.: Penumbra, 1983, pp. 35-36. A brief examination of the way in which Jeremy Sadness "acquires insight by turning Indian."

C32    New, William H. Among Worlds: An Introduction to Modern Commonwealth and South African Fiction. Erin, Ont.: Porcepic, 1975, pp. 106, 107, 119, 247. In Canada, "... a strong tradition of parody constantly punctures the dream of literary accomplishment." New cites The Studhorse Man as an example of the overriding sense of self-parody in our Jungian society. Kroetsch's "witty Odyssean quest stories, The Studhorse Man (1968) and Gone Indian (1973), tell of the encounter between limited factual reality and a Protean dream ...," a common tension in Canadian literature. Brief bibliographical data is included.

C33    Train, Sylvia. "Musical Groups Introduced at Big Bash." The Toronto Sun, 16 Sept. 1975, p. 24. Train announces that Don Harron is writing a filmscript of The Studhorse Man.

C34    "The Surfacing of Can-Lit: A Weekend with Six Canadian Novelists" West End Courier, 25 Sept. 1975, p. 5. An article about discussions and readings by Canadian novelists, including Robert Kroetsch.

C35    Carpenter, David C. "Alberta in Fiction: The Emergence of a Provincial Consciousness" Journal of Canadian Studies/Revue d'etudes canadiennes, 10, No.4 (Nov. 1975), 13, 21-22, 23. In But We Are Exiles, Alberta "holds out a promise of dramatic fulfillment, even if that promise is ultimately a mirage." Kroetsch, "perhaps Alberta's most distinguished fiction writer to date," "delights in working in exotic dream-like sequences in which the destruction of urban white civilization is accomplished by the victims of his same civilization: Indians, buffalo, horses, social outcasts" This process is also evident in The Studhorse Man and Gone Indian, since, in each novel, "an animal stampede ... disrupts the artificial patterns" of civilization. Kroetsch envisions this rebellion "in outlandishly chaotic scenes" in which the victims "of the technocracy ... symbolically destroy the materialistic society which has raped the wilderness, sullied Eden."

C36    Mandel, Ann. "Useful Fictions: Legends of the Self in Roth, Blaise, Kroetsch, and Nowlan." The Ontario Review, No.3 (Fall-Winter 1975-76), pp. 28-30, 32. Mandel examines literature that explores "that borderline area between autobiography and fiction, between document and legend, between the teller and the tale -- the borderline space where the useful fictions are born and thrive." She considers works "which employ similar technical experiments" and suggests that "... they share common attitudes to history and to art which are especially revealing of what is happening in contemporary Canadian literature and culture." In The Studhorse Man, "...investigation of a past leads the investigator to a confrontation of self or of a body of fate (a place, a person) which reveals and clarifies his own personal history, or changes or conceals it. The method of search is story: a mixture of memory, memoir, document, imagination." Kroetsch is, like many of his contemporaries, "moving the novel towards personal history, away from social man to ... the self writing about itself and its life, creating its own masks through the assumption of style." The novels that Mandel examines move away from traditional views of art, in which "Art is someone else's idea of life. The only useful, fertile art is the progress of one's own life through one's own mind." Mandel echoes Kroetsch's suggestion that "... we don't have an identity until someone tells our story -- 'The fiction makes us real.'"

C37    Bissell, Claude. "Politics and Literature in the 1960s." In Literary History of Canada: Canadian Literature in English. Gen. ed. and introd. Carl F. Klinck. 2nd ed. Toronto: Univ. of Toronto Press, 1976. Vol. III, 9. Bissell classes Kroetsch as a "literary radical." Like bpNichol, Graeme Gibson, bill bissett, Matt Cohen, and Dave Godfrey, Kroetsch is a Postmodernist who emphasizes "discontinuity and a direct perceptual approach" and sees art "as a process in which the reader... [works] with the writer in an uncertain and shifting world, rather than as a finished, ordered product that the reader" understands "and passively" contemplates.

C38    Colombo, John Robert. Colombo's Canadian References. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1976, p. 280.

Brief bio-bibliographical data.

C39    Dahlie, Hallvard. "Kroetsch, Robert (Paul)." In Contemporary Novelists. Ed. James Vinson. 2nd ed. New York: St. Martin's, 1976, pp. 779-80. 3rd ed., 1982, pp. 376-77. Kroetsch's settings are realistic, but "... the fictional situations within these settings are subjected to a mythical transmutation so that the ultimate effect is much closer to allegory than to literal realism." In his novels, we witness "a narcissistic concern with one's identity, the death-rebirth pattern, an obsession with the dead and the dying, the vast, cosmic jokes." In The Words of my Roaring, Gone Indian, and The Studhorse Man, Kroetsch illustrates his "obsession with survival" and his "concern with the sexual force." The Words of my Roaring is more "restricted" than the others since "... it is essentially a parable of ... political upheaval ...." In these novels, Kroetsch successfully welds "the realistic and the surrealistic elements .... But We Are Exiles is the only one of his novels which reflects a tragic vision of life, and in it Kroetsch seems to miss his later broad and flexible vision which allows for an organic fusion between the physical landscape and the inner landscape."

C40    Fee, Margery, and Ruth Cawker. "Kroetsch, Robert 1927- ." In their Canadian Fiction: An Annotated Bibliography. Toronto: Peter Martin, 1976, p. 64. Fee and Cawker include bibliographical data on But We Are Exiles, The Words of my Roaring, The Studhorse Man, and Gone Indian.

C41    "Kroetsch, Robert 1927- ." In Contemporary Authors: A Bio-Bibliographical Guide to Current Authors and Their Works. Ed. Clare D. Kinsman. First Revision. Vols.XVII-XX. Detroit: Gale, 1976, p. 421. Bio-bibliographical data.

C42    New, William H. "Fiction." In Literary History of Canada: Canadian Literature in English. Gen. ed. and introd. Carl F. Klinck. 2nd ed. Toronto: Univ. of Toronto Press, 1976. Vol.III, 261, 268, 279, 280-81, 283. While The Words of my Roaring and The Studhorse Man "concern themselves with political and mythic apprehensions of reality," Gone Indian "records an encounter with the real and imagined landscapes of 'West' -- from romantic stereotyped Indian to Indian vision, from the Canadian, post-Edenic fact to the American transformation of Canada into another Edenic American frontier" resulting in spiritual and physical conflict. Kroetsch's narrative process "utters an alienation of a profound and horrifying kind," and it carries cultural overtones related to those of Margaret Atwood and Dave Godfrey, in the sense that "... a way of saying implicitly establishes a way of knowing ...."

C43    Lotz, Jim. "Generally Speaking ... and Publishing ... in Canada." The Canadian Review, Feb. 1976, p. 32. Lotz discusses problems in the Canadian publishing industry in general and the "Trendsetters" series in particular. Badlands is among the "short stories" which will go right over the heads of most Canadians. In Badlands, "Even if you don't understand it at all levels, the images stay with you ...." It is enjoyable and difficult: an adventure story and an historical novel. Kroetsch's prose and people "linger." He has the ability to sum up the essence of a place or a person in one phrase. Like Martin Myers' Frigate, Badlands is disconcerting to read, but enjoyable. Badlands is complicated, bawdy, and mysterious like the country itself.

C44    "Robert Kroetsch." Medium [Univ. of Lethbridge], 3 Feb. 1976, p. 2. Kroetsch's methods as an author, teacher, and creative artist are described.

C45    Tennenhouse, Esther. "Writer Counting on Seed Catalogues to Inspire Winter Poetry Growth." Winnipeg Free Press, 16 Sept. 1976, p. 17. Kroetsch's position as writer-in-residence and his role at the University of Manitoba, 1976-77, are discussed. Western Canada is "such a machismo world." Tennenhouse provides background information about Kroetsch.

C46    Brown, Russell M., and Donna A. Bennett. "Magnus Eisengrim: The Shadow of the Trickster in the Novels of Robertson Davies." Modern Fiction Studies, 22 (Autumn 1976), 348n., 349, 357. Sheila Watson's explorations of the trickster figure "influenced later writers, most notably Robert Kroetsch who has frequently acknowledged his interest in the trickster and who has made him a central, rather than a secondary, character in his recent novels." As a result, "... the phallus is central to Kroetsch's books ...."

C47    "Robert Kroetsch: Writer in Residence." Manitoban [Univ. of Manitoba], 23 Sept. 1976, p. 4. This announcement that Kroetsch is at the University of Manitoba is accompanied by a photograph of Kroetsch.

C48    Smith, Chris. "Writer-in-Residence Is Friend to Novices." The Tribune, 25 Sept. 1976, p. 45. Smith describes Kroetsch's role as a writer-inresidence at the University of Manitoba. Kroetsch "will visit classes in Canadian Literature, give public readings of his work on campus, discuss writing with vistors, and of course work on the novel and long poem he has started." Kroetsch claims that there is "an oral tradition on the Prairies ... with a lot of visiting and storytelling:' By returning to the Prairies, from Binghamton, New York, Kroetsch has an opportunity "to renew the closeness" with the locale.

C49    "A Little of Narcissus and Goldmund Too." Bulletin [Univ. of Manitoba], 29 Sept. 1976, pp. 1-2. "The tall, thin, aescetic-looking Prof. Kroetsch is carnate proof that the atavistic man and the delicate scholar, the beast and the beauty, can be reconciled within a single individual." This two-fold nature of Kroetsch is reflected by his works in which he "tries to reveal the Canadian consciousness by juxtaposing the rural and the urban, the western Canadian and the eastern Canadian." Kroetsch is a "lover of nature" who places his stories "in a rural setting .... He draws on many true stories of the west to shape the plots for his own stories. Especially prominent in his work are references to Indian legends, myths and symbols." Badlands is "indicative of the kind of surreal episodes to be found in ... [Kroetsch's] writings."

C50    Boughton, Noelle. "Kroetsch Gets Crotchy." Manitoban [Univ. of Manitoba], 13 Oct. 1976, p.8. Kroetsch, the new writer-in-residence, gave a reading which Boughton discusses. His work expresses a rural mythology.

C51    Mathews, Robin. "Le Roman engage: The Social/Political Novel in English Canada." Laurentian University Review/Revue de l'Universite Laurentienne, 9, No.1 (nov./Nov. 1976), 16. Rpt. ("The Social-Political Novel") in Canadian Literature: Surrender or Revolution. By Robin Mathews. Ed. Gail Dexter. Toronto: Steel Rail, 1978, p. 132. "The novels of Robert Kroetsch are the novels of an expatriate, eschewing any serious ideological or political position and moving the U.S. anarchist individualist onto the Canadian landscape as a part of the imperial myth replacement." The social-political novel is "an antiindividualist genre" that is "community oriented." Kroetsch's examination of the self defies Canadian mainstream literature and is a disruptive American process.

C52    Melnyk, George. "Kroetsch: Leaving a Comfortable Exile." Quill & Quire, Nov. 1976, pp. 19-20. Melnyk provides biographical information and comments by Kroetsch on writing and the relation between language and identity. "Kroetsch is a comic writer, a humorist who loves the satirical and the ironic .... The influence of the entertaining fable is prevalent in the raucous, irreverent characters created by Kroetsch ...." For Kroetsch, the comic is serious. He is avant-garde in style and hopes that the "old neo-colonial attitude of using the West just for content would be superseded with advances in form."

C53    "Robert Kroetsch: Canadian Writers Must Try to Capture 'our own voice.'" Manitoban [Univ. of Manitoba], 25 Nov. 1976, pp. 6, 11. This is a brief synopsis of Kroetsch's speech at a colloquium at the University of Manitoba, "Canada: Prospects of a Future." Kroetsch finds "a strange difference between American-English and Canadian-English" and between the ways in which Americans and Canadians see themselves. For Kroetsch, "... the American is so fascinated with seeing himself in the mirror, a new novel is always viewed with great interest ... The Canadian, on the other hand, ... is uneasy of the image of himself and would rather see evil in a foreign land." This contrasting view of self is reflected in the literature of the two countries. In Kroetsch's opinion, "... Americans ... [are] concerned with the solitary hero who... ]confronts] nature and existence on his own." Canadians, Kroetsch explains, "have a tremendous fascination with community. We deal with questions like 'How do I get along with the person next door?'"

C54    Livesay, Dorothy. "Expatriates, Exiles and Some Homebodies." Editorial. CV/ll, 2, No.4 (Dec. 1976), 2. "Robert Kroetsch ... writes out of a deep commitment to the Canadian prairie, in spite of having spent over a decade in the U.S."

C55    Thomas, D.P. "Robert Kroetsch, Rupert Brooke, The Voices of the Dead." Studies in Canadian Literature, 1 (Winter 1976), 124-29. In The Studhorse Man, Gone Indian, and Badlands Kroetsch confronts "the problem of historiography and apocalypse with obsessive insistence" In Gone Indian "... the unconcluded self is a given, viewed neutrally and not, as in Brooke's case, a source of unease." Like Frank Kermode in The Sense of an Ending, Kroetsch expresses "precisely that lack of a sense of an ending, either psychically or temporally." He "seizes Canadian metaphors for their post-modern significance." Kroetsch does not resolve the questions "As to where historiography ends and apocalypse begins," because "... the absurdity of the quest denies the comfort of history and structures in time." Kroetsch is naturally lead "into the myths of re-birth and a flock of thanaturgical imagery." These are fictions "which free us briefly from time." In this sense "Gone Indian and Badlands are of considerable interest in that the narrative technique of both is itself a comment on the temporality of fictional forms."

C56    Blodgett, E.D. "Cold Pastorals: A Prolegomenon." Panel discussion. Canadian Comparative Literature Association. 1977. Printed in Canadian Review of Comparative Literature/Revue canadienne de litterature comparee, 6 (Spring 1979), 181-83, 194. Rpt. ("Cold Pastorals") in Configuration: Essays in the Canadian Literatures. By E.D. Blodgett. Downsview, Ont.: ECW, 1982, pp. 168-71, 181. Kroetsch "may be readily interpreted as abstract .... He wants us to see the world as fiction, for only then do its signs have significance. It is the conscious fictionality of pastoral, paradox as it may appear, that urges the reader to consider some of the unconscious truths of the human situation." Blodgett compares Kroetsch's The Studhorse Man to Antoine Gerin-Lajoie's Jean Rivard, le defricheur, since Lepage is "ever returning to some spiritual Ithaca and the Penelope of memory." Kroetsch "wants the reader to know his work is fictional and not mere mimesis." As a result, Demeter is "a dimension of the protagonist" and the "narrative procedure itself acquires a double design." Demeter reconstructs time in a style that is "at once georgic and sentimental pastoral." Demeter's pasteralism is "a pose,.., the necessary condition of artifice,.., the stylization of desire .... In Kroetsch's novel, order, style, art, and insanity -- no matter how ironic the relationship -- conspire against natural energies and issue in a georgic elegy."

C57    Carpenter, David. Introduction. In Wild Rose Country: Stories from Alberta. Ed. David Carpenter. Ottawa: Oberon, 1977, pp.6-7, 12-17. "... Alberta's mythology.., is haunted by strains of romantic promise and romantic disenchantment." Carpenter cites many of Kroetsch's works to support this view. "The Harvester," for instance, "arises quite naturally out of a provincial milieu where sudden wealth and its attendant commercial value structure are impinging upon people whose values were nurtured in a more humane and pastoral setting." Kroetsch portrays the rural environment, "as ... [he] must have witnessed it in his boyhood, endowed with the kind of rustic heartiness associated with the days when harvesting was done by men, women and horses."

C58    Mandel, Eli. "Atwood Gothic." The Malahat Review, [Margaret Atwood: A Symposium], No.41 (Jan. 1977), pp.171-72. Rpt. in Another Time. By Eli Mandel. Three Solitudes: Contemporary Literary Criticism in Canada, No.3. Erin, Ont.: Porcepic, 1977, p. 142. The question of how to read duplicitous works by Margaret Atwood, Michael Ondaatje, and Robertson Davies is raised again by Kroetsch's "insistent attempt to uninvent the world he wants so desperately to be at home in."

C59    Mitchell, Ken. Preface. In Horizon: Writings of the Canadian Prairie. Ed. Ken Mitchell. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1977, p. x, xi. Prairie writers respond to the landscape and produce literature "that is different in theme, subject, and tone from that of the rest of Canada. For the creative writer the Prairie has become a symbolic place in the geography of the imagination [or an object such as Kroetsch's stone hammer] ... that continues to evoke love and allegiance, as it inspires works of literature."

C60    Moss, John. Sex and Violence in the Canadian Novel: The Ancestral Present. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1977, pp. 7, 10, 26, 38-39, 104-05, 186, 259-60, 274-75, 276-78, 287-98, 307. "Humour in the Kroetsch cosmology means the comic, which for Kroetsch always veils an intensely serious pursuit of self, m terms of both knowledge and possession .... Kroetsch's quest for moral identity ... [speaks] from a side of the Canadian personality too often ignored." Moss closely examines Kroetsch's humour and method in The Studhorse Man, Gone Indian, and The Words of my Roaring. Moss examines the manner in which Kroetsch integrates sexuality as life and death and the narrative/biography style in The Studhorse Man, which is Kroetsch's "most inventive" novel. Gone Indian is a classic novel, "where sexual experience is fully integrated thematically and structurally and which capitalizes beautifully on Freudian cliche by making it the surreal basis of a very traditional search for identity ...." Kroetsch's common themes in these novels are recognized, with "metamorphosis and the struggle toward identity being the most significant." The Words of my Roaring is a statement from "Out West," in which "There is a great deal of passion and compassion ..., sincerity and high-mindedness ...." Yet the novel is also "whimsical and irreverant. Half-way between documentary and parody, a collective identity quest in the guise of a moral dilemma in the form of a quixotic struggle for personal achievement, this novel marks a beginning of some sort, but is no end in itself." Kroetsch works with "felt-ideas, not intellectual schemes" and writes "to communicate ideas, using humour in comic and satiric forms to deliver them forcefully."

C61    Sutherland, Ronald. The New Hero: Essays in Comparative Quebec / Canadian Literature. Toronto: Macmillan, 1977, pp. 27, 85. Kroetsch's Gone Indian illustrates a "new confidence, an escape from the self-consciousness of the young Hugh MacLennan ...."

C62    Woodcock, George. "Possessing the Land: Notes on Canadian Fiction." In The Canadian Imagination: Dimensions of a Literary Culture. Ed. David Staines. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard Univ. Press, 1977, pp. 85, 86, 94-95. Rpt. in The World of Canadian Writing: Critiques & Recollections. By George Woodcock. Vancouver: Douglas & McIntyre, 1980, pp. 30, 31, 38. Robert Kroetsch, Sinclair Ross, Rudy Wiebe, and W.O. Mitchell "have kept the prairies in the centre of Canadian fiction .... the Great Plains have served as a uniting membrane to sustain whatever collective consciousness English-speaking Canada may in fact have." The writing style of the Prairie, "a combination of realistic method and symbolist intent" has become, for writers like Kroetsch, "a kind of super-realistic fantasy." Kroetsch's The Studhorse Man, among other contemporary Prairie novels, introduces "a new sense of history merging into myth, of theme coming out of a perception of the land, of geography as a source of art."

C63    Davis, Melanie. Paper Airplane [Evan Hardy Prairie Writers Collegiate Institute], 8, No. 6 (March 1977), p. 3. Kroetsch attended a Prairie Writers' Workshop. Melanie Davis' pencil portrait of him is reproduced.

C64    Mandel, Eli. "Writing West: On the Road to Wood Mountain." The Canadian Forum, June-July 1977, pp. 26, 27. Rpt. in Another Time. By Eli Mandel. Three Solitudes: Contemporary Literary Criticism in Canada, No.3. Erin, Ont.: Porcepic, 1977, pp. 70, 71. Kroetsch is cited as one of the "many writers 'writing west.'... The gap between culture and nature, the European-American tension, these have been talked about... [by many writers], but for my purpose, [Wallace] Stegner's version of it, like Robert Kroetsch's later account, is the important one because it strikes so close to home, because he writes about the place and language and experience..." Mandel knows.

C65    Lecker, Robert. "An Annotated Bibliography of Works by and about Robert Kroetsch" Essays on Canadian Writing, Nos.7-8 (Fall 1977), pp. 74-96. Primary and secondary bibliographical data up to 1977.

C66    Harrison, Dick. Unnamed Country: The Struggle for a Canadian Prairie Fiction. Edmonton: Univ. of Alberta Press, 1977, pp. xii, 2, 6, 42, 44, 70, 92, 99, 136, 149, 153-54, 182, 183, 184, 185, 187-88, 189, 190, 192, 199, 200, 202, 204, 205-08, 209, 210-12, 213. "As we can see from The Words of my Roaring and The Studhorse Man, Kroetsch is very conscious of the need to dispel ... forms of false or misleading order which have been imposed upon the West." Kroetsch insists that in order to rename the Prairie he must "de-mythologize" the West. "The process of de-mythologizing has, at least initially, a tendency to shred the world back to its original chaos, and Kroetsch has a considerable tolerance for chaos .... for the formless and fecund darkness of the mind." By reducing order to chaos, Kroetsch exposes the insanity of the ordering process. Demeter, the ultimate orderer, who will kill "... his subject for the sake of his art, can be taken as a sardonic comment upon the patterns imposed by novelists, especially prairie novelists .... Despite the danger of a kind of creative nihilism which lurks [behind the demythologizing process], Kroetsch has done much to create the prairie past by drawing its legendary or mythic forms closer to immediate, local experience." Harrison recognizes Kroetsch as an experimental modern writer whose "... novels search out the spirit of the West and the mythology that has attached to it, particularly through the effects of popular fiction and the entertainment media."

C67    Davidson, Arnold E. "Frustrated Sexuality in Robert Kroetsch's The Studhorse Man." The American Review of Canadian Studies, 7, No. 2 (Autumn 1977), 23-32. "... Hazard Lepage, the studhorse man, is a man more laid against than laying, a man whose entanglements are more often an ordeal than an adventure." The Studhorse Man is "not simply the 'passionate and comic celebration of fertility -- in man and beast' that the paperback cover promises. In fact, generative impulses are regularly misdirected or thwarted, and the course of true sex never does run smooth." Davidson traces Hazard's misadventures to find that "The real romance in The Studhorse Man is not between male and female or man and beast but between sex and death .... the two are intertwined throughout the novel." Sexuality is "tied to life and death; part of nature and necessarily imperfect; a force that is regularly sublimated, subverted, misdirected, frustrated; a force for which Hazard's inconclusive career and ambiguous demise provide a summary symbol."

C68    Gnarowski, Michael. "Kroetsch, Robert, 1927- ." In his A Concise Bibliography of English-Canadian Literature. Rev. ed. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1978, pp. 68-69. Bibliographical data.

C69    Mathews, Robin. "John Richardson: The Wacousta Factor." In Canadian Literature: Surrender or Revolution. By Robin Mathews. Ed. Gail Dexter. Toronto: Steel Rail, 1978, p. 23. Rpt. (revised -- "The Wacousta Factor") in Figures in a Ground: Canadian Essays on Modern Literature Collected in Honor of Sheila Watson. Ed. Diane Bessai and David Jackel. Saskatoon: Western Producer Prairie, 1978, pp. 308-09. Kroetsch's Gone Indian is "a latter-day version of [Mark Twain's] Huckleberry Finn." Jeremy Sadness "is an American character following an American quest and deciding that Canada is a frontier." He is a "Wacousta character, a wholly anarchist, individualist, selfregarding American citizen, an idealized hero .... Ironically, Canadians who theorize about community in terms of the idealized Wacousta figure, as Kroetsch does in Gone Indian, have often accepted the social mythology of the United States as 'American,' meaning North American social mythology."

C70    "Robert Kroetsch." In Poetry Goes Public. Canadian Poets on Posters, No. 1. Calgary: n.p., 1978. "... in his books of poetry a character usually seeks and finds the primordial .... In Seed Catalogue, this character is the male principle in pursuit of the female principle as a means of combining the duality that the poet sees as his and our heritage."

C71    Wiebe, Rudy. "The Death and Life of Albert Johnson: Collected Notes on a Possible Legend." In Figures in a Ground: Canadian Essays on Modern Literature Collected in Honor of Sheila Watson. Ed. Diane Bessai and David Jackel. Saskatoon: Western Producer Prairie, 1978, pp. 240, 242-43. In Kroetsch's "Poem of Albert Johnson," Johnson, in his silence, "in his complete emotionlessness ... becomes for Kroetsch the 'poet of survival / to our suburban pain'; by baiting 'their pride' with his own body he becomes 'the poet of our survival.'" Wiebe questions this, since Johnson "was wordless, he was -- is forever, unnamed."

C72    Cameron, Barry. Panelist. The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel, Univ. of Calgary, Calgary, Alta. 16 Feb. 1978. Printed ("Criteria of Evaluation in the Canadian Novel: A Response to Robert Kroetsch") in Essays on Canadian Writing, No. 20 (Winter 1980-81), pp. 19, 21, 26, 27, 28. Rpt. in Taking Stock: The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel. Ed. Charles R. Steele. Downsview, Ont.: ECW, 1982, pp. 21, 23, 28, 29, 30. "Literature ... is, as Robert Kroetsch has said, an unnaming, a demythologizing, a retelling, a reinventing -- destroying, reshaping, the old story to tell the new one -- and even as we invent the writer, the writer invents us, the reader." Cameron refers to Kroetsch's essay "Contemporary Standards in the Canadian Novel" (B124) in order to shape this discussion of critical method and approach. He points out that, for Kroetsch, "... novels are not artifacts concealing or revealing ideas but 'fictional histories' in a Dantean sense signifying ideas, values, and figural relationships ...."

C73    Cameron, Elspeth. Panelist. The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel, Univ. of Calgary, Calgary, Alta. 16 Feb. 1978. Printed in Taking Stock: The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel. Ed. Charles R. Steele. Downsview, Ont.: ECW, 1982, pp. 61, 63. Cameron comments on Kroetsch's essay "Unhiding the Hidden: Recent Canadian Fiction" (Bl14), in which Kroetsch "explored briefly the un-naming, un-covering, un-hiding, both personal and national, which to his mind typifies contemporary Canadian fiction. For a nation overlaid, first as a colony of England, then as an economic satellite of the U.S., this concept is central."

C74    New, William H. Panelist. The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel, Univ. of Calgary, Calgary, Alta. 16 Feb. 1978. Printed in Taking Stock: The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel. Ed. Charles R. Steele. Downsview, Ont.: ECW, 1982, p. 34. New comments on Kroetsch's "Contemporary Standards in the Canadian Novel" (B124) and provides "footnotes to his exploration of the language of understanding."

C75    Tallman, Warren. Panelist. The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel, Univ. of Calgary, Calgary, Alta. 16 Feb. 1978. Printed in Taking Stock: The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel. Ed. Charles R. Steele. Downsview, Ont.: ECW, 1982, p. 40. Tallman dedicates his discussion to Kroetsch, "knowing that lilacs will soon again bloom in the dooryard, and the MacKenzie River once again begin to flow."

C76    Mandel, Eli. "The Regional Novel: Borderline Art." The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel, Univ. of Calgary, Calgary, Alta. 17 Feb. 1978. Printed in Taking Stock: The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel. Ed. Charles R. Steele. Downsview, Ont.: ECW, 1982, pp.ll0, 112, 115, 117, 120. "Kroetsch speaks of regional writing not as a matter of place so much as a matter of what he calls 'voice.' This moves us from mere landscape art to something else in writing, something closer to the shared assumptions of a region, something carried in the folk culture, or the unofficial culture rather than in literary traditions as such. This ... calls for a renewal or revitalization of language through a turn toward spoken rather than written or literary modes. Formally, it calls for a rejection of realism and a reworking of form ...." In The Studhorse Man, Kroetsch allows "structural features of ... [the] work to show, the ribs and skeleton of the novel very deliberately evident."

C77    Watt, Frank. Panelist. The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel, Univ. of Calgary, Calgary, Alta. 17 Feb. 1978. Printed in Taking Stock: The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel. Ed. Charles R. Steele. Downsview, Ont.: ECW, 1982, p. 128. In a discussion of regionalism, Watt points to Kroetsch's Badlands, in which "... one of the members of the expedition looks around and says, 'Where are we?' and William Dawe answers in a phrase that magnificently dramatizes the new regionalism's simultaneous sense of the centrality of its own place, and its complex awareness of what's around .... Dawe answers, 'Asshole of the world.' You can't really find a region more central than that."

C78    Wiebe, Rudy. Panelist. The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel, Univ. of Calgary, Calgary, Alta. 17 Feb. 1978. Printed in Taking Stock: The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel. Ed. Charles R. Steele. Downsview, Ont.: ECW, 1982, p. 129. Wiebe comments that "to see in the Prairie region, in the often slapstick humour of W.O. Mitchell, the ribald irony of Robert Kroetsch, the hoary moroseness of Sinclair Ross, and the warmth and religious quests of Margaret Laurence, anything in common other than the commonality of the human condition, is for me silly."

C79    Ross, Malcolm. "The Ballot." The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel, Univ. of Calgary, Calgary, Alta. 18 Feb. 1978. Printed in Taking Stock: The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel. Ed. Charles R. Steele. Downsview, Ont.: ECW, 1982, pp. 139-40, 141, 147, 152, 153. Kroetsch's The Studhorse Man and The Words of my Roaring are included in the list of Canada's "most 'important' one hundred works of fiction" now in "general use." Badlands is included in the list of works which "run within just one or two points of each other, and in no significant way behind the last twenty of the list of one hundred ...."

C80    Brown, Russell M. "In Search of Lost Causes: The Canadian Novelist as Mystery Writer." MOSAIC: A Journal for the Comparative Study of Literature and Ideas [Univ. of Manitoba], 11, No. 3 (Spring 1978), 4-6. But We Are Exiles uses not only the structure of the detective story but the surface appearance as well. The investigation of Hornyak's violent death slowly unveils the "interactive guilt" of the other characters. The story "resembles a mystery but reverses one convention of the form: rather than gradually removing suspicion from the innocent to reveal the guilt of a single party, But We Are Exiles progressively reveals a complex pattern of interconnected responsibility in which none is free from blame."

C81    Lecker, Robert. "Robert Kroetsch's Poetry." Open Letter, Ser. 3, No.8 (Spring 1978), pp. 72-88. "The process of finding a voice through memory calls for complex movements of unfinding ... 'demythologizing,' 'uninventing,' or 'unnarrating,'" which free the artist to rename. "Only when this re-destructuring activity has begun can meditation come into play, for the subject of meditation is the mystery produced in the act of 'unhiding the hidden.' ... By following ... [Kroetsch's] poetry toward the beginning, we can attempt to see how memory and meditation join to produce song." Lecker discusses Kroetsch's exploration of "the chaos of meaning produced in wedding oppositions" (art as "doubled vision"), the oral tradition and the "importance of uninventing speech ... by uninventing himself as a speaker," storytelling and the "dialectic between perceiver and perceived ... resolved into the synthesizing idea that to be is to perceive," and the location of the milieu of voice. Kroetsch locates the language of place by "replacing ... sounds which have been lost." Through the act of "mythologizing his own identity... Kroetsch begins to realize the visionary power that brings him from memory and meditation into the nexus of song."

C82    Mandel, Ann. "Uninventing Structures: Cultural Criticism and the Novels of Robert Kroetsch." Open Letter, Ser.3, No.8 (Spring 1978), pp. 52-71. "Kroetsch, with his radical belief in man as fictional animal, writes out of that uninventing place, where only the most violent and ceremonious fictions could possibly raise an image from the ground." He sees the empty plain is "an image of absence and potential" from which he argues "against the historical past in favor of fictive present, uncreated past, and reimagined self (inventing the crawl)." For Kroetsch, death is "the creative act which allows a rediscovery of creation ...." His characters must "uninvent" themselves and "return to the source" in order to exist and throw off the "burden of their histories .... Kroetsch's sense of the intolerability of inherited words, thoughts, and history, of systems and traditions pre-existent to the self but not experienced by it ...," surfaces in his novels in which "... the conflict between man's sexual nature and his fear of death is also man's fear of, and devotion to, history." Mandel discusses Kroetsch's novels and poetry and recognizes his "intricate obsessions with sex, death, and rebirth, affirmation through negation, desexualized history contrasted with sexual man, desexualized man with sexual animal, sterile facts and life-giving fictions." His works "parody and defy academic analysis through self-parody, sheer extravagance of language and situation, and a singular yoking of crudity and farce with a sense of 'serious aesthetics.'"

C83    Sullivan, Rosemary. "The Fascinating Place Between: The Fiction of Robert Kroetsch." MOSAIC: A Journal for the Comparative Study of Literature and Ideas [Univ. of Manitoba], [Post-War Canadian Fiction], 11, No.3 (Spring 1978), 165-76. Sullivan analyzes The Words of my Roaring, The Studhorse Man, and Badlands in terms of their binary structures. Kroetsch's "deepest, and most typical dilemma as a writer is how to flesh the form, to prevent the structure from taking over." Kroetsch's fiction conforms to a "structuralist analysis of myth" and "provides us with some very disturbing insights into our ways of ordering experience." For Kroetsch, the urge toward a process of binary discrimination is cultural. "The habit of mind which sees in terms of 'equally matched opposites' lays itself open to the ironic threat of stasis and silence; rather than creative tension, the risk is mutual cancellation, or equally unfortunate, endless repetition." One cannot gravitate toward one side or the other (Coyote/God, Self/Community, Energy/Stasis), but must reside in "the fascinating and safe place between the two." Kroetsch progresses in his novels. The Words of my Roaring features a strong mythic presence and a dichotomous structure, and "... romantic egotism ... comes in for radical scrutiny ...." In The Studhorse Man, the binary structure prevails, but Kroetsch "engages in selfconscious self-parody in his use of myth." In Badlands, Kroetsch "must not only deconstruct myth; he must go all the way and deconstruct the very binary structures that inform his thinking in order to seek genuine meditation."

C84    Djwa, Sandra. "Response: The Fear of Women in Prairie Fiction: An Erotics of Space." Crossing Frontiers, Univ. of Alberta/Idaho State Univ., Banff, Alta. 14 April 1978. Printed in Crossing Frontiers: Papers in American and Canadian Western Literature. Ed. Dick Harrison. Edmonton: Univ. of Alberta Press, 1979, pp. 84-88. Kroetsch's thesis in "The Fear of Women in Prairie Fiction: An Erotics of Space" (B125) "is that Jim Burden of [Willa Cather's] My Antonia and Philip Bentley of [Sinclair Ross's] As for Me and My House are failed writers. They fail because of fear of the woman as muse." Djwa argues against this thesis, pointing out that neither Jim nor Philip are truly failed nor do they suffer any lack of muse. Instead, "... the novels are more complex than the present sexist formula allows ..." and, although Kroetsch's essay is "bracing in style, full of imagistic wit, and fun to listen to," it does not do justice to My Antonia and As for Me and My House.

C85    New, W.H. "Response: The Border League: American 'West' and Canadian 'Region.'" Crossing Frontiers, Univ. of Alberta/Idaho State Univ., Banff, Alta. 15 April 1978. Printed in Crossing Frontiers: Papers in American and Canadian Western Literature. Ed. Dick Harrison. Edmonton: Univ. of Alberta Press, 1979, pp. 127-29. In Kroetsch's Seed Catalogue, "... word and world appear to be one." For Kroetsch, "whose interest is in home more than territory, in energy more than space, the ... distinction [imported from the United States] between the will to deny the land and the desire to be illuminated by the land ... does not end up as an either/or distinction, and he strives repeatedly ... to find a literary means that will sound the paradoxes of his society without becoming culturally reductive, and evoke the fluidity of his private vision without becoming technically abstruse."

C86    Sullivan, Rosemary. "Summing Up." Crossing Frontiers, Univ. of Alberta/Idaho State Univ., Banff, Alta. 15 April 1978. Printed in Crossing Frontiers: Papers in American and Canadian Western Literature. Ed. Dick Harrison. Edmonton: Univ. of Alberta Press, 1979, pp. 149, 154-55. Like Eli Mandel and Leslie Fiedler, Kroetsch explores "the myth of the West," "a narrative defining collective psychology." In "The Fear of women in Prairie Fiction: An Erotics of Space" (B125), Kroetsch demythologizes "the myth that threatens to define him -- the American cowboy myth." He transforms "the romantic, energetic myth into a myth of impotence," a struggle between horse and house. "In Kroetsch's version, woman is the unknown chaos, and man holds on to the known and safe by resisting her."

C87    Harvey, Connie. "Tear-Glazed Vision of Laughter." Essays on Canadian Writing, No.ll (Summer 1978), pp. 28-54. Harvey examines the symbolism, narrative technique, language, and mythic significance in Badlands. She traces William Dawe's journey to the Badlands, to the "inner landscape, a nightmare spiritual world of ... [his] own psyche." Dawe's expedition is a descent to the source, to "a place of unusual reality, of heightened perception." Harvey divides the journey into three parts -- "the downstream journey, the base camp at Deadlodge Canyon and the trip out," each of which suggest a particular phase of the psyche. As she tells her father's story, "... Anna comes to know herself as an individual. Because she refused to accept what her father was, she was possessed and governed by her memory of him and by the masculine part of her psyche." Badlands illustrates the process of individuation of both father and daughter.

C88    Harvey, Roderick W. "The Limitations of Media." Canadian Literature, No.77 (Summer 1978), pp. 20-27. "In The Studhorse Man and Gone Indian, Kroetsch's philosophical position is ambiguous. Both Demeter and Jeremy are limited in their power to communicate, and they seem compelled to explore their respective psyches through the media available to them. One novel is a mock biography, the other is a collection of... tape recordings." Both show Kroetsch's "interest in how the media control us." Demeter and Jeremy are "Gutenberg men" who are trapped, respectively, by print and tapes and "continue to question and rebel against the media."

C89    MacKendrick, Louis K. "Robert Kroetsch and the Modern Canadian Novel of Exhaustion." Essays on Canadian Writing, No.11 (Summer 1978), pp.10-27. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, Short Story Writers, Filmmakers, Scriptwriters, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Sharon R. Gunton and Jean C. Stine. Vol.XXIII. Detroit: Gale, 1983, 272-73. "'The novel of exhaustion' ... [metafiction, fabulation, irrealism, surfiction] describes fiction whose subject is fiction in the making, the creative process in action. It is often manifested in parodic forms and an indulgence in private fantasy which threaten to become precious." The Studhorse Man and Gone Indian "reflect this postmodern approach to the house of fiction." MacKendrick clearly defines and gives numerous examples of "the novel of exhaustion."

C90    Nicolaisen, W.F.H. "Ordering the Chaos: Name Strategies in Robert Kroetsch's Novels." Essays on Canadian Writing, No.11 (Summer 1978), pp. 55-65. "The selected onomastic strategies ... lend substance to ... an interpretation for the artist Robert Kroetsch and his names. When read as a text -- whether as commentary on, or as distilled essence of, the connected discourse in which they are embedded -- the fabric and textual interwovenness reveal the world which he has created. They order the chaotic, vouchsafe the survival of the mind, and in doing so, they serve as a eulogy, a paean to homo nominans -- Man the Namer." Whether real or fictive, Kroetsch's self-conscious naming strategies help him to create a world for, and to enhance his control over, the reader.

C91    Surette, P.L. "The Fabular Fiction of Robert Kroetsch." Canadian Literature, No.77 (Summer 1978), pp. 6-19. Kroetsch "wishes to distinguish his own writing from the tradition of realism, but wishes also to retain some of the connotations of honest-to-god truthfulness that cling irremovably to the term." In the "Out West trilogy," Kroetsch strains against realistic conventions of "plausibility of event," of "character definition in terms of sociological and psychological type," and of "the Aristotelian plot, ... unified and rational action." Through use of "recurring patterns and recurring figures," Kroetsch guides his audience in interpreting his tales. "For in the fabular tradition, the tale is a vehicle of significance, and it is the artist's function to articulate that significance. A tale is not a record of an event, as history, epic, and novella purport to be, but a parable of the human condition, and the parable requires a rubric... [to form a] contextual frame to reveal its significance."

C92    Wood, Susan. "Reinventing the Word: Kroetsch's Poetry." Canadian Literature, No. 77 (Summer 1978), pp. 28-39. In a special issue devoted to Alberta writers, Wood analyzes the quest and analogous search for words of Kroetsch's novels. She focuses on the double search which recurs in Kroetsch's poetry. She offers a helpful commentary on The Stone Hammer Poems: 1960-1975, Seed Catalogue, and The Ledger. Kroetsch "seeks his own roots (which assume national and archetypal significance) and an authentic language appropriate to the reality he discovers."

C93    Tefs, Wayne. "Where Is Your Voice Coming From, Rudy Wiebe." Canadian Dimension, 13, No. 2 ([July] 1978), 51. In an article about Wiebe's regional voice, Tefs notes that Margaret Laurence and Robert Kroetsch "have both demonstrated that meaningful literary experience begins in the details of the here-and-now."

C94    Daniel, Lorne. "Prairie Publishing: A Community Grows." The Canadian Forum, Oct.-Nov. 1978, pp. 31-32. An article about Turnstone Books and other smaller presses across the Prairie Provinces. There are quotations from Kroetsch (from an interview in Arts Manitoba [C235]) about art as a political act. Kroetsch believes in the local. Seed Catalogue sold out within six months. It was enthusiastically reviewed. Eli Mandel called it "the central work of Canadian prairie poetry." There are quotations from Kroetsch at the Crossing Frontiers literary conference in Banff. General information is given about NeWest Press, Tree Frog Press, Peguis Press, and Thistledown Press. There is a general lack of distribution between provinces. Consequently, Daniel concludes the Prairie literary community "currently merely threatens to exist."

C95    "Canadian Literature Coming of Age." Insight [Univ. of Regina], 2, No. 2 (Dec. 1978), 5-6. The article records a discussion between Ken Mitchell and Robert Kroetsch at the University of Manitoba. According to Kroetsch, a country "coming apart" turns to the arts. This is not a new search but, like the ancient Greeks, people are turning to poets and artists in times of crisis. Regional literature flourishes. Kroetsch attributes the success of Western Canadian plays and literature in central Canada to the fascination with the West, a spirit of pioneering.

C96    Harrison, Dick. Introduction. In Crossing Frontiers: Papers in American and Canadian Western Literature. Ed. Dick Harrison. Edmonton: Univ. of Alberta Press, 1979, pp. 3, 6, 7, 9. "... Kroetsch's hero, even when mounted, rides around and around the house which contains the elements of domesticity and stability." In "Fear of Women in Prairie Fiction: An Erotics of Space" (B125), Kroetsch "traces specific mythic motifs in fiction to draw broader cultural inferences about man in the space of the plains." Kroetsch's characters "do not flee to the wilderness but forever approach the desired female in love and fear." Kroetsch compares Sinclair Ross's As for Me and My House to Willa Cather's My Antonia "in their most intimate and characteristic features of narrative structure, form and typical imagery .... Kroetsch's choice of parallel Edenic motifs leads to some unexpected insights ...."

C97    Marshall, Tom. Harsh and Lovely Land: The Major Canadian Poets and the Making of a Canadian Tradition. Vancouver: Univ. of British Columbia Press, 1979, pp. 123-24. Kroetsch "might be cited as a rather special case, a novelist-poet whose novels have become more bizarre as he has taken to writing documentary poems."

C98    Pacey, Desmond. Essays: Canadian Literature in English Ed. and preface A.L. McLeod. Foreword H.H. Anniah Gowda. Powre above Powres, No.4. Mysore, India: Centre for Commonwealth Literature and Research, Univ. of Mysore, 1979, p. 176. Pacey classifies Kroetsch's But We Are Exiles and The Words of my Roaring, "studies of rural life on the prairies," as regional novels. Such novels of the sixties are "often more sophisticated, almost always more realistic and violent, but still recognizably the same genre as flourished in the earlier decades of this century."

C99    French, William. "CanLit's Stout Maples vs. the Tender Trilliums." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 4 Jan. 1979, p. 13. French discusses a Canadian poll conducted by Books in Canada concerning English-Canadian literature. George Bowering praised Kroetsch's Gone Indian.

C100   Sedgwick, Don. "Poet's Revenge." Quill & Quire, Feb. 1979, p. 33. Kroetsch's The Sad Phoenician "is based on a juxtaposition of cliches and includes several lighthearted references to his own work." He was well-received by a capacity audience at the Coach House Press annual literary "bash," called "Revenge of the Big Sonnet," held on 9 December 1978, at Innis College Town Hall, Toronto.

C101   Dragland, S.L. "Questions of Form in Contemporary Canadian Writing." TICS [Univ. of Western Ontario], 1, No.1 (March 1979), 5-6, 14, 22. This article is a record of "a talk introductory to a graduate course ...." Kroetsch's The Ledger and Seed Catalogue are listed among "the most exciting new Canadian writing ...." Dragland also mentions that he "found quite a bit [of work] of interest" in boundary 2, for which he is "quite indebted to [William] Spanos and Kroetsch," the editors. Kroetsch also revived interest in Sinclair Ross's As for Me and My House.

C102   Stanley, Don. "Read poy-ems! Read poy-ems!". Vancouver Express, 21 March 1979, p. A11. This is an article about an ill-fated poetry reading. Margaret Laurence refused to attend. Then Lawrence Ferlinghetti declined to participate. Kroetsch "frowned" and turned "grim." Stanley concludes: "We wouldn't want to know what Kroetsch was thinking."

C103   Wilson, Robert Rawdon. "On the Boundary of the Magic and the Real: Notes on InterAmerican Fiction." The Compass [Univ. of Alberta], No. 6 (Spring 1979), pp. 37-53. "The legendary, the fabulous, the mythic, indeed the whole spectrum of the human marvellous, can be found in Alberta if only one possesses the eyes with which to see .... In Kroetsch's hands Alberta's dullness becomes a surface veneer, a mistake in labelling, or the error of stereotyped perception. Enchanting and fabulous, the marvellous subsurface waits to be revealed." What the Crow Said unearths that subsurface to reveal an "undeniably fabulous" Alberta. The success of the novel "stems from Kroetsch's virtuoso performance in importing some of the salient strategies of South American fiction in order to shape the image of Big Indian." Kroetsch's "... Big Indians, like [Gabriel] Garcia Marquez' Macondians, live in an oral world, isolated, drenched in unskeptical faith and autonomous." Kroetsch fabulates but does not remove the exterior real world. "The novel is cloven upon the disjunction between the claims of the fantasy and the too-well-known outlines of Albertan culture. Kroetsch cannot prevent the technological world from intervening ...." He treads the boundary of the magic and the real.

C104   Fournier, Suzanne. "B.C. Poetry: Off the Page, onto the Stage." Maclean's, 7 May 1979, p. 20f. At a poetry discussion held in conjunction with a seven-part series of poetry readings organized in Vancouver as "a fund-raising effort to help the West Coast literary presses" Kroetsch broke his "painful silence only occasionally." He suggested "During a discussion of sacred and profane poetry.., that the former was to be found only in beer parlors."

C105   Davey, Frank. "The Explorer in Western Canadian Literature." Studies in Canadian Literature, 4, No.2 (Summer 1979), 94-100. Rpt. in Surviving the Paraphrase: Eleven Essays on Canadian Literature. By Frank Davey. Preface Eli Mandel. Winnipeg: Turnstone, 1983, pp. 140-49. In The Studhorse Man, Kroetsch's "treatment of the Odysseus story," the quest "is viewed as absurd and mistaken." Kroetsch's novels, especially Badlands, are models of the Odyssean wanderer. William Dawe is an example of a "wrongheaded, goal oriented" quester. He and the photographer, Sinnott, are "inadequate" explorers "because they ignore time -- Dawe by trying to preserve the dead, . . . Sinnott by photographing the 'vanishing' instant." The "true explorers in Badlands are not any quest-driven men but the two Annas with whom the book ends .... " They are models of Daphne Marlatt's "'continuous present'" and illustrate that the future is not quested for, but "stumbled upon."

C106   Brennan, Brian. "Theatre Calgary Hard at Work Turning Alberta Novel into Play." The Calgary Herald, 22 Dec. 1979, p. C1. Brennan previews the dramatic adaptation of The Words of my Roaring, by Rick McNair (C253). Miles Potter, the director, attempts to maintain "the lusty life of the novel" and to use every necessary technique to attain his goal. Kroetsch attended these rehearsals and provided valuable background for the actors. Kroetsch described his novel to them as a "morality play dealing with the choice between the 'old knowledge' of Murdoch and the 'new energy' of Backstrom."

C107   Barbour, Douglas. Introduction. The Crow Journals. By Robert Kroetsch. Edmonton: NeWest, 1980, pp. 5-10. "Like so many of Kroetsch's fictions, The Crow Journals is a kind of quest, in a kind of labyrinth, & it continually conjugates beginnings & endings. Neither exists fully separate from the other except perhaps in birth & death, & Kroetsch has always been fictionally fascinated by their varied & various conjunctions. But in the very act of putting these 'notes' in order, of making a book out of them & therefore choosing to have a beginning & an ending, Kroetsch also dis/covers a form in which a pattern of intermingled beginnings & endings, endings & beginnings, become meaning-full." Kroetsch's notes are "haphazard, the product not of a deliberate & disciplined attempt to record his own life but rather of a catch-as-catch-can process, written only when he remembered to, or, perhaps more importantly, felt the need to say something about events & situations in his life .... A Journal like this allows us to watch a writer noticing what goes on about & within him. Kroetsch notices & notes: his articulation of his perceptions & speculations provides us with insights into the writing life of one writer; those insights also provoke us to speculate about the whole situation of the artist in Canada today."

C108   Brown, Russell M. "Robert Kroetsch." In Profiles in Canadian Literature. Ed. Jeffrey M. Heath. Vol. II. Toronto: Dundurn, 1980, pp. 97-108. In Kroetsch's works, "There is always a core of authorial experience, an intensely felt, personal starting point providing the initial impetus to the story. This choice of experience from his own past is more than merely personal, however; it is also a kind of political act, an expression of Kroetsch's conviction that the Canadian artist must give some account of his territory, of his region and place." Kroetsch's novels "are given a mythological grounding; each has a subterranean text that grows out of the patterns and allusions introduced into the welter of detail." The author's presence is "vivid," "playful and ironic." He is "engaged in the same struggle as his characters, that of seeking meaning and coherence in apparent chaos." Brown discusses Kroetsch's novels from But We Are Exiles to What the Crow Said, but focuses on the "Out West Triptych," which "is a recapitulation of modern prairie history." Each of the three novels chronicles "an ironic search for some kind of Eden, for a redemption variously sought in political action (Words), in sex and the continuity of the species (Studhorse Man), and in the reclamation of pastoral nature (Gone Indian)." Brown discusses all of the novels in terms of their "mythic grounding" and "intertextuality." He also touches on the poetry, which seeks "to transform the daily objects of rural Canada into the substance of dreams." The poems, like the novels, "have generated their own remarkable mythic version of history which not only stretches from creation to Apocalypse but brings the two events together, showing them to be two aspects of a single universal and ongoing moment." Brown includes a biographical sketch, a list of some of Kroetsch's more illuminating comments, a list of critical comments, and brief bibliographical data. There is also an original draft of "Bear Story with or without Bear" (B53) in the article.

C109   Ritz, Regis. "Fete et defaite de l'ouest canadien dans The Studhorse Man de Robert Kroetsch." Annales du CRAA [Univ. de Bordeaux III], NS No. 6 (1980), pp.177-84. Rpt. in Seminaires 1980. Ed. Jean Beranger, Jean Cazemajon, and Pierre Spriet. Talence: Publications de la Maison des Sciences de l'Homme d'Aquitaine, Univ. de Bordeaux III, 1981, pp. 177-84. In The Studhorse Man, Demeter, "un fou qui se veut biographe omniscient," reflects "la nature et la structure de recit .... Mythes et mythologies, croyances et tabous s'effacent comme s'il s'agissait de revenir A l'essentiel, aux phenomenes" The novel burlesques accepted ideas of Western literature and is based on a Hazard-Ulysses parallel. "The Studhorse Man est un roman ecrit avec brio, avec aisance" and "prenne une valeur universelle .... les dieux qui veillent au destin de Hazard Lepage on perdu leur splendeur olympienne. Leurs forces d'intervention sont reduites a l'instinct animal de l'etalon Poseidon et a la folie creatrice de Demeter-auteur .... Hazard est a la fois hors du temps [myth] et dans le temps [Canadian society] .... Kroetsch-Demeter prend plaisir denoncer ces e1ements de mythes qui appartiennent a la conscience collective de l'homo canadianus et qui son destructeurs de verite" With laughter, Kroetsch systematically denounces "les bienseances sociales, religieuses, semantiques. C'est ainsi que la creation est detournee et qu'elle devient principe destructeur. Le mythe de la science dominatrice reduit l'homme a l'esclavage, annonce le chaos .... C'est donc bien cette juxtaposition du mythe originel de la creation et des mythes historiques de l'alienation qui fair surgir les terribles malentendus de la societe." Demeter contains "les deux principes de fertilite et de mort .... Mais ce qui est autant la reproduction du sexe que la production du texte .... Il devient le prototype de l'ecrivain de l'ouest canadien, empetre dans le realisme historique, incapable de maitriser les referents culturels, les motifs lyriques ou dramatiques que l'ecriture installee lui impose."

C110   Brennan, Brian. "Lovely Literary Creation Disappoints as Limp Piece of Theatre." The Calgary Herald, 9 Jan. 1980, p. B11. Rick McNair's adaptation of The Words of my Roaring (C253) is weak when compared to its source. "Instead of striding onto the stage and thundering and roaring in tune with Kroetsch's robust and energetic novel, this TC production tip-toes hesitantly and self-consciously .... "

C111   Merivale, Patricia. "The Biographical Compulsion: Elegiac Romances in Canadian Fiction." Journal of Modern Literature [Temple Univ., Pa.], 8 (Feb. 1980), 139-41, 142, 143, 146, 149-52. Kroetsch's The Studhorse Man is one of four Canadian novels named" 'elegiac,' in that a first-person narrator is under a sort of biographical compulsion to tell us the story of a person now dead," while assuming ("in varying degrees") a narrative posture that is not ironic. The novels are" 'romances' in that the 'hero' is a little larger and more splendid than the conventions of psychological realism encourage, while the narrator subdues his own characterization to those same conventions." These narratives are essentially duplicitous; their narrators are unreliable. "... Demeter Proudfoot ... [is] the most biographically obsessed, perhaps the most duplicitous, narrator of all." The novels culminate "in an epiphany of personal and/or artistic identity" for the narrator, which is "secular and aesthetic in Kroetsch." The "identity between narrator and hero.., extends to include the author, in a kind of jokester's aesthetic epiphany."

C112   Tivy, Patrick. "Alberta's Finest Country Writer Ready with Novel 7." The Calgary Herald, 1 March 1980, p. D5. Tivy notes Kroetsch's Calgary reading and provides some biographical information. Kroetsch participated in an Ink-Alive reading at Memorial Park Library, Calgary. He read from The Crow Journals.

C113   Blodgett, E.D. "Gardens at the World's End or Gone West in French." Essays on Canadian Writing, No.17 (Spring 1980), p.125. Rpt. (revised, expanded -- "Gone West to Geometry's Country") in Configuration: Essays in the Canadian Literatures. By E.D. Blodgett. Downsview, Ont.: ECW, 1982, pp. 198, 207, 208, 214. In Kroetsch's novels "geographical 'frontiers' possess geometric force," and space connotes psychological dimensions. That space, the Prairie, is the meeting point of "nostalgia" of the past and "technology" of the future. "In ... [Kroetsch's] novels everyone goes west ..., but faster, and certainly more apocalyptically" than in other novels. Blodgett discusses the tape recorder as subtext in Gone Indian and the machine which reduces the past to "immediacy." "Here history becomes a function of technology: it is not lived, it is shelved." Badlands also contains a subtext. It is "read as a modern Odyssey, thus fostering a sense of myth and universality." Kroetsch's novel is linked to a version of history while being a "marvellous parody on the search for roots."

C114   Davidson, Arnold E. "History, Myth, and Time in Robert Kroetsch's Badlands." Studies in Canadian Literature, 5 (Spring 1980), 127-37. Kroetsch is "the one character in Badlands who transcends chronology to achieve the cyclic vision hinted at in the epigraphs. Kroetsch moves forward and backward in time, speaks in many voices, gives us parallel histories, the truth of correspondences, fully human characters, and a setting rich in bones. Perhaps only in such a fiction do we have the real history and the living mythology of the vast and still largely empty Badlands." Kroetsch manipulates time in Badlands. He is "the real historian ..., the true myth-maker, who knows that history, like life, must be fleshed out -- and in -- with marrow and red meat." Kroetsch is "concerned with the process of making -- in both senses of the word -- history." His character, William Dawe, "attempts to create a myth of himself' and his field notes are "aimed at posterity" Anna Dawe is caught up in the confines of time and in a mythic view of her father from which she, by the end of the novel, is freed.

C115   Kostash, Myrna. "Book View." The Edmonton Journal, 3 May 1980, p. I4. This article is about a publication party for The Crow Journals. Kroetsch is a personality, a certified raconteur, with cryptic eloquence about heing a writer. The book shifts between modes of experience like the South American experience, or from High-Modernism to Post-Modernism, in intellectual development.

C116   "Thanks Canada Council: Words of my Roaring Author Gives Reading." Golden Gazette [Field, B.C.], 11 June 1980. One seventh of the town's population attended the reading.

C117   Adamson, Arthur. "Notes from a Dark Cellar: Ruminations on the Nature of Regionalism and Metaphor in Mid-Western Canadian Poetry." Essays on Canadian Writing, Nos. 18-19 (Summer-Fall 1980), pp. 234-36. Rpt. in RePlacing. Ed. Dennis Cooley. [Canadian Perspectives, No.1.] Downsview, Ont.: ECW, 1980, pp. 234-36. Adamson provides a line-by-line analysis of Kroetsch's poem "Snowfall," which "is about the creation of life at the moment which, in the natural world, marks the absolute zero of death: midnight, winter." It "envisages death not as antagonistic to life, but as intrinsic to it ... Kroetsch's poem comes out of a depth which is at the very core of chthonian regional experience."

C118   Arnason, David, Dennis Cooley, and Robert Enright. "Interview with Eli Mandel, March 16/ 78." Essays on Canadian Writing, Nos.18-19 (Summer-Fall 1980), pp.85, 88. Rpt. in RePlacing. Ed. Dennis Cooley. [Canadian Perspectives, No. 1 .] Downsview, Ont.:ECW, 1980, pp. 85, 88. Mandel describes his reaction to Kroetsch's poetry and states that he is compelled to speak out about the works. Kroetsch is an important writer and should be part of 15 Canadian Poets. Kroetsch "has made the biggest effort" to resolve the tension between form and language in Prairie poetry.

C119   Beckmann, Susan A. "Prairie Harvest: A Consideration of Two Anthologies of Prairie Poetry." Essays on Canadian Writing, Nos. 18-19 (Summer-Fall 1980), pp. 192-93, 203. Rpt. in RePlacing. Ed. Dennis Cooley. [Canadian Perspectives, No.1.] Downsview, Ont.: ECW, 1980, pp. 192-93, 203. Beckmann briefly discusses "Old Man Stories (No. 7)" as "a Canadian version of a kind of Icarus myth," "Stone-Hammer Poem" as a "local myth" with universal implications, and "Elegy for Wong Toy" as a lamentation for a "pagan outsider."

C120   Cooley, Dennis. "RePlacing." Essays on Canadian Writing, Nos.18-19 (Summer-Fall 1980), pp.9, 10, 17. Rpt. in RePlacing. Ed. Dennis Cooley. [Canadian Perspectives, No.1.] Downsview, Ont.: ECW, 1980, 9, 10, 17. Cooley includes Kroetsch in a list of prominent prose writers and a list of accomplished poets of the Prairies. He, like Andrew Suknaski, is instrumental in the sounding of "local pride." "The jerk of their vernacular, the outrageous directness in their stories, snap through our poetry."

C121   Thomas, Peter. "Robert Kroetsch and Silence." Essays on Canadian Writing, Nos.18-19 (Summer-Fall 1980), pp.33-53. Rpt. in RePlacing. Ed. Dennis Cooley. [Canadian Perspectives, No.1.] Downsview, Ont.: ECW, 1980, pp. 33-53. "Kroetsch's novels and poems disclose the parody of Narcissus behind the Orphic mask and in the interplay of these symbolisms the poetics of silence is inescapable and central. In his poetry .... Kroetsch addresses fundamental problems of language and selfhood" Kroetsch's use of "dual, paired, or antithetical strategies" in his novels and his poetry "leads him to extreme statements of extreme situations ... Silence not only fascinates, compels, in its perverse eloquence, but appeals to both the Orphic and the Narcissistic." Thomas explores the mythic tensions in Kroetsch's novels and poetry. He closely examines Kroetsch's urge toward silence. "Kroetsch has claimed that 'silence is a terrible temptation to Canadians. Young Canadian writers I meet are terribly tempted just to embrace silence .... Canadians have this terrible fear that they'll look in the mirror and nobody's there.'"

C122   Davidson, Arnold E. "Will the Real R. Mark Madham Please Stand Up: A Note on Robert Kroetsch's Gone Indian." Studies in Canadian Literature, 6 (1981), 135-39. Davidson discusses the juxtaposition of the "old dualities" in Gone Indian, "Kroetsch's most sustained balancing act." Madham and Sadness are characters who reflect the novel's dichotomous structure of professor/student, age/youth, East/West, order/chaos, life/death, freedom/ stasis, beginnings/endings. Davidson notes that, "... the drowned Robert Sunderman has resurfaced as R. Mark Madham." This transition is a "seeming conjunction of seeming opposites ... [which] redefines a number of oppositions in the novel and particularly the central polarity of student versus professor ... the suggested secret past of Professor Madham, a question that is finally unanswerable, ... gives us another structuring polarity in the novel."

C123   Fogel, Stanley. "Lost in the Canadian Funhouse." Queen's Quarterly, 88 (Winter 1981), 692. Rpt. (revised, expanded -- "Cathectic America: Anorectic Canada") in A Tale of Two Countries: Contemporary Fiction in English Canada and the United States. By Stanley Fogel. Toronto: ECW, 1984, p. 26. "... 'The Fabular Fiction of Robert Kroetsch' by P.L. Surette [C91] ... does not place Gone Indian in the framework of the new historical fiction ...."

C124   Goldie, Terry. Introduction. In Violence in the Canadian Novel since 1960/dans le roman canadien depuis 1960. Ed. Virginia HargerGrinling and Terry Goldie. [St. John's: Memorial Univ., 1981], pp. 5-6. Goldie's introductory note explains the content of Kroetsch's paper, "The Exploding Porcupine: Violence of Form in English-Canadian Fiction," and comments that Kroetseh "does violence to the structure of the usual academic paper," suggesting that "... critical reaction to it [the Canadian novel about Canadian violence] must not be static or contained."

C125   Jones, Joseph, and Johanna Jones. Canadian Fiction. Twayne's World Authors Series, No. 630. Boston: Twayne, 1981, pp. 69, 70-71. Kroetsch represents a "possible synthesis of the various viewpoints about the land .... He is ready to use some of the newer, experimental techniques of fiction as well as an extended timespan." The authors include brief bibliographical data and outline the The Words of my Roaring and Gone Indian in order to compare Kroetsch to other Prairie writers.

C126   MacKendrick, Louis K. "Aggression and Form in English-Canadian Literary Comedy." In Violence in the Canadian Novel since 1960/clans le roman canadien depuis 1960. Ed. Virginia Harger-Grinling and Terry Goldie. [St. John's: Memorial Univ., 1981], pp. 68-70. Kroetsch "has been increasingly concerned with literary form, conventional language, and the subversion of these and other received fictional structures at a ground zero of unnaming and rediscovery." In The Words of my Roaring, Backstrom's "language of assault is couched in superhuman terms, and all his actions.., are violently felt." His "thundering biblical oratory and the rhetoric of threat and confrontation" are "intellectual" and "earthly." The "travesty of the Ulysses story" and of epic conventions, in The Studhorse Man, forms a "literary" violence. "But the real story, and its real aggression, is in the growing contest between Hazard's biographer and not only his subject but also the nature of biography. The Studhorse Man is Demeter's story as much as it is Hazard's; biographer turns subject .... In the absence of facts, Demeter attacks Hazard with violations of etiquette and baseless assumptions, and his language often judges and measures his nominal subject invidiously/' In Gone Indian, Kroetsch again "plays with strict literary form" by using imitation and parody. The thematic violence includes "sexual rivalry" and Madham's intrusion on Jeremy Sadness' "experiences, criticizing, paraphrasing, and interpreting without warrant," as well as "Madham's sometimes self indulgent rhetoric."

C127   Mandel, Eli. Preface. In Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch. By Robert Kroetsch. Spectrum Poetry Series. Don Mills, Ont.: General, 1981, pp. [5-8]. "... Robert Kroetsch is a mythical being, a self-created, quite wonderful self-made myth of a man constantly disappearing into his own laughter as his self-made world (yours [the reader's] too) destructs repeatedly .... An articulate theorist of silence, he is a compulsive talker and teller of tales .... His achievements ... have been only partially understood for the simple reason that his aim is evidently to prevent the realization that would complete his project: to keep on talking, writing the poem." Mandel mystifies/mythologies Kroetsch, names the poet, who "may very well be the one Canadian writer who created a literary tradition by destroying it .... You hear Bob Kroetsch telling stories, not writing poems .... The double voice of that comic spiller of tales or speller of kells or teller of spills. The antiphonal endless story of love and death, truth and lies .... everything high is low, everything spiritual gross .... Out of nothing: something. The poem. Continuing."

C128   Monkman, Leslie. A Native Heritage: Images of the Indian in English-Canadian Literature. Toronto: Univ. of Toronto Press, 1981, pp. 141, 148, 151-56. Kroetsch does not "retell the myths and legends of the Indian but instead make[s] elements borrowed from red mythology central to the thematic and structural development of ... [his] novels." The traditional trickster figure becomes an organizing principle in his novels, and is linked in his "Out West" trilogy to "unbridled sexuality." This creates a "focus for all the irrational and chaotic impulses that direct his characters' lives. In ordered communities that take pride in having 'turned Indian trails into highways,' Kroetsch's heroes introduce the disorder identified with the trickster, a figure more and more explicitly associated with the Indian as the trilogy progresses." Monkman's discussion focuses on The Studhorse Man and Gone Indian.

C129   Moss, John. A Reader's Guide to the Canadian Novel. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1981, pp.148-54, 265, 354, 355, 359, 362, 363, 368, 370, 372,373, 374. Moss focuses on The Studhorse Man, Gone Indian, and Badlands. "Motifs in The Studhorse Man echo through the rest of Kroetsch's work: a seemingly puerile obsession with the male sex organ and all the improbable calamities to which it can fall heir, and all the resurrections it can sustain; the coffin or lying-in-state sequence, which gives rise to a different but associated resurrection; the picaresque journey, quest, escape, all of which are the same. Kroetsch's writing suggests no one so much as himself. Thus, while his best is very good indeed, the rest can seem derivative/' Gone Indian has "less emotional impact" than does The Studhorse Man, but "is aggressively sophisticated, intricate and intellectual, an accomplished self-parody." Kroetsch is "readily visible" in the novel. His "creative ingenuity gives the novel its effervescent power, but his gamesmanship ultimately drags it down to the level of clever exercise -- albeit the best of its kind." Badlands is "a strange and splendid work of fiction," "one of the most exhilarating novels ... [Moss has] ever read." The novel's setting and narrative account "participate in the complex explorations of reality .... All parts of this novel serve the whole vision with a coherence of form and meaning not found in Kroetsch's other works."
