Moss includes Kroetsch's novels in numerous categories of the lists which form the lengthy Appendix to his book.

C130   Woodcock, George. "Don Quixote's Dilemma, or, the Future of Fiction." In Canadian Novelists and the Novel. Ed. Douglas Daymond and Leslie Monkman. Ottawa: Borealis, 1981, p. 216. Margaret Atwood, Gwendolyn MacEwen, and Robert Kroetsch show "relevance and promise." These writers "have developed the mythic insights that [Howard] O'Hagan and [Sheila] Watson applied to fiction illuminating the Canadian ambiance."

C131   Grace, Sherrill E. "Wastelands and Badlands: The Legacies of Pynchon and Kroetsch." MOSAIC: A Journal for the Interdisciplinary Study of Literature [Univ. of Manitoba], [Beyond Nationalism: The Canadian Literary Scene in Global Perspective], 14, No. 2 (Spring 1981), 20-34. Grace's comparison of Robert Kroetsch's Badlands and Thomas Pynchon's The Crying of Lot 49 "reveals differences between American and Canadian responses, both to the facts of this continent and to the dream of the West .... The perception of binary opposites is a governing habit of mind .... " and "inheritance, or legacy, of modern Western man, living in the West and confronting the challenge, inconsistency, paradox and failure of the Western dream" is a central theme for both authors. Grace discusses narrative technique, language, concepts of time and space in both novels, but focuses on a comparison of Anna Dawe and Oedipa, Pynchon's character. Anna is a prisoner of time, of her mythic view of her father, and of herself. "Anna's quest, however, is successful and in her very success lies the ironic comment upon William Dawe's 'little ceremony of success' .... Anna inherits fieldnotes, a story, a version of the past, but with this material she reconstructs; she ... orders the scattered information by accepting correspondences instead of truth. Anna frees herself from the dead past, reverses her father's will, turns the Badlands upside down and reaches the source .... she proclaims her freedom from Rapunzel roles and paternal prisons .... "

C132   Graham, Kenneth W. "Picaro as Messiah: Backstrom's Election in The Words of my Roaring." MOSAIC: A Journal for the Interdisciplinary Study of Literature [Univ. of Manitoba], [Beyond Nationalism: The Canadian Literary Scene in Global Perspective], 14, No. 2 (Spring 1981), 177-86. "In The Words of my Roaring .... [Kroetsch] has both used and worked against picaresque conventions of character, narrative and setting not only to capture some of the emotional intensities of prairie life during the Depression, but also to extend the implications of picaresque alienation to embrace the complexities and mysteries of the human condition .... Kroetsch is introducing a concept of the picaro hinted at by Thomas Mann in his Bekenntnisse des Hochstaplers Felix Krull where Mann imparts a shadow of divinity to Felix Krull by encouraging the reader to see in him the outlines of Hermes or Mercurius, the divine Trickster .... Just as the Trickster presides over the potent forces of chaos, so Johnnie, with his speech and his promise of rain, initiates a series of activities of growing unreason .... In the course of the day, Johnnie is forced under the pressure of the desperate longings of his community to exchange the isolation of the picaro for the more intense and responsible isolation of a messiah."

C133   Bentley, D.M.R. "A Stretching Landscape: Notes on Some Formalistic Continuities in the Poetry of the Hinterland." Pt. I. CV/II, 5, No. 3 (Summer 1981), 16. Bentley mentions Kroetsch's Seed Catalogue as part of new Prairie poetry that reflects "'new forms' with which ... experimentation has just begun."

C134   Brown, Russell M. "Crossing Borders." Essays on Canadian Writing, [Canadian-American Literary Relations], No. 22 (Summer 1981), pp. 155, 156, 159-62, 166, 167. "Kroetsch is immensely more optimistic about the act of crossing all those real and imagined borders than are his contemporaries ...." Brown discusses the significance of borders for Canadians and the way in which this concern is articulated by Canadian authors. Gone Indian is an illustration of Canadian's preoccupation with borders. In Gone Indian, "... border crossing is an act which is immediately accomplished and instantly liberating, if still one of heroic daring. Kroetsch's general sense of crossing borders as a risky, yet freeing, investigation of the unknown can be documented in many ... places in his work .... "

C135   van Herk, Aritha. "Desire in Fiction: De-Siring Realism." Dandelion, 8, No.2 (Fall-Winter 1981-82), 33, 36, 37. In Badlands, Kroetsch "de-sires" the conventional view of women as "victims, cripples, betrayers, servants, objects, bitches." The two Annas are "fully realized characters" who counter conventions. Badlands "is one of the few Canadian novels written by a man that allows its women an unlimited scope and range, that lets them be themselves rather than the product of a misogynist society."

C136   Blodgett, E.D. Configuration: Essays in the Canadian Literatures. Downsview, Ont.: ECW, 1982, pp. 34, 92, 106-07. In a discussion of the international aspect of literary influence, Blodgett notes "the same attraction ... for the prose of Gabriel Garcia Marquez" in the works of "Jack Hodgins, Robert Kroetsch, and Michael Ondaatje." Kroetsch is "as much an ambiguity as [Margaret] Laurence ...." He belongs to a "second generation" of Prairie writers who "each in their fashion ... [project[ the female as a stronger figure than in the first generation. Kroetsch's Badlands has even been referred to as a feminist novel." Blodgett also refers to Dick Harrison's argument (C66) "that Kroetsch's novels demonstrate the problem of ambiguity, that is, cultural and colonial interference, most emphatically." Kroetsch "may be said to continue the ethnic question .... in more contemporary terms ...," since one of his "central preoccupations" is questioning whether Canadian Western fiction can be distinguished from American.

C137   Bowering, George. The Mask in Place: Essays on Fiction in North America. Winnipeg: Turnstone, 1982, pp.106, 109, 163. Kroetsch, among others, is cited as a writer in the comic, anti-realist mode of Post-Modernism. Bowering points to the "fantastic communal uplift" at the end of Kroetsch's novels and states that Kroetsch knows "surfiction ... and goes after it with one of his eyes."

C138   Dahlie, Hallvard. Introduction. In Taking Stock: The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel. Ed. Charles R. Steele. Downsview, Ont.: ECW, 1982, pp. 3, 4. Discussing the current status of Canadian literature, Dahlie mentions Kroetsch's "frustrations at being unable to be as confident about his assertions as [F. R.] Leavis was about his." Dahlie states Kroetsch's warning: "'... we are engaged in a kind of pantheon-making among the living. We occupy the most treacherous ground'" See C72-C79 for the papers presented in the conference.

C139   Frye, Northrop. Divisions on a Ground: Essays on Canadian Culture. Ed. James Polk. Toronto: House of Anansi, 1982, pp. 31-32. Frye compares Wilson Harris' Palace of the Peacock to Robert Kroetsch's Badlands and maintains that although "... there is no similarity between them ... certain structural affinities, such as the fold over in time, indicate that they are both products of much the same phase of cultural development."

C140   Lecker, Robert. "Robert Kroetsch, 1927- " In Canadian Poetry. Ed. Jack David and Robert Lecker. Introd. George Woodcock. New Press Canadian Classics. Toronto/Downsview, Ont.: General/ECW, 1982. Vol. II, 289-91. Lecker provides bio-bibliographical information and outlines some major themes and methods used by Kroetsch. "Kroetsch's attraction to doubled experience emerges in his early use of a three-line stanza with split, binary lines." Kroetsch articulates "a prairie-oriented sense of 'local pride' in a 'grammar,' which is Post-Modern and processive, embodies the dialectical tensions central to Kroetsch's work ...." In the long poem form, Kroetsch "finds room for serious narrative play .... At once colloquial, anecdotal, and formally complex, Kroetsch's most involved verse articulates a radical theory of writing in which the poet finds both 'a dispatch of silence' as well as 'the destruction that allows the new.'"

C141   Woodcock, George. "Canadian Poetry: An Introduction to Volume Two." In Canadian Poetry. Ed. Jack David and Robert Lecker. New Press Canadian Classics. Toronto/Downsview, Ont.: General/ECW, 1982. Vol. II, 23. "Robert Kroetsch is as experimental in his verse as in his novels, but in each he remains close to his prairie background, and the sense of vast spaces and of an equally vast if unrecorded background permeates many of his works ...."

C142   Garratt, James. "Toward a New Eden." Letter. Books in Canada, March 1982, pp. 30-31. Garratt objects to what he perceives to be Kroetsch's ultimate belief that man can find no "rest or succour" in nature ("or perhaps anywhere") and his confusion of "'primitivistic longing'" with "the coarsest definition of bestiality" (which he "pretentiously" veils in metaphor). "Robert Kroetsch has indeed written the poetry of nothingness, of lack. [Albert] Moritz, in his review [Dl10], does not hit strongly enough at the facile, nothing-to-say quality of this poetry .... It's time to take the world and shape it with our words and actions toward a new Eden, the garden as it was in the beginning."

C143   O'Brien, T. Peter. "Intimations of Mortality: The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch." McGill Literary Journal, 3, No.2 (Summer 1982), 63-77. "Within the chaotic poetry of Field Notes there is an attempt at reckoning, an attempt at balancing, even if it is only the balancing of random snippets of the world. There is an energy built up within the form, the flutter of movement, the vibrations of the mind, all of which is positioned on the page." Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch is a collection of "notes left to us ... which the wandering archaeologist, the wandering poet, chooses to include in his inventory. The beginning for Kroetsch ... is mid-journey, as one wakes to find oneself in a prairie wheatfield .... the right road wholly lost and gone." The feeling of "lostness" runs throughout the book. There is a movement back to the source, to "the original forest," the "chaos." In the poems, "... orderliness is always in question," and "the distinction between form and formlessness" is always unsure. "There is a volcanic rumbling inside the poetry and one is never quite sure when the eruption will take place. Denotative language becomes detonative." O'Brien questions whether Kroetsch "is content with naming, devoid of conviction .... Kroetsch is able to infuse into his poetry the magic of words, but is not always able to make that next step, to infuse in those words the magic of the world." O'Brien examines each poem in the collection.

C144   Cooley, Dennis. "An Interview with Don Gutteridge." CV/II, 6, No. 4 (Aug. 1982), 42, 48. In this interview with Cooley, Gutteridge says, "I haven't seen too many critical new ideas in some time but Kroetsch's statement about fiction ... [being written] first, and then the poetry, was extremely revealing about the Prairies ... I have always assumed that poetry comes first anywhere ...." Kroetsch's Seed Catalogue is exciting: "The kind of thing that Seed Catalogue has done is an imaginative visual possibility that had never occurred to me: having the shaded materials behind the poems. The first time through I didn't even look at them, I wanted to hear Kroetsch's voice (which really pleased me), and then to go back, read the poems, glance at the material, go over to the side, see what's on the other pages. It's a very gentle way of using the material."

C145   Lecker, Robert. "Bordering On: Robert Kroetsch's Aesthetic" Journal of Canadian Studies, 17, No.3 (Fall 1982), 124-33. Rpt. (revised, expanded) in Robert Kroetsch. By Robert Lecker. Twayne's World Authors Series, No. 768. Boston: Twayne, 1986, pp. 1-21. Kroetsch's concept of borders is instrumental to his aesthetic and, therefore, his works. "Kroetsch sees Canada as a locus of poetic reference, as a dynamic centre of activity which thrives on the tension between extremes." Canada is the "borderland," a home for dialectic process, which Kroetsch "turns ... into a prominent metaphor of poetic structure and intent: naming meets un-naming; creation meets decreation; fabulation meets documentation; form meets anti-form." Kroetsch centres on the meeting point, the "border point at which opposites unite and undergo metamorphosis .... For Kroetsch, the creative act therefore involves a fundamentally duplicitous pursuit -- duplicitous because Kroetsch knows that he must give form to what he recognizes as eminently formless. The contradictions suggest that Kroetsch's poetic is 'about' the paradox of creative choice; it is 'about' the contradictions inherent in the reading/writing process. If we ignore those contradictions -- if we forget Kroetsch's fertile border -- we run the risk of naming an author who, like his tricksters, remains powerfully unnamed."

C146   Ricou, Laurence. "Field Notes and Notes in a Field: Forms of the West in Robert Kroetsch and Tom Robbins." Journal of Canadian Studies, 17, No. 3 (Fall 1982), 117-23. Comparison of Robert Kroetsch's Badlands and Tom Robbins' Even Cowgirls Get the Blues reveals a re-invention of the West "by women and whimsy, by a peculiarly gentle combination of whim and fantasy." Both novels are "extravagent, fanciful, playful, satirical, and bawdy." They are concerned with the myths shaping the country across the forty-ninth parallel. Both novels are written by men about women and parody the old male desire for "'Greater freedom of movement.'" They are "nostalgic for the life of the native Indian," "locate stability in passive, deep Oriental wisdom," and criticize "'Eastern'" values. Badlands is an "aberration even among Kroetsch's Alberta novels" in that it is not "about the daily lives and work and festivities of rural prairie people; rather its concern is a rare scientific adventure, conducted by interlopers." With his Post-Modernist sympathies, Kroetsch "writes toward the minimal novel, toward the point where only enough is given to stimulate the reader to maximum involvement, maximum participation, in the work." He relys on the reader to "complete the composition, on the reader's ability to cherish 'the text not as artefact, but as enabling act. Not meaning, but the possibility of meaning.'"

C147   Conklin, Jamie. "Manitoba Writers Show Up in Force." Quill & Quire, Dec. 1982, p. 13. Conklin briefly discusses the first annual conference of the Manitoba Writers Guild. The growth of Manitoba's artistic community is the result of "'great cultural implications,'" which Kroetsch sees as part of "the shift of power from east to west."

C148   Bennett, Donna. "Criticism in English." In The Oxford Companion to Canadian Literature. Ed. William Toye. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1983, pp. 164, 165, 166. "Kroetsch originally felt that prairie writers ... had to name the as-yet-undefined features of their experience and find myths to give life meaning in the vast and empty prairie landscape." Kroetsch modifies this view, "suggesting that, before naming, Canadian writers must 'unname' ...," they must "demythologize 'the systems that threaten to define them.'" Kroetsch attempts to "establish a grammar of western experience .... " Bennett mentions Kroetsch's discussion with Shirley Neuman and Robert Wilson in their Labyrinths of Voice: Conversations with Robert Kroetsch.

C149   Bennett, Donna, and Russell Brown. "Robert Kroetsch, b. 1927." In An Anthology of Canadian Literature in English. Ed. Donna Bennett and Russell Brown. Vol. II. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1983, 237-38. This biographical sketch of Kroetsch includes brief descriptions of each of his works. Bennett and Brown note that "... while drawing on classical mythology and North American Indian tales, Kroetsch provides his reader with parodies as much as with parallels, creating a blend of comedy and fantasy that marked a new departure in Canadian fiction." Kroetsch's critical essays are also mentioned.

C150   Brown, Russell. "Kroetsch, Robert." In The Oxford Companion to Canadian Literature. Ed. William Toye. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1983, pp. 418-19. Brown briefly sketches bio-bibliographical material and comments on Kroetsch's move "away from realism: by using an exuberantly comic treatment, surreal and fabulous events, and actions in which the mythic level dominates the literal." He discusses Kroetsch's attraction to the "Indian trickster myth" and his urge to deconstruct the novel. Brown comments on Kroetsch's poetry and states that "... it does not use narrative structures but is unified through juxtaposition, repetition, permutation, and voice." Kroetsch's contribution to Canadian literary criticism is recognized. His critical essays are "characterized by an informal voice that is at once playful and oracular."

C151   Davey, Frank. The Contemporary Canadian Long Poem. Island Writing Series. Lantzville, B.C.: Island, 1983. 22 pp. Rpt. ("The Language of the Contemporary Canadian Long Poem") in Surviving the Paraphrase: Eleven Essays on Canadian Literature. By Frank Davey. Preface Eli Mandel. Winnipeg: Turnstone, 1983, pp. 183-93. Davey argues Kroetsch's view of "the energy of the long poem as sexual energy, and delay as postponement of a terminating orgasm." Davey criticizes Kroetsch's "exclusively male perspective" and maintains that the long poem "requires recurring orgasm, movement from surprise to surprise, [and] is prolonged not only to delay but to continue, it anticipates more rather than postpones the most." He discusses many poets' attempts to "replace narrative as the long poem's dominant sign" with a strong sense of place, as in The Sad Phoenician or with "inventiveness, linguistic and narrative adventure, game, jest, and play," as in Seed Catalogue. Poets also use "contemporary subtext," for instance Kroetsch's ledger and seed catalogue, to displace dominant narrative forms. Autobiography is also part of the contemporary long poem. "The sequence of life-events enters the poem, not to become one of its subjects ... but to occasion its images, and to provide some framework for its language." The life-metaphor is "non-romantic" and "low-mimetic" and necessitates a voice that is "oral and personal." Davey cites the poems in Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch as examples of this autobiographical stance.

C152   Hosek, Chaviva. "Poetry in English 1950 to 1982." In The Oxford Companion to Canadian Literature. Ed. William Toye. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1983, p. 666. "Kroetsch is interested in the possibilities of the long poem and of creative alternatives to narrative." Hosek briefly comments on The Stone Hammer Poems: 1960-1975, The Ledger, The Sad Phoenician, and Field Notes I-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch. "His poetry, which transforms personal experience into myth and uses lists of names, places, and objects to celebrate the past, is colloquial, sometimes racy and audacious."

C153   Hoy, Helen. "Kroetsch, Robert (1927- )." In her Modern English-Canadian Prose. Vol.XXXVIII of American Literature, English Literature, and World Literatures in English: An Information Guide Series. Detroit: Gale, 1983, pp. 231-37. Bibliographical data.

C154   "Kroetsch, Robert." Who's Who in Canadian Literature 1983-84 (1983). Bio-bibliographical data.

C155   Mandel, Eli. Preface. In Surviving the Paraphrase: Eleven Essays on Canadian Literature. By Frank Davey. Winnipeg: Turnstone, 1983, p. iii. Mandel commends Kroetsch's attempt to discern "the distinguishing features of the long poem in a brilliant show of dialectical play."

C156   Mitcham, Allison. The Northern Imagination: A Study of Northern Canadian Literature. Moonbeam, Ont.: Penumbra, 1983, pp. 9, 10, 12. Gone Indian is "inspired by the North." Jeremy Sadness "flees northward -- to northern Alberta -- hoping like the legendary Grey Owl to slough off his civilized veneer by becoming Indian."

C157   Olendorf, Donna. "Kroetsch, Robert 1927- ." In Contemporary Authors: A Bio-Bibliographical Guide to Current Writers in Fiction, General Nonfiction, Poetry, Journalism, Drama, Motion Pictures, Television, and Other Fields. New Revision Series. Ed. Ann Evory and Linda Metzger. Vol. VIII. Detroit: Gale, 1983, 299-300. In this biographical sketch, Olendorf also includes a brief description of critical approaches to Kroetsch. She draws from the work of Geoff Hancock (C236), Connie Harvey (C87), Louis K. MacKendrick (C89), Peter Thomas (C30 and C121), and Paul West (D28) in order to discuss But We Are Exiles as "drawn from the ancient myth of Narcissus" and The Studhorse Man as "the Odyssey retold on dry land."

C158   Precosky, Don. Rev. of Labyrinths of Voice: Conversations with Robert Kroetsch, by Shirley Neuman and Robert Wilson. Canadian Book Review Annual: 1982. Toronto: Simon & Pierre, 1983, pp. 232-33. Labyrinths of Voice: Conversations with Robert Kroetsch is "a not-too-well-concealed ego trip" on the part of the three participants. Shirley Neuman, Robert Wilson, and Robert Kroetsch compete to see "Who can quote the most? Who can attempt a synthesis of the most unlikely sources?' The quotations throughout the work are both pretentious and useless additions to the contrived conversation. Preeosky questions whether the discussion was rehearsed "so that they'd all sound as if they'd committed [Roland] Barthes, [Northrop] Frye, and the Russian Formalist school to memory." Precosky suggests that "If you really want to understand Kroetsch better, reread his novels and poems."

C159   Solecki, Sam. "Novels in English 1960 to 1982." In The Oxford Companion to Canadian Literature. Ed. William Toye. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1983, p. 582. "Rejecting realistic characters, linear narrative, and conventional plots, the fabulist creates a fiction of pure contingency, an imagined world in which everything is possible:' Kroetsch, the fabulist, is "self-consciously post-modernist" and is determined "to resist and even reverse the conventions of traditional fiction." His novels portray "a fictional West that owes more to the personal inflections of memory and imagination than to geography and history/' Kroetsch's novels are usually "organized around a quest that has mythic overtones:' They have "obsessed male heroes [who] lead lives that resist, even avoid, community and history because these are synonymous with place and memory, and are therefore repressive." Solecki criticizes Kroetsch for "too-obviously punning" and for lacking a sense "that there is a significance in the characters' actions and thoughts beyond the purely literary and formal one."

C160   Munton, Ann. "On Line." Prairie Fire, 4, No.4 (March-April 1983), 3-4. The article consists of the "somewhat eclectic, impressionistic observations" made by Munton while participating in a University of Manitoba conference entitled "Realignment/Realinement, Narrative in Contemporary Canadian Writing," which was "about the differentiation between poetry and prose" and at which Kroetsch gave a reading. Kroetsch claims that "... even the gods seemingly were caught on different days between poetry and prose."

C161   Davey, Frank. Introduction. In Robert Kroetsch: Essays. By Robert Kroetsch. Ed. Frank Davey and bpNichol. [Open Letter, Ser. 5, No. 4 (Spring 1983)], pp. 7-10. "In terms of the prevailing rhetorics of Canadian and Anglo-American criticism, these are eccentric essays. They are provocations, incitements to read or reread the texts they respond to." They are not "essays that invoke authority .... Kroetsch insists on their discontinuity, constructing them of numbered sections, numbered paragraphs, with only the numbers offering transition .... In this collection... [the archaeological vision] leads Kroetsch to challenge those critical fictions that pose as objective truth (other 'authorized histories') with fictions that announce and celebrate their own partiality."

C162   Munten, Ann. "The Structural Horizons of Prairie Poetics: The Long Poem, Eli Mandel, Andrew Suknaski, and Robert Kroetsch." Dalhousie Review, 63 (Spring 1983), 69-97. Munton notes that regionalism is as much a component of Post-Modernism "as is the concern with structures .... The natural extension is, of course, the long poem form -- a form big enough to encompass such matters ...." Eli Mandel, Andrew Suknaski, and Robert Kroetsch share a strong sense of place and format in the long poem. "They are all vitally concerned with process in poetry, not just with product." These poets are "steeped authentically in the 'language of West'"; they are regional, but not parochial. Munton discusses the history of the long poem in Canada and places Mandel, Suknaski, and Kroetsch in a tradition of longpoem writers with a "renewed sense of place," "memory and mythologized history." She explains the similarities between the three writers and examines each poet on the basis of his poetry's style, structure, language, and sense of place. When discussing Kroetsch, Munton focuses on Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch, which is "clearly autobiographical" and "profoundly regionalist .... Kroetsch goes back in memory ... to discover the appropriate forms and to comment on the process of memory and creativity." Time, in Kroetsch's work, is "uninvented" and memory is the route to discovery of a mythic image. Kroetsch's "exploration of prairie place is an examination of the poet's unconscious, his imagination in the very process of writing." His poetry is tension in process. '"the duplicity that is at the heart of Western Canadian poetics is evident. If subject seems to negate system and questions writing, deconstruction is one structural solution; the long poem, the form."

C163   Ricou, Laurie. "Prairie Poetry and Metaphors of Plain/s Space." Great Plains Quarterly [Univ. of Nebraska], 3 (Spring 1983), 109, 112-13, 115-17. Ricou's intention is "to discuss, by consideration of some persistent metaphors in plains poetry, the displacement and extension of the meaning of words, especially such words as space, place, plains, and prairie." For Kroetsch, poetic form is synonymous with poetic space. He is, like Edward Dorn, "stimulated by absence," which is the" 'fulcrum that's art'" in a place and culture that is not "'too obviously interesting.'"

C164   Conklin, Jamie. Rev. of Labyrinths of Voice: Conversations with Robert Kroetsch, by Shirley Neuman and Robert Wilson. Quill & Quire, April 1983, p. 31. "Kroetsch's erudition, coupled with the quotations that break in upon the interview, suggest a bizarre overabundance of influence." The conversation takes on "two of the dominant characteristics of Kroetsch's fiction: fragmentation and multiplicity .... Despite this inconclusiveness, Kroetsch emerges as a man passionately dedicated to contemporary writing. He dwells upon some key critical concepts (intertextuality, dis/continuity, metalanguage) and offers the best definition of metonymic narrative that I have yet seen .... post-modernism has arrived in western Canada."

C165   MacKendrick, Louis W. "Context, Construct, and Canadian Metafictional Novels." NEMLA, Erie, Pa. April 1983. Printed in The University of Windsor Review, 18, No. 1 (Fall-Winter 1984), 59-60, 61-62. "... Gone Indian (1973)... is a contest of language and lifestyle between a professor and his roving student .... the metafictional quality is inherent within the narrative premise, and is significantly of its development. The actual existence of a character is reduced to the whim of another -- the untrustworthy narrator of much modernist fiction goes beyond verbal expression in actual physical manipulation of primary sources." The Studhorse Man is also metafiction. It is "a masterly contemporary biographical imposture in which the ostensible author completely scrambles the conventions of his nominal genre ...."

C166   Wilson, Paul. "Hybrid Vigour." Rev. of Labyrinths of Voice: Conversations with Robert Kroetsch, by Shirley Neuman and Robert Wilson. Books in Canada, May 1983, pp. 23-24. "Robert Kroetsch writes prose and poetry that are alive with vigorous contending energies. He delights in the details of language and life and his books, with their epic sense of metaphor, convey a vivid experience of the West and the people who live in it." Wilson, however, feels "cheated" by "an almost wilful abstruseness" in Kroetsch's novels. Labyrinths of Voice: Conversations with Robert Kroetsch, as conversation, "fails because the tone is so self-consciously academic" and because "the conversation is continually being interrupted by other 'voices.'" Wilson also objects to the book on the grounds that it "blurs over crucial distinctions between criticism and creation .... When criticism is allowed too much authority, it can usurp the artist's role and start constructing models for artists to follow." Wilson suggests that Kroetsch should "give the artist in him more leeway."

C167   Barbour, Douglas. Rev. of Labyrinths of Voice: Conversations with Robert Kroetsch, by Shirley Neuman and Robert Wilson. NeWest Review, 8, No. 9 (Summer 1983), 16. Labyrinths of Voice: Conversations with Robert Kroetsch is a "provocative, thoughtful, and highly entertaining narrative." Kroetsch is "one of the most self-consciously aware writers around today, fascinated by the theoretical roots of his art." He, Shirley Neuman, and Robert Wilson discuss "the nature of literary influence, the importance of game theory in literature, the uses of myth, and the variety of approaches to the central problem of narration. Throughout the open-ended, yet often circling, questioning of their conversations, the voices of other poets, novelists, and critics interrupt the speech of the three: they illustrate or elaborate, concur or disagree, with what is being said."

C168   Adachi, Ken. "Just a Storyteller Kroetsch Insists." The Toronto Star, 20 Aug. 1983, p. F10. "... Kroetsch insists he's 'just a storyteller, not a post-modernist as some critics like to call me.'" Growing up in a milieu dominated by female family members and their gossip, Kroetsch was "'engrained early in the oral tradition.'" Alibi may be read on several levels: "a picaresque journey, a Christian allegory, an old-fashioned Holy Grail quest." It is "a book for the active reader who must work at it, put something into the process of reading. It's more difficult, in a sense, to be a good reader than a writer."

C169   Lecker, Robert. "Caught in the Balance: Robert Kroetsch's Gone Indian." The American Review of Canadian Studies, 13 (Autumn 1983), 139-56. Rpt. (revised, expanded) in Robert Kroetsch. By Robert Lecker. Twayne's World Authors Series, No. 768. Boston: Twayne, 1986, pp. 61-77. Two integral concerns of Gone Indian are "frontier consciousness" and the "transformative" dynamic of the border. Lecker explores these aspects in relation to the structure and development of the novel. Jeremy, the "trickster," is on a "deconstructive quest ... to peel back the layers of accumulated culture and reveal the name under the name, the self beneath the self he has disguised for a culture thriving on closure -- its own metaphorical death wish .... If he is constantly transformed, it is because he embodies a fictional process which, in Kroetsch's eyes, is by definition transformational." The quest is fulfilled when "those images conventionally defined in terms of opposition" merge. Madham, Jeremy's biographer, "embodies a set of dead narrative conventions," yet discovers, paradoxically, that "his lie becomes life and the only reality worth recording." Lecker concludes by articulating this irony residing at the symbolic and, by extension, the structural heart of the novel: "... to write is to name, to give form, to mythologize; but this very naming process frees the author from his own named stasis. Not to write is to embrace the uninvented, unformed, and pre-literate realm Jeremy seeks; but this process enslaves the author to the stupefying silence of an uninvented realm frozen out of time and space. Kroetsch can't win. He can only win."

C170   Neuman, Shirley. "Allow Self, Portraying Self: Autobiography in Field Notes." Line [Simon Fraser Univ.], No. 2 (Fall 1983), pp. 104-21. "Where contemporary criticism emphasizes the attempt to escape the alienation of the Sells loss in the Other or loss of the Other, Kroetsch feels the need to escape the solipsistic I." In "Stone Hammer Poem" and "How I Joined the Seal Herd," the I is present, but not escaped. "The Sad Phoenician" and "The Silent Poet Sequence" illustrate the dialectic tension between "meaning and meaninglessness." "The Sad Phoenician, the lost man, is the man without language: he speaks in cliche. Because cliche fails to communicate the subjectivity of the speaker, he finally lives silent." The poem's "and/but" sequence of contradiction "can only be the incapacity to act. Its linguistic equivalent is silence. Succumb sufficiently to language and you end up either a poet or speaking in cliche. Resist it sufficiently and you end up silent .... Kroetsch has ... moved from the convention of the poem as speech utterance.., to the idea of the poem as intertext .... That is to take the speech act of talking about oneself and to discover for it one set of writing conventions, to move toward autobiography."

C171   Metcalf, John. "What Happened to CanLit?". The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 19 Nov. 1983, Sec. Literary Supplement, p. [1 ]. In this assessment of Canadian literature, Metcalf questions why good books often fail while boring publications are promoted. He wonders, "Is Robert Kroetsch beginning to flicker?"

C172   Buitenhuis, Peter. "Robert Kroetsch and the De-Mythologising of the Canadian West." Canadian Studies Conference/Conference d'Etudes Canadiennes, Nordic Association for Canadian Studies, Univ. of Aarhus, Aarhus, Denmark. 1984. Printed in Canadiana: Studies in Canadian Literature/Etudes de Litterature Canadienne. Ed. Jorn Carlsen and Knud Larsen. Aarhus, Den.: Dept. of English, Univ. of Aarhus, 1985, pp. 43-50. In The Studhorse Man, Poseidon and Rosinante of Don Quixote "tie into the same myth of inter-dependence of man and horse on the quest for that mystical grail .... Like Arthur's sword, Excalibur, Poseidon arises with his helper from a lake .... But the quest hero is no Arthur... but much more like Sancho Panzo the rogue, the trickster, the self-server. The Don Quixote figure in The Studhorse Man is the mad narrator, Demeter Proudfoot .... Kroetsch has embarked on a triple intent: firstly to demythologise the American frontier west, the ruling dream; secondly to de-mythologise the Garden myth of the Canadian west, and thirdly to de-mythologise the west of the prairie realists [Sinclair Ross, F.P. Grove], set until this time in a slough of puritan despond and sexual repression .... The Studhorse Man is, then, a book which exposes the myths of the west to ridicule and laughter. Yet it is clear that Kroetsch is not deconstructing the western in order to replace it by nihilism or absurdity .... Like [Edgar Allan] Poe, Kroetsch has gone in for a radical act of reseeing his culture. He has attempted to shadow forth a new mythic structure from the figurative forms of the prairie- the shaman, the trickster, the medicine man from Indian legend, as well as by the transformed and ironic avatars of classical myth and literature."

C173   Fogel, Stanley. A Tale of Two Countries: Contemporary Fiction in English Canada and the United States. Toronto: ECW, 1984, p. 6, 18-19, 19-20, 24-25, 31, 32, 125-26. Fogel quotes from Kroetsch's "The Canadian Writer and the American Literary Tradition" (B113) to illustrate that "... Canadians and Americans have had to confront an identical linguistic situation ...." He points out that in this essay, as well as in Kroetsch's prologue to MOSAIC: A Journal for the Interdisciplinary Study of Literature, [Beyond Nationalism: The Canadian Literary Scene in Global Perspective], the question "'Where is here?' " is considered to be "a seminal quest for modern Canadian writers" and "vital to the nineteenth-century American writer." For Kroetsch, "... the search for identity ... [is] paramount ...." Fogel discusses Sherrill Grace's study of Badlands (C131). Kroetsch "writes receptively of the avant-garde ... in the vocabulary of the postmodernist artist and critic .... His sense of the metafictive is apt and incisive, and his own fiction has its radical engagement with traditional forms." Fogel suggests that "... Kroetsch can be seen to be a transitional figure who is alert and receptive to the deconstructive quality of contemporary American literature .... Kroetsch, yoking Canadian and American literary enterprises, has written, 'A reading of the word is at best a misreading of the world.'" Much "of Canadian fiction, except the kind written by Kroetsch .... is clearly British stylistically."

C174   Hancock, Geoff. "Geomantic Romantic: The Pre-historic Art of Robert Kroetsch." Cross-Canada Writers' Quarterly, 6, No. 3 (1984), 8, 32. The contrast between primitive and civilized is prominent in Kroetsch's work but, although "post-modern influences may swirl around in his head, ... in his heart he's just a caveman." Hancock maintains that Kroetsch's use of "prehistoric image patterns" is related to geomancy, "the ancient science of humans in harmony with the visible and invisible worlds about us." Kroetsch is "on an inner journey, perhaps even a spiritual one, and each book departs from traditional behaviour models to evoke a more complex system of cosmic order." Kroetsch's writing is "a recovery of a prehistory transformed for our time." His "recovery of archetypes, our animal and trickster sides, the goddess and feminine within, as well as the dreamworks submerged in our culture are remarkable achievements."

C175   Molnar, Judit. "Quest and Survival in Two Recent Canadian Novels: Position Four." Hungarian Studies in English, 17 (1984), 113-19. In light of Margaret Atwood's Survival: A Thematic Guide to Canadian Literature, Molnar compares Dorf's quest in Alibi to that of L.G. in Sirens and Graces, by Lawrence Garber. Dorf "is on a spiritual quest from the very beginning" He is looking for a spa not only for Deemer but for himself. "He hopes, even if subconsciously, that a kind of rebirth or purification is waiting for him somewhere. His being thirsty is referred to all through the novel, implying a kind of spiritual thirst as well ...." Dorf is on a quest for spiritual healing, and his journal is a means to that end. Dorf reaches Position Four, in Atwood's terms, in that he "finds creation the ultimate end in life .... What ultimately satisfies Dorf is not the spa he has found, called Deadman Spring implying both the creative and the destructive force, but creation, writing .... Kroetsch's and Garber's novels reveal that creation is possible, and that there is hope that 'Position Four' with its possibilities for creative activities is not very far away, at least for the individual."

C176   Stouck, David. Major Canadian Authors: A Critical Introduction. Lincoln, Neb.: Univ. of Nebraska Press, 1984, pp. 273, 287-88, 296. Kroetsch is one of Canada's "more experimental writers" and has been influenced by John Barth and Thomas Pynchon. His novels are "intellectual and self-reflexive in the postmodern manner .... Kroetsch writes about vital but sexually troubled young men whose quest for self-knowledge and creativity are bound up with the complexities of storytelling"

C177   Fogel, Stanley. "Robert Kroetsch and the Canadian Fantastic." Fifth International Conference on the Fantastic in the Arts, Boca Raton, F1. March 1984. Printed (revised, expanded "Robert Kroetsch: Figure of Rapprochements") in A Tale of Two Countries: Contemporary Fiction in English Canada and the United States. By Stanley Fogel. Toronto: ECW, 1984, pp. 73-95. Rpt. (revised, excerpt- "'I See England, I See France...': Robert Kroetsch's Alibi") in Studies in Canadian Literature, 9 (1984), 233-40. "Robert Kroetsch provides an ideal and unique bridge between Canadian and American sensibilities and literary practices." However, "... Kroetsch is acutely aware that the concerns of Canadian writers differ from those of American writers, for the most part because the orientation of the two countries compels such divergent tendencies .... Kroetsch depends on the difference between Canadian and American voices for a good many of his techniques as well as for many of his insights." Fogel discusses Gone Indian, The Studhorse Man, and Alibi in terms of Kroetsch's voice and concern for identity. "Gone Indian is a witty, raucous novel that contains a keen insight into the lure of redefining or recreating a self." The novel illustrates the clash "between a world written out painstakingly and pedantically and an oral preliterate culture .... " Similarly, in The Studhorse Man, "... Kroetsch provides a sense of the state that is dualistic: the attraction of defining a place and the ultimate hollowness of such an activity." Kroetsch names and simultaneously unnames. In Alibi, Kroetsch also engages in this dualistic process. Fogel quotes extensively from Peter Thomas' study (C1) as he examines these novels which are "rich and unsettling because they do not subscribe simplistically either to the strident definition of place or person or to the renunciation of it."

C178   Whiteman, Bruce. The Archive of The Macmillan Company of Canada Ltd.: Part I, 1905-1965 [Library Research News (McMaster Univ.), 8, No. 1 (Spring 1984)], 66, 94. Whiteman lists the Macmillan holdings for Kroetsch and many others.

C179   Adam, Ian. "Narcissus in the Drylands: Autobiography in the Poetry of Two Canadian Prairie Writers." European Association for Commonwealth Literature and Language Studies, Sitges, Spain. 12 April 1984. Printed (revised) in Autobiographical & Biographical Writing in the Commonwealth. Ed. Doireann MacDermott. Sabadell, Barcelona: Depto. de Lengua y Literatura Inglesa, Univ. de Barcelona, 1984, pp. 15-21. The act of autobiography involves the Narcissistic seeking of an image of self, a reflection from a pool. Robert Kroetsch, like Andrew Suknaski, must find a reflection in the dry Prairie, "a minimal iconography." Each writer is confronted by the "ensuing lack of cultural mirrors," which "undermines the autobiographical project." The author's "sense of self' is "relatively unconfirmed and correspondingly uncertain and insecure." Kroetsch's Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch is "very self-consciously antiautobiographical, subverting teleologies of beginnings and endings, cosmologies of order, and ontologies of identity." Death and absence are asserted, while legend and origin are denied. The fragment replaces the linearity of narrative structure. Objects "are used as both starting points and recursive motifs" and become "cultural signs," which fill absences. The "minimal narrative form" suggests "abundance" through use "of rhetoric, of invention, and of Prairie anecdote." There is a voice "countering all of Kroetsch's gestures in undercut conventions and abandoned forms," which suggests "the very opposite of exhaustion." Despite its assertion of absence, the presence of voice breaths life and identity into the poetry.

C180   Arnason, David, Roy Miki, and Frank Davey. Contributors. "The Long Poem: The Cosmology of the Long Poem in Contemporary Canadian Poetry: Discussion" Long-Liners Conference on the Canadian Long Poem, York Univ., Toronto. 29 May-1 June 1984. Printed in Open Letter, [Long-Liners Conference Issue], Ser. 6, Nos.2-3 (Summer-Fall 1985), pp. 85, 86. Arnason notes that, in Seed Catalogue, Kroetsch "does choose a kind of language which would not have been considered poetic in any sense." Miki notes that the "speaking voice" in Seed Catalogue is "the vernacular but it's always being bounced against this wall of place and of document and the text itself. So the context of the text is always limiting that voice from taking off. So it keeps returning on itself as you get into pun ...." Kroetsch "never allows the text as otherness to disappear." The poem assumes "its own history ... outside of the control of the poet and begins to inform the poet." Davey notes that "... perhaps when the poem goes into wordplay as in [Daphne] Marlatt or [bp]Nichol or in Bob's Field Notes, perhaps that's a movement beyond the vernacular. That is, further away from literary language."

C181   Bentley, D.M.R. "'From the Hollow, Blasted Pine': Centrifugal Tendencies in Adam Kidd's The Huron Chief." Long-Liners Conference on the Canadian Long Poem, York Univ., Toronto. 29 May-1 June 1984. Printed in Open Letter, [Long-Liners Conference Issue], Ser. 6, Nos.2-3 (Summer-Fall 1985), pp. 234, 236, 237, 240, 241, 247, 254n., 255n., 256n. Bentley argues that Adam Kidd's The Huron Chief is "A real long poem rather than an ecstactic lyric like [Ezra] Pound's 'Metro' poem, or a greater romantic lyric like Kroetsch's Stone Hammer Poem." Kidd uses "a degree of indeterminacy that is consistent with the centrifugal resistance to enclosure and entrapment of which Kroetsch speaks" and "anticipates such poems as Kroetsch's Field Notes and [Michael] Ondaatje's Billy the Kid." Connections can also be seen with "the Amerindian and archaeological orientation of The Huron Chief and ... Kroetsch's Gone Indian."

C182   Bentley, David, Magdalene Redekop, Dennis Cooley, Russell Brown, Gary Geddes, Smaro Kamboureli, Pamela Banting, Juliet McLaren, Donna Bennett, and Angela Bowering. Contributors. "Locality and the Long Poem: Discussion." Long-Liners Conference on the Canadian Long Poem, York Univ., Toronto. 29 May-1 June 1984. Printed in Open Letter, [Long-Liners Conference Issue], Ser. 6, Nos. 2-3 (Summer-Fall 1985), pp. 278, 279-80, 281, 288, 289, 290, 291, 293, 296, 297. Bentley posits Milton's Paradise Lost and Spenser's The Faerie Queen as the basis for two distinct traditions in the long poem. Kroetsch follows in Spenser's "twenty thousand lines of beginning." Redekop notes that Kroetsch follows in the Romantic tradition established in Wordsworth's Prelude. "The whole of the Prelude ... was like one long letter to Coleridge" Kroetsch addresses "the fear of closure if you dramatize the reader as a friend." Cooley takes exception to this, arguing that Robert Kroetsch and Eli Mandel are "not discovering some mysterious gods or presences particularly," but that the "poem is a poem of absence and an inventing out of that absence" and an "exhilaration, in finding things." Brown notes that "When a Kroetsch or a Mandel deconstructs, what they find at the core is emptiness and absence and so on. And on the one hand, that fits in with a lot of larger traditions, but on the other hand, at least in Kroetsch's poetry, I hear a real anxiety about the absences that he keeps finding." Geddes wonders "Are those people in the Prairies, are they in place, and can they write as if they're in place." Kamboureli argues that Kroetsch and Mandel are "in place and out of place at the same time." Geddes wonders if this kind of long poem "is the exile's poem -- Kroetsch as an exile to the Prairies, going back and never finding it." Brown sees it as "a kind of pun. You're both out of place and writing 'out' of place." Cooley argues that Kroetsch and Mandel create "reflexive" writing that is not as concerned with place as the other, "more referential" writing of Prairie space. Banting notes that place is most evident in Kroetsch's language. "And I think he's tricked you a tiny bit about the absence. I think Kroetsch is more in place than you [Russell Brown] made him out to be." Brown argues that "... the whole point of these 'found' poems in the seed catalogue is to deconstruct them, to take that language as problematic and to find out what lies under that language. So I don't think that language is a comfortable placement either." McLaren raises the issue of "Playing with language, playing with the mind, playing with the real." The "... absences make that exploration possible and don't those gaps make an entrance.., through which one 'plays out' both language and experience?" Brown sees anxiety and play as "two aspects of the same thing .... Kroetsch is always turning fear into merriment." Bennett notes that, for Kroetsch, "... it's not the empty Prairie format, which he experienced, ... but a more and more urban or urbanized culture" and that he is not writing "in an empty world but a crowded one." Geddes notes that in some of Kroetsch's "writings he seems to suggest that the deconstruction is a Canadian phenomenon, that we're always breaking down and trying to begin again." Angela Bowering discusses the importance of photographs and documents in Canadian literature, as in Kroetsch's Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch. These "fragmentary" documents call up "mystery" and "absence."

C183   Bowering, George. "Stone Hammer Narrative."' Long-Liners Conference on the Canadian Long Poem, York Univ., Toronto. 29 May-1 June 1984. Printed in Open Letter, [Long-Liners Conference Issue], Ser.6, Nos.2-3 (Summer-Fall 1985), pp. 131-44. "THIS WILL BE A NARRATIVE OF MY READING OF THE 'STONE HAMMER POEM.' How do you read a Kroetsch, I wondered." Bowering gives a line-by-line commentary of his impressions. "Kroetsch you know is playing ... rock, paper, scissors [with us], and you know what he is doing to the poem with his scissors. But you also know what the rock can do to his scissors (and the hand that holds them)." Bowering examines Kroetsch's games with narrative. "By erasing one gets back to the nothing of beginning, but not really, because the erasure is something, a history of the poem's making. That is the narrative of an alternative to narrative, an attack on the demonstrative." As he reads through the poem, Bowering remarks that "The poet's mind is alternating, as if he cannot get narrative into gear, or as if he does not want to, as if he wants to continue rather than arrive at his stop" Kroetsch achieves a sense of timelessness, a sense that the poem and the stone are part of ages past and ages yet to come. The poem advances from the ice age through time and "... suggests that all retreating here will be recreating." Notation in the poem is used by Kroetsch "to the advantage that his words, gerunds and others, do double duty, acting as more than one part of speech .... For this poet the stone is a muse's tool that teases him further than the cycles of the ice ages, all the way to the dying sun, past Robert Frost's fire and ice metaphysic, to the most universal of seasons .... The stone, given that cosmic field, is made of an original element, as was the buffalo blood, as is the poet himself. Sometimes the archaeologist stops looking at the losses that are his occupation, and writes, field notes, not for this stone hammer but for that."

C184   Brown, Russell. "On Not Saying Uncle: Kroetsch and the Place of Place in the Long Poem." Long-Liners Conference on the Canadian Long Poem, York Univ., Toronto. 29 May-1 June 1984. Printed in Open Letter, [Long-Liners Conference Issue], Ser.6, Nos.2-3 (Summer/Fall 1985), pp. 257-66. In Seed Catalogue, Kroetsch's poem of "'the home place,'" Kroetsch faces the problems of the Prairie. The West "is a giant and mostly empty space that confronts him and that he seeks to respond to, to give account of, to account for .... On what tradition can the Canadian westerner draw.., without falsifying, that is, the roots of his own art?" This question is fundamental to Seed Catalogue and Kroetsch's attempt to "grow a poet." The poet in the West cannot find a muse or draw on memories. "Memory is a problem not only because history is brief in the West (especially in the Canadian West), and not only because there are no native muses there -- that is, no regional tradition for the poets of the long poem -- but also because the past that is there, the history that seems to exist is falsifying." Prairie history is, as Kroetsch has said, "an imported past, an alien tradition cast in a language that seems our own but is not, or not fully." This loss of history is for the poet both "freeing" and "frightening." The poet, Kroetsch, is threatened by the silence and emptiness of the Prairie. He must reach an "understanding that what appears to be negative may turn out also to be positive... 'the home place,' ... 'the double hook.'" In Seed Catalogue, Kroetsch shows "us the roots of his art on the Prairies, the way that his environment provides the seeds of stories to the Prairie writer." For the poet who does not "say uncle," the Prairie and its absences become fertile sources of creativity.

C185   Brown, Russell, and George Bowering. Contributors. "Alternatives to Narrative: Discussion:' Long-Liners Conference on the Canadian Long Poem, York Univ., Toronto. 29 May-1 June 1984. Printed in Open Letter, [Long-Liners Conference Issue], Ser. 6, Nos. 2-3 (Summer-Fall 1985), p. 158. Brown notes that, in "Stone Hammer Poem," "While there are small narrative elements, it's trying to put them together in a non-narrative structure that works against the tense relationship." Bowering comments that "Bob's problem about erasure is that all erasure is additive. You add another line to the poem every time you erase the previous one." Brown notes that this creates a "narrative of erasure."

C186   Davey, Frank. "Countertextuality in the Long Poem." Long-Liners Conference on the Canadian Long Poem, York Univ., Toronto. 29 May-1 June 1984. Printed in Open Letter, [Long-Liners Conference Issue], Ser. 6, Nos.2-3 (SummerFall 1985), pp. 33, 37, 40. Kroetsch's Seed Catalogue exemplifies the use of "surreal" metaphors to create "multiple, coexistent truths" and, like other long poems, contains "other documents," which suggest "poetry as oxymoronically true," rather than "scientifically true." Contrarily, in Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch, "... the countertextual goal can be to write out of the absence of documents

C187   Geddes, Gary. "Going the Distance." LongLiners Conference on the Canadian Long Poem, York Univ., Toronto. 29 May-1 June 1984. Printed in Open Letter, [Long-Liners Conference Issue], Ser. 6, Nos.2-3 (Summer-Fall 1985), pp. 169, 170, 174, 175, 176n. Although Geddes is "sympathetic to those poets who wish to try alternatives to sequential narration, ... [he] cannot take seriously their statements to the effect that story-telling is somehow aesthetically and morally reprehensible." This "hesitation, the fear, and ... the impotence" is "essential Puritanism." Kroetsch "tries to delimit the poet's function by disallowing the very freedoms he takes in his novels... though any reader of these wonderful creations might detect a high component of bullshit, international or otherwise, as the poet tries to create/discover and project an image of his 'real' self." Geddes draws similarities between E.J. Pratt's Towards the Last Spike and Kroetsch's Seed Catalogue to demonstrate that the techniques and preoccupations are not all that new.

C188   Mandel, Eli. "The Death of the Long Poem." Long-Liners Conference on the Canadian Long Poem, York Univ., Toronto. 29 May-1 June 1984. Printed in Open Letter, [Long-Liners Conference Issue], Ser. 6, Nos. 2-3 (Summer-Fall 1985), pp. 11, 15, 17, 21, 22. Kroetsch's conception of the long poem "as writing" challenges "the ideas of structure, in which ease form ... must be an illusion .... Frank Davey and Robert Kroetseh have written brilliant, provocative essays, that reveal the long poem as a process of renewal that works by violating our expectations of continuity and completion .... Kroetsch ... is... ruthlessly discontinuous ...."

C189   Miki, Roy. "The Lang Poem: The Cosmology of the Long Poem in Contemporary Canadian Poetry." Long-Liners Conference on the Canadian Long Poem, York Univ., Toronto. 29 May-1 June 1984. Printed in Open Letter, [Long-Liners Conference Issue], Ser. 6, Nos.2-3 (SummerFall 1985), pp. 71-72, 80, 84n. In Kroetsch's "deconstructive reading," in Seed Catalogue, "... silence is the effect of writing, a way of giving back to words the negativity that speech, trapped as it is by the ephemerality of its occasion, cannot offer. The implication is that silence ... is itself a source which makes speech possible. Writing words down then becomes a kind of descent to the ground of language where the creative binds itself to creation."

C190   Munton, Ann. "The Long Poem as Poetic Diary." Long-Liners Conference on the Canadian Long Poem, York Univ., Toronto. 29 May-1 June 1984. Printed in Open Letter, [Long-Liners Conference Issue], Ser. 6, Nos. 2-3 (Summer-Fall 1985), pp. 93, 94, 95, 96-97, 98, 102, 105n. "The creators of contemporary poetic journals ... have much in common .... they are explorers, often attempting to understand themselves and their place through travel, mapping their consciousnesses. They share a renewed sense of their roots, and their travel often takes them back in their own and their ancestors' pasts .... Relationship to a parent is often crucial .... Patterns are thus important, the parallels outside of chronology being more significant than any purely sequential ordering in time. The journal form is, of course, self-reflexive, and the division between writer and written is no longer rigid. Valuing synchronicity, writers now assume the fictive nature of reality. Experimentation is key, with the relationship of all questions to language perhaps the most common bond between these writers." The Crow Journals "is unique in that Kroetsch makes the distinction of publishing his journals quite separately from his other writing .... Kroetsch's entries are sequential but certainly not daily, and themselves reflect many different forms .... Kroetsch now works, sometimes subversively, to reverse language's powers for concealment." Kroetsch is "directed by maps," but concentrates on "the writing process" and "contact with fellow writers. He takes journeys, travelling in time and space ...."

C191   Wah, Fred. "Making Strange Poetics." LongLiners Conference on the Canadian Long Poem, York Univ., Toronto. 29 May-1 June 1984. Printed in Open Letter, [Long-Liners Conference Issue], Ser. 6, Nos. 2-3 (Summer-Fall 1985), pp. 214, 215-16, 218-19, 221n. Kroetsch "views the impulse toward the long poem as a resistance to end .... By placing ... seemingly complete and 'contained' poems as part of an open-ended 'continuing poem' Kroetsch is providing a continuity for a larger, more intangible structure called Field Notes ...." The "device of avoiding full recognition has become a necessity to the long-poem writer at the level of cadence .... The pleasure of anticipated cadence is a prime factor in Kroetsch's ... The Sad Phoenician ...."

C192   Loverso, Marco P. Rev. of Canadian Novelists and the Novel, ed. Douglas Daymond and Leslie Monkman; and MOSAIC: A Journal for the Interdisciplinary Study of Literature, [Beyond Nationalism: The Canadian Literary Scene in Global Perspective], 14, No.2 (Spring 1981). English Studies in Canada, 10 (June 1984), 245, 246-47, 249-50. Kroetsch believes that writers must "'uninvent the world'" and that there is an oral tradition in recent Canadian fiction. Loverso comments on Kroetsch's prologue in the special issue of MOSAIC: A Journal for the Interdisciplinary Study of Literature, [Beyond Nationalism: The Canadian Literary Scene in Global Perspective] (B133), in which Kroetsch focuses "on the connection between the writer and the world .... In conveying this connection, Canadian writing is, as Kroetsch sees it, essentially genealogical." Kroetsch is concerned with "the problem of definition. He sees the Canadian hero as one who might seek Eden, ... who might seek a beginning place, but who cannot find an easy definition." In conclusion, Loverso discusses Kenneth W. Graham's "Picaro as Messiah: Backstrom's Election in The Words of my Roaring" (C132), an "insightful essay, which convincingly shows how Kroetsch takes an established literary genre and 'un-invents' it ... to conform to the Canadian cultural experience."

C193   Lecker, Robert. "Letters in Canada: 1983. Humanities" Rev. of Labyrinths of Voice: Conversations with Robert Kroetsch, by Shirley Neuman and Robert Wilson. University of Toronto Quarterly, 53 (Summer 1984), 468-69. Kroetsch supports "a poetics of process" and asserts "that 'postmodern writers' are involved in a 'virtual mocking of the exegetical act' while at the same time arguing that 'Criticism is really a version of story ....'" He "shuns those 'answers' that announce the product-oriented stance," yet carries with him numerous "models of traditional narrative forms." Labyrinths of Voice: Conversations with Robert Kroetsch is an "open-ended, serious/playful sourcebook that allows us to understand some of the many ways in which Kroetsch has fictionalized himself into becoming a "'magister labyrinthorum' -- the man we think we know as one of Canada's most important writers."

C194   Lewis, Robert W. "Four Books Canadian." Rev. of MOSAIC: A Journal for the Interdisciplinary Study of Literature [Univ. of Manitoba], [Beyond Nationalism: The Canadian Literary Scene in Global Perspective], 14, No.2 (Spring 1981); Major Canadian Authors: A Critical Introduction, by David Stouck; Labyrinths of Voice: Conversations with Robert Kroetsch, by Shirley Neuman and Robert Wilson; and Understanding Canada: A Multidisciplinary Introduction to Canadian Studies, ed. William Metcalfe. NDQ: North Dakota Quarterly [Univ. of North Dakota], 52, No. 3 (Summer 1984), 323-25. In his review of Labyrinths of Voice: Conversations with Robert Kroetsch, Lewis notes that "In the first two sections on influence and game," a number of Post-Modern techniques are referred to, including "art, life, and language as high forms of game, the preferred position to Kroetsch as neither a total 'realist' (seeing language as picture) nor a total gamesman (seeing language and art as non-mimetic but as serious games) .... There is little personal information about Kroetsch here; ... but we learn a tremendous amount about his vital mind and his numerous and often witty insights ...." Kroetsch is "one of ... [Canadian literature's] crown jewels."

C195   Bennett, Donna. "Weathercock: The Directions of Report." Open Letter, [Essays on Robert Kroetsch], Ser. 5, Nos. 8-9 (Summer-Fall 1984), pp. 116-45. "Intertextuality, genealogy, archaeology, grammar, deconstruction are among several 'traces' through which Kroetsch articulates his poetics and by means of which the reader is able to link Kroetsch's criticism to that of his contemporaries. However, the underlying sense of fragmentation and discontinuity with which these terms are associated in Kroetsch's writing are tied not only to [Jacques] Derrida's, [Julia] Kristeva's, [Roland] Barthes', and [Michel] Foucault's theories but to Kroetsch's own experience of space in the yet-to-be created West and to the loss he suffered when he forsook Modernism .... Kroetsch is a writer who fears and longs for place, but feels at home nowhere." Bennett describes the process of un-naming and renaming, evaluates Kroetsch's place in PostModernism in a fable of critical evolution, and, in a ledger of poetic technique, assesses Kroetsch's own parameters. Kroetsch found "that any naming, indigenous or foreign, invalidates itself and is therefore both dangerous and false ...." Once un-named, once freed, the process of re-naming begins. "This kind of naming -- 'renaming' -- stands in opposition to an absolute name: it is a metonymic naming rather than a metaphoric one and, as such, is neither fixed nor definitive." For Kroetsch, re-naming is "like the Western traditions of occasional storytelling and anecdote. Stories, told and retold, in an informal oral tradition, take on new structures and aspects, and even new material, to suit the teller's and the occasion's needs." Bennett also discusses Kroetsch's use of the trickster figure and his use of the carnival as a merging point of community and anarchy. "The carnival is not a revolution, but the enactment of one -- a safe, or reasonably safe, embrace of violence." It is "the closest event in life to the literary experience, a recasting of reality in terms that allow for change and new visions."

C196   Blodgett, E.D. "The Book, its Discourse, and the Lyric: Notes on Robert Kroetsch's Field Notes." Open Letter, [Essays on Robert Kroetsch], Ser. 5, Nos. 8-9 (Summer-Fall 1984), pp. 195-205. It "is the notion of the book as originator of 'differance' that (con)textually grounds discontinuity, and Field Notes, as the collected poetry, reflects the several books and discourses of its composition. The book becomes a signifier whose signified is another book, and the closure that Kroetsch strives to avoid is always at a beginning." Blodgett recognizes Kroetsch's movement toward the oral tradition and toward the original source. "If speech, the spoken word, contains presence, and writing continually loses sight of origin, to make origin the object of writing, by silencing the myth of the spoken word and capturing it in a game of signs, is to efface the distinction between prose and poetry." This "is precisely Kroetsch's enterprise, by using both a ledger and ... a seed catalogue -- both examples of prose at a zero grade -- as matrices of origin."

C197   Brown, Russell. "Seeds and Stones: Unhiding in Kroetsch's Poetry." Open Letter, [Essays on Robert Kroetsch], Ser. 5, Nos. 8-9 (Summer-Fall 1984), pp. 154-75. In this examination of "Seed Catalogue" and "Stone Hammer Poem," Brown traces Kroetsch's processes of unhiding, of exposing the many surfaces. Kroetsch's "nonsense chorus" ("'I don't give a damn if I do die do die do die do die do die ....'"), is "a chill intimation of mortality which unexpectedly emerges into the poem .... 'Seed Catalogue' is a poem of absences ... but -- as is so often true -- the central absence is the one that it skirts and dodges and confronts only ... in jest. And only in lines that turn the language into ... non-language, lines that uncreate the utterance even before it is fully uttered .... This discovery of the inevitable loss of life and self ... is what ultimately awaits our final act of unhiding, and the poet hides his discovery of this (or hides from it) as promptly as he unhides it ...." "Stone Hammer Poem," like "Seed Catalogue," "deals with the inevitability of loss," but shows that what is lost is inevitably found. Although lost to us, "... there are recompenses -- the most notable of which is the creation of this poem .... In writing his poems for the stone hammer, the poet turns not only stone into hammer into poem, but absence into art: the art of the hammer-maker inspiring the art of the poet and bridging the absence that separates them. 'Stone Hammer Poem' is more than just Kroetsch's fullest exploration of the act of un-creating and unhiding, of peeling away layers and confronting the ultimate loss, ... it is also an enactment of the poet's invariable response .... Kroetsch fills his absences with his writing."

C198   Fitzgerald, Judith. "Structure and Coherence in Robert Kroetsch's Alibi." Open Letter, [Essays on Robert Kroetsch], Ser. 5, Nos. 8-9 (Summer-Fall 1984), pp. 79-82. "The key to Alibi lies in its title. An alibi, above all else, is a plea; it is not merely an excuse." In Alibi, Kroetsch "has effectively writ. ten his narrator's non-novel." Since "... the story is told from the perspective of already having happened in 'real time,' the intentions of the narrator (and ultimately, of course, the author) involve both telling the story for the story's sake and, more significantly, telling that same story for the teller's sake. In other words, the narrator makes a case for himself in retrospect. He pleads his story." Fitzgerald counters interpretations of Alibi as a "'quest' novel or a variation on the old Odyssean theme .... The idea of the quest involves the notion that the end justifies the means; conversely, the idea of the voyage of discovery [of the self in terms of 'the other'] involves the notion that the means ... implicitly justify the end. In the case of Alibi, the emphasis can only be placed on the latter."

C199   Godard, Barbara. "Other Fictions: Robert Kroetsch's Criticism." Open Letter, [Essays on Robert Kroetsch], Ser. 5, Nos. 8-9 (Summer-Fail 1984), pp. 5-21. Godard examines critical theories and the way in which Kroetsch manipulates them in order to tell his critical fiction, his stories about "the search for story." Godard outlines the Phenomenology of Martin Heidegger and Wolfgang Iser, the Structuralism of Ferdinand de Saussure and Tzvetan Todorov, the PostStructuralism of Roland Barthes, the Deconstructionism of Michel Foucault and Jacques Derrida, and the carnival of Mikhail Bakhtin -the "literary fashions (fads?)" of Kroetsch's era. "The history of Kroetsch's publications is also the unfolding history of the 'new new criticism' of Canadian literature." Godard discusses the shift, in Kroetsch's critical approach, "from phenomenology to deconstructive" and maintains that "... Kroetsch's criticism and criticism of his work ... [are] the main locus of deconstructive activity in Canadian criticism." However, "The deconstructionist influence remains essentially a stylistic one, characterized by its 'difficulty.'" Godard also discusses "... Kroetsch's appropriation of Bakhtin's theory of the novel." Kroetsch's story "... is the story of a generation's quest as it attempts a critical retracing of the scepticism of contemporary writers."

C200   Kizuk, A.R. "Meaning and Narrative Strategies in the Novels of Robert Kroetsch." Open Letter, [Essays on Robert Kroetsch], Ser. 5, Nos. 8-9 (Summer-Fall 1984), pp. 57-70. Kizuk discusses Kroetsch's novels and critical theory on the basis of "bar talk" and "club talk." "Club talk is an area of literary competence, by which is meant a field of choices concerning how one speaks about things, and what is to be spoken about. These choices are determined by and effective within the author's milieu. Club talk is marked by the style of thought and expression common to this milieu." It functions in the language of the "faculty club" and on an international level. "Kroetsch's systematic subversions of Odyssean and Eleusinian motifs ... as a narrative strategy, is marked by club talk in the sense that a writer like Jorges Luis Borges, for instance, would immediately recognize it as a strategy he has himself used." Bar talk functions on a different level and speaks to an audience which "shares in common a body of information which is not easily available to the literary milieu." It is an audience "which decreases in number and geographical extent, in inverse proportion to the amount of local information received .... For Kroetsch, club talk confirms his membership in a milieu ... [in which he] is merely one among many, and must accept the 'marginality' of his authorship .... "In the bar, on the other hand, "... he is elected to the position of power"; he is storyteller recounting "the narrative that contains, and partially conceals, the sacred names of the land."

C201   Kroller, Eva-Marie. "History and Photography in Robert Kroetsch's Alibi." Open Letter, [Essays on Robert Kroetsch], Ser. 5, Nos. 8-9 (Summer-Fall 1984), pp. 71-78. "... Karen Strike is Kroetsch's version of a motif obsessively repeated in Canadian literature .... " She is the photographer who "attempts to preserve a perfect record of time and space in photographic images." She "attempts to string out events horizontally in a sequence of cause and effect, ignoring the impossibility of discovering origins in a world of artifact." The motif of photography is integrated "into Dorf's healing self as one of his options." In Alibi, "... the sense of aleatory movement, of alternatives left both exhilaratingly and depressingly open" is enhanced by the structure. Meaning is unsettled and "the notion of time and place as unmistakable entities" is questioned. The heroes of Alibi are sent "on a spiritual quest in which they gradually learn to accept models and copies as the necessary compensations for human imperfection ...." Dorf's "journal at the end of Alibi is an attempt at cautiously synthesizing the results of his quest, at developing, as he puts it, the negatives provided by his original journal."

C202   Lecker, Robert. "Con/Texts of Desire: Robert Kroetsch's Alibi." Open Letter, [Essays on Robert Kroetsch], Ser. 5, Nos. 8-9 (Summer-Fall 1984), pp. 83-98. Rpt. (revised, expanded) in Robert Kroetsch. By Robert Lecker. Twayne's World Authors Series, No. 768. Boston: Twayne, 1986, pp. 106-22. In Alibi, "... the tension between opposites creates an interplay of revealed and unrevealed codes which allows the novel to become ... a novel of desire in which the text is flaunted at us in patches, brief. The text we want resists us, invites us, hides from us, infuriates us." Lecker links Alibi to Roland Barthes' The Pleasure of the Text and maintains that "Dorf's words do much to reveal Kroetsch's developing sense of textual erotics .... Talking and telling become erotic activities linked to the notion of desire ... [which is] the intimacy between the reader and the text, the interplay enticed by reading." However, Kroetsch "will not reveal all, will not satisfy our desire, simply because desire satisfied is desire negated." Kroetsch maintains desire by building "on our expectations regarding his writing," by remaining "fundamentally anonymous," and by disallowing "overlap." Dorf, "the chief spokesman for Kroetsch's emphasis on desire," is "the agent of deconstruction in one Kroetschian sense." Dorf moves "against closure and resolution .... By following his dreams, by searching for beginnings which can never be found, and by moving backward toward source ... [Dorf moves] against closure and resolution." Lecker also discusses the interplay between Dorf and the other characters in the novel. Jack Deemer is "a (vanished) symbol of the conventional author selecting and arranging his fictional world." Karen Strike is more than "Dorf's antithesis" a female pole of tension. She possesses "the binary characteristics associated with Doff." In her attempt to present Doffs journal, "to reconstruct Dorf," she "undoes Dorf and her own narration by allowing us to see that the conventionalized narrative will not work." The chapter headings she adds to the work "must be seen in deconstructive and ironic lights." The interplay between "undone/done up" cannot be resolved if desire is to be maintained. "Dorf and Karen intertwine, overlap, move back and forth between poles; but ultimately, their dance remains as tensionridden as the text, which moves among conventions and possibilities, hiding and revealing itself before us."

C203   Neuman, Shirley. "Figuring the Reader, Figuring the Self in Field Notes: 'Double or noting:" Open Letter, [Essays on Robert Kroetsch], Ser. 5, Nos. 8-9 (Summer-Fall 1984), pp. 176-94. The reader must actively respond to Kroetsch's poetry. The reader "realizes the poem, acts to bring it into being," functions "as reader in the text (instead of reader of the text.). ... To conceive of the poem's notation as 'the reader in the text' is to remove the poem from the ivory tower of the author's Intention and the critic's Interpretation and to make it part of the living plurality of the social 'order' in which our sense of self is shaped by our sense of difference from others, in which all language, even when we talk to ourselves, implies a response" In Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch, "... language and self are doubled. Behind both lies absence within presence, the failure of the sign, of the self, to ever be fully present to itself. Both refuse the myth of Origin, of ultimate Authority, while both remain fascinated by origins. The myth of Origin confronted and denied (again and again), the absent/lost poem, the absent/lost self can be found only in the play of differences" Realization of "that play of difference, that poem, that self' depends upon the active reader and "the 'dialogic response' between reader and poem, between other and self .... The reader in the text is that (plural) other, her reading(s) predicted but never closed off by the notation of the poem, by the manifestations of the self."

C204   Seim, Jeanette. "Horses & Houses: Further Readings in Kroetsch's Badlands and Sinclair Ross's As for Me and My House." Open Letter, [Essays on Robert Kroetsch], Ser.5, Nos.8-9 (Summer-Fall 1984), pp. 99-115. The dichotomy of "horse: house" that Kroetsch discusses in "The Fear of Women in Prairie Fiction: An Erotics of Space" (B125) is unhinged in Robert Kroetsch's Badlands and Sinclair Ross's As for Me and My House. "Anna Dawe unhinges the horse: house dichotomy without resorting to the 'most obvious resolution of the dialectic.., the whore's-house" She rather instigates her own 'unhousing' through a range of textual strategies that work toward relegating the male quest story, with all its trappings of heroism, to mere 'horse-play' .... Anna Dawe 'unnames' both 'horse' and 'house.'" She is gifted in her ability "to 'untell' while telling, to tell a story while assaulting that story, to mediate ... between naming and unnaming." Anna "must break the rules, speak the story, in order to arrive at a more authentic vision, a vision characterized by a demythologizing of the male-hero-explorer figure."

C205   Bowering, George. "Recent Reading 2: Journals." Line [Simon Fraser Univ.], No.4 (Fall 1984), p. 101. In a brief review of the special issue of Open Letter that is dedicated to Kroetsch (C3), Bowering notes that Kroetsch "is the most innovative of our writers with reputation .... and ... offers us ... much of his own new literary theory."

C206   Lecker, Robert. "Freed from Story: Narrative Tactics in Badlands." Essays on Canadian Writing, No.30 (Winter 1984-85), pp.160-86. Rpt. (revised) in Robert Kroetsch. By Robert Lecker. Twayne's World Authors Series, No. 768. Boston: Twayne, 1986, pp. 78-96. Kroetsch "has persistently tried to balance story and anti-story ... because it is the only way he can distance himself from the kind of writing which implicitly questions the writing act that defines him." He foists the resulting "guilt" "on the narrative, so that the text must paradoxically resolve the double bind that he, the writer, cannot. This is why the narrative impulses behind Kroetsch's novels are increasingly guilt-driven .... In Badlands, the tactics Kroetsch uses to convey this failure create an intricate web of narrative evasions. The book unites Kroetsch's drive to anti-story with his repudiation of the female claim in time through a complex narrative structure that is highly, and appropriately, ironic .... Anna seems to have escaped from history, from the female stereotype confining all of Kroetsch's women, but what she escapes into is precisely that time consciousness she tries to evade through her narrative quest ...
