Anna's narrative comprises a predictable response to this trap: caged in a labyrinth of time, she runs back and forth between narrative possibilities, unwilling to choose any possibility because choice implies the closure she is supposed to be transcending" Lecker examines ten "representative examples" of her third-person narration which reveal "Anna's attempt to deal with a specific problem or question connected with writing the story .... To grant Anna her freedom we must argue that, like Dawe, she rejects the written word from the start, that she is not searching for a cathartic retelling of her father's story, but for a non-telling, for a form of narrative that defies conventional narrative expectations." This can be seen in Anna's conscious "parody of traditional narrative forms .... In this context, Anna becomes the agent, and most powerfully the voice, of the tall-tale tradition that Kroetsch himself is beginning to pursue .... The writer [like Anna] who becomes the oral poet is freed from the conundrum: everything is possible when spoken by one whose aim is to embellish, backtrack, invite interjection, refuse closure .... By throwing away her father's notes, she discards precisely the 'heirloom model' which would compel her to record, rather than to imagine," and "rejects the notion of mimesis that obsesses Kroetsch ...." Her "imagined" narrative "gives the lie to any sense of 'reality' as something solid and fixed ...." Thus, Anna becomes the "trickster who defies the rational frame ...." Lecker supports her role as trickster by outlining how "... she can assume every role .... It is through this silence, rather than through any conventional notion of freedom, that Anna's story starts."

C207   Germundson, Karen. "Reentering the Wasteland: Robert Kroetsch's Postmodern Fiction." In Present Tense: A Critical Anthology. Vol. IV of The Canadian Novel. Ed. John Moss. Toronto: NC, 1985, pp. 232-48. Kroetsch's postmodern vision of the world is "grotesque, yet undeniably banal." Germundson maintains that "... the violence, absurdity, and incongruity of Kroetsch's world are not a distortion but an accurate reflection of a world which is itself bizarre." Postmodern literature focuses on the more incomprehensible and disturbing aspects of life -- "cruelty, suffering, dying, unconscious impulses, especially the sexual drive" -- because, "as prominent features of our age, they demand confrontation." In a survey of Kroetsch's fiction, Germundson notes three overriding obsessions -- a concern with death, a "morbid fear of failure," and the "'terrors of human relationships'." The techniques of postmodern fiction employed by Kroetsch are examined -- "tragi-comedy, new types of realism, the tall tale, a unique narrative voice" -- but are dismissed as being "not important in themselves" They are valuable only in that they give us a new perspective, "a view of our world from a very new and startling vantage point."

C208   Keith, W.J. Canadian Literature in English. Longman Literature in English. London: Longman, 1985, pp. 6, 7, 111, 115-16, 133, 157, 164-66, 197, 258. Kroetsch is an important writer and scholar who, with Patrick Lane, has produced "the most exciting Canadian poetry to have emerged in recent years." Kroetsch is "conspicuously present in his poems, reproducing and embodying the processes of thinking and making." Kroetsch has a "delight in language." In Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch, "... Kroetsch pushes his poetic impulse to deconstructing extremes, playing complex linguistic games with himself and the reader." Keith uses Kroetsch as an example of a Canadian writer who has "explored the possibilities of post-modernism, deconstruction, and 'metafiction' ...." Keith briefly discusses Kroetsch's prose. In the novels, "... the serious games played with meaning, form, and language are conspicuous." Kroetsch "believes that traditional fiction limits the ways in which we view reality and deliberately deconstructs the sanctioned conventions in order to build up new forms. The result is a curious combination of the gutsily vigorous ... and the self-consciously cerebral." In his early novels, Kroetsch explores "the bizarre and the mythical." With experience, Kroetsch has developed his "parody-picaresque form" and his ability to tell "unequivocally intellectual tall tales." Keith also includes Kroetsch in a chronological list of Canadian authors and their works.

C209   McGregor, Gaile. The Wacousta Syndrome: Explorations in the Canadian Langscape. Toronto: Univ. of Toronto Press, 1985, pp. 53, 65, 74, 79, 90, 118, 137, 154, 196, 216, 220-21, 233-49, 282, 307, 322-23, 333, 344, 347-48, 350, 361, 364, 365, 367, 370-71, 380-83, 394, 399, 410, 438, 442. Kroetsch's works are used to exemplify various patterns in Canadian literature.

C210   Moss, John. "Himmler's Got the King: An Essay on Badlands and Burning Water." Present Tense: A Critical Anthology. Vol. IV of The Canadian Novel. Ed. John Moss. Toronto: NC, 1985, pp. 249-64. Two distinctly separate versions of reality are simultaneously present in Badlands: "... one is linear, an existential adventure, which Kroetsch associates with the male quest for continuity and significance, ... the other is transformational, a structuralist reality of patterned repetition, associated with the female, with re-birth." To Kroetsch, reality "is a story told in two ways, each of which may deny the other, but which are mutually dependent on the other's presence." Kroetsch demands that we "wrestle free of print, the false and narrow dictates of narrative reality." We must abandon the "modernist fallacy (the fallacy of existential realism), wherein we have come to accept words as facts and syntax as sense; where we have come to think of reality as a text." His ultimate goal is "to break down the artificial and arbitrary barriers between life and the printed word, to break through the walls of the labyrinth which language has built around us and in which we too readily find ourselves lost."

C211   Pache, Walter. "The Fiction Makes Us Real': Aspects of Postmodernism in Canada." In Gaining Ground: European Critics on Canadian Literature. Ed. Robert Kroetsch and Reingard M. Nischik. Western Canadian Literary Documents. Vol. VI. Edmonton: NeWest, 1985, 67-72, 73, 74, 75, 76, 77. Narrative "fabulation is already evident in ... The Words of my Roaring," but, in The Studhorse Man and Gone Indian, he "makes full use of the whole repertoire of postmodern narrative techniques." In The Studhorse Man, "The narrator, who once guaranteed the authenticity of the story, ends up immobilized and incompetent as a lunatic in a bathtub .... In its utter failure, the narrative report reveals the intrinsic absurdity of any fictional representation of reality .... The Studhorse Man becomes overtly metafictional: it is a book about writing a book .... Because the narrator's perspective and the events he refers to openly contradict each other, the reader experiences the narrative as fictitious .... The novel's claim to originality rests, paradoxically, on its insistence on the inescapable dialectic of creation and reproduction, of innovation and imitation .... Kroetsch's fiction shows an increasing tendency 'towards the minimal novel, towards the point where only enough is given to stimulate the reader to maximum involvement, maximum participation in the work.' Kroetsch's following novel, Gone Indian .... represents the next stage of this process of reduction." In Gone Indian, Kroetsch structurally moves to "the 'frontier' of fictional experiment" The "two competing narrators claiming equal credibility" present the reader with "two versions of events .... Both the unresolved duplicity of the novel's plot and the blatantly obvious unreliability of the interpretations offered function as an ironic critique of the traditional activities of the reader of realistic fiction .... Even though it is certainly true that Kroetsch's attack on the reality principle and on realism in fiction is indebted to contemporary American models, it has obvious Canadian implications. Most noticeable are the topical allusions .... At a deeper level, Kroetsch's narrative experiment would seem to be in keeping with the Canadian tradition because it rarely goes to extremes: important epic categories... are models .... the ironic destruction of realistic narrative is more than just an aesthetic exercise: it is an essential step towards an independent national literature."

C212   Schafer, Jurgen. "A Farewell to Europe: Rudy Wiebe's The Temptations of Big Bear and Robert Kroetsch's Gone Indian." In Gaining Ground: European Critics on Canadian Literature. Ed. Robert Kroetsch and Reingard M. Nischik. Western Canadian Literary Documents. Vol. VI. Edmonton: NeWest, 1985, 79-80, 84-87, 88, 89, 90. Schafer chooses Rudy Wiebe's The Temptations of Big Bear and Robert Kroetsch's Gone Indian to exemplify a "radically new image of the Canadian Indian," one which includes Native culture in the history of Canada. "... Gone Indian is a postmodern construct, set in a realistic world precariously bordering on the surreal, whose fast-moving plot and characters constantly seem to elude the reader's grasp .... Gone Indian relates the urbanized present to the prairies prior to white settlement .... there is a structuralist synthesis on the mythic level." Schafer outlines Jeremy's transformation into a Native. "Among the various themes and structural elements, however, the idea of a Canadian fusion of Western and Indian identity and the discovery of the Indian tradition on Canadian soil are clearly predominant. Professor Madham's persistent efforts to cut and censor Jeremy's tale of symbolism and dream vision, his insistence on having successfully lived down his own Indian encounters, ultimately reveal his desperate attempt to repress a truth uncomfortable for Western rationality: the Indian spiritual tradition has to be absorbed by the white settler on Canadian soil .... A significant part of this uninvention consists in the incorporation of the Indian past into Canadian consciousness not as an alien graft, but as ur-Canadian, as the quintessence of Canadianness .... both novels present not a celebration of nostalgic primitivism but an imaginative evocation of the Indian past as a new and significant dimension of Canadian history."

C213   Stanzel, Franz K. "Texts Recycled: 'Found' Poems in Canada." In Gaining Ground: European Critics on Canadian Literature. Ed. Robert Kroetsch and Reingard M. Nischik. Western Canadian Literary Documents. Vol. VI. Edmonton: NeWest, 1985, 94, 104, 105, 106. In this discussion of found poems, Stanzel notes that the "technique of collage ... is refined ... in Seed Catalogue .... Line breaks, closure, and spacing on the printed page are used here to spin a very subtle and intricate web of significant references, reconnecting the dislocated words and phrases on the page." The "severe" growing climate relates to the "contingencies of the 'growth of a poet's mind.'"

C214   Lernout, Geert. "Alibi: An Exercise in Post-Modernism" Fourth Literature Conference, Vrije Universiteit, Amsterdam. 18 Jan. 1985. Printed in Commonwealth Literature -- Mostly Canadian: Papers Presented at the Fourth Literature Conference Held at the Vrije Universiteit on Friday 18 January 1985. Ed. Th. L. D'haen and A.J. Fry. Amsterdam: Free Univ. Press, 1986, pp. 23-33. The Post-Modern novel in Canada exemplifies, not the "'novel of exhaustion'" but "'the novel of replenishment'" which is characterized by "narrative over-abundance" a movement "out of the city and into the village or smaller rural community," and "earthy and bodily life ... [which is] rooted in oral narration," rather than an "intellectual" tone. The narration in Alibi differs from What the Crow Said "because we have here an I-narrator who describes what happens to him in his diary, then copies the diary into a manuscript .... The chapter headings are not his, they are the work of Karen Strike ... [who] is, in a way, a postmodernist stereotype: she is the fixer, the setter of boundaries .... Another image of the traditional artist is Deemer himself .... All these figures are associated with death and order .... " Dorf is preoccupied "with collecting, ordering and measuring .... A second difference with novels such as What the Crow Said is the presence of philosophical, psychological and literary allusions," both to Kroetsch's own works and to others'. "A last difference of this novel ... is its treatment of the ineffable." Kroetsch's contact with the ineffable "is the most important reason why this novel is so utterly post-modernist. The I-narrator and the lack of community perspective are not the only reason for this .... " The "exclusion of a genuinely historical dimension" occurs in "the fiction in Alibi in the attempt to stop time." The "game-element," puns, and "overt discussions about language and reality' are also mentioned as evidence of Post-Modernism. "But in the final analysis this book seems to be little more than just that: a writer's exercise, a summary of his earlier work and a step back since What the Crow Said."

C215   Conklin, Jamie. "System Unsystem" Rev. of Labyrinths of Voice: Conversations with Robert Kroetsch, by Shirley Neuman and Robert Wilson; and Alibi, by Robert Kroetsch. Brick [Ilderton, Ont.], No. 24 (Spring 1985), pp. 10-13. Labyrinths of Voice: Conversations with Robert Kroetsch, "a postmodern chat with Mr. Postmodernism himself, .... reveals many of the virtues and contradictions that are to be found in Kroetsch's fiction ... Just as Kroetsch violates formal conventions, Wilson and Neuman violate the conventions of an interview in order to show their sympathy with Kroetsch. Labyrinths therefore participates in a contradiction that pervades Kroetsch's work: the denial of systems is itself a positing of a new system .... the contradiction leads to an irritating web of quotations and a rather self-satisfied tone on the part of the editors." In Kroetsch's work, however, contradiction is "nothing more than tangible evidence of his determination to seek freedom through language ...." This book is "especially notable for the light it sheds on Kroetsch's notion of metonymy and his notion of self." Kroetsch discusses his "idea of a fragmented, shifting self' and his attitude toward metonymy as a "renaming" process that resists "the temptation to establish a relationship between the story being told and some grandsemantic system .... As a whole, Labyrinths is pretentious and silly; but insofar as Kroetsch is able to speak with conviction about his beliefs and his writing, it has value."

C216   Ross, Brian L. "The Naked Narrator: The Studhorse Man & the Structuralist Imagination." Canadian Literature, No. 104 (Spring 1985), pp. 65-73. Demeter Proudfoot, The Studhorse Man's narrator, exhibits the "self-conscious nakedness of the structuralist imagination" so that the narrative moves toward the "narcissistic indulgence" that is "characteristic of the literature of exhaustion." As the tale of Hazard Lepage is told, literary convention is exposed to parody" so that the "'biography'" becomes a self-aware fabulation that constantly satirizes itself. The Studhorse Man is "an insightful parody of how the structuralist writer's awareness of the conventions of literary construction and their applications interferes with his creative output." The novel is not, therefore, a quest for the "perfect horse," but a quest "to save Poesy, literature, from extinction."

C217   Webb-Proctor, Gary. "Magic Realism Finds Home in Canada." The Globe and Mail [Toronto] 18 May 1985, Sec. Entertainment, p. 11. In a discussion of Magic Realism in Canada, Webb-Proctor notes "The premier Canadian author of magic realism is either Jack Hodgins ... or Alberta's Robert Kroetsch ...."

C218   Whalen, Terry. Rev. of Labyrinths of Voice: Conversations with Robert Kroetsch, by Shirley Neuman and Robert Wilson. Quarry, 34, No. 4 (Autumn 1985), 99-102. Kroetsch speaks "like a 'gentle anarchist'... who is always threatening to run away from meaning rather than to pursue it. There is a tendency in his bias, therefore, to love nonsense a bit too much .... Kroetsch comments ... on the value of literary 'play' .... But he as well makes many standard Postmodernist comments on the reader-writer relationship .... " He "sees the value of an awareness of mythic structures, but he values more what he calls 'anecdotal texture, narrativity' .... -- the uniqueness in story and in narrative voice .... When ... Kroetsch says that in Badlands he was 'trying to tell the story of nothing to tell' ..., we realize that such an intention is generated out of his Postmodernist scepticism about myth, and his understanding of the existential fix of the Canadian imagination. To tell a story which compromises itself into a larger pattern of closed mythical meaning is to betray the conversation between mystery and muddle which lies at the centre of the Canadian spiritual reality .... Kroetsch's loudest assumptions as a deconstructionist writer and as one who worries the relationship between word and thing, language and reality, are given their fullest play in the final section in Labyrinths of Voice .... Yet, the most interesting parts of the conversation ... are those which begin -- unfortunately, without developing -- a discussion of the potential inadequacy of the Postmodernist's views of Modernism and the assumption that language has only a peripheral relationship to the real world." Labyrinths of Voice: Conversations with Robert Kroetsch, "an important" text, "contains one of the most detailed airings of the Postmodernist aesthetic .... "The conversations "will give you second thoughts about ... [Postmodernism's] potential for intellectual nihilism and time-consuming obscurity."

C219   Stratford, Philip. All the Polarities: Comparative Studies in Contemporary Canadian Novels in French and English. Toronto: ECW, 1986, pp. 71-81, 100, 101, 102, 106. Stratford compares and contrasts the comic elements of Robert Kroetsch's The Studhorse Man and Roch Carrier's La Guerre, Yes Sir!. "Both writers draw heavily on the traditional stockpile of comic themes, characters, situations, and devices, but both also cultivate a particularly modern brand of black comedy. Their work is characterized by boisterous sexual high-jinks and pointed social and cultural satire." Stratford discusses "some outstanding differences" between the two: differences in scope, use of historical references, choice of narrator, techniques of narration, use of dreams and symbolism, individualism, and the use of satire: "... Carrier's and Kroetsch's novels differ the way burlesque morality differs from picaresque epic .... Kroetsch's novel comes from comic epic and Carrier's from comic drama .... "The Studhorse Man is characterized by "movement in space." The studhorse man's odyssey provides a varied panorama against which he displays his character .... "Evolution in time" and an "American presence" are also important elements of the novel.

Awards and Honours

C258   University Fellowship, University of Iowa (1960-61).

C259   Breadloaf Fellow in Fiction, Breadloaf Writers' Conference (1966).

C260   Governor-General's Award for Fiction for The Studhorse Man (1970).

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Books, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews and profiles, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Books  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Part II

Works on Robert Kroetsch

[underbar]

C   Books, Articles and Sections of Books, Theses and Dissertations, Interviews and Profiles, Adaptations, Miscellaneous, and Awards and Honours

Books

C1      Thomas, Peter. Robert Kroetsch. Studies in Canadian Literature, No. 13. Vancouver: Douglas & McIntyre, 1980. 139 pp. "Like the resourceful Coyote of Plains Indian mythology, a figure central to his imagination, Robert Kroetsch is difficult to trap. His narratives are ambitiously expansive in theme and varied in tone. Their range of physical movement and lexical bravura repudiates the more restricted and tightlipped traditions of social realism. The nature of his comedy belies its superficial qualities, especially the wild sexual farce." In Thomas' view, "Kroetsch's main affinities are with those writers whose work most demonstrates this concern for the aesthetics of narrative -- above all, Conrad, Faulkner, Beckett, Nabokov, Borges. For while the characteristic Kroetsch hero is engaged upon some version of the male quest -- in outline, probably the most familiar of all narrative structureshis actions are contained by complex ironies and parody. He moves in a world of language, of lies greater than his own, his freedom mocked by the contingencies of intricate fictions which deny him a sense of closure, of an ending." Thomas examines the manner in which Kroetsch manipulates characterization, form, influence, voice, and critical methodology. One chapter is devoted to The Stone Hammer Poems: 1960-1975, The Ledger, and Seed Catalogue, another discusses But We Are Exiles and Words of my Roaring, and a third combines Gone Indian and Badlands. The Studhorse Man and What the Crow Said have a chapter devoted to each of them. Thomas includes a brief biography of Kroetsch in the Introduction and a Bibliography at the conclusion of his text.

C2      Neuman, Shirley, and Robert Wilson. Labyrinths of Voice: Conversations with Robert Kroetsch. Western Canadian Literary Documents. Vol. III. Edmonton: NeWest, 1982. 246 pp. This is an interchange of thoughts between Neuman, Wilson, and Kroetsch. It breaks away from the formal interview and allows "unexpected byways in the conversation." The authors describe the work as conversations "intercut by informal allusiveness: a representative, though far from exhaustive, series of other voices that intersect with our own, that (in their absolute fragmentariness) allude to other discourse and further possible discursiveness." The discussion is divided under the subject headings "Influence," "Game," "Myth," and "Narration," which are central areas of concern for Kroetsch. Interwoven throughout the work are excerpts from numerous literary critics and philosophers, which serve to illuminate and to catalyze the ongoing intercourse.

C3      Open Letter, [Essays on Robert Kroetsch]. Ed. Frank Davey and bpNichol. Ser.5, Nos. 8-9 (Summer-Fall 1984). 205 pp. A special issue devoted to Robert Kroetsch. Since two works by Kroetsch are included, each piece has been listed separately in the appropriate sections of Sections B, C, and D of this bibliography. See B73, B141, C195-C204, C252, D91, and D129.

C4      Lecker, Robert. Robert Kroetsch. Preface and Chronology Robert Lecker. Twayne's World Authors Series, No. 768. Boston: Twayne, 1986. [vii], [ix-x], 165 pp. Lecker shows "that there is an aesthetic center in Kroetsch's work, a crucial tension that haunts him and influences everything he writes. The terms used to describe this tension shift as Kroetsch's art develops, but the basic situation remains the same: Kroetsch is fascinated by the space between polarities, inhabits that space, and writes from the viewpoint of one who is repeatedly seduced by the two poles he tries to embrace. To describe these poles is to evoke a cluster of associations connected with Kroetsch's art. On one side, there is Tradition, the model, inherited form, the father, history, genealogy, convention, archetype, myth, mimesis, stability, east, endings, closure, death. On the other side there is Innovation, anarchy, invention, sonship, presence, isolation, experimentation, fragmentation, tall tales, instability, west, beginnings, openings, birth ... If we look back over Kroetsch's theory, fiction, and poetry we see this border everywhere. In essays and interviews he persistently evokes the borderline metaphor in relation to his life and the stories he creates. His 'double experience' produces a 'literature of dangerous middles,' a double hook consciousness steeped in 'the total ambiguity that is so essentially Canadian.' Embracing this ambiguity, Kroetsch evolves a theory of contra-diction in which a host of opposites merge, overlap, reform." Parts of this book were previously published (see C145, C169, C202, and C206).

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors ; no. 7 ISBN: 0920763111 (hardcover); 092076312X (paperback), Book ID: ABCMA07RKP2.

Title:

Other Title:

<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP2000007003003004&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Books, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews and profiles, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Interviews and profiles</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Books, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews and profiles, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Interviews and profiles  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Interviews and Profiles

C231   Brown, Russell M. "An Interview with Robert Kroetsch." The University of Windsor Review, 7, No. 2 (Spring 1972), pp. 1-18. This interview (taped in 1970) touches upon Kroetsch's most important literary concerns. Kroetsch discusses his "experience" of the western landscape in Canada ("the kind of undefined vastness of it with points of reference within that vastness"). This landscape is without boundaries, so any sense of location is simultaneously an assertion of order against chaos objects signify the need to survive in a "mythic" landscape. Kroetsch stressed the importance of bringing in an outsider figure to experience the landscape, "that immense sense of space." He admires Sheila Watson's creation of a mythical landscape, in The Double Hook, and sees her as "the Western writer with whom I have the most affinity." He has also been influenced by Olson's and Williams' attempts to structure long poems without a narrative, and by Beckett, who is "always facing that question of language" and "looking at the problem inherent in the act of creation itself." Kroetsch also comments on the importance of process in writing ("... creation and destruction operate simultaneously"), and on the metaphorical relation between the sex urge and the act of writing in his own work. Kroetsch's most interesting statement is perhaps this: "... we have the wilderness which traditionally seems to inspire the prophetic voice; instead Canada produces a very confessional voice."

C232   Cameron, Donald. "Robert Kroetsch: The American Experience and the Canadian Voice." Journal of Canadian Fiction, 1, No. 3 (Summer 1972), pp.48-52. Rpt. in Conversations with Canadian Novelists. By Donald Cameron. Toronto: Macmillan, 1973, pp. 81-95. In this discussion with Donald Cameron, Kroetsch says "I suppose Canadians have a front-row seat on power and yet feel powerless quite often, and develop a sense of the absurd out of their own predicament .... I think we've got a sense of memory that's different from ... [Americans], and maybe again a sense of futility, I don't know .... We can ignore history completely and with ease, and yet we can be overwhelmed by history at opportune moments." Kroetsch also relates his definition of the Canadian sense of things and the way in which literature reflects our sensibilities. He discusses But We Are Exiles, The Studhorse Man, and The Words of my Roaring in this context.

C233   Cameron, Donald. "Conversations with Canadian Novelists." Pt. II. Interview with Roch Carrier, Robertson Davies, David Godfrey, Robert Kroetsch, W.O. Mitchell, Martin Myer, and Gabrielle Roy. Anthology. Prod. John Douglas. CBC Radio, 14 Oct. 1972. Kroetsch discusses The Studhorse Man. He explains why he writes in the first person and suggests that our culture has been reduced from a shared community vision to personal, private visions.

C234   Sunday Supplement. CBC Radio, 27 May 1973. Kroetsch discusses Gone Indian.

C235   Enright, Robert, and Dennis Cooley. "Uncovering Our Dream World: An Interview with Robert Kroetsch" Arts Manitoba, 1, No. 1 (Jan.-Feb. 1977), 32-39. Rpt. (revised)in Essays on Canadian Writing, Nos. 18-19 (Summer-Fall 1980), pp.21-32. Rpt. in RePlacing. Ed. Dennis Cooley. [Canadian Perspectives, No. 1.] Downsview, Ont.: ECW, 1980, pp. 21-32. Kroetsch discusses his "exile" in New York, the relation of teaching to writing, his methods of composition and its relation to the finished product. Considerable discussion is devoted to Kroetsch's poetic technique and to the dialectical aesthetic which has influenced his concept of writing and Canadian culture, particularly the Prairie vision, voice, and form. Kroetsch also discusses the formal relation of his poetry to his novels.

C236   Hancock, Geoff. "An Interview with Robert Kroetsch." Canadian Fiction Magazine, Nos. 24-25 (Spring-Summer 1977), 32-52. Kroetsch states, "The world that I write about is non-intellectual -- in the sense that it's terribly rural. The intellectual stuff in my head seems to work well in relationship to that." Kroetsch recounts childhood memories and educational experiences which he feels have influenced him. When asked to explain deconstruction, Kroetsch states, "You take a given set of conventions and play with them in a certain way. I think some of the conventions of fiction control too much our way of seeing the world. It starts to get interesting when you take those conventions and both use them and work against them." Kroetsch claims to have "a great deal of respect for the critical act," since he explores critical method in his fiction. Naming characters, for Kroetsch, is a complex process, since "... there's the sense in which we control the world by naming it and lose it by naming it. Because the name starts to replace the whatever else .... The way answers do." For Kroetsch, the reader is not the passive receiver of information. Kroetsch explains, "I want the reader to be engaged with me in fiction making. I work a reader pretty hard, I guess, in that I want him to enter into the process with me." For Kroetsch, sex is "the ultimate attempt to deny the loneliness, to join the world and have consequences. Like writing." In this interview, Kroetsch discusses his daily routine, as author and as professor.

C237   Bessai, Diane. "Death is a Happy Ending: A Dialogue in Thirteen Parts." In Figures in a Ground: Canadian Essays on Modern Literature Collected in Honor of Sheila Watson. Ed. Diane Bessai and David Jackel. Saskatoon: Western Producer Prairie, 1978, pp.206-15. Rpt. in Canadian Novelists and the Novel. Ed. Douglas Daymond and Leslie Monkman. Ottawa: Borealis, 1981, pp. 244-51. In this conversation with Bessai, Kroetsch says "The double hook. The total ambiguity that is so essentially Canadian: be it in terms of two solitudes, the bush garden, Jungian opposites, or the raw and the cooked binary structures of Levi-Straus. Behind the multiplying theories of Canadian literature is always the pattern of equally matched opposites." Kroetsch refers to Sheila Watson and Margaret Laurence, among other Canadian authors, in this discussion of Canadian literature. Language, the critic, the reader, deconstruction, post-modernism, and the artist are all topics which come under consideration. Kroetsch reveals his view of art, of its function, and of its openness of meaning in brief encapsulized comments to Bessai.

C238   Twigg, Alan. "Kroetsch." NeWest Review, Oct. 1979, pp. 3-4, 14. Rpt. (revised -- "Male: Robert Kroetsch") in For Openers: Conversations with 24 Canadian Writers. By Alan Twigg. Madiera Park, B.C.: Harbour, 1981, pp. 107-16. In this conversation with Alan Twigg, Kroetsch says "When I look at the male world that I grew up in, I think I mock it now a great deal. I think Western Canadian males are into this macho posture which is grotesque. They're acting in a way which doesn't fit any societal need any more .... In order to go west, a man had to define himself as an orphan, as an outlaw, as a cowboy. With those definitions, how can you marry a woman? How can you enter the house again? You have to lose that self-definition. That's the problem for the male. He must break his self-inflicted definition of maleness." Kroetsch also discusses his Alberta upbringing and the way in which it has shaped his literary perspective.

C239   Brahms, Flemming. "Robert Kroetsch." Kunapipi [Aarhus, Denmark], 2, No.2 (1980), 117-25. "It's that terrible tension between community and self' which constitutes the basic dichotomy in Canadian life and fiction. We must avoid stasis by building new myths, by using (and departing from) traditional mythic models: "... you have to re-tell stories all the time .... Keep opening them up." Kroetsch discusses the tall tale, the retold story: it combines the mythic and the local; it is the "shared tradition" of a "frontier world," a "sub-literary" sub-text; it deconstructs established literary form, including "notions of realism," and yet, paradoxically, it is a prejudiced response to reality which "has to be broken up while you're using it." Deconstruction, for Kroetsch, is a means of finding a new naming pattern to replace an inherited one that does not fit, but is a dangerous process in that it can become a static, controlling pattern itself. Further discussion focuses on the father as representative of a "past literary tradition" who "somehow has to disappear," the "erotics of space" embodied by the male outlaw fearful of entering into "feminine space," the invention of a "grammar of fiction" to create Prairie space, and the role of regionalism in determining patterns of perception.

C240   Marshall, John. "from THE REMEMBRANCE DAY TAPES." Island [Lantzville, B.C.], No. 7 (1980), pp. 35-50. The effacement, or death of the author is effected by the act of writing; the author's personality "is in the story itself." We have been "using a borrowed grammar" that controls and defines us, but Kroetsch identifies "space and silence" as the essence of a new grammatical perspective: silence does not violate; there are "unrealized poems" in the silent spaces; "... silence gets punctuated by some words ...," and the interview itself is punctuated by spaces and ellipses. The interview focuses on poetry and includes discussions on beginnings ("... the beginning is always something one beginning ahead ...") and endings ("... whatever force: that initially started that movement is used up .... the reader takes over from the writer at the point where the poem ends"), coherence as closure, the virtues of "letting the contradictions ride" despite the author's will to order metaphor as "equation" and, therefore, as "false grammar," and the author as archaeologist ("We want to see the thing in its place").

C241   Corbett, Helen. "Book Celebration Attracts Authors and Their Stories." The Edmonton Journal, 5 May 1980, p. E11. "Robert Kroetsch ... [is] an expert in evocative language ...." He "started his literary career in Grade 4, winning a prize for a poem." Corbett discusses the "Alberta Book Celebration."

C242   Neuman, Shirley. "Unearthing Language: An Interview with Rudy Wiebe and Robert Kroetsch." In A Voice in the Land: Essays by and about Rudy Wiebe. Ed. W.J. Keith. Edmonton: NeWest, 1981, pp. 226-47. In Neuman's interview with Robert Kroetsch and Rudy Wiebe, the discussion centres on Wiebe and his works. Kroetsch comments on Wiebe: "Your sense of story structure, of pattern, leads you to apocalypic endings which are great endings for novels, let's face it. But for you something that works against the story is forever redeemed." The two writers also compare themselves to one another. Kroetsch states, "I think we're both cosmological -- maybe that's a kind of shared ground -- and that we are immediately different about the cosmology. My cosmology is its own obsession with stories. Every story needs another story." Although this interchange focuses on Wiebe, Kroetsch adds personal comments on his approach to literature.

C243   MacKinnon, Brian. "'The Writer Has Got to Know Where He Lives': An Interview with Robert Kroetsch." Pt. 1. Writers News Manitoba, 4, No.l, [No. 21], (Feb. 1982), 3-18. MacKinnon and Kroetsch discuss the early "structuring" of Kroetsch's imagination: "I felt that I grew up with a kind of double vision." His parents embody the duality of East, "the dream place away," and West, Alberta. They also discuss the impact of the storytelling tradition (comprised of male tall-tale and female gossip); the North's importance to the national literary imagination as a "source of symbolism, metaphor, mythology"; the importance of the journal form, the confession, in Canadian writing; the vital notion of "geography," which "addresses the relationship between people and landscape"; and the relation of history to myth and fiction. The dynamics of Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch are examined. Kroetsch describes the Prairie storyteller's need to find a voice, an "adequate language," and comments on parody as part of a search for form. The importance of "local pride" to a writer's creative orientation is discussed as well as the emergence of the shaman/poet figure in Kroetsch's work.

C244   MacKinnon, Brian. "'We Always Tell Stories': An Interview with Robert Kroetsch." Pt.II. Writers News Manitoba, 4, No. 2, [No. 22] (Dec. 1982), 3-13. The first part of the interview is given over to Kroetsch's acknowledgement of the influence of a number of writers (including Wallace Stevens, William Carlos Williams, Joseph Conrad, William Faulkner, F. Scott Fitzgerald, and T. S. Eliot) and to a related discussion of the destruction of "traditional myths of time" in the twentieth century. Kroetsch goes on to address the issue of Canadian cultural identity: "... history has defined us into a corner ... so we turn to literature as a kind of renewal, as a kind of freedom." Kroetsch articulates distinctions between American and Canadian "voice and vision" and points to the role of women in redefining traditional mythic roles in Canadian literature: "One of the exciting things about our culture is the breakdown of the male as a questing figure." The tension in The Studhorse Man between Hazard's energy and Demeter's stasis "sums up the state of the Canadian predicament. We have that wild energy .... But, on the other hand, there is this incredible caution that is always trying to establish itself throughout the community."

C245   Neuman, Shirley, and Robert Wilson. Labyrinths of Voice: Conversations with Robert Kroetsch. Western Canadian Literary Documents. Vol. III. Edmonton: NeWest, 1982, 122-25, 126, 134-36, 154-55, 206-09. Rpt. (excerpts -- "Dis-Covering the Syntax of Living: A Conversation with Robert Kroetsch") in CV/II, [Special Alberta Poetry Issue], 7, No.2 (April 1983), 49-52. This excerpt from a series of interviews focuses on myth and narration and includes "interpolations" from other writers in the form of quoted passages. Kroetsch elaborates the tension in his work represented by "the allure.., of an overriding mythology" on one hand, and the need to demythologize on the other. Canada, embodying a host of "binary antagonisms" may develop a myth of stasis, but Kroetsch is less attracted to this equilibrium than to the "continuing play that is going on .... I think that literature is myth-making as well as mythusing. We have to find a way to be myth-making. It might be highly ironic or it might be parodic." Kroetsch discusses the relation between history and myth: history can modify myth, for "... the old mythic paradigm will be shifted because of an historical fact"; myth is essentially prophetic, history rationalistic; myth characterizes the Canadian West, and history, Central Canada. The problems inherent in autobiographical narration are explored: "It's a language problem for me to write this autobiography" Autobiography is "paradoxical" in that it "frees us from self.... Language, then, as signifier, frees me into a new relationship with signified"

C246   Slopen, Beverley. "Book World." The Sunday Star [The Toronto Star], 17 July 1983, p. G9. Slopen briefly mentions Kroetsch's visits to spas in disparate parts of the world to complete. his research for Alibi. By way of explaining his return to Canada from the United States after twenty years, Kroetsch remarks, "I guess reality impinged ...."

C247   Wilkins, Charles. "Robert Kroetsch: An Uncompromising Spinner of Tales." Quill & Quire, Aug. 1983, p. 36. Kroetsch is "a man of many aspects," most of which are contradictory: "an architect of elaborate, metaphoric novels," he is also "just a simple story-teller." The profile focuses on revealing the man behind the reputation, humanizing the "monster of letters." Kroetsch "wants to appeal to a probing and intelligent readership, to move literary boundaries, not masses of people." He articulates the dilemma of his need to write "a serious kind of novel," while at the same time attracting a readership from a culture which resists such writing. Kroetsch speaks of engaging the reader in his stories: "I like to draw the reader into the sense of labyrinth or puzzle that we live in." He comments on the importance to the creative process of maintaining a dialogue with the world: "As long as I keep my self-definition loose enough that I can participate in a variety of experience, I'm okay."

C248   Hancock, Geoff. Interview with Robert Kroetsch. Books in Canada, Oct. 1983, pp. 34-36. This interview focuses on Alibi, which Kroetsch notes was "a consequence of my returning to Canada after a long absence, my attempt to deal with a Canada that had become very urban." In Alibi, Kroetsch claims, "... two kinds of story are operating. The first is the kind you make as a keeper of a journal, where you respond to the immediate. The second is the kind of story we make as rewriters when we try to organize all those days to make some kind of continuum." Two narrative processes are in effect. In Alibi, "Words mean and don't mean. [Kroetsch is] ... always tempted by that double thing .... The reader has the pleasant task of deciding how to read the story. How to read the alibi. In a larger sense we all have alibis that we tell ourselves."

C249   Miki, Roy. "Prairie Poetics: An Interchange with Eli Mandel and Robert Kroetsch." Dandelion, 10, No. 2 (Fall-Winter 1983), 82-92. Eli Mandel and Robert Kroetsch discuss their respective interests in West Coast and Prairie poetics and their notions of Deconstruction and "crisis of meaning." The Prairie and the West Coast are "Two of the extraordinary regions of writing." Kroetsch and Mandel discuss their memories of editing the Canadian issue of boundary 2, a project that made them aware of Prairie poetics. The two writers concur that Kroetsch's Seed Catalogue, Mandel's Out of Place, and Andrew Suknaski's Wood Mountain Poems form "the statement of the poetics" in the Prairies. Prairie poetics combines ideas: "... on the one hand, it's vernacular, and on the other band, it's anecdotal, and third, paradoxically, it's structured ... and [Mandel notes] ... builds a series of bipolar structures." Kroetsch discusses his return to Canada and his interest in "that notion of place as a local pride" and in returning to the vernacular, the "speech of place." Kroetsch's concern with language and space generates a discussion on Deconstruction. Mandel and Kroetsch define the idea as they see it acting in their writing. As Mandel states, "... we are always caught up in somebody's dream of our self ... or the story we tell of our self" and, therefore, we must, as Kroetsch suggests, seek "a deconstruction toward our own definition." Deconstruction is a movement away from meaning, a denial of the "abstraction." Kroetsch states that he feels "betrayed" by meaning "in terms of language, [and] in terms of form." For Kroetsch and Mandel, the Prairie and its poetics defy abstraction, and they, as writers with Prairie sensibilities, must articulate away from the"crisis of meaning."

C250   Burke, Anne. "Robert Kroetsch: A Man of Contraries" Cross-Canada Writers' Quarterly, 6, No. 3 (1984), 7, 30-31. Burke discusses Kroetsch's background and the development of his works. Several aspects of his novels are scrutinized: the significance of the tall tale and card game in his works, the mistrust of relationships, the sense of local pride. Kroetsch is a "man of contraries." He is "a writer, editor, post-modernist theorist, and ... centrally a generous friend .... The good person, gentle, kind, wise, considerate, a father and husband, a man who needs a wife, children, home. And then the son of a bitch who can't stand those things, the stud, the charlatan, the bastard, the wild drinking man, the deceiver and liar, the tall-tale self. 'I sometimes think I have a sense of irony which threatens to destroy me. That is Canadian."

C251   Smith, Patricia Keeney. "WQ Interview with Robert Kroetsch." Cross-Canada Writers' Quarterly, 6, No. 3 (1984), 3-5, 29. This is a wide-ranging discussion of Kroetsch's approach to writing and research, literary technique, the relation between personal experience and writing, poetry, autobiography, limits, and borders. Brief mention is made of What the Crow Said, Alibi, and Theatre Passe Muraille's production of The Studhorse Man.

C252   Kamboureli, Smaro. "A Poem out of Love: An Interview with Robert Kroetsch on The Sad Phoenician." Open Letter, [Essays on Robert Kroetsch], Ser. 5, Nos. 8-9 (Summer-Fall 1984), pp.47-52. In order for language to "stay alive it must be in a state of civil unrest, the kind of contradiction that's implicit in the yoking of those two words." Kroetsch describes the move toward the oral tradition: "We're trying to demystify the written word and that takes us aback to the Egyptians' or whoever's wall. The wall was permanent. You couldn't turn it the way you turn a page, and it was superior to the reader in an absolute way. With the page the reader is in charge .... I feel that writing on the wall was often a denial of speech, while the page must offer a sense of speechness. A peachy speechiness."

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Books, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews and profiles, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Miscellaneous  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Miscellaneous

C256   Waddington, Miriam. "Signs." Saturday Night, Feb. 1972, p. 10. Rpt. (revised) in Driving Home: Poems New and Selected. By Miriam Waddington. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1972, pp. 10-11. Poem about Robert Kroetsch.

C257   Lane, Patrick. "Perhaps There Is Snow (for Robert Kroetsch)." Arts Manitoba, 2, No. 1 (Fall 1982), 67. Poem dedicated to Robert Kroetsch.

Source: Lecker, Robert (compiler); . Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch, Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987. pp. 291-397 ; Lecker, Robert (editor). David, Jack (editor). Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors ; no. 7 ISBN: 0920763111 (hardcover); 092076312X (paperback), Book ID: ABCMA07RKP2.
Item Number: ABCMA07RKP2000007003003006
Record: 80
Title:
Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Books, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews and profiles, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Theses and dissertations
Other Title:
Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Books, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews and profiles, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours

Reference Series

ABCMA07RKP2000007003003003

<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP2000007003003003&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Books, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews and profiles, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Theses and dissertations</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Books, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews and profiles, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Theses and dissertations  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Theses and Dissertations

C220   Cherewick, Janice Darlene. "A Pattern for the Prairie Novel: Romance Elements in Selected Prose of the Canadian West, 1930-1970." M.A. Thesis Alberta 1973. The Words of my Roaring is discussed in the final section of this thesis. Cherewick outlines the numerous "allusions to the suffering and humiliation evoked in Psalm 22 .... "The novel, like the Psalm, is based on "metamorphosis" Johnnie Backstrom is transformed from an object of ridicule "into a god-like figure." Despite this transformation, Johnnie "roars with very real human pain" so that the novel "is a compromise.., between metamorphosis and mimesis," between "romance and realism." Cherewick discusses Kroetsch's use of the prairie setting, which he knows "intimately" and "recreates with precision, economy and efficiency." She also points to Kroetsch's awareness of the "transience and innate futility of mortal endeavour on the abiding prairie ...." Johnnie is a "radically human" character and proof of Kroetsch's "insight into the real nature of prairie dwellers." Johnnie is not entirely realistic, however; he is endowed with a "surrealist sensibility" which allows for a dream-like dimension, romantic possibilities. He is linked with God, as if privy to divine dictates, so that Kroetsch must use "ironic deflation" to bring the tall-tale telling Backstrom down to earth. Johnnie Backstrom possesses dimensions that are "larger than life; but his imperfect humanness is fully apparent."

C221   Fuchs, Terrence David. "Larger-Than-Life: Robert Kroetsch's Out West Trilogy." M.A. Thesis Waterloo 1974. The Words of my Roaring, The Studhorse Man, and Gone Indian are bound together by "their vitality, their gusto, their exuberance." Fuchs finds an energy in the novels that affects Kroetsch's "style and voice and shapes and directs the technique and form of his narrative .... Kroetsch's trilogy is a major work for the twentieth century, and for Canada ... Kroetsch's protagonists function against a Fate that seems to nullify their actions as individuals." Hazard Lepage, Johnnie Backstrom, and Jeremy Sadness are rebels. Hazard rebels against "technological mechanisms ... which render the sexual impulse obsolete" and "champions the normal sexuality of man and beast." Jeremy Sadness rebels against "the urban values" which society has striven to establish since the Industrial Revolution, and heads west to Alberta. Backstrom rebels against "failure," the "unreliability of the land," and the "monetary crisis" of the Depression. The protagonists' urge toward freedom and assertion against the false order of things creates a great energy in the novels. Kroetsch's use of myth and tall tale are means of expressing this energy and the immense Prairie setting. "The natural response to the environmental contingencies of the West are the gargantuan appetites and enthusiasms which Kroetsch's characters possess -- and which frequently possess them .... Johnnie Backstrom and Hazard Lepage are typical of the West Robert Kroetsch paints. Johnnie Backstrom's appetites generally are prodigious and Hazard Lepage's energy is typified by his sexual conduct .... These characters are larger-than-life bespeaking the environment in which they live." In contrast, Jeremy Sadness is smaller, weaker than the life that the West demands. All three characters have a large purpose, however. "The energy of Kroetsch's protagonists is aggressive, questing, longing, and an appropriate part of the vigour of life in a frontier environment."

C222   Thompson, Eric Callum. "The Prairie Novel in Canada: A Study of Changing Form and Perception." Diss. New Brunswick 1974. The history of Prairie literature is traced. Kroetsch is discussed in Chapter vi, "Land of Horizons" as a fabulist "creating an imaginative land of many horizons" Thompson discusses But We Are Exiles, The Words of my Roaring, and The Studhorse Man as comic fabulation. In The Studhorse Man, the most advanced of the three, Kroetsch is able "to burlesque the picaresque form itself; to invoke and parody the tall-tale tradition of western adventure; and to satirize sexuality and sanity and other death-outwitting fantasies of modern man."

C223   Alexander, Laura E. "Kroetsch's Tragicomic Romance: The Out West Trilogy." M.A. Thesis McMaster 1975. "Kroetsch discovers a symbolic richness in the seemingly empty vastness of the prairie landscape. In his trilogy, ... [The Words of my Roaring, The Studhorse Man, and Gone Indian,] the prairie is a landscape of elementals. Here the human being is confronted by uninterrupted space. The earth appears to stretch from one vacant horizon to another; the sky is a vacuum." In the novels, the gulf "between man's desires and his achievements" is a source of satire. The protagonists of these novels "are overwhelmed by a sense of their own insignificance." The three works present different aspects of the same essential theme; "the failure of existing myth in contemporary society." They explore "three major myth-making forces in Western culture -- the Christian religion, classical civilization, and the discovery of the New World."

C224   Harrison, Richard Terrence. "The Unhoused Imagination: The Struggle for Imaginative Survival in Prairie Fiction." Diss. Western Ontario 1975. Kroetsch is discussed in Chapter VI, "Time and Distance." Robert Kroetsch, like Rudy Wiebe and Margaret Laurence, encounters an internal, rather than external, Prairie space. He must, therefore, turn from traditional preoccupations with space and direct himself toward time, placing himself in the Prairie past.

C225   Gibson, James. "The Quest for Order in the Novels of Robert Kroetsch." M.A. Thesis Manitoba 1976. "The quest motif appears prominently in... [Kroetsch's] first novel, But We Are Exiles, and is of central concern also in the novels of his Gone West trilogy -- The Words of my Roaring, The Studhorse Man, and Gone Indian .... the quest engaged in by the protagonists of Kroetsch's works is essentially a quest for a clearer 'naming,' that is, an attempt to define the conditions of existence." Gibson devotes a chapter to each of the above novels and focuses on the quest for "self-definition" which each novel illustrates. He connects the four novels and shows them to represent the development in their author. Gibson points out that most of Kroetsch's protagonists fail in their "quest for clearer 'naming.'" They remain exiles lost, like Demeter Proudfoot, "... in a labyrinth of file cards .... Fortunately, Johnny Backstrom and Jeremy Sadness provide evidence of constructive naming, and their examples suggest that exile does not have to be the perpetual state of Kroetsch's protagonists. Each protagonist encounters a "spiritual wasteland" where "... there is always in the background the spectre of death which ultimately unnames all, there is also, in the foreground, the comic figure of man, the compulsive name-caller." This condition is, however, "... amenable to reordering through redefinition:' This redefinition is the goal of the quest, the grail, which "... inspires the transformation of the exile into the initiate who ... becomes the centre of his own society ...."

C226   Watson, Leah. "The Thematic Significance of Point-of-View in the Novels of Robert Kroetsch." M.A. Thesis Saskatchewan 1977. "Kroetsch is an experimenter with the form of the novel," and "... his work displays a continual attempt to make form an embodiment of theme." In this discussion of how "Kroetsch has become increasingly more convinced of the importance of form," Watson examines But We Are Exiles, The Words of my Roaring, The Studhorse Man, Gone Indian, and Badlands.

C227   Harvey, Constance. "'Verily, I Insist: I Did Not Raise the Purple Crow': Evolution of Voice in the Novels of Robert Kroetsch." M.A. Thesis Carleton 1978. "Kroetsch believes that the creative process involves exposing the underlying assumptions and the repressed elements of perception and existence -- 'uninventing' or 'renaming' -- and, through that act, reinventing a vision that is more responsive to the dialectics of existence -- for Kroetsch, the comic-ironic vision." Kroetsch's novels are "attempts to articulate a vision of existence and of literature." Harvey focuses on voice in Kroetsch's The Words of my Roaring, The Studhorse Man, Gone Indian, and Badlands. Harvey examines the manner in which Kroetsch seeks "a voice that would translate his experience as a Canadian and a Westerner into form and language." Harvey also examines the response that this voice elicits in "the two functions of literature that Kroetsch perceives: the aesthetic function, that is, the internal patterning of the novel, and the vital function, that is, the relationship between the novel and the reader." Harvey devotes a chapter to each of the four novels and a chapter to Kroetsch's early short stories in order to trace the development of Kroetsch's quest for voice.

C228   Lecker, Robert. "Time and Form in the Contemporary Canadian Novel." Diss. York 1979. Lecker studies the handling of time in relation to seven Canadian novels: The Swing in the Garden, by Hugh Hood; The Temptations of Big Bear, by Rudy Wiebe; The Disinherited, by Matt Cohen; The Invention of the World, by Jack Hodgins; The New Ancestors, by Dave Godfrey; Trou de Memoire, by Hubert Aquin. Chapter five, "The Uninvention of the World," is devoted to this topic in The Studhorse Man. Kroetsch is among those authors whose view of time reveals an increasing scepticism about man's ability to order time and about the need to order time.

C229   Kuester, Martin. "Narrative Structure in the Contemporary Canadian Novel." Staatsexamen Thesis Trier [Germany] 1983. Kuester examines Kroetsch's Post-Modernism in terms of "Narrative Situation," "Textual Self-Consciousness, Metafiction," "Myth Structure: Bricolage," "Spatial Form: Connection of Fragments in the Architectonic Novel," and a "Summary of the Formal Aspects of Postmodernism." He presents the "General Structure," an "Analysis," and a summary of the Post-Modern aspects in But We Are Exiles, The Words of my Roaring, The Studhorse Man, Gone Indian, Badlands, and What the Crow Said. "The Different Layers of Narrative" are examined in But We Are Exiles; "Narrative Situation and Bricolage Structure," "Film Structure," and "Tall Tales" are examined in Badlands; and "The Narrative Situation of Magic Realism" and "Metafiction" are examined in What the Crow Said. The "Structural Characteristics of Kroetsch's Novels" are "Narrative Situation," "Metafiction" "Bricolage Structure ... Parody," and "Non-Causal Connections" Kuester includes a Bibliography at the end.

C230   Harris, Beverly. "Dissonance in Practice and in Theory: Robert Kroetsch's Field Notes." M.A. Thesis Calgary 1984. "The contemporary Canadian long poem is a poetry of consequence which resists conventional modes of exegesis: this hypothesis provides the starting point for ... [Harris'] study of Kroetsch's continuing long poem, Field Notes. Field Notes is a work which flaunts discontinuities, as well as deliberately disguising poetic voice. It discourages traditional critical examinations of poetic symbol, metaphoric pattern, motif, and mythical system." Harris identifies the "competing modes of narrative ... the fragment and the list, and competing sources of narrative voice ... the document and the tale." The dissonance which arises from these competing modes of expression is Harris' focus.

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; Advice to My Friends  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Advice to My Friends

D118      Sutherland, Fraser. "Company and the Lonely Life of Poetry." Rev. of Oab I and Oab 2, by Robert Zend; and Advice to My Friends, by Robert Kroetsch. The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 14 Dec. 1985, Books: Literary Supplement, p. E19. Kroetsch shows "great lyrical strengths in this book .... But such flights thud to earth ...." "Letters to Salonika" "sets a new low for embarrassing uxoriousness. We are also given ingroup chatter and social notes ...." "Postcards from China .... is almost as bad, though relieved by gastronomical asides. Elsewhere, Kroetsch abundantly shows that he shares the contemporary penchant for marginalia and intertextuality .... These, along with the home movies, boring letters and travelogues, make for the weakest portions of the book. It's sad to see a writer of Kroetsch's great gifts descend to maudlinity and clubbiness."

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP2000007003004018&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; Alberta</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; Alberta  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Alberta

D130     Caston, Doug. "Edson Lawyer's Cousin Writes Interesting Book on Alberta and This Area." Edson Leader, 27 Nov. 1968, p. 11. All the chapters on Alberta were well and literally set down. Caston is intrigued with the names of families known in the Edson area. Caston found a native son in Kroetsch and "a well summed up point of view from a Yank university."

D131     Woodcock, George. Rev. of Alberta. Canadian Literature, No. 39 (Winter 1969), p. 103. "The manner is sheer journalese, cosy and breathless by turn, and most irritating to read, particularly as much time is wasted with completely uninteresting personal experiences."

D132     Preshing, William. "Robert Kroetsch's Book Captures Province's Vastness and Variety." Western Catholic Reporter [Edmonton], 9 Feb. 1969, p. 3. Alberta is a straight-forward and prosaic interpretation. Kroetsch did a reasonably good job despite his bias. The personal element intrudes into the descriptive aspects of the book. There is emphasis on rural areas, with a lack of coverage for some areas. The book has a place in Alberta homes. The article is accompanied with a full page of photographs of Alberta.

D133     Mandel, Eli. Rev. of Alberta. University of Toronto Quarterly, 38 (July 1969), 401-02. Mandel sees Alberta as a "present-tense book," the result of Kroetsch's attention to narrative detail. The author's personal and direct style admits the legendary, the esoteric, and the anecdotal. However, the book suffers because bits of random information are "scattered like debris throughout the mixture."

D134     Archer, J.H. Rev. of Alberta. Queen's Quarterly, 76 (Autumn 1969), 551-52. Alberta offers a travel book treatment by a native returning to Alberta. Kroetsch writes as a tourist reporting. Archer questions Kroetsch's assertions that the religious fundamentalism evident in Alberta was born of the depression and that Aberhart's attempts to apply social credit were frustrated by "'a trick of history.'" The book reveals as much about the author's changed point of view as about the changed provincial scene. Archer evaluates the topics chosen. Alberta is about cities, not agriculture. It provides an introduction to individuals, but others remain anonymous. Alberta is compared with Edward McCourt's Saskatchewan. These are the first two books of the travel series, "The Traveller's Canada." Kroetsch treats Alberta as a wonderful tourist resort where one meets interesting individuals at various parks or in cities. He writes as a visitor describing the scenes he saw. He uses conversations and description which is over-enthusiastic and banal. There are vignettes of local celebrities. Kroetsch presents interesting and informative views on William Aberhart.

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Record: 83
Title:
Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; Alibi
Other Title:
Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews
Record Type:
Reference Series
Series Title:
Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors, no. 7
Author(s):
Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Authors discussed:  KROETSCH, Robert; KROETSCH, Robert -- Criticism & interpretation -- Bibliography
Titles critiqued:  ALIBI (Book)

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP2000007003004008&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; Alibi</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; Alibi  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Alibi

D67       Fitzgerald, Judith. "The Wolf in Sheep's Clothing Looks for a Spa." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 27 Aug. 1983, Sec. Entertainment, p. 15. Alibi is "a rich and complex narrative that reads with deceptive ease." The novel, which is simultaneously the story of Dorf, a quest-story, and a mystery-story, unfolds in "soul-searching and heart-searing language." while plot orchestration and language attest to the novelist's "tremendous skill and sensitivity." Kroetsch's "penchant for repetition for its own sake" may be seen as "the one tiny fault in this otherwise flawless achievement."

D68       MacFarlane, David. "Outpourings of a Leaky Imagination." Maclean's, 29 Aug. 1983, p. 51. In Alibi, "... Kroetsch is not so much interested in weaving a story as in preparing a syllabus of essay topics for undergraduate students of Canadian literature. Alibi is about bathing, healing, curing, purifying, cleansing, drinking, sweating, ejaculating and vomiting. Lest anyone forget his grand theme of liquids, Kroetsch dispenses with almost everything else between the two covers." Alibi is a failed imitation of Thomas Pynchon's work, with intentions that are "so obvious, self-conscious and finally irritating that Kroetsch's humour is, to say the least, as flat as day-old ginger ale."

D69       Manguel, Alberto. "No Excuses: Despite Occasional Glimmers, in His New Novel Robert Kroetsch Fails to Live Up to the Quality His Intended Story Requires." Books in Canada, Oct. 1983, pp. 20-22. "'Alibi can be defined as a parodic quest in which neither the language, nor the characters nor the story itself, is convincing." It is "a parody of the James Bond films," which is "the root of Alibi's failure as a novel." This is a male story "in the sense of being uni-sexual, of focusing entirely on a stereotyped version of what a male's fantasies and desires are supposed to be." Alibi exhibits the "spy-story technique," but "does not live up to the reader's expectations .... in the end, the story makes no sense."

D70       Clark, David. "Water on the Brain." Saturday Night, Nov. 1983, pp. 74-75. "To be human, Kroetsch's novel suggests, is never to achieve the unself-conscious stupidity that Dorf envies in the octopus; it is to live life along the pulses, with all the peril that implies, inventing and reinventing the world as Dorf does when he writes the journal that makes up Alibi." It is interesting that "... Kroetsch has sabotaged his narrator but not his narrator's discoveries" Kroetsch "gives us a beautifully written story of strange tensions and suggestive ambiguities, as befits a diagnosis of the disease called man."

D71       Conklin, Jamie. Rev. of Alibi. Quill & Quire, Dec. 1983, p. 26. Although Alibi displays Kroetsch's "strong flair for comic episodes" the novel is flawed. "Kroetsch imports considerable mythological baggage into the story, and the resulting heroic dimension sits uncomfortably alongside the characters and events depicted" Alibi is marred by Kroetsch's frequent use of "archaic phrases" and "unlikely and platitudinous dialogue." The novel's "unremitting obsession with sex is oddly theoretical."

D72       Sward, Robert. "'Find Me a Spa, Dorf .... '" Cross-Canada Writers" Quarterly, 6, No. 3 (1984), 9, 32. The prose style of Alibi is "jaunty, sassy, freewheeling, sexy, compelling, innovative, ribald, self-indulgent, irritating, appealing and readable." Although Kroetsch is a "wonderfully gifted writer and a fine storyteller" Alibi is "something of a disappointment" in that Doff does not emerge as a convincing character. Tbe other characters are "one-dimensional" and must compete with Dorf's "first person account of his adventures and the extreme focus of Dorf's attention on Dorf." Although flawed, Alibi is still "a hard book to put down."

D73       York, Thomas. Rev. of Alibi. The Malahat Review [Univ. of Victoria], No.67 (Feb. 1984), pp. 132-33. The "obsessive centre [of Alibi] is in the liberation attendant on divorce .... There is no love in this novel, or poignancy of love lost. It is written from the glands, but it is well-written." Alibi depicts "male menopausal desire: its sensibility mid-forties male; its narrative tone combative and aggrieved; its attitude toward women condescending." York considers Alibi "to be a message from the 1960's, and not particularly appropriate for the 1980's."

D74       Mills, John. Rev. of Alibi. West Coast Review [Simon Fraser Univ.], 18, No.4 (April 1984), 57-60. "Alibi fails, in my opinion, because the conceptions behind it are not strongly worked out nor vehemently felt. Nothing in the book comes over as mattering very much and the generally feeble language and weak imaginative structure reflect this." Mills compliments Kroetsch's vivid and competent sense of place, which "is certainly the best thing in it." Kroetsch's novel "ought not to be judged in the conventional terms of plot, theme, characterization, narrative," but Mills questions whether Kroetsch has replaced the conventions with something valid. Kroetsch asserts a "pattern of sub-Christian images" with great "forcefulness," but, due to Kroetsch's language use, he fails in his aim.

D75       Tadich, Alex. "One Gutsy Novelist." The Calgary Sunday Sun, 20 May 1984, p. S2. Alibi "is really about the meaning of life and sex, and reads a bit like J.D. Salinger's Catcher in the Rye." Kroetsch is a "gutsy novelist" because he dares to write about Calgary. Tadich applauds Kroetsch's loyalty to his Alberta roots and boasts that Kroetsch works "hard to get a local flavour for his novels. Kroetsch has gone white water rafting and looking for dinosaur bones in Alberta's Badlands." Although writing about Calgary is not economically advantageous, "... we've got to thank writers like Kroetsch for trying."

D76       MacKendrick, Louis K. "Words Seeking the Single Life." NeWest Review, June 1984, p. 4. "Alibi has a greater philosophical, even spiritual, depth than Kroetsch's previous novels, in spite of the offsetting contrariness, self-consciousness, even zaniness of its narrator." The novel's "motifs work together and merge on a level of virtually poetic correspondence; symbols and metaphors, by not always being completely specific in value, naturally have a greater range of association." Dorf's quest for the perfect spa is the quest for an "authentic personality." In the mud spa in Greece, Dorf's "personality becomes unified and he becomes generous, understanding, unpressured, open, and in rapture returns to an ur-human condition of inspired clay." Dorf, whose "life has been an alibi for not being himself," becomes "whole, free to collect himself, freed from bondage to another's whim, newly and remarkably free of rhetoric, and free to enjoy the health which Alibi has argued in metaphor and meditation throughout."

D77       Hoy, Helen. "Letters in Canada: 1983. Fiction." University of Toronto Quarterly, 53 (Summer 1984), 329-30. Alibi "celebrates ... connectedness, healing contact with hands and earth, and the essential 'complicities of love' from which one needs an airtight alibi to exempt oneself." Despite "all its sexual highjinks -- of imagery and action -- and its championing of desire, the book is curiously unsensual .... sex is in the service of ideas; it is metaphoric, not real. The lurking mistrust of desire may extend beyond Dorf to the novel itself. So the pursuit of the fantastic sexual image becomes forced, a kind of bravado, and the story itself coolly cerebral, emotionally unpersuasive."

D78       Palmer, Jill. Rev. of Alibi. Scrivener [McGill Univ.], 5, No. 2 (Summer 1984), 33. Alibi is "unusual, innovative, even selfindulgent" and "shows Kroetsch in an increasingly daring light." Palmer defends Kroetsch's "apparent preoccupation with [his character] Bill Dorfen's sexual tendencies" since Dorfen's "exploits only exploit himself, rather than women .... His sex drive is hilarious and ludicrous, rather than belittling," and part of his physical and material search. The character is led through a "destructuralizing, demystifying, demythologizing course of events on a quest for an unobtainable idea .... Kroetsch probes once again at a past that cannot be changed, nor recaptured, and a present that relies on retrieving reality rather than fantasy."

D79       Hutcheon, Linda. "Double Vision." Canadian Literature, No. 102 (Autumn 1984), pp. 76-80. Hutcheon examines double voicing, double names, double lives, and the collector as "artist," "discoverer" and "conqueror." As in John Fowles The Collector, "Here, collecting is still lethal, but it is also an attack on randomness; it is a way of coping with time past ... it is a means of 'acting out reality.' In all these functions, collecting becomes, for Dorf, a metaphoric surrogate for writing .... Dorf's two lives are separated by his realization that he is capable of killing someone." This is "a paradoxical novel that, on one level, is a bawdy and amusing romp. Yet, the deliberate echo of [James] Joyce's 'The Dead' ... signals to the reader that this story will also be one about loving, living, and dying. As in the poetry of [W.B.] Yeats and [T.S.] Eliot, ambivalence is the key to interpreting the dominant imagery of earth and water: both are sources of life and death .... The underlying duality, however, is a basic and familiar one -- that of body and soul." Kroetsch recalls the "Latin meaning of alibi: elsewhere. Perhaps there is also an allusion to [William M.] Thackeray's 'Women are not so easily cured by the alibi treatment,' for Julie is not allowed a cure or an alibi .... The imagery involving sex and woman in the novel is always doubled or ambivalent .... " The novel includes "a parodic inversion of Ulysses and the Cyclops," and Doffs violation echoes "the male rape scene in ... [Timothy] Findley's The Wars .... The doubled or twice written story ends with ... a memory and a metaphor .... To leave one's mark on the landscape or on the page is to court death, as Kroetsch explored in What the Crow Said. Writing fixes and kills, but like collecting, it can also offer a means to new life through art." Dorfs "final words ... suggest some resolution, but it is one that must come from acceptance of ambivalence. Quests in modern literature do not always lead to one answer .... The final duality we are left with is the novelist's eternal obsession: that of art and life."

D80       Conklin, Jamie. "System Unsystem." Rev. of Labyrinths of Voice: Conversations with Robert Kroetsch, by Shirley Neuman and Robert Wilson; and Alibi, by Robert Kroetsch. Brick [Ilderten, Ont.], No. 24 (Spring 1985), pp. 10, 12-13. "It seems to me that though Alibi may not be Kroetsch's best novel, it deserves to be read and understood for what it is .... the version of the quest story found in Alibi involves a narrator searching for a voice .... Dorf is quite self-consciously assuming the role of a narrator of a work of fiction." As Dorf tells his story, he "is transformed into a rather boorish literary creature .... Dorf, seduced by the power he finds at the centre of his narration, begins to utter pronouncements." He becomes a "smug, self-important, pompous" "literary theorist." Dorf becomes "Kroetsch's agent: bent on subverting metaphor with metonymy, on undermining a singular meaning with fragmented meanings ...." Given its narrative complexities, "... Alibi be read as a mystery, as a quest for eternal youth, as a quest for personal meaning," and as an examination of narrative convention.

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.
