Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; Badlands  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Badlands

D47      MacSkimming, Roy. "Dazzling Writer Offers a Lunatic Comic Saga." The Toronto Star, 27 Sept. 1975, p. F7. "Badlands is written in Faulknerian tones of grandeur and wonder, almost burlesque in their formality, and yet sustains a beautiful evocation of that desert-like, south-Albertan landscape of buttes and clays, wolf willow and cottonwood, sage and sky." Kroetsch is one novelist who has succeeded in fashioning a Canadian mystique -- something that compels the mind and the gut, something mythic yet rooted in a familiar reality. The ethos is masculine and Western. The characters are tough, symbolic, quixotic fools. Kroetsch is a prodigiously comic and dazzlingly unpredictable novelist. This is a picaresque saga that would make a sensational film.

D48      Thomas, Peter. "The Stud at Bay; Like His Predecessors, Kroetsch's Latest Hero is a Sexual Bonehead with a Chaotic Mission." Books in Canada, Oct. 1975, pp. 13-14. Badlands is another example of Kroetsch's preoccupation with man's attempt "to conquer time and mortality by asserting his vital sexual self." Although some of the humour seems forced and overly sentimental, Badlands is a solid novel, but not as successful as Gone Indian.

D49      Simpson, Leo. "Dense, Lofty, Complex -- and Slightly Cheap." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 1 Nov. 1975, p. 35. Simpson criticizes the design as hideous, garish, and cheap. It suggests pulp fiction and looks like a cheapie western of 1941. Badlands is a lofty and complex novel, as well as an extremely ambitious and successful achievement. The emphasis is on characters who are larger than life, familiar, all unique, in command of their own obsessions, selfish, tormented, driven people, and destructive of those who love them. The writing is demanding and opaque: it conceals what it describes. There are long passages of repetition, introspection, and incantation. Kroetsch captured the actual character of the Red River badlands, the "character" in the book that was most important to him.

D50      Nodelman, Perry. "Books: Heaven of Darkness." Winnipeg Free Press, 8 Nov. 1975, p. 16. Nodelman compares the Americans in a bad American movie with Canadians whose landscape conquers men. The characters are captured by the Badlands, even lost to it. This is a good novel in which Kroetsch discovers the mythical dimensions inherent in ordinary human behaviour. Badlands reveals the influence of William Faulkner. It is not a big novel, but interesting despite its sleazy newsprint and is a bargain.

D51      MacSkimming, Roy. "Holiday Books: A Gift Guide: Literary Someone Gets Fiction." The Toronto Star, 29 Nov. 1975, p. F7. Badlands is a "Sophisticated, dead-pan comic saga." It is another quest for the father.

D52      Ramsey, R.H. "Questing for Origins." The Canadian Forum, Dec.-Jan. 1975-76, p. 55. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, Short Story Writers, Filmmakers, Scriptwriters, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Sharon R. Gunton and Jean C. Stine. Vol. XXIII. Detroit: Gale, 1983, 271-72. Ramsey interprets Dawe's voyage westward as an "epic descent" and Dawe himself as an unreliable narrator who is "obsessed with the past." Although Kroetsch's particular blend of the actual and the mythical makes the book appealing, it is marred by the style, which "reads like a deliberate and sustained parody of Faulkner."

D53      Bradbury, Maureen. Rev. of Badlands. Canadian Book Review Annual: 1975. Ed. Dean Tudor, Nancy Tudor, and Linda Biesenthal. Toronto: PMA, 1976, p. 103. The voyage down the Red Deer River suggests thematic parallels with the Odyssey. This in itself is promising, but "... the trip is excessively long ..." in Badlands, and the novel is further weakened by the presence of "a motley array of characters" who remain under-developed.

D54      Russell, Nancy. "On Books: Expedition into Badlands Compelling Novel." Star-Phoenix [Saskatoon], 9 Jan. 1976, p. 15. Badlands is a compelling novel. The main character is unbearable. It is a book of destruction, obsession, and hatred; also a book of building passion and love touched with a humour that keeps it believable.

D55      Sylvestre, Reg. "Strange Creatures Kroetsch as Novelist." NeWest Review, Jan. 1976, p. 8. Kroetsch has an incredible devotion to detail and to realistic geographic descriptions. Badlands has the hazy credibility of a mirage. Sylvestre briefly notes that, as an adventure novel, it is remythologizing the West. It is an anti-war novel, a microcosm of the heartless commanders, the vain heroes, the patient survivors, the wise deserters, the murdered youth. Kroetsch attempts to explore the behaviouristic differences in men and women. Men are fools for their grand plans, their solitude. Women are fools for waiting for their solitude. Badlands has unknown meanings, with puzzles as strange as those which took men to the badlands for bones.

D56      Ricou, Laurie. Rev. of Badlands. Quill & Quire, Feb. 1976, p. 38. The novel has an intricate interrelationship of meanings which defies brief examination. Its "fictional technique.., is drawn from field notes .... "It is a "gruesome and wild comedy, ... man is essential spirit; eternity is a moment; like Dawe we are 'cured of nothing but death, of everything but death.'"

D57      Struthers, J.R.(Tim). "She Found Her Freedom Following Father's Trail." London Free Press, 21 Feb. 1976, p. 49. Badlands has a double narrative; a double quest, with reverberations of meaning. It is a fictive kaleidoscope made into a convincing pattern. This is a story of damnation and redemption. The search for a lost father is a search for the self. The quest involves a Doppelganger (Anna Dawe and Anne Yellowbird).

D58      "Book Banter: Resident Writer." The Lethbridge Herald, 30 April 1976, p. 16. Badlands is another zany and hilarious novel about Alberta. It is an adventure novel with a Prairie mythology, plays-on words, and raunchy sex. Badlands is about a haunting search for the source of life.

D59      Geddes, Gary. "Kroetsch Is a Greedy Researcher, but Field Notes Fall Before Lyrics and Love Letters:' Rev. of Badlands and The Stone Hammer Poems: 1960-1975. The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 1 May 1976, p. 39. Badlands is an example of "the documentary impulse" in Canadian art. Kroetsch is compared with Pratt (Towards the Last Spike): "Both writers are steeped in classical literature and mythology ...," inspired by "the mock heroic tradition of the eighteenth century." They are concerned with "the trivia of the external world" and the problem of interpreting that into art.

D60      James, W.D. Rev. of Badlands, by Robert Kroetsch; The Sentence, by Jeffrey Konvitz; and Psyche, by Phyllis Brett Young. The Heritage [Picton, Amherstview, Ont.], 16 June 1976, p. 2. Kroetsch is one of Canada's leading exponents of the "stream of consciousness" novel. Badlands is incoherent, yet forceful, compelling, and shocking. Kroetsch is a "Guru of the Groin." The unbelievable expedition represents an allegorical parallel to mankind's fumbling progress towards infinity -- pointless and ineffectual. Kroetsch follows the narrow, sterile path of ugliness and degradition which so many modern authors insist on presenting as truth. That Kroetsch refuses to admit that flowers exist as well as weeds is "the reader's loss."

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Title:
Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; But We Are Exiles
Other Title:

<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP2000007003004001&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; But We Are Exiles</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; But We Are Exiles  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Selected Book Reviews

But We Are Exiles

D1     Gelmon, Joseph N. "Cool and Simple Plot, But People Sterile." The Globe Magazine [The Globe and Mail] [Toronto], 18 Dee. 1965, p. 19. The plot sounds "silly," but it is not "a bad idea." Kroetsch reveals a good understanding of his material. He depicts human motivations against a raw background of stark nature. The book "fails to come off" despite his coolness due to the fact that his characters fail. "They're too obviously laboratory exercises."

D2     Rev. of But We Are Exiles. St. Martin's Books for Fall. New York: St. Martin's, 1965, p. 8. A stirring novel of guilt and absolution in the Canadian wilderness. It introduces a novelist of mature power and depth.

D3     Kroetsch, Robert. Rev. of But We Are Exiles. Library Journal, 1 Feb. 1966, p. 729. A divided interest between the wilderness and civilization is the principal theme of the novel according to Kroetsch. A second novel is scheduled for release in the fall. See B145.

D4     Gregson, Lillian. "Books 'n Stuff." Rev. of But We Are Exiles, by Robert Kroetsch; and A Businessman Looks at Red China, by James S. Duncan. The De Kalb New Era Record [Decatur, Ga.], 3 March 1966, p. 5. The love triangle plot is somewhat hackneyed. A fascinating river is the attention-absorbing feature of the story. The review is offered as restitution by an American columnist for the general lack of attention to Canadian books.

D5     Levin, Martin. "A Reader's Report." Rev. of The Eagle and His Egg, by Mark Rascovich; Goodbye to the Hill, by Lee Dunne; But We Are Exiles, by Robert Kroetsch; The Ballad of Dingus Magee, by David Markson; and Bay of Traitors, by Garland Roark. The New York Times Book Review, 13 March 1966, p. 38. The setting is reminiscent of one of Eugene O'Neill's gloomy scows. Kroetsch "is not as solid in explaining the motives behind Peter's six year hiatus and his ambivalent inner feelings as he is in depicting the hair-raising voyage."

D6     Clarkson, Paul R. Rev. of But We Are Exiles. Best Sellers [Univ. of Scranton, Pa.], 1 April 1966, pp. 11-12. Rpt. in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, Short Story Writers, Filmmakers, Scriptwriters, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Sharon R. Gunton and Jean C. Stine. Vol.XXIII Detroit: Gale, 1983, 269. "Deftly with subtle power, author Kroetsch communicates the sorry existence of characters adrift, lacking a purpose for living, assaulted from within and without." But We Are Exiles "is about a young man's flight from the entanglements, pressures, personal relationships and unplanned happening inherent in living."

D7     Kune, Hank. "Robert Kroetsch: The Dual Voice of Harpur's Resident Writer." The Colonial News, 8 April 1966, pp. 2-3. Kroetsch is not a celebrity, but is "a damn good" author and teacher, as well as the first published novelist from Harpur College, University of New York, Binghamton. He views the academic environment as no hindrance to inspiration. The writer must be part entertainer and part preacher. He is a story-teller like Faulkner or Hemingway. His voice is his own, but shows the influence of Conrad, Dickens, and Lowry. He enjoys reading the Romantics. But We Are Exiles is not a deep or a good story, but is a good novel with "immense style." Although not quite stream of consciousness, it is effective and powerful.

D8     Edinborough, Arnold. "New Canadian Fiction." Saturday Night, May 1966, pp. 47, 49. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, Short Story Writers, Filmmakers, Scriptwriters, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Sharon R. Gunton and Jean C. Stine. Vol. XXIII. Detroit: Gale, 1983, 269. "Though there are great moments in But We Are Exiles ... one wonders, with all that symbolism, what the fuss is really about."

D9     Frakes, James. "New Fiction: Troubled Waters." Book Week [The Washington Post], 19 June 1966, p. 12. The major problem of the book is "the uncertain characterization of the three leading figures": Hornyak, Kettle, and Peter. The minor figures (the crew, the cook and Kettle's father) "are all stamped with individuality .... The novel moves rapidly. Details are extremely selective, and Mr. Kroetsch knows when to summarize and when to dramatize." Like Melville, he is familiar with his subject -- "hard, convincing, and never [a] show-off." The love episode "may be more ludicrous than the author planned." Frakes praises the "obliquity, reserve power, and masculine humor" of But We Are Exiles.

D10    Watt, F.W. Rev. of But We Are Exiles. University of Toronto Quarterly, 35 (July 1966), 389-90. Watt notes that "... through the realistic detail runs a dark, turbulent plot which never quite clarifies itself."

D11    Biswas, Robindra. Rev. of But We Are Exiles. The Tamarack Review, No. 38 (Winter 1966), pp. 100-03. Kroetsch "packs an amazing multitudinousness" into the "severe slimness" of the volume, but "... the multitudinousness has succeeded only in obscuring and overwhelming." Due to "Kroetsch's unwillingness to distinguish between levels of significance, the issues have been refined into a thin blur of irrelevance." But We Are Exiles is "an original, thoughtful, able work" which has "serious flaws" causing it to be "unsatisfactory"

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; Creation

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP2000007003004004&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; Creation</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; Creation  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Creation

D33     Stratford, Philip. "A Fetus in Good Health." The Globe Magazine [The Globe and Mail] [Toronto], 27 March 1971, p. 37. Creation has a good title and is a "kind of literary club sandwich." The authors "share a kind of contained desperation about the future." The interviews should have been "bluepencilled." The whole experience is "prenatal."

D34     Harcourt, Joan. Rev. of Creation. Quarry, 20, No. 2 (Summer 1971), 60-62. The collection of excerpts is "a fascinating example of our national ambivalence." Kroetsch is caught in "the Canadian trap. He attempts to pit a somewhat raw vernacular ... against a sensitive acknowledgement of the immense landscape ...."

D35     Mandel, Eli. "Letters in Canada: 1970. Literary Studies." University of Toronto Quarterly, 40 (Summer 1971), 316-18. Mandel stresses the fact that Kroetsch was involved in "putting together a series of pieces intended both to reflect the process of creation and by its very incompleteness and imperfection to involve the reader in that process." Kroetsch's poems are "wiry and exact." His conversation with Margaret Laurence draws out an important theme of the book: "'... exiles return.'"

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

This content is intended solely for the use of the individual user.
Source: Lecker, Robert (compiler); . Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch, Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987. pp. 291-397 ; Lecker, Robert (editor). David, Jack (editor). Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors ; no. 7 ISBN: 0920763111 (hardcover); 092076312X (paperback), Book ID: ABCMA07RKP2.
Item Number: ABCMA07RKP2000007003004004
Record: 87
Title:
Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch
Other Title:
Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews
Record Type:
Reference Series
Series Title:
Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors, no. 7
Author(s):
Lecker, Robert (compiler)
Genre(s):
Bibliography
Subject(s):

<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP2000007003004013&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch

D106      Barbour, Douglas. "Kroetsch: A Poet of Rich, Comic Life. Rev. of Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch, by Robert Kroetsch; and Maggie, by Rosalind MacPhee. The Sunday Star [The Toronto Star], 21 June 1981, p. C10. Eli Mandel's "witty" and thorough Preface (C127) examines with precision Kroetsch's poetic structuring, the richness of his allusion, and the importance of "literary parody ... to this learned but in no way coldly academic poet." Kroetsch builds on "paradoxical oppositions ... the comic disjunctiveness of life and art." His work is complex and entertaining.

D107      Serafin, Bruce. "From the Raw to a Mosaic That's Art!". The Vancouver Sun, 26 June 1981, p. L36. To transform memory and surroundings into literature is to make them one's own. Many Canadian poets, "aching" to extract an indigenous art from a meager cultural and historical heritage, have "mythologized" Canada, "anthropomorphizecd" it, and "peopled [it] with angelic and demonic forces." Generally considered, their poetry has failed. With Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch, Kroetsch has succeeded. He rejects "drama," the "demonic, the mythical, the 'psychological'." He has absorbed Roland Barthes and Michel Butor and has emerged with a structural vision. The meaning of his work resides in the "arrangement and interaction" of "textual fragments" in the overall design. Kroetsch's writing is "dry and luminous," free of emotional manipulation, "saturated with an awareness of the tension that exists between the raw, heavy material of our culture and the transparency of art."

D108      Thomas, Peter. "Talking on the Run." The Canadian Forum, June-July 1981, pp. 36-38. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, Short Story Writers, Filmmakers, Scriptwriters, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Sharon R. Gunton and Jean C. Stine. Vol. XXIII. Detroit: Gale, 1983, 275-76. Eli Mandel's Preface to Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch (C127) is "sprightly and acute ... part of the act." The inclusion of Kroetsch's MLA address, "For Play and Entrance: The Contemporary Canadian Long Poem" (B130), though a "source text" for anyone involved in its subject, has, in this context, "an anti-climactic, even slightly bathetic impact." Kroetsch lives "in a binary world, where everything is capable of parody." The poetry is "full of puns, panic and a kind of impish nervous cackle as his own sexual absurdities afflict him, the Kroetsch persona inflates and self-deflates with compulsive, triumphant eloquence." Beginning with "Stone Hammer Poem," and expanding through all sections of the text, is Kroetsch's fascination with "the conflicting or perhaps adjacent claims of flight, quest, enlargement, fiction -- the world-self is an empire of possibility, of open forms w and origins, 'ground,' place, descent, mining the dark places for the motherlode." The poet recognizes that "... language ... must be renewed, rediscovered." There is "the option of silence .... But for the time being he accepts the Orphic paradox: word-men only opt-out into more language."

D109      Barbour, Douglas. "Robert Kroetsch in Review." Rev. of Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch, by Robert Kroetsch; and Robert Kroetsch, by Peter Thomas. NeWest Review, Oct. 1981, pp. 7, 10. Kroetsch approaches a truly personal voice, "a condition of nakedness," the present which "surrounds the very act of writing." The poetry shares the "duplicities" the "thematic baggage," the "rich and protean energy," and the formal innovation of the novels: "... while deeply serious in intent ... they [the poems] are marvelously entertaining."

D110      Moritz, Albert. "Scaffolds in Chaos: Robert Kroetsch's Selected Poems Reflect the Barren Newness of the Prairie, and the Poet's Struggle to Create a Self out of Its 'Absences.'" Books in Canada, Dee. 1981, pp. 21-22. Rpt. in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, Short Story Writers, Filmmakers, Scriptwriters, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Sharon R. Gunton and Jean C. Stine. Vol. XXIII. Detroit: Gale, 1983, 276-77. The nine long poems constituting Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch manifest a "gathering, selfreflexive awareness," which develops and intensifies "through all variations of style and form." The poet's search leads to "an agony of not finding," denied, in the later works, through "self-deprecation, irony, and ambiguity." Kroetsch criticizes and rejects the "presumption of innocence, this idealization of the poem," and satirizes "the self and the society that can do nothing more than dwell in its confusions." Ultimately, Kroetsch articulates the dilemma of the poet who perceives the contemporary void, yet finds himself unable or unwilling to "reject radically what he has radically criticized."

D111      Dyck, E.F. "The Place of Recursion in Poetry." Brick, No. 14 (Winter 1982), pp. 20, 21, 22, 23. Dyck fabricates a trio of critics, a critical essayist (Professor Platzl), and a critically inclined waitress with an infant named Diffy (for "Differance"), to act as participants in a satirical dialectic on the essential dynamic of Kroetsch's Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch. The central argument of Platzl's paper "The Place of Recursion in Poetry," is that "... 'place is a nest of words.'" In it, the poet lays the egg that is the poem; place "gains its power through recursion." Kroetsch's poems, however, are "secrets -- not nests or eggs -- in an essential way: if Platzl is right, then poetry is wrong, for poetry is the desire to repeat the essence of experiencing the secret, and any formula at once renders such desire superfluous" Ultimately, "... Platzl's theory is round, Kroetsch's game is a spiral ...."

D112      Suknaski, Andrew. "Out of Narayan to Bifrost/ the Word Arresting Entropy." Brick, No.14 (Winter 1982), pp. 5, 6, 16, 30, 31, 39, 44-45, 51, 54-55. Kroetsch, along with Eli Mandel, articulates a Post-Modern vocabulary: "duplicity, remembered place, dreamed place, naming (renaming), invent/reinvent, to begin again and origins. Nothing exists until you name it and write it all into existence for the first time .... it's the trick of the Old Coyote [Kroetsch] balancing the cosmic and terrestrial ledgers in the entropy/of [sic] energy dynamic of verticals and horizontals (Coyote shunning as much as possible the tyranny of the left hand margin) .... Seed Catalogue and The Ledger changed forever the molecular structure of the rafters in a poet's head." Kroetsch's search for "The Ledger of all ledgers" alludes to Platonic thought, and his "infinite regression of beginnings" has "glimmerings ... of a poet's post-Kantian logic .... R.K. balancing the binaries: earth/world of Dennis Lee's Savage Fields, J[ohn]. N[ewlove].'s 'twin and original' (as in 'Stone Hammer Poem' -- paleo-reality vis a vis frontier and contemporary reality), and cosmic (mythic?) in face of ordinary earth." Kroetsch is able to see "the possibility in art." He takes the obvious and reconstructs it "to deconstruct the intangible."

D113      Dempster, Barry. "In Review." Poetry Canada Review, 3, No. 3 (Spring 1982), 3. Field Notes l-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch is "vivid in its breadth and consummation"; it contains all. Kroetsch explores "the passage of time ... the growth of place," and writes about a history which uncompasses things local and personal, as well as "a universal philosophy of life and death." History is in constant flux, engendered by life's perpetual, undeniable cycles: "Nothing is as simple as it first appears."

D114      Kertzer, Jon. Rev. of Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch, by Robert Kroetsch; and Robert Kroetsch, by Peter Thomas. The Fiddlehead, No. 132 (April 1982), pp. 116-17. Kroetsch's fascination with narrative, evident in the novels and his "stories about storytelling," manifests itself on a more submerged level in the poetry. "The motion of time and change, the continuity of the living process, must be apprehended as a story, and even if that story is not told, its structure underlies the poem." Kroetsch is his own poetic hero: "... the implied narrative base for his lifelong poem is autobiography"; the poetry is about the act of writing itself. The poet sets disorder against traditional forms of order: "... he loves forms of allusion and parody which offer him the best of both worlds: his and ours." He is the "'anarchist' " who needs both order and freedom. This book is "confusing," yet "delightful." Kroetsch is "restlessly experimental," his metaphor rich and suggestive.

D115      Djwa, Sandra. "Letters in Canada: 1981. Poetry." University of Toronto Quarterly, 51 (Summer 1982), 353, 355. Kroetsch's Field Notes: 1-8. a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch "to some degree ... combines poems with fragments from journals." The word "'Notes' doubles as a description of the journal and of singing quality -- as in the 'raucous crow.' Kroetsch is amusing, witty, wry. A major technique in 'The Ledger' is ironic juxtaposition .... Here, as in his novels, he enjoys exploding traditional categories. Yet his underlying questions reveal a humanist rage for order."

D116      MacKendrick, Louis K. "The Gaited Sun, The Galloping Night: On Kroetsch." Rev. of Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch, by Robert Kroetsch; and Robert Kroetsch, by Peter Thomas. Essays on Canadian Writing, No.26 (Summer 1983), pp. 99-104. "In Field Notes, Kroetsch is always aware of semantic and syntactic ambiguities, in their high form as metaphor and in their low as crudely effective puns, for his sequences are often very oral. He is a conscious technician in a variety of forms, and even at his most seemingly offhand and colloquial, the effect is no less a function of his strongly schematic imagination." The "title itself, Field Notes, suggests... [Kroetsch's] dedication to a fertile ambiguity: composition by field, the pastoral, individual elements of song, sketches rather than completions:' Love, for Kroetsch, is "a major metaphorical interest through which his preoccupations may be understood." Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch is poem as process, as life.

Previous Entry in publication.

<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP2000007003004005&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; Gone Indian</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; Gone Indian  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Gone Indian

D36     Gutteridge, Don. "No Reservations" Books in Canada, April-May-June 1973, p. 55. The themes of the novel expand upon those in But We Are Exiles: "the clash between 'civilized' and instinctual man; the simultaneous attraction and repulsion of a natural world giving spirit to our emotional and instinctual lives while at the same time randomly destroying both those who love it and hate it." Kroetsch writes about life close to the myths of Canadian experience.

D37     Ricou, Laurie. Rev. of Gone Indian. Quill & Quire, April 1973, p. 10. "This is Kroetsch's most concentrated, most resonant novel. Only occasionally is its fluidity marred by the awkwardness of Madham's retelling Jeremy's story ...."

D38     Sorestad, Glen. Rev. of Gone Indian. Saskatchewan English Teachers" Association, Winter 1973-74, p. 62. Kroetsch is a major Canadian novelist. Gone Indian does not possess the strength and consistent reader involvement of The Studhorse Man. Hazard Lepage overshadows Jeremy Sadness. The reader expects more than Kroetsch can deliver. Mark Madham could have been excluded. Character is Kroetsch's forte. He reveals flashes of wit and a sense of the ludicrous or bizarre. He has awareness of the West, its history and Indian lore. Gone Indian is "worth reading," but Kroetsch has "failed to score."

D39     Smith, R. Fenwick "A Canadian Vision." The Malahat Review, No. 29 (Jan. 1974), pp. 133-36. Unlike many Canadian writers, Kroetsch cut through the "disguises of language" to explore the world "beyond the mirror." His deliberate search for a Canadian identity involves him in legends of the North American Indians. Simultaneously, Kroetsch is brilliantly ambiguous: like Swift's Gulliver: "... Jeremy moves in a hundred directions ...." His quest is "not only comic and tragic ... but visionary."

D40     MacLulich, T.D. Rev. of Gone Indian. Essays on Canadian Writing, No. 1 (Winter 1974), pp. 47-50. Kroetsch's "chief innovation has been, along with many other modern novelists, to remove even the appearance of rationality from the telling of his zany tale." Jeremy Sadness dissolves into the future by "going backwards in his mental outlook, by becoming an Indian."

D41     Stow, Glenys. Rev. of Gone Indian. Journal of Canadian Fiction, 3, No. 1 (Winter 1974), 93-95. Stow recounts the plot and presents a character analysis. The concept of death and rebirth, and of the transmutation related to such an experience, is the key to many of the complexities of the novel.

D42     Dickson, Lovat. "Stinging and Gentle. Kroetsch Touches a Jumping Nerve in Pursuit of Myth and Satire." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 5 May 1973, p. 37. "Two moods are constant in Kroetsch's work, humor of a savage, revulsive, Swiftian kind; and movement. His novels all have a picaresque theme." With its "sustained visionary passages" Gone Indian is "Canadian to the core."

D43     Margoshes, Dave. "Finding Salvation in Alberta: Tangled Up in a Myth." The Herald Magazine [The Calgary Herald], 8 June 1973, p. 6. This review debates whether Canada has myths or lacks them. Kroetsch appreciates Canadian myths and "sees in them an abundance of heroes." He "seizes upon the fascinating personage of Grey Owl" in Gone Indian. Jeremy is reborn or destroyed in the end. The wilderness is the "touchstone" of his transformation. The humour is "strained" when "... cuteness gets in the way of the narrative flow." Yet there is "a profound intelligence and wit at work here." Kroetsch is "saying something important about the human condition in general and life above the 49th parallel in particular."

D44     Wiebe, Rudy. "The Year of the Indian." Rev. of Across the Medicine Line, by C. Frank Turner; Wilderness Man, by Lovat Dickson; and Gone Indian, by Robert Kroetsch. Dalhousie Review, 54 (Spring 1974), 166. Wiebe notes that "Jeremy's silly act is a unified, comprehensible one which drives us towards understanding .... "He does not expand.

D45     Bessai, Diane. Rev. of Gone Indian. The Lakehead University Review, 7, No. 1 (Summer 1974), 156-59. Kroetsch transforms Alberta "into a crazy western Land of Oz" associated with a double theme of romance-reality. Through Jeremy's imagination we step into a nether-world of lost Blackfoot culture to "discover a new vein through which the reality of romance may emerge." In Madham, but also in Jeremy, we find a metaphorical representation of "the perennial dilemma of the writer's relation to his material."

D46     Brown, Russell M. "Freedom to Depart." Canadian Literature, No. 61 (Summer 1974), pp. 103-04. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Carolyn Riley and Phyllis Carmel Mendelson. Vol.v. Detroit: Gale, 1976, 221-22. Brown discusses Kroetsch's fascination with myth and symbol. The title suggests the book's dominant themes: "the North American fascination with and search for the Edenic, pastoral world; the novel's ironic play with urban man's romanticization of the Indian and the lost culture he represents; and finally its very serious play with the Indian trickster myth."

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; Letters to Salonika  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Letters to Salonika

D117      Hoy, Helen. "Letters in Canada: 1983. Fiction: 2." University of Toronto Quarterly, 53 (Summer 1984), 321. "Kroetsch's Letters to Salonika ... is a miniature Alibi Journal, two months' love letters composed during the writing of Alibi, evidence of Kroetsch's sometimes wearisome willingness to turn his life, including private references and intimate details, into art, into metaphor, into metaphor for art."

Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors ; no. 7 ISBN: 0920763111 (hardcover); 092076312X (paperback), Book ID: ABCMA07RKP2.
Item Number: ABCMA07RKP2000007003004014
Record: 90
Title:
Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; Robert Kroetsch: Essays [Open Letter, Ser.5, No.4 (Spring 1983)]
Other Title:
Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews
Record Type:
Reference Series
Series Title:
Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors, no. 7
Author(s):
Lecker, Robert (compiler)
Genre(s):
Bibliography
Subject(s):
Authors discussed:  KROETSCH, Robert; KROETSCH, Robert -- Criticism & interpretation -- Bibliography
Titles critiqued:  ROBERT Kroetsch: Essays [Open letter, ser.5, no.4 (Spring 1983)] (Book)
Topics:  CANADIAN literature -- Bibliography; FRENCH-CANADIAN literature -- Bibliography
Book Source:
Lecker, Robert (compiler) Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch.
Publisher Information: Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987. (pp. 291-397)
ISBN: 0920763111 (hardcover); 092076312X (paperback)
Series Data: Lecker, Robert (editor). David, Jack (editor). Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors ; no. 7

ABCMA07RKP2000007003004017
Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP2000007003004017&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP2000007003004017&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; Robert Kroetsch: Essays [Open Letter, Ser.5, No.4 (Spring 1983)]</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; Robert Kroetsch: Essays [Open Letter, Ser.5, No.4 (Spring 1983)]  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Robert Kroetsch: Essays [Open Letter, Ser.5, No. 4 (Spring 1983)]

D126     Lecker, Robert. "Letters in Canada: 1983. Humanities" University of Toronto Quarterly, 53 (Summer 1984), 466-68. The essays collected in Robert Kroetsch: Essays "demonstrate that Kroetsch is still one of the very few Canadian critics willing to assail our values, to clamour about our silence, to make noise about how we read." The essays move from an examination of "binary structures" to centring on "metaphors of play, carnival, and consummation. These new metaphors signify Kroetsch's increasing attraction to poststructuralist thought, to a reader-responsive theory of game and deconstruction ([Wolfgang] Iser, [Jacques] Derrida) and to notions of the text as an intertextual object of desire ([Harold] Bloom, [Roland] Barthes)." These essays, "in their own erratic, duplicitous, and subversive ways, succeed in redirecting our idea of text."

D127     Cooley, Dennis. Rev. of Robert Kroetsch: Essays [Open Letter, Ser. 5, No.4 (Spring 1983)]. CV/II, 8, No. 3 (Sept. 1984), 19-22. "Kroetsch in fear of the old certainties, the overriding patterns we all inherit. That love of closure, of climax, the managed story. Its grids of power & fixity. Against that, a distrust of hierarchies. The coordinate imagination. Inordinate in its extremities:' Cooley comments on "K. with his passion for beginnings .... Spring seeding. The perpetual dreams of origins .... Dreams of innocence, of naming the prairie out from under the official language/literature that tells us we don't matter. Don't even exist." Kroetsch asserts the "snappy vernacular, the oral tradition, invoking the world as it is re/ presented, lived in, bodied forth (bawdied first,). The more thoughtful more studied voice of the urbane sophisticate. Who's read his [Jacquesl Derrida & his [Roland] Barthes. The K, the studious one, drawn to a more reflexive art, a more conscious working through of the possibilities .... hire him on as a writer in reticence."

D128     Billings, Robert. "Battle Lines." Rev. of The Mask in Place: Essays on Fiction in North America, by George Bowering; Robert Kroetsch: Essays [Open Letter, Ser. 5, No. 4 (Spring 1983)], by Robert Kroetsch, ed. Frank Davey and bpNichol; and Modern Times, vol. III of The Canadian Novel, ed. John Moss. Canadian Literature, No. 102 (Autumn 1984), pp. 109-11. Robert Kroetsch: Essays "is written in the language and style that the book itself expounds, basically an 'archaeological' approach to life and art in which bits of information and language are placed side by side and it is as much the reader's as the writers task to ascertain meaning .... "This archaeological approach is "useful," but "random thoughts are often disguised as the treasures from a dig."

D129     Mandel, Ann. "Robert Kroetsch: rara avis a review of Kroetsch's critical essays." Open Letter, [Essays on Robert Kroetsch], Ser.5, Nos. 8-9 (Summer-Fall 1984), 53-56. In his essays, "... Kroetsch appears as the protean effacer of old identities, refusing to be caught by any music but his own song, in any shape or form but that which, through a continuing study of past masterpieces, he fashions, refines, and then frees from generations of tradition." Kroetsch is caught in a paradox, "... each motion of the finite self towards the eternal possibilities of story moves him simultaneously towards that form closest to the dying body, autobiography." Kroetsch's essays are autobiographical, "tracing Kroetsch's relationship with Canada and with literature from the physical primacy of the prairie in his childhood to the linguistic landscape Canadian writing has become."

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Title:
Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; Seed Catalogue
Other Title:

ABCMA07RKP2000007003004011

https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP2000007003004011&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP2000007003004011&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; Seed Catalogue</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; Seed Catalogue  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Seed Catalogue

D93       Daniel, Lome. "A Fitful Summer's Reading." NeWest Review, Sept. 1977, pp. 10, 12. Seed Catalogue has an impressive format and design. Kroetsch is the most invigorating poet now writing on the Prairies. The poems are an intense, exciting, revealing exploration. Daniel reiterates the jacket blurb. He stops "before I say too many good things about this book."

D94       Johnson, Jay. "Kroetsch in Bloom!". Essays on Canadian Writing, No. 9 (Winter 1977-78), pp. 89-92. "The unifying mechanism of the [title] poem-the seed catalogue -- is for Kroetsch a kind of magic talisman or a generator of mythic energy which gives him access to the past .... The central images of the poem are those of birth and rebirth, growth and maturation, ... [and are reflected in the poem] in terms of the growing of a garden ... the growing of a past and a community and finally the growing of a poet." Seed Catalogue is "interesting and substantial," in keeping with the whole body of Kroetsch's work. "One has the feeling with this man, as with many of the best writers, that the process of discovery in which he is engaged is of such scope that it will take his whole career to articulate it fully."

D95       Mandel, Eli. Rev. of Seed Catalogue. The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 11 Feb. 1978, p. 45. Kroetsch is "an experimental writer of the first order" whose "claim to our attention as a poet is as strong as his firmly established presence as a novelist." In Seed Catalogue, Kroetsch attempts to "bring into existence the forms of a fictional world, the 'west' as myth and place, the prairies as poetic form." He "sets out with ... wit and precision the connections of place and poetry." He is a "meticulous craftsman, often preceeding through apparent disorder to order, through denial to affirmation. The method enables him to write moving lyrics built out of syntactical ambiguities, the ironic play of minute particulars, formal surprises." Kroetsch is a "formalist" who skilfully manipulates language and is driven "by a passion, a wild longing for a lost time and place."

D96       Mulhallen, Karen. "Book of Life." The Canadian Forum, Oct.-Nov. 1978, pp. 46-47. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, Short Story Writers, Filmmakers, Scriptwriters, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Sharon R. Gunton and Jean C. Stine. Vol. XXIII. Detroit: Gale, 1983, 273. Seed Catalogue is "a difficult work to review." Its "elusiveness" is like Tobe's seed catalogue. It is a "long autobiographical poem." Mulhallen provides an evaluation of this genre, as seen in the works of Walt Whitman, Charles Olson, William Carlos Williams, and Allen Ginsberg. Kroetsch's work has a "strong narrative voice" that is "humorous, probing, specific, [and] tragic." In Kroetsch's canon, Seed Catalogue is one of the poems of the "'imagined real place.'" Its patterning "transcends the individual life in the best way [and] is embodied as this dream of, really a search for, origins, the quintessential Canadian voyage." Seed Catalogue is coherent, "an engrossing and moving work," parts two and three of a continuing poem entitled "Field Notes." Part one of that poem was published as The Ledger. The complete poem is to appear. Unlike Michael Ondaatje's The Collected Works of Billy The Kid: Left Handed Poems and Margaret Atwood's The Journals of Susanna Moodie, Kroetsch's poem is not about historical figures as personae, yet it is equal in importance. The book is "beautifully designed" and "a remarkable achievement." Mulhallen concludes that it is "too soon to say ... [Kroetsch] will be for Canadian poetry what Whitman and company are for American poetry."

D97       Hunter, Lynette. "Some Versions of Narrative (Review of Eleven Books of Poetry from Turnstone Press)." Bulletin of Canadian Studies, 5, No. 1 (April 1981), 77-79. Kroetsch's juxtaposition of prose and poetry in Seed Catalogue (especially in the title poem) engenders a "relationship of narrative and response... [and] provides the central allegory of the work." The poem, like the seed, "is potential." Kroetsch's juxtaposition of experiences indicates "control being subtly contrasted to the arbitrary." Kroetsch does not suggest complete lack of control, since "At all times it is imperative to control the check of the unknown. It must recognise its own limitations and fictions if it is to be generative?' At the same time, the poet must "allow the words their own direction if they are to have their own life." Hunter notes that "The poet harrows language for the reader to make it possible for him to love the real, to meet the actual in the words of the text." The other poems in the volume "leave one with a sense of having strayed ... and lost direction," although they do "illuminate" Kroetsch's poetics of cultivation. Kroetsch only succeeds in overcoming these obstacles when he "has the courage to allow his audience a full participation in the text, unhindered by his subjective and didactic intrusion?"

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; Sundogs: Stories from Saskatchewan  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Sundogs: Stories from Saskatchewan

D135     Kerr, Donald C. Rev. of Sundogs: Stories from Saskatchewan. Prairie Forum, 6 (Spring 1981), 104-06. "Stories often set up their fragile barricades against the destruction brought by time and progress, and when the stories are at last about our own places, they can hold a special poignancy." Sundogs: Stories from Saskatchewan includes stories by twenty-three authors with only "diversity/' in common. "The collection is like an old city street where every house is different from every other, though some look a bit alike." The collection does not articulate "a typical regional prose style or a collective myth that defines people in this political entity." It does, however, indicate "the literary ferment of the last decade as the primarily third generation in Saskatchewan begins to write the province in detail."

D136     Griffiths, Alison. Rev. of Sundogs: Stories from Saskatchewan. Quill & Quire, April 1981, pp. 31-32. Sundogs: Stories from Saskatchewan "is a good collection of stories, some frivolous, others experimental, but all are written with the imprint of genuine experience." Griffiths briefly outlines the stories that are included. "No theme binds them together but metaphors of the landscape and the body are richly apparent." Although "Regional labels are sometimes a curse in Canadian literature ...," it is the regional presence that unifies the collection. For Griffiths, "... the prairie sweeps a definitive yet gratifying brushstroke across the characters in the stories."

D137     Jackel, David. "Particulars." Rev. of Fiction of Contemporary Canada, ed. George Bowering; Manitoba Stories, ed. Joan Parr; and Sundogs: Stories from Saskatchewan, ed. Robert Kroetsch. Canadian Literature, No.96 (Spring 1983), pp. 151, 152-53. Of the three collections reviewed, despite the promise of their titles, Sundogs: Stories from Saskatchewan is the only one offering stories that "convey a sense of place.., observed, felt, analyzed, and understood" While most of the stories are "good," none of them are "outstanding'; the "range of experience dealt with is limited"; the "post-modernist attitudes" reflected in the collection may "challenge" and "engage" the reader, but are too narrow to encompass the "particulars of culture," or "the social, political, and economic characteristics of a region or a nation."

Previous Entry in publication.

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; The Camrose Review: a journal of lutheran thought  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

The Camrose Review: a journal of lutheran thought

D138     Daniel, Lorne. Rev. of The Camrose Review: a journal of lutheran thought, No. 1. CV/II, 7, No. 2 (April 1983), 20-21. The Camrose Review: a journal of lutheran thought "was created to throw something of a curve into the limited world of Alberta-based literary periodicals .... This first issue shows an open-mindedness on behalf of the editors .... " Wade Bell, Robert Kroetsch, and Monty Reid. "There is no foreword or editorial statement to clue-in readers; the content speaks alone." The journal includes a wide range of literary styles and forms by such authors as Patrick Lane, Stan Dragland, Mary Howes, bpNichol, and Michael Ondaatje. The journal is a "valuable new work by established writers ... [with] entertaining entries by lesser-knowns, and the occasional weak link."

Record: 94
Title:
Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; The Crow Journals
Other Title:
Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Titles critiqued:  CROW journals (Book)

ABCMA07RKP2000007003004016

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP2000007003004016&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; The Crow Journals</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; The Crow Journals  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

The Crow Journals

D119     Grace, Sherrill E. Rev. of The Crow Journals. Prairie Forum, 5, No. 1 (Spring 1980), 111-14. Grace notes that "... there is an over-riding sense of writing as living," of the "novelist continuously writing himself." The Crow Journals shows "Kroetsch, fully aware of postmodernism, but reaching out for a synthesis of those conventions with the language of a particular and real place, a synthesis that will lead to What the Crow Said." Since What the Crow Said "lacks an authorial alter-ego," Kroetsch "has refined himself out of existence ... until we read The Crow Journals." The journals "assert the writer as a separate being, standing outside his creation, shoring up the ruins of self, after the exhausting completion of the work." Grace recommends that "This book should be read for what Kroetsch reveals about the writers relationship with his work, about his submergence in it and final separation from it ... in preparation for a new beginning."

D120     Daniel, Lorne. "Books: Book Reveals Authors' Insights." The Advocate [Red Deer, Alta.], 10 May 1980, n. pag. The Crow Journals is recommended as a companion to What the Crow Said. Both are lively, vigorous works, joyful in their exploration of Prairie experience. It is an intriguing record, the work of a generous man. It is unpretentious and shows great interest in virtually any artistic endeavor that seeks to interpret human experience. Kroetsch's observations of other writers are brief but sharp insights that crystalize the brightest aspects of others' personalities at work. The Crow Journals is full of recurring images and allusions from Kroetsch's personal life and the writings of others. There are repeated references to One Hundred Years of Solitude, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. There are familiar references but some with less immediate appeal to the general reader.

D121     Aubert, Rosemary. Rev. of The Crow Journals. Quill & Quire, June 1980, p. 36. The Crow Journals is "like watching home movies: interesting now and then, fascinating when one finds a picture of someone one knows personally, but generally not able to sustain enthusiastic attention." The prose is "jotty, personal, anecdotal," but "most mysterious and most compelling when it deals directly with the novel that is taking shape in the writer's head." If Kroetsch addressed himself more toward the process of the novel and less toward "mundane matters, we would indeed have the 'literary diary' and 'rare document' Kroetsch's publisher mistakenly thinks this book is."

D122     Morrissey, Stephen. "Two Modern Writers." Rev. of Gradations of Grandeur, by Ralph Gustafson; and The Ledger and The Crow Journals, by Robert Kroetsch. CV/II, 5, No. 1 (Autumn 1980), 37. The Crow Journals is "sparse," lacks "depth"; "... the Journal isn't complete .... this is the skeleton of what might have been a more substantial book." While Douglas Barbour's editing is "good," his Introduction (C107) is "laudatory in the extreme," emphasizing the "thinness" of the text.

D123     Kertzer, Jon. Rev. of The Sad Phoenician and The Crow Journals. The Fiddlehead, No.128 (Winter 1981), pp. 115, 116-18. The Crow Journals is "a poetic commentary on... [Kroetsch's] life, and its subjects and style suggest that it too could be a field note. It is confessional, fragmentary, erratic." The entries reveal "a writer writing about himself writing, a self-reflexive task with romantic precedents." The entries are "unified by the brooding presence of the author." In the journal, Kroetsch "tries to work out a dialectic of literary composition," a dialectic "based on the antagonistic yet vital relation between the writer and his work, between the work and the tradition in which it participates." Kroetsch is a "martyr to his own creation"; his identity is destroyed as he creates. The writer must defy the conventions of the novel in order to use them; "... he must 'decompose' before he can compose ...." Language, the "'trickster' that both deceives and rewards us," is explored in the journals to illuminate Kroetsch's ability, in What the Crow Said, to create "characters with such verbal vitality that they can tell us things about ourselves that we did not recognize."

D124     Mandel, Ann. Rev. of What the Crow Said and The Crow Journals. Periodics, Nos. 7-8 (Winter 1981), pp. 184-86. The Crow Journals is compiled of "scattered diary entries Kroetsch made during the five years he was writing What the Crow Said ...." It is a record. "In and among the friends and events that move in and out of Kroetsch's moving here and there, a special concern keeps recurring, for the novel, his novel, as an expanded tall-tale, a way of uniting the local -- 'the hard core of detail' -- and the mythological."

D125     Kertzer, Jon. "Letters in Canada: 1980. Humanities." University of Toronto Quarterly, 50 (Summer 1981), 170-71. The Crow Journals "is an intimate literary diary, a blending of truth and artfulness that portrays the artist in pursuit of the truth of his art." The journal is a "puzzling but provoking' collection of entries that are often "impressionistic rather than factual .... Each fragment indirectly comments on every other one," which "encourages us to look for what Kroetsch calls the 'text beneath the text, an everlasting grope into the shape of that darkness.'" The organizing agent in this journal of fragments is the author's voice. Kroetsch "speaks in the voice of a writer fascinated by the nature and power of his artistry. He turns a seemingly haphazard diary into a carefully drawn self-portrait of the artist undertaking the essential task of his life." The Crow Journals "is an account and demonstration, not just of the composition of one novel, but of the craft and inspiration of fiction generally."

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP2000007003004010&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; The Ledger</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; The Ledger  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

The Ledger

D87       Carpenter, David. "Balanced Account." CV/II, 2, No. 1 (Jan. 1976), 12. The Ledger is one of Kroetsch's "most important experiments in postmodern literature." This is "a kind of regional map," rather than a found poem. "One hesitates to call it a poem, though!" It is a collage; an "adventurous experiment in spatial relationships." The page "is a technological space to be exploited" Good design and printing complement the text.

D88       Thomas, Peter. Rev. of The Ledger. The Fiddlehead, No. 108 (Winter 1976), pp. 114-17. The Ledger "proclaims a historical and personal 'field' within which Kroetsch attempts the increasingly familiar task of recovering some of the genealogical and perhaps tempermental bases of his own creative impulse." However, historical facts "must be expressed in part by their actual randomness; the effort of recovery is both a stress on specificity.., and a proclamation of the poet's contention with his material."

D89       McCarthy, Dermot. "Ancestors, Real or Imaginative." Rev. of Rhythms, by Les Arnold; The Ledger, by Robert Kroetsch; and Long Sault, by Don McKay. Essays on Canadian Writing, No. 4 (Spring 1976), pp. 74-75. "The Ledger is a notebook of possibilities": "damning lack of language"; achieving a form beyond initial ideas. Kroetsch "lacks the poetic craft necessary to manipulate the fragments." The Ledger is "simply rough-work made public" prematurely. The result is not for lack of trying.

D90       Cook, John. "New Directions and Old: 'The Ledger.'" The Canadian Forum, March 1980, p.38. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, Short Story Writers, Filmmakers, Scriptwriters, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Sharon R. Gunton and Jean C. Stine. Vol. XXIII. Detroit: Gale, 1983, 274-75. In The Ledger, personal quest is "the controlling motif" and the accountant's ledger is the controlling form. "Within this form, the poet as book-keeper, as a clerk of the imagination, records the various possibilities of the ledger metaphor .... The poem lies, the ledger lies, each in the service of a kind of truth. Both the poem and the ledger are balancing acts .... the great balancing act may simply be the one that allows Kroetsch so deftly and with such grace to balance the credit of his poetic vision with the debit of a sawyer's ledger."

D91       McKay, Don. "At Work and Play in The Ledger." Brick, No. 10 (Fall 1980), pp. 48-52. Rpt. in Open Letter, [Essays on Robert Kroetsch], Ser. 5, Nos. 8-9 (Summer-Fall 1984), pp. 146-53. "In its form and parodic metaform The Ledger approximates ... [the] struggle between God and Coyote. The humourless ledger form is inhabited and undone by the trickster poet, who is nevertheless constrained by it." Kroetsch finds the ledger form, "the pattern of equally matched opposites," only to infiltrate it as the "trickster poet," the "Coyote," the natural enemy of "rational forms," who is "always liable to intervene with a resurgence of chaos." In the resulting state of imbalance, art becomes possible. Exploring a series of dictionary definitions of the word "ledger," enables Kroetsch "to mine its possibilities and undermine its fixities with puns and implicit meanings .... the definitions both close and disclose, act as frame and window." The novelist defines, builds myths, with one hand, and "uninvents" or "deconstructs" with the other. "Deconstructive writing is simply this: writing which invites you to see through." The ledger is, essentially, "a relic, a form, an idea, a point of departure, a way for the poet to center, pay homage to and fight free from the enclosing past."

D92       Morrissey, Stephen. "Two Modem Writers." Rev. of Gradations of Grandeur, by Ralph Gustafson; and The Ledger and The Crow Journals, by Robert Kroetsch. CV/II, 5, No. 1 (Autumn 1980), 37. Kroetsch uses the ledger "as a means of illuminating the present"; it becomes part of the "search for the meaning and purpose of existence" The ledger is at once a concrete and specific historical artifact, a general indictment of North American industrialization, and an entry point to "something primeval" for the individual reader. Comparable to Margaret Atwood's The Journals of Susanna Moodie, The Ledger is a collective history, accurately revitalized by "the truth of poetic vision."

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; The Sad Phoenician

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP2000007003004012&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; The Sad Phoenician</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; The Sad Phoenician  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

The Sad Phoenician

D98      Quaife, Darlene. "Canadian Poetry Round-Up: Senior Poet Irving Layton Berates Colleagues for Self-Involvement." Rev. of Droppings from Heaven, by Irving Layten; A Balancing Act, by Florence McNeil; The Gods, by Dennis Lee; Another Mouth, by George Bowering; and The Sad Phoenician, by Robert Kroetsch. The Weekend Herald [The Calgary Herald], 22 Dec. 1979, p. C11. Quotations are drawn from the notes on the back cover. "The book is one long poem consisting of what appears to be stream-of-consciousness ... The poet as lover is a cynic and the flippant tone makes his poetry seem thin and complaining despite the mask of masculine bravado."

D99      Reagan, Dale. "Rowing Home to Haven in Sunny Prairie Style." Books in Canada, Feb. 1980, pp.6-8. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, Short Story Writers, Filmmakers, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Sharon R. Gunton and Jean C. Stine. Vol.XXIII. Detroit: Gale, 1983, 273-74. The Sad Phoenician is the latest sequence of "Field Notes." Unlike most incoherent, contemporary serial poems, The Sad Phoenician is identifiably part of a poetic sequence. Reagan reads it as the fourth movement (after The Ledger, Seed Catalogue, and "How I Joined the Seal Herd") with "The Silent Poet Sequence." Kroetsch attempts to find a language for exploring "'the imagined real place.'" The Sad Phoenician is a succession of imposed imaginative structures. Kroetsch sounds out possible ways of imagining the real. In the context of the longer poem, Kroetsch moves back in the rudiments of language: he probes poetic speech, with the alphabet as an organizing device. The poem has a rigorous syntax and an embattled protagonist, the poet as failed lover. He has lost contact with his home. There are twenty-six shufflings of contending images of the poet which culminate in the Phoenician/"Phoney." Kroetsch is master of the long poem in the tradition of Basil Bunting. The poem is intricately patterned like the work of David Jones, a British poet. "The Silent Poet Sequence" is a coda. It has the same initials, but is an afterthought. Following the process of diminishment, the sequence is confusing.

D100     Scobie, Stephen. "Silence Is the Skeleton." Rev. of Four Stories, by Sheila Watson; and The Sad Phoenician, by Robert Kroetsch. NeWest Review, Feb. 1980, pp. 13-14. Scobie compares The Sad Phoenician with Four Stories, by Sheila Watson. Both authors move through sound, alike in "pattern and tumble, order and spontaneity, the controlling imagination and the expansive delight in words." Watson is a Modernist, while Kroetsch is Post-Modernist. "Without The Double Hook a poem like Robert Kroetsch's The Sad Phoenician would scarcely have been possible." Kroetsch has confidence in the structuring capabilities of language and mythology. Kroetsch carries some Modernist baggage, just as the Phoenicians transported language and yard-goods. Sound is built around firm structuring principles: "on the immediate level of the poetic line, the alternation between 'and' and 'but,' the connectives of continuity and contradiction, holding the flux in check like the bounds of a tennis court"; on the "wider level of imagery, the identification of the four women with the four elements"; "on the level of structure, ... the letters of the alphabet"; and the "ironical stance" of a Prufrockian narrator. The poem is "a parody of Kroetsch's own image as the male-chauvinist hellion," a "Phoney" pose. The only words left are those of the "Silent Poet" in fragments.

D101     Dempster, Barry. Rev. of The Sad Phoenician. Quill & Quire, April 1980, p. 37. In The Sad Phoenician, Kroetsch examines "being a poet, and.., being human, a lover too, those two states of well intentioned slavery." Though it is poetry, the book "has the developmental structure of a novel." Kroetsch's writing is "plain but metaphorical, obviously structured but giving the illusion of diving down the pages like an airplane. It's easy to read but is still both intelligent and challenging." Dempster notes a shift in tone in the final pages of the book: '"the poet speaks clearly as if he's stepped out from behind a curtain, without costume or makeup, to explain himself ...."

D102     Buckley, Vincent. "Two Western Canadians." Rev. of The Sad Phoenician, by Robert Kroetsch; and Four Stories, by Sheila Watson. The CRNLE Reviews Journal [Flinders Univ. of South Australia], No. 2 (Dec. 1980), pp. 12-13, 14. Kroetsch is "a prose-writer who essays verse (and very much his own brand) .... "In The Sad Phoenician, Kroetsch attempts to "establish a character and to make poetry out of the moods of his voice." Buckley examines Kroetsch's use of dialectical structure, "resembling versicle and response, to get into speech the hubbub of the 'lovers' head and life." The "regular alteration of 'but' and 'and'" and "the irregular length of the lines" create a "rushing, jamming, selfcontradictory eloquence." The eloquence is threatened, however, by the "pervasive Canadian jokiness" which also plagues Sheila Watson.

D103     Kertzer, Jon. Rev. of The Sad Phoenician and The Crow Journals. The Fiddlehead, No. 128 (Winter 1981), pp. 115-16. "In its tentativeness, its fragmentary forms, its restless ingenuity, its emphasis on time and process, and its determination to run on continually beside the life of the author, Field Notes suggests a modern Prelude, the 'heroic argument' of the poet's life." The Sad Phoenician is part of this argument. It is a poem of "considerable order, wit, and ingenuity," which "first strikes the reader as an unbroken monologue in which the speaker hardly pauses for breath." Like the other poems in Field Notes 1-8: a continuing poem. The Collected Poetry of Robert Kroetsch, it "relies on an organizing image to give shape to the poem and to act as a metaphor for the poet's life and for the poetic process which he serves." The Sad Phoenician, however, is "more chatty," "more petulant," "less lyrical," "less revealing," less "poignant," "less tactful," and less "controlled" than the other poems in the collection. "The final impression of the poem is that the poet and his material resist each other too much."

D104     Wah, Fred. Rev. of The Sad Phoenician. Periodics, Nos. 7-8 (Winter 1981), pp. 180--81. In The Sad Phoenician, "... the poet is caught in the story the poem makes." The left-hand margin, the alternation of "and" and "but," "becomes lineal, a veritable story-line of the poet's mind making the poem/story. It's a never ending syntagm which propels the language forward in rambling common tongue .... Each line can keep going out and out just so long as it comes back to the edge, fishing, casting."

D105     West, David S. "Wrestling the Alpha-Bet Beast." Canadian Literature, No.91 (Winter 1981), pp. 122-24. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, Short Story Writers, Filmmakers, Scriptwriters, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Sharon R. Gunton and Jean C. Stine. Vol. XXIII. Detroit: Gale, 1983, 275. "The Sad Phoenician is an ambitious undertaking; an existential portrait of the plight of sensitive individuals, it is an excursion into the turbulent waters of communication that it attempts to describe and chart even as it traverses them for the first time." Kroetsch is "writing about writing," he is "lurking behind the language, manipulating, contriving, and interjecting at will." The humour reflects "the final willingness to undergo the frustrations, failures, and imbecilities of life encountered during the quest for ways of expression"

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Item Number: ABCMA07RKP2000007003004012
Record: 97
Title:
Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; The Stone Hammer Poems: 1960-1975
Other Title:
Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

Titles critiqued:  STONE hammer poems: 1960-1975 (Book)

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP2000007003004009&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; The Stone Hammer Poems: 1960-1975</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; The Stone Hammer Poems: 1960-1975  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

The Stone Hammer Poems: 1960-1975

D81       Carpenter, David. "Stone Chipped and Hammered." CV/II, 2, No. 2 (May 1976), 38-39. Although The Stone Hammer Poems: 1960-1975 violates poetic conventions, the contents "are poems indeed, but they aspire to that definition by virtue of their intensity of metaphor, of paradox, and of sensuous detail, and by virtue of the obvious pressure under which they have been realized." Carpenter comments on each poem in the collection. He considers many of the love poems to be dominated by sexual innuendo, but applauds the clean, raw quality of the regional sketches. The regional poems exhibit a paring down of emotions and allow actions to speak for themselves. The title poem is seen in terms of Kroetsch's struggle as a PostModernist to articulate the artistic process. The poem exposes the ravages of time, but also defies them. It "will outlast its creator and lend a sense of fixity to a changing, chaotic, and often sad world." The Stone Hammer Poems: 1960-1975 illustrates Kroetsch's acute sense of "the chaos and the sad evanescence of things" in "a world in the throes of spiritual and moral reexamination" and represents Kroetsch's lyrical and sensitive response.

D82       Geddes, Gary. "Kroetsch Is a Greedy Researcher, but Field Notes Fall Before Lyrics and Love Letters." Rev. of Badlands and The Stone Hammer Poems: 1960-1975. The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 1 May 1976, p. 39. The Stone Hammer Poems: 1960-1975 is based on research into the Blackfoot Indian legends. The poems "are not so powerful or interesting as Ted Hughes' Crow poems." Kroetsch uses delightful, outrageous, and robust Western language. The title poem "is a paradigm of the recovery process" of human history. Kroetsch is best in his love poems. Geddes selects "Elegy for Wong Toy" as his personal favourite poem. The lyrical side of Kroetsch is emerging. Can he survive the "slurring off of his chrysalis"?

D83       Davis, Barb. "The University of Lethbridge Student Research: Literature of the Prairies." The Lethbridge Herald, 11 May 1976, p. 5. An article about an English course called, "Prairie Regionalism." Davis summarizes a discussion by students with a collage of their interests, perceptions, and discoveries. About The Stone Hammer Poems: 1960-1975, she notes that "... nearly all of Kroetsch's central male characters exemplify the main traits of the 'Old Man.'"

D84       Tidler, Charles. Rev. of The Stone Hammer Poems: 1960-1975. Quill & Quire, Feb. 1976, p. 45. The Stone Hammer Poems: 1960-1975 "is a valuable document" as a new perspective. Tidler argues that novelists are "notorious for misunderstanding and mishandling the forms and content of poetry. Kroetsch is no exception" The "Old Man Stories" are primarily prose. "Stone Hammer Poem" is "ambitious" but ruined by belabouring a "lightweight, secondary metaphor." Kroetsch "is capable of competent verse" in "Elegy for Wong Toy," but this is only a beginning. The publisher extended a "deplorable," coffee-table "tradition in small pressmanship." Tidler objects to the photograph of an Indian village, which "particularly lacks taste."

D85       Gasparini, Len. "Chips, Nuts and Wafers." Rev. of Stone Hammer Poems: 1960-1975, by Robert Kroetsch; Pocket Pool, by David Berry; and Some Breath, by Linda Rogers. Books in Canada, March 1976, p. 18. The Stone Hammer Poems: 1960-1975 has "strength of line and effective use of dramatic detail." Kroetsch has a "wise" disregard for abstraction. His "poetic instinct is... on target; he peers through the eye of his own imagination." The "title poem is a superb example of the fusion of metaphor and self-knowledge." It is droll, adept, symbolic, and elegiac. Kroetsch proves he is a poet of exceptional talent. Unfortunately, Kroetsch is verbose, a habit from his prose fiction.

D86       Suknaski, Andrew. "Old Man River: Kroetsch as Poet." NeWest Review, Jan. 1976, p. 9. Suknaski claims that all poems are written for "a momento that becomes the microcosm of everything beyond our skin. "He compares the Old Man to Bilbo and Strider in J.R.R. Tolkien's The Lord of the Rings. Kroetsch is at his bacchanalian best. He is a delightful trickster. Suknaski points to Kroetsch's chauvinism; merging of white and Indian wit; and the coyote myth. The title poem is imagistic and Black Mountain in style. It becomes a graphic metaphor for the stone maul itself. Suknaski speaks of Kroetsch's debt to the Black Mountain school and illuminates several of the poems, notably "Old Man Stories."

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

This content is intended solely for the use of the individual user.

Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors ; no. 7 ISBN: 0920763111 (hardcover); 092076312X (paperback), Book ID: ABCMA07RKP2.
Item Number: ABCMA07RKP2000007003004009
Record: 98
Title:
Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; The Studhorse Man
Other Title:
Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews
Record Type:
Reference Series
Series Title:
Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors, no. 7
Author(s):
Lecker, Robert (compiler)
Genre(s):
Bibliography
Subject(s):
Authors discussed:  KROETSCH, Robert; KROETSCH, Robert -- Criticism & interpretation -- Bibliography
Titles critiqued:  STUDHORSE Man, The (Book)
Topics:  CANADIAN literature -- Bibliography; FRENCH-CANADIAN literature -- Bibliography
Book Source:
Lecker, Robert (compiler) Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch.
Publisher Information: Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987. (pp. 291-397)
ISBN: 0920763111 (hardcover); 092076312X (paperback)
Series Data: Lecker, Robert (editor). David, Jack (editor). Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors ; no. 7
Book Control ID: ABCMA07RKP2
p. 369-371 (3 p.)
