Accession Number:
ABCMA07RKP2000007003004003
Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP2000007003004003&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP2000007003004003&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; The Studhorse Man</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; The Studhorse Man  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

The Studhorse Man

D23     Rev. of The Studhorse Man. The Times Literary Supplement [London], 11 Dec. 1969, p. 1431. The Studhorse Man is a pleasantly bizarre, imaginative exercise in blackish humour. Kroetsch seems to have learned much from Nabokov's Pale Fire in style and technique. Kroetsch has much to offer. The tone of high seriousness makes the book funny by allowing it to be risque and macabre at the same time.

D24     Tivy, Pat. "From the Bookshelf: Prairie Tale Crackles Along." The Province [Vancouver], 27 Dec. 1969, Sec. Entertainment and the Arts, p. 27. This is a smart little book, well-printed and well-bound. It crackles with good writing and subtle humour. Tivy laments the fact that Kroetsch lives in the West and is published by a British firm, yet that status ironically earmarks a true Canadian novelist.

D25     Coles, Don. "A Rare Alberta Animal." The Globe Magazine [The Globe and Mail] [Toronto], 31 Jan. 1970, p. 15. The Studhorse Man is a good story, economically told, fresh and vital, marking a real advance on Kroetsch's previous work. The tonalities are reminiscent of Laurence Stem's The Life and Opinions of Tristam Shandy, Gentleman. The novel has sophistication and distinction. "In its focusing upon sub-zero seasons and its unforced use of names and places which testify to its author's immersion in the folklore of contemporary Canada, it is genuinely mythic, western, and Canadian."

D26     Sypnowich, Peter. "The Studhorse Man Given Recognition It Deserves." Toronto Daily Star, 14 April 1970, Sec. Entertainment, p. 36. This review is about the second printing of The Studhorse Man. Sypnowich believes it must be one of the most entertaining, satisfying novels ever to win a Governor-General's Award for literature. The first printing received little attention from reviewers. Now it will enjoy the wide popularity it deserves. The Studhorse Man is an inventive, comic novel. It is almost a tall tale. The re-creation of time and place is quite enough to support the novel's mythic dimension. Sexual betrayal has been a consistent theme in Kroetsch's work. He has explored the mythic dimension in the rivalry between a hero and his disciple. The Studhorse Man is positively crowded with timeless ingredients -- dreams and darkness, bones, mice, poltergeists, and axis mundi. It is packed with local colour and the rich, real force of comedy. It all becomes what every novel is supposed to be -- the truth.

D27     Sypnowich, Peter. "Honored Novelist's Passion Is Capturing Canada's Voice." Toronto Daily Star, 16 April 1970, p. 32. Kroetsch is a typical Canadian confronted by America. He realized being a Canadian is permanent -- "'... something you couldn't escape from if you wanted to.'" He would like a Canadian company to film the novel. At times he is self-deprecating, but still capable of self-assertion, by turns passive and aggressive. The Studhorse Man has a trace of Oriental quietism which Kroetsch seems to have picked up from his hippie students. Its comedy represents a fatalistic strain that is distinctly Canadian. For Kroetsch, the tragic vision is a partial view. In comedy, change operates against cause and effect. The unpredictable studhorse is not mortal or immoral. Like the struggle between a titanic figure and his disciple in all of Kroetsch's novels, The Studhorse Man represents American-Canadian relations: Kroetsch's surrender of the will to writing is a "good old" Canadian characteristic. Alberta is a sort of "'total metaphor'" with which he can say many things.

D28     West, Paul. "Hazard's Life-Wish: A Perfect Foal." The New York Times Book Review, 26 April 1970, p. 44. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, Short Story Writers, Filmmakers, Scriptwriters, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Sharon R. Gunton and Jean C. Stine. Vol.XXIII. Detroit: Gale, 1983, 270. "The book's pattern is circular," like the journey of its protagonist. It "fuses prairie talltale with Odyssean myth" -- making the point "that perfectionists procrastinate and thus waste their lives while life in general goes muddling on around them." In trying to follow the narrative, the reader may experience "a certain amount of strain." However, if the reader can avoid "what the narrator calls 'the necessity of interpretation' he will have a ball as Mr. Kroetsch's gross hero stalks with his prize beast through a landscape as abstract as it is lovingly delineated, as crammed with garrulous eccentrics as it is also demoralizingly empty." The book "stretches the mind, and does so with a gross yet realistic central notion flanked by bouts of farce." Kroetsch acknowledges "the mundanities he starts from .... His region has its reasons, and he respects them ..." and uses them "relentlessly throughout the hyperbolical fun of the whole thing."

D29     New, W.H. Rev. of The Studhorse Man. Canadian Literature, No. 44 (Spring 1970), p. 98. New compares the novel to Earle Birney's Turvey: A Military Picaresque. He sees both operating on three levels: "narrative epic, national burlesque, and literary parody." Kroetsch's "deliberate use of understatement and anti-climax contributes happily to the success of his witty and entertaining book."

D30     "Mating Horses Now." Variety [New York], 20 May 1970, p. 3. The Studhorse Man has been obtained for filming by Herbert B. Leonard, who expects to make the film in Canada.

D31     Roper, Gordon. Rev. of The Studhorse Man. University of Toronto Quarterly, 39 (July 1970), 344. Although the novel is convoluted in form, Kroetsch "particularizes and localizes in a way which sends out reverberations like a struck bell." Roper poses an important question concerning Kroetsch: "... is the truth in the apparent reality or in the creating of Reality?"

D32     Brown, Russell M. "Odyssean Journey." Canadian Literature, No. 45 (Summer 1970), pp. 88-90. Brown comments on the symbolic and mythical dimensions of Kroetsch's work. In The Studhorse Man, "Style reinforces the mythic quality, for the novel utilizes the precise, sparse language of the fable." Kroetsch's regional novels transcend their settings by "mythicizing." He is a myth-maker in the tradition of F.P. Grove and Margaret Laurence. There are re-workings of the Oedipus archetype in But We Are Exiles, The Words of my Roaring, and The Studhorse Man. In The Studhorse Man two male figures are revealed as the duality which exists within man. Other archetypes that appear in Kroetsch's novels are Narcissus, in But We Are Exiles, Pluto and Persephone, in The Words of my Roaring, and Odysseus, in The Studhorse Man. Kroetsch is essentially "a writer of comic vision." His attempt at tragedy, in But We Are Exiles, was mistaken. Brown praises Kroetsch's "ingenuity, ... skilful manipulation of the twin foci," and "spirit of comic madness." Such "great technical ability and careful craftsmanship" represent a "significant achievement"

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors ; no. 7 ISBN: 0920763111 (hardcover); 092076312X (paperback), Book ID: ABCMA07RKP2.

<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP2000007003004002&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; The Words of my Roaring</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; The Words of my Roaring  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

The Words of my Roaring

D12     Franklin, Stephen. "Canadian Literary Pot Boiling and Bubbling." The Montreal Star, 29 Jan. 1966, Sec. Entertainments, p. 4. The Alberta censors and Kroetsch do not agree about Canadian sex mores or knowledge.

D13     Rotondaro, Fred. Rev. of The Words of my Roaring. Best Sellers [Univ. of Scranton, Pa.], 1 Aug. 1966, p.171. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, Short Story Writers, Filmmakers, Scriptwriters, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Sharon R. Gunton and Jean C. Stine. Vol.XXIII. Detroit: Gale, 1983, 269-70. Johnnie is not a very likable character. The humour "fails because of his excessive stupidity. The attempted psychological penetration" is told completely through his eyes. He is "not sensitive enough to understand" The "moments of truth fall flat." The lies are "more believable but not very interesting."

D14     Blaise, Clark. "To the Palace of Wisdom." The Montreal Star, 17 Sept. 1966, Sec. Entertainments, p. 8. In a second novel, Kroetsch has happily confirmed Blake's notion that the road of excess leads to the palace of wisdom. His greatest achievement in this book is the creation of a "super" character and the mystic forces that return him to our dimension.

D15     Coles, Donald. "Dreams of a Prairie Undertaker." The Globe Magazine [The Globe and Mail] [Toronto], 17 Sept. 1966, p. 21. Kroetsch is a professional, a publisher's author. "You're not left with much when you've reached the last page, but at least you've reached it." The characters' dreams in The Words of my Roaring "never get off the ground." Kroetsch studied under Hugh MacLennan at McGill University and "that's about how he reads. No special relationship to words, but a solid grounding in somebody's idea of a creative writing course."

D16     Eckman, Lynn. "Change or Only Self-Deception? Books of the Times." The Roanone Times, 23 Oct. 1966, p. 10. The Words of my Roaring displays excellence in creating characters and a command of Rabelaisian humour, as well as a knowledge of human frailties and aspirations. Kroetsch may be added to a growing list of novelists of the absurd. He portrays the conflict between man and his environment. The new resolutions are another ludicrous instance of Johnnie's self-deception.

D17     Shrapnel, Norman. "New Fiction: Mild and Bitter." The Guardian [London], 18 Nov. 1966, p. 8. Kroetsch is a don leaving his ivory tower -- to come out shooting. This is a rough story told with intelligence and skill. It reveals a genuine obsession with the violent, sentimental, and riproaring politics of that time and place.

D18     Laurence, Margaret. "Canada Still Too CanadaFocused." The Montreal Star, 3 Dec. 1966, Sec. Entertainment, p. 2. The Words of my Roaring is a good novel, a large step forward from his first novel. It has a completely contemporary idiom and a truly active character, Johnnie Backstrom.

D19     Price, R.G.G. "New Novels: 'The Words of my Roaring.'" Punch [London, Eng.], 14 Dec. 1966, p. 902. Rpt. (excerpt) in Contemporary Literary Criticism: Excerpts from Criticism of the Works of Today's Novelists, Poets, Playwrights, Short Story Writers, Filmmakers, Scriptwriters, and Other Creative Writers. Ed. Sharon R. Gunton and Jean C. Stine. Vol. XXIII. Detroit: Gale, 1983, 270. "The Words of my Roaring is weird but energetic and readable." Kroetsch contrasts the "roughneck Alberta undertaker" with the "long established Member" of the legislature who serves as a "father figure" for Backstrom. Kroetsch's "fascination with the material comes through and hefts the tale over the sticky bits."

D20     Stedmond, J.M. Rev. of The Words of my Roaring. University of Toronto Quarterly, 36 (July 1967), 386. Kroetsch tries "though perhaps a little too hard, to inject some humour into his Alberta novel."

D21     Helwig, David. "Pay Your Money -- Take Your Choice." The Tamarack Review, No.43 (Spring 1967), pp. 65-66. Helwig describes this "wild and lovely story." He concentrates on Backstrom, who sounds "a bit too much like Holden Caulfield, but usually with a remarkable drive and vigour." He is like Duddy Kravitz or Gully Jimson in his creative destructive energy.

D22     New, W.H. "Cliches and Roaring Words." Rev. of The Hostages, by Charles E. Israel; Honey in the Rock, by Christine Van der Mark; and The Words of my Roaring, by Robert Kroetsch. Canadian Literature, No. 31 (Winter 1967), pp.66-67. Rpt. (revised -- "A Fiction Chronicle, Part I: Art and Politics") in Articulating West: Essays on Purpose and Form in Modern Canadian Literature. By W.H. New. [Three Solitudes: Contemporary Literary Criticism, No.1.] Toronto: new, 1972, pp. 160-62. New concentrates on the figure of Johnnie, who survives the "stereotyped catch phrases ... to become a real figure-- cynical, bawdy, brash, and profoundly innocent." Unfortunately, the novel is marred by imitative and "hackneyed phrases"

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors ; no. 7 ISBN: 0920763111 (hardcover); 092076312X (paperback), Book ID: ABCMA07RKP2.
Item Number: ABCMA07RKP2000007003004002
Record: 100
Title:
Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; What the Crow Said
Other Title:
Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews
Record Type:

Titles critiqued:  WHAT the crow said (Book)

ABCMA07RKP2000007003004007

https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP2000007003004007&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07RKP2000007003004007&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; What the Crow Said</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Robert Kroetsch. Lecker, Robert (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 291-397

Part 2 Works on Robert Kroetsch; Selected book reviews; What the Crow Said  

Lecker, Robert (compiler)

What the Crow Said

D61      Bacque, James. "Stunning Novel Deserves Award." The Toronto Star, 11 Nov. 1978, p. C7. What the Crow Said is an astonishing book. Its reckless narrative is like an aging stripper who makes the fantastic plausible. With such fertile character invention, Kroetsch is at his best. He was wise to "stick to" Alberta. He deserves the Nobel Prize or the Governor-General's Award.

D62      Scott, Chris. "Cosmos Derailed Near Big Knife; Entropy Blamed." Books in Canada, Dec. 1978, p. 17. The novel seems overdrawn and at times tendentious. In Kroetsch's hands, the "great mythopoetic idea fails to transcend the humoresque" what-if-feeling. The editors needed to be "worthy of the author's imagination." The printing leaves a lot of "white space."

D63      Godfrey, Ellen. "Bees Fertilizing a Woman, a 15i-Day Card Game and Endless Winter. Strange Goings-On." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 23 Dec. 1978, p. 33. This is a "fabulous," "funny, lusty fable." It "uses the techniques of the dark Germanic fairy tales," with a "mixture of tall tale and fairy tale" of a "heroic quality." Godfrey recounts the plot. The book is "dominated by an essentially male myth." All Kroetsch's books, at some level, are "alien, impenetrable to the female sensibility." In previous novels, his women characters "were still part of a man's heroic quest." They are "reflections of men or part of the men's design." The best Canadian recent fiction is dominated by women so Godfrey welcomes "books where hard-drinking men boast of their manhood, challenge the sky, fear women, and are joyfully swept away by the floods of their words."

D64      Twigg, Alan. "Books: Tall Tale Has Deep Roots." The Magazine [The Province] [Vancouver], 16 Sept. 1979, p. 16. This is an anecdotal piece about Kroetsch at an uneventful three-day conference on regional literature in Regina. Kroetsch has become the most intriguing experimental stylist in the country. The novel is an attempt to take the tall tale as far as it can go. Kroetsch admits to mocking the male world in which he grew up. His interest in the erotic involves not only male and female brought together, but also the self in a total relationship with the world. Kroetsch's fault is his obsession with symbolism according to Twigg, such that his novels can become mere mazes of meanings. Kroetsch acknowledges a lack of sentimental depth in his work, emphasizing intellectual play. Twigg also offers an overview of the other novels. What the Crow Said ranks with The Studhorse Man as an example of Kroetsch at his uncompromising best. He writes, not about breaking the land, but how people remember rural experience and how that conditions how we all act today. The piece includes a number of comments by Kroetsch.

D65      Lakevold, Dale. "Cauliflower and Kroetsch." The Meliorist [Univ. of Lethbridge], 5 Oct. 1979, p. 5. Lakevold notes Kroetsch's appearance at the Southern Alberta Art Gallery. While the author was on the faculty of Lethbridge as writer-inresidence (1976-77), he worked on What the Crow Said. Kroetsch is more than a historian and more than a teller of tall tales. He reveals much about people and untapped sources of human life, particularly among Canadians. The novel is bawdy, but, nevertheless, opens doors. It can perhaps serve to "loosen" elements of literature like conservatism. It allows people to gain a true glimpse of themselves. A photograph captioned "The questionable cover" accompanies this article.

D66      Mandel, Ann. Rev. of What the Crow Said and The Crow Journals. Periodics, Nos. 7-8 (Winter 1981), 182-83. What the Crow Said is "a fable, a comic-fantastic narrative which, like all good comedy, is deadly serious." It is, "in a peculiar way," a "feminist novel," in that it "continues, furthers, Kroetsch's articulation of a male world of self-hate, guilt, death-obsessions, fear of emptiness, hate and fear of women." It becomes increasingly clear, with this novel, that Kroetsch's hero has cast woman as "bearer and healer of his own fears and self-hate," and that she will resist the confinements of the role. Adrienne Rich, among others, articulates women's need to join the search for "communal source," the as-yet-unearthed "dark core." Male writers must stop "denying women their own emptiness, their own void." When women join in Kroetsch's "everlasting falling," the question arises: "Whose arms, then, are waiting below?"

     Serials

B74   "Roger Sudden." Pt. I. Adventure Magazine, Canadian Ed., Nov. 1944, pp.4-27. Rpt. in Adventure Magazine, U.S. Ed., Dec. 1944, pp. 12-42. RS. The excerpt in the Canadian edition is Part I of a six-part series. The excerpt in the American edition is Part I of a five-part series. Further issues of this journal cannot be located.

Source: Part 1: Works By Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 405-425

Part 1 Works by Thomas H. Raddall; Contributions to periodicals and books (short stories, serials, excerpts from novels and histories, reprinted anthology contributions: A selection, articles, reviews, and poems), radio material, and television material; Excerpts from novels and histories  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

     Excerpts from Novels and Histories

B75   "A Page from the Book" (fiction). Wings: The Literary Guild Review, Nov. 1946, pp. 4-6. PF.

B76   The Wings of Night (abridged), in "Book of the Week." Evening Telegram [St. John's], Omnibook World Wide Abridgement, 9 March 1957, pp. 1-12. WN (expanded).

B77      "How George Washington Lost Canada" (history). Illus. Bruce Johnson. Maclean's, 14 Sept. 1957, pp. 34-35, 70, 72-74, 76-79. PD (expanded -- "1775 Nova Scotia, the Fourteenth American Colony" and "1775-1781 Rebellion in Nova Scotia -- Attack on Fort Cumberland -- American Privateers -- The Turn of the Tide").

Record: 103
Title:

Raddall; Contributions to periodicals and books (short stories, serials, excerpts from novels and histories, reprinted anthology contributions: A selection, articles, reviews, and poems), radio material, and television material; Reprinted anthology contributions: A selection

ABCMA07TRP1000007004002004

https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP1000007004002004&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP1000007004002004&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 1 Works by Thomas H. Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 1: Works By Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 405-425

Part 1 Works by Thomas H. Raddall; Contributions to periodicals and books (short stories, serials, excerpts from novels and histories, reprinted anthology contributions: A selection, articles, reviews, and poems), radio material, and television material; Reprinted anthology contributions: A selection  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

     Reprinted Anthology Contributions: A Selection

B78      "Bald Eagle 'Iggins." In Post Stories of 1940. Boston: Little, Brown, 1941, pp. 353-73.

B79     "The Wedding Gift." In Post Stories of 1941. Gen. ed. Wesley Winans Stout. Boston: Little, Brown, 1942, pp. 281-96.

B80     "A Nova Scotia Seaman-Lumberman" (excerpt from "Tit for Tat") and "Roddie John Practices on the Pipes" (excerpt from "The Pied Piper of Dipper Creek"). In A Pocketful of Canada. Ed., preface, and introd. John D. Robins. Toronto: Collins, 1946, pp. 135-38, 220-23.

B81     "The Amulet." In A Book of Canadian Stories. Ed., preface, and introd. Desmond Pacey. Toronto: Ryerson, 1947, pp. 223-36.

B82     "Miss Letty Canvasses for the Monument" (excerpt from "Memorial to Miss Letty"). In A Book of Canadian Humour. Ed., preface, and introd. John D. Robins and Margaret V. Ray. Toronto: Ryerson, 1951, pp. 137-48.

B83     "Petticoat Pilot." In Shining Skies. Ed. Fred C. Biehl, J. Ranton McIntosh, and Claude E. Lewis. Illus. Margaret Salisbury, Mabell Marshall, W.R. Stark, and Louis Dobry. Toronto: Copp Clark, 1952, pp. 267-82.

B84      "Resurrection." In Cavalcade of the North: An Entertaining Collection of Distinguished Writing by Canadian Authors. Ed. George E. Nelson. Introd. Thomas B. Costain. Toronto: Doubleday, 1958, pp. 439-55.

B85     "The Halifax Explosion" (excerpt from Halifax, Warden of the North). In Atlantic Anthology. Ed. and introd. Will R. Bird and Alec Lucas. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1959, pp. 230-35.

B86     "Blind MacNair." In Canadian Short Stories. Ed. and introd. Robert Weaver. London: Oxford Univ. Press, 1960, pp. 137-56.

B87     "The Golden Age." In Northern Lights: A New Collection of Distinguished Writing by Canadian Authors. Ed. George E. Nelson. Introd. Mazo de la Roche. Toronto: Doubleday, 1960, pp. 555-67.

B88     "Pax Britannica." In Man and His World. Ed. and introd. Malcolm Ross and John Stevens. Toronto: Dent, 1961, pp. 393-413.

B89     "The Amulet" (excerpt). In The Craft of Writing. Ed. and preface R.J. McMaster. Don Mills, Ont.: Longmans Canada, 1962, p. 102.

B90     "Spawning Time" (excerpt from His Majesty's Yankees). In A Book of Canada. Ed. and introd. William Toye. London: Collins, 1962, pp. 260-61.

B91     "Pax Britannica." In Eighteen Stories. Ed. Malcolm Ross and John Stevens. Don Mills, Ont.: Dent, 1965, pp. 22-42.

B92      The Nymph and the Lamp (excerpt). In Great Canadian Writing: A Century of Imagination. Ed. and introd. Claude Bissell. Toronto: The Canadian Centennial Library, 1966, p. 39.

B93     "The Trumpeter." In Man's Search for Values. Ed. Thomas H.W. Martin, Dorothy Chamberlin, and Imgard Wieler. Preface Maurice Gibbons. Toronto: Gage, 1966, pp. 153-60.

B94   "The Amulet." In The House of the Nightmare and Other Eerie Tales. Ed. and foreword Kathleen Lines. London: Bodley Head, 1967, pp. 129-42.

B95   "The Trap." In Stories from Across Canada. Ed. and introd. Bernard L. McEvoy. Philadelphia/Toronto: Lippincott/McClelland and Stewart, 1967, pp. 93-109.

B96   "The Wedding Gift." In In Search of Ourselves. Ed. and introd. Malcolm M. Ross and John Stevens. Toronto: Dent, 1967, pp. 170-86.

B97   "At the Tide's Turn." In Stories from Atlantic Canada. Ed. and introd. Kent Thompson. Toronto: Macmillan, 1973, pp. 1-23.

B98      "At the Tide's Turn" and "Winter's Tale." In The Evolution of Canadian Literature, 1914-1945. Ed. and introd. George L. Parker. Toronto: Holt, Rinehart and Winston, 1973, pp. 195-22.

B99      "Bald Eagle 'Iggins." In The Canadian Century: English-Canadian Writing since Confederation. Vol. II of The Book of Canadian Prose. Ed. and preface A.J.M. Smith. Toronto: Gage, 1973, pp. 395-411.

B100      "The Wedding Gift." In Canadian Literature: Two Centuries in Prose. Ed. and preface Brita Mickleburgh. Foreword Malcolm Ross. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1973, pp. 234-46.

B101      "Bald Eagle." In The Canadian Experience: A Brief Survey of English-Canadian Prose. Ed. and introd. A.J.M. Smith. Agincourt, Ont.: Gage, 1974, pp. 159-75.

B102      "Blind MacNair." In The Maritime Experience. Ed. and introd. Michael 0. Nowlan. Toronto: Macmillan, 1975, pp. 14-30.

B103      "The Wedding Gift." In Modern Canadian Stories. Ed. and introd. John Stevens. New York: Bantam, 1975, pp. 46-62.

B104      "The Wedding Gift." In Literature in Canada. Ed. and preface Douglas Daymond and LesLie Monkman. Toronto: Gage, 1978. Vol. II, 129-41.

B105      "Winter's Tale." In Nearly an Island: A Nova Scotia Anthology. Ed. and introd. Alice Hale and Sheila Brooks. St. John's, Nfld.: Breakwater, 1979, pp. 53-74.

B106      "The Amulet." In Visions from the Edge: An Anthology of Atlantic Science Fiction and Fantasy. Ed. and introd. John Bell and Lesley Choyse. Illus. Rand Gaynor. Porters Lake, N.S.: Pottersfield, 1981, pp. 139-48.

B107      "Winter's Tale." In The Atlantic Anthology. Ed. and introd. Fred Cogswell. Vol. I. Charlottetown: Ragweed, 1984, pp. 156-68.

B108      "The Wedding Gift." In The Oxford Book of Canadian Short Stories in English. Ed. and introd. Margaret Atwood and Robert Weaver. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1986, pp. 60-72.

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 1: Works By Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 405-425

Part 1 Works by Thomas H. Raddall; Contributions to periodicals and books (short stories, serials, excerpts from novels and histories, reprinted anthology contributions: A selection, articles, reviews, and poems), radio material, and television material; Articles  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

     Articles

Note: See category J, in the Raddall Manuscript Collection (A35), for articles that were apparently published, but for which the source cannot be located.

B109      "Ogomkegea: The Story of Liverpool, Nova Scotia." Port and Province [Halifax], 2, No.8 (July-Aug. 1934), 7-9, 20-22. Rpt. (revised -"Two Centuries of Ogomkegeak: The Story of Liverpool, N.S.") in The Atlantic Advocate, Aug. 1959, pp.16-23. O:SLN (revised -- "Ogomkegea: The Story of Liverpool, Nova Scotia").

B110      "Return Engagement." Saturday Evening Post [Philadelphia], 10 Aug. 1940, p. 6.

B111      "Swordin'." Maclean's, 15 Aug. 1941, pp. 8, 29-31.

B112      "Navy Base." Maclean's, 15 March 1942, pp. 12-13, 50-53.

B113      "They Were Prepared:' Maclean's, 15 April 1942, pp. 10, 30-32, 42.

B114      "Combined Operations, 1758." Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh], Nov. 1943, pp. 312-21. This item could possibly be classified as a short story; see B68.

B115      "Early Medical Practice in Nova Scotia." Nova Scotia Medical Bulletin, 23 (1944), 187-94.

B116      "Three against Death." Maclean's, 1 March 1944, pp. 5-6, 37-39. MAOS ("Resurrection"). Originally signed: Robert E. Coffman. This item could be classified as a short story; see B69.

B117      "My Home Town." Maclean's, 1 Sept. 1944, pp. 19-20, 36, 38.

B118      "Guest Editorial." The Mohawk Beam, 1, No. 4 (March 1945), 2.

B119      "The Writer and the War." Canadian Author & Bookman, 21, No.1 (March 1945), 7. [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2.202J.2.A]

B120      "Tale of Life." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 29 June 1946, p. I0.

B121      "Happy Island." Maclean's, 1 Nov. 1946, pp. 23-24, 34, 36.

B122      Foreword. In Tales of the Sea. By Archibald MacMechan. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1947, pp. vii-xiv.

B123      "The Old House." Maritime Quarterly [Halifax], 1 [1947], 15, 17.

B124      "Tarleton's Legion." Nova Scotia Historical Society, Halifax. 11 April 1947. Printed in Collections of the Nova Scotia Historical Society [Halifax], 28 (1949), 1-50.

B125      "Nova Scotia's First Telegraph System." The Dalhousie Review, 27 (July 1947), 131-42.

B126      "Christmas at Sable Island." In All Sails Set. Ed. Fred C. Biehl. Toronto: Copp, Clark, 1948, pp. 375-85.

B127      "Island for Sale." Saturday Evening Post [Philadelphia], 6 Nov. 1948, pp. 36-37, 136, 138, 140, 143.

B128      "The Importance of Things Past." Convocation for Honorary Degrees, Dalhousie Univ., Halifax. 8 March 1949. Printed in The Dalhousie Review, 29 (July 1949), 113-18.

B129      "Halifax Has Packed Plenty of Thrills into Two Centuries of Turbulent History." The Standard Magazine [The Standard] [Montreal], 4 June 1949, pp. 3-4.

B130      "The Literary Tradition." Canadian Author & Bookman, 25, No. 3 (Autumn 1949), 3-7.

B131      Foreword. In Lure of the Sea: Leaves from My Pictorial Log. By Wallace R. MacAskill. Halifax: Eastern Photo Engravers, 1951, n. pag.

B132      "Joe Howe: Maritimes Gadfly." Saturday Night, 8 Dec. 1951, pp.13, 49.

B133      "My First Book." Canadian Author & Bookman, 28, No. 3 (Autumn 1952), 4-8.

B134      "Sword and Pen in Kent, 1903-1913." The Dalhousie Review, 32 (Autumn 1952), 145-52.

B135      "Canada. Look North!". House and Garden [New York], March 1954, pp. 58,149.

B136      "The Literary Art." The Dalhousie Review, 34 (Summer 1954), 138-46. Rpt. in Canadian Novelists and the Novel. Ed. Douglas Daymond and Leslie Monkman. Ottawa: Borealis, 1981, pp. 181-85.

B137      "Turbulent Days of Early Liverpool Are Recalled." The Halifax Chronicle Herald, 16 Aug. 1955, p.6.

B138      "The Widow Dexter's Tavern: Ancient House Saw More Musket-Balls than Cherries." The Halifax Chronicle Herald, 17 Aug. 1955, p. 2.

B139      "Thomas Brenton Smith." Liverpool Advance, 1 Dec. 1955, p. 4. Unsigned obituary.

B140      "Dr. Raddall Gives History of Zion Church." Liverpool Advance, 22 Dec. 1955, p. 4.

B141      "My Most Memorable Meal: No.17." Maclean's, 16 March 1957, p. 36.

B142      "The Streets of Canada: Barrington." Maclean's, 7 June 1958, pp. 16-19, 38, 40-44.

B143      "Liverpool's Founding Is Recalled." The Halifax Chronicle Herald, 29 June 1959, p. 13.

B144      "Nova Scotia." World Book Encyclopedia (1960).

B145      "A Boy's Reading and a Man's Writing." In Canadian Library Association Conference Proceedings. Halifax, 1964, pp. 47-52.

B146      "Adventures of H.M.S. Blonde in Nova Scotia 1778-1782." Nova Scotia Historical Society, Halifax. 10 April 1964. Printed in Collections of the Nova Scotia Historical Society [Halifax], 35 (1966), 29-52. FOF (revised -- "Adventures of the H.M.S. Blonde").

B147      "To a Young Writer." The Atlantic Advocate, Aug. 1965, pp. 27-28.

B148      "We're All Canadians Now." Toronto Daily Star, 31 Dec. 1966, [Sec. 1], p. 12.

B149      "The Assassination of D'Arcy McGee." In Historic Headlines. Ed. Pierre Berton and Leslie F. Hannon. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1967, pp. 7-18.

B150      "Halifax: Where Ships and Much History Meet." In Century 1867-1967: The Canadian Saga [The Chronicle-Herald and Mail Star (Halifax), 13 Feb. 1967], pp. 30-31.

B151      "A Century in Queen's County 1867-1967." Mersey Quarterly [Liverpool, N.S.], 43 (Summer 1967), 2-6.

B152      "A Sea Raid on Liverpool 187 Years Ago: An Incident of the American Revolution" Printed in the programme for Liverpool Centennial Celebrations, Liverpool, N.S. 16-22 July 1967. Programme published by Kinsmen Club of Liverpool, N.S.

B153      "Bluenose View of the Centennial:' The Montreal Star, 14 Oct. 1967, p. 9.

B154      "The Feast of St. Aspinquid." Nova Scotia Historical Quarterly, 1, No. 1 (March 1971), 1-9.

B155      "Groundwork and Guesswork." Social Studies Review [Nova Scotia Teachers' Union], 6, No. 2 (June 1974), 7-12.

B156      Foreword. In The Lighthouse. By Dudley Witney. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1975, pp. 8-11.

B157      "Pioneers and Privateers." Nova Scotia Magazine, Dec. 1971, pp.13-15. Rpt. in Sojourn, 1 (March 1975), 26-28.

B158      "Sable Island." World Book Encyclopedia (1978).

B159      Foreword. Sable Island. By Bruce Armstrong. Toronto: Doubleday, 1981, p.[vi].

B160      "Sam Glode: Travels of a Micmac." Cape Breton's Magazine [Wreck Cove, Victoria County, Cape Breton], No. 35 [c. 1983], pp. 21-29.

Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 1: Works By Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 405-425

Part 1 Works by Thomas H. Raddall; Contributions to periodicals and books (short stories, serials, excerpts from novels and histories, reprinted anthology contributions: A selection, articles, reviews, and poems), radio material, and television material; Reviews  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

     Reviews

B161      "Mystical Theme of Melville's Novels Is Denied by Canadian Seaman-Author." Rev. of Herman Melville: A Critical Study, by Richard Chase. The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 4 Feb. 1950, p. 12.

B162      Rev. of The Micmac Indians of Eastern Canada, by D. Wilson and Ruth S. Wallis. The Dalhousie Review, 35 (Autumn 1955), 286, 288.

B163      Rev. of Diary of Simeon Perkins 1780-89, ed. D.C. Harvey, notes C. Bruce Fergusson. The Dalhousie Review, 39 (Summer 1959), 269, 271, 273.

B164      Rev. of Diary of Simeon Perkins 1790-1796, ed. Charles Bruce Fergusson. The Dalhousie Review, 42 (Winter 1962-63), 539, 541.

B165      Rev. of The Atlantic Provinces: The Emergence of a Colonial Society, by W.S. MacNutt. Dalhousie Review, 45 (Winter 1965-66), 543, 545,547.

B166      Rev. of Maine Rubicon, by John Howard Ahlin. The Dalhousie Review, 47 (Summer 1967), 248-49.

B167      Rev. of Yankees at Louisbourg, by G.A. Rawlyk. The Dalhousie Review, 47 (Winter 1967-68), 597, 599, 601.

B168      Rev. of Diary of Simeon Perkins 1797-1803, ed. Charles Bruce Fergusson. Dalhousie Review, 48 (Summer 1968), 279, 281, 283.

B169      Rev. of Canada: The War of the Conquest, by Guy Fregault. Dalhousie Review, 49 (Winter 1969-70), 579, 581.

B170      "A Handful of Haliburton." Rev. of The Clockmaker, by T.C. Haliburton, introd. R.L.M. McDougall; The Sam Slick Anthology, by T.C. Haliburton, ed. R.E. Watters; and The Old Judge, by T.C. Haliburton, introd. R.E. Watters. Journal of Canadian Fiction, [Special Issue], 2, No. 3 (Summer 1973), 105-07. Rpt. ("Haliburton: A Lasting Impression") in Beginnings. Vol. II of The Canadian Novel: A Critical Anthology. Ed. John Moss. Toronto: No, 1980, pp. 37-39.

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 1: Works By Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 405-425

Part 1 Works by Thomas H. Raddall; Contributions to periodicals and books (short stories, serials, excerpts from novels and histories, reprinted anthology contributions: A selection, articles, reviews, and poems), radio material, and television material; Poems  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

     Poems

B171      "Autumn." In Canada Geese in Rhyme and Dish. [Broadside], [c. 1930]. This broadside also includes a recipe for cooking geese, by C.H.L. Jones.

B172      "Honkers:' In Canada Geese in Rhyme and Dish. [Broadside], [c. 1930]. This broadside also includes a recipe for cooking geese, by C.H.L. Jones.

B173      "Spring." In Canada Geese in Rhyme and Dish. [Broadside], [c. 1930]. This broadside also includes a recipe for cooking geese, by C.H.L. Jones.

B174      "Hull Down." In An Acadian Sheaf." Selections from Current Nova Scotia Poetry. Halifax: Canadian Authors' Association, 1935, pp. 50-51.

B175      "Where the Dead Lay Thickest." In "Raeviews." Parnassus [Toronto], Sept. 1945, p. 19. This poem was first published earlier in 1945 in a Halifax literary magazine The Harpsichord, edited by Andrew Merkel. This journal cannot be located.

Raddall; Contributions to periodicals and books (short stories, serials, excerpts from novels and histories, reprinted anthology contributions: A selection, articles, reviews, and poems), radio material, and television material; Radio material</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 1: Works By Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 405-425

Part 1 Works by Thomas H. Raddall; Contributions to periodicals and books (short stories, serials, excerpts from novels and histories, reprinted anthology contributions: A selection, articles, reviews, and poems), radio material, and television material; Radio material  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

     Radio Material

B176      "A Nova Scotia Privateer." Narr. Thomas H. Raddall. CBC Radio, 10 Jan. 1941. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.] Raddall adapted this from his Saga of the 'Rover'.

B177      "Old Norse Voyages to America." Narr. Thomas H. Raddall. CBa Radio, 11 Aug. 1941. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.] Raddall adapted this from The Markland Sagas, by Thomas H. Raddall and C.H.L. Jones.

B178      "A Muster of Arms." Victor)' Loan Broadcast. CBC Radio, 13 Oct. 1944. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.] See B55.

B179      "Brooms for Sale." Canadian Yarns. CBC Radio, July 1945. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.] See Dream.

B180      "Jim Charles and His Gold Mine." Canadian Yarns. CBC Radio, July 1945. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.] See FOF ("The Lost Gold at Kejimkujik").

B181      "Halifax Explosion." CBC Short Wave beamed to U.K., 21 July 1945. Recorded in Montreal by wire from Halifax. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.]

B182      "The Indian Devil." Canadian Yarns. CBC Radio, 22 July 1945. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.]

B183      Roger Sudden (excerpt). CBC Radio, 1947. (30 min.) Rebroadcast. CBC Radio, March 1948. (30 min.) Rerecorded (expanded)Action Theatre. CBC Radio, 1964. (6 parts; 30 min. each). Rerecorded. Theatre Ten-Thirty. Prod. Helen Golding. CBC Radio, 31 May, 1 June, 3 June, 4 June 1971. [Public Archives of Nova Scotia; tapes, uncatalogued.] See RS.

B184      "Tales of Two Cities." CBC International Short Wave, April 1947. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.]

B185      "Halifax and the Army." CBC Radio, 1949. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.]

B186      "Halifax and the Navy." CBC Radio, 1949. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.]

B187      "Halifax: The Story of Water Street." CBC Radio, 1949. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.]

B188      "Canada's Heritage of Sail." CBC Wednesday Night. CBC Radio, 7 Dec. 1949. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.]

B189      "Halifax: The Disaster of '17." CBC Radio, 1951. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.]

B190      "Sable Island." Canadian Chronicle. CBC Radio [Weekly broadcast to New Zealand], 15 Jan. 1951. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.]

B191      "Canadian Sparks." CBC Radio [Trans-Canada], 2 Dec. 1951. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.] Part I of a three-part series. See B192-B193.

B192      "Canadian Sparks." CBC Radio [Trans-Canada], 9 Dec. 1951. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.] Part II of a three-part series. See B191 and B193.

B193      "Canadian Sparks." CBC Radio [Trans-Canada], 19 Dec. 1951. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.] Part III of a three-part series. See B191-192.

B194      The Nymph and the Lamp. A Book at Bedtime. BBC Radio, 1952. Rerecorded (excerpt). Narr. Thomas Raddall. CBC Radio, 25 Dec. 1955. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.] The 1952 production was a 15-episode serialization. See NL, B212, and C209.

B195      Raddall discussing his own work. This Week. CBC Radio, 14 March 1953.

B196      "My First Novel." CBC Wednesday Night. CBC Radio, 16 Dec. 1953. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.]

B197      "Sam Slick." CKBW Radio [Bridgewater, N.S.], Nov. 1955. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.] Recorded for rebroadcasting on various Maritime stations by Imperial Oil Company.

B198      "One Christmas on Sable." CBC Radio, 21 Dec. 1955. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.]

B199      Untitled talk on Liverpool, Nova Scotia. CBC Radio [Liverpool, N.S.], June 1957. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.]

B200      "I Fell in Love with a House." Matinee. CBC Radio [Trans-Canada], [Bridgewater, N.S.], 20 Aug. 1957. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.]

B201      "Halifax Explosion." CBC Radio [Halifax], 23 Nov. 1958. Rebroadcast. CBC Radio, 25 Nov. 1958. [Public Archives of Nova Scotia; 4 tapes, uncatalogued.]

B202      "The Powers of Darkness." Halifax Theatre. CBC Radio, 26 Jan. 1961. Rebroadcast. Montreal Playhouse. CBC Radio, 1962. [Public Archives of Nova Scotia; tape, uncatalogued.] See TOS, B59, C206, and C210.

B203      "The Halifax Disaster of 1917." Narr. Thomas Raddall. Prod. Harro Garmsen and Bill Harper. CBC Radio, Sept. 1967. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.] See B218.

B204      Contributor. "The Shattered Gateway." Between Ourselves. CBC Radio, 6 Dec. 1967. This documentary on the Halifax explosion of 6 December 1917 includes Raddall.

B205      "Between the Lines." CBC Radio [Vancouver]. (30 min.) [Not located.] See B25. Raddall contracted with abe Radio in Dec. 1967 for use of this story prior to 1 Dec. 1968.

B206      "The Wedding Gift." RIAS [Berlin], 1968 [not located]. Rerecorded. Westdeutscher Rundfunk, 1972 [not located]. Rebroadcast. Radio Telfis Eirann, 1972 [not located]. See B50 and B220.

B207      Commentator. "Imitations of Innocence: MacMechan's Ocean." Studio '74. CBC Radio, 24 Feb. 1974.

B208      "MacIvor's Salvation." CBC Stage. Prod. John Douglas. CBC Radio [Halifax], 21 June 1975. [Public Archives of Nova Scotia; tapes, uncatalogued.] See B34.

B209      The Wings of Night. Narr. Bill Carr. Introd. Jim Bennett. Prod. Elizabeth Fox. By Word of Mouth. CBC Radio [Toronto], 20 Jan.-8 Feb. 1982. (14 parts.) Rebroadcast. Narr. Bill Carr. Introd. Jim Bennett. Prod. Elizabeth Fox. Atlantic Airwaves. CBC Radio [Halifax], 7 May-6 Aug. 1983. (14 parts.)

B210      "MacNab's Island." CBC A.M. CBC Radio [Halifax], 24 June 1982. See HB.

B211      "Anthology: Thomas Raddall at Eighty. In My Time: A Memoir [excerpts]." Narr. John Fulton. CBC Radio [Halifax], 12 Nov. 1983. See IMT. Neil Copeland also interviews Raddal (C203).

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Raddall; Contributions to periodicals and books (short stories, serials, excerpts from novels and histories, reprinted anthology contributions: A selection, articles, reviews, and poems), radio material, and television material; Television material</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 1: Works By Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 405-425

Part 1 Works by Thomas H. Raddall; Contributions to periodicals and books (short stories, serials, excerpts from novels and histories, reprinted anthology contributions: A selection, articles, reviews, and poems), radio material, and television material; Television material  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

     Television Material

B212      The Nymph and the Lamp. Theatre of the Air. CBC TV, Dec. 1952. (1 hr.) [Not located.] The cast includes Robert Preston and Margaret Sullavan. See NL, B194, and C209.

B213      "Admiralty House, Halifax." Narr. Thomas H. Raddall. CBC TV, 16 Jan. 1960. (30 min.) [Public Archives of Nova Scotia; tapes 968B-972. Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.]

B214      "The Habitation, Port Royal, Nova Scotia." Where History Was Made. CBC TV [National Schools Telecast], 9 March 1960. [Public Archives of Nova Scotia; tapes 491-505. Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.]

B215      "The Assembly Chamber." Narr. Thomas H. Raddall. CBC TV [Province House, N.S.], 13 June 1960. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.]

B216      Discussant with Charles Lynch. The Sixties. CBC TV [1961?]. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.] The other participants were Eric Nichol (British Columbia), Harry Boyle (Ontario), and Yves Theriault(Quebec).

B217      "Perkins House." Host Lloyd MacKinnis. Gazette. CBC TV, 4 Aug. 1961. [Public Archives of Nova Scotia; tape 174.]

B218      "A City's Story -- Halifax." CBC TV [Halifax] [Fall 1967]. (Colour; 30 min.) [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.]

B219      "The Halifax Disaster of 1917." Narr. Thomas Raddall. Prod. Harrow Garmsen and Bill Harper. CBC TV, 26 Oct. 1967. Rebroadcast. Heritage Series. CBC TV, 12 Dec. 1978. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.] See B203.

B220      "The Wedding Gift." CBC TV, 30 Sept. 1971. (30 min.) [Not located.] Rebroadcast. CBC TV, Sept. 1973. (30 min.) [Not located. ] In September 1972 CBC sold Westdeutscher Rundfunk the rights to one television broadcast of this production. In October 1972 CBC sold CBC the rights to use the play on Central Scotland and Yorkshire section of their television network. In January 1974 CBC sold New Zealand Broadcasting Corporation the rights to use the play. See B50 and B206.

B221      Narrator. "The Jewel in the Crown." The Days Before Yesterday: Struggle for Nationhood, CBC TV, 4 Nov. 1973. Part I of a seven part series.

B222      "Thomas H. Raddall." Authors Series. CBC TV, 22 June 1979.

Title:
Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Books, bibliographies, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Adaptations
Other Title:

Raddall; Books, bibliographies, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Adaptations</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Books, bibliographies, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Adaptations  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

Adaptations

C205     Schull, Joseph, adapted. Pride's Fancy. Prod. J. Frank Willis. CBC Radio, 25 Sept. 1948. A dramatic adaptation of Raddall's novel of the same title (A4).

C206     Douglas, Clyde, adapted. "The Powers of Darkness." CBC Radio, 1956. Rebroadcast. Halifax Theatre. CBC Radio, 26 Jan. 1961. Rebroadcast. Montreal Playhouse Series. CBC Radio, Nov. 1962. A dramatic adaptation of Raddall's short story of the same title (B59). See also B202 and C210.

C207     Douglas, J. Clyde, adapted. The Golden Age. CBC Radio, 24 March 1962. A dramatic adaptation of Raddall's short story of the same title (B65).

C208     Fox, Elizabeth, adapted. The Wings of Night. Prod. and dir. Ronald Weyman. CBC TV, April-May 1963. (8 parts; 60 min. each.) Rebroadcast. CBC TV, Dec. 1963-Jan. 1964. (8 parts; 60 min. each.) A dramatic adaptation of Raddall's novel of the same title (A8). The cast includes Joe Austin, Eric Clavering, Laddie Dennis, James Doonan, John Drainie, Jane Mallett, Irena Mayeska, Charles Palmer, and Jeremy Wilkin.

C209     Schull, Joseph, adapted. The Nymph and the Lamp. CBC Stage. CBC Radio, 3 April 1964. A dramatic adaptation of Raddall's novel of the same title (A5). See also B194 and B212.

C210     Schull, Joseph, adapted. "The Powers of Darkness."Show of the Week. CBCTV, 6 Dec. 1965. A dramatic adaptation of Raddall's short story of the same title (B59). See also B202 and C206.

C211     Rivers, Claire, adapted. "Naval Honours." CBC Playhouse. CBC Radio, 16 Sept. 1974. (30 min.) A dramatic adaptation of Raddall's short story of the same title (A15).

Title:
Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Books, bibliographies, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Articles and sections of books
