Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP2000007004003003&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Books, bibliographies, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Articles and sections of books</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Books, bibliographies, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Articles and sections of books  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

Articles and Sections of Books

C6     "A Bride of June." The Halifax Herald, May 1927. [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2. 202. B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] Raddall will marry Edith Freeman. Her photograph is included.

C7     "Raddall-Freeman." Halifax-Chronicle, 10 June 1927, p. 3. Raddall's wedding on 9 June is described.

C8     "Raddall-Freeman." The Halifax Herald, 15 June 1927, p. 12. Raddall's wedding on 9 June is described.

C9     "Armistice Dinner." [Newspaper clipping, 10 Nov. 1931.] [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2.202.B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] At the first Armistice Dinner of the Queen's Company Branch of the Canadian Legion in Liverpool, Raddall responded to the toast to "The Army and Navy."

C10     "Armistice Dinner." Liverpool Advance, 18 Nov. 1931, p. 1. This is a report of Raddall's reply to a toast at an Armistice dinner in Liverpool, Nova Scotia.

C11      "Canadian Legion, Queen's County Branch, Holds Armistice Dinner." Liverpool Advance, 16 Nov. 1932, p. 1. Raddall was toastmaster at the annual Armistice dinner.

C12     Tweedsmuir, Lord (John Buchan). Foreword. In The Pied Piper of Dipper Creek and Other Tales. By Thomas H. Raddall. Edinburgh: Blackwood, 1939, pp. v-vi. Buchan praises Raddall's abilities as a storyteller and places him in the same literary tradition as Walter Scott, Robert Louis Stevenson, Guy de Maupassant, Rudyard Kipling, and Joseph Conrad. He points out that the stories in the collection concern modern Nova Scotia at a time "when the old life is being broken into by ugly modernity." He notes that elsewhere Raddall has written admirably of the past.

C13     "Canadian Legion Holds Banquet." [Newspaper clipping, 1939.] [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2.202.B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] Raddall attended the annual Remembrance Day banquet at the Mersey Hotel, Liverpool, and responded to the toast "Canada and the Empire."

C14       "Author Plays Active Role in Gaining Widespread Publicity for Province." [The Halifax Herald], 14 Oct. 1942. [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2. 202. B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] Bio-bibliographical data on Raddall's career and recent publication of His Majesty's Yankees.

C15       "Citizens Pay Tribute to Author T.H. Raddall." Liverpool Advance, 10 Dec. 1942, p. 1. A testimonial dinner was given for Raddall at Legion Club rooms in Liverpool, Nova Scotia, at the regular quarterly meeting of the Board of Trade.

C16      "Is Honored." Halifax Chronicle, 10 Dec. 1942, p.3. A brief comment is made on the testimonial dinner given to Raddall in Liverpool, Nova Scotia, hosted by the Board of Trade, the Kiwanis Club, and the Town Council. A photograph is included.

C17       "Pay Tribute to Author." Halifax Chronicle, 10 Dec. 1942, p. 3. The author comments on the testimonial dinner given to Raddall on 9 December in Liverpool, Nova Scotia, by the Board of Trade, the Kiwanis Club, and the Town Council.

C18       Lowe, Frank. "Tom Raddall, Tale Teller, Digs in on New Opus." [Newspaper clipping, 1943.] [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2. 202. B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] Raddall's career leading up to the publication of His Majesty's Yankees is briefly discussed. Raddall is now working on another book.

C19      "The Crucible." [The Halifax Herald, c. March 1943.] [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2.202.B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] Raddall's story, "Memorial to Miss Letty," appeared in the February-March issue of The Crucible.

C20       Wright, Ethel [sic; Esther] Clark. "A Conflict of Loyalties." The Dalhousie Review, 23 (April 1943), 83-86. Wright, a well-known historian of the Maritime Loyalists, praises the "amazing fidelity" with which Raddall depicts actual figures from Nova Scotia history. She suggests that Raddall has "set a new high" in historical novel writing, creating "a stirring tale, well told, full of adventure and hairbreadth escapes." But what impresses her more than this is Raddall's study of "an inner conflict, a conflict of loyalties." This is a novel dealing with "a great theme treating of an important epoch, and bringing to life men and women of the provinces by the sea." Of Raddall's attempts to suggest the idioms of eighteenth-century speech, she says: "There may be anachronisms, but they did not reveal themselves to one who has been reading eighteenth century documents by the hundreds."

C21     "Is Proud of Literary Son." [Halifax Echo, c. 1944.] [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2.202.B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] In this article about Raddall's mother, she is quoted as saying that Raddall's love of writing began at age eight. By age eleven he had an extraordinary vocabulary.

C22     Deacon, William Arthur. "Governor-General's Annual Literary Awards." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 15 April 1944, p. 16. Deacon notes that Raddall has won the Governor-General's Literary Award for Fiction for The Pied Piper of Dipper Creek.

C23     "T.H. Raddall Wins 1943 Literary Award." The Halifax Herald, 15 April 1944, p. 2. A photograph is included in this report on Raddall's Governor-General's Literary Award for Fiction for The Pied Piper of Dipper Creek.

C24      Middleton, J.E. "Governor-General's Awards for Best Canadian Books of 1943." Saturday Night, 22 April 1944, p. 28. Middleton reports that Raddall has won the Governor-General's Literary Award for Fiction for The Pied Piper of Dipper Creek.

C25     "'C' Company Notes." [Liverpool Advance, 27 April 1944.] [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2.202.B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] Raddall, a former Lieutenant in the West Nova Scotia Regiment, has won a Gevernor-General's Award.

C26     "Distinguished Guests Attend Reception." The Halifax Mail, 4 May 1944, p. 13. Raddall attended the dinner for Thomas Haliburton at the University of King's College.

C27     "For Your Scrapbook." [Liverpool Advance, 25 May 1944.] [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2.202.B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] A young prisoner of war in Germany had written home saying how much he enjoyed reading Raddall's His Majesty's Yankees.

C28     "To Tell of Archives in Fiction." [Liverpool Advance, 25 May 1944.] [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2. 202. B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] Margo Dill will speak on the use Raddall made of the Public Archives of Nova Scotia when writing His Majesty's Yankees and the stories in The Pied Pipper of Dipper Creek.

C29     "Thomas H. Raddall Heard in Address" [Halifax Star, 9 June 1944.] [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2. 202. B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] Raddall addresses the Writers' Group (service men and women interested in writing) at Dalhousie University.

C30     [Newspaper clipping, Sept. 1944.] [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2. 202. B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] His Majesty's Yankees has been placed on the supplementary reading list for English literature at Queen's University.

C31      Moore, H. Napier. "In the Editor's Confidence." Maclean's, 1 Sept. 1944, p. 2. Brief biographical data.

C32      Tyler, H. Washington. "Raddall of the Maritimes." Canadian Author & Bookman, 20, No. 3 (Sept. 1944), 26. Bio-bibliographical data.

C33     "Raddall Tells His Own Story." Halifax Chronicle, 18 Nov. 1944, p. 10. The author comments on an interview with Raddall on CJCH Radio the previous evening (C183).

C34     "Raddall to Autograph Books." Halifax Chronicle, 18 Nov. 1944, p. 20. Raddall will be autographing copies of Roger Sudden at Simpsons in Halifax.

C35     "T.H. Raddall Is Guest Speaker." [Halifax Chronicle, 18 Nov. 1944.] [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2.202. B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] Raddall addresses the Nova Scotia Centre of the Poetry Society at the home of Andrew Merkel, in Halifax.

C36     "Support Is Demanded." [The Halifax Herald, 23 Nov. 1944, front page.] [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2. 202. B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] Raddall, who was President of Queen's Company Branch of the Canadian Legion, signed telegrams, which were sent from Liverpool, Nova Scotia, to the Canadian Government in Ottawa, urging the government to supply reinforcements to the army overseas.

C37      "The Camp-Fire." Adventure Magazine, U.S. Ed., Dec. 1944, pp.6, 8. Beginning with this issue, Roger Sudden will be published in a five-part series (see B74).

C38      "The Camp-Fire." Adventure Magazine, Jan. 1945, pp. 6, 8. This article includes comments by Raddall on himself and the writing of Roger Sudden. He expresses his admiration for the American historian Francis Parkman and his own experiences of the Nova Scotia forest which have given him valuable background for his fiction. He states that in the writing of Roger Sudden the most interesting job was the field research he carried out at Louisbourg.

C39     "Know Halifax Says Raddall." [Newspaper clipping, c.1945.] [Public Archives of Nova Scotia MG9, Vol. 188, p. 119.] Raddall gave a speech to the Commercial Club at a luncheon in Halifax. A photograph accompanies this report of the address.

C40     D[eacon]., W[illiam]. A[rthur]. "The Fly Leaf." [The Globe and Mail (Toronto), 3 Feb. 1945.] [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2.202.B. Vol. 1 (Scrapbook).] Raddall is suggested as one possible candidate in this discussion of who is Canada's major novelist.

C41     "Authors Visit Howe's Grave." Liverpool Advance, 22 March 1945, p. 1. Raddall and James Gillis, the Cape Breton poet, visited Joseph Howe's grave in Halifax.

C42      "On the Radio." Liverpool Advance, 22 March 1945, p. 1. Raddall and James D. Gillis, the Cape Breton poet, have twice been on the radio during the previous week.

C43      "Author Gives Address to Historical Society." The Halifax Herald, 13 Aug. 1945, p. 3. Raddall spoke on the "First Settler of Nova Scotia" to the Cape Sable Historical Society in Barrington, Nova Scotia, on 12 July.

C44     [Rae, James Penman.] "Rae-views." Parnassus [Toronto], Sept. 1945, p. 19. Raddall's "Where the Dead Lay Thickest" (B175) is "one of the sincerest and most beautiful tributes ever paid by a loving son to a beloved father."

C45      Thomas, Clara. "Raddall, Thomas H." In her Canadian Novelists, 1920-1945. Toronto: Longmans, Green, 1946, pp. 100-01. A bio-bibliographical note.

C46     "Tom Raddall Enchants with Stories of Beloved Micmac 'Scabby Lou.'" Hants Journal [Windsor, N.S.], 22 May 1946, p. 1. Raddall delivered an address at King's College School, Windsor, Nova Scotia.

C47      "Tendered Luncheon." [Halifax Star, 28 June 1946.] [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2. 202. B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] Raddall was being tendered a luncheon by McClelland and Stewart (his publisher) in Toronto.

C48     W., E.L. "Raddall Used to Walking Deck of a Bluenose Ship." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 29 June 1946, p. 10. Raddall's visit to Toronto was the first time he had been more than fifty miles from the sea. The article is mainly composed of bio-bibliographical data on Raddall's work to date.

C49     "Canadian Authors Meet at Convention." Quill & Quire, July-Aug. 1946, p. 36. Raddall attended the convention of Canadian authors.

C50     Beecroft, John. "Pride's Fancy: The Story behind the Illustrations." Wings: The Literary Guild Review, Nov. 1946, pp. 7-9. Beecroft discusses the illustrations for Pride's Fancy and gives some biographical details about Raddall as a means of introducing Pride's Fancy as a book-club choice.

C51     "In the Editor's Confidence." Maclean's, 1 Nov. 1946, p. 4. A biographical note.

C52     "Author Thinks Sexy Novel Has Now Run Its Gamut." Toronto Daily Star, 18 Nov. 1946, p. 2. Raddall spoke on the fashion for sex in novels, on his work habits, and on his early life.

C53      "Let's Ignore Dirty Writers Author Urges." Windsor Daily Star [Windsor, Ont.], 19 Nov. 1946, p. 9. While speaking in Toronto, Raddall deplored the exploitation of sex in modern novels.

C54      Hurlow, W.J. "Writer Raddall Raps Obscenity by Novelists." The Evening Citizen [Ottawa], 29 Nov. 1946, p. 21. Hurlow reports Raddall's comments on the use of obscene words and on the exploitation of sex in modern novels.

C55     "Raddall Tells of His Experiences." The Evening Citizen [Ottawa], 29 Nov. 1946, p. 21. Raddall gave an address to the Ottawa branch of the Canadian Authors' Association.

C56     "Thomas H. Raddall Describes Best Method of Writing Novel." The Evening Journal [Ottawa], 29 Nov. 1946, p. 25. Raddall spoke to the Ottawa branch of the Canadian Authors' Association. Some biographical information is also included.

C57     "'Teddy' Roosevelt Made Him Author, Raddall Asserts." The Standard [Montreal], 30 Nov. 1946, p. 3. Raddall gave an address to the Montreal branch of the Canadian Authors' Association. Theodore Roosevelt's influence on Raddall's writing is also noted.

C58       "May We Present? -- Thomas H. Raddall." Quill & Quire, Dec. 1946, pp. 28-29. Bio-bibliographical data.

C59       "Canadian Authors Hear T.H. Raddall." The Gazette [Montreal], 2 Dec. 1946, p. 4. Raddall gave an address to the Montreal branch of the Canadian Authors' Association. References are also made to Raddall's early career.

C60      Eggleston, Wilfred. "The Causerie." Winnipeg Free Press, 16 Dec. 1946, p. 17. Eggleston refers to Raddall's research techniques.

C61     Portrait. Saturday Night, 28 Dec. 1946, p. 4. This is a pencil sketch of Raddall by Stanley G. Moyer and a comment on the recent success of Pride's Fancy.

C62     Pacey, Desmond. "Thomas H. Raddall." In A Book of Canadian Stories. Ed. Desmond Pacey. Toronto: Ryerson, 1947, p.222. Rpt. (revised). 2nd rev. ed., 1962, p. 155. Pacey claims that Raddall is the leading present-day exponent of the Romantic tradition in Canadian fiction, a tradition he associates with John Richardson, Rosanna Leprohon, William Kirby, Gilbert Parker, Charles G.D. Roberts, Theodore Goodridge Roberts, and others. Pacey suggests that the chief influence on Raddall was the Romantic school of fiction in England represented by Robert Louis Stevenson and Joseph Conrad, and at the lower level by Henry Rider Haggard and Thomas Henry Hall Caine. Pacey states that Raddall lacks the psychological subtlety and the richness of style of Conrad and Stevenson, but he can be vivid and vigorous, rich in local colour, and full of suspense. The second revised edition is updated.

C63     "Thomas H. Raddall." The School [Faculty of Education, Univ. of Toronto], 35 (Feb. 1947), 346. Brief biographical data.

C64     "News from the World of Books: Halifax Fetes Raddall." Quill & Quire, Dec. 1948, p. 22. Raddall is held in high regard in Halifax, where he grew up.

C65     "Dalhousie Honors Author." [Halifax Mail-Star, 9 March 1948 (sic; 1949).] [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2. 202. B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] A photograph shows Raddall receiving his honorary LL.D.

C66     "Noted Liverpool Author Receives Honorary Degree." The Chronicle-Herald [Halifax], 9 March 1949, p. 9. Raddall received an honorary degree at Dalhousie University.

C67     "The Honor Is Well Deserved." [Editorial. Halifax Chronicle-Herald, 10 March 1949.] [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2. 202. B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] Dalhousie University has bestowed an honorary LL.D. on Raddali, who has greatly contributed to Canadian literature.

C68     "Dr. Raddall Invested at Dal." Liverpool Advance, 10 March 1949, p. 1. Raddall received an honorary degree at Dalhousie University.

C69     "Dalhousie Honors Noted Canadian Author'." The Alumni News [Dalhousie Univ.], April 1949, pp. 13-14. C.L. Bennet's citation is included in this report of Raddall's receipt of an honorary degree at Dalhousie University.

C70     Shaw, Hugh. "Between Ourselves: Bluenose Boswell." The Standard Magazine [The Standard] [Montreal], 4 June 1949, p. 2. This short biographical note introduces Raddall's article on Halifax (B129).

C71     "Thomas Raddall's Book on Halifax Wins Award." [Halifax Chronicle-Herald[ 11 June 1949. [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2. 202. B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] Raddall received the Governor-General's Literary Award for Non-Fiction for Halifax, Warden of the North. A photograph is included.

C72     "Governor-General's Literary Awards." Canadian Author & Bookman, 25, No.2 (Summer 1949), 12. Raddall was awarded the 1948 Governor-General's Literary Award for Creative Non- Fiction for Halifax, Warden of the North.

C73     "Attends Authors Convention." [Halifax Chronicle-Herald] 6 July 1949. [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2.202. B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] A photograph, with a brief caption, shows Raddall with the other delegates to the Canadian Authors Association Convention in Halifax.

C74     "Premier Angus L. MacDonald of Nova Scotia." [The Globe and Mail (Toronto), 16 July 1949.] [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2. 202. B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] A photograph, with a brief caption, shows Raddall with the Premier after receiving the Governor-General's Literary Award for Non-Fiction.

C75      "Notes about People: Raddall Goes Modern." Quill & Quire, Aug. 1949, p. 18. The author refers to the Reprint Society of Canada's edition of Roger Sudden and says that Raddall is currently working on a novel based on his own experience as a wireless operator in lonely stations. The article also includes brief comments on Raddall's interest in Indian artefacts and his experiences in the reserve of the West Nova Scotia Regiment during World War II.

C76      "Halifax Is Suffering from Dual Personality." The Chronicle-Herald [Halifax], 21 Sept. 1949, p. 22. Raddall's address to the Kiwanis was on "Romance of Halifax."

C77     "A Maritimes Album." Mayfair, Oct. 1949, p. 60. A photograph, with a brief caption, shows Raddall at a Navy Week buffet in Halifax.

C78     "Special Gift for Liverpool Author." The Chronicle-Herald [Halifax], 23 Nov. 1949, p. 2. The West Nova Scotia Regiment (Reserve) presented Raddall with a silver tray for writing the history of the regiment. A photograph is included.

C79     "Author Honored." Liverpool Advance, 24 Nov. 1949, p. 1. The West Nova Scotia Regiment (Reserve) presented Raddall with a silver tray for writing the history of the regiment. A photograph is included.

C80       Rhodenizer, Vernon Blair. "Thomas H. Raddall (1903-)." In his At the Sign of the Hand and Pen: Nova Scotian Authors. Halifax: Nova Scotia Branch Canadian Authors Association, [1949], p. 19. Rpt. Toronto: Canadian House, 1968, p. 19. Bio-bibliographical data.

C81     "Fiftieth Anniversary of Board of Trade." Liverpool Advance, 15 June 1950, p. 1. Raddall was a guest speaker at a banquet in Liverpool, Nova Scotia. His address concerned the history of trade in Liverpool.

C82     "N.S. Author Tells Thrilling Story of Tarleton's Legion." Wolfville Acadian [Wolfville, N.S.], 23 Nov. 1950, p. 1. Rpt. ("Dr. Thomas Raddall Tells Story of Tarleton's Legion") in Liverpool Advance, 30 Nov. 1950, p. 7. Raddall spoke on Tarleton's Legion to the Wolfville Historical Society. A summary of the talk and quotations are included.

C83     Chalmers, J.W., and H.T. Coutts. Landmarks: A Guidebook for Prose and Poetry for Canadians. Toronto: Dent, 1951, p. 53. Chalmers and Coutts include teaching notes on "The Pied Piper of Dipper Creek." Raddall is "one of Canada's foremost novelists." The aim of the teacher when examining this story should be to increase students' knowledge of Canada's land and people, in this instance, the Highland Scottish ancestry of many Cape Bretoners.

C84     "Nova Scotia Author Addresses Club." [Halifax Chronicle-Herald, Jan. 1951.] [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2. 202. B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] A photograph, with a brief caption, shows Raddall addressing the Liverpool, Nova Scotia, Kiwanis Club.

C85     Phelps, Arthur Leonard. "Thomas Raddall." In his Canadian Writers. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1951, pp. 60-69. Phelps praises Raddall's short story "Before the Snow Flies" (B23) and his Halifax, Warden of the North. He argues that readers outside Canada are enthusiastic towards Raddall, but in Canada the response is ignorant, grudging, or apathetic. "It is the nemesis of our colonialism at work once again."

C86     Walbridge, Earle F. "Thomas H. Raddall." Wilson Library Bulletin, 25 (April 1951), 576. Rpt. in Current Biography Yearbook 1951. Ed. A. Rothe. New York: H.W. Wilson, 1952, pp. 497-98. Bio-bibliographical data with a photograph.

C87     Ness, Margaret. "Now When I Was a Bride ..." Saturday Night, 12 June 1951, p. 30. Ness reports Edith Raddall's (Raddall's wife's) story of her wedding.

C88     "Liverpool Man Appears Before Supreme Court on Manslaughter Charge." The Chronicle-Herald [Halifax], 13 June 1951, p. 11. Raddall was foreperson of the jury in the manslaughter case that he used in his The Wings of Night.

C89     "Jury Acquits Liverpool Man of Manslaughter." The Chronicle-Herald [Halifax], 14 June 1951, p. 13. Raddall, foreperson of the jury, was cheered in court after giving a "not guilty" verdict in the manslaughter case that he used in The Wings of Night.

C90     "Plaque to Mark Site of Old Indian Encampment." The Chronicle-Herald [Halifax], 19 June 1951, p. 5. Raddall was the guest speaker at the unveiling of a plaque to mark an ancient Micmac camp at Shubenacadie, Nova Scotia. A photograph is included.

C91     "Canadian 'Sparks.'" CBC Times, 2-8 Dec. 1951, p. 5. Raddall will give three talks to mark the fifty-year celebration of the first wireless transmission.

C92     Pacey, Desmond. Creative Writing in Canada: A Short History of English-Canadian Literature. Toronto: Ryerson, 1952, pp. 158, 163-65, 190, 197-98. Rpt. (revised). 2nd ed., 1961, pp. 187, 193-96, 255, 275. Raddall is a "conscientious craftsman and stylist" and "undoubtedly the most distinguished present day exponent of the historical romance in Canada." Pacey's warmest praise is reserved for His Majesty's Yankees, its portrayal of "turbulent characters" and "violent emotions" and its vivid and compelling climax. His reactions to other works prior to The Nymph and the Lamp are mixed and generally less favourable. This last novel, however, he praises for its "capacity to deal convincingly with the contemporary scene," its "rapid" pace, and for its convincingly realistic portrayal of Sable Island. He does, however, criticize the characterization of the female protagonist and the "too elaborately contrived" ending. Pacey's later review of At the Tide's Turn and Other Stories (D70) revealed a self-confessed bias against historical fiction. And, although Pacey repeats many of his earlier comments in the revised edition of his book, he is increasingly less favourable to Raddall's work. Of the books published since The Nymph and the Lamp, he concludes that, although the historical romance "is likely to survive merely as a form of popular entertainment rather than as a serious literary enterprise" the genre arise s from "a failure of nerve, from a fear of attempting to cope with the complexity and amorphousness of contemporary Canadian society."

C93     Shea, Harold. "'Heart' of World's First Radio Set Preserved by Nova Scotia Author." The Chronicle-Herald [Halifax], 11 Feb. 1952, p. 9. Shea notes details concerning the former Marconi radio set used on the Mackay-Bennett. Raddall served as a radio operator on this ship and was instrumental in preserving part of the radio.

C94     Roberts, Kenneth L. "Raddall and Monsarrat." The Globe and Mail [Toronto]. "Saturday Review of Books," 27 June 1952, p. 4. Roberts briefly refers to what Raddall and Nicholas Monsarrat had to say about writing during a convention of Canadian authors. Raddall said that he begins with the characters and opening incident and "feels his way forward." A photograph of the two writers is included.

C95     "Karsh's Halifax, Warden of the Atlantic." Maclean's, 15 Feb. 1953, p. 10. In Yousef Karsh's photographic essay on Halifax, a photograph of Raddall on the historic Citadel Hill is included because "author Thomas H. Raddall often writes of Nova Scotia's past."

C96     "Dr. Raddall on Air Sunday." Liverpool Advance, 12 March 1953, p. 1. Raddall will speak on radio concerning his own work (B195).

C97       Young, Scott. "What's Wrong with the Canadian Novel?". Saturday Night, 29 May 1954, pp. 16-17. In a passing reference to Raddall, Young points out that Raddall is the only Canadian novelist he knows who makes a living from writing novels.

C98     Hill, Mary O. "How Factual Is the Novelist's Businessman?". Canadian Business [Montreal], June 1955, pp. 25, 26, 28. In brief, passing references to "Tambour," Hill notes the manner in which the passions and "dark motivations" of the central character, Saxby Nowlan, overrule his business judgement.

C99     Thomson, James S. "Lorne Pierce Medal: Thomas Head Raddall." Royal Society of Canada, Transactions, Ser. 3, 50 (1956), 37-38. Thomson reports on the June meeting of the Royal Society of Canada and the presentation of the Lorne Pierce Medal to Raddall "in recognition of his distinction as a novelist, as a writer of stories, and as a historian." In particular it is remarked that "with fresh vigour of new inspiration he [Raddall] has exercised himself in the oldest of the arts, delighting the mind by the revival of heroic history, writing of things elemental and courageous to fire the heart in another and very different day."

C100     "T.H. Raddall Wins Literature Award." The Chronicle-Herald [Halifax], 12 June 1956, p. 1. Raddall was awarded the Royal Society of Canada Lorne Pierce Medal for outstanding contributions to Canadian literature.

C101     Daniells, Roy. "Literature: Poetry and the Novel." In The Culture of Contemporary Canada. Ed. Julian Park. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell Univ. Press, 1957, pp. 30-31. Raddall is listed among the "enviable group of exponents" of the regional novel in Nova Scotia. Daniells praises Raddall's ability to combine action and description "to produce a kind of novel which is a staple of Canadian fiction and which no contemporary handles better." In this kind of narration, "... plot gives way to episode, and delineation of human character is subordinated to the character of the land itself -- and, in this instance, to the Nova Scotian seas ..." Brief comments then follow on the manner in which the land and the sea have an integral role in His Majesty's Yankees and The Nymph and the Lamp.

C102     Bissell, Claude T. "The Novel." In The Arts in Canada: Stocktaking at Midcentury. Ed. Malcolm Ross. Toronto: Macmillan, 1958, pp. 92-96. Bissell speaks of Raddalrs "compelling power to render time and place that raises a novel like His Majesty's Yankees far above the level of previous Canadian historical fiction." In novels such as The Nymph and the Lamp, Raddall uses the methods of the historical romance. These include "a sweeping, rhetorical style and a heavier concentration on place than person."

C103     "Thomas Raddall Awarded Prize for Third Time." The Chronicle-Herald [Halifax], 3 May 1958, p. 32. Raddall has won the Governor-General's Award for History for The Path of Destiny.

C104     Bevan, Allan. Introduction. In At the Tide's Turn and Other Stories. By Thomas H. Raddall. New Canadian Library, No.9. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1959, pp. v-xi.   Bevan discusses some of the features of historical fiction and praises Raddall as a fine exponent of the genre, pointing out that he should be judged according to the nature of the genre. Raddall "writes about the past with knowledge, understanding, humour, and affection."

C105     MacDonald, Sandy. "Jewish Merchants Played Role in Early History." The Mail-Star[Halifax], 21 March 1960, p.15. Rpt. in Shalom, 5, No.4 (March-April 1980), 47-48. MacDonald comments upon Raddalrs portrait in His Majesty's Yankees of Aaron Hart, the first Jew to settle permanently in Canada, in 1759. MacDonald argues that Hart is presented as "a philosophical, pacifist Jew" who is "so often the object of discrimination that he is the first to seek justice for others."

C106     "Liverpool Author Wins Novel Prize: $10,000 for Wentworth Story." The Chronicle-Herald [Halifax], 20 June 1960, p. 5. The Governor's Lady has been awarded the 1959 Doubleday prize and has been named the December 1960 Doubleday Book Club selection.

C107     Pike, David. "Novelist Raddall in Unique Place." The Chronicle-Herald [Halifax], 22 Sept. 1962, p. 25. In April and May of 1963 CBC will present eight one-hour television episodes based on Raddall's The Wings of Night (C208).

C108     Matthews, John. Introduction. In The Nymph and the Lamp. By Thomas H. Raddall. New Canadian Library, No.38. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1963, pp.v-ix. Matthews perceives a continuity between the themes of Raddall's earlier historical novels and The Nymph and the Lamp, the first of his novels with a modern setting. "Whether Raddall's narratives are set against the clash of Indians, French, British, Americans, privateers, or pirates, an emphasis is always upon the analysis of human motive and of the individual's overriding responsibility for his own integrity." Matthews considers that the novel "is satisfying at many levels," among which he includes Raddall's handling of narrative, his presentation of the contrasting worlds of the Annapolis Valley and Marina (Sable Island), and the mythic significance with which Raddall invests his principal characters.

C109     "Raddall, Thomas Head, 1903- ." In Contemporary Authors: A Bio-Bibliographical Guide to Current Authors and Their Works. Ed. James M. Ethridge. Vol. II. Detroit: Gale, 1963, 155-56. Rpt. (revised). First Revision Series. Ed. James M. Ethridge and Barbara Kopala. Vols.I-IV. Detroit: Gale, 1967, 781-82. Bio-bibliographical data.

C110     Robinson, Cyril. "A Novel Series for TV." Weekend Magazine, No.11, 1963, pp. 10-13. Robinson discusses the filming in Nova Scotia for the eight-episode television dramatization of Raddall's The Wings of Night (C208). Photographs of the filming and of the various actors are included. Robinson tells of how some scenes were shot around Sheet Harbour, but most were shot within an hour's drive of Raddall's home in Liverpool and, hence, in the actual area in which the novel was set.

C111     Spicer, Stanley T. "Great Stories to Tell: A Profile of Thomas H. Raddall." The Atlantic Advocate, Dec. 1963, pp. 44-46. Essentially this is a portrait (with photographs) of Raddall. However, Spicer includes a swift survey of Raddall's works, comments on his working habits, and mentions some of Raddall's favourite authors, among them Joseph Conrad, Rudyard Kipling, T.E. Lawrence, and Thomas Chandler Haliburton. Spicer agrees with John Buchan (C12) that Raddall belongs in the tradition of Walter Scott, Robert Louis Stevenson, Guy de Maupassant, and Rudyard Kipling as a teller of tales.

C112     "Thomas H. Raddall (1903- )." In Ecrivains Canadiens/ Canadian Writers: A Biographical Dictionary. Ed. Guy Sylvestre, Brandon Conron, and Carl F. Klinck. Toronto: Ryerson, 1964, p p.lll-12. Rpt. (revised) in Canadian Writers/ Ecrivains Canadiens: A Biographical Dictionary. Rev. and enl. ed. Toronto: Ryerson, 1966, pp. 125-26. This entry contains mainly bio-bibliographical material, but includes comments on the fact that Raddall belongs to "the Romantic tradition of novelists" and that he uses little psychological subtlety, instead offering "vivid and suspenseful tales of an age when the heroic virtues of courage and magnanimity had full play."

C113     "Thomas Head Raddall." Canadian Library [Ottawa], 20 (May/mai 1964), Pt. II, 382. Raddall will be the guest speaker at the luncheon on 10 June at Halifax Citadel. A photograph of Raddall and a bio-bibliographical note are included.

C114     Morton, E.H. "Halifax Conference, June 7-12, 1964." Canadian Library [Ottawa], 21 (Sept/ sept. 1964), 72. Raddall was the guest speaker (a "rare treat") at the luncheon at Halifax Citadel on 10 June.

C115     Fowke, Edith. "Folktales and Folk Songs." In Literary History of Canada: Canadian Literature in English. Gen. ed. and introd. Carl F. Klinck. Toronto: Univ. of Toronto Press, 1965, p. 171. 2nd ed., 1976. Vol. I, 185. Fowke briefly notes that old Canadian ballads play a leading role in Raddall's "fine short story 'Blind MacNair.'"

C116     Kilbourn, William. "Canadian History and Social Sciences after 1920: I. The Writing of Canadian History." In Literary History of Canada: Canadian Literature in English. Gen. ed. and introd. Carl F. Klinck. Toronto: Univ. of Toronto Press, 1965, p.509. Rpt. ("The Writing of Canadian History"). 2nd ed., 1976. Vol.II, 33. Raddall is mentioned, among others, in a discussion of "Some of the best historical writing by Canadians [that] has been regional or local in character."

C117     McPherson, Hugo, with Douglas Spettigue and Miriam Leranbaum. "Fiction 1940-1960." In Literary History of Canada: Canadian Literature in English. Gen. ed. and introd. Carl F. Klinck. Toronto: Univ. of Toronto Press, 1965, pp.696-97, 720, 721. 2nd ed., 1976. Vol.II, 207-08. In a discussion of Raddall's historical fiction, the authors comment on Raddall's "unusual ability to recreate moments of dramatic action" and on his "vigorous, fluent, highly sensory style." Raddall's weakness is his "inability to penetrate deeply into the psychology of his characters."

C118      Rhodenizer, Vernon Blair. Canadian Literature in English. Montreal: Quality, 1965, pp. 425, 550, 687, 782-83, 1041. Rhodenizer makes few critical comments, but he does mention the "vivid backgrounds" of Raddall's fiction. He also refers to Tidefall as "a powerful novel of contemporary life," whereas most critics have been very sparing in their praise of this particular novel.

C119     Watters, Reginald Eyre, and Inglis Freeman Bell. "Raddall, Thomas Head, 1903- ." In their On Canadian Literature 1806-1960: Theses on English-Canadian Literature, Its Authors and Language. Toronto: Univ. of Toronto Press, 1966, p. 143. Bibliographical data.

C120     Story, Norah. "Raddall, Thomas (1903- )." In her The Oxford Companion to Canadian History and Literature. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1967, pp.690-91. Rpt. in Supplement to The Oxford Companion to Canadian History and Literature. Ed. William Toye. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1973, p. 273. Story comments upon Raddall's "effective use of local colour" and his "careful research into the early history of Nova Scotia."

C121     "Canadians All: Thomas Raddall." Canadian Author & Bookman, 42, No. 3 (Spring 1967), 17. Bio-bibliographical information from a series of biographies of Canadian authors who have "chosen to remain in Canada" and who have all achieved personal success "without benefit of governmental grants."

C122     Hawkins, Walter John. "Thomas H. Raddall: The Man and His Work." Queen's Quarterly, 75 (Spring 1968), 137-46. Hawkins defines Raddall as a regional novelist, a Maritimer who perceives central Canada "as a complex, foreboding presence in the offing, a hostile" urban environment. He notes Raddall's preference for dealing with the concrete, whether based on historical fact or direct personal observation. Hawkins devotes much of his article to a biography of Raddall and to an account of Raddall's career as a writer.

C123     Cameron, Donald. "Letter from Halifax." Canadian Literature, No. 40 (Spring 1969), pp. 55-60. Cameron is mainly concerned with a re-telling of Raddall's biography, but he does point out how Raddall has been "curiously ignored by Academic criticism."

C124     Cameron, Donald. "Thomas Raddall: The Art of Historical Fiction." Dalhousie Review, 49 (Winter 1969-70), 540-48. Cameron remarks upon Raddall's international reputation, his popularity, his honours, and the ironic fact that "... there is hardly an essay on his work, and none that approaches it critically with any real degree of rigour or penetration." Cameron points out that historical fiction has generally been despised in the world of literary thought, and he goes on to note the parallels between the classic form of the historical novel as defined by Georg Lukacs and what one discerns in His Majesty's Yankees. He praises Raddall's ability to re-create the past, his ear for speech, and his dramatization of "the continuity between our present and our past."

C125     Jones, D.G. Butterfly on Rock: A Study of Themes and Images in Canadian Literature. Toronto: Univ. of Toronto Press, 1970, pp. 35-36, 68. Jones refers to Raddall's retelling of the story of Tarleton's Legion in "'The Harp Among the Reeds'" [sic; "A Harp in the Willows"]. He singles out Raddall's picture of the Southerners' heroic but vain attempt to create a settlement on the Nova Scotian coast and quotes Raddall's comparison of them to the exiled Israelites beside the waters of Babylon. Elsewhere, referring to the manner in which Canadians have historically attempted to live according to principles rather than "the spontaneous processes of nature," he mentions "At the Tide's Turn," in which the citizens of Liverpool, because of their faith in the crown and their faith in law and order, are led to oppose and fire upon their own kith and kin.

C126     Jones, Joseph, and Johanna Jones. Authors and Areas in Canada. People and Places in World English Literature, No.1. Austin, Tex.: Steck-Vaughn, 1970, pp. 54-55. Bio-bibliographical data.

C127     Reference Division, McPherson Library, University of Victoria, B.C., comp. "Raddall, Thomas Head* 1903- ." In their Creative Canada: A Biographical Dictionary of Twentieth Century Creative and Performing Artists. Vol. I. Toronto: Univ. of Toronto Press, 1971, 254-55. Bio-bibliographical data.

C128     Cameron, Donald. "Raddall, Thomas Head, 1903- ." In Contemporary Novelists. Ed. James Vinson. New York: St. Martin's, 1972,, pp. 1037-39; 2nd ed., 1976, pp. 1136-39; 3rd ed., 1982, pp. 543-45. Cameron stresses that Raddall is "curiously ignored by criticism." This maybe due to Raddall's conservativism: "... he is no experimenter in either form or choice of material, he is personally retiring, and he unabashedly seeks a wide audience." Cameron considers that Raddall's strengths as a writer are his strong sense of story, his "flair for the description of action," his "clear and muscular style," and his "astute awareness of the inter-relation between such private concerns as sex and such public concerns as revolution."

C129     Leitold, John Ronald. Introduction. In Roger Sudden. By Thomas H. Raddall. New Canadian Library, No.85. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1972, pp. [iv-viii]. Leitold points out Raddall's belief that the historical novel is an ideal form with which to "probe cultural roots." He uses this as his starting point for his analysis of Roger Sudden, in which he stresses the recurring motif of flight, something that he identifies as typical of romance. This motif and the corresponding unconscious search for the protagonist's self provide Leitold with the main material for his critical analysis.

C130     Watters, Reginald Eyre. "Raddall, Thomas Head (1903-)." In his A Checklist of Canadian Literature and Background Materials, 1628-1960. 2nd ed. Toronto: Univ. of Toronto Press, 1972, pp. 370, 726, 877, 891. Bibliographical data.

C131     Mathews, Robin. "Survival and Struggle in Canadian Literature." Rev. of Survival: A Thematic Guide to Canadian Literature, by Margaret Atwood. This Magazine Is about Schools, 6, No. 4 (Winter 1972-73), 122. Rpt. (revised "Margaret Atwood: Survivalism") in Canadian Literature: Surrender or Revolution. By Robin Mathews. Ed. Gail Dexter. Toronto: Steel Rail, 1978, p. 127. Mathews cites Raddall's works, among others', as examples of writing about families that cannot be adequately described by Margaret Atwood's "blunt" thesis.

C132     Dickson, Lovat. Wilderness Man. Toronto: Macmillan, 1973, pp. 50-51, 76, 102-03, 104. In this biography of Grey Owl, Dickson includes a number of critical statements about Raddall's very different views on this enigmatic Canadian folk figure. In In My Time: A Memoir, Raddall later pointed out that the discoveries about Grey Owl that he published in Footsteps on Old Floors: True Tales of Mystery were used very selectively by Dickson, Grey Owl's most persistent apologist. Raddall felt in particular that his damning exposure of Grey Owl's self-inflicted war wounds was deliberately ignored by Dickson.

C133     Mickleburgh, Brita. "Thomas Raddall." In Canadian Literature: Two Centuries in Prose. Ed. Brita Mickleburgh. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1973, pp. 232-34. Mickleburgh stresses the theme of travel in Canadian literature and the frequency of presentations of the landscape as something hostile. In "The Wedding Gift," the heroine turns an enforced journey and a vicious winter storm to her own advantage in order to replace an enforced marriage with one based on genuine affection.

C134     Parker, George L. "Thomas H. Raddall." In The Evolution of Canadian Literature in English 1914-1945. Ed. George L. Parker. Toronto: Holt, Rinehart and Winston, 1973, pp. 193-94. Parker provides a brief introduction to a reprint of Raddall's short story "Winter's Tale." He describes the typical Raddall story as "carefully-plotted" and "action centred," and he argues that the kind of story Raddall writes "has received little critical notice since the 1930s, when academic critics turned their attention to the modern short story (as practiced by Chekov and Joyce)." Such stories, he suggests, tend "to place more emphasis on the psychological springs of character than on external action." Parker considers that Raddall's chief virtues as a writer are his "crisp and elegant prose style," his emphasis on "character-in-action" and his ability in his historical romances to "re-create a past that contains a germ of a community's identity."

C135     Strickland, David. "Quotations" from English Canadian Literature. Modern Canadian Library. Toronto: Pagurian, 1973, pp. 13, 15, 25, 36, 43, 59, 67, 81, 108, 113, 123, 158, 160, 169, 173. Quotations from Raddall's works are listed under the headings "Ambition," "Argument," "Canada," "Courage," "Despair," "Fear," "God," "Indians," "Marriage," "Money," "Past," "United Empire Loyalists," "War," "Work," and "Yankee."

C136     Waterston, Elizabeth. Survey: A Short History of Canadian Literature. Methuen Canadian Literature Series. Toronto: Methuen, 1973, pp. 51, 107. Waterston notes that His Majesty's Yankees is a Canadian example of an historical novel examining Loyalist settlers in the Maritimes.

C137     Cogswell, Fred. Introduction. In Pride's Fancy. By Thomas H. Raddall. New Canadian Library, No.98. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1974, pp.iii-x. Cogswell places Raddall in the literary tradition of Walter Scott and his successors and argues that what "Scott did in the nineteenth century for Scotland, his follower, Thomas H. Raddall, might conceivably be attempting with respect to the Nova Scotia of the twentieth century." He sees in Pride's Fancy a central conflict between the noble and humanizing vision of Nathan Cain and the self-seeking, materialistic ego of Amos Pride. On its surface the novel depicts the triumph of the former, but historically it was the latter which triumphed in Nova Scotia. In his novel, Raddall allows the reader to perceive that something in our heritage has been tragically lost. "Thomas H. Raddall writes so very much about our past because he wants us to know both where we lost our way and how precious was the way which we lost."

C138      Moss, John. Patterns of Isolation in English-Canadian Fiction. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1974, pp. 109, 111, 127, 129-38, 146-48, 155, 157. Moss makes a number of passing references to Raddall's The Nymph and the Lamp and, in one chapter, provides a detailed analysis of certain aspects of the novel which he also compares with Ethel Wilson's Swamp Angel. Moss's main concern is with the manner in which Raddall explores the characteristics of his remote setting of Marina (Sable Island) "to evoke the universality of individual experience, and to circumscribe its uniqueness." The remote and austere Marina provides Raddall with "the appropriate context for a story of love and self-discovery emerging into consciousness, residual effects and behaviour engendered by the conditions of individual being." In Raddall's conception, man places demands upon his environment as surely as it imposes its own on him. For Moss this process is "akin to the romantic determinism of William Faulkner in the extent to which the characters submit to its effect on their lives."

C139     Colombo, John Robert. "Raddall, Thomas H." In his Colombo's Canadian Quotations. Edmonton: Hurtig, 1974, p. 488. Colombo quotes from His Majesty's Yankees and "The Canadian Age."

C140     "Raddall's Papers Go to Dal." Liverpool Advance, 22 May 1974, p. 1. Raddall's papers have been acquired by Dalhousie University.

C141     French, William. "Without Help -- Without Regrets." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 26 June 1975, [Sec. 1], p. 15. This article is based on an interview with Raddall. French reviews Raddall's life and early writing career and attempts to assess Raddall's achievement after thirty-seven years as a professional writer. Three of Raddall's nineteen books have won Governor-General's Awards. Raddall is particularly praised for his strong sense of place, for his meticulous historical research, and for his insistence upon fidelity to history.

C142     Colombo, John Robert. "Raddall, Thomas H." In his Colombo's Canadian References. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1976, p. 434. Brief bio-bibliographical data.

C143     Egoff, Sheila A. "Children's Literature to 1960." In Literary History of Canada: Canadian Literature in English. Gen. ed. and introd. Carl F. Klinck. 2nd ed. Toronto: Univ. of Toronto Press, 1976, Vol. II, 141. Raddall is listed among "Such well known and reputable authors ... [who] ranged in subject matter as diverse as the fur trade and the Canadian Navy in the Second World War."

C144     Fee, Margery, and Ruth Cawker. "Raddall, Thomas Head 1903- ." In their Canadian Fiction: An Annotated Bibliography. Toronto: Peter Martin, 1976, pp. 91-92, 119, 121, 123, 124, 127, 128, 131, 132, 141, 162. Bibliographical data.

C145     Bell, John. "A Chronicle of the Chronicler: Seven Decades of the Life of Thomas H. Raddall." Dalhousie University News, 6 Feb. 1976, pp. 6-7. A bio-bibliographical chronicle with photographs.

C146     Seaman, Andrew Thompson. "Literature in Atlantic Canada." Canadian Literature, Nos. 68-69 (Spring-Summer 1976), pp. 26-39. Seaman includes in his article a number of brief comments concerning Hangman's Beach and The Nymph and the Lamp. In Seaman's view the love-story in the former "dominates two-thirds of the novel" and is "crudely-spliced into the more serious historical themes of the novel by circumstances alone." The Nymph and the Lamp by contrast "possesses a nice artistic unity, with no sense of a split between academic research and romantic tale-telling."

C147     Gray, James. Introduction. In His Majesty's Yankees. By Thomas H. Raddall. New Canadian Library, No.133. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1977, pp. xi-xviii. Gray discusses the history of Nova Scotia at the time of the American Revolution and concludes that His Majesty's Yankees "admirably captures the spirit of this frustrating but ultimately fruitful period of our history." Gray praises Raddall's gifts as a storyteller, "his capacity for invoking the spirit of place as well as time," and his "rare talent for epitomizing a mood or an occasion." Gray also includes some interesting comments about Raddall's earlier drafts of the novel and the changes that were made during its composition.

C148     Moss, John. Sex and Violence in the Canadian Novel: The Ancestral Present. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1977, pp. 27, 105. Raddall is listed among "pioneers" of Canadian literature. The theme of "Trisexuality and the Urthona triangle" is discussed in relation to The Nymph and the Lamp.

C149     Young, Philip. Revolutionary Ladies. New York: Knopf, 1977, pp. 206-09. Young, with only a few qualifications, gives high praise on grounds of historical authenticity to Raddall's portraits of John Wentworth and Frances Wentworth in The Governor's Lady, a book that has received little positive comment from literary critics.

C150     Marchak, Patricia. "Given a Certain Latitude: A (Hinterland) Sociologist's View of AngloCanadian Literature." In In Our Own House: Social Perspectives on Canadian Literature. Ed. Paul Cappon. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1978, p. 194. "In the more rural hinterlands of Canada psychological portraits were even more subjected to social concerns?' Isabel, in The Nymph and the Lamp, is cited among characters who "find peace and salvation by turning their backs on urban societies?"

C151     Ross, Malcolm. "The Ballot." The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel, Univ. of Calgary, Calgary. 18 Feb. 1978. Printed in Taking Stock: The Calgary Conference on the Canadian Novel. Ed. Charles R. Steele. Downsview, Ont.: ECW, 1982, pp. 139, 152, 153. Raddall's The Nymph and the Lamp and His Majesty's Yankees were included in the "most 'important' one hundred works of fiction."

C152     Cockburn, Robert. "'Nova Scotia is My Dwelen Plas': The Life and Work of Thomas Raddall." Acadiensis: Journal of the History of the Atlantic Region [Univ. of New Brunswick], 7, No. 2 (Spring/printemp s 1978), 135-41. Cockburn's article is especially useful for its sympathetic attempt to deal with Raddall's critical reputation. He points out that in 1953 Jack McClelland told Raddall that "... he was Canada's outstanding, and best-selling, author." However, in the 1960s there was a transformation in Canadian sensibility, "changing tastes among the reading audience, and the rise to prominence of a pride of new, fashionable, less conventional novelists:' As a result, Raddall's reputation west of the Maritimes perished; ... when not a forgotten man, he was regarded as a minor talent, as a mere 'popular' historical novelist." Today "... Raddall is dismissed by those who shape literary taste for being only a writer of 'escape fiction.'"

C153     Melanson, Lloyd J. "Raddall, Thomas H. (1903-)." In his Thirty-Four Atlantic Provinces Authors. Halifax: Atlantic Provinces Library Association, 1979, p. 33. Bio-bibliographical data.

C154     Pacey, Desmond. Essays: Canadian Literature in English. Ed. and preface A.L. McLeod. Foreword H.H. Anniah Gowda. Powre above Powres, No. 4. Mysore, India: Centre for Commonwealth Literature and Research, Univ. of Mysore, 1979, p. 151. Raddall's early stories are "lithe and vigorous" and "are enlivened by vivid descriptive passages and by a robust humour. They often lack plausibility, however, and they never penetrate very deeply into character." His Majesty's Yankees is "Crowded with lively characters and a series of violent and surprising events" and is "carefully constructed and written in a sinewy style. It is perhaps the best historical novel of the period." His "later historical romances showed a steady decline," and "... his modern novels attain distinction only in their descriptive passages ..."

C155     "Raddall Writes Mersey History." Mersey Quarterly [Liverpool, N.S.], 67 (Nov. 1979), 5. Raddall was commissioned to write The Mersey Story to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the Bowater Mersey Paper Company.

C156     Fowke, Edith. "'Blind MacNair': A Canadian Short Story and Its Sources." In Folklore Studies in Honour of Herbert Halpert: A Festschrift. Ed. Kenneth S. Goldstein and Neil V. Rosenberg, with Richard E. Buehler, Sonia Paine, and Leslie Prosterman. Folklore and Language Publications Series, Bibliographical and Special Series, No.7. St. John's, Nfld.: Memorial Univ. of Newfoundland, 1980, pp. 173-86. Raddall's short story "Blind MacNair" is one of the best examples of the literary use of folklore in Canadian fiction. The words of some of the folksongs Raddall quotes are not from printed sources, but were obtained directly by Raddall himself from traditional singers. Fowke quotes a letter to her from Raddall in which he describes his sources. The location of the written transcripts of these sources is also given. "Raddall's story is a faithful presentation of folk tradition, and it is also a true artistic creation based on and strengthened by authentic folklore."

C157     Cunningham, John. "A Novel Life." Halifax, 2, No.4 (March 1980), 44-48. This article is based on an interview with Raddall, in which he recalls his experiences on Sable Island and the writing of The Nymph and the Lamp. Raddall mentions that a film company (he does not disclose which) has just bought an option on the novel. He also discusses his refusal to be "typecast": "I never intended to be typed as a historical novelist or a forest novelist or a sea novelist or any other kind of a stereotype:' Having retired from writing, Raddall explains that he is currently devoting much of his attention to historical research.

C158     Jones, Joseph, and Johanna Jones. Canadian Fiction. Twayne's World Authors Series, No. 630. Boston: Twayne, 1981, pp. 68-69. The authors briefly survey Raddall's works. The plot of The Nymph and the Lamp, a wife caught in the loneliness of a place to which her husband takes her, is compared to Susanna Moodie's backwoods and F.P. Grove's Prairie. The Nymph and the Lamp is Raddall's "best novel set in our time." The "vividness and power" of His Majesty's Yankees are unmatched by Roger Sudden and Pride's Fancy.

C159     Moss, John. "Raddall, Thomas." In his A Reader's Guide to the Canadian Novel. Toronto: McClelland and Stewart, 1981, pp. 228-30, 352, 353, 356, 361, 368, 369, 372, 378. Moss discusses His Majesty's Yankees and The Nymph and the Lamp. Raddall is "one of our finest story-tellers" and His Majesty's Yankees is "a sweeping tale that blends high romance with discerning political and social commentary." The novel has little in common with costume romances, although it abounds in "swashbuckling intrigue and adventure:' Moss comments on Raddall's careful historical research, praises his clear and precise prose, and the control of narrative and mood. The Nymph and the Lamp is primarily the story of a woman (Isabel Jardine) "growing into the full dimensions of her own personality, a woman taking possession of herself." She is liberated, not by love, but by self-knowledge, and this transition is handled by Raddall in a "convincing and engaging" manner. Raddall moves "perilously close to sentimental romance," but is saved by his firm hold on the psychology of his characters' lives. Image and symbol are merged quite brilliantly in the novel.

C160     Hancock, Glen. "Blackwood's Magazine, after 164 Years, Ceases Publication." The Chronicle-Herald [Halifax], 4 April 1981, p.7. Hancock discusses Raddall's early stories for Blackwood's Magazine and the status of the magazine in the late 1930s.

C161     Cameron, Silver Donald. "Raddall in Retirement." Atlantic Insight, 3, No.4 (May 1981), 40, 42. Cameron discusses Raddall's life and professional career and explains Raddalrs decision to stop writing after the completion of In My Time: A Memoir. He also mentions that Raddall is an admirer of Churchill's writing, but has found that authors he once admired such as Rudyard Kipling, Arthur Conan Doyle, and John Galsworthy no longer retain their appeal for him.

C162     Bauchman, Rosemary. "Dr. Thomas Raddall: 'I Was Primarily Interested in People.'" In her Scotia Story Tellers: Personal Glimpses of 7I Nova Scotia Writers. Hantsport, N.S.: Lancelot, 1983, pp. 121-30. This profile of Raddall includes biographical data about his childhood, his education, his role in the army, his marriage, and his writing career. His second story, "Tit for Tat," was rejected by Maclean's, but accepted by Blackwoods Magazine. Raddall's relations with Maclean's and Blackwoods Magazine are discussed, as well as his beginnings as a writer. "Most of Thomas Raddall's eighteen books are based on historical events, all painstakingly researched in archives and museums, in studying old diaries and family papers, in talking to old-timers and acquainting himself with the scene of the action." Raddall's The Nymph and the Lamp "'has been translated into every language west of the Iron Curtain,'" and Raddall "has sold the movie rights to a Hollywood film company." Raddall was unable to watch the film being made because he had broken his leg. Raddall had always wanted to travel, but, by the time he had the leisure, his wife had died, and he "had a three year battle with blindness, cataracts, with post-operative troubles ..." Raddall decided to "stop writing before the quality of his work deteriorated" Thus, In My Time: A Memoir was his last book.

C163     Bumstead, J.M. "Historical Writing in English: 6. Popular History." In The Oxford Companion to Canadian Literature. Ed. William Toye. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1983, pp. 354-55. West Novas: A History of the West Nova Scotia Regiment and The Path of Destiny: Canada from the British Conquest to Home Rule 1763-1850 are apprentice works to Raddall's Halifax, Warden of the North, a work in which the author's strength in "forceful narrative and accurate setting' is exploited to the full.

C164     Cockburn, Robert. "Raddall, Thomas (b. 1903)." In The Oxford Companion to Canadian Literature. Ed. William Toye. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1983, pp. 692-93. Raddall's short stories demonstrate their author's "knowledge of the texture of Nova Scotia life, past and present, and his facility for straightforward, entertaining storytelling" Cockburn notes Raddall's meticulous historical research and robust style in the historical fiction and praises The Nymph and the Lamp as "a work of enduring merit that cannot be dismissed as romance." However, Tidefall and The Wings of Night are "mediocre by comparison."

C165     Hoy, Helen. "Raddall, Thomas (1903- )." In her Modern English-Canadian Prose. American Literature, English Literature and World Literatures in English Information Series, Vol. XXXVIII. Detroit: Gale, 1983, 369-75. Bibliographical data.

C166     Ripley, Gordon, and Anne V. Mercer. "Raddall, Thomas Head." Who's Who in Canadian Literature (1983-1984) (1983). Bio-bibliographical data.

C167     "Bowater Announces Thomas Raddall Prize in History." The Advance [Liverpool, N.S.], 21 March 1984, p.4A. The Bowater-Mersey Company has established a prize named after Thomas Raddall.

C168     "Literary Prize for Local Student." The Vanguard [Yarmouth, N.S.], 21 March 1984, p.7. The Bowater-Mersey Company has established a prize named after Thomas Raddall.

C169     Whiteman, Bruce. The Archive of the Macmillan Company of Canada Ltd.: Part I, 1905-1965 [Library Research News (McMaster Univ.), 8, No.1 (Spring1984)], 79. Whiteman provides a reference for material in the Macmillan archives between 1956 and 1963 relating to Raddall's The Rover: The Story of a Canadian Privateer (Box 128, folder 22).

C170     "Thomas H. Raddall Prize in History Announced by Bowater-Mersey" The Bulletin, Progress Enterprise, 4 April 1984, p.1.c. The Bowater-Mersey Company has established a prize named after Thomas Raddall.

C171     Keith, W.J. Canadian Literature in English. Longman Literature in English. New York: Longman, 1985, pp. 132-33, 268. Keith praises Raddall's ability, in His Majesty's Yankees, to explore "a serious theme conscientiously and responsibly" with "scrupulous historical accuracy" in an unostentatious style that is nonetheless "always appropriate and often quietly and movingly eloquent." The Governor's Lady maintains a fine balance between swashbuckling heroism and historical authenticity, but Pride's Fancy is little "more than a thrilling yarn." The short stories in The Wedding Gift and Other Stories impressively recreate "a community deriving strength and sustenance from its regional roots," and The Nymph and the Lamp is a twentieth-century romance that achieves "a human and timeless truth."

C172     McGregor, Gaile. The Wacousta Syndrome: Explorations in the Canadian Langscape. Toronto: Univ. of Toronto Press, 1985, pp. 48, 67, 134, 144-45, 156, 172. Raddall's works are drawn upon to exemplify various patterns in Canadian literature.

C173     "Raddall Honored." Acadia University Alumni Bulletin, 69, No.3 (Summer 1985), 9. At the dinner hosted by the Bowater-Mersey Paper Company, Dr. J. Perkin, President, Acadia University, presented Raddall with a copy of the plaque given each year to the winner of the T.H. Raddall Prize. The prize was established by the Bowater-Mersey Paper Company to promote historical research and literary excellence among high-school students.

C174     Young, Alan R. "The Genesis and Composition of Thomas H. Raddall's His Majesty's Yankees." Essays on Canadian Writing, No.31 (Summer 1985), pp. 142-57. Using Raddall's letters and manuscripts, Young attempts to show the sources of His Majesty's Yankees and the manner in which the novel was composed. Young shows how Raddall received early encouragement from the success of his historical short stories, one of which ("At the Tide's Turn") provided the initial inspiration for the novel. Young also discusses Raddall's research techniques, the important relationship between Raddall and his editor, Thomas Costain, and the many changes that occurred as the novel was written and re-written.

C175     Atwood, Margaret, and Robert Weaver, eds. The Oxford Book of Canadian Short Stories. Toronto: Oxford Univ. Press, 1986, p. 428. In this bibliographical note, Atwood and Weaver comment that "'The Wedding Gift' is an attractive example of Raddall's treatment of historical material in the short-story form."

C176     Bell, John. Foreword. In The Dreamers. By Thomas Raddall. Atlantic Classics. Porters Lake, N.S.: Pottersfield, 1986, pp. 5-7. The ten finely crafted stories in this collection have never appeared before in a published collection; yet they are "first-rate Raddall," spanning nearly three decades in Raddall's career. Bell describes Raddall's writing career from his early success in having his stories published in such prestigious and lucrative magazines as The Saturday Evening Post and Collier's to his "much lamented retirement in the early 1970s." Raddall's work forms "a body of writing that is equalled by few Canadian authors from his generation," a fact recognized when he received the Order of Canada in 1971. Though consciously "out of step with modernist literary practices, his writing displays the same virtues as that, of his chief mentors: Robert Louis Stevenson, Arthur Conan Doyle, Rudyard Kipling, and Joseph Conrad."

C177     "Three Live Ghosts." [The Advance (Liverpool, N.S.), n.d.] [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 202.2. B. Vol. I (Scrapbooks).] Raddall played Ghost No. 1 in the play Three Live Ghosts.

Previous Entry in publication.

Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Books, bibliographies, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Awards and honours  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

Miscellaneous

C212     Portrait. Saturday Night, 18 Dec. 1948, p. 21.A portrait of Raddall.

C213     Portrait. The Mail-Star [Halifax], 9 March 1949, p. 21. A portrait of Raddall receiving an honorary degree at Dalhousie University.

C214     Portrait. Saturday Night, 28 Nov. 1950, p. 24. A portrait of Raddall.

C215     Portrait. Canadian Business [Montreal], June 1955, p. 28. A portrait of Raddall.

C216     Portrait. Saturday Night, 9 Nov. 1957, p. 43.A portrait of Raddall.

C217     Portrait. The Chronicle-Herald [Halifax], 1 Oct. 1959, p.19. A photograph of Raddall addressing the Canadian Legion, Branch 38.

C218     "You Asked Us." The Canadian, 13 Sept. 1975, p.18. A portrait of Raddall.

C219     Portrait. The Canadian, 23 Dec. 1978, p. 4.A portrait of Raddall.

Awards and Honours

C220     Governor-General's Literary Award for Fiction for The Pied Piper of Dipper Creek (1944).

C221     Canadian Members' Book Choice, Literary Guild (Canadian Branch), for Pride's Fancy (1946).

C222     Canadian Radio Awards for 1949 gives first prize to "Canada's Heritage of Sail" (B188).

C223     Governor-General's Literary Award for Creative Non-Fiction for Halifax, Warden of the North (1949).

C224     Honorary LL.D., Dalhousie Univ., Halifax, N.S. (1949).

C225     Boys' Club of America Junior Book Award for Son of the Hawk (1951).

C226     Elected Fellow of the Royal Society of Canada (1953).

C227     Tidefall voted Book-of-the-Month, Book League of America (1954).

C228     Lorne Pierce Medal (Royal Society of Canada) (1956).

C229     Governor-General's Award for History for The Path of Destiny (1958).

C230     Doubleday Canada Novel Prize for The Governor's Lady (1960).

C231     Honorary D. Litt. from St. Mary's Univ., Halifax, N.S. (1969).

C232     Officer of the Order of Canada (1970).

C233     Honorary D.C.L., from Univ. of King's College, Halifax, N.S. (1972).

C234     Honorary LL.D., from St. Francis Xavier Univ., Antigonish, N.S. (1973).

C235     Gold Medal from the University of Alberta for "Distinguished Service to Canadian Literature" (1977).

C236     T.H. Raddall Prize, established by the Bowater Mersey Paper Company, for historical research and literary excellence, awarded to high-school students in western Nova Scotia (annual) (1984-).

Raddall; Books, bibliographies, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Bibliographies</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Books, bibliographies, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Bibliographies  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

     Bibliographies

C3    Martin, Margaret Elizabeth Burns. A Bibliography of the Published Work of Thomas Head Raddall. Together with a Short Bibliography of the Biographies of the Writer. Toronto: Univ. of Toronto School of Library Science, 1953.11 pp. This typescript contains bio- and bibliographical data.

C4     Young, Alan R. Thomas Head Raddali: A Bibliography. Preface Alan R. Young. Kingston, Ont.: Loyal Colonies, 1982. xi, 71 pp. This bibliography does not contain any critical annotations. It does, however, include a fairly comprehensive listing of book reviews and a long section of items relating to Raddall's biography. In the Preface, Young discusses the current critical neglect of Raddall and points out that the bibliography is not complete and should be taken as a mere preliminary.

C5      Special Collections Staff, Dalhousie University Library. Thomas Head Raddall: Bibliography. Halifax: Dalhousie Univ. Library, [n.d.]. 26 pp. In 1973 Dalhousie University obtained Raddall's papers and since that time the library has attempted to complete a full collection of his published works as well as any material published about him. This bibliography includes a listing of Raddall's novels, short stories, and articles. Also included are book reviews and short sections on criticism and biography. The compilers have made use of information on the publishing history of Raddall's works contained in the various files of his unpublished papers.

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Books, bibliographies, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Books  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

Part II

Works on Thomas H. Raddall

[underbar]

C   Books, Bibliographies, Articles and Sections of Books, Theses and Dissertations, Interviews, Adaptations, Miscellaneous, and Awards and Honours

Books

C1     Young, Alan R. Thomas H. Raddall. Twayne's World Author Series, No. 710. Boston: Twayne, 1983. [xiv], 152 pp. This first full-length critical examination of Raddall's work includes discussions of Raddall's early books and historical novels, his short stories, his three novels set in modern times, and his histories. The current neglect of Raddall by contemporary literary critics is considered, and it is argued that Raddall has suffered because Canadian literary critics, in their attempts to delineate the essential characteristics of their national literature, have been reluctant to accord historical fiction a respectable status. Throughout the book a certain amount of attention is given to Raddall's creative methods, and his unpublished manuscripts, now deposited in the Dalhousie University Archives, are frequently cited in order to show the genesis of each work and the creative processes of its author. Raddall's biography and writing career are also discussed but only insofar as they relate to his works and to our critical understanding of them.

C2      Barkhouse, Joyce. A Name for Himself." A Biography of Thomas Head Raddall. Contemporary Canadian Biographies. Toronto: Irwin, 1986. 87 pp. Barkhouse's biography is illustrated and includes a brief appendix listing "Honours and Awards" as well as a list of Raddall's published books. The bulk of the book is concerned with Raddall's life up to World War II. His career as a professional writer is given a more summary treatment, but this is appropriate since, as Barkhouse shows, Raddall became something of a recluse, immersing himself in the world of his fictions and histories, often at the expense of his family life. Much of Barkhouse's book is based on material in Raddall's In My Time: A Memoir, but a number of details appear to originate from her personal interviews with Raddall.

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Record: 114
Title:
Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Books, bibliographies, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Interviews
Other Title:
