<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP2000007004003005&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Books, bibliographies, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Interviews</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Books, bibliographies, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Interviews  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

Interviews

C183     Martell, J.S. Interview with Thomas Raddall. CJCH Radio [Halifax], 17 Nov. 1944. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.] This interview took place shortly after the publication of Roger Sudden. Raddall discusses why he has remained in Nova Scotia, despite his success at writing, commenting in particular on the importance for him of being in close contact with his subject-matter. Raddall goes on to describe his method of visiting the actual locations described in his stories, and he describes his visit to Louisbourg in preparation for the writing of Roger Sudden. Raddall explains that Roger Sudden is not the usual hero of historical romance, since he is a scoundrel.

C184     Martell, J.S. Interview with Thomas Raddall. CJCH Radio [Halifax], 1945. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.] Raddall begins by explaining the pronounciation of his name. He stresses that for him a short story must tell a tale, with a beginning, a middle, and an end. The writers who have most influenced him are Thomas Haliburton, Robert Louis Stevenson, Rudyard Kipling, Guy de Maupassant, Joseph Conrad, and Somerset Maugham. He describes his life in Nova Scotia, his early writing career, and his current work on Pride's Fancy.

C185     Sideris, Nita. "Thomas Raddall Interviewed by Gazette Staff Writer." Dalhousie Gazette [Dalhousie Univ.], 23 Feb. 1945, p. 2. Among other things, Raddall discusses his boyhood reading. Charles Reade, Frederick Marryat, and Robert Louis Stevenson still hold their charm for him.

C186     Frost, Rex. Interview with Thomas Raddall. CFRB Radio [Toronto], 28 June 1946. [Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.] Raddall discusses his working routine, his use of personal experiences in his fiction, and the real-life characters in his stories. He describes his historical research in preparation for the writing of His Majesty's Yankees, and he outlines the problems faced by a Canadian writer living in Canada.

C187     Barry, Keith. Interview with Thomas Raddall. Gazette. CBC TV, 30 Sept. 1958. [Public Archives of Nova Scotia; tapes 98 and 99. Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.] Barry asks Raddall why most of his books, if not all, are stories about Nova Scotia. Raddall replies that he feels any writer should stick with what he knows -- the scene and the people. He discusses his books, his career, and why he located in Nova Scotia.

C188     Barry, Keith. Interview with Thomas Raddall. Gazette. CBC TV, 23 Oct. 1958. Raddall discusses coming to Nova Scotia when he was a little over nine years old. He talks about being born in England, his father's military career, and his own work before becoming a writer.

C189     MacInnis, Lloyd. "Haliburton ('Clifton') House." Gazette. CBC TV, 12 Dec. 1960. [Public Archives of Nova Scotia; tape 136. Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.] Raddall and MacInnis discuss Thomas Haliburton and his best-known character, Sam Slick. Raddali talks about Haliburton's education at King's College, his becoming a judge of the Supreme Court of Nova Scotia, and his association with Joseph Howe. The second part of the interview is conducted in Haliburton's study. Here, MacInnis congratulates Raddall on winning the Doubleday Canada Novel Prize, and they discuss Raddall's The Governor's Lady for the remainder of the interview.

C190     Canadian Writers for Senior High Schools. Pt. IV. CBC Radio, 28 Nov. 1961. Raddall talks about his work, himself, and writing in general. He is interviewed in Liverpool, Nova Scotia.

C191     Homer, Ken. "Canadian Writers: Thomas H. Raddall." Prod. Sandy Lumsden. CBC TV [National School Telecast], 28 Nov. 1961. [Public Archives of Nova Scotia; tape, uncatalogued. Ts Dalhousie Univ. Archives.] This program was filmed in Perkins House, Nova Scotia. Homer and Raddall discuss Raddall's life in Liverpool and his writing of books and novels, including his latest book, The Governor's Lady. Raddall goes on to discuss the research for his books, and he reads a paragraph from Simeon Perkins' diary that he later used in The Wedding Gift.

C192     "Portrait of Thomas Raddall." Radio International. CBC Radio, 24 Aug. 1962. Raddall is interviewed at his home in the Maritimes.

C193     Willis, Frank. Interview with Thomas Raddall. Close-Up. CBC TV, 23 Sept. 1962. The sound track for this program includes Frank Willis interviewing Raddall.

C194     Assignment. CBC Radio, 11 April 1968. Raddall discusses the antecedants of Grey Owl.

C195     Thomas H. Raddall. CBC Radio, 6 Feb. 1969. In this brief, biographical, unedited telephone interview, Raddall discusses society's dangerous preoccupation with the present. He notes that his novels have been adapted for television and that Maclean's refused to print his stories until they found they had been published by the British Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh]. He discusses the demise of the Saturday Evening Post [Philadelphia] and Collier's, and the stories he wrote for them. Raddall mentions his life in Liverpool, Nova Scotia, where he has lived since 1923. The Nymph and the Lamp was his most successful novel. He discusses this, as well as the prospects for young writers living in Canada today and the research he is now working on.

C196     Interview with Thomas Raddall. Sunday Supplement. CBC Radio, 23 Feb. 1969. Raddall talks about his attempts to gain recognition and how his rejection by Maclean's led him to write for Blackwood's Magazine [Edinburgh] and receive more money.

C197     Cameron, Donald. "Thomas Raddall: The Past Is Always Important." Quill & Quire, Dec. 1971, pp.3, 9, 10. Rpt. (abridged) in Conversations with Canadian Novelists. By Donald Cameron. Toronto: Macmillan, 1973, pp. 99-113. This detailed interview covers Raddall's biography, his writing career, and isolated situation within Canadian letters. Cameron asks some important questions regarding Raddalrs concepts of historical fiction, and Raddall's answers help define the nature of his fiction. What interests him are the phases in history where something important in human destiny is being worked out. Raddall wants "to study the lives of the people who were connected with it, and to bring out the small details of their lives which gradually led to these decisions, these actions."

C198     Sorfleet, John Robert. "Thomas Raddall: I Was Always a Rebel Underneath." Journal of Canadian Fiction, 2, No. 4 (Fall 1973), 45-64. This interview includes information about Raddall's biography and writing career. Raddall notes the influence Thomas Haliburton and W.S. Maugham had on him. The former opened his eyes to the possibilities of humour in literature and offered a model of the way in which an ear for idiom could be of great advantage to a writer. What attracted Raddall to Maugham was the latter's ability to write a story "as if he were sitting down telling it to somebody in a quiet corner of a hotel." Elsewhere, Raddall expresses his strong admiration for Francis Parkman and his method of studying in great detail the actual locations of historical events prior to writing about them.

C199     Hale, Alice K. "An Interview with Thomas H. Raddall." In her An Introduction to Teaching Canadian Literature. Halifax: Atlantic Institute of Education, 1975, pp. 27-33. Raddall discusses the fact that he is not solely a writer of historical fiction, a role in which critics and publishers have often attempted to confine him: "... any writer ... should be able to write about the present or the past with equal facility, because his primary study is the human being, human nature." Raddall goes on to express his admiration for Thomas Haliburton, and, when asked about his response to certain modem Canadian writers, expresses admiration for Hugh MacLennan and Morley Callaghan.

C200     Copeland, Neil. "Neutral Yankees." Heritage. CBCTV, 9 Feb. 1977. Part I of a two-part program (see C201). Copeland interviewed Raddall in Liverpool, Nova Scotia. Raddall recounts how Simeon Perkins, commander of the Liverpool militia at the time of the American Revolution, led the citizens of the town when they took a stand against the New England privateers. Raddall discusses the significance of this incident and then goes on to discuss his own interest in local history and his career as a writer.

C201     Copeland, Neil. "Neutral Yankees." Heritage. CBCTV, 15 Feb. 1977. Part II of a two-part program (see C200). In this interview, which takes place in Liverpool, Nova Scotia, Raddall recalls his less than noteworthy days as a student and his fondness for history and English composition. He talks of his early career as a radio operator and his beginnings as a writer. He discusses briefly a number of his novels and the importance of historical research and the "mystic connection" of going to the actual site of the events he writes about. He ends by mentioning his decision in 1968 to stop writing.

C202     Hall, Steve. "Steve Hall Interviews Thomas Raddall." Prod. R.E. Bennett. CBC Radio [Halifax], 10, 17, 24, 31 Jan.; 7, 14, 21, 28 Feb.; 7, 15 March 1978. (10 parts.) [Public Archives of Nova Scotia; tapes, uncatalogued.] Raddall discusses his early years in Liverpool, his views of other writers, of universities, of Nova Scotia politics. He also describes the research for The Governor's Lady.

C203     Copeland, Neil. "Thomas Raddall at Eighty." Anthology. CBC Radio [Halifax], 12 Nov. 1983. Raddall talks about his schooldays, his early interests in history and English composition, and his voracious reading. He describes the necessity of getting a job at age fifteen after his father had been killed in World War I. He describes his job as a wireless operator at sea and then on Sable Island, his habit of keeping a diary, his love of Joseph Conrad, and his first short story. He then talks about his job as a book-keeper for a small pulp mill near Liverpool, Nova Scotia, of his growing interest in local history, and the beginning of his writing career. Finally, he talks about his attitude to critics, his relationships with publishers, his feelings about his own books, and his eventual decision to stop writing. Excerpts from In My Time: A Memoir are also read (B211).

C204     Johnson, Wendy. Interview with Thomas Raddall. First Edition. CBC TV [Halifax], 26 Sept. 1986. The main topic of the interview is supposed to be Raddall's new collection of short stories, The Dreamers. This collection was made up entirely of stories not previously published in any collection, although all had been published before in newspapers and magazines, one as long ago as 1928. Much of the interview, however, concerns Raddall's life, rather than the new book. He tells how he did not do well in school, but loved to read. During World War I, his father used to send him books from England, including books by Rudyard Kipling, from whom Raddall claims he learned his writing style. Raddall also comments on his early years as a radio operator and the Sable Island background for The Nymph and the Lamp. He recounts how that book brought protests from some readers who objected to the descriptions of sex in the book. The interview shows Raddall in his study in Liverpool, surrounded by the mementos of his literary career.

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP2000007004003004&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Books, bibliographies, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Theses and dissertations</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Books, bibliographies, articles and sections of books, theses and dissertations, interviews, adaptations, miscellaneous, and awards and honours; Theses and dissertations  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

Theses and Dissertations

C178     Rogers, Edith Laura. "The Life and Works of Dr. Thomas H. Raddall." M.A. Thesis Acadia 1954. Rogers' thesis contains quotations from long and detailed letters sent to her by Raddall. In these letters he provides a great deal of information about his writing career and works prior to 1954. Much of what he says has subsequently been re-stated in In My Time: A Memoir.

C179     Rogers, Robert Amos. "American Recognition of Canadian Authors Writing in English 1890-1960." Diss. Michigan 1964. Bibliographical data.

C180     Hawkins, Walter John. "The Life and Fiction of Thomas H. Raddall." M.A. Thesis New Brunswick 1965. Hawkins is primarily concerned with providing an exposition of Raddall's life together with various details about his works. Hawkins states that, though Raddall's fiction has been widely read in North America and Europe, it has not been the subject of detailed study by Canadian critics. The analysis of Raddall's artistry and technical skills that follows attempts to show that Raddall's characterizations tend to be weak, while his great strengths are to be found in his physical descriptions and fluent style.

C181     Leitold, John Ronald. "A Spirit of Place: The Historical Fiction of Thomas Raddall." M.A. The sis Dalhousie 1972. Leitold examines the prominent themes of Raddall's historical novels. He stresses the frequent use of the search for identity by, and the maturation of, the central characters in each novel. His Majesty's Yankees and The Governor's Lady "reflect, through an individual character, the response of people to conflicting political forces." Pride's Fancy and Hangman's Beach, on the other hand, "emphasize the role of natural forces in shaping a people's character." In Roger Sudden, Raddall depicts "the hardships of struggle against a hostile environment:' Throughout, Leitold attempts to place Raddall within the romance tradition.

C182     West, David Stanley. "Romance and Realism in the Contemporary Novels of Thomas H. Raddall." M.A. Thesis New Brunswick 1977. West discusses Raddall's three novels with modern settings -- The Nymph and the Lamp, Tidefall, and The Wings of Night. He argues that all these novels have the central theme that Romanticism is a necessary adjunct to life and must be preserved no matter how insistently life in the real world seems to demand its abandonment. According to West, Raddall deliberately uses Realism to undercut and modify the meaning of the romance conventions that he observes.

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; A Muster of Arms and Other Stories  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

A Muster of Arms and Other Stories

D67     Burnet, Jean. Rev. of A Muster of Arms and Other Stories. The Canadian Forum, Feb. 1955, p. 263. Burnet claims that this collection contains the typical charm of Raddall's Nova Scotian adventure yarns. However, the book begins with a laboured and predictable story and it ends "with a non-too-skilful rehash of Maritime history, as recorded in a farm wife's collection of firearms." When reading such items, one begins to feel impatient with Raddall's predilection for the yarn and "wishes that he would aspire to tightly strung plots, piercing psychological insights, and biting aptness of diction."

<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP2000007004004015&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; At the Tide's Turn and Other Stories</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; At the Tide's Turn and Other Stories  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

At the Tide's Turn and Other Stories

D68     "Books in Brief." Rev. of At the Tide's Turn and Other Stories, by Thomas Raddall; Arcadian Adventures with the Idle Rich, by Stephen Leacock; Habitant Poems, by William Henry Drummond; and Poets of the Confederation, ed. Malcolm Ross. The Dalhousie Review, 40 (Spring 1960), 131, 135. In a very brief review, it is stated that Raddall "is a superb story-teller with a deep awareness of the past, as he well demonstrates in these eleven stories ..."

D69     Woodcock, George. "Venture on the Verge." Canadian Literature, No.5 (Summer 1960), pp. 73-75. This is a very negative review in which Woodcock says that he finds it hard to see any justification at all for the inclusion of the book in the New Canadian Library series. The stories have "very little to be said for them," apart from "their money-earning possibilities" The characters are so shallowly drawn "that one cannot even begin to judge the psychological plausibility of their actions:' Although Raddall is a good historical researcher and the stories contain some effective and authentic detail, they have little more interest than the objects in a rural museum.

D70     Pacey, Desmond. Rev. of At the Tide's Turn and Other Stories. Queen's Quarterly, 68 (Spring 1961), 179-80. Pacey admits that he has a prejudice against historical fiction. Raddall's stories and Allan Bevan's Introduction to them, he explains, leave him "quite cold." What he cannot understand is why anyone would "turn his back on the contemporary life of Nova Scotia to write of these fancy-dress personages"

D71     Bickerstaff, Isaac. "New Canadian Library." Pt. I. Books in Canada, 2, No. 2 (April-May-June 1973), 34. Bickerstaff briefly notes that the emphasis in the collection is upon "fidelity to historical particular, on the musket-flash of battle, on the glimpse of a well-turned ankle, the stink of death when small pox savages a coastal settlement."

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; Footsteps on Old Floors: True Tales of Mystery  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

Footsteps on Old Floors: True Tales of Mystery

D83     Grant, Mary Kent. Rev. of Footsteps on Old Floors: True Tales of Mystery. Library Journal, 1 Feb. 1968, p. 574. This work is "more spell binding and more varied than the usual such collection." Grant praises Raddall's "study in depth" of the mystery surrounding the fate of the Mary Celeste.

D84     Boucher, Anthony. "Criminals at Large." The New York Times Book Review, 25 Feb. 1968, p. 34. Boucher praises Raddall's intensive research and his ability to "make the results palatable." Raddall knows "how to write a book of marked appeal to an unlimited public."

D85     F[ord]., E.K. "Kejimkujik Subject of Raddall Volume." The Advertiser [Kentville, N.S.], 7 March 1968, p. 17. Ford reviews each story and article in turn, praising Raddall's vivid descriptions and his ability to write in a way that "lives" and that "relieves history of the sterility so often associated with it." He also confirms Raddall's fidelity to "genuine local lore in every detail," whether in the matter of the lost gold of Kejimkujik or the bawdy houses of Halifax before and during World War I.

D86     Phillips, Bluebell. Rev. of Footsteps on Old Floors: True Tales of Mystery. Canadian Author & Bookman, 43, No. 4 (Summer 1968), 17. Phillips summarizes the six essays and concludes by remarking that "For those who love adventure and to adventure into the lives of people who are anything but mundane," the book "is a gold mine."

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP2000007004004018&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; Halifax, Warden of the North</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; Halifax, Warden of the North  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

Halifax, Warden of the North

D75     Nelles, Malcolm. "Halifax in a Balanced Treatment That Mirrors Its Achievement:' Saturday Night, 18 Dec. 1948, p. 21. Nelles considers that, compared to the dull painstaking efforts of earnest antiquarians, Raddall's history is vividly and skilfully told. Raddall's emphasis is upon the more distant past, which, Nelles implies, is as it should be if historical perspective is to be achieved. He praises in particular the physical format of the book.

D76     Dunn, C.W., and J. R. MacGillivray. "Letters in Canada: 1948. Canada: The Land and the People." University of Toronto Quarterly, 18 (April 1949), 303. The reviewers refer to the display of the "narrative skill of an experienced novelist," and they praise Raddall's "masterly historical synthesis of the abundant source-material" and his deftly realized characters.

D77     Hebb, Andrew. Rev. of Halifax, Warden of the North. The Canadian Forum, July 1949, p. 93. Hebb complains that the kind of details in the earlier chapters which build "an intimate and interesting picture of other times and other customs" have a tendency to become tedious in the later chapters that deal with modern times. He admits that the book must be the result of an immense amount of research, but, not being the work of a professional historian, it contains little political or economic interpretation. He points out a few minor errors and suggests, as Hugh N. MacLean does (D74), that the omission of a map is difficult to understand.

D78     Bonenfant, Jean-Charles. "Les livres canadiensanglais." La revue de l'Universite Laval, 5 (nov. 1950), 260-62. Raddall's careful and scholarly research is no bar to his ability to present the telling picturesque detail or to recreate the atmosphere of an historical period through the magic of his style. No other Canadian city has yet had such a history, written "avec autant de brio" by such an author. Halifax, Warden of the North is a work that will be consulted by scholars, but it is also delightful reading for the general reader.

D79     Cogswell, Fred. "Halifax History." Canadian Literature, No. 28 (Spring 1966), p. 72. In this discussion of the 1965 re-issue of the book, Cogswell refers to Raddall's combination of "thorough and careful historical research" with the best qualities he possesses as a novelist, among which are his "gift of concrete visualization" and his "ability to communicate that vision in English prose that is crisp and readable." He further refers to Raddall's "sense that the primary importance of any time and place lies in human beings." He considers Halifax, Warden of the North to be the most readable history of a Canadian city ever produced, but expresses disappointment that Raddall ignores the impact of evangelicism upon Crawley and the Grenville Street Anglicans and their subsequent conversion to the Baptist faith. He also suggests that Raddall should have dealt with book publishing and the small determined group of writers between 1820 and 1860 who attempted to keep alive a literary culture in the city.

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP2000007004004010&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; Hangman's Beach</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; Hangman's Beach  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

Hangman's Beach

D54     Snow, Katherine. Rev. of Hangman's Beach. Canadian Author & Bookman, 42, No. 1 (Autumn 1966), 19-20. The novel is a "masterful tale of adventure and romance" which "brilliantly brings to life the Town of Halifax" and recreates its "colorful history." The book "does not suffer from the current malady of super sexuality and the neurotic personality." It is "a superb novel, full of freshness and vigour." Its background is "so authentic that one can sense the diligent study and research required in its preparation"

D55     Braddock, John. "Two Master Story Tellers." Rev. of Hangman's Beach, by Thomas Raddall; and Come Back, Geordie, by David Walker. The Atlantic Advocate, Nov. 1966, p. 64. Raddall is a master storyteller "in an age of non-novels, stream-of-consciousness accounts, and episodic fragments." Braddock praises Raddalrs abilities as the author of a story of high adventure, love, intrigue, and suspense, and insists that there is nothing banal about the results. Raddall's historical research is also praised, as are his character portrayals.

D56     Stedmond, J.M. "Letters in Canada: 1966. Fiction." University of Toronto Quarterly, 36 (July 1967), 387-88. Raddall is an old hand at the historical novel, but this time "the kernel of his plot" is none too promising. Raddall does the best he can and "perhaps a little too much for those who are not ardent devotees" of historical fiction. The book displays diligent research but the main characters are "a bit wooden."

D57     Hawkins, W.J. Rev. of Hangman's Beach. Queen's Quarterly, 74 (Summer 1967), 345-46. Hawkins points out that readers "in search of a profound philosophical theme or of introspective characterization" will be disappointed because these are not Raddall's aims. He praises Raddall's direct and vivid style and his ability to make history a "living thing." He also discusses Peter McNab's character as an example of "the patriarch stereotype that appears frequently in Raddall's novels."

D58     Stuewe, Paul. "On the Racks: Half a Shelf, Half a Shelf, Half a Shelf: Onward Lumbers Our Paperback Hero." Books in Canada, Oct. 1979, p. 29. Hangman's Beach (together with The Governor's Lady [D53]) keeps "the historical pot boiling with competent re-creations of 18thcentury North American milieus." The novel emphasizes "descriptive scene-painting at the expense of plot and character development"

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

ABCMA07TRP2000007004004001
Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP2000007004004001&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP2000007004004001&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; His Majesty's Yankees</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; His Majesty's Yankees  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

D      Selected Book Reviews

His Majesty's Yankees

D1        Shorey, Katharine. Rev. of His Majesty's Yankees. Library Journal [New York], 15 Oct. 1942, p. 909. In this brief note, Shorey calls the book "excellent and exciting reading," comparable in style to Kenneth Roberts' writing and "good to read" along with Roberts' Oliver Wiswell.

D2     Hillyer, Dorothy. "Flimsy Promises from Massachusetts:' Boston Globe, 12 Nov. 1942, p.21. The title of the novel is misleading, since it would appear to imply that the book is concerned with Tories. However, "Every student of the Bay State should read this book." Hillyer praises in particular Raddall's vivid recreation of a mise-en-scene and ranks Raddall's abilities with those of Kenneth Roberts and Walter D. Edmonds.

D3     Wallace, Margaret. "In Nova Scotia." The New York Times Book Review, 15 Nov. 1942, pp. 12, 48. Wallace explains that the book offers an unusual thesis for United States readers since it suggests that there was a time in the late Autumn of 1776 when the United States flag almost acquired a fourteenth stripe to represent Nova Scotia. She points out that most Americans will not have heard of the siege of Fort Cumberland, an action which for Raddall has "all the significance of a Saratoga in reverse." She praises Raddall's style, but criticizes the "one glaring piece of theatrical contrivance in the manner of Luke Strang's death which strains the readers credulity to the snapping point." However, not since the arrival of the historical novels of Kenneth Roberts has there been a newcomer to historical fiction with such exciting potential.

D4        Benet, Stephen Vincent. "For King or Congress?". New York Herald Tribune, 29 Nov. 1942, p. 6. Raddall paints a vivid picture of an "independent people caught between two fires." Although Benet dislikes the ending of the book and the manner in which the shooting of Luke is handled, Raddall "can spin an exciting yarn" and has a "real feeling for nature."

D5     Whidden, Graham. "His Majesty's Yankees" Letter. [Halifax Chronicle, 12 Dec. 1942.] [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2. 202. B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] His Majesty's Yankees is "worthy of being set in every library, alongside the historical romances of Sir Walter Scott."

D6     "His Majesty's Yankees Nova Scotian Drama." The Halifax Herald, [13 Nov. 1942]. [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2.202. B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] Raddall reveals the Yankee, rather than British, heritage of many Nova Scotians in the 1750s. Raddall is skilled in presenting the results of fresh historical research, and the readable quality of his novel is entertaining.

D7     Follette, Wilson. Rev. of His Majesty's Yankees. The Atlantic Monthly, Jan. 1943, p. 144. His Majesty's Yankees, like James Fennimore Cooper's Pioneers, has the advantage of being an "outgrowth of [the author's] prolonged familiarity with a region and of [his I intense attention for it." Follette comments on the novelty of the perspective that the work offers with regard to the American Revolution. He praises Raddall's narrative abilities and the element in the work of "pure lyricism, omnipresent in the form of the Nova Scotian landscape, its woods and weathers and tides and seasons, its smells and bird song."

D8     Deacon, William Arthur. "When Nova Scotia Discovered Her Road of Special Destiny." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 2 Jan. 1943, p. 14. Deacon calls the novel "a first-rate yarn," but considers that it will fail in the American market because its thesis does not "flatter our good neighbors in the slightest." He stresses Raddall's painstaking research and argues that the novel should be important to Canadians because it depicts the painful process "by which the Bluenoses realized in 1776 that they must find some middle way between the Crown and the rebellious colonies." The book is "an instructive demonstration in the evolution of a peculiarly Canadian national policy," dramatizing a vital moment of Canada's national past.

D9     Rev. of His Majesty's Yankees. The Booklist [Chicago], 1 Feb. 1943, Pt. I, p. 225. In this brief notice, the reviewer praises the novel for having "plenty of fighting and action" and comments on Raddall's success "in picturing the country and the people" of Nova Scotia. However, "David's romance with a childhood sweetheart" is stereotyped.

D10     Gordon, Wilhelmina. "Among the New Books: III. Fiction." Rev. of His Majesty's Yankees, by Thomas Raddall; The Waltz Is Over, by Hester Pine; Wide Is the Gate, by Upton Sinclair; and Frontier Passage, by Ann Bridge. Echoes: The Official Publication of the Imperial Order Daughters of the Empire, No. 170 (Spring 1943), p.39. Raddall "has made a careful study of the conditions and events during the American Revolution ... With fairness and understanding he shows the grievances which made many of these seamen and farmers and fishermen sympathize with their kinsfolk .... Here is no mere picturesque and glamorous covering of history for a rather squalid tale, but a stirring tale of adventure...."

D11     MacGillivray, J.R. "Letters in Canada: 1942. Fiction." University of Toronto Quarterly, 12 (April 1943), 321. His Majesty's Yankees contains "intrigue, battle, imprisonment, escapes, and, of course, a love-story." MacGillivray also comments on the historical thesis that "... there were as many liberty-boys in Nova Scotia as in other colonies in 1774..." and concludes that the book rivals the best of current American historical fiction.

D12     West, David S. "Past and Present." Journal of Canadian Fiction, No. 20 (1977), pp. 152-55. Raddall is an important but neglected writer, and West has high praise for His Majesty's Yankees. In particular, he praises Raddall's historical realism and style.

D13     O'Hearn, D.P. "Striking Novel of Old Halifax; A Third Book by Emily Cart." Rev. of Roger Sudden, by Thomas Raddall; The House of All Sorts, by Emily Carr; Wednesday Morning, by Robert John Renison; All Clear, Canada, by Jim Wright; and Phantom Fur-Thieves, by Charles Clay. Saturday Night, 16 Dec. 1944, p. 25. O'Hearn praises the "flow" in Raddall's narrative and his refusal of the temptation to dwell "unduly on the dress, topics or idiosyncracies of the times" as lesser historical fiction is apt to do. Raddall's portrayal of the early Nova Scotian settlers and his handling of Indian life are good, but O'Hearn questions Raddall's over-reliance upon coincidence.

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Title:
Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; In My Time: A Memoir
Other Title:

<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP2000007004004021&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; In My Time: A Memoir</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; In My Time: A Memoir  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

In My Time:A Memoir

D87     MacLennan, Hugh. "Raddall of the Sands: From CanLit's Warden of the East, a Magnificent Journey of Self Discovery." Books in Canada, Nov. 1976, pp. 3-5. MacLennan explains that, in his view, an autobiography should not be the story of a career "but of a human life." In My Time: A Memoir is "one of the finest autobiographies" that he has ever read. Most of the review recapitulates Raddall's biography as it is revealed in the book, but MacLennan ends with the statement that "Raddall's country did not include Quebec, Toronto, the West, British Columbia, or le grand nord, but for all that he is as authentically Canadian as Faulkner is authentically American."

D88     Woodcock, George. "Raddall: The Making of the Story-Teller." Saturday Night, Nov. 1976, pp. 67, 69-70. Raddall's entire achievement is to some extent assessed in addition to the qualities of In My Time: A Memoir. The book itself is described as "one of that fine story-teller's least successful tales." After the sections dealing with Raddall's early life, it "falls into a broken-backed limp" as Raddall attempts to deal with his years as a professional writer. In more general statements, Woodcock suggests that Raddall has "gained his experiences and insights by adapting to his conditions, by accepting the standards of his neighbouts rather than by reacting against them." Although Raddall is acknowledged to be "a great amateur scholar, ... in the broader sense, he does not fit into the Canadian intelligentsia ...." He is more at home among Nova Scotian fishermen than among members of the Royal Society of Canada. Woodcock further expresses the idea that Raddall does not belong to the mainstream of Canadian letters by pointing out that his novels "have always read as if they were written before rather than after the Great War, their particular style and the very excellence of their story-telling placing them far nearer to writers like Conrad and Robert Louis Stevenson than to Canadian writers of the present generation."

D89     Blodgett, E.D. Rev. of In My Time: A Memoir. Canadian Fiction Magazine, No.27 (1977), pp. 151-52. Blodgett notes the echo of Ernest Hemingway in Raddall's title, but suggests that this is a characteristic "shy modesty," for Raddall relates himself "to a literary world and then gives the world a provincial and personal turn." Yet, paradoxically, "Raddall seems to speak for the endurance of his generation in a way that Hemingway's somewhat Cato-like nostalgia could never do." Raddall's story is moving, and the book offers an image of Raddall the recluse, using fictional criteria very different from those of the prevailing "modern" literary climate. But the question arises as to whether Raddall was "conservative and anti-modern from conviction or merely caution." In My Time: A Memoir "reflects a kind of durability" and offers an "eloquent testimony and record.., of the solitary struggle of a nation, a province, a man."

D90     Brandeis, Robert C. Rev. of In My Time: A Memoir. Canadian Book Review Annual: 1976. Ed. Dean Tudor, Nancy Tudor, and Linda Biesenthal. Toronto: Peter Martin, 1977, pp. 60-61. Raddall's autobiography combines his talents for story-telling and for close attention to detail. His candid story "is enlivened by a remarkably modern, humane attitude towards his fellows." Particularly fascinating is the account of Raddall's relationship with his publishers and "the slightest understated suggestion of the difficulties of contract and editorial negotiations?"

D91     Godard, Barbara. Rev. of In My Time: A Memoir. Quill & Quire, Jan. 1977, p. 29. Raddall's autobiography probes the social influences upon his work rather than his own psyche. The most interesting parts of the book deal with the record of Raddall's career as a writer. We see revealed the integrity of a writer who chose to stay at home and write about his own country in spite of general Canadian indifference exemplified in the poor payments offered by Canadian publishers and the lack of help from the Canadian government which did nothing at the time to help writers by arranging international tax agreements. However, Raddall's reliance on notebooks and diaries has given his narrative a somewhat "disconnected quality."

D92      Fulford, Robert. Rev. of In My Time: A Memoir. Canadian Reader, Feb. 1977, pp. 2-4. In My Time: A Memoir is an "eccentric but loveable book." Fulford is struck by the fact that Raddall, unlike many other Canadian writers, seems willing to talk "shop" and to discuss "the personalities, the encounters, with people he liked or (rather more often) disliked" As a result, Raddall's book provides a number of enjoyable insights into Canadian literary and publishing history that are otherwise neglected.

D93     Rush, Paul. "A Nova Scotian He Remains." The Financial Post [Toronto], 5 March 1977, p. 34. Rush remarks on Raddall's confidence in turning to autobiography. Raddall "has paid his dues as a Canadian author." In My Time: A Memoir is "an intriguing and opinionated book, well worth reading." Its most interesting sections are those in which Raddall gives his views on writers and writing.

D94     Ross, Malcolm. Rev. of In My Time: A Memoir. Dalhousie Review, 57 (Spring 1977), 187-88. In My Time: A Memoir is both "an illuminating record of a man's life and work" and a portrait of a "time," particularly of the period between the start of World War I and the end of World War II. Ross discusses the insights provided by In My Time: A Memoir regarding the ways in which Raddall's experiences led to some of the material for the novels. He notes how the relentless and exacting historical research behind the books never shows, with the result that "They seem to issue from a loving sense of place taken and touched by time." Raddall has never "sought to teach or preach," but in novels like Roger Sudden and His Majesty's Yankees he "has given us an imaginative hold on our beginnings as a people, an insight into the first fashioning of an identity, an insight which may do much to sustain us now that our identity' is being put severely to the test."

D95     Nowlan, Alden. "An Historical Novelist the Reader Can Trust." The Atlantic Advocate, April 1977, p. 63. Nowlan summarizes some of the information that Raddall provides concerning his work habits, and he praises Raddall as "an astute observer, a convincing reporter, and a highly entertaining story-teller" He compares Raddall as an historical novelist with Robert Graves. Raddall, he claims, "understands and respects our ancestors, he knows how they differed from us and in what ways we resemble them."

D96     Waterston, Elisabeth. "Letters in Canada: 1976. Humanities" University of Toronto Quarterly, 46 (Summer 1977), 476-77. In My Time: A Memoir only intermittently offers the reader any illumination of Raddall's fiction. However, the work is "a crisp and competent contribution to cultural history." The memoir also makes us admire "the endurance and energy of a Canadian writer determined to stay in Canada and to write about Maritime life, past and present." Waterston concludes by quoting in praise of Raddall a comment by E.M. Forster on Edward Gibbon as autobiographer: "Don't look for gaiety here or for spontaneity, but you will find wit, shrewdness and the pardonable weightiness of a man who knows that he has genius and has used it properly."

Previous Entry in publication.

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; Pride's Fancy  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

Pride's Fancy

D21       Schwartz, Robert N. "Wooden Ships and Iron Men." The New York Times Book Review, 3 Nov. 1946, p. 16. Schwartz comments on the popularity of nostalgic tales of the past "when ships were made of wood and their men of iron." Raddall's novel is considerably better than average. Raddall is "a skilled, efficient practitioner of the art of storytelling; he goes about his business with no irritating pretensions and with very little waste motion." Much of the review is taken up with plot-summary which is preceded by the remark that the novel has all the situations that afficionados have come to regard as standard in this type of work.

D22     Deacon, William A. "Seafaring Novelist Says Short Story Higher Art." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 19 Nov. 1946, p. 5. Deacon has very little to say about the novel, but mentions the fact that the publication of the book was marked by a tour for Raddall arranged by his publishers. As a measure of Raddall's great popularity as a writer, Deacon points out that Raddall was accorded "the largest and most representative press conference ever to greet a writer in Toronto."

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Record: 124
Title:
Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; Roger Sudden
Other Title:

Titles critiqued:  ROGER sudden (Book)

Book Source:

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP2000007004004002&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; Roger Sudden</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; Roger Sudden  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

Roger Sudden

D14     M[artin]., B[urns]. Rev. of Roger Sudden. The Dalhousie Review, 24 (Jan. 1945), 489. This is a more successful novel than His Majesty's Yankees, since it displays a "more skillful grasp of character, and a more cunning blending of diverse material." Martin praises Raddalrs ability to provide a "convincing picture of a period in the mass," the vigorous vulgar, pulsating life of the eighteenth century. In this last respect, Raddall has much in common with Smollett.

D15     Purtell, Thelma. Rev. of Roger Sudden. The New York Times Book Review, 18 March 1945, p. 25. Purtell comments on Roger Sudden's odd last name, but notes that it is very suitable in a novel in which "the gyrations through whole oceans of hot water which comprise his [Sudden's] saga are the result of acting first and thinking afterward." Roger Sudden is "a cadet of the swashbuckling (or faint-heart-never-got-anyone-anywhere) branch of the historical novel," but "... the most dilatory reader will pick up an excellent idea of the precise mechanics of founding one type of New World colony."

D16     MacGillivray, J.R. "Letters in Canada: 1944. Fiction." University of Toronto Quarterly, 14 (April 1945), 272. In comparison with His Majesty's Yankees, MacGillivray claims, the novel is rather "trite and common in its conversation and description," though it is often vivid and rarely dull. He considers that Raddall, given the record of his two novels, is one of Canada's very best exponents of historical romance.

D17     Fields, Harold. "Flash in a Halifax Pan." The Saturday Review of Literature [New York], 14 April 1945, p. 58. Just as George Henty and James Fennimore Cooper provide American literature with a surfeit of tales from the Colonial period which "reach into the present," Kenneth Roberts, Hervey Allen, and Thomas Raddall are continuing in that tradition "with tales that are rich in historical research and filled with suspense in breath-taking situations" Raddall takes an unusual risk in creating as a hero so "calculating and selfish a person as Roger Sudden." He gives more historical detail than the casual reader of romance will probably like. On the other hand, for those who want pure history, this makes no attempt at being a source book.

D18     Rev. of Roger Sudden. The Booklist [Chicago], 15 April 1945, p. 238. The reviewer considers the novel "Adequate for the historical portrayal," but lacking in "satisfactory characterization and the spark of good adventure"

D19     Sorfleet, John Robert. "The NCL Series: An Appraisal Past and Present" Journal of Canadian Fiction, 1, No. 2 (Spring 1972), 94-95. In discussing the New Canadian Library Series reprint of the novel, Sorfleet points out the original date of publication (1945) and its bearing upon the overstated pro-English patriotism in the novel which so colours its melodramatic ending. He also mentions Raddall's thesis that the early French settlers in Nova Scotia possessed a garrison mentality, exemplified in the building of Fort Louisbourg, whereas none of the English settlements had walls, a dichotomy that favoured (so Raddall believes) the English. This idea offers a challenge to those literary theorists who have seen in English-Canadian literature an expression of so-called "garrison mentality."

D20       Bickerstaff, Isaac. "New Canadian Library." Pt. t. Books in Canada, 2, No. 2 (April-May-June 1973), 34. Bickerstaff briefly stresses the adventure element in the novel.

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; Son of the Hawk

Titles critiqued:  SON of the hawk (Book)

ABCMA07TRP2000007004004005

https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP2000007004004005&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP2000007004004005&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; Son of the Hawk</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; Son of the Hawk  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

Son of the Hawk

D34     Baker, Nina Brown. "Blue Nose Rebel." The New York Times Book Review, 16 April 1950, p. 26. Baker, who seems unaware that Son of the Hawk is a version of His Majesty's Yankees, says that the novel as a story of revolution has a very original approach since it deals with Nova Scotia, one of the colonies that did not join the Thirteen in the War for Independence. She remarks upon the novel's unbiased portrayal of both Tory and Revolutionary sides and stresses the excitement Raddall generates during his turbulant fast-moving adventure tale for younger readers.

D35     McEvoy, Ruth M. "Raddall, Thomas H. Son of the Hawk." Library Journal [New York], 1 June 1950, p. 990. McEvoy briefly summarizes the plot and remarks that "There is the quiet of the forest and the noise of attack in the book, the defiance and despair of a young country conquered. There is, too, a bit of romance."

D36     Rev. of Son of the Hawk. The Booklist [Chicago], 1 July 1950, p. 337. The reviewer notes that the book contains "Plenty of action and good historical background." The novel is an abridgement by Raddall of His Majesty's Yankees, a detail "inadvertently omitted from the title page."

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Copyright of this work is the property of Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press  and its content may not be copied without the copyright holder's expressed written permission except for the print or download capabilities of the retrieval software used for access. This content is intended solely for the use of the individual user.
Source: Young, Alan R. (compiler); . Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall, Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987. pp. 426-473 ; Lecker, Robert (editor). David, Jack (editor). Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors ; no. 7 ISBN: 0920763111 (hardcover); 092076312X (paperback), Book ID: ABCMA07TRP2.
Item Number: ABCMA07TRP2000007004004005
Record: 126
Title:
Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; Tambour and Other Stories
Other Title:
Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews
Record Type:
Reference Series
Series Title:

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; Tambour and Other Stories  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

Tambour and Other Stories

D63     M[artin]., B[urns]. Rev. of Tambour and Other Stories. The Dalhousie Review, 25 (Jan. 1946), 506. The book offers a vivid and varied portrait of Nova Scotia today and yesterday. Martin praises Raddall's narrative abilities, claiming that each story "tells itself in its own way and at its own pace." This results in "a delightful naturalness, a feeling that life has been unrolling itself' before the eyes of the reader.

D64     MacGillivray, J.R. "Letters in Canada: 1945. Fiction." University of Toronto Quarterly, 15 (April 1946), 288. MacGillivray comments on the wide range of subject-matter in the book. Although he feels that the tales are "without any subtlety and style or technique," he praises them for being "unusual but within the range of probability made vivid by the adequate use of description and dialect speech." The stories are "told with verve and the assured manner of a person who might have been there and seen it all."

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; The Dreamers

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; The Dreamers  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

The Dreamers

D72     Seaman, Andrew. "Thomas H. Raddall, a Decade Later." Rev. of The Dreamers, by Thomas Raddall; and A Name for Himself: A Biography of Thomas Head Raddall, by Joyce Barkhouse. Atlantic Provinces Book Review, 14, No. 1 (Feb.-March 1987), 19. Seaman praises the stories in The Dreamers and notes that they are as much about what their characters do as about their personalities. Though some of the earlier stories "strike a false note here and there," others are masterpieces, "vivid with colour and imbued with a comic sense of the vicissitudes of human nature."

Title:
Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; The Governor's Lady
Other Title:

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP2000007004004009&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; The Governor's Lady</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; The Governor's Lady  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

The Governor's Lady

D48      Harlow, Robert. "Varieties of Waste." Canadian Literature, No. 6 (Autumn 1960), pp. 74-76. Harlow writes an extremely negative review in which he asserts that Raddall's characters have "no real life of their own" because they spend their time "bowing to events." The novel "is not literature," and it "lacks sensibility, sensitivity' and "a feeling for language."

D49     Parr, D. Kermode. Rev. of The Governor's Lady. The Atlantic Advocate, Oct. 1960, pp. 79, 81. This is "a very fine novel" and "a major success." Raddall's story brings alive his blending of solid historical facts and convincing imagined actions and talk. The many lesser characters are also praised as "believable," and the background against which they move is described as "always vivid and convincing." The novel offers "a brilliant portrait of a wicked woman and an extremely interesting study of a man who did indeed blend in his eighteenth-century manner eager self-seeking with genuine patriotic vision."

D50     Match, Richard. "The Price of Loyalty to a King." The New York Times Book Review, 9 Oct. 1960, p. 54. Raddall's "book is sound, responsible and readable." Match notes that those living in the United States tend not to know much about "the plight of the Loyalists during our American Revolution." A good account of those who left for Canada "is always welcome." Raddall "was a long-time friend of the late [American historical fiction author] Kenneth Roberts, whose professional integrity he shares. However, he lacks the Roberts propensity for splashing splendid battle pieces across a wide canvass."

D51     W., R.T.C. "Unfaithful Loyalist." Saturday Night, Dec. 1960, p. 34. Raddall has taken a minor figure from history and "fashioned a novel out of his personal life, the details of which are presumably pretty obscure." Unfortunately, Raddall's characters turn out to be "fundamentally uninteresting." The Governor's Lady is too "slow moving" as a result, but the socio-historical background is good.

D52     Watt, F.W. "Letters in Canada: 1960. Fiction." University of Toronto Quarterly, 30 (July 1961), 411-12. Watt complains that historical events alone are not enough. "The novelist has to provide plot and theme, a beginning, middle, and end, and a meaning." His chief reservation concerns the characters, who are weakly drawn. His Majesty's Yankees showed the very best that historical fiction could achieve. However, in The Governor's Lady "... we must settle for what might have been."

D53     Stuewe, Paul. "On the Racks: Half a Shelf, Half a Shelf, Half a Shelf: Onward Lumbers Our Paperback Hero." Books in Canada, Oct. 1979, p. 29. The Governor's Lady (together with Hangman's Beach [D58]) keeps "the historical pot boiling with competent re-creations of 18thcentury North American milieus." The novel emphasizes "descriptive scene-painting at the expense of plot and character development."

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; The Markland Sagas  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

The Markland Sagas

D73     Nickerson, M. H. "An Appreciation" The Halifax Herald, n.d. [Dalhousie Univ. Archives MSS 2. 202. B. Vol. I (Scrapbook).] The Markland Sagas is an important contribution to Lief Erikson literature.

West Novas: A History of the West Nova Scotia Regiment

D74     MacLean, Hugh N. "Letters in Canada: 1949. Canadians in the Second World War." University of Toronto Quarterly, 19 (April 1950), 313. MacLean complains that the book lacks good maps, but he considers that it is written with "greater clarity and command of the language than any other regimental history yet received." The book is "designed to appeal primarily to veterans of the units concerned." As such, it is "quite satisfactory."

Title:
Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; The Nymph and the Lamp
Other Title:
Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews

Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors, no. 7
Author(s):
Young, Alan R. (compiler)
Genre(s):
Bibliography
Subject(s):
Authors discussed:  RADDALL, Thomas; RADDALL, Thomas -- Criticism & interpretation -- Bibliography
Titles critiqued:  NYMPH and the lamp (Book)
Topics:  CANADIAN literature -- Bibliography; FRENCH-CANADIAN literature -- Bibliography
Book Source:
Young, Alan R. (compiler) Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall.

ABCMA07TRP2000007004004004
Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP2000007004004004&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP2000007004004004&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; The Nymph and the Lamp</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; The Nymph and the Lamp  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

The Nymph and the Lamp

D23     B[owes]., C[arleton]. F. "Off the Press." Rev. of Operation Cicero, by L.C. Moyzisch; The Nymph and the Lamp, by Thomas Raddall; The Wit and Wisdom of Franklin D. Roosevelt, ed. Maxwell Meyersohn; Stormswept, by Stanley C. Tiller; and Traditional Songs from Nova Scotia, ed. Helen Creighton and Doreen H. Senior. Public Affairs [Dalhousie Univ.], 13, No.1 (Autumn 1950), 88, 90. Bowes notes that the twentieth-century setting of The Nymph and the Lamp is a departure for Raddall from his previous use of historical settings and that the background of the novel is autobiographical. Bowes praises Raddall's descriptions of Sable Island and the Annapolis Valley and the sections of the novel describing the operation of the island radio station. Surprisingly, sex "bulks very largely" in this book, perhaps at the request of Raddall's American publishers.

D24     Rev. of The Nymph and the Lamp. The Booklist [Chicago], 15 Oct. 1950, p. 69. In this brief notice, the reviewer praises the novel for being "Well written" and having "good characterization and atmosphere"

D25     Deacon, William Arthur. "Sable Island the Scene of Canadian Live Story." The Globe and Mail [Toronto], 28 Oct. 1950, p. 12. This novel marks a turning point in Raddall's career, ending triumphantly his first decade in book-length fiction. As Raddall's first attempt at a novel with a contemporary setting, The Nymph and the Lamp is "powerful beyond any other Canadian novel that is, primarily, a love story." Raddall's success is due to his ability to understand women, his great skill in presenting nature, and the "symphonic relationship" he creates between all parts of the tale. Raddall has been for a decade among the more important Canadian authors. His new novel is "unlike anything he had done before," but is "entirely successful." It is "so powerful, that we receive it with profound respect .... A hard-working artist of great talent seems to have reached a rich maturity of his powers. Few Canadians have written as good a novel and none a better."

D26     Henderson, Robert W. "Raddall, The Nymph and the Lamp." Library Journal [New York], 1 Nov. 1950, p. 1903. Henderson briefly summarizes the plot and praises the novel's "dramatic, poignant, unexpected denouement."

D27     McFee, William. "Nova Scotia Viking." The Saturday Review of Literature [New York], 11 Nov. 1950, p. 15. McFee claims he has never before heard of Raddall, but that this work is "a thundering fine novel." He praises Raddall's "superlative story telling," the depth of character in the presentation of Isabel, and Raddall's mastery of background. The Nymph and the Lamp is "a solidly constructed novel, a tale with thews and sinews, a story that moves and sometimes races at high speed, and is packed with rich color, vivid minor characters, and dry humor."

D28     "Briefly Noted: Fiction." The New Yorker, 18 Nov. 1950, p. 167. In a brief review, the novel is described as "A mild romantic tale about a gigantic bronzed hermit, very shy; a charming, unawakened girl of thirty-four, quite sensitive; and a lonely, almost inaccessible island in the North Atlantic." Raddall has written "with patience and affection."

D29     P[arsons]., J.E. "Canadian Best.?". Saturday Night, 28 Nov. 1950, p. 24. The Nymph and the Lamp, Raddall's first contemporary novel, "is a book so superbly written that the honest reviewer is at a loss how to tone down his superlatives." Many readers will find it to be "the best Canadian novel to be had." Parson praises Raddall's talents for story telling, description, and character portrayal.

D30     Cournos, John. "Power of Kindness" The New York Times Book Review, 10 Dec. 1950, p. 24. The Nymph and the Lamp is a "novel of truth and feeling." What particularly impresses Cournos is that Raddall has been able to "make self-sacrifice lovely and authentic." Many other novels attempting such a theme are marred by false sentimentality, but the self-sacrifice of Isabel "to a man whom she does not wholly love but who is infinitely kind to her bears the stamp of reality that is altogether convincing."

D31     Bissell, Claude T. "Letters in Canada: 1950. Fiction." University of Toronto Quarterly, 20 (April 1951), 262-64. Bissell has high praise for Raddall's achievement. He comments on the author's admirable qualities as an historical novelist and in particular "the easy and confident way with which he [Raddall] assimilated background and mood." This aspect is now even more apparent as Raddall draws upon his own personal experience. Bissell also praises Raddall's handling of sex relationships, "something rare in the Canadian novel," but he argues that Raddall falls short when it comes to creating character and "a series of situations that will display the moving logic of human motives and emotions." He also perceives a further weakness in the novel in that Raddall "intends his plot to bear a weight of meaning that it cannot quite sustain." Nonetheless Raddall's achievement "remains a notable one."

D32     Bonenfant, Jean-Charles. "Quatre romans recent." Rev. of The Loved and the Lost, by Morley Callaghan; Each Man's Son, by Hugh MacLennan; The Nymph and the Lamp, by Thomas Raddall; and Home Is the Stranger, by Edward McCourt. La Revue de l'Universite Laval, 6 (sept. 1951), 54-56. Bonenfant comments on Raddall's shift away from historical fiction to an almost contemporary setting. He praises Raddall's portrayal of Sable Island as "un veritable documentaire sur un des endroits les plus pittoresques du Canada." He notes Raddall's command of language and mentions that some have compared him to Joseph Conrad. The Nymph and the Lamp, he concludes, may not be the masterpiece that the young English-Canadian literature is always dreaming about, but it is a fine novel which merits international success and translation into French.

D33     Bickerstaff, Isaac. "New Canadian Library." Pt. I. Books in Canada, 2, No. 2 (April-May-June 1973), 34. Bickerstaff praises the skill with which Raddall has evoked the barren island setting of the novel on the one hand and the "fecund Annapolis Valley" on the other.

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP2000007004004019&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; The Path of Destiny: Canada from the British Conquest to Home Rule 1763-1850</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; The Path of Destiny: Canada from the British Conquest to Home Rule 1763-1850  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

The Path of Destiny: Canada from the British Conquest to Home Rule 1763-1850

D80     Wade, Mason. "Canada Before Nationhood:' The New York Times Book Review, 22 Sept. 1957, p. 32. The central theme of Raddall's history is the effort by the British North Americans "to resist the expansion of the United States over the whole northern part of the continent." Raddall writes military and naval history with all the "verve of the novelist." Wade praises the attention given by Raddall to the Maritimes, the North, and the West Coast, but suggests that "... the political, economic, and cultural aspects of the period are somewhat neglected .... " In particular, he feels that "the historical picture is seriously distorted when the Quebec Act, the Constitutional Act, the Durham Report, and the Union Act are dismissed in a few paragraphs, while whole chapters are devoted to inconclusive skirmishes which had far less lasting effects on Canadian history."

D81     R., F.A. "Breezy History." Rev. of The Path of Destiny: Canada from the British Conquest to Home Rule 1763-1850. Saturday Night, 9 Nov. 1957, pp. 42-43. The reviewer, commenting on Raddall's "breezy, journalistic style," praises Raddall for writing history that "is never dull." In particular, he mentions the value of the book due to its quotations from contemporary sources and its interesting comments on the War of 1812 and the arts in Canada.

D82     Craig, G.M. Rev. of The Path of Destiny: Canada from the British Conquest to Home Rule 1763-1850. The Canadian Historical Review, 39 (June 1958), 154-55. Raddall's book "must be judged as a piece of popular narrative history, not as a work of original research or synthesis:' Craig complains about what he sees as Raddall's over-emphasis on wars and his insufficient attention to nonmilitary aspects. Among these latter he includes such things as French-Canadian society before 1791 and the Convention of 1818. He praises Raddall's short accounts of the overland and seafaring expeditions to and along the Pacific and says that the outstanding feature of the book is the extended narrative of the battles of the War of 1812.

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Title:
Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; The Pied Piper of Dipper Creek and Other Tales

<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP2000007004004011&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; The Pied Piper of Dipper Creek and Other Tales</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; The Pied Piper of Dipper Creek and Other Tales  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

The Pied Piper of Dipper Creek and Other Tales

D59     MacGillivray, J.R. "Letters in Canada: 1943. Fiction." University of Toronto Quarterly, 13 (April 1944), 318-19. MacGillivray comments on Raddall's abilities to work within the established conventions of the well-told tale. He remarks that Raddall shows promise of becoming both a humorist and a recorder of regional life, both being much-needed attributes in Canadian letters.

D60     "Short Stories of Nova Scotia." The Globe and Mail [Toronto],18 Dec. 1943, p. 11. Although this reviewer suggests that the quality of the stories is uneven, he emphasizes that this is a work of distinction and originality of approach. In particular he notes Raddall's use of Micmac Indians and claims that this adds a brand new note to Canadian fiction.

D61     Middleton, J.E. "Tales of Nova Scotia" Saturday Night, 29 Jan. 1944, p. 20. Middleton contends that even more attractive than the beauty of Nova Scotia's scenery is the "variety and vigor of her people." Raddall has drawn fascinating pictures of many of those people in vivid prose. Raddall throughout is the "admiring chronicler with a laugh in his eyes and with humor in his pen."

D62     MacLennan, D. Rev. of The Pied Piper of Dipper Creek and Other Tales. Culture, 5 (mars 1944), 96-97. MacLennan argues that because of World War II "Canadians have suddenly come to an inquisitive age" and are now more interested in their homeland. A new folklore is emerging, "saturated with the present day expression of peoples who came to Canada, made it their own, yet ever remained loyal to the memory of their old homes." The Pied Piper of Dipper Creek is a work "vibrating with the reactions" of Nova Scotians' love for the new world. The stories are "true yarns by a skilled storyteller who manages to capture all the beauty and ruggedness of the locality by means of significant details that prick us like a knife." Raddall has the ability to "give reality and atmosphere to a story through incident and detail."

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; The Rover: The Story of a Canadian Privateer  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

The Rover: The Story of a Canadian Privateer

D47     Parr, D. Kermode. Rev. of The Rover: The Story of a Canadian Privateer. The Atlantic Advocate, June 1958, p. 83. This book is "stirring good stuff" for boys.

<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP2000007004004013&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; The Wedding Gift and Other Stories</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; The Wedding Gift and Other Stories  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

The Wedding Gift and Other Stories

D65     M., C. "Raddall's Earliest Stories." The Halifax Herald, 19 Dec. 1947, p. 4. The reviewer claims that although Raddall is well known for his novels, he is perhaps not so familiar as a short-story writer. However, it is as a short-story writer that he aroused the admiration of such competent critics as John Buchan, Rudyard Kipling, Kenneth Roberts, and Colonel Theodore Roosevelt. In the stories, "The historical background.., is perfect in every detail, but still manages to remain secondary to his story." As for the characters, "these are living, breathing people that you can love or hate, laugh at or sympathize with."

D66     Bissell, Claude T. "Letters in Canada: 1947. Fiction." University of Toronto Quarterly, 17 (April 1948), 276. Bissell stresses the delightful qualities of these stories in a very brief notice. In particular he emphasizes that no other Canadian writer "can assimilate historical material more easily and gracefully" than Raddall.

Previous Entry in publication.

Record: 135
Title:
Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; The Wings of Night
Other Title:
Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews

Titles critiqued:  WINGS of night (Book)

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP2000007004004007&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; The Wings of Night</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; The Wings of Night  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

The Wings of Night

D42     Nordyke, Lewis. "Neil Jamieson in Quest of His Youth." The New York Times Book Review, 23 Sept. 1956, p. 30. Few authors have "a better feel for the sights and sounds of their milieu." Raddall seems especially at home with small-town Canadian life and even more at home in the woods "where he is impeccably surefooted in his descriptions of building a log cabin, stalking a deer, or paddling a canoe." Such passages are "reminiscent of Hemingway." The trial scene that provides the climax to the novel is warmly praised for its "restraint," which results in "a sustained and suspenseful climax." The novel should add to "Mr. Raddall's growing reputation as one of the most competent and engaging of Canadian story-tellers?"

D43     Levin, Martin. "Forester Come Home." Rev. of The Wings of Night. Saturday Review [New York], 24 Nov. 1956, pp. 34-35. The novel is "first-rate ... as solidly authentic as the Nova Scotian forests that form its backdrop." Levin has special praise for the manner in which the novel "unites place and character in a counterpoint so skilful that the reader is barely conscious of the specialized background as his attention becomes increasingly riveted on what happens there."

D44     King, Carlyle. "Fiction Chronicle:' The Tamarack Review, No. 2 (Winter 1957), p. 75. Raddall is an experienced author "who can do much better" and "in fact has done so." The Wings of Night "is obviously a potboiler for the Doubleday mass readership:' The love plot is both "slick and perfunctory."

D45     Rev. of The Wings of Night. The Booklist [Chicago], 15 Dec. 1956, p. 200. The novel is "fresh, direct" and "skillfully written."

D46     Bissell, Claude T. "Letters in Canada: 1956. Fiction." University of Toronto Quarterly, 26 (April 1957), 314-15. Raddall is "searching for something more compelling than a conventional romantic complication." However, the concluding episodes "are more striking as melodrama than as symbol." Bissell concludes that the most effective aspect of the novel is Raddall's treatment of his protagonist's return to "the village of his youth and the melancholy pastoral" to which this plotpattern gives rise.

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.

Record: 136
Title:
Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; Tidefall
Other Title:
Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews

Reference Series
Series Title:
Annotated bibliography of Canada's major authors, no. 7
Author(s):
Young, Alan R. (compiler)
Genre(s):
Bibliography
Subject(s):
Authors discussed:  RADDALL, Thomas; RADDALL, Thomas -- Criticism & interpretation -- Bibliography
Titles critiqued:  TIDEFALL (Book)
Topics:  CANADIAN literature -- Bibliography; FRENCH-CANADIAN literature -- Bibliography
Book Source:
Young, Alan R. (compiler) Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall.
Publisher Information: Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987. (pp. 426-473)
ISBN: 0920763111 (hardcover); 092076312X (paperback)
