ABCMA07TRP2000007004004006
Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP2000007004004006&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://lib-ezproxy.concordia.ca/login?url=https://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=cjh&AN=ABCMA07TRP2000007004004006&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; Tidefall</A>
Database:
Canadian Literary Centre

Source: Part 2: Works On Thomas H. Raddall. Young, Alan R. (compiler); Toronto, Ontario : ECW Press, 1987, pp. 426-473

Part 2 Works on Thomas H. Raddall; Selected book reviews; Tidefall  

Young, Alan R. (compiler)

Tidefall

D37       Keate, Stuarte. "Refreshing Sea-Change." The New York Times Book Review, 22 Nov. 1953, p.44. Raddall is "one of Canada's best-known authors." In Tidefall, Raddall tells his engaging adventure-story with "fine feeling" for his subject-matter. Unlike C.S. Forester, Raddall is not concerned with "manners, logistics, or maritime strategy,' Raddall is then compared with Rudyard Kipling, Joseph Conrad, and Robert Louis Stevenson in his ability to combine "a romantic story line with realistic detail." Raddall's virtues are "hardy if somewhat unfashionable,' Tidefall is "a refreshing sea-change from the current sargasso of psychology-and-sex studies"

D38     Pacey, Desmond. Rev. of Tidefall. The Canadian Forum, Jan. 1954, p. 237. Tidefall is a novel in the John Buchan tradition, a good yarn, "lively in action, piquant in characterization, and leanly athletic in style," the product of a professional craftsman. There is also praise for Raddall's descriptive powers, but Pacey considers that Raddall's handling of the personal relations of his characters is not so successful, and he finds the love triangle in particular unconvincing. Tidefall is not a great novel, but it is skillful, entertaining, and will demonstrate to the world that "the Canadian novel is now capable of avoiding the Scylla of mawkish sentimentality and the Charybdis of pretentious glamor."

D39     B[ennet]., C.L. Rev. of Tidefall. The Dalhousie Review, 34 (Spring 1954), 399. The novel follows in the footsteps of The Nymph and the Lamp in its use of a contemporary rather than historical setting. Bennet praises Raddall as a master of prose, "vivid and accurate in description, swift and economical in narrative." He touches on Raddall's ability to conjure up a sense of the felt reality of the scenes he depicts, and he notes the interesting detail concerning the way Raddall admits us, "Kiplingwise, to some of the secrets of his craft" by having two of the characters discuss the art of fiction. Tidefall "will unquestionably increase Mr. Raddall's large and discerning body of readers."

D40     Bissell, Claude T. "Letters in Canada: 1953. Fiction." University of Toronto Quarterly, 23 (April 1954), 270. Bissell points out that Tidefall is similar to The Nymph and the Lamp in that both novels have a "central heavily emphasized character who lives in a world of his own peculiar making, largely cut off from normal society, and who is placed against a remote and exotic physical setting." Though Bissell praises Raddall's descriptions of the exploits of the protagonist, Saxby, on the high seas, he considers that one must question "whether Raddall is as close to making the transition from historical romancer to novelist of contemporary manners as The Nymph and the Lamp seemed to indicate." The novel is a disappointment and a failure. In particular, the central character (Saxby) is oversimplified and the two other main characters (Rena and her lover) never come alive.

D41     Bonenfant, Jean-Charles. "Livres canadiens d'expression anglaise: un roman de la met." Rev. of Tidefall, by Thomas Raddall; and No Other Gods, by Wilder Penfield. La revue de l'Universite Laval, 8 (mai 1954), 858-59. Bonenfant largely confines himself to a plot-summary of Tidefall, but does comment on Raddall's facility in mixing episodes from the past and present of the life of the central character, Saxby Nowlan. Raddall is a fine sea-story novelist, perhaps one of the best currently writing in any language, something which has led some critics in Canada and the United States to compare him with Joseph Conrad.

Previous Entry in publication.

Next Entry in publication.
